 13044	ULYSSES
 13045	
 13046	by James Joyce
 13047	
 13048	
 13049	
 13050	
 13051	-- I --
 13052	
 13053	Stately, plump Buck Mulligan came from the stairhead, bearing a bowl of
 13054	lather on which a mirror and a razor lay crossed. A yellow dressinggown,
 13055	ungirdled, was sustained gently behind him on the mild morning air. He
 13056	held the bowl aloft and intoned:
 13057	
 13058	--_Introibo ad altare Dei_.
 13059	
 13060	Halted, he peered down the dark winding stairs and called out coarsely:
 13061	
 13062	--Come up, Kinch! Come up, you fearful jesuit!
 13063	
 13064	Solemnly he came forward and mounted the round gunrest. He faced about
 13065	and blessed gravely thrice the tower, the surrounding land and the
 13066	awaking mountains. Then, catching sight of Stephen Dedalus, he bent
 13067	towards him and made rapid crosses in the air, gurgling in his throat
 13068	and shaking his head. Stephen Dedalus, displeased and sleepy, leaned
 13069	his arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking
 13070	gurgling face that blessed him, equine in its length, and at the light
 13071	untonsured hair, grained and hued like pale oak.
 13072	
 13073	Buck Mulligan peeped an instant under the mirror and then covered the
 13074	bowl smartly.
 13075	
 13076	--Back to barracks! he said sternly.
 13077	
 13078	He added in a preacher's tone:
 13079	
 13080	--For this, O dearly beloved, is the genuine Christine: body and soul
 13081	and blood and ouns. Slow music, please. Shut your eyes, gents. One
 13082	moment. A little trouble about those white corpuscles. Silence, all.
 13083	
 13084	He peered sideways up and gave a long slow whistle of call, then paused
 13085	awhile in rapt attention, his even white teeth glistening here and there
 13086	with gold points. Chrysostomos. Two strong shrill whistles answered
 13087	through the calm.
 13088	
 13089	--Thanks, old chap, he cried briskly. That will do nicely. Switch off
 13090	the current, will you?
 13091	
 13092	He skipped off the gunrest and looked gravely at his watcher, gathering
 13093	about his legs the loose folds of his gown. The plump shadowed face and
 13094	sullen oval jowl recalled a prelate, patron of arts in the middle ages.
 13095	A pleasant smile broke quietly over his lips.
 13096	
 13097	--The mockery of it! he said gaily. Your absurd name, an ancient Greek!
 13098	
 13099	He pointed his finger in friendly jest and went over to the parapet,
 13100	laughing to himself. Stephen Dedalus stepped up, followed him wearily
 13101	halfway and sat down on the edge of the gunrest, watching him still as
 13102	he propped his mirror on the parapet, dipped the brush in the bowl and
 13103	lathered cheeks and neck.
 13104	
 13105	Buck Mulligan's gay voice went on.
 13106	
 13107	--My name is absurd too: Malachi Mulligan, two dactyls. But it has a
 13108	Hellenic ring, hasn't it? Tripping and sunny like the buck himself.
 13109	We must go to Athens. Will you come if I can get the aunt to fork out
 13110	twenty quid?
 13111	
 13112	He laid the brush aside and, laughing with delight, cried:
 13113	
 13114	--Will he come? The jejune jesuit!
 13115	
 13116	Ceasing, he began to shave with care.
 13117	
 13118	--Tell me, Mulligan, Stephen said quietly.
 13119	
 13120	--Yes, my love?
 13121	
 13122	--How long is Haines going to stay in this tower?
 13123	
 13124	Buck Mulligan showed a shaven cheek over his right shoulder.
 13125	
 13126	--God, isn't he dreadful? he said frankly. A ponderous Saxon. He thinks
 13127	you're not a gentleman. God, these bloody English! Bursting with money
 13128	and indigestion. Because he comes from Oxford. You know, Dedalus, you
 13129	have the real Oxford manner. He can't make you out. O, my name for you
 13130	is the best: Kinch, the knife-blade.
 13131	
 13132	He shaved warily over his chin.
 13133	
 13134	--He was raving all night about a black panther, Stephen said. Where is
 13135	his guncase?
 13136	
 13137	--A woful lunatic! Mulligan said. Were you in a funk?
 13138	
 13139	--I was, Stephen said with energy and growing fear. Out here in the dark
 13140	with a man I don't know raving and moaning to himself about shooting a
 13141	black panther. You saved men from drowning. I'm not a hero, however. If
 13142	he stays on here I am off.
 13143	
 13144	Buck Mulligan frowned at the lather on his razorblade. He hopped down
 13145	from his perch and began to search his trouser pockets hastily.
 13146	
 13147	--Scutter! he cried thickly.
 13148	
 13149	He came over to the gunrest and, thrusting a hand into Stephen's upper
 13150	pocket, said:
 13151	
 13152	--Lend us a loan of your noserag to wipe my razor.
 13153	
 13154	Stephen suffered him to pull out and hold up on show by its corner a
 13155	dirty crumpled handkerchief. Buck Mulligan wiped the razorblade neatly.
 13156	Then, gazing over the handkerchief, he said:
 13157	
 13158	--The bard's noserag! A new art colour for our Irish poets: snotgreen.
 13159	You can almost taste it, can't you?
 13160	
 13161	He mounted to the parapet again and gazed out over Dublin bay, his fair
 13162	oakpale hair stirring slightly.
 13163	
 13164	--God! he said quietly. Isn't the sea what Algy calls it: a grey
 13165	sweet mother? The snotgreen sea. The scrotumtightening sea. _Epi oinopa
 13166	ponton_. Ah, Dedalus, the Greeks! I must teach you. You must read them
 13167	in the original. _Thalatta! Thalatta_! She is our great sweet mother.
 13168	Come and look.
 13169	
 13170	Stephen stood up and went over to the parapet. Leaning on it he looked
 13171	down on the water and on the mailboat clearing the harbourmouth of
 13172	Kingstown.
 13173	
 13174	--Our mighty mother! Buck Mulligan said.
 13175	
 13176	He turned abruptly his grey searching eyes from the sea to Stephen's
 13177	face.
 13178	
 13179	--The aunt thinks you killed your mother, he said. That's why she won't
 13180	let me have anything to do with you.
 13181	
 13182	--Someone killed her, Stephen said gloomily.
 13183	
 13184	--You could have knelt down, damn it, Kinch, when your dying mother
 13185	asked you, Buck Mulligan said. I'm hyperborean as much as you. But to
 13186	think of your mother begging you with her last breath to kneel down and
 13187	pray for her. And you refused. There is something sinister in you...
 13188	
 13189	He broke off and lathered again lightly his farther cheek. A tolerant
 13190	smile curled his lips.
 13191	
 13192	--But a lovely mummer! he murmured to himself. Kinch, the loveliest
 13193	mummer of them all!
 13194	
 13195	He shaved evenly and with care, in silence, seriously.
 13196	
 13197	Stephen, an elbow rested on the jagged granite, leaned his palm against
 13198	his brow and gazed at the fraying edge of his shiny black coat-sleeve.
 13199	Pain, that was not yet the pain of love, fretted his heart. Silently, in
 13200	a dream she had come to him after her death, her wasted body within its
 13201	loose brown graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her
 13202	breath, that had bent upon him, mute, reproachful, a faint odour of
 13203	wetted ashes. Across the threadbare cuffedge he saw the sea hailed as a
 13204	great sweet mother by the wellfed voice beside him. The ring of bay
 13205	and skyline held a dull green mass of liquid. A bowl of white china had
 13206	stood beside her deathbed holding the green sluggish bile which she had
 13207	torn up from her rotting liver by fits of loud groaning vomiting.
 13208	
 13209	Buck Mulligan wiped again his razorblade.
 13210	
 13211	--Ah, poor dogsbody! he said in a kind voice. I must give you a shirt
 13212	and a few noserags. How are the secondhand breeks?
 13213	
 13214	--They fit well enough, Stephen answered.
 13215	
 13216	Buck Mulligan attacked the hollow beneath his underlip.
 13217	
 13218	--The mockery of it, he said contentedly. Secondleg they should be. God
 13219	knows what poxy bowsy left them off. I have a lovely pair with a hair
 13220	stripe, grey. You'll look spiffing in them. I'm not joking, Kinch. You
 13221	look damn well when you're dressed.
 13222	
 13223	--Thanks, Stephen said. I can't wear them if they are grey.
 13224	
 13225	--He can't wear them, Buck Mulligan told his face in the mirror.
 13226	Etiquette is etiquette. He kills his mother but he can't wear grey
 13227	trousers.
 13228	
 13229	He folded his razor neatly and with stroking palps of fingers felt the
 13230	smooth skin.
 13231	
 13232	Stephen turned his gaze from the sea and to the plump face with its
 13233	smokeblue mobile eyes.
 13234	
 13235	--That fellow I was with in the Ship last night, said Buck Mulligan,
 13236	says you have g.p.i. He's up in Dottyville with Connolly Norman. General
 13237	paralysis of the insane!
 13238	
 13239	He swept the mirror a half circle in the air to flash the tidings abroad
 13240	in sunlight now radiant on the sea. His curling shaven lips laughed and
 13241	the edges of his white glittering teeth. Laughter seized all his strong
 13242	wellknit trunk.
 13243	
 13244	--Look at yourself, he said, you dreadful bard!
 13245	
 13246	Stephen bent forward and peered at the mirror held out to him, cleft by
 13247	a crooked crack. Hair on end. As he and others see me. Who chose this
 13248	face for me? This dogsbody to rid of vermin. It asks me too.
 13249	
 13250	--I pinched it out of the skivvy's room, Buck Mulligan said. It does her
 13251	all right. The aunt always keeps plainlooking servants for Malachi. Lead
 13252	him not into temptation. And her name is Ursula.
 13253	
 13254	Laughing again, he brought the mirror away from Stephen's peering eyes.
 13255	
 13256	--The rage of Caliban at not seeing his face in a mirror, he said. If
 13257	Wilde were only alive to see you!
 13258	
 13259	Drawing back and pointing, Stephen said with bitterness:
 13260	
 13261	--It is a symbol of Irish art. The cracked looking-glass of a servant.
 13262	
 13263	Buck Mulligan suddenly linked his arm in Stephen's and walked with him
 13264	round the tower, his razor and mirror clacking in the pocket where he
 13265	had thrust them.
 13266	
 13267	--It's not fair to tease you like that, Kinch, is it? he said kindly.
 13268	God knows you have more spirit than any of them.
 13269	
 13270	Parried again. He fears the lancet of my art as I fear that of his. The
 13271	cold steelpen.
 13272	
 13273	--Cracked lookingglass of a servant! Tell that to the oxy chap
 13274	downstairs and touch him for a guinea. He's stinking with money and
 13275	thinks you're not a gentleman. His old fellow made his tin by selling
 13276	jalap to Zulus or some bloody swindle or other. God, Kinch, if you and I
 13277	could only work together we might do something for the island. Hellenise
 13278	it.
 13279	
 13280	Cranly's arm. His arm.
 13281	
 13282	--And to think of your having to beg from these swine. I'm the only one
 13283	that knows what you are. Why don't you trust me more? What have you
 13284	up your nose against me? Is it Haines? If he makes any noise here I'll
 13285	bring down Seymour and we'll give him a ragging worse than they gave
 13286	Clive Kempthorpe.
 13287	
 13288	Young shouts of moneyed voices in Clive Kempthorpe's rooms. Palefaces:
 13289	they hold their ribs with laughter, one clasping another. O, I shall
 13290	expire! Break the news to her gently, Aubrey! I shall die! With slit
 13291	ribbons of his shirt whipping the air he hops and hobbles round the
 13292	table, with trousers down at heels, chased by Ades of Magdalen with the
 13293	tailor's shears. A scared calf's face gilded with marmalade. I don't
 13294	want to be debagged! Don't you play the giddy ox with me!
 13295	
 13296	Shouts from the open window startling evening in the quadrangle. A deaf
 13297	gardener, aproned, masked with Matthew Arnold's face, pushes his mower
 13298	on the sombre lawn watching narrowly the dancing motes of grasshalms.
 13299	
 13300	To ourselves... new paganism... omphalos.
 13301	
 13302	--Let him stay, Stephen said. There's nothing wrong with him except at
 13303	night.
 13304	
 13305	--Then what is it? Buck Mulligan asked impatiently. Cough it up. I'm
 13306	quite frank with you. What have you against me now?
 13307	
 13308	They halted, looking towards the blunt cape of Bray Head that lay on the
 13309	water like the snout of a sleeping whale. Stephen freed his arm quietly.
 13310	
 13311	--Do you wish me to tell you? he asked.
 13312	
 13313	--Yes, what is it? Buck Mulligan answered. I don't remember anything.
 13314	
 13315	He looked in Stephen's face as he spoke. A light wind passed his brow,
 13316	fanning softly his fair uncombed hair and stirring silver points of
 13317	anxiety in his eyes.
 13318	
 13319	Stephen, depressed by his own voice, said:
 13320	
 13321	--Do you remember the first day I went to your house after my mother's
 13322	death?
 13323	
 13324	Buck Mulligan frowned quickly and said:
 13325	
 13326	--What? Where? I can't remember anything. I remember only ideas and
 13327	sensations. Why? What happened in the name of God?
 13328	
 13329	--You were making tea, Stephen said, and went across the landing to
 13330	get more hot water. Your mother and some visitor came out of the
 13331	drawingroom. She asked you who was in your room.
 13332	
 13333	--Yes? Buck Mulligan said. What did I say? I forget.
 13334	
 13335	--You said, Stephen answered, _O, it's only Dedalus whose mother is
 13336	beastly dead._
 13337	
 13338	A flush which made him seem younger and more engaging rose to Buck
 13339	Mulligan's cheek.
 13340	
 13341	--Did I say that? he asked. Well? What harm is that?
 13342	
 13343	He shook his constraint from him nervously.
 13344	
 13345	--And what is death, he asked, your mother's or yours or my own? You
 13346	saw only your mother die. I see them pop off every day in the Mater and
 13347	Richmond and cut up into tripes in the dissectingroom. It's a beastly
 13348	thing and nothing else. It simply doesn't matter. You wouldn't kneel
 13349	down to pray for your mother on her deathbed when she asked you. Why?
 13350	Because you have the cursed jesuit strain in you, only it's injected the
 13351	wrong way. To me it's all a mockery and beastly. Her cerebral lobes
 13352	are not functioning. She calls the doctor sir Peter Teazle and picks
 13353	buttercups off the quilt. Humour her till it's over. You crossed her
 13354	last wish in death and yet you sulk with me because I don't whinge like
 13355	some hired mute from Lalouette's. Absurd! I suppose I did say it. I
 13356	didn't mean to offend the memory of your mother.
 13357	
 13358	He had spoken himself into boldness. Stephen, shielding the gaping
 13359	wounds which the words had left in his heart, said very coldly:
 13360	
 13361	--I am not thinking of the offence to my mother.
 13362	
 13363	--Of what then? Buck Mulligan asked.
 13364	
 13365	--Of the offence to me, Stephen answered.
 13366	
 13367	Buck Mulligan swung round on his heel.
 13368	
 13369	--O, an impossible person! he exclaimed.
 13370	
 13371	He walked off quickly round the parapet. Stephen stood at his post,
 13372	gazing over the calm sea towards the headland. Sea and headland now grew
 13373	dim. Pulses were beating in his eyes, veiling their sight, and he felt
 13374	the fever of his cheeks.
 13375	
 13376	A voice within the tower called loudly:
 13377	
 13378	--Are you up there, Mulligan?
 13379	
 13380	--I'm coming, Buck Mulligan answered.
 13381	
 13382	He turned towards Stephen and said:
 13383	
 13384	--Look at the sea. What does it care about offences? Chuck Loyola,
 13385	Kinch, and come on down. The Sassenach wants his morning rashers.
 13386	
 13387	His head halted again for a moment at the top of the staircase, level
 13388	with the roof:
 13389	
 13390	--Don't mope over it all day, he said. I'm inconsequent. Give up the
 13391	moody brooding.
 13392	
 13393	His head vanished but the drone of his descending voice boomed out of
 13394	the stairhead:
 13395	
 13396	     _And no more turn aside and brood
 13397	     Upon love's bitter mystery
 13398	     For Fergus rules the brazen cars._
 13399	
 13400	
 13401	Woodshadows floated silently by through the morning peace from the
 13402	stairhead seaward where he gazed. Inshore and farther out the mirror of
 13403	water whitened, spurned by lightshod hurrying feet. White breast of
 13404	the dim sea. The twining stresses, two by two. A hand plucking the
 13405	harpstrings, merging their twining chords. Wavewhite wedded words
 13406	shimmering on the dim tide.
 13407	
 13408	A cloud began to cover the sun slowly, wholly, shadowing the bay in
 13409	deeper green. It lay beneath him, a bowl of bitter waters. Fergus' song:
 13410	I sang it alone in the house, holding down the long dark chords. Her
 13411	door was open: she wanted to hear my music. Silent with awe and pity
 13412	I went to her bedside. She was crying in her wretched bed. For those
 13413	words, Stephen: love's bitter mystery.
 13414	
 13415	Where now?
 13416	
 13417	Her secrets: old featherfans, tasselled dancecards, powdered with musk,
 13418	a gaud of amber beads in her locked drawer. A birdcage hung in the sunny
 13419	window of her house when she was a girl. She heard old Royce sing in the
 13420	pantomime of Turko the Terrible and laughed with others when he sang:
 13421	
 13422	     _I am the boy
 13423	     That can enjoy
 13424	     Invisibility._
 13425	
 13426	
 13427	Phantasmal mirth, folded away: muskperfumed.
 13428	
 13429	_And no more turn aside and brood._
 13430	
 13431	
 13432	Folded away in the memory of nature with her toys. Memories beset his
 13433	brooding brain. Her glass of water from the kitchen tap when she had
 13434	approached the sacrament. A cored apple, filled with brown sugar,
 13435	roasting for her at the hob on a dark autumn evening. Her shapely
 13436	fingernails reddened by the blood of squashed lice from the children's
 13437	shirts.
 13438	
 13439	In a dream, silently, she had come to him, her wasted body within its
 13440	loose graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her breath,
 13441	bent over him with mute secret words, a faint odour of wetted ashes.
 13442	
 13443	Her glazing eyes, staring out of death, to shake and bend my soul. On me
 13444	alone. The ghostcandle to light her agony. Ghostly light on the tortured
 13445	face. Her hoarse loud breath rattling in horror, while all prayed on
 13446	their knees. Her eyes on me to strike me down. _Liliata rutilantium te
 13447	confessorum turma circumdet: iubilantium te virginum chorus excipiat._
 13448	
 13449	Ghoul! Chewer of corpses!
 13450	
 13451	No, mother! Let me be and let me live.
 13452	
 13453	--Kinch ahoy!
 13454	
 13455	Buck Mulligan's voice sang from within the tower. It came nearer up the
 13456	staircase, calling again. Stephen, still trembling at his soul's cry,
 13457	heard warm running sunlight and in the air behind him friendly words.
 13458	
 13459	--Dedalus, come down, like a good mosey. Breakfast is ready. Haines is
 13460	apologising for waking us last night. It's all right.
 13461	
 13462	--I'm coming, Stephen said, turning.
 13463	
 13464	--Do, for Jesus' sake, Buck Mulligan said. For my sake and for all our
 13465	sakes.
 13466	
 13467	His head disappeared and reappeared.
 13468	
 13469	--I told him your symbol of Irish art. He says it's very clever. Touch
 13470	him for a quid, will you? A guinea, I mean.
 13471	
 13472	--I get paid this morning, Stephen said.
 13473	
 13474	--The school kip? Buck Mulligan said. How much? Four quid? Lend us one.
 13475	
 13476	--If you want it, Stephen said.
 13477	
 13478	--Four shining sovereigns, Buck Mulligan cried with delight. We'll
 13479	have a glorious drunk to astonish the druidy druids. Four omnipotent
 13480	sovereigns.
 13481	
 13482	He flung up his hands and tramped down the stone stairs, singing out of
 13483	tune with a Cockney accent:
 13484	
 13485	     _O, won't we have a merry time,
 13486	     Drinking whisky, beer and wine!
 13487	     On coronation,
 13488	     Coronation day!
 13489	     O, won't we have a merry time
 13490	     On coronation day!_
 13491	
 13492	
 13493	Warm sunshine merrying over the sea. The nickel shavingbowl shone,
 13494	forgotten, on the parapet. Why should I bring it down? Or leave it there
 13495	all day, forgotten friendship?
 13496	
 13497	He went over to it, held it in his hands awhile, feeling its coolness,
 13498	smelling the clammy slaver of the lather in which the brush was stuck.
 13499	So I carried the boat of incense then at Clongowes. I am another now and
 13500	yet the same. A servant too. A server of a servant.
 13501	
 13502	In the gloomy domed livingroom of the tower Buck Mulligan's gowned form
 13503	moved briskly to and fro about the hearth, hiding and revealing its
 13504	yellow glow. Two shafts of soft daylight fell across the flagged floor
 13505	from the high barbacans: and at the meeting of their rays a cloud of
 13506	coalsmoke and fumes of fried grease floated, turning.
 13507	
 13508	--We'll be choked, Buck Mulligan said. Haines, open that door, will you?
 13509	
 13510	Stephen laid the shavingbowl on the locker. A tall figure rose from the
 13511	hammock where it had been sitting, went to the doorway and pulled open
 13512	the inner doors.
 13513	
 13514	--Have you the key? a voice asked.
 13515	
 13516	--Dedalus has it, Buck Mulligan said. Janey Mack, I'm choked!
 13517	
 13518	He howled, without looking up from the fire:
 13519	
 13520	--Kinch!
 13521	
 13522	--It's in the lock, Stephen said, coming forward.
 13523	
 13524	The key scraped round harshly twice and, when the heavy door had been
 13525	set ajar, welcome light and bright air entered. Haines stood at the
 13526	doorway, looking out. Stephen haled his upended valise to the table and
 13527	sat down to wait. Buck Mulligan tossed the fry on to the dish beside
 13528	him. Then he carried the dish and a large teapot over to the table, set
 13529	them down heavily and sighed with relief.
 13530	
 13531	--I'm melting, he said, as the candle remarked when... But, hush! Not a
 13532	word more on that subject! Kinch, wake up! Bread, butter, honey. Haines,
 13533	come in. The grub is ready. Bless us, O Lord, and these thy gifts.
 13534	Where's the sugar? O, jay, there's no milk.
 13535	
 13536	Stephen fetched the loaf and the pot of honey and the buttercooler from
 13537	the locker. Buck Mulligan sat down in a sudden pet.
 13538	
 13539	--What sort of a kip is this? he said. I told her to come after eight.
 13540	
 13541	--We can drink it black, Stephen said thirstily. There's a lemon in the
 13542	locker.
 13543	
 13544	--O, damn you and your Paris fads! Buck Mulligan said. I want Sandycove
 13545	milk.
 13546	
 13547	Haines came in from the doorway and said quietly:
 13548	
 13549	--That woman is coming up with the milk.
 13550	
 13551	--The blessings of God on you! Buck Mulligan cried, jumping up from his
 13552	chair. Sit down. Pour out the tea there. The sugar is in the bag. Here,
 13553	I can't go fumbling at the damned eggs.
 13554	
 13555	He hacked through the fry on the dish and slapped it out on three
 13556	plates, saying:
 13557	
 13558	--_In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti._
 13559	
 13560	Haines sat down to pour out the tea.
 13561	
 13562	--I'm giving you two lumps each, he said. But, I say, Mulligan, you do
 13563	make strong tea, don't you?
 13564	
 13565	Buck Mulligan, hewing thick slices from the loaf, said in an old woman's
 13566	wheedling voice:
 13567	
 13568	--When I makes tea I makes tea, as old mother Grogan said. And when I
 13569	makes water I makes water.
 13570	
 13571	--By Jove, it is tea, Haines said.
 13572	
 13573	Buck Mulligan went on hewing and wheedling:
 13574	
 13575	--_So I do, Mrs Cahill,_ says she. _Begob, ma'am,_ says Mrs Cahill, _God
 13576	send you don't make them in the one pot._
 13577	
 13578	He lunged towards his messmates in turn a thick slice of bread, impaled
 13579	on his knife.
 13580	
 13581	--That's folk, he said very earnestly, for your book, Haines. Five
 13582	lines of text and ten pages of notes about the folk and the fishgods of
 13583	Dundrum. Printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind.
 13584	
 13585	He turned to Stephen and asked in a fine puzzled voice, lifting his
 13586	brows:
 13587	
 13588	--Can you recall, brother, is mother Grogan's tea and water pot spoken
 13589	of in the Mabinogion or is it in the Upanishads?
 13590	
 13591	--I doubt it, said Stephen gravely.
 13592	
 13593	--Do you now? Buck Mulligan said in the same tone. Your reasons, pray?
 13594	
 13595	--I fancy, Stephen said as he ate, it did not exist in or out of the
 13596	Mabinogion. Mother Grogan was, one imagines, a kinswoman of Mary Ann.
 13597	
 13598	Buck Mulligan's face smiled with delight.
 13599	
 13600	--Charming! he said in a finical sweet voice, showing his white teeth
 13601	and blinking his eyes pleasantly. Do you think she was? Quite charming!
 13602	
 13603	Then, suddenly overclouding all his features, he growled in a hoarsened
 13604	rasping voice as he hewed again vigorously at the loaf:
 13605	
 13606	     _--For old Mary Ann
 13607	     She doesn't care a damn.
 13608	     But, hising up her petticoats..._
 13609	
 13610	
 13611	He crammed his mouth with fry and munched and droned.
 13612	
 13613	The doorway was darkened by an entering form.
 13614	
 13615	--The milk, sir!
 13616	
 13617	--Come in, ma'am, Mulligan said. Kinch, get the jug.
 13618	
 13619	An old woman came forward and stood by Stephen's elbow.
 13620	
 13621	--That's a lovely morning, sir, she said. Glory be to God.
 13622	
 13623	--To whom? Mulligan said, glancing at her. Ah, to be sure!
 13624	
 13625	Stephen reached back and took the milkjug from the locker.
 13626	
 13627	--The islanders, Mulligan said to Haines casually, speak frequently of
 13628	the collector of prepuces.
 13629	
 13630	--How much, sir? asked the old woman.
 13631	
 13632	--A quart, Stephen said.
 13633	
 13634	He watched her pour into the measure and thence into the jug rich white
 13635	milk, not hers. Old shrunken paps. She poured again a measureful and
 13636	a tilly. Old and secret she had entered from a morning world, maybe
 13637	a messenger. She praised the goodness of the milk, pouring it out.
 13638	Crouching by a patient cow at daybreak in the lush field, a witch on her
 13639	toadstool, her wrinkled fingers quick at the squirting dugs. They lowed
 13640	about her whom they knew, dewsilky cattle. Silk of the kine and poor old
 13641	woman, names given her in old times. A wandering crone, lowly form of
 13642	an immortal serving her conqueror and her gay betrayer, their common
 13643	cuckquean, a messenger from the secret morning. To serve or to upbraid,
 13644	whether he could not tell: but scorned to beg her favour.
 13645	
 13646	--It is indeed, ma'am, Buck Mulligan said, pouring milk into their cups.
 13647	
 13648	--Taste it, sir, she said.
 13649	
 13650	He drank at her bidding.
 13651	
 13652	--If we could live on good food like that, he said to her somewhat
 13653	loudly, we wouldn't have the country full of rotten teeth and rotten
 13654	guts. Living in a bogswamp, eating cheap food and the streets paved with
 13655	dust, horsedung and consumptives' spits.
 13656	
 13657	--Are you a medical student, sir? the old woman asked.
 13658	
 13659	--I am, ma'am, Buck Mulligan answered.
 13660	
 13661	--Look at that now, she said.
 13662	
 13663	Stephen listened in scornful silence. She bows her old head to a voice
 13664	that speaks to her loudly, her bonesetter, her medicineman: me she
 13665	slights. To the voice that will shrive and oil for the grave all there
 13666	is of her but her woman's unclean loins, of man's flesh made not in
 13667	God's likeness, the serpent's prey. And to the loud voice that now bids
 13668	her be silent with wondering unsteady eyes.
 13669	
 13670	--Do you understand what he says? Stephen asked her.
 13671	
 13672	--Is it French you are talking, sir? the old woman said to Haines.
 13673	
 13674	Haines spoke to her again a longer speech, confidently.
 13675	
 13676	--Irish, Buck Mulligan said. Is there Gaelic on you?
 13677	
 13678	--I thought it was Irish, she said, by the sound of it. Are you from the
 13679	west, sir?
 13680	
 13681	--I am an Englishman, Haines answered.
 13682	
 13683	--He's English, Buck Mulligan said, and he thinks we ought to speak
 13684	Irish in Ireland.
 13685	
 13686	--Sure we ought to, the old woman said, and I'm ashamed I don't speak
 13687	the language myself. I'm told it's a grand language by them that knows.
 13688	
 13689	--Grand is no name for it, said Buck Mulligan. Wonderful entirely. Fill
 13690	us out some more tea, Kinch. Would you like a cup, ma'am?
 13691	
 13692	--No, thank you, sir, the old woman said, slipping the ring of the
 13693	milkcan on her forearm and about to go.
 13694	
 13695	Haines said to her:
 13696	
 13697	--Have you your bill? We had better pay her, Mulligan, hadn't we?
 13698	
 13699	Stephen filled again the three cups.
 13700	
 13701	--Bill, sir? she said, halting. Well, it's seven mornings a pint at
 13702	twopence is seven twos is a shilling and twopence over and these three
 13703	mornings a quart at fourpence is three quarts is a shilling. That's a
 13704	shilling and one and two is two and two, sir.
 13705	
 13706	Buck Mulligan sighed and, having filled his mouth with a crust thickly
 13707	buttered on both sides, stretched forth his legs and began to search his
 13708	trouser pockets.
 13709	
 13710	--Pay up and look pleasant, Haines said to him, smiling.
 13711	
 13712	Stephen filled a third cup, a spoonful of tea colouring faintly the
 13713	thick rich milk. Buck Mulligan brought up a florin, twisted it round in
 13714	his fingers and cried:
 13715	
 13716	--A miracle!
 13717	
 13718	He passed it along the table towards the old woman, saying:
 13719	
 13720	--Ask nothing more of me, sweet. All I can give you I give.
 13721	
 13722	Stephen laid the coin in her uneager hand.
 13723	
 13724	--We'll owe twopence, he said.
 13725	
 13726	--Time enough, sir, she said, taking the coin. Time enough. Good
 13727	morning, sir.
 13728	
 13729	She curtseyed and went out, followed by Buck Mulligan's tender chant:
 13730	
 13731	     _--Heart of my heart, were it more,
 13732	     More would be laid at your feet._
 13733	
 13734	
 13735	He turned to Stephen and said:
 13736	
 13737	--Seriously, Dedalus. I'm stony. Hurry out to your school kip and bring
 13738	us back some money. Today the bards must drink and junket. Ireland
 13739	expects that every man this day will do his duty.
 13740	
 13741	--That reminds me, Haines said, rising, that I have to visit your
 13742	national library today.
 13743	
 13744	--Our swim first, Buck Mulligan said.
 13745	
 13746	He turned to Stephen and asked blandly:
 13747	
 13748	--Is this the day for your monthly wash, Kinch?
 13749	
 13750	Then he said to Haines:
 13751	
 13752	--The unclean bard makes a point of washing once a month.
 13753	
 13754	--All Ireland is washed by the gulfstream, Stephen said as he let honey
 13755	trickle over a slice of the loaf.
 13756	
 13757	Haines from the corner where he was knotting easily a scarf about the
 13758	loose collar of his tennis shirt spoke:
 13759	
 13760	--I intend to make a collection of your sayings if you will let me.
 13761	
 13762	Speaking to me. They wash and tub and scrub. Agenbite of inwit.
 13763	Conscience. Yet here's a spot.
 13764	
 13765	--That one about the cracked lookingglass of a servant being the symbol
 13766	of Irish art is deuced good.
 13767	
 13768	Buck Mulligan kicked Stephen's foot under the table and said with warmth
 13769	of tone:
 13770	
 13771	--Wait till you hear him on Hamlet, Haines.
 13772	
 13773	--Well, I mean it, Haines said, still speaking to Stephen. I was just
 13774	thinking of it when that poor old creature came in.
 13775	
 13776	--Would I make any money by it? Stephen asked.
 13777	
 13778	Haines laughed and, as he took his soft grey hat from the holdfast of
 13779	the hammock, said:
 13780	
 13781	--I don't know, I'm sure.
 13782	
 13783	He strolled out to the doorway. Buck Mulligan bent across to Stephen and
 13784	said with coarse vigour:
 13785	
 13786	--You put your hoof in it now. What did you say that for?
 13787	
 13788	--Well? Stephen said. The problem is to get money. From whom? From the
 13789	milkwoman or from him. It's a toss up, I think.
 13790	
 13791	--I blow him out about you, Buck Mulligan said, and then you come along
 13792	with your lousy leer and your gloomy jesuit jibes.
 13793	
 13794	--I see little hope, Stephen said, from her or from him.
 13795	
 13796	Buck Mulligan sighed tragically and laid his hand on Stephen's arm.
 13797	
 13798	--From me, Kinch, he said.
 13799	
 13800	In a suddenly changed tone he added:
 13801	
 13802	--To tell you the God's truth I think you're right. Damn all else they
 13803	are good for. Why don't you play them as I do? To hell with them all.
 13804	Let us get out of the kip.
 13805	
 13806	He stood up, gravely ungirdled and disrobed himself of his gown, saying
 13807	resignedly:
 13808	
 13809	--Mulligan is stripped of his garments.
 13810	
 13811	He emptied his pockets on to the table.
 13812	
 13813	--There's your snotrag, he said.
 13814	
 13815	And putting on his stiff collar and rebellious tie he spoke to them,
 13816	chiding them, and to his dangling watchchain. His hands plunged and
 13817	rummaged in his trunk while he called for a clean handkerchief. God,
 13818	we'll simply have to dress the character. I want puce gloves and
 13819	green boots. Contradiction. Do I contradict myself? Very well then, I
 13820	contradict myself. Mercurial Malachi. A limp black missile flew out of
 13821	his talking hands.
 13822	
 13823	--And there's your Latin quarter hat, he said.
 13824	
 13825	Stephen picked it up and put it on. Haines called to them from the
 13826	doorway:
 13827	
 13828	--Are you coming, you fellows?
 13829	
 13830	--I'm ready, Buck Mulligan answered, going towards the door. Come out,
 13831	Kinch. You have eaten all we left, I suppose. Resigned he passed out
 13832	with grave words and gait, saying, wellnigh with sorrow:
 13833	
 13834	--And going forth he met Butterly.
 13835	
 13836	Stephen, taking his ashplant from its leaningplace, followed them out
 13837	and, as they went down the ladder, pulled to the slow iron door and
 13838	locked it. He put the huge key in his inner pocket.
 13839	
 13840	At the foot of the ladder Buck Mulligan asked:
 13841	
 13842	--Did you bring the key?
 13843	
 13844	--I have it, Stephen said, preceding them.
 13845	
 13846	He walked on. Behind him he heard Buck Mulligan club with his heavy
 13847	bathtowel the leader shoots of ferns or grasses.
 13848	
 13849	--Down, sir! How dare you, sir!
 13850	
 13851	Haines asked:
 13852	
 13853	--Do you pay rent for this tower?
 13854	
 13855	--Twelve quid, Buck Mulligan said.
 13856	
 13857	--To the secretary of state for war, Stephen added over his shoulder.
 13858	
 13859	They halted while Haines surveyed the tower and said at last:
 13860	
 13861	--Rather bleak in wintertime, I should say. Martello you call it?
 13862	
 13863	--Billy Pitt had them built, Buck Mulligan said, when the French were on
 13864	the sea. But ours is the _omphalos_.
 13865	
 13866	--What is your idea of Hamlet? Haines asked Stephen.
 13867	
 13868	--No, no, Buck Mulligan shouted in pain. I'm not equal to Thomas Aquinas
 13869	and the fiftyfive reasons he has made out to prop it up. Wait till I
 13870	have a few pints in me first.
 13871	
 13872	He turned to Stephen, saying, as he pulled down neatly the peaks of his
 13873	primrose waistcoat:
 13874	
 13875	--You couldn't manage it under three pints, Kinch, could you?
 13876	
 13877	--It has waited so long, Stephen said listlessly, it can wait longer.
 13878	
 13879	--You pique my curiosity, Haines said amiably. Is it some paradox?
 13880	
 13881	--Pooh! Buck Mulligan said. We have grown out of Wilde and paradoxes.
 13882	It's quite simple. He proves by algebra that Hamlet's grandson is
 13883	Shakespeare's grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own
 13884	father.
 13885	
 13886	--What? Haines said, beginning to point at Stephen. He himself?
 13887	
 13888	Buck Mulligan slung his towel stolewise round his neck and, bending in
 13889	loose laughter, said to Stephen's ear:
 13890	
 13891	--O, shade of Kinch the elder! Japhet in search of a father!
 13892	
 13893	--We're always tired in the morning, Stephen said to Haines. And it is
 13894	rather long to tell.
 13895	
 13896	Buck Mulligan, walking forward again, raised his hands.
 13897	
 13898	--The sacred pint alone can unbind the tongue of Dedalus, he said.
 13899	
 13900	--I mean to say, Haines explained to Stephen as they followed, this
 13901	tower and these cliffs here remind me somehow of Elsinore. _That beetles
 13902	o'er his base into the sea,_ isn't it?
 13903	
 13904	Buck Mulligan turned suddenly for an instant towards Stephen but did
 13905	not speak. In the bright silent instant Stephen saw his own image in
 13906	cheap dusty mourning between their gay attires.
 13907	
 13908	--It's a wonderful tale, Haines said, bringing them to halt again.
 13909	
 13910	Eyes, pale as the sea the wind had freshened, paler, firm and prudent.
 13911	The seas' ruler, he gazed southward over the bay, empty save for the
 13912	smokeplume of the mailboat vague on the bright skyline and a sail
 13913	tacking by the Muglins.
 13914	
 13915	--I read a theological interpretation of it somewhere, he said bemused.
 13916	The Father and the Son idea. The Son striving to be atoned with the
 13917	Father.
 13918	
 13919	Buck Mulligan at once put on a blithe broadly smiling face. He looked
 13920	at them, his wellshaped mouth open happily, his eyes, from which he had
 13921	suddenly withdrawn all shrewd sense, blinking with mad gaiety. He moved
 13922	a doll's head to and fro, the brims of his Panama hat quivering, and
 13923	began to chant in a quiet happy foolish voice:
 13924	
 13925	     _--I'm the queerest young fellow that ever you heard.
 13926	     My mother's a jew, my father's a bird.
 13927	     With Joseph the joiner I cannot agree.
 13928	     So here's to disciples and Calvary._
 13929	
 13930	
 13931	He held up a forefinger of warning.
 13932	
 13933	     _--If anyone thinks that I amn't divine
 13934	     He'll get no free drinks when I'm making the wine
 13935	     But have to drink water and wish it were plain
 13936	     That i make when the wine becomes water again._
 13937	
 13938	
 13939	He tugged swiftly at Stephen's ashplant in farewell and, running forward
 13940	to a brow of the cliff, fluttered his hands at his sides like fins or
 13941	wings of one about to rise in the air, and chanted:
 13942	
 13943	     _--Goodbye, now, goodbye! Write down all I said
 13944	     And tell Tom, Dick and Harry I rose from the dead.
 13945	     What's bred in the bone cannot fail me to fly
 13946	     And Olivet's breezy... Goodbye, now, goodbye!_
 13947	
 13948	
 13949	He capered before them down towards the fortyfoot hole, fluttering his
 13950	winglike hands, leaping nimbly, Mercury's hat quivering in the fresh
 13951	wind that bore back to them his brief birdsweet cries.
 13952	
 13953	Haines, who had been laughing guardedly, walked on beside Stephen and
 13954	said:
 13955	
 13956	--We oughtn't to laugh, I suppose. He's rather blasphemous. I'm not a
 13957	believer myself, that is to say. Still his gaiety takes the harm out of
 13958	it somehow, doesn't it? What did he call it? Joseph the Joiner?
 13959	
 13960	--The ballad of joking Jesus, Stephen answered.
 13961	
 13962	--O, Haines said, you have heard it before?
 13963	
 13964	--Three times a day, after meals, Stephen said drily.
 13965	
 13966	--You're not a believer, are you? Haines asked. I mean, a believer in
 13967	the narrow sense of the word. Creation from nothing and miracles and a
 13968	personal God.
 13969	
 13970	--There's only one sense of the word, it seems to me, Stephen said.
 13971	
 13972	Haines stopped to take out a smooth silver case in which twinkled a
 13973	green stone. He sprang it open with his thumb and offered it.
 13974	
 13975	--Thank you, Stephen said, taking a cigarette.
 13976	
 13977	Haines helped himself and snapped the case to. He put it back in his
 13978	sidepocket and took from his waistcoatpocket a nickel tinderbox, sprang
 13979	it open too, and, having lit his cigarette, held the flaming spunk
 13980	towards Stephen in the shell of his hands.
 13981	
 13982	--Yes, of course, he said, as they went on again. Either you believe
 13983	or you don't, isn't it? Personally I couldn't stomach that idea of a
 13984	personal God. You don't stand for that, I suppose?
 13985	
 13986	--You behold in me, Stephen said with grim displeasure, a horrible
 13987	example of free thought.
 13988	
 13989	He walked on, waiting to be spoken to, trailing his ashplant by his
 13990	side. Its ferrule followed lightly on the path, squealing at his heels.
 13991	My familiar, after me, calling, Steeeeeeeeeeeephen! A wavering line
 13992	along the path. They will walk on it tonight, coming here in the dark.
 13993	He wants that key. It is mine. I paid the rent. Now I eat his salt
 13994	bread. Give him the key too. All. He will ask for it. That was in his
 13995	eyes.
 13996	
 13997	--After all, Haines began...
 13998	
 13999	Stephen turned and saw that the cold gaze which had measured him was not
 14000	all unkind.
 14001	
 14002	--After all, I should think you are able to free yourself. You are your
 14003	own master, it seems to me.
 14004	
 14005	--I am a servant of two masters, Stephen said, an English and an
 14006	Italian.
 14007	
 14008	--Italian? Haines said.
 14009	
 14010	A crazy queen, old and jealous. Kneel down before me.
 14011	
 14012	--And a third, Stephen said, there is who wants me for odd jobs.
 14013	
 14014	--Italian? Haines said again. What do you mean?
 14015	
 14016	--The imperial British state, Stephen answered, his colour rising, and
 14017	the holy Roman catholic and apostolic church.
 14018	
 14019	Haines detached from his underlip some fibres of tobacco before he
 14020	spoke.
 14021	
 14022	--I can quite understand that, he said calmly. An Irishman must think
 14023	like that, I daresay. We feel in England that we have treated you rather
 14024	unfairly. It seems history is to blame.
 14025	
 14026	The proud potent titles clanged over Stephen's memory the triumph
 14027	of their brazen bells: _et unam sanctam catholicam et apostolicam
 14028	ecclesiam:_ the slow growth and change of rite and dogma like his own
 14029	rare thoughts, a chemistry of stars. Symbol of the apostles in the
 14030	mass for pope Marcellus, the voices blended, singing alone loud in
 14031	affirmation: and behind their chant the vigilant angel of the church
 14032	militant disarmed and menaced her heresiarchs. A horde of heresies
 14033	fleeing with mitres awry: Photius and the brood of mockers of
 14034	whom Mulligan was one, and Arius, warring his life long upon the
 14035	consubstantiality of the Son with the Father, and Valentine, spurning
 14036	Christ's terrene body, and the subtle African heresiarch Sabellius who
 14037	held that the Father was Himself His own Son. Words Mulligan had spoken
 14038	a moment since in mockery to the stranger. Idle mockery. The void
 14039	awaits surely all them that weave the wind: a menace, a disarming and a
 14040	worsting from those embattled angels of the church, Michael's host,
 14041	who defend her ever in the hour of conflict with their lances and their
 14042	shields.
 14043	
 14044	Hear, hear! Prolonged applause. _Zut! Nom de Dieu!_
 14045	
 14046	--Of course I'm a Britisher, Haines's voice said, and I feel as one. I
 14047	don't want to see my country fall into the hands of German jews either.
 14048	That's our national problem, I'm afraid, just now.
 14049	
 14050	Two men stood at the verge of the cliff, watching: businessman, boatman.
 14051	
 14052	--She's making for Bullock harbour.
 14053	
 14054	The boatman nodded towards the north of the bay with some disdain.
 14055	
 14056	--There's five fathoms out there, he said. It'll be swept up that way
 14057	when the tide comes in about one. It's nine days today.
 14058	
 14059	The man that was drowned. A sail veering about the blank bay waiting
 14060	for a swollen bundle to bob up, roll over to the sun a puffy face,
 14061	saltwhite. Here I am.
 14062	
 14063	They followed the winding path down to the creek. Buck Mulligan stood on
 14064	a stone, in shirtsleeves, his unclipped tie rippling over his shoulder.
 14065	A young man clinging to a spur of rock near him, moved slowly frogwise
 14066	his green legs in the deep jelly of the water.
 14067	
 14068	--Is the brother with you, Malachi?
 14069	
 14070	--Down in Westmeath. With the Bannons.
 14071	
 14072	--Still there? I got a card from Bannon. Says he found a sweet young
 14073	thing down there. Photo girl he calls her.
 14074	
 14075	--Snapshot, eh? Brief exposure.
 14076	
 14077	Buck Mulligan sat down to unlace his boots. An elderly man shot up near
 14078	the spur of rock a blowing red face. He scrambled up by the stones,
 14079	water glistening on his pate and on its garland of grey hair, water
 14080	rilling over his chest and paunch and spilling jets out of his black
 14081	sagging loincloth.
 14082	
 14083	Buck Mulligan made way for him to scramble past and, glancing at Haines
 14084	and Stephen, crossed himself piously with his thumbnail at brow and lips
 14085	and breastbone.
 14086	
 14087	--Seymour's back in town, the young man said, grasping again his spur of
 14088	rock. Chucked medicine and going in for the army.
 14089	
 14090	--Ah, go to God! Buck Mulligan said.
 14091	
 14092	--Going over next week to stew. You know that red Carlisle girl, Lily?
 14093	
 14094	--Yes.
 14095	
 14096	--Spooning with him last night on the pier. The father is rotto with
 14097	money.
 14098	
 14099	--Is she up the pole?
 14100	
 14101	--Better ask Seymour that.
 14102	
 14103	--Seymour a bleeding officer! Buck Mulligan said.
 14104	
 14105	He nodded to himself as he drew off his trousers and stood up, saying
 14106	tritely:
 14107	
 14108	--Redheaded women buck like goats.
 14109	
 14110	He broke off in alarm, feeling his side under his flapping shirt.
 14111	
 14112	--My twelfth rib is gone, he cried. I'm the _Uebermensch._ Toothless
 14113	Kinch and I, the supermen.
 14114	
 14115	He struggled out of his shirt and flung it behind him to where his
 14116	clothes lay.
 14117	
 14118	--Are you going in here, Malachi?
 14119	
 14120	--Yes. Make room in the bed.
 14121	
 14122	The young man shoved himself backward through the water and reached
 14123	the middle of the creek in two long clean strokes. Haines sat down on a
 14124	stone, smoking.
 14125	
 14126	--Are you not coming in? Buck Mulligan asked.
 14127	
 14128	--Later on, Haines said. Not on my breakfast.
 14129	
 14130	Stephen turned away.
 14131	
 14132	--I'm going, Mulligan, he said.
 14133	
 14134	--Give us that key, Kinch, Buck Mulligan said, to keep my chemise flat.
 14135	
 14136	Stephen handed him the key. Buck Mulligan laid it across his heaped
 14137	clothes.
 14138	
 14139	--And twopence, he said, for a pint. Throw it there.
 14140	
 14141	Stephen threw two pennies on the soft heap. Dressing, undressing. Buck
 14142	Mulligan erect, with joined hands before him, said solemnly:
 14143	
 14144	--He who stealeth from the poor lendeth to the Lord. Thus spake
 14145	Zarathustra.
 14146	
 14147	His plump body plunged.
 14148	
 14149	--We'll see you again, Haines said, turning as Stephen walked up the
 14150	path and smiling at wild Irish.
 14151	
 14152	Horn of a bull, hoof of a horse, smile of a Saxon.
 14153	
 14154	--The Ship, Buck Mulligan cried. Half twelve.
 14155	
 14156	--Good, Stephen said.
 14157	
 14158	He walked along the upwardcurving path.
 14159	
 14160	     _Liliata rutilantium.
 14161	     Turma circumdet.
 14162	     Iubilantium te virginum._
 14163	
 14164	
 14165	The priest's grey nimbus in a niche where he dressed discreetly. I will
 14166	not sleep here tonight. Home also I cannot go.
 14167	
 14168	A voice, sweettoned and sustained, called to him from the sea. Turning
 14169	the curve he waved his hand. It called again. A sleek brown head, a
 14170	seal's, far out on the water, round.
 14171	
 14172	Usurper.
 14173	
 14174	
 14175	
 14176	--You, Cochrane, what city sent for him?
 14177	
 14178	--Tarentum, sir.
 14179	
 14180	--Very good. Well?
 14181	
 14182	--There was a battle, sir.
 14183	
 14184	--Very good. Where?
 14185	
 14186	The boy's blank face asked the blank window.
 14187	
 14188	Fabled by the daughters of memory. And yet it was in some way if not as
 14189	memory fabled it. A phrase, then, of impatience, thud of Blake's wings
 14190	of excess. I hear the ruin of all space, shattered glass and toppling
 14191	masonry, and time one livid final flame. What's left us then?
 14192	
 14193	--I forget the place, sir. 279 B. C.
 14194	
 14195	--Asculum, Stephen said, glancing at the name and date in the
 14196	gorescarred book.
 14197	
 14198	--Yes, sir. And he said: _Another victory like that and we are done
 14199	for._
 14200	
 14201	That phrase the world had remembered. A dull ease of the mind. From
 14202	a hill above a corpsestrewn plain a general speaking to his officers,
 14203	leaned upon his spear. Any general to any officers. They lend ear.
 14204	
 14205	--You, Armstrong, Stephen said. What was the end of Pyrrhus?
 14206	
 14207	--End of Pyrrhus, sir?
 14208	
 14209	--I know, sir. Ask me, sir, Comyn said.
 14210	
 14211	--Wait. You, Armstrong. Do you know anything about Pyrrhus?
 14212	
 14213	A bag of figrolls lay snugly in Armstrong's satchel. He curled them
 14214	between his palms at whiles and swallowed them softly. Crumbs adhered to
 14215	the tissue of his lips. A sweetened boy's breath. Welloff people, proud
 14216	that their eldest son was in the navy. Vico road, Dalkey.
 14217	
 14218	--Pyrrhus, sir? Pyrrhus, a pier.
 14219	
 14220	All laughed. Mirthless high malicious laughter. Armstrong looked round
 14221	at his classmates, silly glee in profile. In a moment they will laugh
 14222	more loudly, aware of my lack of rule and of the fees their papas pay.
 14223	
 14224	--Tell me now, Stephen said, poking the boy's shoulder with the book,
 14225	what is a pier.
 14226	
 14227	--A pier, sir, Armstrong said. A thing out in the water. A kind of a
 14228	bridge. Kingstown pier, sir.
 14229	
 14230	Some laughed again: mirthless but with meaning. Two in the back bench
 14231	whispered. Yes. They knew: had never learned nor ever been innocent.
 14232	All. With envy he watched their faces: Edith, Ethel, Gerty, Lily. Their
 14233	likes: their breaths, too, sweetened with tea and jam, their bracelets
 14234	tittering in the struggle.
 14235	
 14236	--Kingstown pier, Stephen said. Yes, a disappointed bridge.
 14237	
 14238	The words troubled their gaze.
 14239	
 14240	--How, sir? Comyn asked. A bridge is across a river.
 14241	
 14242	For Haines's chapbook. No-one here to hear. Tonight deftly amid wild
 14243	drink and talk, to pierce the polished mail of his mind. What then? A
 14244	jester at the court of his master, indulged and disesteemed, winning a
 14245	clement master's praise. Why had they chosen all that part? Not wholly
 14246	for the smooth caress. For them too history was a tale like any other
 14247	too often heard, their land a pawnshop.
 14248	
 14249	Had Pyrrhus not fallen by a beldam's hand in Argos or Julius Caesar not
 14250	been knifed to death. They are not to be thought away. Time has
 14251	branded them and fettered they are lodged in the room of the infinite
 14252	possibilities they have ousted. But can those have been possible seeing
 14253	that they never were? Or was that only possible which came to pass?
 14254	Weave, weaver of the wind.
 14255	
 14256	--Tell us a story, sir.
 14257	
 14258	--O, do, sir. A ghoststory.
 14259	
 14260	--Where do you begin in this? Stephen asked, opening another book.
 14261	
 14262	-_-Weep no more,_ Comyn said.
 14263	
 14264	--Go on then, Talbot.
 14265	
 14266	--And the story, sir?
 14267	
 14268	--After, Stephen said. Go on, Talbot.
 14269	
 14270	A swarthy boy opened a book and propped it nimbly under the breastwork
 14271	of his satchel. He recited jerks of verse with odd glances at the text:
 14272	
 14273	     _--Weep no more, woful shepherds, weep no more
 14274	     For Lycidas, your sorrow, is not dead,
 14275	     Sunk though he be beneath the watery floor..._
 14276	
 14277	
 14278	It must be a movement then, an actuality of the possible as possible.
 14279	Aristotle's phrase formed itself within the gabbled verses and floated
 14280	out into the studious silence of the library of Saint Genevieve where he
 14281	had read, sheltered from the sin of Paris, night by night. By his elbow
 14282	a delicate Siamese conned a handbook of strategy. Fed and feeding brains
 14283	about me: under glowlamps, impaled, with faintly beating feelers: and
 14284	in my mind's darkness a sloth of the underworld, reluctant, shy of
 14285	brightness, shifting her dragon scaly folds. Thought is the thought of
 14286	thought. Tranquil brightness. The soul is in a manner all that is: the
 14287	soul is the form of forms. Tranquility sudden, vast, candescent: form of
 14288	forms.
 14289	
 14290	Talbot repeated:
 14291	
 14292	     _--Through the dear might of Him that walked the waves,
 14293	     Through the dear might..._
 14294	
 14295	
 14296	--Turn over, Stephen said quietly. I don't see anything.
 14297	
 14298	--What, sir? Talbot asked simply, bending forward.
 14299	
 14300	His hand turned the page over. He leaned back and went on again, having
 14301	just remembered. Of him that walked the waves. Here also over these
 14302	craven hearts his shadow lies and on the scoffer's heart and lips and
 14303	on mine. It lies upon their eager faces who offered him a coin of the
 14304	tribute. To Caesar what is Caesar's, to God what is God's. A long
 14305	look from dark eyes, a riddling sentence to be woven and woven on the
 14306	church's looms. Ay.
 14307	
 14308	     _Riddle me, riddle me, randy ro.
 14309	     My father gave me seeds to sow._
 14310	
 14311	
 14312	Talbot slid his closed book into his satchel.
 14313	
 14314	--Have I heard all? Stephen asked.
 14315	
 14316	--Yes, sir. Hockey at ten, sir.
 14317	
 14318	--Half day, sir. Thursday.
 14319	
 14320	--Who can answer a riddle? Stephen asked.
 14321	
 14322	They bundled their books away, pencils clacking, pages rustling.
 14323	Crowding together they strapped and buckled their satchels, all gabbling
 14324	gaily:
 14325	
 14326	--A riddle, sir? Ask me, sir.
 14327	
 14328	--O, ask me, sir.
 14329	
 14330	--A hard one, sir.
 14331	
 14332	--This is the riddle, Stephen said:
 14333	
 14334	     _The cock crew,
 14335	     The sky was blue:
 14336	     The bells in heaven
 14337	     Were striking eleven.
 14338	     'Tis time for this poor soul
 14339	     To go to heaven._
 14340	
 14341	
 14342	What is that?
 14343	
 14344	--What, sir?
 14345	
 14346	--Again, sir. We didn't hear.
 14347	
 14348	Their eyes grew bigger as the lines were repeated. After a silence
 14349	Cochrane said:
 14350	
 14351	--What is it, sir? We give it up.
 14352	
 14353	Stephen, his throat itching, answered:
 14354	
 14355	--The fox burying his grandmother under a hollybush.
 14356	
 14357	He stood up and gave a shout of nervous laughter to which their cries
 14358	echoed dismay.
 14359	
 14360	A stick struck the door and a voice in the corridor called:
 14361	
 14362	--Hockey!
 14363	
 14364	They broke asunder, sidling out of their benches, leaping them. Quickly
 14365	they were gone and from the lumberroom came the rattle of sticks and
 14366	clamour of their boots and tongues.
 14367	
 14368	Sargent who alone had lingered came forward slowly, showing an open
 14369	copybook. His thick hair and scraggy neck gave witness of unreadiness
 14370	and through his misty glasses weak eyes looked up pleading. On his
 14371	cheek, dull and bloodless, a soft stain of ink lay, dateshaped, recent
 14372	and damp as a snail's bed.
 14373	
 14374	He held out his copybook. The word _Sums_ was written on the headline.
 14375	Beneath were sloping figures and at the foot a crooked signature with
 14376	blind loops and a blot. Cyril Sargent: his name and seal.
 14377	
 14378	--Mr Deasy told me to write them out all again, he said, and show them
 14379	to you, sir.
 14380	
 14381	Stephen touched the edges of the book. Futility.
 14382	
 14383	--Do you understand how to do them now? he asked.
 14384	
 14385	--Numbers eleven to fifteen, Sargent answered. Mr Deasy said I was to
 14386	copy them off the board, sir.
 14387	
 14388	--Can you do them yourself? Stephen asked.
 14389	
 14390	--No, sir.
 14391	
 14392	Ugly and futile: lean neck and thick hair and a stain of ink, a snail's
 14393	bed. Yet someone had loved him, borne him in her arms and in her heart.
 14394	But for her the race of the world would have trampled him underfoot,
 14395	a squashed boneless snail. She had loved his weak watery blood drained
 14396	from her own. Was that then real? The only true thing in life? His
 14397	mother's prostrate body the fiery Columbanus in holy zeal bestrode.
 14398	She was no more: the trembling skeleton of a twig burnt in the fire,
 14399	an odour of rosewood and wetted ashes. She had saved him from being
 14400	trampled underfoot and had gone, scarcely having been. A poor soul
 14401	gone to heaven: and on a heath beneath winking stars a fox, red reek
 14402	of rapine in his fur, with merciless bright eyes scraped in the earth,
 14403	listened, scraped up the earth, listened, scraped and scraped.
 14404	
 14405	Sitting at his side Stephen solved out the problem. He proves by algebra
 14406	that Shakespeare's ghost is Hamlet's grandfather. Sargent peered askance
 14407	through his slanted glasses. Hockeysticks rattled in the lumberroom: the
 14408	hollow knock of a ball and calls from the field.
 14409	
 14410	Across the page the symbols moved in grave morrice, in the mummery of
 14411	their letters, wearing quaint caps of squares and cubes. Give hands,
 14412	traverse, bow to partner: so: imps of fancy of the Moors. Gone too from
 14413	the world, Averroes and Moses Maimonides, dark men in mien and movement,
 14414	flashing in their mocking mirrors the obscure soul of the world, a
 14415	darkness shining in brightness which brightness could not comprehend.
 14416	
 14417	--Do you understand now? Can you work the second for yourself?
 14418	
 14419	--Yes, sir.
 14420	
 14421	In long shaky strokes Sargent copied the data. Waiting always for a word
 14422	of help his hand moved faithfully the unsteady symbols, a faint hue of
 14423	shame flickering behind his dull skin. _Amor matris:_ subjective and
 14424	objective genitive. With her weak blood and wheysour milk she had fed
 14425	him and hid from sight of others his swaddling bands.
 14426	
 14427	Like him was I, these sloping shoulders, this gracelessness. My
 14428	childhood bends beside me. Too far for me to lay a hand there once or
 14429	lightly. Mine is far and his secret as our eyes. Secrets, silent, stony
 14430	sit in the dark palaces of both our hearts: secrets weary of their
 14431	tyranny: tyrants, willing to be dethroned.
 14432	
 14433	The sum was done.
 14434	
 14435	--It is very simple, Stephen said as he stood up.
 14436	
 14437	--Yes, sir. Thanks, Sargent answered.
 14438	
 14439	He dried the page with a sheet of thin blottingpaper and carried his
 14440	copybook back to his bench.
 14441	
 14442	--You had better get your stick and go out to the others, Stephen said
 14443	as he followed towards the door the boy's graceless form.
 14444	
 14445	--Yes, sir.
 14446	
 14447	In the corridor his name was heard, called from the playfield.
 14448	
 14449	--Sargent!
 14450	
 14451	--Run on, Stephen said. Mr Deasy is calling you.
 14452	
 14453	He stood in the porch and watched the laggard hurry towards the scrappy
 14454	field where sharp voices were in strife. They were sorted in teams and
 14455	Mr Deasy came away stepping over wisps of grass with gaitered feet. When
 14456	he had reached the schoolhouse voices again contending called to him. He
 14457	turned his angry white moustache.
 14458	
 14459	--What is it now? he cried continually without listening.
 14460	
 14461	--Cochrane and Halliday are on the same side, sir, Stephen said.
 14462	
 14463	--Will you wait in my study for a moment, Mr Deasy said, till I restore
 14464	order here.
 14465	
 14466	And as he stepped fussily back across the field his old man's voice
 14467	cried sternly:
 14468	
 14469	--What is the matter? What is it now?
 14470	
 14471	Their sharp voices cried about him on all sides: their many forms closed
 14472	round him, the garish sunshine bleaching the honey of his illdyed head.
 14473	
 14474	Stale smoky air hung in the study with the smell of drab abraded leather
 14475	of its chairs. As on the first day he bargained with me here. As it was
 14476	in the beginning, is now. On the sideboard the tray of Stuart coins,
 14477	base treasure of a bog: and ever shall be. And snug in their spooncase
 14478	of purple plush, faded, the twelve apostles having preached to all the
 14479	gentiles: world without end.
 14480	
 14481	A hasty step over the stone porch and in the corridor. Blowing out his
 14482	rare moustache Mr Deasy halted at the table.
 14483	
 14484	--First, our little financial settlement, he said.
 14485	
 14486	He brought out of his coat a pocketbook bound by a leather thong. It
 14487	slapped open and he took from it two notes, one of joined halves, and
 14488	laid them carefully on the table.
 14489	
 14490	--Two, he said, strapping and stowing his pocketbook away.
 14491	
 14492	And now his strongroom for the gold. Stephen's embarrassed hand moved
 14493	over the shells heaped in the cold stone mortar: whelks and money
 14494	cowries and leopard shells: and this, whorled as an emir's turban, and
 14495	this, the scallop of saint James. An old pilgrim's hoard, dead treasure,
 14496	hollow shells.
 14497	
 14498	A sovereign fell, bright and new, on the soft pile of the tablecloth.
 14499	
 14500	--Three, Mr Deasy said, turning his little savingsbox about in his hand.
 14501	These are handy things to have. See. This is for sovereigns. This is for
 14502	shillings. Sixpences, halfcrowns. And here crowns. See.
 14503	
 14504	He shot from it two crowns and two shillings.
 14505	
 14506	--Three twelve, he said. I think you'll find that's right.
 14507	
 14508	--Thank you, sir, Stephen said, gathering the money together with shy
 14509	haste and putting it all in a pocket of his trousers.
 14510	
 14511	--No thanks at all, Mr Deasy said. You have earned it.
 14512	
 14513	Stephen's hand, free again, went back to the hollow shells. Symbols too
 14514	of beauty and of power. A lump in my pocket: symbols soiled by greed and
 14515	misery.
 14516	
 14517	--Don't carry it like that, Mr Deasy said. You'll pull it out somewhere
 14518	and lose it. You just buy one of these machines. You'll find them very
 14519	handy.
 14520	
 14521	Answer something.
 14522	
 14523	--Mine would be often empty, Stephen said.
 14524	
 14525	The same room and hour, the same wisdom: and I the same. Three times
 14526	now. Three nooses round me here. Well? I can break them in this instant
 14527	if I will.
 14528	
 14529	--Because you don't save, Mr Deasy said, pointing his finger. You don't
 14530	know yet what money is. Money is power. When you have lived as long as I
 14531	have. I know, I know. If youth but knew. But what does Shakespeare say?
 14532	_Put but money in thy purse._
 14533	
 14534	--Iago, Stephen murmured.
 14535	
 14536	He lifted his gaze from the idle shells to the old man's stare.
 14537	
 14538	--He knew what money was, Mr Deasy said. He made money. A poet, yes, but
 14539	an Englishman too. Do you know what is the pride of the English? Do you
 14540	know what is the proudest word you will ever hear from an Englishman's
 14541	mouth?
 14542	
 14543	The seas' ruler. His seacold eyes looked on the empty bay: it seems
 14544	history is to blame: on me and on my words, unhating.
 14545	
 14546	--That on his empire, Stephen said, the sun never sets.
 14547	
 14548	--Ba! Mr Deasy cried. That's not English. A French Celt said that. He
 14549	tapped his savingsbox against his thumbnail.
 14550	
 14551	--I will tell you, he said solemnly, what is his proudest boast. _I paid
 14552	my way._
 14553	
 14554	Good man, good man.
 14555	
 14556	_--I paid my way. I never borrowed a shilling in my life._ Can you feel
 14557	that? _I owe nothing._ Can you?
 14558	
 14559	Mulligan, nine pounds, three pairs of socks, one pair brogues, ties.
 14560	Curran, ten guineas. McCann, one guinea. Fred Ryan, two shillings.
 14561	Temple, two lunches. Russell, one guinea, Cousins, ten shillings, Bob
 14562	Reynolds, half a guinea, Koehler, three guineas, Mrs MacKernan, five
 14563	weeks' board. The lump I have is useless.
 14564	
 14565	--For the moment, no, Stephen answered.
 14566	
 14567	Mr Deasy laughed with rich delight, putting back his savingsbox.
 14568	
 14569	--I knew you couldn't, he said joyously. But one day you must feel it.
 14570	We are a generous people but we must also be just.
 14571	
 14572	--I fear those big words, Stephen said, which make us so unhappy.
 14573	
 14574	Mr Deasy stared sternly for some moments over the mantelpiece at the
 14575	shapely bulk of a man in tartan filibegs: Albert Edward, prince of
 14576	Wales.
 14577	
 14578	--You think me an old fogey and an old tory, his thoughtful voice said.
 14579	I saw three generations since O'Connell's time. I remember the famine in
 14580	'46. Do you know that the orange lodges agitated for repeal of the
 14581	union twenty years before O'Connell did or before the prelates of your
 14582	communion denounced him as a demagogue? You fenians forget some things.
 14583	
 14584	Glorious, pious and immortal memory. The lodge of Diamond in Armagh the
 14585	splendid behung with corpses of papishes. Hoarse, masked and armed, the
 14586	planters' covenant. The black north and true blue bible. Croppies lie
 14587	down.
 14588	
 14589	Stephen sketched a brief gesture.
 14590	
 14591	--I have rebel blood in me too, Mr Deasy said. On the spindle side. But
 14592	I am descended from sir John Blackwood who voted for the union. We are
 14593	all Irish, all kings' sons.
 14594	
 14595	--Alas, Stephen said.
 14596	
 14597	--_Per vias rectas_, Mr Deasy said firmly, was his motto. He voted for
 14598	it and put on his topboots to ride to Dublin from the Ards of Down to do
 14599	so.
 14600	
 14601	     _Lal the ral the ra
 14602	     The rocky road to Dublin._
 14603	
 14604	
 14605	A gruff squire on horseback with shiny topboots. Soft day, sir John!
 14606	Soft day, your honour!... Day!... Day!... Two topboots jog dangling
 14607	on to Dublin. Lal the ral the ra. Lal the ral the raddy.
 14608	
 14609	--That reminds me, Mr Deasy said. You can do me a favour, Mr Dedalus,
 14610	with some of your literary friends. I have a letter here for the press.
 14611	Sit down a moment. I have just to copy the end.
 14612	
 14613	He went to the desk near the window, pulled in his chair twice and read
 14614	off some words from the sheet on the drum of his typewriter.
 14615	
 14616	--Sit down. Excuse me, he said over his shoulder, _the dictates of
 14617	common sense._ Just a moment.
 14618	
 14619	He peered from under his shaggy brows at the manuscript by his elbow
 14620	and, muttering, began to prod the stiff buttons of the keyboard slowly,
 14621	sometimes blowing as he screwed up the drum to erase an error.
 14622	
 14623	Stephen seated himself noiselessly before the princely presence. Framed
 14624	around the walls images of vanished horses stood in homage, their meek
 14625	heads poised in air: lord Hastings' Repulse, the duke of Westminster's
 14626	Shotover, the duke of Beaufort's Ceylon, _prix de Paris_, 1866. Elfin
 14627	riders sat them, watchful of a sign. He saw their speeds, backing king's
 14628	colours, and shouted with the shouts of vanished crowds.
 14629	
 14630	--Full stop, Mr Deasy bade his keys. But prompt ventilation of this
 14631	allimportant question...
 14632	
 14633	Where Cranly led me to get rich quick, hunting his winners among the
 14634	mudsplashed brakes, amid the bawls of bookies on their pitches and reek
 14635	of the canteen, over the motley slush. Fair Rebel! Fair Rebel! Even
 14636	money the favourite: ten to one the field. Dicers and thimbleriggers
 14637	we hurried by after the hoofs, the vying caps and jackets and past
 14638	the meatfaced woman, a butcher's dame, nuzzling thirstily her clove of
 14639	orange.
 14640	
 14641	Shouts rang shrill from the boys' playfield and a whirring whistle.
 14642	
 14643	Again: a goal. I am among them, among their battling bodies in a medley,
 14644	the joust of life. You mean that knockkneed mother's darling who seems
 14645	to be slightly crawsick? Jousts. Time shocked rebounds, shock by shock.
 14646	Jousts, slush and uproar of battles, the frozen deathspew of the slain,
 14647	a shout of spearspikes baited with men's bloodied guts.
 14648	
 14649	--Now then, Mr Deasy said, rising.
 14650	
 14651	He came to the table, pinning together his sheets. Stephen stood up.
 14652	
 14653	--I have put the matter into a nutshell, Mr Deasy said. It's about
 14654	the foot and mouth disease. Just look through it. There can be no two
 14655	opinions on the matter.
 14656	
 14657	May I trespass on your valuable space. That doctrine of _laissez faire_
 14658	which so often in our history. Our cattle trade. The way of all our old
 14659	industries. Liverpool ring which jockeyed the Galway harbour scheme.
 14660	European conflagration. Grain supplies through the narrow waters of
 14661	the channel. The pluterperfect imperturbability of the department of
 14662	agriculture. Pardoned a classical allusion. Cassandra. By a woman who
 14663	was no better than she should be. To come to the point at issue.
 14664	
 14665	--I don't mince words, do I? Mr Deasy asked as Stephen read on.
 14666	
 14667	Foot and mouth disease. Known as Koch's preparation. Serum and virus.
 14668	Percentage of salted horses. Rinderpest. Emperor's horses at Murzsteg,
 14669	lower Austria. Veterinary surgeons. Mr Henry Blackwood Price. Courteous
 14670	offer a fair trial. Dictates of common sense. Allimportant question. In
 14671	every sense of the word take the bull by the horns. Thanking you for the
 14672	hospitality of your columns.
 14673	
 14674	--I want that to be printed and read, Mr Deasy said. You will see at the
 14675	next outbreak they will put an embargo on Irish cattle. And it can
 14676	be cured. It is cured. My cousin, Blackwood Price, writes to me it is
 14677	regularly treated and cured in Austria by cattledoctors there. They
 14678	offer to come over here. I am trying to work up influence with
 14679	the department. Now I'm going to try publicity. I am surrounded by
 14680	difficulties, by... intrigues by... backstairs influence by...
 14681	
 14682	He raised his forefinger and beat the air oldly before his voice spoke.
 14683	
 14684	--Mark my words, Mr Dedalus, he said. England is in the hands of the
 14685	jews. In all the highest places: her finance, her press. And they are
 14686	the signs of a nation's decay. Wherever they gather they eat up the
 14687	nation's vital strength. I have seen it coming these years. As sure
 14688	as we are standing here the jew merchants are already at their work of
 14689	destruction. Old England is dying.
 14690	
 14691	He stepped swiftly off, his eyes coming to blue life as they passed a
 14692	broad sunbeam. He faced about and back again.
 14693	
 14694	--Dying, he said again, if not dead by now.
 14695	
 14696	     _The harlot's cry from street to street
 14697	     Shall weave old England's windingsheet._
 14698	
 14699	
 14700	His eyes open wide in vision stared sternly across the sunbeam in which
 14701	he halted.
 14702	
 14703	--A merchant, Stephen said, is one who buys cheap and sells dear, jew or
 14704	gentile, is he not?
 14705	
 14706	--They sinned against the light, Mr Deasy said gravely. And you can see
 14707	the darkness in their eyes. And that is why they are wanderers on the
 14708	earth to this day.
 14709	
 14710	On the steps of the Paris stock exchange the goldskinned men quoting
 14711	prices on their gemmed fingers. Gabble of geese. They swarmed loud,
 14712	uncouth about the temple, their heads thickplotting under maladroit silk
 14713	hats. Not theirs: these clothes, this speech, these gestures. Their full
 14714	slow eyes belied the words, the gestures eager and unoffending, but
 14715	knew the rancours massed about them and knew their zeal was vain. Vain
 14716	patience to heap and hoard. Time surely would scatter all. A hoard
 14717	heaped by the roadside: plundered and passing on. Their eyes knew their
 14718	years of wandering and, patient, knew the dishonours of their flesh.
 14719	
 14720	--Who has not? Stephen said.
 14721	
 14722	--What do you mean? Mr Deasy asked.
 14723	
 14724	He came forward a pace and stood by the table. His underjaw fell
 14725	sideways open uncertainly. Is this old wisdom? He waits to hear from me.
 14726	
 14727	--History, Stephen said, is a nightmare from which I am trying to awake.
 14728	
 14729	From the playfield the boys raised a shout. A whirring whistle: goal.
 14730	What if that nightmare gave you a back kick?
 14731	
 14732	--The ways of the Creator are not our ways, Mr Deasy said. All human
 14733	history moves towards one great goal, the manifestation of God.
 14734	
 14735	Stephen jerked his thumb towards the window, saying:
 14736	
 14737	--That is God.
 14738	
 14739	Hooray! Ay! Whrrwhee!
 14740	
 14741	--What? Mr Deasy asked.
 14742	
 14743	--A shout in the street, Stephen answered, shrugging his shoulders.
 14744	
 14745	Mr Deasy looked down and held for awhile the wings of his nose tweaked
 14746	between his fingers. Looking up again he set them free.
 14747	
 14748	--I am happier than you are, he said. We have committed many errors and
 14749	many sins. A woman brought sin into the world. For a woman who was no
 14750	better than she should be, Helen, the runaway wife of Menelaus, ten
 14751	years the Greeks made war on Troy. A faithless wife first brought the
 14752	strangers to our shore here, MacMurrough's wife and her leman, O'Rourke,
 14753	prince of Breffni. A woman too brought Parnell low. Many errors, many
 14754	failures but not the one sin. I am a struggler now at the end of my
 14755	days. But I will fight for the right till the end.
 14756	
 14757	     _For Ulster will fight
 14758	     And Ulster will be right._
 14759	
 14760	
 14761	Stephen raised the sheets in his hand.
 14762	
 14763	--Well, sir, he began...
 14764	
 14765	--I foresee, Mr Deasy said, that you will not remain here very long
 14766	at this work. You were not born to be a teacher, I think. Perhaps I am
 14767	wrong.
 14768	
 14769	--A learner rather, Stephen said.
 14770	
 14771	And here what will you learn more?
 14772	
 14773	Mr Deasy shook his head.
 14774	
 14775	--Who knows? he said. To learn one must be humble. But life is the great
 14776	teacher.
 14777	
 14778	Stephen rustled the sheets again.
 14779	
 14780	--As regards these, he began.
 14781	
 14782	--Yes, Mr Deasy said. You have two copies there. If you can have them
 14783	published at once.
 14784	
 14785	_ Telegraph. Irish Homestead._
 14786	
 14787	--I will try, Stephen said, and let you know tomorrow. I know two
 14788	editors slightly.
 14789	
 14790	--That will do, Mr Deasy said briskly. I wrote last night to Mr Field,
 14791	M.P. There is a meeting of the cattletraders' association today at the
 14792	City Arms hotel. I asked him to lay my letter before the meeting. You
 14793	see if you can get it into your two papers. What are they?
 14794	
 14795	_--The Evening Telegraph..._
 14796	
 14797	--That will do, Mr Deasy said. There is no time to lose. Now I have to
 14798	answer that letter from my cousin.
 14799	
 14800	--Good morning, sir, Stephen said, putting the sheets in his pocket.
 14801	Thank you.
 14802	
 14803	--Not at all, Mr Deasy said as he searched the papers on his desk. I
 14804	like to break a lance with you, old as I am.
 14805	
 14806	--Good morning, sir, Stephen said again, bowing to his bent back.
 14807	
 14808	He went out by the open porch and down the gravel path under the trees,
 14809	hearing the cries of voices and crack of sticks from the playfield.
 14810	The lions couchant on the pillars as he passed out through the gate:
 14811	toothless terrors. Still I will help him in his fight. Mulligan will dub
 14812	me a new name: the bullockbefriending bard.
 14813	
 14814	--Mr Dedalus!
 14815	
 14816	Running after me. No more letters, I hope.
 14817	
 14818	--Just one moment.
 14819	
 14820	--Yes, sir, Stephen said, turning back at the gate.
 14821	
 14822	Mr Deasy halted, breathing hard and swallowing his breath.
 14823	
 14824	--I just wanted to say, he said. Ireland, they say, has the honour of
 14825	being the only country which never persecuted the jews. Do you know
 14826	that? No. And do you know why?
 14827	
 14828	He frowned sternly on the bright air.
 14829	
 14830	--Why, sir? Stephen asked, beginning to smile.
 14831	
 14832	--Because she never let them in, Mr Deasy said solemnly.
 14833	
 14834	A coughball of laughter leaped from his throat dragging after it a
 14835	rattling chain of phlegm. He turned back quickly, coughing, laughing,
 14836	his lifted arms waving to the air.
 14837
