 16251	not doing a hand's turn all day. Sleep six months out of twelve. Too hot
 16252	to quarrel. Influence of the climate. Lethargy. Flowers of idleness. The
 16253	air feeds most. Azotes. Hothouse in Botanic gardens. Sensitive plants.
 16254	Waterlilies. Petals too tired to. Sleeping sickness in the air. Walk on
 16255	roseleaves. Imagine trying to eat tripe and cowheel. Where was the chap
 16256	I saw in that picture somewhere? Ah yes, in the dead sea floating on his
 16257	back, reading a book with a parasol open. Couldn't sink if you tried: so
 16258	thick with salt. Because the weight of the water, no, the weight of
 16259	the body in the water is equal to the weight of the what? Or is it the
 16260	volume is equal to the weight? It's a law something like that. Vance in
 16261	High school cracking his fingerjoints, teaching. The college curriculum.
 16262	Cracking curriculum. What is weight really when you say the weight?
 16263	Thirtytwo feet per second per second. Law of falling bodies: per second
 16264	per second. They all fall to the ground. The earth. It's the force of
 16265	gravity of the earth is the weight.
 16266	
 16267	He turned away and sauntered across the road. How did she walk with her
 16268	sausages? Like that something. As he walked he took the folded _Freeman_
 16269	from his sidepocket, unfolded it, rolled it lengthwise in a baton and
 16270	tapped it at each sauntering step against his trouserleg. Careless air:
 16271	just drop in to see. Per second per second. Per second for every second
 16272	it means. From the curbstone he darted a keen glance through the door of
 16273	the postoffice. Too late box. Post here. No-one. In.
 16274	
 16275	He handed the card through the brass grill.
 16276	
 16277	--Are there any letters for me? he asked.
 16278	
 16279	While the postmistress searched a pigeonhole he gazed at the recruiting
 16280	poster with soldiers of all arms on parade: and held the tip of his
 16281	baton against his nostrils, smelling freshprinted rag paper. No answer
 16282	probably. Went too far last time.
 16283	
 16284	The postmistress handed him back through the grill his card with a
 16285	letter. He thanked her and glanced rapidly at the typed envelope.
 16286	
 16287	Henry Flower Esq, c/o P. O. Westland Row, City.
 16288	
 16289	Answered anyhow. He slipped card and letter into his sidepocket,
 16290	reviewing again the soldiers on parade. Where's old Tweedy's regiment?
 16291	Castoff soldier. There: bearskin cap and hackle plume. No, he's a
 16292	grenadier. Pointed cuffs. There he is: royal Dublin fusiliers. Redcoats.
 16293	Too showy. That must be why the women go after them. Uniform. Easier to
 16294	enlist and drill. Maud Gonne's letter about taking them off O'Connell
 16295	street at night: disgrace to our Irish capital. Griffith's paper is on
 16296	the same tack now: an army rotten with venereal disease: overseas or
 16297	halfseasover empire. Half baked they look: hypnotised like. Eyes front.
 16298	Mark time. Table: able. Bed: ed. The King's own. Never see him dressed
 16299	up as a fireman or a bobby. A mason, yes.
 16300	
 16301	He strolled out of the postoffice and turned to the right. Talk: as if
 16302	that would mend matters. His hand went into his pocket and a forefinger
 16303	felt its way under the flap of the envelope, ripping it open in jerks.
 16304	Women will pay a lot of heed, I don't think. His fingers drew forth the
 16305	letter the letter and crumpled the envelope in his pocket. Something
 16306	pinned on: photo perhaps. Hair? No.
 16307	
 16308	M'Coy. Get rid of him quickly. Take me out of my way. Hate company when
 16309	you.
 16310	
 16311	--Hello, Bloom. Where are you off to?
 16312	
 16313	--Hello, M'Coy. Nowhere in particular.
 16314	
 16315	--How's the body?
 16316	
 16317	--Fine. How are you?
 16318	
 16319	--Just keeping alive, M'Coy said.
 16320	
 16321	His eyes on the black tie and clothes he asked with low respect:
 16322	
 16323	--Is there any... no trouble I hope? I see you're...
 16324	
 16325	--O, no, Mr Bloom said. Poor Dignam, you know. The funeral is today.
 16326	
 16327	--To be sure, poor fellow. So it is. What time?
 16328	
 16329	A photo it isn't. A badge maybe.
 16330	
 16331	--E... eleven, Mr Bloom answered.
 16332	
 16333	--I must try to get out there, M'Coy said. Eleven, is it? I only heard
 16334	it last night. Who was telling me? Holohan. You know Hoppy?
 16335	
 16336	--I know.
 16337	
 16338	Mr Bloom gazed across the road at the outsider drawn up before the door
 16339	of the Grosvenor. The porter hoisted the valise up on the well. She
 16340	stood still, waiting, while the man, husband, brother, like her,
 16341	searched his pockets for change. Stylish kind of coat with that roll
 16342	collar, warm for a day like this, looks like blanketcloth. Careless
 16343	stand of her with her hands in those patch pockets. Like that haughty
 16344	creature at the polo match. Women all for caste till you touch the spot.
 16345	Handsome is and handsome does. Reserved about to yield. The honourable
 16346	Mrs and Brutus is an honourable man. Possess her once take the starch
 16347	out of her.
 16348	
 16349	--I was with Bob Doran, he's on one of his periodical bends, and what do
 16350	you call him Bantam Lyons. Just down there in Conway's we were.
 16351	
 16352	Doran Lyons in Conway's. She raised a gloved hand to her hair. In came
 16353	Hoppy. Having a wet. Drawing back his head and gazing far from beneath
 16354	his vailed eyelids he saw the bright fawn skin shine in the glare, the
 16355	braided drums. Clearly I can see today. Moisture about gives long sight
 16356	perhaps. Talking of one thing or another. Lady's hand. Which side will
 16357	she get up?
 16358	
 16359	--And he said: _Sad thing about our poor friend Paddy! What Paddy?_ I
 16360	said. _Poor little Paddy Dignam_, he said.
 16361	
 16362	Off to the country: Broadstone probably. High brown boots with laces
 16363	dangling. Wellturned foot. What is he foostering over that change for?
 16364	Sees me looking. Eye out for other fellow always. Good fallback. Two
 16365	strings to her bow.
 16366	
 16367	--_Why?_ I said. _What's wrong with him?_ I said.
 16368	
 16369	Proud: rich: silk stockings.
 16370	
 16371	--Yes, Mr Bloom said.
 16372	
 16373	He moved a little to the side of M'Coy's talking head. Getting up in a
 16374	minute.
 16375	
 16376	--_What's wrong with him_? He said. _He's dead_, he said. And, faith,
 16377	he filled up. _Is it Paddy Dignam_? I said. I couldn't believe it when I
 16378	heard it. I was with him no later than Friday last or Thursday was it in
 16379	the Arch. _Yes,_ he said. _He's gone. He died on Monday, poor fellow_.
 16380	Watch! Watch! Silk flash rich stockings white. Watch!
 16381	
 16382	A heavy tramcar honking its gong slewed between.
 16383	
 16384	Lost it. Curse your noisy pugnose. Feels locked out of it. Paradise and
 16385	the peri. Always happening like that. The very moment. Girl in Eustace
 16386	street hallway Monday was it settling her garter. Her friend covering
 16387	the display of _esprit de corps_. Well, what are you gaping at?
 16388	
 16389	--Yes, yes, Mr Bloom said after a dull sigh. Another gone.
 16390	
 16391	--One of the best, M'Coy said.
 16392	
 16393	The tram passed. They drove off towards the Loop Line bridge, her rich
 16394	gloved hand on the steel grip. Flicker, flicker: the laceflare of her
 16395	hat in the sun: flicker, flick.
 16396	
 16397	--Wife well, I suppose? M'Coy's changed voice said.
 16398	
 16399	--O, yes, Mr Bloom said. Tiptop, thanks.
 16400	
 16401	He unrolled the newspaper baton idly and read idly:
 16402	
 16403	_What is home without Plumtree's Potted Meat? Incomplete With it an
 16404	abode of bliss._
 16405	
 16406	--My missus has just got an engagement. At least it's not settled yet.
 16407	
 16408	Valise tack again. By the way no harm. I'm off that, thanks.
 16409	
 16410	Mr Bloom turned his largelidded eyes with unhasty friendliness.
 16411	
 16412	--My wife too, he said. She's going to sing at a swagger affair in the
 16413	Ulster Hall, Belfast, on the twenty-fifth.
 16414	
 16415	--That so? M'Coy said. Glad to hear that, old man. Who's getting it up?
 16416	
 16417	Mrs Marion Bloom. Not up yet. Queen was in her bedroom eating bread and.
 16418	No book. Blackened court cards laid along her thigh by sevens. Dark lady
 16419	and fair man. Letter. Cat furry black ball. Torn strip of envelope.
 16420	
 16421	     _Love's
 16422	     Old
 16423	     Sweet
 16424	     Song
 16425	     Comes lo-ove's old..._
 16426	
 16427	--It's a kind of a tour, don't you see, Mr Bloom said thoughtfully.
 16428	_Sweeeet song_. There's a committee formed. Part shares and part
 16429	profits.
 16430	
 16431	M'Coy nodded, picking at his moustache stubble.
 16432	
 16433	--O, well, he said. That's good news.
 16434	
 16435	He moved to go.
 16436	
 16437	--Well, glad to see you looking fit, he said. Meet you knocking around.
 16438	
 16439	--Yes, Mr Bloom said.
 16440	
 16441	--Tell you what, M'Coy said. You might put down my name at the funeral,
 16442	will you? I'd like to go but I mightn't be able, you see. There's a
 16443	drowning case at Sandycove may turn up and then the coroner and myself
 16444	would have to go down if the body is found. You just shove in my name if
 16445	I'm not there, will you?
 16446	
 16447	--I'll do that, Mr Bloom said, moving to get off. That'll be all right.
 16448	
 16449	--Right, M'Coy said brightly. Thanks, old man. I'd go if I possibly
 16450	could. Well, tolloll. Just C. P. M'Coy will do.
 16451	
 16452	--That will be done, Mr Bloom answered firmly.
 16453	
 16454	Didn't catch me napping that wheeze. The quick touch. Soft mark. I'd
 16455	like my job. Valise I have a particular fancy for. Leather. Capped
 16456	corners, rivetted edges, double action lever lock. Bob Cowley lent him
 16457	his for the Wicklow regatta concert last year and never heard tidings of
 16458	it from that good day to this.
 16459	
 16460	Mr Bloom, strolling towards Brunswick street, smiled. My missus has just
 16461	got an. Reedy freckled soprano. Cheeseparing nose. Nice enough in its
 16462	way: for a little ballad. No guts in it. You and me, don't you know:
 16463	in the same boat. Softsoaping. Give you the needle that would. Can't
 16464	he hear the difference? Think he's that way inclined a bit. Against
 16465	my grain somehow. Thought that Belfast would fetch him. I hope that
 16466	smallpox up there doesn't get worse. Suppose she wouldn't let herself be
 16467	vaccinated again. Your wife and my wife.
 16468	
 16469	Wonder is he pimping after me?
 16470	
 16471	Mr Bloom stood at the corner, his eyes wandering over the multicoloured
 16472	hoardings. Cantrell and Cochrane's Ginger Ale (Aromatic). Clery's Summer
 16473	Sale. No, he's going on straight. Hello. _Leah_ tonight. Mrs Bandmann
 16474	Palmer. Like to see her again in that. _Hamlet_ she played last night.
 16475	Male impersonator. Perhaps he was a woman. Why Ophelia committed
 16476	suicide. Poor papa! How he used to talk of Kate Bateman in that. Outside
 16477	the Adelphi in London waited all the afternoon to get in. Year before
 16478	I was born that was: sixtyfive. And Ristori in Vienna. What is this the
 16479	right name is? By Mosenthal it is. Rachel, is it? No. The scene he was
 16480	always talking about where the old blind Abraham recognises the voice
 16481	and puts his fingers on his face.
 16482	
 16483	Nathan's voice! His son's voice! I hear the voice of Nathan who left his
 16484	father to die of grief and misery in my arms, who left the house of his
 16485	father and left the God of his father.
 16486	
 16487	Every word is so deep, Leopold.
 16488	
 16489	Poor papa! Poor man! I'm glad I didn't go into the room to look at his
 16490	face. That day! O, dear! O, dear! Ffoo! Well, perhaps it was best for
 16491	him.
 16492	
 16493	Mr Bloom went round the corner and passed the drooping nags of the
 16494	hazard. No use thinking of it any more. Nosebag time. Wish I hadn't met
 16495	that M'Coy fellow.
 16496	
 16497	He came nearer and heard a crunching of gilded oats, the gently champing
 16498	teeth. Their full buck eyes regarded him as he went by, amid the sweet
 16499	oaten reek of horsepiss. Their Eldorado. Poor jugginses! Damn all they
 16500	know or care about anything with their long noses stuck in nosebags.
 16501	Too full for words. Still they get their feed all right and their doss.
 16502	Gelded too: a stump of black guttapercha wagging limp between their
 16503	haunches. Might be happy all the same that way. Good poor brutes they
 16504	look. Still their neigh can be very irritating.
 16505	
 16506	He drew the letter from his pocket and folded it into the newspaper he
 16507	carried. Might just walk into her here. The lane is safer.
 16508	
 16509	He passed the cabman's shelter. Curious the life of drifting cabbies.
 16510	All weathers, all places, time or setdown, no will of their own. _Voglio
 16511	e non_. Like to give them an odd cigarette. Sociable. Shout a few flying
 16512	syllables as they pass. He hummed:
 16513	
 16514	     _La ci darem la mano
 16515	     La la lala la la._
 16516	
 16517	He turned into Cumberland street and, going on some paces, halted in the
 16518	lee of the station wall. No-one. Meade's timberyard. Piled balks. Ruins
 16519	and tenements. With careful tread he passed over a hopscotch court with
 16520	its forgotten pickeystone. Not a sinner. Near the timberyard a squatted
 16521	child at marbles, alone, shooting the taw with a cunnythumb. A wise
 16522	tabby, a blinking sphinx, watched from her warm sill. Pity to disturb
 16523	them. Mohammed cut a piece out of his mantle not to wake her. Open it.
 16524	And once I played marbles when I went to that old dame's school. She
 16525	liked mignonette. Mrs Ellis's. And Mr? He opened the letter within the
 16526	newspaper.
 16527	
 16528	A flower. I think it's a. A yellow flower with flattened petals. Not
 16529	annoyed then? What does she say?
 16530	
 16531	Dear Henry
 16532	
 16533	I got your last letter to me and thank you very much for it. I am sorry
 16534	you did not like my last letter. Why did you enclose the stamps? I am
 16535	awfully angry with you. I do wish I could punish you for that. I called
 16536	you naughty boy because I do not like that other world. Please tell me
 16537	what is the real meaning of that word? Are you not happy in your home
 16538	you poor little naughty boy? I do wish I could do something for you.
 16539	Please tell me what you think of poor me. I often think of the beautiful
 16540	name you have. Dear Henry, when will we meet? I think of you so often
 16541	you have no idea. I have never felt myself so much drawn to a man as
 16542	you. I feel so bad about. Please write me a long letter and tell me
 16543	more. Remember if you do not I will punish you. So now you know what I
 16544	will do to you, you naughty boy, if you do not wrote. O how I long to
 16545	meet you. Henry dear, do not deny my request before my patience are
 16546	exhausted. Then I will tell you all. Goodbye now, naughty darling, I
 16547	have such a bad headache. today. and write _by return_ to your longing
 16548	
 16549	Martha
 16550	
 16551	P. S. Do tell me what kind of perfume does your wife use. I want to
 16552	know.
 16553	
 16554	He tore the flower gravely from its pinhold smelt its almost no smell
 16555	and placed it in his heart pocket. Language of flowers. They like it
 16556	because no-one can hear. Or a poison bouquet to strike him down. Then
 16557	walking slowly forward he read the letter again, murmuring here and
 16558	there a word. Angry tulips with you darling manflower punish your cactus
 16559	if you don't please poor forgetmenot how I long violets to dear roses
 16560	when we soon anemone meet all naughty nightstalk wife Martha's perfume.
 16561	Having read it all he took it from the newspaper and put it back in his
 16562	sidepocket.
 16563	
 16564	Weak joy opened his lips. Changed since the first letter. Wonder did she
 16565	wrote it herself. Doing the indignant: a girl of good family like me,
 16566	respectable character. Could meet one Sunday after the rosary. Thank
 16567	you: not having any. Usual love scrimmage. Then running round corners.
 16568	Bad as a row with Molly. Cigar has a cooling effect. Narcotic. Go
 16569	further next time. Naughty boy: punish: afraid of words, of course.
 16570	Brutal, why not? Try it anyhow. A bit at a time.
 16571	
 16572	Fingering still the letter in his pocket he drew the pin out of it.
 16573	Common pin, eh? He threw it on the road. Out of her clothes somewhere:
 16574	pinned together. Queer the number of pins they always have. No roses
 16575	without thorns.
 16576	
 16577	Flat Dublin voices bawled in his head. Those two sluts that night in the
 16578	Coombe, linked together in the rain.
 16579	
 16580	     _O, Mary lost the pin of her drawers.
 16581	     She didn't know what to do
 16582	     To keep it up
 16583	     To keep it up._
 16584	
 16585	It? Them. Such a bad headache. Has her roses probably. Or sitting all
 16586	day typing. Eyefocus bad for stomach nerves. What perfume does your wife
 16587	use. Now could you make out a thing like that?
 16588	
 16589	     _To keep it up._
 16590	
 16591	Martha, Mary. I saw that picture somewhere I forget now old master or
 16592	faked for money. He is sitting in their house, talking. Mysterious. Also
 16593	the two sluts in the Coombe would listen.
 16594	
 16595	     _To keep it up._
 16596	
 16597	Nice kind of evening feeling. No more wandering about. Just loll there:
 16598	quiet dusk: let everything rip. Forget. Tell about places you have been,
 16599	strange customs. The other one, jar on her head, was getting the supper:
 16600	fruit, olives, lovely cool water out of a well, stonecold like the hole
 16601	in the wall at Ashtown. Must carry a paper goblet next time I go to the
 16602	trottingmatches. She listens with big dark soft eyes. Tell her: more and
 16603	more: all. Then a sigh: silence. Long long long rest.
 16604	
 16605	Going under the railway arch he took out the envelope, tore it swiftly
 16606	in shreds and scattered them towards the road. The shreds fluttered
 16607	away, sank in the dank air: a white flutter, then all sank.
 16608	
 16609	Henry Flower. You could tear up a cheque for a hundred pounds in the
 16610	same way. Simple bit of paper. Lord Iveagh once cashed a sevenfigure
 16611	cheque for a million in the bank of Ireland. Shows you the money to be
 16612	made out of porter. Still the other brother lord Ardilaun has to change
 16613	his shirt four times a day, they say. Skin breeds lice or vermin. A
 16614	million pounds, wait a moment. Twopence a pint, fourpence a quart,
 16615	eightpence a gallon of porter, no, one and fourpence a gallon of porter.
 16616	One and four into twenty: fifteen about. Yes, exactly. Fifteen millions
 16617	of barrels of porter.
 16618	
 16619	What am I saying barrels? Gallons. About a million barrels all the same.
 16620	
 16621	An incoming train clanked heavily above his head, coach after coach.
 16622	Barrels bumped in his head: dull porter slopped and churned inside.
 16623	The bungholes sprang open and a huge dull flood leaked out, flowing
 16624	together, winding through mudflats all over the level land, a lazy
 16625	pooling swirl of liquor bearing along wideleaved flowers of its froth.
 16626	
 16627	He had reached the open backdoor of All Hallows. Stepping into the porch
 16628	he doffed his hat, took the card from his pocket and tucked it again
 16629	behind the leather headband. Damn it. I might have tried to work M'Coy
 16630	for a pass to Mullingar.
 16631	
 16632	Same notice on the door. Sermon by the very reverend John Conmee S.J.
 16633	on saint Peter Claver S.J. and the African Mission. Prayers for the
 16634	conversion of Gladstone they had too when he was almost unconscious. The
 16635	protestants are the same. Convert Dr William J. Walsh D.D. to the true
 16636	religion. Save China's millions. Wonder how they explain it to the
 16637	heathen Chinee. Prefer an ounce of opium. Celestials. Rank heresy for
 16638	them. Buddha their god lying on his side in the museum. Taking it easy
 16639	with hand under his cheek. Josssticks burning. Not like Ecce Homo. Crown
 16640	of thorns and cross. Clever idea Saint Patrick the shamrock. Chopsticks?
 16641	Conmee: Martin Cunningham knows him: distinguishedlooking. Sorry I
 16642	didn't work him about getting Molly into the choir instead of that
 16643	Father Farley who looked a fool but wasn't. They're taught that. He's
 16644	not going out in bluey specs with the sweat rolling off him to baptise
 16645	blacks, is he? The glasses would take their fancy, flashing. Like to see
 16646	them sitting round in a ring with blub lips, entranced, listening. Still
 16647	life. Lap it up like milk, I suppose.
 16648	
 16649	The cold smell of sacred stone called him. He trod the worn steps,
 16650	pushed the swingdoor and entered softly by the rere.
 16651	
 16652	Something going on: some sodality. Pity so empty. Nice discreet place
 16653	to be next some girl. Who is my neighbour? Jammed by the hour to slow
 16654	music. That woman at midnight mass. Seventh heaven. Women knelt in the
 16655	benches with crimson halters round their necks, heads bowed. A batch
 16656	knelt at the altarrails. The priest went along by them, murmuring,
 16657	holding the thing in his hands. He stopped at each, took out a
 16658	communion, shook a drop or two (are they in water?) off it and put it
 16659	neatly into her mouth. Her hat and head sank. Then the next one. Her hat
 16660	sank at once. Then the next one: a small old woman. The priest bent down
 16661	to put it into her mouth, murmuring all the time. Latin. The next one.
 16662	Shut your eyes and open your mouth. What? _Corpus:_ body. Corpse. Good
 16663	idea the Latin. Stupefies them first. Hospice for the dying. They
 16664	don't seem to chew it: only swallow it down. Rum idea: eating bits of a
 16665	corpse. Why the cannibals cotton to it.
 16666	
 16667	He stood aside watching their blind masks pass down the aisle, one by
 16668	one, and seek their places. He approached a bench and seated himself in
 16669	its corner, nursing his hat and newspaper. These pots we have to wear.
 16670	We ought to have hats modelled on our heads. They were about him here
 16671	and there, with heads still bowed in their crimson halters, waiting for
 16672	it to melt in their stomachs. Something like those mazzoth: it's that
 16673	sort of bread: unleavened shewbread. Look at them. Now I bet it makes
 16674	them feel happy. Lollipop. It does. Yes, bread of angels it's called.
 16675	There's a big idea behind it, kind of kingdom of God is within you feel.
 16676	First communicants. Hokypoky penny a lump. Then feel all like one family
 16677	party, same in the theatre, all in the same swim. They do. I'm sure of
 16678	that. Not so lonely. In our confraternity. Then come out a bit spreeish.
 16679	Let off steam. Thing is if you really believe in it. Lourdes cure,
 16680	waters of oblivion, and the Knock apparition, statues bleeding. Old
 16681	fellow asleep near that confessionbox. Hence those snores. Blind faith.
 16682	Safe in the arms of kingdom come. Lulls all pain. Wake this time next
 16683	year.
 16684	
 16685	He saw the priest stow the communion cup away, well in, and kneel an
 16686	instant before it, showing a large grey bootsole from under the lace
 16687	affair he had on. Suppose he lost the pin of his. He wouldn't know what
 16688	to do to. Bald spot behind. Letters on his back: I.N.R.I? No: I.H.S.
 16689	Molly told me one time I asked her. I have sinned: or no: I have
 16690	suffered, it is. And the other one? Iron nails ran in.
 16691	
 16692	Meet one Sunday after the rosary. Do not deny my request. Turn up with
 16693	a veil and black bag. Dusk and the light behind her. She might be here
 16694	with a ribbon round her neck and do the other thing all the same on the
 16695	sly. Their character. That fellow that turned queen's evidence on the
 16696	invincibles he used to receive the, Carey was his name, the communion
 16697	every morning. This very church. Peter Carey, yes. No, Peter Claver I am
 16698	thinking of. Denis Carey. And just imagine that. Wife and six children
 16699	at home. And plotting that murder all the time. Those crawthumpers,
 16700	now that's a good name for them, there's always something shiftylooking
 16701	about them. They're not straight men of business either. O, no, she's
 16702	not here: the flower: no, no. By the way, did I tear up that envelope?
 16703	Yes: under the bridge.
 16704	
 16705	The priest was rinsing out the chalice: then he tossed off the dregs
 16706	smartly. Wine. Makes it more aristocratic than for example if he drank
 16707	what they are used to Guinness's porter or some temperance beverage
 16708	Wheatley's Dublin hop bitters or Cantrell and Cochrane's ginger ale
 16709	(aromatic). Doesn't give them any of it: shew wine: only the other.
 16710	Cold comfort. Pious fraud but quite right: otherwise they'd have one old
 16711	booser worse than another coming along, cadging for a drink. Queer the
 16712	whole atmosphere of the. Quite right. Perfectly right that is.
 16713	
 16714	Mr Bloom looked back towards the choir. Not going to be any music. Pity.
 16715	Who has the organ here I wonder? Old Glynn he knew how to make that
 16716	instrument talk, the _vibrato_: fifty pounds a year they say he had in
 16717	Gardiner street. Molly was in fine voice that day, the _Stabat Mater_
 16718	of Rossini. Father Bernard Vaughan's sermon first. Christ or Pilate?
 16719	Christ, but don't keep us all night over it. Music they wanted.
 16720	Footdrill stopped. Could hear a pin drop. I told her to pitch her voice
 16721	against that corner. I could feel the thrill in the air, the full, the
 16722	people looking up:
 16723	
 16724	_Quis est homo._
 16725	
 16726	Some of that old sacred music splendid. Mercadante: seven last words.
 16727	Mozart's twelfth mass: _Gloria_ in that. Those old popes keen on music,
 16728	on art and statues and pictures of all kinds. Palestrina for example
 16729	too. They had a gay old time while it lasted. Healthy too, chanting,
 16730	regular hours, then brew liqueurs. Benedictine. Green Chartreuse. Still,
 16731	having eunuchs in their choir that was coming it a bit thick. What kind
 16732	of voice is it? Must be curious to hear after their own strong basses.
 16733	Connoisseurs. Suppose they wouldn't feel anything after. Kind of a
 16734	placid. No worry. Fall into flesh, don't they? Gluttons, tall, long
 16735	legs. Who knows? Eunuch. One way out of it.
 16736	
 16737	He saw the priest bend down and kiss the altar and then face about and
 16738	bless all the people. All crossed themselves and stood up. Mr Bloom
 16739	glanced about him and then stood up, looking over the risen hats. Stand
 16740	up at the gospel of course. Then all settled down on their knees again
 16741	and he sat back quietly in his bench. The priest came down from the
 16742	altar, holding the thing out from him, and he and the massboy answered
 16743	each other in Latin. Then the priest knelt down and began to read off a
 16744	card:
 16745	
 16746	--O God, our refuge and our strength...
 16747	
 16748	Mr Bloom put his face forward to catch the words. English. Throw them
 16749	the bone. I remember slightly. How long since your last mass? Glorious
 16750	and immaculate virgin. Joseph, her spouse. Peter and Paul. More
 16751	interesting if you understood what it was all about. Wonderful
 16752	organisation certainly, goes like clockwork. Confession. Everyone wants
 16753	to. Then I will tell you all. Penance. Punish me, please. Great weapon
 16754	in their hands. More than doctor or solicitor. Woman dying to. And I
 16755	schschschschschsch. And did you chachachachacha? And why did you? Look
 16756	down at her ring to find an excuse. Whispering gallery walls have ears.
 16757	Husband learn to his surprise. God's little joke. Then out she comes.
 16758	Repentance skindeep. Lovely shame. Pray at an altar. Hail Mary and Holy
 16759	Mary. Flowers, incense, candles melting. Hide her blushes. Salvation
 16760	army blatant imitation. Reformed prostitute will address the meeting.
 16761	How I found the Lord. Squareheaded chaps those must be in Rome: they
 16762	work the whole show. And don't they rake in the money too? Bequests
 16763	also: to the P.P. for the time being in his absolute discretion.
 16764	Masses for the repose of my soul to be said publicly with open doors.
 16765	Monasteries and convents. The priest in that Fermanagh will case in the
 16766	witnessbox. No browbeating him. He had his answer pat for everything.
 16767	Liberty and exaltation of our holy mother the church. The doctors of the
 16768	church: they mapped out the whole theology of it.
 16769	
 16770	The priest prayed:
 16771	
 16772	--Blessed Michael, archangel, defend us in the hour of conflict. Be
 16773	our safeguard against the wickedness and snares of the devil (may God
 16774	restrain him, we humbly pray!): and do thou, O prince of the heavenly
 16775	host, by the power of God thrust Satan down to hell and with him those
 16776	other wicked spirits who wander through the world for the ruin of souls.
 16777	
 16778	The priest and the massboy stood up and walked off. All over. The women
 16779	remained behind: thanksgiving.
 16780	
 16781	Better be shoving along. Brother Buzz. Come around with the plate
 16782	perhaps. Pay your Easter duty.
 16783	
 16784	He stood up. Hello. Were those two buttons of my waistcoat open all the
 16785	time? Women enjoy it. Never tell you. But we. Excuse, miss, there's a
 16786	(whh!) just a (whh!) fluff. Or their skirt behind, placket unhooked.
 16787	Glimpses of the moon. Annoyed if you don't. Why didn't you tell me
 16788	before. Still like you better untidy. Good job it wasn't farther south.
 16789	He passed, discreetly buttoning, down the aisle and out through the main
 16790	door into the light. He stood a moment unseeing by the cold black marble
 16791	bowl while before him and behind two worshippers dipped furtive hands in
 16792	the low tide of holy water. Trams: a car of Prescott's dyeworks: a widow
 16793	in her weeds. Notice because I'm in mourning myself. He covered himself.
 16794	How goes the time? Quarter past. Time enough yet. Better get that lotion
 16795	made up. Where is this? Ah yes, the last time. Sweny's in Lincoln place.
 16796	Chemists rarely move. Their green and gold beaconjars too heavy to stir.
 16797	Hamilton Long's, founded in the year of the flood. Huguenot churchyard
 16798	near there. Visit some day.
 16799	
 16800	He walked southward along Westland row. But the recipe is in the other
 16801	trousers. O, and I forgot that latchkey too. Bore this funeral affair.
 16802	O well, poor fellow, it's not his fault. When was it I got it made up
 16803	last? Wait. I changed a sovereign I remember. First of the month it must
 16804	have been or the second. O, he can look it up in the prescriptions book.
 16805	
 16806	The chemist turned back page after page. Sandy shrivelled smell he seems
 16807	to have. Shrunken skull. And old. Quest for the philosopher's stone. The
 16808	alchemists. Drugs age you after mental excitement. Lethargy then. Why?
 16809	Reaction. A lifetime in a night. Gradually changes your character.
 16810	Living all the day among herbs, ointments, disinfectants. All his
 16811	alabaster lilypots. Mortar and pestle. Aq. Dist. Fol. Laur. Te Virid.
 16812	Smell almost cure you like the dentist's doorbell. Doctor Whack. He
 16813	ought to physic himself a bit. Electuary or emulsion. The first fellow
 16814	that picked an herb to cure himself had a bit of pluck. Simples. Want to
 16815	be careful. Enough stuff here to chloroform you. Test: turns blue
 16816	litmus paper red. Chloroform. Overdose of laudanum. Sleeping draughts.
 16817	Lovephiltres. Paragoric poppysyrup bad for cough. Clogs the pores or the
 16818	phlegm. Poisons the only cures. Remedy where you least expect it. Clever
 16819	of nature.
 16820	
 16821	--About a fortnight ago, sir?
 16822	
 16823	--Yes, Mr Bloom said.
 16824	
 16825	He waited by the counter, inhaling slowly the keen reek of drugs, the
 16826	dusty dry smell of sponges and loofahs. Lot of time taken up telling
 16827	your aches and pains.
 16828	
 16829	--Sweet almond oil and tincture of benzoin, Mr Bloom said, and then
 16830	orangeflower water...
 16831	
 16832	It certainly did make her skin so delicate white like wax.
 16833	
 16834	--And white wax also, he said.
 16835	
 16836	Brings out the darkness of her eyes. Looking at me, the sheet up to
 16837	her eyes, Spanish, smelling herself, when I was fixing the links in my
 16838	cuffs. Those homely recipes are often the best: strawberries for the
 16839	teeth: nettles and rainwater: oatmeal they say steeped in buttermilk.
 16840	Skinfood. One of the old queen's sons, duke of Albany was it? had only
 16841	one skin. Leopold, yes. Three we have. Warts, bunions and pimples to
 16842	make it worse. But you want a perfume too. What perfume does your? _Peau
 16843	d'Espagne_. That orangeflower water is so fresh. Nice smell these soaps
 16844	have. Pure curd soap. Time to get a bath round the corner. Hammam.
 16845	Turkish. Massage. Dirt gets rolled up in your navel. Nicer if a nice
 16846	girl did it. Also I think I. Yes I. Do it in the bath. Curious longing
 16847	I. Water to water. Combine business with pleasure. Pity no time for
 16848	massage. Feel fresh then all the day. Funeral be rather glum.
 16849	
 16850	--Yes, sir, the chemist said. That was two and nine. Have you brought a
 16851	bottle?
 16852	
 16853	--No, Mr Bloom said. Make it up, please. I'll call later in the day and
 16854	I'll take one of these soaps. How much are they?
 16855	
 16856	--Fourpence, sir.
 16857	
 16858	Mr Bloom raised a cake to his nostrils. Sweet lemony wax.
 16859	
 16860	--I'll take this one, he said. That makes three and a penny.
 16861	
 16862	--Yes, sir, the chemist said. You can pay all together, sir, when you
 16863	come back.
 16864	
 16865	--Good, Mr Bloom said.
 16866	
 16867	He strolled out of the shop, the newspaper baton under his armpit, the
 16868	coolwrappered soap in his left hand.
 16869	
 16870	At his armpit Bantam Lyons' voice and hand said:
 16871	
 16872	--Hello, Bloom. What's the best news? Is that today's? Show us a minute.
 16873	
 16874	Shaved off his moustache again, by Jove! Long cold upper lip. To look
 16875	younger. He does look balmy. Younger than I am.
 16876	
 16877	Bantam Lyons's yellow blacknailed fingers unrolled the baton. Wants a
 16878	wash too. Take off the rough dirt. Good morning, have you used Pears'
 16879	soap? Dandruff on his shoulders. Scalp wants oiling.
 16880	
 16881	--I want to see about that French horse that's running today, Bantam
 16882	Lyons said. Where the bugger is it?
 16883	
 16884	He rustled the pleated pages, jerking his chin on his high collar.
 16885	Barber's itch. Tight collar he'll lose his hair. Better leave him the
 16886	paper and get shut of him.
 16887	
 16888	--You can keep it, Mr Bloom said.
 16889	
 16890	--Ascot. Gold cup. Wait, Bantam Lyons muttered. Half a mo. Maximum the
 16891	second.
 16892	
 16893	--I was just going to throw it away, Mr Bloom said.
 16894	
 16895	Bantam Lyons raised his eyes suddenly and leered weakly.
 16896	
 16897	--What's that? his sharp voice said.
 16898	
 16899	--I say you can keep it, Mr Bloom answered. I was going to throw it away
 16900	that moment.
 16901	
 16902	Bantam Lyons doubted an instant, leering: then thrust the outspread
 16903	sheets back on Mr Bloom's arms.
 16904	
 16905	--I'll risk it, he said. Here, thanks.
 16906	
 16907	He sped off towards Conway's corner. God speed scut.
 16908	
 16909	Mr Bloom folded the sheets again to a neat square and lodged the soap
 16910	in it, smiling. Silly lips of that chap. Betting. Regular hotbed of it
 16911	lately. Messenger boys stealing to put on sixpence. Raffle for large
 16912	tender turkey. Your Christmas dinner for threepence. Jack Fleming
 16913	embezzling to gamble then smuggled off to America. Keeps a hotel now.
 16914	They never come back. Fleshpots of Egypt.
 16915	
 16916	He walked cheerfully towards the mosque of the baths. Remind you of a
 16917	mosque, redbaked bricks, the minarets. College sports today I see. He
 16918	eyed the horseshoe poster over the gate of college park: cyclist doubled
 16919	up like a cod in a pot. Damn bad ad. Now if they had made it round
 16920	like a wheel. Then the spokes: sports, sports, sports: and the hub big:
 16921	college. Something to catch the eye.
 16922	
 16923	There's Hornblower standing at the porter's lodge. Keep him on hands:
 16924	might take a turn in there on the nod. How do you do, Mr Hornblower? How
 16925	do you do, sir?
 16926	
 16927	Heavenly weather really. If life was always like that. Cricket weather.
 16928	Sit around under sunshades. Over after over. Out. They can't play it
 16929	here. Duck for six wickets. Still Captain Culler broke a window in the
 16930	Kildare street club with a slog to square leg. Donnybrook fair more
 16931	in their line. And the skulls we were acracking when M'Carthy took the
 16932	floor. Heatwave. Won't last. Always passing, the stream of life, which
 16933	in the stream of life we trace is dearer than them all.
 16934	
 16935	Enjoy a bath now: clean trough of water, cool enamel, the gentle tepid
 16936	stream. This is my body.
 16937	
 16938	He foresaw his pale body reclined in it at full, naked, in a womb of
 16939	warmth, oiled by scented melting soap, softly laved. He saw his
 16940	trunk and limbs riprippled over and sustained, buoyed lightly upward,
 16941	lemonyellow: his navel, bud of flesh: and saw the dark tangled curls of
 16942	his bush floating, floating hair of the stream around the limp father of
 16943	thousands, a languid floating flower.
 16944	
 16945	
 16946	
 16947	Martin Cunningham, first, poked his silkhatted head into the creaking
 16948	carriage and, entering deftly, seated himself. Mr Power stepped in after
 16949	him, curving his height with care.
 16950	
 16951	--Come on, Simon.
 16952	
 16953	--After you, Mr Bloom said.
 16954	
 16955	Mr Dedalus covered himself quickly and got in, saying:
 16956	
 16957	Yes, yes.
 16958	
 16959	--Are we all here now? Martin Cunningham asked. Come along, Bloom.
 16960	
 16961	Mr Bloom entered and sat in the vacant place. He pulled the door to
 16962	after him and slammed it twice till it shut tight. He passed an arm
 16963	through the armstrap and looked seriously from the open carriagewindow
 16964	at the lowered blinds of the avenue. One dragged aside: an old woman
 16965	peeping. Nose whiteflattened against the pane. Thanking her stars she
 16966	was passed over. Extraordinary the interest they take in a corpse. Glad
 16967	to see us go we give them such trouble coming. Job seems to suit them.
 16968	Huggermugger in corners. Slop about in slipperslappers for fear he'd
 16969	wake. Then getting it ready. Laying it out. Molly and Mrs Fleming making
 16970	the bed. Pull it more to your side. Our windingsheet. Never know who
 16971	will touch you dead. Wash and shampoo. I believe they clip the nails and
 16972	the hair. Keep a bit in an envelope. Grows all the same after. Unclean
 16973	job.
 16974	
 16975	All waited. Nothing was said. Stowing in the wreaths probably. I am
 16976	sitting on something hard. Ah, that soap: in my hip pocket. Better shift
 16977	it out of that. Wait for an opportunity.
 16978	
 16979	All waited. Then wheels were heard from in front, turning: then nearer:
 16980	then horses' hoofs. A jolt. Their carriage began to move, creaking and
 16981	swaying. Other hoofs and creaking wheels started behind. The blinds of
 16982	the avenue passed and number nine with its craped knocker, door ajar. At
 16983	walking pace.
 16984	
 16985	They waited still, their knees jogging, till they had turned and were
 16986	passing along the tramtracks. Tritonville road. Quicker. The wheels
 16987	rattled rolling over the cobbled causeway and the crazy glasses shook
 16988	rattling in the doorframes.
 16989	
 16990	--What way is he taking us? Mr Power asked through both windows.
 16991	
 16992	--Irishtown, Martin Cunningham said. Ringsend. Brunswick street.
 16993	
 16994	Mr Dedalus nodded, looking out.
 16995	
 16996	--That's a fine old custom, he said. I am glad to see it has not died
 16997	out.
 16998	
 16999	All watched awhile through their windows caps and hats lifted by
 17000	passers. Respect. The carriage swerved from the tramtrack to the
 17001	smoother road past Watery lane. Mr Bloom at gaze saw a lithe young man,
 17002	clad in mourning, a wide hat.
 17003	
 17004	--There's a friend of yours gone by, Dedalus, he said.
 17005	
 17006	--Who is that?
 17007	
 17008	--Your son and heir.
 17009	
 17010	--Where is he? Mr Dedalus said, stretching over across.
 17011	
 17012	The carriage, passing the open drains and mounds of rippedup roadway
 17013	before the tenement houses, lurched round the corner and, swerving back
 17014	to the tramtrack, rolled on noisily with chattering wheels. Mr Dedalus
 17015	fell back, saying:
 17016	
 17017	--Was that Mulligan cad with him? His _fidus Achates_!
 17018	
 17019	--No, Mr Bloom said. He was alone.
 17020	
 17021	--Down with his aunt Sally, I suppose, Mr Dedalus said, the Goulding
 17022	faction, the drunken little costdrawer and Crissie, papa's little lump
 17023	of dung, the wise child that knows her own father.
 17024	
 17025	Mr Bloom smiled joylessly on Ringsend road. Wallace Bros: the
 17026	bottleworks: Dodder bridge.
 17027	
 17028	Richie Goulding and the legal bag. Goulding, Collis and Ward he calls
 17029	the firm. His jokes are getting a bit damp. Great card he was. Waltzing
 17030	in Stamer street with Ignatius Gallaher on a Sunday morning, the
 17031	landlady's two hats pinned on his head. Out on the rampage all night.
 17032	Beginning to tell on him now: that backache of his, I fear. Wife ironing
 17033	his back. Thinks he'll cure it with pills. All breadcrumbs they are.
 17034	About six hundred per cent profit.
 17035	
 17036	--He's in with a lowdown crowd, Mr Dedalus snarled. That Mulligan is a
 17037	contaminated bloody doubledyed ruffian by all accounts. His name stinks
 17038	all over Dublin. But with the help of God and His blessed mother I'll
 17039	make it my business to write a letter one of those days to his mother
 17040	or his aunt or whatever she is that will open her eye as wide as a gate.
 17041	I'll tickle his catastrophe, believe you me.
 17042	
 17043	He cried above the clatter of the wheels:
 17044	
 17045	--I won't have her bastard of a nephew ruin my son. A counterjumper's
 17046	son. Selling tapes in my cousin, Peter Paul M'Swiney's. Not likely.
 17047	
 17048	He ceased. Mr Bloom glanced from his angry moustache to Mr Power's mild
 17049	face and Martin Cunningham's eyes and beard, gravely shaking. Noisy
 17050	selfwilled man. Full of his son. He is right. Something to hand on. If
 17051	little Rudy had lived. See him grow up. Hear his voice in the house.
 17052	Walking beside Molly in an Eton suit. My son. Me in his eyes. Strange
 17053	feeling it would be. From me. Just a chance. Must have been that morning
 17054	in Raymond terrace she was at the window watching the two dogs at it by
 17055	the wall of the cease to do evil. And the sergeant grinning up. She had
 17056	that cream gown on with the rip she never stitched. Give us a touch,
 17057	Poldy. God, I'm dying for it. How life begins.
 17058	
 17059	Got big then. Had to refuse the Greystones concert. My son inside her.
 17060	I could have helped him on in life. I could. Make him independent. Learn
 17061	German too.
 17062	
 17063	--Are we late? Mr Power asked.
 17064	
 17065	--Ten minutes, Martin Cunningham said, looking at his watch.
 17066	
 17067	Molly. Milly. Same thing watered down. Her tomboy oaths. O jumping
 17068	Jupiter! Ye gods and little fishes! Still, she's a dear girl. Soon be a
 17069	woman. Mullingar. Dearest Papli. Young student. Yes, yes: a woman too.
 17070	Life, life.
 17071	
 17072	The carriage heeled over and back, their four trunks swaying.
 17073	
 17074	--Corny might have given us a more commodious yoke, Mr Power said.
 17075	
 17076	--He might, Mr Dedalus said, if he hadn't that squint troubling him. Do
 17077	you follow me?
 17078	
 17079	He closed his left eye. Martin Cunningham began to brush away
 17080	crustcrumbs from under his thighs.
 17081	
 17082	--What is this, he said, in the name of God? Crumbs?
 17083	
 17084	--Someone seems to have been making a picnic party here lately, Mr Power
 17085	said.
 17086	
 17087	All raised their thighs and eyed with disfavour the mildewed buttonless
 17088	leather of the seats. Mr Dedalus, twisting his nose, frowned downward
 17089	and said:
 17090	
 17091	--Unless I'm greatly mistaken. What do you think, Martin?
 17092	
 17093	--It struck me too, Martin Cunningham said.
 17094	
 17095	Mr Bloom set his thigh down. Glad I took that bath. Feel my feet quite
 17096	clean. But I wish Mrs Fleming had darned these socks better.
 17097	
 17098	Mr Dedalus sighed resignedly.
 17099	
 17100	--After all, he said, it's the most natural thing in the world.
 17101	
 17102	--Did Tom Kernan turn up? Martin Cunningham asked, twirling the peak of
 17103	his beard gently.
 17104	
 17105	--Yes, Mr Bloom answered. He's behind with Ned Lambert and Hynes.
 17106	
 17107	--And Corny Kelleher himself? Mr Power asked.
 17108	
 17109	--At the cemetery, Martin Cunningham said.
 17110	
 17111	--I met M'Coy this morning, Mr Bloom said. He said he'd try to come.
 17112	
 17113	The carriage halted short.
 17114	
 17115	--What's wrong?
 17116	
 17117	--We're stopped.
 17118	
 17119	--Where are we?
 17120	
 17121	Mr Bloom put his head out of the window.
 17122	
 17123	--The grand canal, he said.
 17124	
 17125	Gasworks. Whooping cough they say it cures. Good job Milly never got
 17126	it. Poor children! Doubles them up black and blue in convulsions. Shame
 17127	really. Got off lightly with illnesses compared. Only measles. Flaxseed
 17128	tea. Scarlatina, influenza epidemics. Canvassing for death. Don't miss
 17129	this chance. Dogs' home over there. Poor old Athos! Be good to Athos,
 17130	Leopold, is my last wish. Thy will be done. We obey them in the grave.
 17131	A dying scrawl. He took it to heart, pined away. Quiet brute. Old men's
 17132	dogs usually are.
 17133	
 17134	A raindrop spat on his hat. He drew back and saw an instant of shower
 17135	spray dots over the grey flags. Apart. Curious. Like through a colander.
 17136	I thought it would. My boots were creaking I remember now.
 17137	
 17138	--The weather is changing, he said quietly.
 17139	
 17140	--A pity it did not keep up fine, Martin Cunningham said.
 17141	
 17142	--Wanted for the country, Mr Power said. There's the sun again coming
 17143	out.
 17144	
 17145	Mr Dedalus, peering through his glasses towards the veiled sun, hurled a
 17146	mute curse at the sky.
 17147	
 17148	--It's as uncertain as a child's bottom, he said.
 17149	
 17150	--We're off again.
 17151	
 17152	The carriage turned again its stiff wheels and their trunks swayed
 17153	gently. Martin Cunningham twirled more quickly the peak of his beard.
 17154	
 17155	--Tom Kernan was immense last night, he said. And Paddy Leonard taking
 17156	him off to his face.
 17157	
 17158	--O, draw him out, Martin, Mr Power said eagerly. Wait till you hear
 17159	him, Simon, on Ben Dollard's singing of _The Croppy Boy_.
 17160	
 17161	--Immense, Martin Cunningham said pompously. _His singing of that simple
 17162	ballad, Martin, is the most trenchant rendering I ever heard in the
 17163	whole course of my experience._
 17164	
 17165	--Trenchant, Mr Power said laughing. He's dead nuts on that. And the
 17166	retrospective arrangement.
 17167	
 17168	--Did you read Dan Dawson's speech? Martin Cunningham asked.
 17169	
 17170	--I did not then, Mr Dedalus said. Where is it?
 17171	
 17172	--In the paper this morning.
 17173	
 17174	Mr Bloom took the paper from his inside pocket. That book I must change
 17175	for her.
 17176	
 17177	--No, no, Mr Dedalus said quickly. Later on please.
 17178	
 17179	Mr Bloom's glance travelled down the edge of the paper, scanning the
 17180	deaths: Callan, Coleman, Dignam, Fawcett, Lowry, Naumann, Peake, what
 17181	Peake is that? is it the chap was in Crosbie and Alleyne's? no, Sexton,
 17182	Urbright. Inked characters fast fading on the frayed breaking paper.
 17183	Thanks to the Little Flower. Sadly missed. To the inexpressible grief of
 17184	his. Aged 88 after a long and tedious illness. Month's mind: Quinlan. On
 17185	whose soul Sweet Jesus have mercy.
 17186	
 17187	_It is now a month since dear Henry fled To his home up above in the sky
 17188	While his family weeps and mourns his loss Hoping some day to meet him
 17189	on high._
 17190	
 17191	I tore up the envelope? Yes. Where did I put her letter after I read it
 17192	in the bath? He patted his waistcoatpocket. There all right. Dear Henry
 17193	fled. Before my patience are exhausted.
 17194	
 17195	National school. Meade's yard. The hazard. Only two there now. Nodding.
 17196	Full as a tick. Too much bone in their skulls. The other trotting round
 17197	with a fare. An hour ago I was passing there. The jarvies raised their
 17198	hats.
 17199	
 17200	A pointsman's back straightened itself upright suddenly against a
 17201	tramway standard by Mr Bloom's window. Couldn't they invent something
 17202	automatic so that the wheel itself much handier? Well but that fellow
 17203	would lose his job then? Well but then another fellow would get a job
 17204	making the new invention?
 17205	
 17206	Antient concert rooms. Nothing on there. A man in a buff suit with a
 17207	crape armlet. Not much grief there. Quarter mourning. People in law
 17208	perhaps.
 17209	
 17210	They went past the bleak pulpit of saint Mark's, under the railway
 17211	bridge, past the Queen's theatre: in silence. Hoardings: Eugene
 17212	Stratton, Mrs Bandmann Palmer. Could I go to see LEAH tonight, I wonder.
 17213	I said I. Or the _Lily of Killarney_? Elster Grimes Opera Company. Big
 17214	powerful change. Wet bright bills for next week. _Fun on the Bristol_.
 17215	Martin Cunningham could work a pass for the Gaiety. Have to stand a
 17216	drink or two. As broad as it's long.
 17217	
 17218	He's coming in the afternoon. Her songs.
 17219	
 17220	Plasto's. Sir Philip Crampton's memorial fountain bust. Who was he?
 17221	
 17222	--How do you do? Martin Cunningham said, raising his palm to his brow in
 17223	salute.
 17224	
 17225	--He doesn't see us, Mr Power said. Yes, he does. How do you do?
 17226	
 17227	--Who? Mr Dedalus asked.
 17228	
 17229	--Blazes Boylan, Mr Power said. There he is airing his quiff.
 17230	
 17231	Just that moment I was thinking.
 17232	
 17233	Mr Dedalus bent across to salute. From the door of the Red Bank the
 17234	white disc of a straw hat flashed reply: spruce figure: passed.
 17235	
 17236	Mr Bloom reviewed the nails of his left hand, then those of his right
 17237	hand. The nails, yes. Is there anything more in him that they she sees?
 17238	Fascination. Worst man in Dublin. That keeps him alive. They sometimes
 17239	feel what a person is. Instinct. But a type like that. My nails. I
 17240	am just looking at them: well pared. And after: thinking alone. Body
 17241	getting a bit softy. I would notice that: from remembering. What causes
 17242	that? I suppose the skin can't contract quickly enough when the flesh
 17243	falls off. But the shape is there. The shape is there still. Shoulders.
 17244	Hips. Plump. Night of the dance dressing. Shift stuck between the cheeks
 17245	behind.
 17246	
 17247	He clasped his hands between his knees and, satisfied, sent his vacant
 17248	glance over their faces.
 17249	
 17250	Mr Power asked:
 17251	
 17252	--How is the concert tour getting on, Bloom?
 17253	
 17254	--O, very well, Mr Bloom said. I hear great accounts of it. It's a good
 17255	idea, you see...
 17256	
 17257	--Are you going yourself?
 17258	
 17259	--Well no, Mr Bloom said. In point of fact I have to go down to the
 17260	county Clare on some private business. You see the idea is to tour the
 17261	chief towns. What you lose on one you can make up on the other.
 17262	
 17263	--Quite so, Martin Cunningham said. Mary Anderson is up there now.
 17264	
 17265	Have you good artists?
 17266	
 17267	--Louis Werner is touring her, Mr Bloom said. O yes, we'll have all
 17268	topnobbers. J. C. Doyle and John MacCormack I hope and. The best, in
 17269	fact.
 17270	
 17271	--And _Madame_, Mr Power said smiling. Last but not least.
 17272	
 17273	Mr Bloom unclasped his hands in a gesture of soft politeness and clasped
 17274	them. Smith O'Brien. Someone has laid a bunch of flowers there. Woman.
 17275	Must be his deathday. For many happy returns. The carriage wheeling by
 17276	Farrell's statue united noiselessly their unresisting knees.
 17277	
 17278	Oot: a dullgarbed old man from the curbstone tendered his wares, his
 17279	mouth opening: oot.
 17280	
 17281	--Four bootlaces for a penny.
 17282	
 17283	Wonder why he was struck off the rolls. Had his office in Hume street.
 17284	Same house as Molly's namesake, Tweedy, crown solicitor for Waterford.
 17285	Has that silk hat ever since. Relics of old decency. Mourning too.
 17286	Terrible comedown, poor wretch! Kicked about like snuff at a wake.
 17287	O'Callaghan on his last legs.
 17288	
 17289	And _Madame_. Twenty past eleven. Up. Mrs Fleming is in to clean. Doing
 17290	her hair, humming. _voglio e non vorrei_. No. _vorrei e non_. Looking at
 17291	the tips of her hairs to see if they are split. _Mi trema un poco
 17292	il_. Beautiful on that _tre_ her voice is: weeping tone. A thrush. A
 17293	throstle. There is a word throstle that expresses that.
 17294	
 17295	His eyes passed lightly over Mr Power's goodlooking face. Greyish over
 17296	the ears. _Madame_: smiling. I smiled back. A smile goes a long way.
 17297	Only politeness perhaps. Nice fellow. Who knows is that true about the
 17298	woman he keeps? Not pleasant for the wife. Yet they say, who was it
 17299	told me, there is no carnal. You would imagine that would get played
 17300	out pretty quick. Yes, it was Crofton met him one evening bringing her
 17301	a pound of rumpsteak. What is this she was? Barmaid in Jury's. Or the
 17302	Moira, was it?
 17303	
 17304	They passed under the hugecloaked Liberator's form.
 17305	
 17306	Martin Cunningham nudged Mr Power.
 17307	
 17308	--Of the tribe of Reuben, he said.
 17309	
 17310	A tall blackbearded figure, bent on a stick, stumping round the corner
 17311	of Elvery's Elephant house, showed them a curved hand open on his spine.
 17312	
 17313	--In all his pristine beauty, Mr Power said.
 17314	
 17315	Mr Dedalus looked after the stumping figure and said mildly:
 17316	
 17317	--The devil break the hasp of your back!
 17318	
 17319	Mr Power, collapsing in laughter, shaded his face from the window as the
 17320	carriage passed Gray's statue.
 17321	
 17322	--We have all been there, Martin Cunningham said broadly.
 17323	
 17324	His eyes met Mr Bloom's eyes. He caressed his beard, adding:
 17325	
 17326	--Well, nearly all of us.
 17327	
 17328	Mr Bloom began to speak with sudden eagerness to his companions' faces.
 17329	
 17330	--That's an awfully good one that's going the rounds about Reuben J and
 17331	the son.
 17332	
 17333	--About the boatman? Mr Power asked.
 17334	
 17335	--Yes. Isn't it awfully good?
 17336	
 17337	--What is that? Mr Dedalus asked. I didn't hear it.
 17338	
 17339	--There was a girl in the case, Mr Bloom began, and he determined to
 17340	send him to the Isle of Man out of harm's way but when they were both
 17341	...
 17342	
 17343	--What? Mr Dedalus asked. That confirmed bloody hobbledehoy is it?
 17344	
 17345	--Yes, Mr Bloom said. They were both on the way to the boat and he tried
 17346	to drown...
 17347	
 17348	--Drown Barabbas! Mr Dedalus cried. I wish to Christ he did!
 17349	
 17350	Mr Power sent a long laugh down his shaded nostrils.
 17351	
 17352	--No, Mr Bloom said, the son himself...
 17353	
 17354	Martin Cunningham thwarted his speech rudely:
 17355	
 17356	--Reuben and the son were piking it down the quay next the river on
 17357	their way to the Isle of Man boat and the young chiseller suddenly got
 17358	loose and over the wall with him into the Liffey.
 17359	
 17360	--For God's sake! Mr Dedalus exclaimed in fright. Is he dead?
 17361	
 17362	--Dead! Martin Cunningham cried. Not he! A boatman got a pole and fished
 17363	him out by the slack of the breeches and he was landed up to the father
 17364	on the quay more dead than alive. Half the town was there.
 17365	
 17366	--Yes, Mr Bloom said. But the funny part is...
 17367	
 17368	--And Reuben J, Martin Cunningham said, gave the boatman a florin for
 17369	saving his son's life.
 17370	
 17371	A stifled sigh came from under Mr Power's hand.
 17372	
 17373	--O, he did, Martin Cunningham affirmed. Like a hero. A silver florin.
 17374	
 17375	--Isn't it awfully good? Mr Bloom said eagerly.
 17376	
 17377	--One and eightpence too much, Mr Dedalus said drily.
 17378	
 17379	Mr Power's choked laugh burst quietly in the carriage.
 17380	
 17381	Nelson's pillar.
 17382	
 17383	--Eight plums a penny! Eight for a penny!
 17384	
 17385	--We had better look a little serious, Martin Cunningham said.
 17386	
 17387	Mr Dedalus sighed.
 17388	
 17389	--Ah then indeed, he said, poor little Paddy wouldn't grudge us a laugh.
 17390	Many a good one he told himself.
 17391	
 17392	--The Lord forgive me! Mr Power said, wiping his wet eyes with his
 17393	fingers. Poor Paddy! I little thought a week ago when I saw him last and
 17394	he was in his usual health that I'd be driving after him like this. He's
 17395	gone from us.
 17396	
 17397	--As decent a little man as ever wore a hat, Mr Dedalus said. He went
 17398	very suddenly.
 17399	
 17400	--Breakdown, Martin Cunningham said. Heart.
 17401	
 17402	He tapped his chest sadly.
 17403	
 17404	Blazing face: redhot. Too much John Barleycorn. Cure for a red nose.
 17405	Drink like the devil till it turns adelite. A lot of money he spent
 17406	colouring it.
 17407	
 17408	Mr Power gazed at the passing houses with rueful apprehension.
 17409	
 17410	--He had a sudden death, poor fellow, he said.
 17411	
 17412	--The best death, Mr Bloom said.
 17413	
 17414	Their wide open eyes looked at him.
 17415	
 17416	--No suffering, he said. A moment and all is over. Like dying in sleep.
 17417	
 17418	No-one spoke.
 17419	
 17420	Dead side of the street this. Dull business by day, land agents,
 17421	temperance hotel, Falconer's railway guide, civil service college,
 17422	Gill's, catholic club, the industrious blind. Why? Some reason. Sun or
 17423	wind. At night too. Chummies and slaveys. Under the patronage of the
 17424	late Father Mathew. Foundation stone for Parnell. Breakdown. Heart.
 17425	
 17426	White horses with white frontlet plumes came round the Rotunda corner,
 17427	galloping. A tiny coffin flashed by. In a hurry to bury. A mourning
 17428	coach. Unmarried. Black for the married. Piebald for bachelors. Dun for
 17429	a nun.
 17430	
 17431	--Sad, Martin Cunningham said. A child.
 17432	
 17433	A dwarf's face, mauve and wrinkled like little Rudy's was. Dwarf's body,
 17434	weak as putty, in a whitelined deal box. Burial friendly society
 17435	pays. Penny a week for a sod of turf. Our. Little. Beggar. Baby. Meant
 17436	nothing. Mistake of nature. If it's healthy it's from the mother. If not
 17437	from the man. Better luck next time.
 17438	
 17439	--Poor little thing, Mr Dedalus said. It's well out of it.
 17440	
 17441	The carriage climbed more slowly the hill of Rutland square. Rattle his
 17442	bones. Over the stones. Only a pauper. Nobody owns.
 17443	
 17444	--In the midst of life, Martin Cunningham said.
 17445	
 17446	--But the worst of all, Mr Power said, is the man who takes his own
 17447	life.
 17448	
 17449	Martin Cunningham drew out his watch briskly, coughed and put it back.
 17450	
 17451	--The greatest disgrace to have in the family, Mr Power added.
 17452	
 17453	--Temporary insanity, of course, Martin Cunningham said decisively. We
 17454	must take a charitable view of it.
 17455	
 17456	--They say a man who does it is a coward, Mr Dedalus said.
 17457	
 17458	--It is not for us to judge, Martin Cunningham said.
 17459	
 17460	Mr Bloom, about to speak, closed his lips again. Martin Cunningham's
 17461	large eyes. Looking away now. Sympathetic human man he is. Intelligent.
 17462	Like Shakespeare's face. Always a good word to say. They have no mercy
 17463	on that here or infanticide. Refuse christian burial. They used to drive
 17464	a stake of wood through his heart in the grave. As if it wasn't broken
 17465	already. Yet sometimes they repent too late. Found in the riverbed
 17466	clutching rushes. He looked at me. And that awful drunkard of a wife
 17467	of his. Setting up house for her time after time and then pawning the
 17468	furniture on him every Saturday almost. Leading him the life of the
 17469	damned. Wear the heart out of a stone, that. Monday morning. Start
 17470	afresh. Shoulder to the wheel. Lord, she must have looked a sight
 17471	that night Dedalus told me he was in there. Drunk about the place and
 17472	capering with Martin's umbrella.
 17473	
 17474	     _And they call me the jewel of Asia,
 17475	     Of Asia,
 17476	     The Geisha._
 17477	
 17478	He looked away from me. He knows. Rattle his bones.
 17479	
 17480	That afternoon of the inquest. The redlabelled bottle on the table. The
 17481	room in the hotel with hunting pictures. Stuffy it was. Sunlight through
 17482	the slats of the Venetian blind. The coroner's sunlit ears, big and
 17483	hairy. Boots giving evidence. Thought he was asleep first. Then saw like
 17484	yellow streaks on his face. Had slipped down to the foot of the bed.
 17485	Verdict: overdose. Death by misadventure. The letter. For my son
 17486	Leopold.
 17487	
 17488	No more pain. Wake no more. Nobody owns.
 17489	
 17490	The carriage rattled swiftly along Blessington street. Over the stones.
 17491	
 17492	--We are going the pace, I think, Martin Cunningham said.
 17493	
 17494	--God grant he doesn't upset us on the road, Mr Power said.
 17495	
 17496	--I hope not, Martin Cunningham said. That will be a great race tomorrow
 17497	in Germany. The Gordon Bennett.
 17498	
 17499	--Yes, by Jove, Mr Dedalus said. That will be worth seeing, faith.
 17500	
 17501	As they turned into Berkeley street a streetorgan near the Basin sent
 17502	over and after them a rollicking rattling song of the halls. Has anybody
 17503	here seen Kelly? Kay ee double ell wy. Dead March from _Saul._ He's
 17504	as bad as old Antonio. He left me on my ownio. Pirouette! The _Mater
 17505	Misericordiae_. Eccles street. My house down there. Big place. Ward for
 17506	incurables there. Very encouraging. Our Lady's Hospice for the dying.
 17507	Deadhouse handy underneath. Where old Mrs Riordan died. They look
 17508	terrible the women. Her feeding cup and rubbing her mouth with the
 17509	spoon. Then the screen round her bed for her to die. Nice young student
 17510	that was dressed that bite the bee gave me. He's gone over to the
 17511	lying-in hospital they told me. From one extreme to the other. The
 17512	carriage galloped round a corner: stopped.
 17513	
 17514	--What's wrong now?
 17515	
 17516	A divided drove of branded cattle passed the windows, lowing, slouching
 17517	by on padded hoofs, whisking their tails slowly on their clotted bony
 17518	croups. Outside them and through them ran raddled sheep bleating their
 17519	fear.
 17520	
 17521	--Emigrants, Mr Power said.
 17522	
 17523	--Huuuh! the drover's voice cried, his switch sounding on their flanks.
 17524	
 17525	Huuuh! out of that!
 17526	
 17527	Thursday, of course. Tomorrow is killing day. Springers. Cuffe sold them
 17528	about twentyseven quid each. For Liverpool probably. Roastbeef for old
 17529	England. They buy up all the juicy ones. And then the fifth quarter
 17530	lost: all that raw stuff, hide, hair, horns. Comes to a big thing in a
 17531	year. Dead meat trade. Byproducts of the slaughterhouses for tanneries,
 17532	soap, margarine. Wonder if that dodge works now getting dicky meat off
 17533	the train at Clonsilla.
 17534	
 17535	The carriage moved on through the drove.
 17536	
 17537	--I can't make out why the corporation doesn't run a tramline from the
 17538	parkgate to the quays, Mr Bloom said. All those animals could be taken
 17539	in trucks down to the boats.
 17540	
 17541	--Instead of blocking up the thoroughfare, Martin Cunningham said. Quite
 17542	right. They ought to.
 17543	
 17544	--Yes, Mr Bloom said, and another thing I often thought, is to have
 17545	municipal funeral trams like they have in Milan, you know. Run the line
 17546	out to the cemetery gates and have special trams, hearse and carriage
 17547	and all. Don't you see what I mean?
 17548	
 17549	--O, that be damned for a story, Mr Dedalus said. Pullman car and saloon
 17550	diningroom.
 17551	
 17552	--A poor lookout for Corny, Mr Power added.
 17553	
 17554	--Why? Mr Bloom asked, turning to Mr Dedalus. Wouldn't it be more decent
 17555	than galloping two abreast?
 17556	
 17557	--Well, there's something in that, Mr Dedalus granted.
 17558	
 17559	--And, Martin Cunningham said, we wouldn't have scenes like that when
 17560	the hearse capsized round Dunphy's and upset the coffin on to the road.
 17561	
 17562	--That was terrible, Mr Power's shocked face said, and the corpse fell
 17563	about the road. Terrible!
 17564	
 17565	--First round Dunphy's, Mr Dedalus said, nodding. Gordon Bennett cup.
 17566	
 17567	--Praises be to God! Martin Cunningham said piously.
 17568	
 17569	Bom! Upset. A coffin bumped out on to the road. Burst open. Paddy Dignam
 17570	shot out and rolling over stiff in the dust in a brown habit too large
 17571	for him. Red face: grey now. Mouth fallen open. Asking what's up now.
 17572	Quite right to close it. Looks horrid open. Then the insides decompose
 17573	quickly. Much better to close up all the orifices. Yes, also. With wax.
 17574	The sphincter loose. Seal up all.
 17575	
 17576	--Dunphy's, Mr Power announced as the carriage turned right.
 17577	
 17578	Dunphy's corner. Mourning coaches drawn up, drowning their grief. A
 17579	pause by the wayside. Tiptop position for a pub. Expect we'll pull up
 17580	here on the way back to drink his health. Pass round the consolation.
 17581	Elixir of life.
 17582	
 17583	But suppose now it did happen. Would he bleed if a nail say cut him
 17584	in the knocking about? He would and he wouldn't, I suppose. Depends on
 17585	where. The circulation stops. Still some might ooze out of an artery. It
 17586	would be better to bury them in red: a dark red.
 17587	
 17588	In silence they drove along Phibsborough road. An empty hearse trotted
 17589	by, coming from the cemetery: looks relieved.
 17590	
 17591	Crossguns bridge: the royal canal.
 17592	
 17593	Water rushed roaring through the sluices. A man stood on his
 17594	dropping barge, between clamps of turf. On the towpath by the lock a
 17595	slacktethered horse. Aboard of the _Bugabu._
 17596	
 17597	Their eyes watched him. On the slow weedy waterway he had floated on his
 17598	raft coastward over Ireland drawn by a haulage rope past beds of
 17599	reeds, over slime, mudchoked bottles, carrion dogs. Athlone, Mullingar,
 17600	Moyvalley, I could make a walking tour to see Milly by the canal. Or
 17601	cycle down. Hire some old crock, safety. Wren had one the other day at
 17602	the auction but a lady's. Developing waterways. James M'Cann's hobby
 17603	to row me o'er the ferry. Cheaper transit. By easy stages. Houseboats.
 17604	Camping out. Also hearses. To heaven by water. Perhaps I will without
 17605	writing. Come as a surprise, Leixlip, Clonsilla. Dropping down lock by
 17606	lock to Dublin. With turf from the midland bogs. Salute. He lifted his
 17607	brown straw hat, saluting Paddy Dignam.
 17608	
 17609	They drove on past Brian Boroimhe house. Near it now.
 17610	
 17611	--I wonder how is our friend Fogarty getting on, Mr Power said.
 17612	
 17613	--Better ask Tom Kernan, Mr Dedalus said.
 17614	
 17615	--How is that? Martin Cunningham said. Left him weeping, I suppose?
 17616	
 17617	--Though lost to sight, Mr Dedalus said, to memory dear.
 17618	
 17619	The carriage steered left for Finglas road.
 17620	
 17621	The stonecutter's yard on the right. Last lap. Crowded on the spit of
 17622	land silent shapes appeared, white, sorrowful, holding out calm hands,
 17623	knelt in grief, pointing. Fragments of shapes, hewn. In white silence:
 17624	appealing. The best obtainable. Thos. H. Dennany, monumental builder and
 17625	sculptor.
 17626	
 17627	Passed.
 17628	
 17629	On the curbstone before Jimmy Geary, the sexton's, an old tramp sat,
 17630	grumbling, emptying the dirt and stones out of his huge dustbrown
 17631	yawning boot. After life's journey.
 17632	
 17633	Gloomy gardens then went by: one by one: gloomy houses.
 17634	
 17635	Mr Power pointed.
 17636	
 17637	--That is where Childs was murdered, he said. The last house.
 17638	
 17639	--So it is, Mr Dedalus said. A gruesome case. Seymour Bushe got him off.
 17640	Murdered his brother. Or so they said.
 17641	
 17642	--The crown had no evidence, Mr Power said.
 17643	
 17644	--Only circumstantial, Martin Cunningham added. That's the maxim of the
 17645	law. Better for ninetynine guilty to escape than for one innocent person
 17646	to be wrongfully condemned.
 17647	
 17648	They looked. Murderer's ground. It passed darkly. Shuttered, tenantless,
 17649	unweeded garden. Whole place gone to hell. Wrongfully condemned. Murder.
 17650	The murderer's image in the eye of the murdered. They love reading about
 17651	it. Man's head found in a garden. Her clothing consisted of. How she met
 17652	her death. Recent outrage. The weapon used. Murderer is still at large.
 17653	Clues. A shoelace. The body to be exhumed. Murder will out.
 17654	
 17655	Cramped in this carriage. She mightn't like me to come that way without
 17656	letting her know. Must be careful about women. Catch them once with
 17657	their pants down. Never forgive you after. Fifteen.
 17658	
 17659	The high railings of Prospect rippled past their gaze. Dark poplars,
 17660	rare white forms. Forms more frequent, white shapes thronged amid the
 17661	trees, white forms and fragments streaming by mutely, sustaining vain
 17662	gestures on the air.
 17663	
 17664	The felly harshed against the curbstone: stopped. Martin Cunningham put
 17665	out his arm and, wrenching back the handle, shoved the door open with
 17666	his knee. He stepped out. Mr Power and Mr Dedalus followed.
 17667	
 17668	Change that soap now. Mr Bloom's hand unbuttoned his hip pocket swiftly
 17669	and transferred the paperstuck soap to his inner handkerchief pocket.
 17670	He stepped out of the carriage, replacing the newspaper his other hand
 17671	still held.
 17672	
 17673	Paltry funeral: coach and three carriages. It's all the same.
 17674	Pallbearers, gold reins, requiem mass, firing a volley. Pomp of death.
 17675	Beyond the hind carriage a hawker stood by his barrow of cakes and
 17676	fruit. Simnel cakes those are, stuck together: cakes for the dead.
 17677	Dogbiscuits. Who ate them? Mourners coming out.
 17678	
 17679	He followed his companions. Mr Kernan and Ned Lambert followed, Hynes
 17680	walking after them. Corny Kelleher stood by the opened hearse and took
 17681	out the two wreaths. He handed one to the boy.
 17682	
 17683	Where is that child's funeral disappeared to?
 17684	
 17685	A team of horses passed from Finglas with toiling plodding tread,
 17686	dragging through the funereal silence a creaking waggon on which lay a
 17687	granite block. The waggoner marching at their head saluted.
 17688	
 17689	Coffin now. Got here before us, dead as he is. Horse looking round at it
 17690	with his plume skeowways. Dull eye: collar tight on his neck, pressing
 17691	on a bloodvessel or something. Do they know what they cart out here
 17692	every day? Must be twenty or thirty funerals every day. Then Mount
 17693	Jerome for the protestants. Funerals all over the world everywhere every
 17694	minute. Shovelling them under by the cartload doublequick. Thousands
 17695	every hour. Too many in the world.
 17696	
 17697	Mourners came out through the gates: woman and a girl. Leanjawed harpy,
 17698	hard woman at a bargain, her bonnet awry. Girl's face stained with dirt
 17699	and tears, holding the woman's arm, looking up at her for a sign to cry.
 17700	Fish's face, bloodless and livid.
 17701	
 17702	The mutes shouldered the coffin and bore it in through the gates. So
 17703	much dead weight. Felt heavier myself stepping out of that bath. First
 17704	the stiff: then the friends of the stiff. Corny Kelleher and the
 17705	boy followed with their wreaths. Who is that beside them? Ah, the
 17706	brother-in-law.
 17707	
 17708	All walked after.
 17709	
 17710	Martin Cunningham whispered:
 17711	
 17712	--I was in mortal agony with you talking of suicide before Bloom.
 17713	
 17714	--What? Mr Power whispered. How so?
 17715	
 17716	--His father poisoned himself, Martin Cunningham whispered. Had the
 17717	Queen's hotel in Ennis. You heard him say he was going to Clare.
 17718	Anniversary.
 17719	
 17720	--O God! Mr Power whispered. First I heard of it. Poisoned himself?
 17721	
 17722	He glanced behind him to where a face with dark thinking eyes followed
 17723	towards the cardinal's mausoleum. Speaking.
 17724	
 17725	--Was he insured? Mr Bloom asked.
 17726	
 17727	--I believe so, Mr Kernan answered. But the policy was heavily
 17728	mortgaged. Martin is trying to get the youngster into Artane.
 17729	
 17730	--How many children did he leave?
 17731	
 17732	--Five. Ned Lambert says he'll try to get one of the girls into Todd's.
 17733	
 17734	--A sad case, Mr Bloom said gently. Five young children.
 17735	
 17736	--A great blow to the poor wife, Mr Kernan added.
 17737	
 17738	--Indeed yes, Mr Bloom agreed.
 17739	
 17740	Has the laugh at him now.
 17741	
 17742	He looked down at the boots he had blacked and polished. She had
 17743	outlived him. Lost her husband. More dead for her than for me. One must
 17744	outlive the other. Wise men say. There are more women than men in the
 17745	world. Condole with her. Your terrible loss. I hope you'll soon follow
 17746	him. For Hindu widows only. She would marry another. Him? No. Yet who
 17747	knows after. Widowhood not the thing since the old queen died. Drawn on
 17748	a guncarriage. Victoria and Albert. Frogmore memorial mourning. But
 17749	in the end she put a few violets in her bonnet. Vain in her heart of
 17750	hearts. All for a shadow. Consort not even a king. Her son was the
 17751	substance. Something new to hope for not like the past she wanted back,
 17752	waiting. It never comes. One must go first: alone, under the ground: and
 17753	lie no more in her warm bed.
 17754	
 17755	--How are you, Simon? Ned Lambert said softly, clasping hands. Haven't
 17756	seen you for a month of Sundays.
 17757	
 17758	--Never better. How are all in Cork's own town?
 17759	
 17760	--I was down there for the Cork park races on Easter Monday, Ned Lambert
 17761	said. Same old six and eightpence. Stopped with Dick Tivy.
 17762	
 17763	--And how is Dick, the solid man?
 17764	
 17765	--Nothing between himself and heaven, Ned Lambert answered.
 17766	
 17767	--By the holy Paul! Mr Dedalus said in subdued wonder. Dick Tivy bald?
 17768	
 17769	--Martin is going to get up a whip for the youngsters, Ned Lambert said,
 17770	pointing ahead. A few bob a skull. Just to keep them going till the
 17771	insurance is cleared up.
 17772	
 17773	--Yes, yes, Mr Dedalus said dubiously. Is that the eldest boy in front?
 17774	
 17775	--Yes, Ned Lambert said, with the wife's brother. John Henry Menton is
 17776	behind. He put down his name for a quid.
 17777	
 17778	--I'll engage he did, Mr Dedalus said. I often told poor Paddy he ought
 17779	to mind that job. John Henry is not the worst in the world.
 17780	
 17781	--How did he lose it? Ned Lambert asked. Liquor, what?
 17782	
 17783	--Many a good man's fault, Mr Dedalus said with a sigh.
 17784	
 17785	They halted about the door of the mortuary chapel. Mr Bloom stood behind
 17786	the boy with the wreath looking down at his sleekcombed hair and at the
 17787	slender furrowed neck inside his brandnew collar. Poor boy! Was he there
 17788	when the father? Both unconscious. Lighten up at the last moment
 17789	and recognise for the last time. All he might have done. I owe three
 17790	shillings to O'Grady. Would he understand? The mutes bore the coffin
 17791	into the chapel. Which end is his head?
 17792	
 17793	After a moment he followed the others in, blinking in the screened
 17794	light. The coffin lay on its bier before the chancel, four tall yellow
 17795	candles at its corners. Always in front of us. Corny Kelleher, laying a
 17796	wreath at each fore corner, beckoned to the boy to kneel. The mourners
 17797	knelt here and there in prayingdesks. Mr Bloom stood behind near the
 17798	font and, when all had knelt, dropped carefully his unfolded newspaper
 17799	from his pocket and knelt his right knee upon it. He fitted his black
 17800	hat gently on his left knee and, holding its brim, bent over piously.
 17801	
 17802	A server bearing a brass bucket with something in it came out through a
 17803	door. The whitesmocked priest came after him, tidying his stole with one
 17804	hand, balancing with the other a little book against his toad's belly.
 17805	Who'll read the book? I, said the rook.
 17806
