 17807	They halted by the bier and the priest began to read out of his book
 17808	with a fluent croak.
 17809	
 17810	Father Coffey. I knew his name was like a coffin. _Domine-namine._ Bully
 17811	about the muzzle he looks. Bosses the show. Muscular christian. Woe
 17812	betide anyone that looks crooked at him: priest. Thou art Peter. Burst
 17813	sideways like a sheep in clover Dedalus says he will. With a belly on
 17814	him like a poisoned pup. Most amusing expressions that man finds. Hhhn:
 17815	burst sideways.
 17816	
 17817	_--Non intres in judicium cum servo tuo, Domine._
 17818	
 17819	Makes them feel more important to be prayed over in Latin. Requiem mass.
 17820	Crape weepers. Blackedged notepaper. Your name on the altarlist. Chilly
 17821	place this. Want to feed well, sitting in there all the morning in the
 17822	gloom kicking his heels waiting for the next please. Eyes of a toad too.
 17823	What swells him up that way? Molly gets swelled after cabbage. Air of
 17824	the place maybe. Looks full up of bad gas. Must be an infernal lot
 17825	of bad gas round the place. Butchers, for instance: they get like raw
 17826	beefsteaks. Who was telling me? Mervyn Browne. Down in the vaults of
 17827	saint Werburgh's lovely old organ hundred and fifty they have to bore a
 17828	hole in the coffins sometimes to let out the bad gas and burn it. Out it
 17829	rushes: blue. One whiff of that and you're a goner.
 17830	
 17831	My kneecap is hurting me. Ow. That's better.
 17832	
 17833	The priest took a stick with a knob at the end of it out of the boy's
 17834	bucket and shook it over the coffin. Then he walked to the other end and
 17835	shook it again. Then he came back and put it back in the bucket. As you
 17836	were before you rested. It's all written down: he has to do it.
 17837	
 17838	_--Et ne nos inducas in tentationem._
 17839	
 17840	The server piped the answers in the treble. I often thought it would be
 17841	better to have boy servants. Up to fifteen or so. After that, of course
 17842	...
 17843	
 17844	Holy water that was, I expect. Shaking sleep out of it. He must be fed
 17845	up with that job, shaking that thing over all the corpses they trot up.
 17846	What harm if he could see what he was shaking it over. Every mortal
 17847	day a fresh batch: middleaged men, old women, children, women dead in
 17848	childbirth, men with beards, baldheaded businessmen, consumptive girls
 17849	with little sparrows' breasts. All the year round he prayed the same
 17850	thing over them all and shook water on top of them: sleep. On Dignam
 17851	now.
 17852	
 17853	_--In paradisum._
 17854	
 17855	Said he was going to paradise or is in paradise. Says that over
 17856	everybody. Tiresome kind of a job. But he has to say something.
 17857	
 17858	The priest closed his book and went off, followed by the server. Corny
 17859	Kelleher opened the sidedoors and the gravediggers came in, hoisted the
 17860	coffin again, carried it out and shoved it on their cart. Corny Kelleher
 17861	gave one wreath to the boy and one to the brother-in-law. All followed
 17862	them out of the sidedoors into the mild grey air. Mr Bloom came last
 17863	folding his paper again into his pocket. He gazed gravely at the ground
 17864	till the coffincart wheeled off to the left. The metal wheels ground the
 17865	gravel with a sharp grating cry and the pack of blunt boots followed the
 17866	trundled barrow along a lane of sepulchres.
 17867	
 17868	The ree the ra the ree the ra the roo. Lord, I mustn't lilt here.
 17869	
 17870	--The O'Connell circle, Mr Dedalus said about him.
 17871	
 17872	Mr Power's soft eyes went up to the apex of the lofty cone.
 17873	
 17874	--He's at rest, he said, in the middle of his people, old Dan O'. But
 17875	his heart is buried in Rome. How many broken hearts are buried here,
 17876	Simon!
 17877	
 17878	--Her grave is over there, Jack, Mr Dedalus said. I'll soon be stretched
 17879	beside her. Let Him take me whenever He likes.
 17880	
 17881	Breaking down, he began to weep to himself quietly, stumbling a little
 17882	in his walk. Mr Power took his arm.
 17883	
 17884	--She's better where she is, he said kindly.
 17885	
 17886	--I suppose so, Mr Dedalus said with a weak gasp. I suppose she is in
 17887	heaven if there is a heaven.
 17888	
 17889	Corny Kelleher stepped aside from his rank and allowed the mourners to
 17890	plod by.
 17891	
 17892	--Sad occasions, Mr Kernan began politely.
 17893	
 17894	Mr Bloom closed his eyes and sadly twice bowed his head.
 17895	
 17896	--The others are putting on their hats, Mr Kernan said. I suppose we can
 17897	do so too. We are the last. This cemetery is a treacherous place.
 17898	
 17899	They covered their heads.
 17900	
 17901	--The reverend gentleman read the service too quickly, don't you think?
 17902	Mr Kernan said with reproof.
 17903	
 17904	Mr Bloom nodded gravely looking in the quick bloodshot eyes. Secret
 17905	eyes, secretsearching. Mason, I think: not sure. Beside him again. We
 17906	are the last. In the same boat. Hope he'll say something else.
 17907	
 17908	Mr Kernan added:
 17909	
 17910	--The service of the Irish church used in Mount Jerome is simpler, more
 17911	impressive I must say.
 17912	
 17913	Mr Bloom gave prudent assent. The language of course was another thing.
 17914	
 17915	Mr Kernan said with solemnity:
 17916	
 17917	--_I am the resurrection and the life_. That touches a man's inmost
 17918	heart.
 17919	
 17920	--It does, Mr Bloom said.
 17921	
 17922	Your heart perhaps but what price the fellow in the six feet by two
 17923	with his toes to the daisies? No touching that. Seat of the affections.
 17924	Broken heart. A pump after all, pumping thousands of gallons of blood
 17925	every day. One fine day it gets bunged up: and there you are. Lots of
 17926	them lying around here: lungs, hearts, livers. Old rusty pumps: damn
 17927	the thing else. The resurrection and the life. Once you are dead you are
 17928	dead. That last day idea. Knocking them all up out of their graves. Come
 17929	forth, Lazarus! And he came fifth and lost the job. Get up! Last day!
 17930	Then every fellow mousing around for his liver and his lights and the
 17931	rest of his traps. Find damn all of himself that morning. Pennyweight of
 17932	powder in a skull. Twelve grammes one pennyweight. Troy measure.
 17933	
 17934	Corny Kelleher fell into step at their side.
 17935	
 17936	--Everything went off A1, he said. What?
 17937	
 17938	He looked on them from his drawling eye. Policeman's shoulders. With
 17939	your tooraloom tooraloom.
 17940	
 17941	--As it should be, Mr Kernan said.
 17942	
 17943	--What? Eh? Corny Kelleher said.
 17944	
 17945	Mr Kernan assured him.
 17946	
 17947	--Who is that chap behind with Tom Kernan? John Henry Menton asked. I
 17948	know his face.
 17949	
 17950	Ned Lambert glanced back.
 17951	
 17952	--Bloom, he said, Madame Marion Tweedy that was, is, I mean, the
 17953	soprano. She's his wife.
 17954	
 17955	--O, to be sure, John Henry Menton said. I haven't seen her for some
 17956	time. He was a finelooking woman. I danced with her, wait, fifteen
 17957	seventeen golden years ago, at Mat Dillon's in Roundtown. And a good
 17958	armful she was.
 17959	
 17960	He looked behind through the others.
 17961	
 17962	--What is he? he asked. What does he do? Wasn't he in the stationery
 17963	line? I fell foul of him one evening, I remember, at bowls.
 17964	
 17965	Ned Lambert smiled.
 17966	
 17967	--Yes, he was, he said, in Wisdom Hely's. A traveller for blottingpaper.
 17968	
 17969	--In God's name, John Henry Menton said, what did she marry a coon like
 17970	that for? She had plenty of game in her then.
 17971	
 17972	--Has still, Ned Lambert said. He does some canvassing for ads.
 17973	
 17974	John Henry Menton's large eyes stared ahead.
 17975	
 17976	The barrow turned into a side lane. A portly man, ambushed among the
 17977	grasses, raised his hat in homage. The gravediggers touched their caps.
 17978	
 17979	--John O'Connell, Mr Power said pleased. He never forgets a friend.
 17980	
 17981	Mr O'Connell shook all their hands in silence. Mr Dedalus said:
 17982	
 17983	--I am come to pay you another visit.
 17984	
 17985	--My dear Simon, the caretaker answered in a low voice. I don't want
 17986	your custom at all.
 17987	
 17988	Saluting Ned Lambert and John Henry Menton he walked on at Martin
 17989	Cunningham's side puzzling two long keys at his back.
 17990	
 17991	--Did you hear that one, he asked them, about Mulcahy from the Coombe?
 17992	
 17993	--I did not, Martin Cunningham said.
 17994	
 17995	They bent their silk hats in concert and Hynes inclined his ear. The
 17996	caretaker hung his thumbs in the loops of his gold watchchain and spoke
 17997	in a discreet tone to their vacant smiles.
 17998	
 17999	--They tell the story, he said, that two drunks came out here one foggy
 18000	evening to look for the grave of a friend of theirs. They asked for
 18001	Mulcahy from the Coombe and were told where he was buried. After
 18002	traipsing about in the fog they found the grave sure enough. One of the
 18003	drunks spelt out the name: Terence Mulcahy. The other drunk was blinking
 18004	up at a statue of Our Saviour the widow had got put up.
 18005	
 18006	The caretaker blinked up at one of the sepulchres they passed. He
 18007	resumed:
 18008	
 18009	--And, after blinking up at the sacred figure, _Not a bloody bit like
 18010	the man_, says he. _That's not Mulcahy_, says he, _whoever done it_.
 18011	
 18012	Rewarded by smiles he fell back and spoke with Corny Kelleher, accepting
 18013	the dockets given him, turning them over and scanning them as he walked.
 18014	
 18015	--That's all done with a purpose, Martin Cunningham explained to Hynes.
 18016	
 18017	--I know, Hynes said. I know that.
 18018	
 18019	--To cheer a fellow up, Martin Cunningham said. It's pure
 18020	goodheartedness: damn the thing else.
 18021	
 18022	Mr Bloom admired the caretaker's prosperous bulk. All want to be on good
 18023	terms with him. Decent fellow, John O'Connell, real good sort. Keys:
 18024	like Keyes's ad: no fear of anyone getting out. No passout checks.
 18025	_Habeas corpus_. I must see about that ad after the funeral. Did I
 18026	write Ballsbridge on the envelope I took to cover when she disturbed me
 18027	writing to Martha? Hope it's not chucked in the dead letter office. Be
 18028	the better of a shave. Grey sprouting beard. That's the first sign when
 18029	the hairs come out grey. And temper getting cross. Silver threads among
 18030	the grey. Fancy being his wife. Wonder he had the gumption to propose to
 18031	any girl. Come out and live in the graveyard. Dangle that before her. It
 18032	might thrill her first. Courting death... Shades of night hovering
 18033	here with all the dead stretched about. The shadows of the tombs when
 18034	churchyards yawn and Daniel O'Connell must be a descendant I suppose
 18035	who is this used to say he was a queer breedy man great catholic all the
 18036	same like a big giant in the dark. Will o' the wisp. Gas of graves.
 18037	Want to keep her mind off it to conceive at all. Women especially are so
 18038	touchy. Tell her a ghost story in bed to make her sleep. Have you ever
 18039	seen a ghost? Well, I have. It was a pitchdark night. The clock was on
 18040	the stroke of twelve. Still they'd kiss all right if properly keyed up.
 18041	Whores in Turkish graveyards. Learn anything if taken young. You might
 18042	pick up a young widow here. Men like that. Love among the tombstones.
 18043	Romeo. Spice of pleasure. In the midst of death we are in life. Both
 18044	ends meet. Tantalising for the poor dead. Smell of grilled beefsteaks to
 18045	the starving. Gnawing their vitals. Desire to grig people. Molly wanting
 18046	to do it at the window. Eight children he has anyway.
 18047	
 18048	He has seen a fair share go under in his time, lying around him field
 18049	after field. Holy fields. More room if they buried them standing.
 18050	Sitting or kneeling you couldn't. Standing? His head might come up some
 18051	day above ground in a landslip with his hand pointing. All honeycombed
 18052	the ground must be: oblong cells. And very neat he keeps it too: trim
 18053	grass and edgings. His garden Major Gamble calls Mount Jerome. Well,
 18054	so it is. Ought to be flowers of sleep. Chinese cemeteries with giant
 18055	poppies growing produce the best opium Mastiansky told me. The Botanic
 18056	Gardens are just over there. It's the blood sinking in the earth gives
 18057	new life. Same idea those jews they said killed the christian boy. Every
 18058	man his price. Well preserved fat corpse, gentleman, epicure, invaluable
 18059	for fruit garden. A bargain. By carcass of William Wilkinson, auditor
 18060	and accountant, lately deceased, three pounds thirteen and six. With
 18061	thanks.
 18062	
 18063	I daresay the soil would be quite fat with corpsemanure, bones, flesh,
 18064	nails. Charnelhouses. Dreadful. Turning green and pink decomposing. Rot
 18065	quick in damp earth. The lean old ones tougher. Then a kind of a tallowy
 18066	kind of a cheesy. Then begin to get black, black treacle oozing out of
 18067	them. Then dried up. Deathmoths. Of course the cells or whatever they
 18068	are go on living. Changing about. Live for ever practically. Nothing to
 18069	feed on feed on themselves.
 18070	
 18071	But they must breed a devil of a lot of maggots. Soil must be simply
 18072	swirling with them. Your head it simply swurls. Those pretty little
 18073	seaside gurls. He looks cheerful enough over it. Gives him a sense of
 18074	power seeing all the others go under first. Wonder how he looks at life.
 18075	Cracking his jokes too: warms the cockles of his heart. The one about
 18076	the bulletin. Spurgeon went to heaven 4 a.m. this morning. 11 p.m.
 18077	(closing time). Not arrived yet. Peter. The dead themselves the men
 18078	anyhow would like to hear an odd joke or the women to know what's in
 18079	fashion. A juicy pear or ladies' punch, hot, strong and sweet. Keep
 18080	out the damp. You must laugh sometimes so better do it that way.
 18081	Gravediggers in _Hamlet_. Shows the profound knowledge of the human
 18082	heart. Daren't joke about the dead for two years at least. _De mortuis
 18083	nil nisi prius_. Go out of mourning first. Hard to imagine his funeral.
 18084	Seems a sort of a joke. Read your own obituary notice they say you live
 18085	longer. Gives you second wind. New lease of life.
 18086	
 18087	--How many have-you for tomorrow? the caretaker asked.
 18088	
 18089	--Two, Corny Kelleher said. Half ten and eleven.
 18090	
 18091	The caretaker put the papers in his pocket. The barrow had ceased to
 18092	trundle. The mourners split and moved to each side of the hole, stepping
 18093	with care round the graves. The gravediggers bore the coffin and set its
 18094	nose on the brink, looping the bands round it.
 18095	
 18096	Burying him. We come to bury Caesar. His ides of March or June. He
 18097	doesn't know who is here nor care. Now who is that lankylooking galoot
 18098	over there in the macintosh? Now who is he I'd like to know? Now I'd
 18099	give a trifle to know who he is. Always someone turns up you never
 18100	dreamt of. A fellow could live on his lonesome all his life. Yes, he
 18101	could. Still he'd have to get someone to sod him after he died though he
 18102	could dig his own grave. We all do. Only man buries. No, ants too. First
 18103	thing strikes anybody. Bury the dead. Say Robinson Crusoe was true to
 18104	life. Well then Friday buried him. Every Friday buries a Thursday if you
 18105	come to look at it.
 18106	
 18107	     _O, poor Robinson Crusoe!
 18108	     How could you possibly do so?_
 18109	
 18110	Poor Dignam! His last lie on the earth in his box. When you think of
 18111	them all it does seem a waste of wood. All gnawed through. They could
 18112	invent a handsome bier with a kind of panel sliding, let it down that
 18113	way. Ay but they might object to be buried out of another fellow's.
 18114	They're so particular. Lay me in my native earth. Bit of clay from
 18115	the holy land. Only a mother and deadborn child ever buried in the one
 18116	coffin. I see what it means. I see. To protect him as long as possible
 18117	even in the earth. The Irishman's house is his coffin. Embalming in
 18118	catacombs, mummies the same idea.
 18119	
 18120	Mr Bloom stood far back, his hat in his hand, counting the bared heads.
 18121	Twelve. I'm thirteen. No. The chap in the macintosh is thirteen. Death's
 18122	number. Where the deuce did he pop out of? He wasn't in the chapel, that
 18123	I'll swear. Silly superstition that about thirteen.
 18124	
 18125	Nice soft tweed Ned Lambert has in that suit. Tinge of purple. I had
 18126	one like that when we lived in Lombard street west. Dressy fellow he was
 18127	once. Used to change three suits in the day. Must get that grey suit
 18128	of mine turned by Mesias. Hello. It's dyed. His wife I forgot he's not
 18129	married or his landlady ought to have picked out those threads for him.
 18130	
 18131	The coffin dived out of sight, eased down by the men straddled on the
 18132	gravetrestles. They struggled up and out: and all uncovered. Twenty.
 18133	
 18134	Pause.
 18135	
 18136	If we were all suddenly somebody else.
 18137	
 18138	Far away a donkey brayed. Rain. No such ass. Never see a dead one, they
 18139	say. Shame of death. They hide. Also poor papa went away.
 18140	
 18141	Gentle sweet air blew round the bared heads in a whisper. Whisper. The
 18142	boy by the gravehead held his wreath with both hands staring quietly in
 18143	the black open space. Mr Bloom moved behind the portly kindly caretaker.
 18144	Wellcut frockcoat. Weighing them up perhaps to see which will go next.
 18145	Well, it is a long rest. Feel no more. It's the moment you feel. Must be
 18146	damned unpleasant. Can't believe it at first. Mistake must be: someone
 18147	else. Try the house opposite. Wait, I wanted to. I haven't yet. Then
 18148	darkened deathchamber. Light they want. Whispering around you. Would you
 18149	like to see a priest? Then rambling and wandering. Delirium all you hid
 18150	all your life. The death struggle. His sleep is not natural. Press his
 18151	lower eyelid. Watching is his nose pointed is his jaw sinking are the
 18152	soles of his feet yellow. Pull the pillow away and finish it off on the
 18153	floor since he's doomed. Devil in that picture of sinner's death showing
 18154	him a woman. Dying to embrace her in his shirt. Last act of _Lucia.
 18155	Shall i nevermore behold thee_? Bam! He expires. Gone at last. People
 18156	talk about you a bit: forget you. Don't forget to pray for him. Remember
 18157	him in your prayers. Even Parnell. Ivy day dying out. Then they follow:
 18158	dropping into a hole, one after the other.
 18159	
 18160	We are praying now for the repose of his soul. Hoping you're well and
 18161	not in hell. Nice change of air. Out of the fryingpan of life into the
 18162	fire of purgatory.
 18163	
 18164	Does he ever think of the hole waiting for himself? They say you do when
 18165	you shiver in the sun. Someone walking over it. Callboy's warning. Near
 18166	you. Mine over there towards Finglas, the plot I bought. Mamma, poor
 18167	mamma, and little Rudy.
 18168	
 18169	The gravediggers took up their spades and flung heavy clods of clay in
 18170	on the coffin. Mr Bloom turned away his face. And if he was alive all
 18171	the time? Whew! By jingo, that would be awful! No, no: he is dead, of
 18172	course. Of course he is dead. Monday he died. They ought to have
 18173	some law to pierce the heart and make sure or an electric clock or
 18174	a telephone in the coffin and some kind of a canvas airhole. Flag of
 18175	distress. Three days. Rather long to keep them in summer. Just as well
 18176	to get shut of them as soon as you are sure there's no.
 18177	
 18178	The clay fell softer. Begin to be forgotten. Out of sight, out of mind.
 18179	
 18180	The caretaker moved away a few paces and put on his hat. Had enough of
 18181	it. The mourners took heart of grace, one by one, covering themselves
 18182	without show. Mr Bloom put on his hat and saw the portly figure make its
 18183	way deftly through the maze of graves. Quietly, sure of his ground, he
 18184	traversed the dismal fields.
 18185	
 18186	Hynes jotting down something in his notebook. Ah, the names. But he
 18187	knows them all. No: coming to me.
 18188	
 18189	--I am just taking the names, Hynes said below his breath. What is your
 18190	christian name? I'm not sure.
 18191	
 18192	--L, Mr Bloom said. Leopold. And you might put down M'Coy's name too. He
 18193	asked me to.
 18194	
 18195	--Charley, Hynes said writing. I know. He was on the _Freeman_ once.
 18196	
 18197	So he was before he got the job in the morgue under Louis Byrne. Good
 18198	idea a postmortem for doctors. Find out what they imagine they know.
 18199	He died of a Tuesday. Got the run. Levanted with the cash of a few ads.
 18200	Charley, you're my darling. That was why he asked me to. O well, does
 18201	no harm. I saw to that, M'Coy. Thanks, old chap: much obliged. Leave him
 18202	under an obligation: costs nothing.
 18203	
 18204	--And tell us, Hynes said, do you know that fellow in the, fellow was
 18205	over there in the...
 18206	
 18207	He looked around.
 18208	
 18209	--Macintosh. Yes, I saw him, Mr Bloom said. Where is he now?
 18210	
 18211	--M'Intosh, Hynes said scribbling. I don't know who he is. Is that his
 18212	name?
 18213	
 18214	He moved away, looking about him.
 18215	
 18216	--No, Mr Bloom began, turning and stopping. I say, Hynes!
 18217	
 18218	Didn't hear. What? Where has he disappeared to? Not a sign. Well of all
 18219	the. Has anybody here seen? Kay ee double ell. Become invisible. Good
 18220	Lord, what became of him?
 18221	
 18222	A seventh gravedigger came beside Mr Bloom to take up an idle spade.
 18223	
 18224	--O, excuse me!
 18225	
 18226	He stepped aside nimbly.
 18227	
 18228	Clay, brown, damp, began to be seen in the hole. It rose. Nearly over.
 18229	A mound of damp clods rose more, rose, and the gravediggers rested their
 18230	spades. All uncovered again for a few instants. The boy propped
 18231	his wreath against a corner: the brother-in-law his on a lump. The
 18232	gravediggers put on their caps and carried their earthy spades towards
 18233	the barrow. Then knocked the blades lightly on the turf: clean. One bent
 18234	to pluck from the haft a long tuft of grass. One, leaving his mates,
 18235	walked slowly on with shouldered weapon, its blade blueglancing.
 18236	Silently at the gravehead another coiled the coffinband. His navelcord.
 18237	The brother-in-law, turning away, placed something in his free hand.
 18238	Thanks in silence. Sorry, sir: trouble. Headshake. I know that. For
 18239	yourselves just.
 18240	
 18241	The mourners moved away slowly without aim, by devious paths, staying at
 18242	whiles to read a name on a tomb.
 18243	
 18244	--Let us go round by the chief's grave, Hynes said. We have time.
 18245	
 18246	--Let us, Mr Power said.
 18247	
 18248	They turned to the right, following their slow thoughts. With awe Mr
 18249	Power's blank voice spoke:
 18250	
 18251	--Some say he is not in that grave at all. That the coffin was filled
 18252	with stones. That one day he will come again.
 18253	
 18254	Hynes shook his head.
 18255	
 18256	--Parnell will never come again, he said. He's there, all that was
 18257	mortal of him. Peace to his ashes.
 18258	
 18259	Mr Bloom walked unheeded along his grove by saddened angels, crosses,
 18260	broken pillars, family vaults, stone hopes praying with upcast eyes,
 18261	old Ireland's hearts and hands. More sensible to spend the money on some
 18262	charity for the living. Pray for the repose of the soul of. Does anybody
 18263	really? Plant him and have done with him. Like down a coalshoot. Then
 18264	lump them together to save time. All souls' day. Twentyseventh I'll be
 18265	at his grave. Ten shillings for the gardener. He keeps it free of weeds.
 18266	Old man himself. Bent down double with his shears clipping. Near death's
 18267	door. Who passed away. Who departed this life. As if they did it of
 18268	their own accord. Got the shove, all of them. Who kicked the
 18269	bucket. More interesting if they told you what they were. So and So,
 18270	wheelwright. I travelled for cork lino. I paid five shillings in the
 18271	pound. Or a woman's with her saucepan. I cooked good Irish stew.
 18272	Eulogy in a country churchyard it ought to be that poem of whose is it
 18273	Wordsworth or Thomas Campbell. Entered into rest the protestants put it.
 18274	Old Dr Murren's. The great physician called him home. Well it's God's
 18275	acre for them. Nice country residence. Newly plastered and painted.
 18276	Ideal spot to have a quiet smoke and read the _Church Times._ Marriage
 18277	ads they never try to beautify. Rusty wreaths hung on knobs, garlands of
 18278	bronzefoil. Better value that for the money. Still, the flowers are more
 18279	poetical. The other gets rather tiresome, never withering. Expresses
 18280	nothing. Immortelles.
 18281	
 18282	A bird sat tamely perched on a poplar branch. Like stuffed. Like the
 18283	wedding present alderman Hooper gave us. Hoo! Not a budge out of him.
 18284	Knows there are no catapults to let fly at him. Dead animal even sadder.
 18285	Silly-Milly burying the little dead bird in the kitchen matchbox, a
 18286	daisychain and bits of broken chainies on the grave.
 18287	
 18288	The Sacred Heart that is: showing it. Heart on his sleeve. Ought to be
 18289	sideways and red it should be painted like a real heart. Ireland was
 18290	dedicated to it or whatever that. Seems anything but pleased. Why this
 18291	infliction? Would birds come then and peck like the boy with the basket
 18292	of fruit but he said no because they ought to have been afraid of the
 18293	boy. Apollo that was.
 18294	
 18295	How many! All these here once walked round Dublin. Faithful departed. As
 18296	you are now so once were we.
 18297	
 18298	Besides how could you remember everybody? Eyes, walk, voice. Well, the
 18299	voice, yes: gramophone. Have a gramophone in every grave or keep it in
 18300	the house. After dinner on a Sunday. Put on poor old greatgrandfather.
 18301	Kraahraark! Hellohellohello amawfullyglad kraark awfullygladaseeagain
 18302	hellohello amawf krpthsth. Remind you of the voice like the photograph
 18303	reminds you of the face. Otherwise you couldn't remember the face after
 18304	fifteen years, say. For instance who? For instance some fellow that died
 18305	when I was in Wisdom Hely's.
 18306	
 18307	Rtststr! A rattle of pebbles. Wait. Stop!
 18308	
 18309	He looked down intently into a stone crypt. Some animal. Wait. There he
 18310	goes.
 18311	
 18312	An obese grey rat toddled along the side of the crypt, moving the
 18313	pebbles. An old stager: greatgrandfather: he knows the ropes. The grey
 18314	alive crushed itself in under the plinth, wriggled itself in under it.
 18315	Good hidingplace for treasure.
 18316	
 18317	Who lives there? Are laid the remains of Robert Emery. Robert Emmet was
 18318	buried here by torchlight, wasn't he? Making his rounds.
 18319	
 18320	Tail gone now.
 18321	
 18322	One of those chaps would make short work of a fellow. Pick the bones
 18323	clean no matter who it was. Ordinary meat for them. A corpse is meat
 18324	gone bad. Well and what's cheese? Corpse of milk. I read in that
 18325	_Voyages in China_ that the Chinese say a white man smells like a
 18326	corpse. Cremation better. Priests dead against it. Devilling for the
 18327	other firm. Wholesale burners and Dutch oven dealers. Time of the
 18328	plague. Quicklime feverpits to eat them. Lethal chamber. Ashes to ashes.
 18329	Or bury at sea. Where is that Parsee tower of silence? Eaten by birds.
 18330	Earth, fire, water. Drowning they say is the pleasantest. See your whole
 18331	life in a flash. But being brought back to life no. Can't bury in the
 18332	air however. Out of a flying machine. Wonder does the news go about
 18333	whenever a fresh one is let down. Underground communication. We learned
 18334	that from them. Wouldn't be surprised. Regular square feed for them.
 18335	Flies come before he's well dead. Got wind of Dignam. They wouldn't care
 18336	about the smell of it. Saltwhite crumbling mush of corpse: smell, taste
 18337	like raw white turnips.
 18338	
 18339	The gates glimmered in front: still open. Back to the world again.
 18340	Enough of this place. Brings you a bit nearer every time. Last time I
 18341	was here was Mrs Sinico's funeral. Poor papa too. The love that kills.
 18342	And even scraping up the earth at night with a lantern like that case
 18343	I read of to get at fresh buried females or even putrefied with running
 18344	gravesores. Give you the creeps after a bit. I will appear to you after
 18345	death. You will see my ghost after death. My ghost will haunt you after
 18346	death. There is another world after death named hell. I do not like that
 18347	other world she wrote. No more do I. Plenty to see and hear and feel
 18348	yet. Feel live warm beings near you. Let them sleep in their maggoty
 18349	beds. They are not going to get me this innings. Warm beds: warm
 18350	fullblooded life.
 18351	
 18352	Martin Cunningham emerged from a sidepath, talking gravely.
 18353	
 18354	Solicitor, I think. I know his face. Menton, John Henry, solicitor,
 18355	commissioner for oaths and affidavits. Dignam used to be in his office.
 18356	Mat Dillon's long ago. Jolly Mat. Convivial evenings. Cold fowl, cigars,
 18357	the Tantalus glasses. Heart of gold really. Yes, Menton. Got his rag out
 18358	that evening on the bowlinggreen because I sailed inside him. Pure fluke
 18359	of mine: the bias. Why he took such a rooted dislike to me. Hate
 18360	at first sight. Molly and Floey Dillon linked under the lilactree,
 18361	laughing. Fellow always like that, mortified if women are by.
 18362	
 18363	Got a dinge in the side of his hat. Carriage probably.
 18364	
 18365	--Excuse me, sir, Mr Bloom said beside them.
 18366	
 18367	They stopped.
 18368	
 18369	--Your hat is a little crushed, Mr Bloom said pointing.
 18370	
 18371	John Henry Menton stared at him for an instant without moving.
 18372	
 18373	--There, Martin Cunningham helped, pointing also. John Henry Menton took
 18374	off his hat, bulged out the dinge and smoothed the nap with care on his
 18375	coatsleeve. He clapped the hat on his head again.
 18376	
 18377	--It's all right now, Martin Cunningham said.
 18378	
 18379	John Henry Menton jerked his head down in acknowledgment.
 18380	
 18381	--Thank you, he said shortly.
 18382	
 18383	They walked on towards the gates. Mr Bloom, chapfallen, drew behind
 18384	a few paces so as not to overhear. Martin laying down the law. Martin
 18385	could wind a sappyhead like that round his little finger, without his
 18386	seeing it.
 18387	
 18388	Oyster eyes. Never mind. Be sorry after perhaps when it dawns on him.
 18389	Get the pull over him that way.
 18390	
 18391	Thank you. How grand we are this morning!
 18392	
 18393	
 18394	IN THE HEART OF THE HIBERNIAN METROPOLIS
 18395	
 18396	
 18397	Before Nelson's pillar trams slowed, shunted, changed trolley, started
 18398	for Blackrock, Kingstown and Dalkey, Clonskea, Rathgar and Terenure,
 18399	Palmerston Park and upper Rathmines, Sandymount Green, Rathmines,
 18400	Ringsend and Sandymount Tower, Harold's Cross. The hoarse Dublin United
 18401	Tramway Company's timekeeper bawled them off:
 18402	
 18403	--Rathgar and Terenure!
 18404	
 18405	--Come on, Sandymount Green!
 18406	
 18407	Right and left parallel clanging ringing a doubledecker and a singledeck
 18408	moved from their railheads, swerved to the down line, glided parallel.
 18409	
 18410	--Start, Palmerston Park!
 18411	
 18412	
 18413	THE WEARER OF THE CROWN
 18414	
 18415	
 18416	Under the porch of the general post office shoeblacks called and
 18417	polished. Parked in North Prince's street His Majesty's vermilion
 18418	mailcars, bearing on their sides the royal initials, E. R., received
 18419	loudly flung sacks of letters, postcards, lettercards, parcels, insured
 18420	and paid, for local, provincial, British and overseas delivery.
 18421	
 18422	GENTLEMEN OF THE PRESS
 18423	
 18424	
 18425	Grossbooted draymen rolled barrels dullthudding out of Prince's stores
 18426	and bumped them up on the brewery float. On the brewery float bumped
 18427	dullthudding barrels rolled by grossbooted draymen out of Prince's
 18428	stores.
 18429	
 18430	--There it is, Red Murray said. Alexander Keyes.
 18431	
 18432	--Just cut it out, will you? Mr Bloom said, and I'll take it round to
 18433	the _Telegraph_ office.
 18434	
 18435	The door of Ruttledge's office creaked again. Davy Stephens, minute in a
 18436	large capecoat, a small felt hat crowning his ringlets, passed out with
 18437	a roll of papers under his cape, a king's courier.
 18438	
 18439	Red Murray's long shears sliced out the advertisement from the newspaper
 18440	in four clean strokes. Scissors and paste.
 18441	
 18442	--I'll go through the printingworks, Mr Bloom said, taking the cut
 18443	square.
 18444	
 18445	--Of course, if he wants a par, Red Murray said earnestly, a pen behind
 18446	his ear, we can do him one.
 18447	
 18448	--Right, Mr Bloom said with a nod. I'll rub that in.
 18449	
 18450	We.
 18451	
 18452	WILLIAM BRAYDEN, ESQUIRE, OF OAKLANDS, SANDYMOUNT
 18453	
 18454	
 18455	Red Murray touched Mr Bloom's arm with the shears and whispered:
 18456	
 18457	--Brayden.
 18458	
 18459	Mr Bloom turned and saw the liveried porter raise his lettered cap as a
 18460	stately figure entered between the newsboards of the _Weekly Freeman
 18461	and National Press_ and the _Freeman's Journal and National Press_.
 18462	Dullthudding Guinness's barrels. It passed statelily up the staircase,
 18463	steered by an umbrella, a solemn beardframed face. The broadcloth back
 18464	ascended each step: back. All his brains are in the nape of his neck,
 18465	Simon Dedalus says. Welts of flesh behind on him. Fat folds of neck,
 18466	fat, neck, fat, neck.
 18467	
 18468	--Don't you think his face is like Our Saviour? Red Murray whispered.
 18469	
 18470	The door of Ruttledge's office whispered: ee: cree. They always build
 18471	one door opposite another for the wind to. Way in. Way out.
 18472	
 18473	Our Saviour: beardframed oval face: talking in the dusk. Mary, Martha.
 18474	Steered by an umbrella sword to the footlights: Mario the tenor.
 18475	
 18476	--Or like Mario, Mr Bloom said.
 18477	
 18478	--Yes, Red Murray agreed. But Mario was said to be the picture of Our
 18479	Saviour.
 18480	
 18481	Jesusmario with rougy cheeks, doublet and spindle legs. Hand on his
 18482	heart. In _Martha._
 18483	
 18484	     _Co-ome thou lost one,
 18485	     Co-ome thou dear one!_
 18486	
 18487	THE CROZIER AND THE PEN
 18488	
 18489	
 18490	--His grace phoned down twice this morning, Red Murray said gravely.
 18491	
 18492	They watched the knees, legs, boots vanish. Neck.
 18493	
 18494	A telegram boy stepped in nimbly, threw an envelope on the counter and
 18495	stepped off posthaste with a word:
 18496	
 18497	_--Freeman!_
 18498	
 18499	Mr Bloom said slowly:
 18500	
 18501	--Well, he is one of our saviours also.
 18502	
 18503	A meek smile accompanied him as he lifted the counterflap, as he passed
 18504	in through a sidedoor and along the warm dark stairs and passage,
 18505	along the now reverberating boards. But will he save the circulation?
 18506	Thumping. Thumping.
 18507	
 18508	He pushed in the glass swingdoor and entered, stepping over strewn
 18509	packing paper. Through a lane of clanking drums he made his way towards
 18510	Nannetti's reading closet.
 18511	
 18512	WITH UNFEIGNED REGRET IT IS WE ANNOUNCE THE DISSOLUTION OF A MOST
 18513	RESPECTED DUBLIN BURGESS
 18514	
 18515	
 18516	Hynes here too: account of the funeral probably. Thumping. Thump. This
 18517	morning the remains of the late Mr Patrick Dignam. Machines. Smash a man
 18518	to atoms if they got him caught. Rule the world today. His machineries
 18519	are pegging away too. Like these, got out of hand: fermenting. Working
 18520	away, tearing away. And that old grey rat tearing to get in.
 18521	
 18522	HOW A GREAT DAILY ORGAN IS TURNED OUT
 18523	
 18524	
 18525	Mr Bloom halted behind the foreman's spare body, admiring a glossy
 18526	crown.
 18527	
 18528	Strange he never saw his real country. Ireland my country. Member for
 18529	College green. He boomed that workaday worker tack for all it was worth.
 18530	It's the ads and side features sell a weekly, not the stale news in the
 18531	official gazette. Queen Anne is dead. Published by authority in the year
 18532	one thousand and. Demesne situate in the townland of Rosenallis, barony
 18533	of Tinnahinch. To all whom it may concern schedule pursuant to statute
 18534	showing return of number of mules and jennets exported from Ballina.
 18535	Nature notes. Cartoons. Phil Blake's weekly Pat and Bull story. Uncle
 18536	Toby's page for tiny tots. Country bumpkin's queries. Dear Mr Editor,
 18537	what is a good cure for flatulence? I'd like that part. Learn a lot
 18538	teaching others. The personal note. M. A. P. Mainly all pictures.
 18539	Shapely bathers on golden strand. World's biggest balloon. Double
 18540	marriage of sisters celebrated. Two bridegrooms laughing heartily at
 18541	each other. Cuprani too, printer. More Irish than the Irish.
 18542	
 18543	The machines clanked in threefour time. Thump, thump, thump. Now if he
 18544	got paralysed there and no-one knew how to stop them they'd clank on and
 18545	on the same, print it over and over and up and back. Monkeydoodle the
 18546	whole thing. Want a cool head.
 18547	
 18548	--Well, get it into the evening edition, councillor, Hynes said.
 18549	
 18550	Soon be calling him my lord mayor. Long John is backing him, they say.
 18551	
 18552	The foreman, without answering, scribbled press on a corner of the sheet
 18553	and made a sign to a typesetter. He handed the sheet silently over the
 18554	dirty glass screen.
 18555	
 18556	--Right: thanks, Hynes said moving off.
 18557	
 18558	Mr Bloom stood in his way.
 18559	
 18560	--If you want to draw the cashier is just going to lunch, he said,
 18561	pointing backward with his thumb.
 18562	
 18563	--Did you? Hynes asked.
 18564	
 18565	--Mm, Mr Bloom said. Look sharp and you'll catch him.
 18566	
 18567	--Thanks, old man, Hynes said. I'll tap him too.
 18568	
 18569	He hurried on eagerly towards the _Freeman's Journal_.
 18570	
 18571	Three bob I lent him in Meagher's. Three weeks. Third hint.
 18572	
 18573	WE SEE THE CANVASSER AT WORK
 18574	
 18575	
 18576	Mr Bloom laid his cutting on Mr Nannetti's desk.
 18577	
 18578	--Excuse me, councillor, he said. This ad, you see. Keyes, you remember?
 18579	
 18580	Mr Nannetti considered the cutting awhile and nodded.
 18581	
 18582	--He wants it in for July, Mr Bloom said.
 18583	
 18584	The foreman moved his pencil towards it.
 18585	
 18586	--But wait, Mr Bloom said. He wants it changed. Keyes, you see. He wants
 18587	two keys at the top.
 18588	
 18589	Hell of a racket they make. He doesn't hear it. Nannan. Iron nerves.
 18590	Maybe he understands what I.
 18591	
 18592	The foreman turned round to hear patiently and, lifting an elbow, began
 18593	to scratch slowly in the armpit of his alpaca jacket.
 18594	
 18595	--Like that, Mr Bloom said, crossing his forefingers at the top.
 18596	
 18597	Let him take that in first.
 18598	
 18599	Mr Bloom, glancing sideways up from the cross he had made, saw the
 18600	foreman's sallow face, think he has a touch of jaundice, and beyond the
 18601	obedient reels feeding in huge webs of paper. Clank it. Clank it. Miles
 18602	of it unreeled. What becomes of it after? O, wrap up meat, parcels:
 18603	various uses, thousand and one things.
 18604	
 18605	Slipping his words deftly into the pauses of the clanking he drew
 18606	swiftly on the scarred woodwork.
 18607	
 18608	HOUSE OF KEY(E)S
 18609	
 18610	
 18611	--Like that, see. Two crossed keys here. A circle. Then here the name.
 18612	Alexander Keyes, tea, wine and spirit merchant. So on.
 18613	
 18614	Better not teach him his own business.
 18615	
 18616	--You know yourself, councillor, just what he wants. Then round the top
 18617	in leaded: the house of keys. You see? Do you think that's a good idea?
 18618	
 18619	The foreman moved his scratching hand to his lower ribs and scratched
 18620	there quietly.
 18621	
 18622	--The idea, Mr Bloom said, is the house of keys. You know, councillor,
 18623	the Manx parliament. Innuendo of home rule. Tourists, you know, from the
 18624	isle of Man. Catches the eye, you see. Can you do that?
 18625	
 18626	I could ask him perhaps about how to pronounce that _voglio._ But then
 18627	if he didn't know only make it awkward for him. Better not.
 18628	
 18629	--We can do that, the foreman said. Have you the design?
 18630	
 18631	--I can get it, Mr Bloom said. It was in a Kilkenny paper. He has a
 18632	house there too. I'll just run out and ask him. Well, you can do that
 18633	and just a little par calling attention. You know the usual. Highclass
 18634	licensed premises. Longfelt want. So on.
 18635	
 18636	The foreman thought for an instant.
 18637	
 18638	--We can do that, he said. Let him give us a three months' renewal.
 18639	
 18640	A typesetter brought him a limp galleypage. He began to check it
 18641	silently. Mr Bloom stood by, hearing the loud throbs of cranks, watching
 18642	the silent typesetters at their cases.
 18643	
 18644	ORTHOGRAPHICAL
 18645	
 18646	
 18647	Want to be sure of his spelling. Proof fever. Martin Cunningham forgot
 18648	to give us his spellingbee conundrum this morning. It is amusing to view
 18649	the unpar one ar alleled embarra two ars is it? double ess ment of a
 18650	harassed pedlar while gauging au the symmetry with a y of a peeled pear
 18651	under a cemetery wall. Silly, isn't it? Cemetery put in of course on
 18652	account of the symmetry.
 18653	
 18654	I should have said when he clapped on his topper. Thank you. I ought
 18655	to have said something about an old hat or something. No. I could have
 18656	said. Looks as good as new now. See his phiz then.
 18657	
 18658	Sllt. The nethermost deck of the first machine jogged forward its
 18659	flyboard with sllt the first batch of quirefolded papers. Sllt. Almost
 18660	human the way it sllt to call attention. Doing its level best to speak.
 18661	That door too sllt creaking, asking to be shut. Everything speaks in its
 18662	own way. Sllt.
 18663	
 18664	NOTED CHURCHMAN AN OCCASIONAL CONTRIBUTOR
 18665	
 18666	
 18667	The foreman handed back the galleypage suddenly, saying:
 18668	
 18669	--Wait. Where's the archbishop's letter? It's to be repeated in the
 18670	_Telegraph._ Where's what's his name?
 18671	
 18672	He looked about him round his loud unanswering machines.
 18673	
 18674	--Monks, sir? a voice asked from the castingbox.
 18675	
 18676	--Ay. Where's Monks?
 18677	
 18678	--Monks!
 18679	
 18680	Mr Bloom took up his cutting. Time to get out.
 18681	
 18682	--Then I'll get the design, Mr Nannetti, he said, and you'll give it a
 18683	good place I know.
 18684	
 18685	--Monks!
 18686	
 18687	--Yes, sir.
 18688	
 18689	Three months' renewal. Want to get some wind off my chest first. Try it
 18690	anyhow. Rub in August: good idea: horseshow month. Ballsbridge. Tourists
 18691	over for the show.
 18692	
 18693	A DAYFATHER
 18694	
 18695	
 18696	He walked on through the caseroom passing an old man, bowed, spectacled,
 18697	aproned. Old Monks, the dayfather. Queer lot of stuff he must have put
 18698	through his hands in his time: obituary notices, pubs' ads, speeches,
 18699	divorce suits, found drowned. Nearing the end of his tether now. Sober
 18700	serious man with a bit in the savingsbank I'd say. Wife a good cook and
 18701	washer. Daughter working the machine in the parlour. Plain Jane, no damn
 18702	nonsense. AND IT WAS THE FEAST OF THE PASSOVER
 18703	
 18704	
 18705	He stayed in his walk to watch a typesetter neatly distributing type.
 18706	Reads it backwards first. Quickly he does it. Must require some practice
 18707	that. mangiD kcirtaP. Poor papa with his hagadah book, reading backwards
 18708	with his finger to me. Pessach. Next year in Jerusalem. Dear, O dear!
 18709	All that long business about that brought us out of the land of Egypt
 18710	and into the house of bondage _Alleluia. Shema Israel Adonai Elohenu_.
 18711	No, that's the other. Then the twelve brothers, Jacob's sons. And then
 18712	the lamb and the cat and the dog and the stick and the water and the
 18713	butcher. And then the angel of death kills the butcher and he kills the
 18714	ox and the dog kills the cat. Sounds a bit silly till you come to look
 18715	into it well. Justice it means but it's everybody eating everyone else.
 18716	That's what life is after all. How quickly he does that job. Practice
 18717	makes perfect. Seems to see with his fingers.
 18718	
 18719	Mr Bloom passed on out of the clanking noises through the gallery on to
 18720	the landing. Now am I going to tram it out all the way and then catch
 18721	him out perhaps. Better phone him up first. Number? Yes. Same as
 18722	Citron's house. Twentyeight. Twentyeight double four.
 18723	
 18724	ONLY ONCE MORE THAT SOAP
 18725	
 18726	
 18727	He went down the house staircase. Who the deuce scrawled all over those
 18728	walls with matches? Looks as if they did it for a bet. Heavy greasy
 18729	smell there always is in those works. Lukewarm glue in Thom's next door
 18730	when I was there.
 18731	
 18732	He took out his handkerchief to dab his nose. Citronlemon? Ah, the soap
 18733	I put there. Lose it out of that pocket. Putting back his handkerchief
 18734	he took out the soap and stowed it away, buttoned, into the hip pocket
 18735	of his trousers.
 18736	
 18737	What perfume does your wife use? I could go home still: tram: something
 18738	I forgot. Just to see: before: dressing. No. Here. No.
 18739	
 18740	A sudden screech of laughter came from the _Evening Telegraph_ office.
 18741	Know who that is. What's up? Pop in a minute to phone. Ned Lambert it
 18742	is.
 18743	
 18744	He entered softly.
 18745	
 18746	ERIN, GREEN GEM OF THE SILVER SEA
 18747	
 18748	
 18749	--The ghost walks, professor MacHugh murmured softly, biscuitfully to
 18750	the dusty windowpane.
 18751	
 18752	Mr Dedalus, staring from the empty fireplace at Ned Lambert's quizzing
 18753	face, asked of it sourly:
 18754	
 18755	--Agonising Christ, wouldn't it give you a heartburn on your arse?
 18756	
 18757	Ned Lambert, seated on the table, read on:
 18758	
 18759	--_Or again, note the meanderings of some purling rill as it babbles
 18760	on its way, tho' quarrelling with the stony obstacles, to the tumbling
 18761	waters of Neptune's blue domain, 'mid mossy banks, fanned by gentlest
 18762	zephyrs, played on by the glorious sunlight or 'neath the shadows cast
 18763	o'er its pensive bosom by the overarching leafage of the giants of
 18764	the forest_. What about that, Simon? he asked over the fringe of his
 18765	newspaper. How's that for high?
 18766	
 18767	--Changing his drink, Mr Dedalus said.
 18768	
 18769	Ned Lambert, laughing, struck the newspaper on his knees, repeating:
 18770	
 18771	--_The pensive bosom and the overarsing leafage_. O boys! O boys!
 18772	
 18773	--And Xenophon looked upon Marathon, Mr Dedalus said, looking again on
 18774	the fireplace and to the window, and Marathon looked on the sea.
 18775	
 18776	--That will do, professor MacHugh cried from the window. I don't want to
 18777	hear any more of the stuff.
 18778	
 18779	He ate off the crescent of water biscuit he had been nibbling and,
 18780	hungered, made ready to nibble the biscuit in his other hand.
 18781	
 18782	High falutin stuff. Bladderbags. Ned Lambert is taking a day off I see.
 18783	Rather upsets a man's day, a funeral does. He has influence they
 18784	say. Old Chatterton, the vicechancellor, is his granduncle or his
 18785	greatgranduncle. Close on ninety they say. Subleader for his death
 18786	written this long time perhaps. Living to spite them. Might go first
 18787	himself. Johnny, make room for your uncle. The right honourable Hedges
 18788	Eyre Chatterton. Daresay he writes him an odd shaky cheque or two on
 18789	gale days. Windfall when he kicks out. Alleluia.
 18790	
 18791	--Just another spasm, Ned Lambert said.
 18792	
 18793	--What is it? Mr Bloom asked.
 18794	
 18795	--A recently discovered fragment of Cicero, professor MacHugh answered
 18796	with pomp of tone. _Our lovely land_. SHORT BUT TO THE POINT
 18797	
 18798	
 18799	--Whose land? Mr Bloom said simply.
 18800	
 18801	--Most pertinent question, the professor said between his chews. With an
 18802	accent on the whose.
 18803	
 18804	--Dan Dawson's land Mr Dedalus said.
 18805	
 18806	--Is it his speech last night? Mr Bloom asked.
 18807	
 18808	Ned Lambert nodded.
 18809	
 18810	--But listen to this, he said.
 18811	
 18812	The doorknob hit Mr Bloom in the small of the back as the door was
 18813	pushed in.
 18814	
 18815	--Excuse me, J. J. O'Molloy said, entering.
 18816	
 18817	Mr Bloom moved nimbly aside.
 18818	
 18819	--I beg yours, he said.
 18820	
 18821	--Good day, Jack.
 18822	
 18823	--Come in. Come in.
 18824	
 18825	--Good day.
 18826	
 18827	--How are you, Dedalus?
 18828	
 18829	--Well. And yourself?
 18830	
 18831	J. J. O'Molloy shook his head.
 18832	
 18833	SAD
 18834	
 18835	
 18836	Cleverest fellow at the junior bar he used to be. Decline, poor chap.
 18837	That hectic flush spells finis for a man. Touch and go with him. What's
 18838	in the wind, I wonder. Money worry.
 18839	
 18840	--_Or again if we but climb the serried mountain peaks._
 18841	
 18842	--You're looking extra.
 18843	
 18844	--Is the editor to be seen? J. J. O'Molloy asked, looking towards the
 18845	inner door.
 18846	
 18847	--Very much so, professor MacHugh said. To be seen and heard. He's in
 18848	his sanctum with Lenehan.
 18849	
 18850	J. J. O'Molloy strolled to the sloping desk and began to turn back the
 18851	pink pages of the file.
 18852	
 18853	Practice dwindling. A mighthavebeen. Losing heart. Gambling. Debts of
 18854	honour. Reaping the whirlwind. Used to get good retainers from D. and T.
 18855	Fitzgerald. Their wigs to show the grey matter. Brains on their sleeve
 18856	like the statue in Glasnevin. Believe he does some literary work for the
 18857	_Express_ with Gabriel Conroy. Wellread fellow. Myles Crawford began
 18858	on the _Independent._ Funny the way those newspaper men veer about when
 18859	they get wind of a new opening. Weathercocks. Hot and cold in the same
 18860	breath. Wouldn't know which to believe. One story good till you hear
 18861	the next. Go for one another baldheaded in the papers and then all blows
 18862	over. Hail fellow well met the next moment.
 18863	
 18864	--Ah, listen to this for God' sake, Ned Lambert pleaded. _Or again if we
 18865	but climb the serried mountain peaks..._
 18866	
 18867	--Bombast! the professor broke in testily. Enough of the inflated
 18868	windbag!
 18869	
 18870	--_Peaks_, Ned Lambert went on, _towering high on high, to bathe our
 18871	souls, as it were..._
 18872	
 18873	--Bathe his lips, Mr Dedalus said. Blessed and eternal God! Yes? Is he
 18874	taking anything for it?
 18875	
 18876	_--As 'twere, in the peerless panorama of Ireland's portfolio,
 18877	unmatched, despite their wellpraised prototypes in other vaunted prize
 18878	regions, for very beauty, of bosky grove and undulating plain and
 18879	luscious pastureland of vernal green, steeped in the transcendent
 18880	translucent glow of our mild mysterious Irish twilight..._
 18881	
 18882	HIS NATIVE DORIC
 18883	
 18884	
 18885	--The moon, professor MacHugh said. He forgot Hamlet.
 18886	
 18887	_--That mantles the vista far and wide and wait till the glowing orb of
 18888	the moon shine forth to irradiate her silver effulgence..._
 18889	
 18890	--O! Mr Dedalus cried, giving vent to a hopeless groan. Shite and
 18891	onions! That'll do, Ned. Life is too short.
 18892	
 18893	He took off his silk hat and, blowing out impatiently his bushy
 18894	moustache, welshcombed his hair with raking fingers.
 18895	
 18896	Ned Lambert tossed the newspaper aside, chuckling with delight. An
 18897	instant after a hoarse bark of laughter burst over professor MacHugh's
 18898	unshaven blackspectacled face.
 18899	
 18900	--Doughy Daw! he cried.
 18901	
 18902	WHAT WETHERUP SAID
 18903	
 18904	
 18905	All very fine to jeer at it now in cold print but it goes down like hot
 18906	cake that stuff. He was in the bakery line too, wasn't he? Why they call
 18907	him Doughy Daw. Feathered his nest well anyhow. Daughter engaged to that
 18908	chap in the inland revenue office with the motor. Hooked that nicely.
 18909	Entertainments. Open house. Big blowout. Wetherup always said that. Get
 18910	a grip of them by the stomach.
 18911	
 18912	The inner door was opened violently and a scarlet beaked face, crested
 18913	by a comb of feathery hair, thrust itself in. The bold blue eyes stared
 18914	about them and the harsh voice asked:
 18915	
 18916	--What is it?
 18917	
 18918	--And here comes the sham squire himself! professor MacHugh said
 18919	grandly.
 18920	
 18921	--Getonouthat, you bloody old pedagogue! the editor said in recognition.
 18922	
 18923	--Come, Ned, Mr Dedalus said, putting on his hat. I must get a drink
 18924	after that.
 18925	
 18926	--Drink! the editor cried. No drinks served before mass.
 18927	
 18928	--Quite right too, Mr Dedalus said, going out. Come on, Ned.
 18929	
 18930	Ned Lambert sidled down from the table. The editor's blue eyes roved
 18931	towards Mr Bloom's face, shadowed by a smile.
 18932	
 18933	--Will you join us, Myles? Ned Lambert asked.
 18934	
 18935	MEMORABLE BATTLES RECALLED
 18936	
 18937	
 18938	--North Cork militia! the editor cried, striding to the mantelpiece. We
 18939	won every time! North Cork and Spanish officers!
 18940	
 18941	--Where was that, Myles? Ned Lambert asked with a reflective glance at
 18942	his toecaps.
 18943	
 18944	--In Ohio! the editor shouted.
 18945	
 18946	--So it was, begad, Ned Lambert agreed.
 18947	
 18948	Passing out he whispered to J. J. O'Molloy:
 18949	
 18950	--Incipient jigs. Sad case.
 18951	
 18952	--Ohio! the editor crowed in high treble from his uplifted scarlet face.
 18953	My Ohio!
 18954	
 18955	--A perfect cretic! the professor said. Long, short and long.
 18956	
 18957	O, HARP EOLIAN!
 18958	
 18959	
 18960	He took a reel of dental floss from his waistcoat pocket and, breaking
 18961	off a piece, twanged it smartly between two and two of his resonant
 18962	unwashed teeth.
 18963	
 18964	--Bingbang, bangbang.
 18965	
 18966	Mr Bloom, seeing the coast clear, made for the inner door.
 18967	
 18968	--Just a moment, Mr Crawford, he said. I just want to phone about an ad.
 18969	
 18970	He went in.
 18971	
 18972	--What about that leader this evening? professor MacHugh asked, coming
 18973	to the editor and laying a firm hand on his shoulder.
 18974	
 18975	--That'll be all right, Myles Crawford said more calmly. Never you fret.
 18976	Hello, Jack. That's all right.
 18977	
 18978	--Good day, Myles, J. J. O'Molloy said, letting the pages he held slip
 18979	limply back on the file. Is that Canada swindle case on today?
 18980	
 18981	The telephone whirred inside.
 18982	
 18983	--Twentyeight... No, twenty... Double four... Yes.
 18984	
 18985	SPOT THE WINNER
 18986	
 18987	
 18988	Lenehan came out of the inner office with SPORT'S tissues.
 18989	
 18990	--Who wants a dead cert for the Gold cup? he asked. Sceptre with O.
 18991	Madden up.
 18992	
 18993	He tossed the tissues on to the table.
 18994	
 18995	Screams of newsboys barefoot in the hall rushed near and the door was
 18996	flung open.
 18997	
 18998	--Hush, Lenehan said. I hear feetstoops.
 18999	
 19000	Professor MacHugh strode across the room and seized the cringing urchin
 19001	by the collar as the others scampered out of the hall and down the
 19002	steps. The tissues rustled up in the draught, floated softly in the air
 19003	blue scrawls and under the table came to earth.
 19004	
 19005	--It wasn't me, sir. It was the big fellow shoved me, sir.
 19006	
 19007	--Throw him out and shut the door, the editor said. There's a hurricane
 19008	blowing.
 19009	
 19010	Lenehan began to paw the tissues up from the floor, grunting as he
 19011	stooped twice.
 19012	
 19013	--Waiting for the racing special, sir, the newsboy said. It was Pat
 19014	Farrell shoved me, sir.
 19015	
 19016	He pointed to two faces peering in round the doorframe.
 19017	
 19018	--Him, sir.
 19019	
 19020	--Out of this with you, professor MacHugh said gruffly.
 19021	
 19022	He hustled the boy out and banged the door to.
 19023	
 19024	J. J. O'Molloy turned the files crackingly over, murmuring, seeking:
 19025	
 19026	--Continued on page six, column four.
 19027	
 19028	--Yes, _Evening Telegraph_ here, Mr Bloom phoned from the inner office.
 19029	Is the boss...? Yes, _Telegraph_... To where? Aha! Which auction rooms
 19030	?... Aha! I see... Right. I'll catch him.
 19031	
 19032	A COLLISION ENSUES
 19033	
 19034	
 19035	The bell whirred again as he rang off. He came in quickly and bumped
 19036	against Lenehan who was struggling up with the second tissue.
 19037	
 19038	--_Pardon, monsieur_, Lenehan said, clutching him for an instant and
 19039	making a grimace.
 19040	
 19041	--My fault, Mr Bloom said, suffering his grip. Are you hurt? I'm in a
 19042	hurry.
 19043	
 19044	--Knee, Lenehan said.
 19045	
 19046	He made a comic face and whined, rubbing his knee:
 19047	
 19048	--The accumulation of the _anno Domini_.
 19049	
 19050	--Sorry, Mr Bloom said.
 19051	
 19052	He went to the door and, holding it ajar, paused. J. J. O'Molloy slapped
 19053	the heavy pages over. The noise of two shrill voices, a mouthorgan,
 19054	echoed in the bare hallway from the newsboys squatted on the doorsteps:
 19055	
 19056	     _--We are the boys of Wexford
 19057	     Who fought with heart and hand._
 19058	
 19059	EXIT BLOOM
 19060	
 19061	
 19062	--I'm just running round to Bachelor's walk, Mr Bloom said, about this
 19063	ad of Keyes's. Want to fix it up. They tell me he's round there in
 19064	Dillon's.
 19065	
 19066	He looked indecisively for a moment at their faces. The editor who,
 19067	leaning against the mantelshelf, had propped his head on his hand,
 19068	suddenly stretched forth an arm amply.
 19069	
 19070	--Begone! he said. The world is before you.
 19071	
 19072	--Back in no time, Mr Bloom said, hurrying out.
 19073	
 19074	J. J. O'Molloy took the tissues from Lenehan's hand and read them,
 19075	blowing them apart gently, without comment.
 19076	
 19077	--He'll get that advertisement, the professor said, staring through his
 19078	blackrimmed spectacles over the crossblind. Look at the young scamps
 19079	after him.
 19080	
 19081	--Show. Where? Lenehan cried, running to the window.
 19082	
 19083	A STREET CORTEGE
 19084	
 19085	
 19086	Both smiled over the crossblind at the file of capering newsboys in Mr
 19087	Bloom's wake, the last zigzagging white on the breeze a mocking kite, a
 19088	tail of white bowknots.
 19089	
 19090	--Look at the young guttersnipe behind him hue and cry, Lenehan said,
 19091	and you'll kick. O, my rib risible! Taking off his flat spaugs and the
 19092	walk. Small nines. Steal upon larks.
 19093	
 19094	He began to mazurka in swift caricature across the floor on sliding
 19095	feet past the fireplace to J. J. O'Molloy who placed the tissues in his
 19096	receiving hands.
 19097	
 19098	--What's that? Myles Crawford said with a start. Where are the other two
 19099	gone?
 19100	
 19101	--Who? the professor said, turning. They're gone round to the Oval for a
 19102	drink. Paddy Hooper is there with Jack Hall. Came over last night.
 19103	
 19104	--Come on then, Myles Crawford said. Where's my hat?
 19105	
 19106	He walked jerkily into the office behind, parting the vent of his
 19107	jacket, jingling his keys in his back pocket. They jingled then in the
 19108	air and against the wood as he locked his desk drawer.
 19109	
 19110	--He's pretty well on, professor MacHugh said in a low voice.
 19111	
 19112	--Seems to be, J. J. O'Molloy said, taking out a cigarettecase in
 19113	murmuring meditation, but it is not always as it seems. Who has the most
 19114	matches?
 19115	
 19116	THE CALUMET OF PEACE
 19117	
 19118	
 19119	He offered a cigarette to the professor and took one himself. Lenehan
 19120	promptly struck a match for them and lit their cigarettes in turn. J. J.
 19121	O'Molloy opened his case again and offered it.
 19122	
 19123	--_Thanky vous_, Lenehan said, helping himself.
 19124	
 19125	The editor came from the inner office, a straw hat awry on his brow. He
 19126	declaimed in song, pointing sternly at professor MacHugh:
 19127	
 19128	_--'Twas rank and fame that tempted thee, 'Twas empire charmed thy
 19129	heart._
 19130	
 19131	The professor grinned, locking his long lips.
 19132	
 19133	--Eh? You bloody old Roman empire? Myles Crawford said.
 19134	
 19135	He took a cigarette from the open case. Lenehan, lighting it for him
 19136	with quick grace, said:
 19137	
 19138	--Silence for my brandnew riddle!
 19139	
 19140	--_Imperium romanum_, J. J. O'Molloy said gently. It sounds nobler than
 19141	British or Brixton. The word reminds one somehow of fat in the fire.
 19142	
 19143	Myles Crawford blew his first puff violently towards the ceiling.
 19144	
 19145	--That's it, he said. We are the fat. You and I are the fat in the fire.
 19146	We haven't got the chance of a snowball in hell.
 19147	
 19148	THE GRANDEUR THAT WAS ROME
 19149	
 19150	
 19151	--Wait a moment, professor MacHugh said, raising two quiet claws. We
 19152	mustn't be led away by words, by sounds of words. We think of Rome,
 19153	imperial, imperious, imperative.
 19154	
 19155	He extended elocutionary arms from frayed stained shirtcuffs, pausing:
 19156	
 19157	--What was their civilisation? Vast, I allow: but vile. Cloacae: sewers.
 19158	The Jews in the wilderness and on the mountaintop said: _It is meet
 19159	to be here. Let us build an altar to Jehovah_. The Roman, like the
 19160	Englishman who follows in his footsteps, brought to every new shore on
 19161	which he set his foot (on our shore he never set it) only his cloacal
 19162	obsession. He gazed about him in his toga and he said: _It is meet to be
 19163	here. Let us construct a watercloset._
 19164	
 19165	--Which they accordingly did do, Lenehan said. Our old ancient
 19166	ancestors, as we read in the first chapter of Guinness's, were partial
 19167	to the running stream.
 19168	
 19169	--They were nature's gentlemen, J. J. O'Molloy murmured. But we have
 19170	also Roman law.
 19171	
 19172	--And Pontius Pilate is its prophet, professor MacHugh responded.
 19173	
 19174	--Do you know that story about chief baron Palles? J. J. O'Molloy asked.
 19175	It was at the royal university dinner. Everything was going swimmingly
 19176	...
 19177	
 19178	--First my riddle, Lenehan said. Are you ready?
 19179	
 19180	Mr O'Madden Burke, tall in copious grey of Donegal tweed, came in from
 19181	the hallway. Stephen Dedalus, behind him, uncovered as he entered.
 19182	
 19183	--_Entrez, mes enfants!_ Lenehan cried.
 19184	
 19185	--I escort a suppliant, Mr O'Madden Burke said melodiously. Youth led by
 19186	Experience visits Notoriety.
 19187	
 19188	--How do you do? the editor said, holding out a hand. Come in. Your
 19189	governor is just gone.???
 19190	
 19191	
 19192	Lenehan said to all:
 19193	
 19194	--Silence! What opera resembles a railwayline? Reflect, ponder,
 19195	excogitate, reply.
 19196	
 19197	Stephen handed over the typed sheets, pointing to the title and
 19198	signature.
 19199	
 19200	--Who? the editor asked.
 19201	
 19202	Bit torn off.
 19203	
 19204	--Mr Garrett Deasy, Stephen said.
 19205	
 19206	--That old pelters, the editor said. Who tore it? Was he short taken?
 19207	
 19208	     _On swift sail flaming
 19209	     From storm and south
 19210	     He comes, pale vampire,
 19211	     Mouth to my mouth._
 19212	
 19213	--Good day, Stephen, the professor said, coming to peer over their
 19214	shoulders. Foot and mouth? Are you turned...?
 19215	
 19216	Bullockbefriending bard.
 19217	
 19218	SHINDY IN WELLKNOWN RESTAURANT
 19219	
 19220	
 19221	--Good day, sir, Stephen answered blushing. The letter is not mine. Mr
 19222	Garrett Deasy asked me to...
 19223	
 19224	--O, I know him, Myles Crawford said, and I knew his wife too. The
 19225	bloodiest old tartar God ever made. By Jesus, she had the foot and mouth
 19226	disease and no mistake! The night she threw the soup in the waiter's
 19227	face in the Star and Garter. Oho!
 19228	
 19229	A woman brought sin into the world. For Helen, the runaway wife of
 19230	Menelaus, ten years the Greeks. O'Rourke, prince of Breffni.
 19231	
 19232	--Is he a widower? Stephen asked.
 19233	
 19234	--Ay, a grass one, Myles Crawford said, his eye running down the
 19235	typescript. Emperor's horses. Habsburg. An Irishman saved his life on
 19236	the ramparts of Vienna. Don't you forget! Maximilian Karl O'Donnell,
 19237	graf von Tirconnell in Ireland. Sent his heir over to make the king
 19238	an Austrian fieldmarshal now. Going to be trouble there one day. Wild
 19239	geese. O yes, every time. Don't you forget that!
 19240	
 19241	--The moot point is did he forget it, J. J. O'Molloy said quietly,
 19242	turning a horseshoe paperweight. Saving princes is a thank you job.
 19243	
 19244	Professor MacHugh turned on him.
 19245	
 19246	--And if not? he said.
 19247	
 19248	--I'll tell you how it was, Myles Crawford began. A Hungarian it was one
 19249	day... LOST CAUSES
 19250	
 19251	NOBLE MARQUESS MENTIONED
 19252	
 19253	
 19254	--We were always loyal to lost causes, the professor said. Success for
 19255	us is the death of the intellect and of the imagination. We were never
 19256	loyal to the successful. We serve them. I teach the blatant Latin
 19257	language. I speak the tongue of a race the acme of whose mentality is
 19258	the maxim: time is money. Material domination. _Dominus!_ Lord! Where is
 19259	the spirituality? Lord Jesus? Lord Salisbury? A sofa in a westend club.
 19260	But the Greek!
 19261	
 19262	KYRIE ELEISON!
 19263	
 19264	
 19265	A smile of light brightened his darkrimmed eyes, lengthened his long
 19266	lips.
 19267	
 19268	--The Greek! he said again. _Kyrios!_ Shining word! The vowels the
 19269	Semite and the Saxon know not. _Kyrie!_ The radiance of the intellect.
 19270	I ought to profess Greek, the language of the mind. _Kyrie eleison!_ The
 19271	closetmaker and the cloacamaker will never be lords of our spirit. We
 19272	are liege subjects of the catholic chivalry of Europe that foundered at
 19273	Trafalgar and of the empire of the spirit, not an _imperium,_ that
 19274	went under with the Athenian fleets at Aegospotami. Yes, yes. They went
 19275	under. Pyrrhus, misled by an oracle, made a last attempt to retrieve the
 19276	fortunes of Greece. Loyal to a lost cause.
 19277	
 19278	He strode away from them towards the window.
 19279	
 19280	--They went forth to battle, Mr O'Madden Burke said greyly, but they
 19281	always fell.
 19282	
 19283	--Boohoo! Lenehan wept with a little noise. Owing to a brick received in
 19284	the latter half of the _matinÃ©e_. Poor, poor, poor Pyrrhus!
 19285	
 19286	He whispered then near Stephen's ear:
 19287	
 19288	LENEHAN'S LIMERICK
 19289	
 19290	
 19291	     _There's a ponderous pundit MacHugh
 19292	     Who wears goggles of ebony hue.
 19293	     As he mostly sees double
 19294	     To wear them why trouble?
 19295	     I can't see the Joe Miller. Can you?_
 19296	
 19297	In mourning for Sallust, Mulligan says. Whose mother is beastly dead.
 19298	
 19299	Myles Crawford crammed the sheets into a sidepocket.
 19300	
 19301	--That'll be all right, he said. I'll read the rest after. That'll be
 19302	all right.
 19303	
 19304	Lenehan extended his hands in protest.
 19305	
 19306	--But my riddle! he said. What opera is like a railwayline?
 19307	
 19308	--Opera? Mr O'Madden Burke's sphinx face reriddled.
 19309	
 19310	Lenehan announced gladly:
 19311	
 19312	--_The Rose of Castile_. See the wheeze? Rows of cast steel. Gee!
 19313	
 19314	He poked Mr O'Madden Burke mildly in the spleen. Mr O'Madden Burke fell
 19315	back with grace on his umbrella, feigning a gasp.
 19316	
 19317	--Help! he sighed. I feel a strong weakness.
 19318	
 19319	Lenehan, rising to tiptoe, fanned his face rapidly with the rustling
 19320	tissues.
 19321	
 19322	The professor, returning by way of the files, swept his hand across
 19323	Stephen's and Mr O'Madden Burke's loose ties.
 19324	
 19325	--Paris, past and present, he said. You look like communards.
 19326	
 19327	--Like fellows who had blown up the Bastile, J. J. O'Molloy said in
 19328	quiet mockery. Or was it you shot the lord lieutenant of Finland between
 19329	you? You look as though you had done the deed. General Bobrikoff.
 19330	
 19331	OMNIUM GATHERUM
 19332	
 19333	
 19334	--We were only thinking about it, Stephen said.
 19335	
 19336	--All the talents, Myles Crawford said. Law, the classics...
 19337	
 19338	--The turf, Lenehan put in.
 19339	
 19340	--Literature, the press.
 19341	
 19342	--If Bloom were here, the professor said. The gentle art of
 19343	advertisement.
 19344	
 19345	--And Madam Bloom, Mr O'Madden Burke added. The vocal muse. Dublin's
 19346	prime favourite.
 19347	
 19348	Lenehan gave a loud cough.
 19349	
 19350	--Ahem! he said very softly. O, for a fresh of breath air! I caught a
 19351	cold in the park. The gate was open.
 19352	
 19353	YOU CAN DO IT!
 19354	
 19355	
 19356	The editor laid a nervous hand on Stephen's shoulder.
 19357	
 19358	--I want you to write something for me, he said. Something with a bite
 19359	in it. You can do it. I see it in your face. _In the lexicon of youth_
 19360	...
 19361	
 19362	See it in your face. See it in your eye. Lazy idle little schemer.
 19363	
 19364	--Foot and mouth disease! the editor cried in scornful invective. Great
 19365	nationalist meeting in Borris-in-Ossory. All balls! Bulldosing the
 19366	public! Give them something with a bite in it. Put us all into it, damn
 19367	its soul. Father, Son and Holy Ghost and Jakes M'Carthy.
 19368	
 19369	--We can all supply mental pabulum, Mr O'Madden Burke said.
 19370	
 19371	Stephen raised his eyes to the bold unheeding stare.
 19372	
 19373	--He wants you for the pressgang, J. J. O'Molloy said.
 19374	
 19375	THE GREAT GALLAHER
 19376	
 19377	
 19378	--You can do it, Myles Crawford repeated, clenching his hand in
 19379	emphasis. Wait a minute. We'll paralyse Europe as Ignatius Gallaher
 19380	used to say when he was on the shaughraun, doing billiardmarking in the
 19381	Clarence. Gallaher, that was a pressman for you. That was a pen. You
 19382	know how he made his mark? I'll tell you. That was the smartest piece of
 19383	journalism ever known. That was in eightyone, sixth of May, time of
 19384	the invincibles, murder in the Phoenix park, before you were born, I
 19385	suppose. I'll show you.
 19386	
 19387	He pushed past them to the files.
 19388	
 19389	--Look at here, he said turning. The _New York World_ cabled for a
 19390	special. Remember that time?
 19391	
 19392	Professor MacHugh nodded.
 19393	
 19394	--_New York World_, the editor said, excitedly pushing back his straw
 19395	hat. Where it took place. Tim Kelly, or Kavanagh I mean. Joe Brady and
 19396	the rest of them. Where Skin-the-Goat drove the car. Whole route, see?
 19397	
 19398	--Skin-the-Goat, Mr O'Madden Burke said. Fitzharris. He has that
 19399	cabman's shelter, they say, down there at Butt bridge. Holohan told me.
 19400	You know Holohan?
 19401	
 19402	--Hop and carry one, is it? Myles Crawford said.
 19403	
 19404	--And poor Gumley is down there too, so he told me, minding stones for
 19405	the corporation. A night watchman.
 19406	
 19407	Stephen turned in surprise.
 19408	
 19409	--Gumley? he said. You don't say so? A friend of my father's, is it?
 19410	
 19411	--Never mind Gumley, Myles Crawford cried angrily. Let Gumley mind
 19412	the stones, see they don't run away. Look at here. What did Ignatius
 19413	Gallaher do? I'll tell you. Inspiration of genius. Cabled right away.
 19414	Have you _Weekly Freeman_ of 17 March? Right. Have you got that?
 19415	
 19416	He flung back pages of the files and stuck his finger on a point.
 19417	
 19418	--Take page four, advertisement for Bransome's coffee, let us say. Have
 19419	you got that? Right.
 19420	
 19421	The telephone whirred.
 19422	
 19423	A DISTANT VOICE
 19424	
 19425	
 19426	--I'll answer it, the professor said, going.
 19427	
 19428	--B is parkgate. Good.
 19429	
 19430	His finger leaped and struck point after point, vibrating.
 19431	
 19432	--T is viceregal lodge. C is where murder took place. K is Knockmaroon
 19433	gate.
 19434	
 19435	The loose flesh of his neck shook like a cock's wattles. An illstarched
 19436	dicky jutted up and with a rude gesture he thrust it back into his
 19437	waistcoat.
 19438	
 19439	--Hello? _Evening Telegraph_ here... Hello?... Who's there?... Yes...
 19440	Yes... Yes.
 19441	
 19442	--F to P is the route Skin-the-Goat drove the car for an alibi,
 19443	Inchicore, Roundtown, Windy Arbour, Palmerston Park, Ranelagh. F.A.B.P.
 19444	Got that? X is Davy's publichouse in upper Leeson street.
 19445	
 19446	The professor came to the inner door.
 19447	
 19448	--Bloom is at the telephone, he said.
 19449	
 19450	--Tell him go to hell, the editor said promptly. X is Davy's
 19451	publichouse, see? CLEVER, VERY
 19452	
 19453	
 19454	--Clever, Lenehan said. Very.
 19455	
 19456	--Gave it to them on a hot plate, Myles Crawford said, the whole bloody
 19457	history.
 19458	
 19459	Nightmare from which you will never awake.
 19460	
 19461	--I saw it, the editor said proudly. I was present. Dick Adams, the
 19462	besthearted bloody Corkman the Lord ever put the breath of life in, and
 19463	myself.
 19464	
 19465	Lenehan bowed to a shape of air, announcing:
 19466	
 19467	--Madam, I'm Adam. And Able was I ere I saw Elba.
 19468	
 19469	--History! Myles Crawford cried. The Old Woman of Prince's street was
 19470	there first. There was weeping and gnashing of teeth over that. Out of
 19471	an advertisement. Gregor Grey made the design for it. That gave him the
 19472	leg up. Then Paddy Hooper worked Tay Pay who took him on to the _Star._
 19473	Now he's got in with Blumenfeld. That's press. That's talent. Pyatt! He
 19474	was all their daddies!
 19475	
 19476	--The father of scare journalism, Lenehan confirmed, and the
 19477	brother-in-law of Chris Callinan.
 19478	
 19479	--Hello?... Are you there?... Yes, he's here still. Come across
 19480	yourself.
 19481	
 19482	--Where do you find a pressman like that now, eh? the editor cried. He
 19483	flung the pages down.
 19484	
 19485	--Clamn dever, Lenehan said to Mr O'Madden Burke.
 19486	
 19487	--Very smart, Mr O'Madden Burke said.
 19488	
 19489	Professor MacHugh came from the inner office.
 19490	
 19491	--Talking about the invincibles, he said, did you see that some hawkers
 19492	were up before the recorder?
 19493	
 19494	--O yes, J. J. O'Molloy said eagerly. Lady Dudley was walking home
 19495	through the park to see all the trees that were blown down by that
 19496	cyclone last year and thought she'd buy a view of Dublin. And it
 19497	turned out to be a commemoration postcard of Joe Brady or Number One or
 19498	Skin-the-Goat. Right outside the viceregal lodge, imagine!
 19499	
 19500	--They're only in the hook and eye department, Myles Crawford said.
 19501	Psha! Press and the bar! Where have you a man now at the bar like those
 19502	fellows, like Whiteside, like Isaac Butt, like silvertongued O'Hagan.
 19503	Eh? Ah, bloody nonsense. Psha! Only in the halfpenny place.
 19504	
 19505	His mouth continued to twitch unspeaking in nervous curls of disdain.
 19506	
 19507	Would anyone wish that mouth for her kiss? How do you know? Why did you
 19508	write it then?
 19509	
 19510	RHYMES AND REASONS
 19511	
 19512	
 19513	Mouth, south. Is the mouth south someway? Or the south a mouth? Must be
 19514	some. South, pout, out, shout, drouth. Rhymes: two men dressed the same,
 19515	looking the same, two by two.
 19516	
 19517	     _........................ la tua pace
 19518	    .................. che parlar ti piace
 19519	    .... mentrechÃ© il vento, come fa, si tace._
 19520	
 19521	He saw them three by three, approaching girls, in green, in rose, in
 19522	russet, entwining, _per l'aer perso_, in mauve, in purple, _quella
 19523	pacifica oriafiamma_, gold of oriflamme, _di rimirar fe piu ardenti._
 19524	But I old men, penitent, leadenfooted, underdarkneath the night: mouth
 19525	south: tomb womb.
 19526	
 19527	--Speak up for yourself, Mr O'Madden Burke said.
 19528	
 19529	SUFFICIENT FOR THE DAY...
 19530	
 19531	
 19532	J. J. O'Molloy, smiling palely, took up the gage.
 19533	
 19534	--My dear Myles, he said, flinging his cigarette aside, you put a false
 19535	construction on my words. I hold no brief, as at present advised, for
 19536	the third profession qua profession but your Cork legs are running away
 19537	with you. Why not bring in Henry Grattan and Flood and Demosthenes and
 19538	Edmund Burke? Ignatius Gallaher we all know and his Chapelizod boss,
