 19539	Harmsworth of the farthing press, and his American cousin of the Bowery
 19540	guttersheet not to mention _Paddy Kelly's Budget, Pue's Occurrences_
 19541	and our watchful friend _The Skibbereen Eagle_. Why bring in a master
 19542	of forensic eloquence like Whiteside? Sufficient for the day is the
 19543	newspaper thereof. LINKS WITH BYGONE DAYS OF YORE
 19544	
 19545	
 19546	--Grattan and Flood wrote for this very paper, the editor cried in his
 19547	face. Irish volunteers. Where are you now? Established 1763. Dr Lucas.
 19548	Who have you now like John Philpot Curran? Psha!
 19549	
 19550	--Well, J. J. O'Molloy said, Bushe K.C., for example.
 19551	
 19552	--Bushe? the editor said. Well, yes: Bushe, yes. He has a strain of it
 19553	in his blood. Kendal Bushe or I mean Seymour Bushe.
 19554	
 19555	--He would have been on the bench long ago, the professor said, only for
 19556	... But no matter.
 19557	
 19558	J. J. O'Molloy turned to Stephen and said quietly and slowly:
 19559	
 19560	--One of the most polished periods I think I ever listened to in my life
 19561	fell from the lips of Seymour Bushe. It was in that case of fratricide,
 19562	the Childs murder case. Bushe defended him. _And in the porches of mine
 19563	ear did pour._
 19564	
 19565	
 19566	By the way how did he find that out? He died in his sleep. Or the other
 19567	story, beast with two backs?
 19568	
 19569	--What was that? the professor asked.
 19570	
 19571	ITALIA, MAGISTRA ARTIUM
 19572	
 19573	
 19574	--He spoke on the law of evidence, J. J. O'Molloy said, of Roman justice
 19575	as contrasted with the earlier Mosaic code, the _lex talionis_. And he
 19576	cited the Moses of Michelangelo in the vatican.
 19577	
 19578	--Ha.
 19579	
 19580	--A few wellchosen words, Lenehan prefaced. Silence!
 19581	
 19582	Pause. J. J. O'Molloy took out his cigarettecase.
 19583	
 19584	False lull. Something quite ordinary.
 19585	
 19586	Messenger took out his matchbox thoughtfully and lit his cigar.
 19587	
 19588	I have often thought since on looking back over that strange time that
 19589	it was that small act, trivial in itself, that striking of that match,
 19590	that determined the whole aftercourse of both our lives. A POLISHED
 19591	PERIOD
 19592	
 19593	
 19594	J. J. O'Molloy resumed, moulding his words:
 19595	
 19596	--He said of it: _that stony effigy in frozen music, horned and
 19597	terrible, of the human form divine, that eternal symbol of wisdom and
 19598	of prophecy which, if aught that the imagination or the hand of sculptor
 19599	has wrought in marble of soultransfigured and of soultransfiguring
 19600	deserves to live, deserves to live._
 19601	
 19602	His slim hand with a wave graced echo and fall.
 19603	
 19604	--Fine! Myles Crawford said at once.
 19605	
 19606	--The divine afflatus, Mr O'Madden Burke said.
 19607	
 19608	--You like it? J. J. O'Molloy asked Stephen.
 19609	
 19610	Stephen, his blood wooed by grace of language and gesture, blushed. He
 19611	took a cigarette from the case. J. J. O'Molloy offered his case to Myles
 19612	Crawford. Lenehan lit their cigarettes as before and took his trophy,
 19613	saying:
 19614	
 19615	--Muchibus thankibus.
 19616	
 19617	A MAN OF HIGH MORALE
 19618	
 19619	
 19620	--Professor Magennis was speaking to me about you, J. J. O'Molloy said
 19621	to Stephen. What do you think really of that hermetic crowd, the opal
 19622	hush poets: A. E. the mastermystic? That Blavatsky woman started it.
 19623	She was a nice old bag of tricks. A. E. has been telling some yankee
 19624	interviewer that you came to him in the small hours of the morning to
 19625	ask him about planes of consciousness. Magennis thinks you must have
 19626	been pulling A. E.'s leg. He is a man of the very highest morale,
 19627	Magennis.
 19628	
 19629	Speaking about me. What did he say? What did he say? What did he say
 19630	about me? Don't ask.
 19631	
 19632	--No, thanks, professor MacHugh said, waving the cigarettecase aside.
 19633	Wait a moment. Let me say one thing. The finest display of oratory I
 19634	ever heard was a speech made by John F Taylor at the college historical
 19635	society. Mr Justice Fitzgibbon, the present lord justice of appeal, had
 19636	spoken and the paper under debate was an essay (new for those days),
 19637	advocating the revival of the Irish tongue.
 19638	
 19639	He turned towards Myles Crawford and said:
 19640	
 19641	--You know Gerald Fitzgibbon. Then you can imagine the style of his
 19642	discourse.
 19643	
 19644	--He is sitting with Tim Healy, J. J. O'Molloy said, rumour has it, on
 19645	the Trinity college estates commission.
 19646	
 19647	--He is sitting with a sweet thing, Myles Crawford said, in a child's
 19648	frock. Go on. Well?
 19649	
 19650	--It was the speech, mark you, the professor said, of a finished orator,
 19651	full of courteous haughtiness and pouring in chastened diction I will
 19652	not say the vials of his wrath but pouring the proud man's contumely
 19653	upon the new movement. It was then a new movement. We were weak,
 19654	therefore worthless.
 19655	
 19656	He closed his long thin lips an instant but, eager to be on, raised
 19657	an outspanned hand to his spectacles and, with trembling thumb and
 19658	ringfinger touching lightly the black rims, steadied them to a new
 19659	focus.
 19660	
 19661	IMPROMPTU
 19662	
 19663	
 19664	In ferial tone he addressed J. J. O'Molloy:
 19665	
 19666	--Taylor had come there, you must know, from a sickbed. That he
 19667	had prepared his speech I do not believe for there was not even one
 19668	shorthandwriter in the hall. His dark lean face had a growth of shaggy
 19669	beard round it. He wore a loose white silk neckcloth and altogether he
 19670	looked (though he was not) a dying man.
 19671	
 19672	His gaze turned at once but slowly from J. J. O'Molloy's towards
 19673	Stephen's face and then bent at once to the ground, seeking. His
 19674	unglazed linen collar appeared behind his bent head, soiled by his
 19675	withering hair. Still seeking, he said:
 19676	
 19677	--When Fitzgibbon's speech had ended John F Taylor rose to reply.
 19678	Briefly, as well as I can bring them to mind, his words were these.
 19679	
 19680	He raised his head firmly. His eyes bethought themselves once more.
 19681	Witless shellfish swam in the gross lenses to and fro, seeking outlet.
 19682	
 19683	He began:
 19684	
 19685	_--Mr Chairman, ladies and gentlemen: Great was my admiration in
 19686	listening to the remarks addressed to the youth of Ireland a moment
 19687	since by my learned friend. It seemed to me that I had been transported
 19688	into a country far away from this country, into an age remote from
 19689	this age, that I stood in ancient Egypt and that I was listening to the
 19690	speech of some highpriest of that land addressed to the youthful Moses._
 19691	
 19692	His listeners held their cigarettes poised to hear, their smokes
 19693	ascending in frail stalks that flowered with his speech. _And let our
 19694	crooked smokes._ Noble words coming. Look out. Could you try your hand
 19695	at it yourself?
 19696	
 19697	_--And it seemed to me that I heard the voice of that Egyptian
 19698	highpriest raised in a tone of like haughtiness and like pride. I heard
 19699	his words and their meaning was revealed to me._
 19700	
 19701	FROM THE FATHERS
 19702	
 19703	
 19704	It was revealed to me that those things are good which yet are corrupted
 19705	which neither if they were supremely good nor unless they were good
 19706	could be corrupted. Ah, curse you! That's saint Augustine.
 19707	
 19708	_--Why will you jews not accept our culture, our religion and our
 19709	language? You are a tribe of nomad herdsmen: we are a mighty people. You
 19710	have no cities nor no wealth: our cities are hives of humanity and
 19711	our galleys, trireme and quadrireme, laden with all manner merchandise
 19712	furrow the waters of the known globe. You have but emerged from
 19713	primitive conditions: we have a literature, a priesthood, an agelong
 19714	history and a polity._
 19715	
 19716	Nile.
 19717	
 19718	Child, man, effigy.
 19719	
 19720	By the Nilebank the babemaries kneel, cradle of bulrushes: a man supple
 19721	in combat: stonehorned, stonebearded, heart of stone.
 19722	
 19723	_--You pray to a local and obscure idol: our temples, majestic and
 19724	mysterious, are the abodes of Isis and Osiris, of Horus and Ammon Ra.
 19725	Yours serfdom, awe and humbleness: ours thunder and the seas. Israel
 19726	is weak and few are her children: Egypt is an host and terrible are her
 19727	arms. Vagrants and daylabourers are you called: the world trembles at
 19728	our name._
 19729	
 19730	A dumb belch of hunger cleft his speech. He lifted his voice above it
 19731	boldly:
 19732	
 19733	_--But, ladies and gentlemen, had the youthful Moses listened to and
 19734	accepted that view of life, had he bowed his head and bowed his will
 19735	and bowed his spirit before that arrogant admonition he would never have
 19736	brought the chosen people out of their house of bondage, nor followed
 19737	the pillar of the cloud by day. He would never have spoken with the
 19738	Eternal amid lightnings on Sinai's mountaintop nor ever have come down
 19739	with the light of inspiration shining in his countenance and bearing in
 19740	his arms the tables of the law, graven in the language of the outlaw._
 19741	
 19742	He ceased and looked at them, enjoying a silence.
 19743	
 19744	OMINOUS--FOR HIM!
 19745	
 19746	J. J. O'Molloy said not without regret:
 19747	
 19748	--And yet he died without having entered the land of promise.
 19749	
 19750	--A sudden--at--the--moment--though--from--lingering--illness--often--
 19751	previously--expectorated--demise, Lenehan added. And with a great future
 19752	behind him.
 19753	
 19754	The troop of bare feet was heard rushing along the hallway and pattering
 19755	up the staircase.
 19756	
 19757	--That is oratory, the professor said uncontradicted. Gone with the
 19758	wind. Hosts at Mullaghmast and Tara of the kings. Miles of ears of
 19759	porches. The tribune's words, howled and scattered to the four winds.
 19760	A people sheltered within his voice. Dead noise. Akasic records of all
 19761	that ever anywhere wherever was. Love and laud him: me no more.
 19762	
 19763	I have money.
 19764	
 19765	--Gentlemen, Stephen said. As the next motion on the agenda paper may I
 19766	suggest that the house do now adjourn?
 19767	
 19768	--You take my breath away. It is not perchance a French compliment?
 19769	Mr O'Madden Burke asked. 'Tis the hour, methinks, when the winejug,
 19770	metaphorically speaking, is most grateful in Ye ancient hostelry.
 19771	
 19772	--That it be and hereby is resolutely resolved. All that are in favour
 19773	say ay, Lenehan announced. The contrary no. I declare it carried. To
 19774	which particular boosing shed?... My casting vote is: Mooney's!
 19775	
 19776	He led the way, admonishing:
 19777	
 19778	--We will sternly refuse to partake of strong waters, will we not? Yes,
 19779	we will not. By no manner of means.
 19780	
 19781	Mr O'Madden Burke, following close, said with an ally's lunge of his
 19782	umbrella:
 19783	
 19784	--Lay on, Macduff!
 19785	
 19786	--Chip of the old block! the editor cried, clapping Stephen on the
 19787	shoulder. Let us go. Where are those blasted keys?
 19788	
 19789	He fumbled in his pocket pulling out the crushed typesheets.
 19790	
 19791	--Foot and mouth. I know. That'll be all right. That'll go in. Where are
 19792	they? That's all right.
 19793	
 19794	He thrust the sheets back and went into the inner office. LET US HOPE
 19795	
 19796	
 19797	J. J. O'Molloy, about to follow him in, said quietly to Stephen:
 19798	
 19799	--I hope you will live to see it published. Myles, one moment.
 19800	
 19801	He went into the inner office, closing the door behind him.
 19802	
 19803	--Come along, Stephen, the professor said. That is fine, isn't it? It
 19804	has the prophetic vision. _Fuit Ilium!_ The sack of windy Troy. Kingdoms
 19805	of this world. The masters of the Mediterranean are fellaheen today.
 19806	
 19807	The first newsboy came pattering down the stairs at their heels and
 19808	rushed out into the street, yelling:
 19809	
 19810	--Racing special!
 19811	
 19812	Dublin. I have much, much to learn.
 19813	
 19814	They turned to the left along Abbey street.
 19815	
 19816	--I have a vision too, Stephen said.
 19817	
 19818	--Yes? the professor said, skipping to get into step. Crawford will
 19819	follow.
 19820	
 19821	Another newsboy shot past them, yelling as he ran:
 19822	
 19823	--Racing special!
 19824	
 19825	DEAR DIRTY DUBLIN
 19826	
 19827	
 19828	Dubliners.
 19829	
 19830	--Two Dublin vestals, Stephen said, elderly and pious, have lived fifty
 19831	and fiftythree years in Fumbally's lane.
 19832	
 19833	--Where is that? the professor asked.
 19834	
 19835	--Off Blackpitts, Stephen said.
 19836	
 19837	Damp night reeking of hungry dough. Against the wall. Face glistering
 19838	tallow under her fustian shawl. Frantic hearts. Akasic records. Quicker,
 19839	darlint!
 19840	
 19841	On now. Dare it. Let there be life.
 19842	
 19843	--They want to see the views of Dublin from the top of Nelson's pillar.
 19844	They save up three and tenpence in a red tin letterbox moneybox. They
 19845	shake out the threepenny bits and sixpences and coax out the pennies
 19846	with the blade of a knife. Two and three in silver and one and seven
 19847	in coppers. They put on their bonnets and best clothes and take their
 19848	umbrellas for fear it may come on to rain.
 19849	
 19850	--Wise virgins, professor MacHugh said.
 19851	
 19852	LIFE ON THE RAW
 19853	
 19854	
 19855	--They buy one and fourpenceworth of brawn and four slices of panloaf at
 19856	the north city diningrooms in Marlborough street from Miss Kate Collins,
 19857	proprietress... They purchase four and twenty ripe plums from a girl
 19858	at the foot of Nelson's pillar to take off the thirst of the brawn. They
 19859	give two threepenny bits to the gentleman at the turnstile and begin
 19860	to waddle slowly up the winding staircase, grunting, encouraging each
 19861	other, afraid of the dark, panting, one asking the other have you the
 19862	brawn, praising God and the Blessed Virgin, threatening to come down,
 19863	peeping at the airslits. Glory be to God. They had no idea it was that
 19864	high.
 19865	
 19866	Their names are Anne Kearns and Florence MacCabe. Anne Kearns has the
 19867	lumbago for which she rubs on Lourdes water, given her by a lady who got
 19868	a bottleful from a passionist father. Florence MacCabe takes a crubeen
 19869	and a bottle of double X for supper every Saturday.
 19870	
 19871	--Antithesis, the professor said nodding twice. Vestal virgins. I can
 19872	see them. What's keeping our friend?
 19873	
 19874	He turned.
 19875	
 19876	A bevy of scampering newsboys rushed down the steps, scattering in all
 19877	directions, yelling, their white papers fluttering. Hard after them
 19878	Myles Crawford appeared on the steps, his hat aureoling his scarlet
 19879	face, talking with J. J. O'Molloy.
 19880	
 19881	--Come along, the professor cried, waving his arm.
 19882	
 19883	He set off again to walk by Stephen's side. RETURN OF BLOOM
 19884	
 19885	
 19886	--Yes, he said. I see them.
 19887	
 19888	Mr Bloom, breathless, caught in a whirl of wild newsboys near the
 19889	offices of the _Irish Catholic and Dublin Penny Journal_, called:
 19890	
 19891	--Mr Crawford! A moment!
 19892	
 19893	--_Telegraph_! Racing special!
 19894	
 19895	--What is it? Myles Crawford said, falling back a pace.
 19896	
 19897	A newsboy cried in Mr Bloom's face:
 19898	
 19899	--Terrible tragedy in Rathmines! A child bit by a bellows!
 19900	
 19901	INTERVIEW WITH THE EDITOR
 19902	
 19903	
 19904	--Just this ad, Mr Bloom said, pushing through towards the steps,
 19905	puffing, and taking the cutting from his pocket. I spoke with Mr Keyes
 19906	just now. He'll give a renewal for two months, he says. After he'll
 19907	see. But he wants a par to call attention in the _Telegraph_ too,
 19908	the Saturday pink. And he wants it copied if it's not too late I told
 19909	councillor Nannetti from the _Kilkenny People_. I can have access to
 19910	it in the national library. House of keys, don't you see? His name is
 19911	Keyes. It's a play on the name. But he practically promised he'd give
 19912	the renewal. But he wants just a little puff. What will I tell him, Mr
 19913	Crawford? K.M.A.
 19914	
 19915	
 19916	--Will you tell him he can kiss my arse? Myles Crawford said throwing
 19917	out his arm for emphasis. Tell him that straight from the stable.
 19918	
 19919	A bit nervy. Look out for squalls. All off for a drink. Arm in arm.
 19920	Lenehan's yachting cap on the cadge beyond. Usual blarney. Wonder is
 19921	that young Dedalus the moving spirit. Has a good pair of boots on him
 19922	today. Last time I saw him he had his heels on view. Been walking in
 19923	muck somewhere. Careless chap. What was he doing in Irishtown?
 19924	
 19925	--Well, Mr Bloom said, his eyes returning, if I can get the design I
 19926	suppose it's worth a short par. He'd give the ad, I think. I'll tell him
 19927	... K.M.R.I.A.
 19928	
 19929	
 19930	--He can kiss my royal Irish arse, Myles Crawford cried loudly over his
 19931	shoulder. Any time he likes, tell him.
 19932	
 19933	While Mr Bloom stood weighing the point and about to smile he strode on
 19934	jerkily.
 19935	
 19936	RAISING THE WIND
 19937	
 19938	
 19939	--_Nulla bona_, Jack, he said, raising his hand to his chin. I'm up to
 19940	here. I've been through the hoop myself. I was looking for a fellow to
 19941	back a bill for me no later than last week. Sorry, Jack. You must take
 19942	the will for the deed. With a heart and a half if I could raise the wind
 19943	anyhow.
 19944	
 19945	J. J. O'Molloy pulled a long face and walked on silently. They caught up
 19946	on the others and walked abreast.
 19947	
 19948	--When they have eaten the brawn and the bread and wiped their twenty
 19949	fingers in the paper the bread was wrapped in they go nearer to the
 19950	railings.
 19951	
 19952	--Something for you, the professor explained to Myles Crawford. Two old
 19953	Dublin women on the top of Nelson's pillar.
 19954	
 19955	SOME COLUMN!--THAT'S WHAT WADDLER ONE SAID
 19956	
 19957	
 19958	--That's new, Myles Crawford said. That's copy. Out for the waxies
 19959	Dargle. Two old trickies, what?
 19960	
 19961	--But they are afraid the pillar will fall, Stephen went on. They see
 19962	the roofs and argue about where the different churches are: Rathmines'
 19963	blue dome, Adam and Eve's, saint Laurence O'Toole's. But it makes them
 19964	giddy to look so they pull up their skirts...
 19965	
 19966	THOSE SLIGHTLY RAMBUNCTIOUS FEMALES
 19967	
 19968	
 19969	--Easy all, Myles Crawford said. No poetic licence. We're in the
 19970	archdiocese here.
 19971	
 19972	--And settle down on their striped petticoats, peering up at the statue
 19973	of the onehandled adulterer.
 19974	
 19975	--Onehandled adulterer! the professor cried. I like that. I see the
 19976	idea. I see what you mean.
 19977	
 19978	DAMES DONATE DUBLIN'S CITS SPEEDPILLS VELOCITOUS AEROLITHS, BELIEF
 19979	
 19980	
 19981	--It gives them a crick in their necks, Stephen said, and they are too
 19982	tired to look up or down or to speak. They put the bag of plums between
 19983	them and eat the plums out of it, one after another, wiping off with
 19984	their handkerchiefs the plumjuice that dribbles out of their mouths and
 19985	spitting the plumstones slowly out between the railings.
 19986	
 19987	He gave a sudden loud young laugh as a close. Lenehan and Mr O'Madden
 19988	Burke, hearing, turned, beckoned and led on across towards Mooney's.
 19989	
 19990	--Finished? Myles Crawford said. So long as they do no worse.
 19991	
 19992	SOPHIST WALLOPS HAUGHTY HELEN SQUARE ON PROBOSCIS. SPARTANS GNASH
 19993	MOLARS. ITHACANS VOW PEN IS CHAMP.
 19994	
 19995	
 19996	--You remind me of Antisthenes, the professor said, a disciple of
 19997	Gorgias, the sophist. It is said of him that none could tell if he were
 19998	bitterer against others or against himself. He was the son of a noble
 19999	and a bondwoman. And he wrote a book in which he took away the palm of
 20000	beauty from Argive Helen and handed it to poor Penelope.
 20001	
 20002	Poor Penelope. Penelope Rich.
 20003	
 20004	They made ready to cross O'Connell street.
 20005	
 20006	HELLO THERE, CENTRAL!
 20007	
 20008	
 20009	At various points along the eight lines tramcars with motionless
 20010	trolleys stood in their tracks, bound for or from Rathmines,
 20011	Rathfarnham, Blackrock, Kingstown and Dalkey, Sandymount Green, Ringsend
 20012	and Sandymount Tower, Donnybrook, Palmerston Park and Upper Rathmines,
 20013	all still, becalmed in short circuit. Hackney cars, cabs, delivery
 20014	waggons, mailvans, private broughams, aerated mineral water floats with
 20015	rattling crates of bottles, rattled, rolled, horsedrawn, rapidly.
 20016	
 20017	WHAT?--AND LIKEWISE--WHERE?
 20018	
 20019	
 20020	--But what do you call it? Myles Crawford asked. Where did they get the
 20021	plums?
 20022	
 20023	VIRGILIAN, SAYS PEDAGOGUE. SOPHOMORE PLUMPS FOR OLD MAN MOSES.
 20024	
 20025	
 20026	--Call it, wait, the professor said, opening his long lips wide to
 20027	reflect. Call it, let me see. Call it: _deus nobis haec otia fecit._
 20028	
 20029	--No, Stephen said. I call it _A Pisgah Sight of Palestine or the
 20030	Parable of The Plums._
 20031	
 20032	--I see, the professor said.
 20033	
 20034	He laughed richly.
 20035	
 20036	--I see, he said again with new pleasure. Moses and the promised land.
 20037	We gave him that idea, he added to J. J. O'Molloy.
 20038	
 20039	HORATIO IS CYNOSURE THIS FAIR JUNE DAY
 20040	
 20041	
 20042	J. J. O'Molloy sent a weary sidelong glance towards the statue and held
 20043	his peace.
 20044	
 20045	--I see, the professor said.
 20046	
 20047	He halted on sir John Gray's pavement island and peered aloft at Nelson
 20048	through the meshes of his wry smile.
 20049	
 20050	DIMINISHED DIGITS PROVE TOO TITILLATING FOR FRISKY FRUMPS. ANNE WIMBLES,
 20051	FLO WANGLES--YET CAN YOU BLAME THEM?
 20052	
 20053	
 20054	--Onehandled adulterer, he said smiling grimly. That tickles me, I must
 20055	say.
 20056	
 20057	--Tickled the old ones too, Myles Crawford said, if the God Almighty's
 20058	truth was known.
 20059	
 20060	
 20061	Pineapple rock, lemon platt, butter scotch. A sugarsticky girl
 20062	shovelling scoopfuls of creams for a christian brother. Some school
 20063	treat. Bad for their tummies. Lozenge and comfit manufacturer to His
 20064	Majesty the King. God. Save. Our. Sitting on his throne sucking red
 20065	jujubes white.
 20066	
 20067	
 20068	A sombre Y.M.C.A. young man, watchful among the warm sweet fumes of
 20069	Graham Lemon's, placed a throwaway in a hand of Mr Bloom.
 20070	
 20071	Heart to heart talks.
 20072	
 20073	Bloo... Me? No.
 20074	
 20075	Blood of the Lamb.
 20076	
 20077	His slow feet walked him riverward, reading. Are you saved? All are
 20078	washed in the blood of the lamb. God wants blood victim. Birth, hymen,
 20079	martyr, war, foundation of a building, sacrifice, kidney burntoffering,
 20080	druids' altars. Elijah is coming. Dr John Alexander Dowie restorer of
 20081	the church in Zion is coming.
 20082	
 20083	_Is coming! Is coming!! Is coming!!! All heartily welcome._ Paying game.
 20084	Torry and Alexander last year. Polygamy. His wife will put the stopper
 20085	on that. Where was that ad some Birmingham firm the luminous crucifix.
 20086	Our Saviour. Wake up in the dead of night and see him on the wall,
 20087	hanging. Pepper's ghost idea. Iron nails ran in.
 20088	
 20089	
 20090	Phosphorus it must be done with. If you leave a bit of codfish for
 20091	instance. I could see the bluey silver over it. Night I went down to the
 20092	pantry in the kitchen. Don't like all the smells in it waiting to rush
 20093	out. What was it she wanted? The Malaga raisins. Thinking of Spain.
 20094	Before Rudy was born. The phosphorescence, that bluey greeny. Very good
 20095	for the brain.
 20096	
 20097	From Butler's monument house corner he glanced along Bachelor's walk.
 20098	Dedalus' daughter there still outside Dillon's auctionrooms. Must be
 20099	selling off some old furniture. Knew her eyes at once from the father.
 20100	Lobbing about waiting for him. Home always breaks up when the mother
 20101	goes. Fifteen children he had. Birth every year almost. That's in their
 20102	theology or the priest won't give the poor woman the confession, the
 20103	absolution. Increase and multiply. Did you ever hear such an idea? Eat
 20104	you out of house and home. No families themselves to feed. Living on the
 20105	fat of the land. Their butteries and larders. I'd like to see them do
 20106	the black fast Yom Kippur. Crossbuns. One meal and a collation for fear
 20107	he'd collapse on the altar. A housekeeper of one of those fellows if you
 20108	could pick it out of her. Never pick it out of her. Like getting l.s.d.
 20109	out of him. Does himself well. No guests. All for number one. Watching
 20110	his water. Bring your own bread and butter. His reverence: mum's the
 20111	word.
 20112	
 20113	Good Lord, that poor child's dress is in flitters. Underfed she looks
 20114	too. Potatoes and marge, marge and potatoes. It's after they feel it.
 20115	Proof of the pudding. Undermines the constitution.
 20116	
 20117	As he set foot on O'Connell bridge a puffball of smoke plumed up from
 20118	the parapet. Brewery barge with export stout. England. Sea air sours it,
 20119	I heard. Be interesting some day get a pass through Hancock to see the
 20120	brewery. Regular world in itself. Vats of porter wonderful. Rats get in
 20121	too. Drink themselves bloated as big as a collie floating. Dead drunk on
 20122	the porter. Drink till they puke again like christians. Imagine drinking
 20123	that! Rats: vats. Well, of course, if we knew all the things.
 20124	
 20125	Looking down he saw flapping strongly, wheeling between the gaunt
 20126	quaywalls, gulls. Rough weather outside. If I threw myself down? Reuben
 20127	J's son must have swallowed a good bellyful of that sewage. One and
 20128	eightpence too much. Hhhhm. It's the droll way he comes out with the
 20129	things. Knows how to tell a story too.
 20130	
 20131	They wheeled lower. Looking for grub. Wait.
 20132	
 20133	He threw down among them a crumpled paper ball. Elijah thirtytwo feet
 20134	per sec is com. Not a bit. The ball bobbed unheeded on the wake of
 20135	swells, floated under by the bridgepiers. Not such damn fools. Also the
 20136	day I threw that stale cake out of the Erin's King picked it up in the
 20137	wake fifty yards astern. Live by their wits. They wheeled, flapping.
 20138	
 20139	     _The hungry famished gull
 20140	     Flaps o'er the waters dull._
 20141	
 20142	That is how poets write, the similar sounds. But then Shakespeare has
 20143	no rhymes: blank verse. The flow of the language it is. The thoughts.
 20144	Solemn.
 20145	
 20146	
 20147	     _Hamlet, I am thy father's spirit
 20148	     Doomed for a certain time to walk the earth._
 20149	     --Two apples a penny! Two for a penny!
 20150	
 20151	
 20152	His gaze passed over the glazed apples serried on her stand. Australians
 20153	they must be this time of year. Shiny peels: polishes them up with a rag
 20154	or a handkerchief.
 20155	
 20156	Wait. Those poor birds.
 20157	
 20158	He halted again and bought from the old applewoman two Banbury cakes for
 20159	a penny and broke the brittle paste and threw its fragments down into
 20160	the Liffey. See that? The gulls swooped silently, two, then all from
 20161	their heights, pouncing on prey. Gone. Every morsel.
 20162	
 20163	Aware of their greed and cunning he shook the powdery crumb from his
 20164	hands. They never expected that. Manna. Live on fish, fishy flesh they
 20165	have, all seabirds, gulls, seagoose. Swans from Anna Liffey swim down
 20166	here sometimes to preen themselves. No accounting for tastes. Wonder
 20167	what kind is swanmeat. Robinson Crusoe had to live on them.
 20168	
 20169	They wheeled flapping weakly. I'm not going to throw any more. Penny
 20170	quite enough. Lot of thanks I get. Not even a caw. They spread foot and
 20171	mouth disease too. If you cram a turkey say on chestnutmeal it tastes
 20172	like that. Eat pig like pig. But then why is it that saltwater fish are
 20173	not salty? How is that?
 20174	
 20175	His eyes sought answer from the river and saw a rowboat rock at anchor
 20176	on the treacly swells lazily its plastered board.
 20177	
 20178	_Kino's_ 11/- _Trousers_
 20179	
 20180	Good idea that. Wonder if he pays rent to the corporation. How can you
 20181	own water really? It's always flowing in a stream, never the same, which
 20182	in the stream of life we trace. Because life is a stream. All kinds of
 20183	places are good for ads. That quack doctor for the clap used to be stuck
 20184	up in all the greenhouses. Never see it now. Strictly confidential. Dr
 20185	Hy Franks. Didn't cost him a red like Maginni the dancing master self
 20186	advertisement. Got fellows to stick them up or stick them up himself for
 20187	that matter on the q. t. running in to loosen a button. Flybynight.
 20188	Just the place too. POST NO BILLS. POST 110 PILLS. Some chap with a dose
 20189	burning him.
 20190	
 20191	If he...?
 20192	
 20193	O!
 20194	
 20195	Eh?
 20196	
 20197	No... No.
 20198	
 20199	No, no. I don't believe it. He wouldn't surely?
 20200	
 20201	No, no.
 20202	
 20203	Mr Bloom moved forward, raising his troubled eyes. Think no more about
 20204	that. After one. Timeball on the ballastoffice is down. Dunsink time.
 20205	Fascinating little book that is of sir Robert Ball's. Parallax. I never
 20206	exactly understood. There's a priest. Could ask him. Par it's Greek:
 20207	parallel, parallax. Met him pike hoses she called it till I told her
 20208	about the transmigration. O rocks!
 20209	
 20210	Mr Bloom smiled O rocks at two windows of the ballastoffice. She's right
 20211	after all. Only big words for ordinary things on account of the sound.
 20212	She's not exactly witty. Can be rude too. Blurt out what I was thinking.
 20213	Still, I don't know. She used to say Ben Dollard had a base barreltone
 20214	voice. He has legs like barrels and you'd think he was singing into a
 20215	barrel. Now, isn't that wit. They used to call him big Ben. Not half as
 20216	witty as calling him base barreltone. Appetite like an albatross. Get
 20217	outside of a baron of beef. Powerful man he was at stowing away number
 20218	one Bass. Barrel of Bass. See? It all works out.
 20219	
 20220	A procession of whitesmocked sandwichmen marched slowly towards him
 20221	along the gutter, scarlet sashes across their boards. Bargains. Like
 20222	that priest they are this morning: we have sinned: we have suffered. He
 20223	read the scarlet letters on their five tall white hats: H. E. L. Y. S.
 20224	Wisdom Hely's. Y lagging behind drew a chunk of bread from under his
 20225	foreboard, crammed it into his mouth and munched as he walked. Our
 20226	staple food. Three bob a day, walking along the gutters, street after
 20227	street. Just keep skin and bone together, bread and skilly. They are
 20228	not Boyl: no, M Glade's men. Doesn't bring in any business either.
 20229	I suggested to him about a transparent showcart with two smart girls
 20230	sitting inside writing letters, copybooks, envelopes, blottingpaper. I
 20231	bet that would have caught on. Smart girls writing something catch the
 20232	eye at once. Everyone dying to know what she's writing. Get twenty of
 20233	them round you if you stare at nothing. Have a finger in the pie. Women
 20234	too. Curiosity. Pillar of salt. Wouldn't have it of course because he
 20235	didn't think of it himself first. Or the inkbottle I suggested with a
 20236	false stain of black celluloid. His ideas for ads like Plumtree's potted
 20237	under the obituaries, cold meat department. You can't lick 'em. What?
 20238	Our envelopes. Hello, Jones, where are you going? Can't stop, Robinson,
 20239	I am hastening to purchase the only reliable inkeraser _Kansell,_ sold
 20240	by Hely's Ltd, 85 Dame street. Well out of that ruck I am. Devil of a
 20241	job it was collecting accounts of those convents. Tranquilla convent.
 20242	That was a nice nun there, really sweet face. Wimple suited her small
 20243	head. Sister? Sister? I am sure she was crossed in love by her eyes.
 20244	Very hard to bargain with that sort of a woman. I disturbed her at her
 20245	devotions that morning. But glad to communicate with the outside world.
 20246	Our great day, she said. Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel. Sweet name
 20247	too: caramel. She knew I, I think she knew by the way she. If she had
 20248	married she would have changed. I suppose they really were short of
 20249	money. Fried everything in the best butter all the same. No lard for
 20250	them. My heart's broke eating dripping. They like buttering themselves
 20251	in and out. Molly tasting it, her veil up. Sister? Pat Claffey, the
 20252	pawnbroker's daughter. It was a nun they say invented barbed wire.
 20253	
 20254	He crossed Westmoreland street when apostrophe S had plodded by. Rover
 20255	cycleshop. Those races are on today. How long ago is that? Year Phil
 20256	Gilligan died. We were in Lombard street west. Wait: was in Thom's.
 20257	Got the job in Wisdom Hely's year we married. Six years. Ten years ago:
 20258	ninetyfour he died yes that's right the big fire at Arnott's. Val Dillon
 20259	was lord mayor. The Glencree dinner. Alderman Robert O'Reilly emptying
 20260	the port into his soup before the flag fell. Bobbob lapping it for the
 20261	inner alderman. Couldn't hear what the band played. For what we have
 20262	already received may the Lord make us. Milly was a kiddy then. Molly
 20263	had that elephantgrey dress with the braided frogs. Mantailored with
 20264	selfcovered buttons. She didn't like it because I sprained my ankle
 20265	first day she wore choir picnic at the Sugarloaf. As if that. Old
 20266	Goodwin's tall hat done up with some sticky stuff. Flies' picnic
 20267	too. Never put a dress on her back like it. Fitted her like a glove,
 20268	shoulders and hips. Just beginning to plump it out well. Rabbitpie we
 20269	had that day. People looking after her.
 20270	
 20271	Happy. Happier then. Snug little room that was with the red wallpaper.
 20272	Dockrell's, one and ninepence a dozen. Milly's tubbing night. American
 20273	soap I bought: elderflower. Cosy smell of her bathwater. Funny she
 20274	looked soaped all over. Shapely too. Now photography. Poor papa's
 20275	daguerreotype atelier he told me of. Hereditary taste.
 20276	
 20277	He walked along the curbstone.
 20278	
 20279	Stream of life. What was the name of that priestylooking chap was always
 20280	squinting in when he passed? Weak eyes, woman. Stopped in Citron's saint
 20281	Kevin's parade. Pen something. Pendennis? My memory is getting. Pen
 20282	...? Of course it's years ago. Noise of the trams probably. Well, if he
 20283	couldn't remember the dayfather's name that he sees every day.
 20284	
 20285	Bartell d'Arcy was the tenor, just coming out then. Seeing her home
 20286	after practice. Conceited fellow with his waxedup moustache. Gave her
 20287	that song _Winds that blow from the south_.
 20288	
 20289	Windy night that was I went to fetch her there was that lodge meeting on
 20290	about those lottery tickets after Goodwin's concert in the supperroom or
 20291	oakroom of the Mansion house. He and I behind. Sheet of her music blew
 20292	out of my hand against the High school railings. Lucky it didn't.
 20293	Thing like that spoils the effect of a night for her. Professor Goodwin
 20294	linking her in front. Shaky on his pins, poor old sot. His farewell
 20295	concerts. Positively last appearance on any stage. May be for months and
 20296	may be for never. Remember her laughing at the wind, her blizzard collar
 20297	up. Corner of Harcourt road remember that gust. Brrfoo! Blew up all her
 20298	skirts and her boa nearly smothered old Goodwin. She did get flushed
 20299	in the wind. Remember when we got home raking up the fire and frying up
 20300	those pieces of lap of mutton for her supper with the Chutney sauce she
 20301	liked. And the mulled rum. Could see her in the bedroom from the hearth
 20302	unclamping the busk of her stays: white.
 20303	
 20304	Swish and soft flop her stays made on the bed. Always warm from her.
 20305	Always liked to let her self out. Sitting there after till near two
 20306	taking out her hairpins. Milly tucked up in beddyhouse. Happy. Happy.
 20307	That was the night...
 20308	
 20309	--O, Mr Bloom, how do you do?
 20310	
 20311	--O, how do you do, Mrs Breen?
 20312	
 20313	--No use complaining. How is Molly those times? Haven't seen her for
 20314	ages.
 20315	
 20316	--In the pink, Mr Bloom said gaily. Milly has a position down in
 20317	Mullingar, you know.
 20318	
 20319	--Go away! Isn't that grand for her?
 20320	
 20321	--Yes. In a photographer's there. Getting on like a house on fire. How
 20322	are all your charges?
 20323	
 20324	--All on the baker's list, Mrs Breen said.
 20325	
 20326	How many has she? No other in sight.
 20327	
 20328	--You're in black, I see. You have no...
 20329	
 20330	--No, Mr Bloom said. I have just come from a funeral.
 20331	
 20332	Going to crop up all day, I foresee. Who's dead, when and what did he
 20333	die of? Turn up like a bad penny.
 20334	
 20335	--O, dear me, Mrs Breen said. I hope it wasn't any near relation.
 20336	
 20337	May as well get her sympathy.
 20338	
 20339	--Dignam, Mr Bloom said. An old friend of mine. He died quite suddenly,
 20340	poor fellow. Heart trouble, I believe. Funeral was this morning.
 20341	
 20342	_Your funeral's tomorrow While you're coming through the rye.
 20343	Diddlediddle dumdum Diddlediddle..._
 20344	
 20345	--Sad to lose the old friends, Mrs Breen's womaneyes said melancholily.
 20346	
 20347	Now that's quite enough about that. Just: quietly: husband.
 20348	
 20349	--And your lord and master?
 20350	
 20351	Mrs Breen turned up her two large eyes. Hasn't lost them anyhow.
 20352	
 20353	--O, don't be talking! she said. He's a caution to rattlesnakes. He's
 20354	in there now with his lawbooks finding out the law of libel. He has me
 20355	heartscalded. Wait till I show you.
 20356	
 20357	Hot mockturtle vapour and steam of newbaked jampuffs rolypoly poured
 20358	out from Harrison's. The heavy noonreek tickled the top of Mr Bloom's
 20359	gullet. Want to make good pastry, butter, best flour, Demerara sugar,
 20360	or they'd taste it with the hot tea. Or is it from her? A barefoot
 20361	arab stood over the grating, breathing in the fumes. Deaden the gnaw of
 20362	hunger that way. Pleasure or pain is it? Penny dinner. Knife and fork
 20363	chained to the table.
 20364	
 20365	Opening her handbag, chipped leather. Hatpin: ought to have a guard on
 20366	those things. Stick it in a chap's eye in the tram. Rummaging. Open.
 20367	Money. Please take one. Devils if they lose sixpence. Raise Cain.
 20368	Husband barging. Where's the ten shillings I gave you on Monday? Are
 20369	you feeding your little brother's family? Soiled handkerchief:
 20370	medicinebottle. Pastille that was fell. What is she?...
 20371	
 20372	--There must be a new moon out, she said. He's always bad then. Do you
 20373	know what he did last night?
 20374	
 20375	Her hand ceased to rummage. Her eyes fixed themselves on him, wide in
 20376	alarm, yet smiling.
 20377	
 20378	--What? Mr Bloom asked.
 20379	
 20380	Let her speak. Look straight in her eyes. I believe you. Trust me.
 20381	
 20382	--Woke me up in the night, she said. Dream he had, a nightmare.
 20383	
 20384	Indiges.
 20385	
 20386	--Said the ace of spades was walking up the stairs.
 20387	
 20388	--The ace of spades! Mr Bloom said.
 20389	
 20390	She took a folded postcard from her handbag.
 20391	
 20392	--Read that, she said. He got it this morning.
 20393	
 20394	--What is it? Mr Bloom asked, taking the card. U.P.?
 20395	
 20396	--U.P.: up, she said. Someone taking a rise out of him. It's a great
 20397	shame for them whoever he is.
 20398	
 20399	--Indeed it is, Mr Bloom said.
 20400	
 20401	She took back the card, sighing.
 20402	
 20403	--And now he's going round to Mr Menton's office. He's going to take an
 20404	action for ten thousand pounds, he says.
 20405	
 20406	She folded the card into her untidy bag and snapped the catch.
 20407	
 20408	Same blue serge dress she had two years ago, the nap bleaching. Seen its
 20409	best days. Wispish hair over her ears. And that dowdy toque: three old
 20410	grapes to take the harm out of it. Shabby genteel. She used to be a
 20411	tasty dresser. Lines round her mouth. Only a year or so older than
 20412	Molly.
 20413	
 20414	See the eye that woman gave her, passing. Cruel. The unfair sex.
 20415	
 20416	He looked still at her, holding back behind his look his discontent.
 20417	Pungent mockturtle oxtail mulligatawny. I'm hungry too. Flakes of pastry
 20418	on the gusset of her dress: daub of sugary flour stuck to her cheek.
 20419	Rhubarb tart with liberal fillings, rich fruit interior. Josie Powell
 20420	that was. In Luke Doyle's long ago. Dolphin's Barn, the charades. U.P.:
 20421	up.
 20422	
 20423	Change the subject.
 20424	
 20425	--Do you ever see anything of Mrs Beaufoy? Mr Bloom asked.
 20426	
 20427	--Mina Purefoy? she said.
 20428	
 20429	Philip Beaufoy I was thinking. Playgoers' Club. Matcham often thinks of
 20430	the masterstroke. Did I pull the chain? Yes. The last act.
 20431	
 20432	--Yes.
 20433	
 20434	--I just called to ask on the way in is she over it. She's in the
 20435	lying-in hospital in Holles street. Dr Horne got her in. She's three
 20436	days bad now.
 20437	
 20438	--O, Mr Bloom said. I'm sorry to hear that.
 20439	
 20440	--Yes, Mrs Breen said. And a houseful of kids at home. It's a very stiff
 20441	birth, the nurse told me.
 20442	
 20443	---O, Mr Bloom said.
 20444	
 20445	His heavy pitying gaze absorbed her news. His tongue clacked in
 20446	compassion. Dth! Dth!
 20447	
 20448	--I'm sorry to hear that, he said. Poor thing! Three days! That's
 20449	terrible for her.
 20450	
 20451	Mrs Breen nodded.
 20452	
 20453	--She was taken bad on the Tuesday...
 20454	
 20455	Mr Bloom touched her funnybone gently, warning her:
 20456	
 20457	--Mind! Let this man pass.
 20458	
 20459	A bony form strode along the curbstone from the river staring with a
 20460	rapt gaze into the sunlight through a heavystringed glass. Tight as a
 20461	skullpiece a tiny hat gripped his head. From his arm a folded dustcoat,
 20462	a stick and an umbrella dangled to his stride.
 20463	
 20464	--Watch him, Mr Bloom said. He always walks outside the lampposts.
 20465	Watch!
 20466	
 20467	--Who is he if it's a fair question? Mrs Breen asked. Is he dotty?
 20468	
 20469	--His name is Cashel Boyle O'Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, Mr
 20470	Bloom said smiling. Watch!
 20471	
 20472	--He has enough of them, she said. Denis will be like that one of these
 20473	days.
 20474	
 20475	She broke off suddenly.
 20476	
 20477	--There he is, she said. I must go after him. Goodbye. Remember me to
 20478	Molly, won't you?
 20479	
 20480	--I will, Mr Bloom said.
 20481	
 20482	He watched her dodge through passers towards the shopfronts. Denis Breen
 20483	in skimpy frockcoat and blue canvas shoes shuffled out of Harrison's
 20484	hugging two heavy tomes to his ribs. Blown in from the bay. Like old
 20485	times. He suffered her to overtake him without surprise and thrust
 20486	his dull grey beard towards her, his loose jaw wagging as he spoke
 20487	earnestly.
 20488	
 20489	Meshuggah. Off his chump.
 20490	
 20491	Mr Bloom walked on again easily, seeing ahead of him in sunlight the
 20492	tight skullpiece, the dangling stickumbrelladustcoat. Going the two
 20493	days. Watch him! Out he goes again. One way of getting on in the world.
 20494	And that other old mosey lunatic in those duds. Hard time she must have
 20495	with him.
 20496	
 20497	U.P.: up. I'll take my oath that's Alf Bergan or Richie Goulding. Wrote
 20498	it for a lark in the Scotch house I bet anything. Round to Menton's
 20499	office. His oyster eyes staring at the postcard. Be a feast for the
 20500	gods.
 20501	
 20502	He passed the _Irish Times_. There might be other answers Iying there.
 20503	Like to answer them all. Good system for criminals. Code. At their lunch
 20504	now. Clerk with the glasses there doesn't know me. O, leave them there
 20505	to simmer. Enough bother wading through fortyfour of them. Wanted, smart
 20506	lady typist to aid gentleman in literary work. I called you naughty
 20507	darling because I do not like that other world. Please tell me what is
 20508	the meaning. Please tell me what perfume does your wife. Tell me who
 20509	made the world. The way they spring those questions on you. And the
 20510	other one Lizzie Twigg. My literary efforts have had the good fortune to
 20511	meet with the approval of the eminent poet A. E. (Mr Geo. Russell). No
 20512	time to do her hair drinking sloppy tea with a book of poetry.
 20513	
 20514	Best paper by long chalks for a small ad. Got the provinces now. Cook
 20515	and general, exc. cuisine, housemaid kept. Wanted live man for spirit
 20516	counter. Resp. girl (R.C.) wishes to hear of post in fruit or pork shop.
 20517	James Carlisle made that. Six and a half per cent dividend. Made a big
 20518	deal on Coates's shares. Ca' canny. Cunning old Scotch hunks. All the
 20519	toady news. Our gracious and popular vicereine. Bought the _Irish Field_
 20520	now. Lady Mountcashel has quite recovered after her confinement and
 20521	rode out with the Ward Union staghounds at the enlargement yesterday
 20522	at Rathoath. Uneatable fox. Pothunters too. Fear injects juices make
 20523	it tender enough for them. Riding astride. Sit her horse like a man.
 20524	Weightcarrying huntress. No sidesaddle or pillion for her, not for Joe.
 20525	First to the meet and in at the death. Strong as a brood mare some of
 20526	those horsey women. Swagger around livery stables. Toss off a glass
 20527	of brandy neat while you'd say knife. That one at the Grosvenor this
 20528	morning. Up with her on the car: wishswish. Stonewall or fivebarred gate
 20529	put her mount to it. Think that pugnosed driver did it out of spite. Who
 20530	is this she was like? O yes! Mrs Miriam Dandrade that sold me her old
 20531	wraps and black underclothes in the Shelbourne hotel. Divorced Spanish
 20532	American. Didn't take a feather out of her my handling them. As if I was
 20533	her clotheshorse. Saw her in the viceregal party when Stubbs the park
 20534	ranger got me in with Whelan of the _Express._ Scavenging what the
 20535	quality left. High tea. Mayonnaise I poured on the plums thinking it was
 20536	custard. Her ears ought to have tingled for a few weeks after. Want to
 20537	be a bull for her. Born courtesan. No nursery work for her, thanks.
 20538	
 20539	Poor Mrs Purefoy! Methodist husband. Method in his madness. Saffron bun
 20540	and milk and soda lunch in the educational dairy. Y. M. C. A. Eating
 20541	with a stopwatch, thirtytwo chews to the minute. And still his
 20542	muttonchop whiskers grew. Supposed to be well connected. Theodore's
 20543	cousin in Dublin Castle. One tony relative in every family. Hardy
 20544	annuals he presents her with. Saw him out at the Three Jolly Topers
 20545	marching along bareheaded and his eldest boy carrying one in a
 20546	marketnet. The squallers. Poor thing! Then having to give the breast
 20547	year after year all hours of the night. Selfish those t.t's are. Dog in
 20548	the manger. Only one lump of sugar in my tea, if you please.
 20549	
 20550	He stood at Fleet street crossing. Luncheon interval. A sixpenny at
 20551	Rowe's? Must look up that ad in the national library. An eightpenny in
 20552	the Burton. Better. On my way.
 20553	
 20554	He walked on past Bolton's Westmoreland house. Tea. Tea. Tea. I forgot
 20555	to tap Tom Kernan.
 20556	
 20557	Sss. Dth, dth, dth! Three days imagine groaning on a bed with a
 20558	vinegared handkerchief round her forehead, her belly swollen out. Phew!
 20559	Dreadful simply! Child's head too big: forceps. Doubled up inside her
 20560	trying to butt its way out blindly, groping for the way out. Kill me
 20561	that would. Lucky Molly got over hers lightly. They ought to invent
 20562	something to stop that. Life with hard labour. Twilight sleep idea:
 20563	queen Victoria was given that. Nine she had. A good layer. Old
 20564	woman that lived in a shoe she had so many children. Suppose he was
 20565	consumptive. Time someone thought about it instead of gassing about the
 20566	what was it the pensive bosom of the silver effulgence. Flapdoodle to
 20567	feed fools on. They could easily have big establishments whole thing
 20568	quite painless out of all the taxes give every child born five quid at
 20569	compound interest up to twentyone five per cent is a hundred shillings
 20570	and five tiresome pounds multiply by twenty decimal system encourage
 20571	people to put by money save hundred and ten and a bit twentyone years
 20572	want to work it out on paper come to a tidy sum more than you think.
 20573	
 20574	Not stillborn of course. They are not even registered. Trouble for
 20575	nothing.
 20576	
 20577	Funny sight two of them together, their bellies out. Molly and Mrs
 20578	Moisel. Mothers' meeting. Phthisis retires for the time being, then
 20579	returns. How flat they look all of a sudden after. Peaceful eyes. Weight
 20580	off their mind. Old Mrs Thornton was a jolly old soul. All my babies,
 20581	she said. The spoon of pap in her mouth before she fed them. O, that's
 20582	nyumnyum. Got her hand crushed by old Tom Wall's son. His first bow to
 20583	the public. Head like a prize pumpkin. Snuffy Dr Murren. People knocking
 20584	them up at all hours. For God' sake, doctor. Wife in her throes. Then
 20585	keep them waiting months for their fee. To attendance on your wife. No
 20586	gratitude in people. Humane doctors, most of them.
 20587	
 20588	Before the huge high door of the Irish house of parliament a flock of
 20589	pigeons flew. Their little frolic after meals. Who will we do it on? I
 20590	pick the fellow in black. Here goes. Here's good luck. Must be thrilling
 20591	from the air. Apjohn, myself and Owen Goldberg up in the trees near
 20592	Goose green playing the monkeys. Mackerel they called me.
 20593	
 20594	A squad of constables debouched from College street, marching in Indian
 20595	file. Goosestep. Foodheated faces, sweating helmets, patting their
 20596	truncheons. After their feed with a good load of fat soup under their
 20597	belts. Policeman's lot is oft a happy one. They split up in groups and
 20598	scattered, saluting, towards their beats. Let out to graze. Best moment
 20599	to attack one in pudding time. A punch in his dinner. A squad of others,
 20600	marching irregularly, rounded Trinity railings making for the station.
 20601	Bound for their troughs. Prepare to receive cavalry. Prepare to receive
 20602	soup.
 20603	
 20604	He crossed under Tommy Moore's roguish finger. They did right to put him
 20605	up over a urinal: meeting of the waters. Ought to be places for women.
 20606	Running into cakeshops. Settle my hat straight. _There is not in this
 20607	wide world a vallee_. Great song of Julia Morkan's. Kept her voice up to
 20608	the very last. Pupil of Michael Balfe's, wasn't she?
 20609	
 20610	He gazed after the last broad tunic. Nasty customers to tackle. Jack
 20611	Power could a tale unfold: father a G man. If a fellow gave them trouble
 20612	being lagged they let him have it hot and heavy in the bridewell.
 20613	Can't blame them after all with the job they have especially the young
 20614	hornies. That horsepoliceman the day Joe Chamberlain was given his
 20615	degree in Trinity he got a run for his money. My word he did! His
 20616	horse's hoofs clattering after us down Abbey street. Lucky I had the
 20617	presence of mind to dive into Manning's or I was souped. He did come a
 20618	wallop, by George. Must have cracked his skull on the cobblestones. I
 20619	oughtn't to have got myself swept along with those medicals. And the
 20620	Trinity jibs in their mortarboards. Looking for trouble. Still I got to
 20621	know that young Dixon who dressed that sting for me in the Mater and now
 20622	he's in Holles street where Mrs Purefoy. Wheels within wheels. Police
 20623	whistle in my ears still. All skedaddled. Why he fixed on me. Give me in
 20624	charge. Right here it began.
 20625	
 20626	--Up the Boers!
 20627	
 20628	--Three cheers for De Wet!
 20629	
 20630	--We'll hang Joe Chamberlain on a sourapple tree.
 20631	
 20632	Silly billies: mob of young cubs yelling their guts out. Vinegar hill.
 20633	The Butter exchange band. Few years' time half of them magistrates and
 20634	civil servants. War comes on: into the army helterskelter: same fellows
 20635	used to. Whether on the scaffold high.
 20636	
 20637	Never know who you're talking to. Corny Kelleher he has Harvey Duff in
 20638	his eye. Like that Peter or Denis or James Carey that blew the gaff on
 20639	the invincibles. Member of the corporation too. Egging raw youths on to
 20640	get in the know all the time drawing secret service pay from the castle.
 20641	Drop him like a hot potato. Why those plainclothes men are always
 20642	courting slaveys. Easily twig a man used to uniform. Squarepushing up
 20643	against a backdoor. Maul her a bit. Then the next thing on the menu. And
 20644	who is the gentleman does be visiting there? Was the young master saying
 20645	anything? Peeping Tom through the keyhole. Decoy duck. Hotblooded young
 20646	student fooling round her fat arms ironing.
 20647	
 20648	--Are those yours, Mary?
 20649	
 20650	--I don't wear such things... Stop or I'll tell the missus on you. Out
 20651	half the night.
 20652	
 20653	--There are great times coming, Mary. Wait till you see.
 20654	
 20655	--Ah, gelong with your great times coming.
 20656	
 20657	Barmaids too. Tobaccoshopgirls.
 20658	
 20659	James Stephens' idea was the best. He knew them. Circles of ten so that
 20660	a fellow couldn't round on more than his own ring. Sinn Fein. Back out
 20661	you get the knife. Hidden hand. Stay in. The firing squad. Turnkey's
 20662	daughter got him out of Richmond, off from Lusk. Putting up in the
 20663	Buckingham Palace hotel under their very noses. Garibaldi.
 20664	
 20665	You must have a certain fascination: Parnell. Arthur Griffith is a
 20666	squareheaded fellow but he has no go in him for the mob. Or gas about
 20667	our lovely land. Gammon and spinach. Dublin Bakery Company's tearoom.
 20668	Debating societies. That republicanism is the best form of government.
 20669	That the language question should take precedence of the economic
 20670	question. Have your daughters inveigling them to your house. Stuff them
 20671	up with meat and drink. Michaelmas goose. Here's a good lump of thyme
 20672	seasoning under the apron for you. Have another quart of goosegrease
 20673	before it gets too cold. Halffed enthusiasts. Penny roll and a walk with
 20674	the band. No grace for the carver. The thought that the other chap pays
 20675	best sauce in the world. Make themselves thoroughly at home. Show us
 20676	over those apricots, meaning peaches. The not far distant day. Homerule
 20677	sun rising up in the northwest.
 20678	
 20679	His smile faded as he walked, a heavy cloud hiding the sun slowly,
 20680	shadowing Trinity's surly front. Trams passed one another, ingoing,
 20681	outgoing, clanging. Useless words. Things go on same, day after day:
 20682	squads of police marching out, back: trams in, out. Those two loonies
 20683	mooching about. Dignam carted off. Mina Purefoy swollen belly on a
 20684	bed groaning to have a child tugged out of her. One born every second
 20685	somewhere. Other dying every second. Since I fed the birds five minutes.
 20686	Three hundred kicked the bucket. Other three hundred born, washing the
 20687	blood off, all are washed in the blood of the lamb, bawling maaaaaa.
 20688	
 20689	Cityful passing away, other cityful coming, passing away too: other
 20690	coming on, passing on. Houses, lines of houses, streets, miles of
 20691	pavements, piledup bricks, stones. Changing hands. This owner, that.
 20692	Landlord never dies they say. Other steps into his shoes when he gets
 20693	his notice to quit. They buy the place up with gold and still they have
 20694	all the gold. Swindle in it somewhere. Piled up in cities, worn away age
 20695	after age. Pyramids in sand. Built on bread and onions. Slaves Chinese
 20696	wall. Babylon. Big stones left. Round towers. Rest rubble, sprawling
 20697	suburbs, jerrybuilt. Kerwan's mushroom houses built of breeze. Shelter,
 20698	for the night.
 20699	
 20700	No-one is anything.
 20701	
 20702	This is the very worst hour of the day. Vitality. Dull, gloomy: hate
 20703	this hour. Feel as if I had been eaten and spewed.
 20704	
 20705	Provost's house. The reverend Dr Salmon: tinned salmon. Well tinned in
 20706	there. Like a mortuary chapel. Wouldn't live in it if they paid me. Hope
 20707	they have liver and bacon today. Nature abhors a vacuum.
 20708	
 20709	The sun freed itself slowly and lit glints of light among the silverware
 20710	opposite in Walter Sexton's window by which John Howard Parnell passed,
 20711	unseeing.
 20712	
 20713	There he is: the brother. Image of him. Haunting face. Now that's a
 20714	coincidence. Course hundreds of times you think of a person and don't
 20715	meet him. Like a man walking in his sleep. No-one knows him. Must be a
 20716	corporation meeting today. They say he never put on the city marshal's
 20717	uniform since he got the job. Charley Kavanagh used to come out on
 20718	his high horse, cocked hat, puffed, powdered and shaved. Look at the
 20719	woebegone walk of him. Eaten a bad egg. Poached eyes on ghost. I have a
 20720	pain. Great man's brother: his brother's brother. He'd look nice on the
 20721	city charger. Drop into the D.B.C. probably for his coffee, play chess
 20722	there. His brother used men as pawns. Let them all go to pot. Afraid to
 20723	pass a remark on him. Freeze them up with that eye of his. That's the
 20724	fascination: the name. All a bit touched. Mad Fanny and his other sister
 20725	Mrs Dickinson driving about with scarlet harness. Bolt upright lik
 20726	surgeon M'Ardle. Still David Sheehy beat him for south Meath. Apply
 20727	for the Chiltern Hundreds and retire into public life. The patriot's
 20728	banquet. Eating orangepeels in the park. Simon Dedalus said when they
 20729	put him in parliament that Parnell would come back from the grave and
 20730	lead him out of the house of commons by the arm.
 20731	
 20732	--Of the twoheaded octopus, one of whose heads is the head upon which
 20733	the ends of the world have forgotten to come while the other speaks with
 20734	a Scotch accent. The tentacles...
 20735	
 20736	They passed from behind Mr Bloom along the curbstone. Beard and bicycle.
 20737	Young woman.
 20738	
 20739	And there he is too. Now that's really a coincidence: second time.
 20740	Coming events cast their shadows before. With the approval of the
 20741	eminent poet, Mr Geo. Russell. That might be Lizzie Twigg with him. A.
 20742	E.: what does that mean? Initials perhaps. Albert Edward, Arthur Edmund,
 20743	Alphonsus Eb Ed El Esquire. What was he saying? The ends of the world
 20744	with a Scotch accent. Tentacles: octopus. Something occult: symbolism.
 20745	Holding forth. She's taking it all in. Not saying a word. To aid
 20746	gentleman in literary work.
 20747	
 20748	His eyes followed the high figure in homespun, beard and bicycle,
 20749	a listening woman at his side. Coming from the vegetarian. Only
 20750	weggebobbles and fruit. Don't eat a beefsteak. If you do the eyes of
 20751	that cow will pursue you through all eternity. They say it's healthier.
 20752	Windandwatery though. Tried it. Keep you on the run all day. Bad as
 20753	a bloater. Dreams all night. Why do they call that thing they gave me
 20754	nutsteak? Nutarians. Fruitarians. To give you the idea you are eating
 20755	rumpsteak. Absurd. Salty too. They cook in soda. Keep you sitting by the
 20756	tap all night.
 20757	
 20758	Her stockings are loose over her ankles. I detest that: so tasteless.
 20759	Those literary etherial people they are all. Dreamy, cloudy,
 20760	symbolistic. Esthetes they are. I wouldn't be surprised if it was that
 20761	kind of food you see produces the like waves of the brain the poetical.
 20762	For example one of those policemen sweating Irish stew into their shirts
 20763	you couldn't squeeze a line of poetry out of him. Don't know what poetry
 20764	is even. Must be in a certain mood.
 20765	
 20766	     _The dreamy cloudy gull
 20767	     Waves o'er the waters dull._
 20768	
 20769	He crossed at Nassau street corner and stood before the window of Yeates
 20770	and Son, pricing the fieldglasses. Or will I drop into old Harris's and
 20771	have a chat with young Sinclair? Wellmannered fellow. Probably at his
 20772	lunch. Must get those old glasses of mine set right. Goerz lenses six
 20773	guineas. Germans making their way everywhere. Sell on easy terms to
 20774	capture trade. Undercutting. Might chance on a pair in the railway lost
 20775	property office. Astonishing the things people leave behind them in
 20776	trains and cloakrooms. What do they be thinking about? Women too.
 20777	Incredible. Last year travelling to Ennis had to pick up that farmer's
 20778	daughter's ba and hand it to her at Limerick junction. Unclaimed money
 20779	too. There's a little watch up there on the roof of the bank to test
 20780	those glasses by.
 20781	
 20782	
 20783	His lids came down on the lower rims of his irides. Can't see it. If you
 20784	imagine it's there you can almost see it. Can't see it.
 20785	
 20786	He faced about and, standing between the awnings, held out his right
 20787	hand at arm's length towards the sun. Wanted to try that often. Yes:
 20788	completely. The tip of his little finger blotted out the sun's disk.
 20789	Must be the focus where the rays cross. If I had black glasses.
 20790	Interesting. There was a lot of talk about those sunspots when we
 20791	were in Lombard street west. Looking up from the back garden. Terrific
 20792	explosions they are. There will be a total eclipse this year: autumn
 20793	some time.
 20794	
 20795	Now that I come to think of it that ball falls at Greenwich time. It's
 20796	the clock is worked by an electric wire from Dunsink. Must go out there
 20797	some first Saturday of the month. If I could get an introduction to
 20798	professor Joly or learn up something about his family. That would do to:
 20799	man always feels complimented. Flattery where least expected. Nobleman
 20800	proud to be descended from some king's mistress. His foremother. Lay it
 20801	on with a trowel. Cap in hand goes through the land. Not go in and blurt
 20802	out what you know you're not to: what's parallax? Show this gentleman
 20803	the door.
 20804	
 20805	Ah.
 20806	
 20807	His hand fell to his side again.
 20808	
 20809	Never know anything about it. Waste of time. Gasballs spinning about,
 20810	crossing each other, passing. Same old dingdong always. Gas: then solid:
 20811	then world: then cold: then dead shell drifting around, frozen rock,
 20812	like that pineapple rock. The moon. Must be a new moon out, she said. I
 20813	believe there is.
 20814	
 20815	He went on by la maison Claire.
 20816	
 20817	Wait. The full moon was the night we were Sunday fortnight exactly there
 20818	is a new moon. Walking down by the Tolka. Not bad for a Fairview moon.
 20819	She was humming. The young May moon she's beaming, love. He other side
 20820	of her. Elbow, arm. He. Glowworm's la-amp is gleaming, love. Touch.
 20821	Fingers. Asking. Answer. Yes.
 20822	
 20823	Stop. Stop. If it was it was. Must.
 20824	
 20825	Mr Bloom, quickbreathing, slowlier walking passed Adam court.
 20826	
 20827	With a keep quiet relief his eyes took note this is the street here
 20828	middle of the day of Bob Doran's bottle shoulders. On his annual bend,
 20829	M Coy said. They drink in order to say or do something or _cherchez la
 20830	femme_. Up in the Coombe with chummies and streetwalkers and then the
 20831	rest of the year sober as a judge.
 20832	
 20833	Yes. Thought so. Sloping into the Empire. Gone. Plain soda would do him
 20834	good. Where Pat Kinsella had his Harp theatre before Whitbred ran the
 20835	Queen's. Broth of a boy. Dion Boucicault business with his harvestmoon
 20836	face in a poky bonnet. Three Purty Maids from School. How time flies,
 20837	eh? Showing long red pantaloons under his skirts. Drinkers, drinking,
 20838	laughed spluttering, their drink against their breath. More power, Pat.
 20839	Coarse red: fun for drunkards: guffaw and smoke. Take off that white
 20840	hat. His parboiled eyes. Where is he now? Beggar somewhere. The harp
 20841	that once did starve us all.
 20842	
 20843	I was happier then. Or was that I? Or am I now I? Twentyeight I was. She
 20844	twentythree. When we left Lombard street west something changed. Could
 20845	never like it again after Rudy. Can't bring back time. Like holding
 20846	water in your hand. Would you go back to then? Just beginning then.
 20847	Would you? Are you not happy in your home you poor little naughty boy?
 20848	Wants to sew on buttons for me. I must answer. Write it in the library.
 20849	
 20850	Grafton street gay with housed awnings lured his senses. Muslin prints,
 20851	silkdames and dowagers, jingle of harnesses, hoofthuds lowringing in the
 20852	baking causeway. Thick feet that woman has in the white stockings. Hope
 20853	the rain mucks them up on her. Countrybred chawbacon. All the beef to
 20854	the heels were in. Always gives a woman clumsy feet. Molly looks out of
 20855	plumb.
 20856	
 20857	He passed, dallying, the windows of Brown Thomas, silk mercers. Cascades
 20858	of ribbons. Flimsy China silks. A tilted urn poured from its mouth a
 20859	flood of bloodhued poplin: lustrous blood. The huguenots brought that
 20860	here. _La causa Ã¨ santa_! Tara tara. Great chorus that. Taree tara. Must
 20861	be washed in rainwater. Meyerbeer. Tara: bom bom bom.
 20862	
 20863	Pincushions. I'm a long time threatening to buy one. Sticking them all
 20864	over the place. Needles in window curtains.
 20865	
 20866	He bared slightly his left forearm. Scrape: nearly gone. Not today
 20867	anyhow. Must go back for that lotion. For her birthday perhaps.
 20868	Junejulyaugseptember eighth. Nearly three months off. Then she mightn't
 20869	like it. Women won't pick up pins. Say it cuts lo.
 20870	
 20871	Gleaming silks, petticoats on slim brass rails, rays of flat silk
 20872	stockings.
 20873	
 20874	Useless to go back. Had to be. Tell me all.
 20875	
 20876	High voices. Sunwarm silk. Jingling harnesses. All for a woman, home and
 20877	houses, silkwebs, silver, rich fruits spicy from Jaffa. Agendath Netaim.
 20878	Wealth of the world.
 20879	
 20880	A warm human plumpness settled down on his brain. His brain yielded.
 20881	Perfume of embraces all him assailed. With hungered flesh obscurely, he
 20882	mutely craved to adore.
 20883	
 20884	Duke street. Here we are. Must eat. The Burton. Feel better then.
 20885	
 20886	He turned Combridge's corner, still pursued. Jingling, hoofthuds.
 20887	Perfumed bodies, warm, full. All kissed, yielded: in deep summer fields,
 20888	tangled pressed grass, in trickling hallways of tenements, along sofas,
 20889	creaking beds.
 20890	
 20891	--Jack, love!
 20892	
 20893	--Darling!
 20894	
 20895	--Kiss me, Reggy!
 20896	
 20897	--My boy!
 20898	
 20899	--Love!
 20900	
 20901	His heart astir he pushed in the door of the Burton restaurant. Stink
 20902	gripped his trembling breath: pungent meatjuice, slush of greens. See
 20903	the animals feed.
 20904	
 20905	Men, men, men.
 20906	
 20907	Perched on high stools by the bar, hats shoved back, at the tables
 20908	calling for more bread no charge, swilling, wolfing gobfuls of sloppy
 20909	food, their eyes bulging, wiping wetted moustaches. A pallid suetfaced
 20910	young man polished his tumbler knife fork and spoon with his napkin. New
 20911	set of microbes. A man with an infant's saucestained napkin tucked round
 20912	him shovelled gurgling soup down his gullet. A man spitting back on his
 20913	plate: halfmasticated gristle: gums: no teeth to chewchewchew it. Chump
 20914	chop from the grill. Bolting to get it over. Sad booser's eyes. Bitten
 20915	off more than he can chew. Am I like that? See ourselves as others see
 20916	us. Hungry man is an angry man. Working tooth and jaw. Don't! O! A bone!
 20917	That last pagan king of Ireland Cormac in the schoolpoem choked himself
 20918	at Sletty southward of the Boyne. Wonder what he was eating. Something
 20919	galoptious. Saint Patrick converted him to Christianity. Couldn't
 20920	swallow it all however.
 20921	
 20922	--Roast beef and cabbage.
 20923	
 20924	--One stew.
 20925	
 20926	Smells of men. His gorge rose. Spaton sawdust, sweetish warmish
 20927	cigarette smoke, reek of plug, spilt beer, men's beery piss, the stale
 20928	of ferment.
 20929	
 20930	Couldn't eat a morsel here. Fellow sharpening knife and fork to eat all
 20931	before him, old chap picking his tootles. Slight spasm, full, chewing
 20932	the cud. Before and after. Grace after meals. Look on this picture then
 20933	on that. Scoffing up stewgravy with sopping sippets of bread. Lick it
 20934	off the plate, man! Get out of this.
 20935	
 20936	He gazed round the stooled and tabled eaters, tightening the wings of
 20937	his nose.
 20938	
 20939	--Two stouts here.
 20940	
 20941	--One corned and cabbage.
 20942	
 20943	That fellow ramming a knifeful of cabbage down as if his life depended
 20944	on it. Good stroke. Give me the fidgets to look. Safer to eat from his
 20945	three hands. Tear it limb from limb. Second nature to him. Born with a
 20946	silver knife in his mouth. That's witty, I think. Or no. Silver means
 20947	born rich. Born with a knife. But then the allusion is lost.
 20948	
 20949	An illgirt server gathered sticky clattering plates. Rock, the head
 20950	bailiff, standing at the bar blew the foamy crown from his tankard. Well
 20951	up: it splashed yellow near his boot. A diner, knife and fork upright,
 20952	elbows on table, ready for a second helping stared towards the foodlift
 20953	across his stained square of newspaper. Other chap telling him something
 20954	with his mouth full. Sympathetic listener. Table talk. I munched hum un
 20955	thu Unchster Bunk un Munchday. Ha? Did you, faith?
 20956	
 20957	Mr Bloom raised two fingers doubtfully to his lips. His eyes said:
 20958	
 20959	--Not here. Don't see him.
 20960	
 20961	Out. I hate dirty eaters.
 20962	
 20963	He backed towards the door. Get a light snack in Davy Byrne's. Stopgap.
 20964	Keep me going. Had a good breakfast.
 20965	
 20966	--Roast and mashed here.
 20967	
 20968	--Pint of stout.
 20969	
 20970	Every fellow for his own, tooth and nail. Gulp. Grub. Gulp. Gobstuff.
 20971	
 20972	He came out into clearer air and turned back towards Grafton street. Eat
 20973	or be eaten. Kill! Kill!
 20974	
 20975	Suppose that communal kitchen years to come perhaps. All trotting down
 20976	with porringers and tommycans to be filled. Devour contents in the
 20977	street. John Howard Parnell example the provost of Trinity every
 20978	mother's son don't talk of your provosts and provost of Trinity women
 20979	and children cabmen priests parsons fieldmarshals archbishops. From
 20980	Ailesbury road, Clyde road, artisans' dwellings, north Dublin union,
 20981	lord mayor in his gingerbread coach, old queen in a bathchair. My
 20982	plate's empty. After you with our incorporated drinkingcup. Like sir
 20983	Philip Crampton's fountain. Rub off the microbes with your handkerchief.
 20984	Next chap rubs on a new batch with his. Father O'Flynn would make
 20985	hares of them all. Have rows all the same. All for number one. Children
 20986	fighting for the scrapings of the pot. Want a souppot as big as the
 20987	Phoenix park. Harpooning flitches and hindquarters out of it. Hate
 20988	people all round you. City Arms hotel _table d'hÃ´te_ she called it.
 20989	Soup, joint and sweet. Never know whose thoughts you're chewing. Then
 20990	who'd wash up all the plates and forks? Might be all feeding on tabloids
 20991	that time. Teeth getting worse and worse.
 20992	
 20993	After all there's a lot in that vegetarian fine flavour of things from
 20994	the earth garlic of course it stinks after Italian organgrinders crisp
 20995	of onions mushrooms truffles. Pain to the animal too. Pluck and draw
 20996	fowl. Wretched brutes there at the cattlemarket waiting for the poleaxe
 20997	to split their skulls open. Moo. Poor trembling calves. Meh. Staggering
 20998	bob. Bubble and squeak. Butchers' buckets wobbly lights. Give us that
 20999	brisket off the hook. Plup. Rawhead and bloody bones. Flayed glasseyed
 21000	sheep hung from their haunches, sheepsnouts bloodypapered snivelling
 21001	nosejam on sawdust. Top and lashers going out. Don't maul them pieces,
 21002	young one.
 21003	
 21004	Hot fresh blood they prescribe for decline. Blood always needed.
 21005	Insidious. Lick it up smokinghot, thick sugary. Famished ghosts.
 21006	
 21007	Ah, I'm hungry.
 21008	
 21009	He entered Davy Byrne's. Moral pub. He doesn't chat. Stands a drink now
 21010	and then. But in leapyear once in four. Cashed a cheque for me once.
 21011	
 21012	What will I take now? He drew his watch. Let me see now. Shandygaff?
 21013	
 21014	--Hello, Bloom, Nosey Flynn said from his nook.
 21015	
 21016	--Hello, Flynn.
 21017	
 21018	--How's things?
 21019	
 21020	--Tiptop... Let me see. I'll take a glass of burgundy and... let me
 21021	see.
 21022	
 21023	Sardines on the shelves. Almost taste them by looking. Sandwich? Ham
 21024	and his descendants musterred and bred there. Potted meats. What is home
 21025	without Plumtree's potted meat? Incomplete. What a stupid ad! Under the
 21026	obituary notices they stuck it. All up a plumtree. Dignam's potted meat.
 21027	Cannibals would with lemon and rice. White missionary too salty. Like
 21028	pickled pork. Expect the chief consumes the parts of honour. Ought to be
 21029	tough from exercise. His wives in a row to watch the effect. _There was
 21030	a right royal old nigger. Who ate or something the somethings of the
 21031	reverend Mr MacTrigger_. With it an abode of bliss. Lord knows what
 21032	concoction. Cauls mouldy tripes windpipes faked and minced up. Puzzle
 21033	find the meat. Kosher. No meat and milk together. Hygiene that was what
 21034	they call now. Yom Kippur fast spring cleaning of inside. Peace and
 21035	war depend on some fellow's digestion. Religions. Christmas turkeys and
 21036	geese. Slaughter of innocents. Eat drink and be merry. Then casual wards
 21037	full after. Heads bandaged. Cheese digests all but itself. Mity cheese.
 21038	
 21039	--Have you a cheese sandwich?
 21040	
 21041	--Yes, sir.
 21042	
 21043	Like a few olives too if they had them. Italian I prefer. Good glass of
 21044	burgundy take away that. Lubricate. A nice salad, cool as a cucumber,
 21045	Tom Kernan can dress. Puts gusto into it. Pure olive oil. Milly served
 21046	me that cutlet with a sprig of parsley. Take one Spanish onion. God made
 21047	food, the devil the cooks. Devilled crab.
 21048	
 21049	--Wife well?
 21050	
 21051	--Quite well, thanks... A cheese sandwich, then. Gorgonzola, have you?
 21052	
 21053	--Yes, sir.
 21054	
 21055	Nosey Flynn sipped his grog.
 21056	
 21057	--Doing any singing those times?
 21058	
 21059	Look at his mouth. Could whistle in his own ear. Flap ears to match.
 21060	Music. Knows as much about it as my coachman. Still better tell him.
 21061	Does no harm. Free ad.
 21062	
 21063	--She's engaged for a big tour end of this month. You may have heard
 21064	perhaps.
 21065	
 21066	--No. O, that's the style. Who's getting it up?
 21067	
 21068	The curate served.
 21069	
 21070	--How much is that?
 21071

 21073	
 21074	Mr Bloom cut his sandwich into slender strips. _Mr MacTrigger_. Easier
 21075	than the dreamy creamy stuff. _His five hundred wives. Had the time of
 21076	their lives._
 21077	
 21078	--Mustard, sir?
 21079
