 21081	
 21082	He studded under each lifted strip yellow blobs. _Their lives_. I have
 21083	it. _It grew bigger and bigger and bigger_.
 21084	
 21085	--Getting it up? he said. Well, it's like a company idea, you see. Part
 21086	shares and part profits.
 21087	
 21088	--Ay, now I remember, Nosey Flynn said, putting his hand in his pocket
 21089	to scratch his groin. Who is this was telling me? Isn't Blazes Boylan
 21090	mixed up in it?
 21091	
 21092	A warm shock of air heat of mustard hanched on Mr Bloom's heart. He
 21093	raised his eyes and met the stare of a bilious clock. Two. Pub clock
 21094	five minutes fast. Time going on. Hands moving. Two. Not yet.
 21095	
 21096	His midriff yearned then upward, sank within him, yearned more longly,
 21097	longingly.
 21098	
 21099	Wine.
 21100	
 21101	He smellsipped the cordial juice and, bidding his throat strongly to
 21102	speed it, set his wineglass delicately down.
 21103	
 21104	--Yes, he said. He's the organiser in point of fact.
 21105	
 21106	No fear: no brains.
 21107	
 21108	Nosey Flynn snuffled and scratched. Flea having a good square meal.
 21109	
 21110	--He had a good slice of luck, Jack Mooney was telling me, over that
 21111	boxingmatch Myler Keogh won again that soldier in the Portobello
 21112	barracks. By God, he had the little kipper down in the county Carlow he
 21113	was telling me...

 21117	--For near a month, man, before it came off. Sucking duck eggs by God
 21118	till further orders. Keep him off the boose, see? O, by God, Blazes is a
 21119	hairy chap.
 21120	
 21121	Davy Byrne came forward from the hindbar in tuckstitched shirtsleeves,
 21122	cleaning his lips with two wipes of his napkin. Herring's blush. Whose
 21123	smile upon each feature plays with such and such replete. Too much fat
 21124	on the parsnips.
 21125	
 21126	--And here's himself and pepper on him, Nosey Flynn said. Can you give
 21127	us a good one for the Gold cup?
 21128	
 21129	--I'm off that, Mr Flynn, Davy Byrne answered. I never put anything on a
 21130	horse.
 21131	
 21132	--You're right there, Nosey Flynn said.
 21133	
 21134	Mr Bloom ate his strips of sandwich, fresh clean bread, with relish of
 21135	disgust pungent mustard, the feety savour of green cheese. Sips of his
 21136	wine soothed his palate. Not logwood that. Tastes fuller this weather
 21137	with the chill off.
 21138	
 21139	Nice quiet bar. Nice piece of wood in that counter. Nicely planed. Like
 21140	the way it curves there.
 21141	
 21142	--I wouldn't do anything at all in that line, Davy Byrne said. It ruined
 21143	many a man, the same horses.
 21144	
 21145	Vintners' sweepstake. Licensed for the sale of beer, wine and spirits
 21146	for consumption on the premises. Heads I win tails you lose.
 21147	
 21148	--True for you, Nosey Flynn said. Unless you're in the know. There's
 21149	no straight sport going now. Lenehan gets some good ones. He's giving
 21150	Sceptre today. Zinfandel's the favourite, lord Howard de Walden's, won
 21151	at Epsom. Morny Cannon is riding him. I could have got seven to one
 21152	against Saint Amant a fortnight before.
 21153	
 21154	--That so? Davy Byrne said...
 21155	
 21156	He went towards the window and, taking up the pettycash book, scanned
 21157	its pages.
 21158	
 21159	--I could, faith, Nosey Flynn said, snuffling. That was a rare bit of
 21160	horseflesh. Saint Frusquin was her sire. She won in a thunderstorm,
 21161	Rothschild's filly, with wadding in her ears. Blue jacket and yellow
 21162	cap. Bad luck to big Ben Dollard and his John O'Gaunt. He put me off it.
 21163	Ay.
 21164	
 21165	He drank resignedly from his tumbler, running his fingers down the
 21166	flutes.
 21167	
 21168	--Ay, he said, sighing.
 21169	
 21170	Mr Bloom, champing, standing, looked upon his sigh. Nosey numbskull.
 21171	Will I tell him that horse Lenehan? He knows already. Better let him
 21172	forget. Go and lose more. Fool and his money. Dewdrop coming down again.
 21173	Cold nose he'd have kissing a woman. Still they might like. Prickly
 21174	beards they like. Dogs' cold noses. Old Mrs Riordan with the rumbling
 21175	stomach's Skye terrier in the City Arms hotel. Molly fondling him in her
 21176	lap. O, the big doggybowwowsywowsy!
 21177	
 21178	Wine soaked and softened rolled pith of bread mustard a moment mawkish
 21179	cheese. Nice wine it is. Taste it better because I'm not thirsty. Bath
 21180	of course does that. Just a bite or two. Then about six o'clock I can.
 21181	Six. Six. Time will be gone then. She...
 21182	
 21183	Mild fire of wine kindled his veins. I wanted that badly. Felt so
 21184	off colour. His eyes unhungrily saw shelves of tins: sardines, gaudy
 21185	lobsters' claws. All the odd things people pick up for food. Out of
 21186	shells, periwinkles with a pin, off trees, snails out of the ground the
 21187	French eat, out of the sea with bait on a hook. Silly fish learn nothing
 21188	in a thousand years. If you didn't know risky putting anything into your
 21189	mouth. Poisonous berries. Johnny Magories. Roundness you think good.
 21190	Gaudy colour warns you off. One fellow told another and so on. Try it
 21191	on the dog first. Led on by the smell or the look. Tempting fruit.
 21192	Ice cones. Cream. Instinct. Orangegroves for instance. Need artificial
 21193	irrigation. Bleibtreustrasse. Yes but what about oysters. Unsightly like
 21194	a clot of phlegm. Filthy shells. Devil to open them too. Who found them
 21195	out? Garbage, sewage they feed on. Fizz and Red bank oysters. Effect
 21196	on the sexual. Aphrodis. He was in the Red Bank this morning. Was he
 21197	oysters old fish at table perhaps he young flesh in bed no June has
 21198	no ar no oysters. But there are people like things high. Tainted game.
 21199	Jugged hare. First catch your hare. Chinese eating eggs fifty years old,
 21200	blue and green again. Dinner of thirty courses. Each dish harmless might
 21201	mix inside. Idea for a poison mystery. That archduke Leopold was it no
 21202	yes or was it Otto one of those Habsburgs? Or who was it used to eat the
 21203	scruff off his own head? Cheapest lunch in town. Of course aristocrats,
 21204	then the others copy to be in the fashion. Milly too rock oil and flour.
 21205	Raw pastry I like myself. Half the catch of oysters they throw back in
 21206	the sea to keep up the price. Cheap no-one would buy. Caviare. Do the
 21207	grand. Hock in green glasses. Swell blowout. Lady this. Powdered bosom
 21208	pearls. The _Ã©lite. CrÃ¨me de la crÃ¨me_. They want special dishes to
 21209	pretend they're. Hermit with a platter of pulse keep down the stings
 21210	of the flesh. Know me come eat with me. Royal sturgeon high sheriff,
 21211	Coffey, the butcher, right to venisons of the forest from his ex. Send
 21212	him back the half of a cow. Spread I saw down in the Master of the

 21214	Curly cabbage _Ã  la duchesse de Parme_. Just as well to write it on the

 21216	broth. I know it myself. Dosing it with Edwards' desiccated soup. Geese
 21217	stuffed silly for them. Lobsters boiled alive. Do ptake some ptarmigan.
 21218	Wouldn't mind being a waiter in a swell hotel. Tips, evening dress,
 21219	halfnaked ladies. May I tempt you to a little more filleted lemon sole,
 21220	miss Dubedat? Yes, do bedad. And she did bedad. Huguenot name I expect
 21221	that. A miss Dubedat lived in Killiney, I remember. _Du, de la_ French.
 21222	Still it's the same fish perhaps old Micky Hanlon of Moore street ripped

 21226	brogues, worth fifty thousand pounds.
 21227	
 21228	Stuck on the pane two flies buzzed, stuck.
 21229	
 21230	Glowing wine on his palate lingered swallowed. Crushing in the winepress
 21231	grapes of Burgundy. Sun's heat it is. Seems to a secret touch telling me
 21232	memory. Touched his sense moistened remembered. Hidden under wild ferns
 21233	on Howth below us bay sleeping: sky. No sound. The sky. The bay purple
 21234	by the Lion's head. Green by Drumleck. Yellowgreen towards Sutton.
 21235	Fields of undersea, the lines faint brown in grass, buried cities.
 21236	Pillowed on my coat she had her hair, earwigs in the heather scrub
 21237	my hand under her nape, you'll toss me all. O wonder! Coolsoft with
 21238	ointments her hand touched me, caressed: her eyes upon me did not turn
 21239	away. Ravished over her I lay, full lips full open, kissed her mouth.
 21240	Yum. Softly she gave me in my mouth the seedcake warm and chewed.
 21241	Mawkish pulp her mouth had mumbled sweetsour of her spittle. Joy: I ate
 21242	it: joy. Young life, her lips that gave me pouting. Soft warm sticky
 21243	gumjelly lips. Flowers her eyes were, take me, willing eyes. Pebbles
 21244	fell. She lay still. A goat. No-one. High on Ben Howth rhododendrons a
 21245	nannygoat walking surefooted, dropping currants. Screened under ferns
 21246	she laughed warmfolded. Wildly I lay on her, kissed her: eyes, her lips,
 21247	her stretched neck beating, woman's breasts full in her blouse of nun's
 21248	veiling, fat nipples upright. Hot I tongued her. She kissed me. I was
 21249	kissed. All yielding she tossed my hair. Kissed, she kissed me.
 21250	
 21251	Me. And me now.
 21252	
 21253	Stuck, the flies buzzed.
 21254	
 21255	His downcast eyes followed the silent veining of the oaken slab. Beauty:
 21256	it curves: curves are beauty. Shapely goddesses, Venus, Juno: curves the
 21257	world admires. Can see them library museum standing in the round hall,
 21258	naked goddesses. Aids to digestion. They don't care what man looks. All
 21259	to see. Never speaking. I mean to say to fellows like Flynn. Suppose she
 21260	did Pygmalion and Galatea what would she say first? Mortal! Put you in
 21261	your proper place. Quaffing nectar at mess with gods golden dishes, all
 21262	ambrosial. Not like a tanner lunch we have, boiled mutton, carrots and
 21263	turnips, bottle of Allsop. Nectar imagine it drinking electricity: gods'
 21264	food. Lovely forms of women sculped Junonian. Immortal lovely. And we
 21265	stuffing food in one hole and out behind: food, chyle, blood, dung,
 21266	earth, food: have to feed it like stoking an engine. They have no. Never
 21267	looked. I'll look today. Keeper won't see. Bend down let something drop
 21268	see if she.
 21269	
 21270	Dribbling a quiet message from his bladder came to go to do not to
 21271	do there to do. A man and ready he drained his glass to the lees and
 21272	walked, to men too they gave themselves, manly conscious, lay with men
 21273	lovers, a youth enjoyed her, to the yard.
 21274	
 21275	When the sound of his boots had ceased Davy Byrne said from his book:
 21276	
 21277	--What is this he is? Isn't he in the insurance line?
 21278	
 21279	--He's out of that long ago, Nosey Flynn said. He does canvassing for
 21280	the _Freeman._
 21281	
 21282	--I know him well to see, Davy Byrne said. Is he in trouble?
 21283	
 21284	--Trouble? Nosey Flynn said. Not that I heard of. Why?
 21285	
 21286	--I noticed he was in mourning.
 21287	
 21288	--Was he? Nosey Flynn said. So he was, faith. I asked him how was all at
 21289	home. You're right, by God. So he was.
 21290	
 21291	--I never broach the subject, Davy Byrne said humanely, if I see a
 21292	gentleman is in trouble that way. It only brings it up fresh in their
 21293	minds.
 21294	
 21295	--It's not the wife anyhow, Nosey Flynn said. I met him the day before
 21296	yesterday and he coming out of that Irish farm dairy John Wyse Nolan's
 21297	wife has in Henry street with a jar of cream in his hand taking it home
 21298	to his better half. She's well nourished, I tell you. Plovers on toast.
 21299	
 21300	--And is he doing for the _Freeman?_ Davy Byrne said.
 21301	
 21302	Nosey Flynn pursed his lips.
 21303	
 21304	---He doesn't buy cream on the ads he picks up. You can make bacon of
 21305	that.
 21306	
 21307	--How so? Davy Byrne asked, coming from his book.
 21308	
 21309	Nosey Flynn made swift passes in the air with juggling fingers. He
 21310	winked.
 21311	
 21312	--He's in the craft, he said.
 21313	
 21314	---Do you tell me so? Davy Byrne said.
 21315	
 21316	--Very much so, Nosey Flynn said. Ancient free and accepted order. He's
 21317	an excellent brother. Light, life and love, by God. They give him a leg
 21318	up. I was told that by a--well, I won't say who.
 21319	
 21320	--Is that a fact?
 21321	
 21322	--O, it's a fine order, Nosey Flynn said. They stick to you when you're
 21323	down. I know a fellow was trying to get into it. But they're as close as
 21324	damn it. By God they did right to keep the women out of it.
 21325	
 21326	Davy Byrne smiledyawnednodded all in one:
 21327	
 21328	--Iiiiiichaaaaaaach!
 21329	
 21330	--There was one woman, Nosey Flynn said, hid herself in a clock to find
 21331	out what they do be doing. But be damned but they smelt her out and
 21332	swore her in on the spot a master mason. That was one of the saint
 21333	Legers of Doneraile.
 21334	
 21335	Davy Byrne, sated after his yawn, said with tearwashed eyes:
 21336	
 21337	--And is that a fact? Decent quiet man he is. I often saw him in here
 21338	and I never once saw him--you know, over the line.
 21339	
 21340	--God Almighty couldn't make him drunk, Nosey Flynn said firmly. Slips
 21341	off when the fun gets too hot. Didn't you see him look at his watch? Ah,
 21342	you weren't there. If you ask him to have a drink first thing he does
 21343	he outs with the watch to see what he ought to imbibe. Declare to God he
 21344	does.
 21345	
 21346	--There are some like that, Davy Byrne said. He's a safe man, I'd say.
 21347	
 21348	--He's not too bad, Nosey Flynn said, snuffling it up. He's been known
 21349	to put his hand down too to help a fellow. Give the devil his due. O,
 21350	Bloom has his good points. But there's one thing he'll never do.
 21351	
 21352	His hand scrawled a dry pen signature beside his grog.
 21353	
 21354	--I know, Davy Byrne said.
 21355	
 21356	--Nothing in black and white, Nosey Flynn said.
 21357	
 21358	Paddy Leonard and Bantam Lyons came in. Tom Rochford followed frowning,
 21359	a plaining hand on his claret waistcoat.
 21360	
 21361	--Day, Mr Byrne.
 21362	
 21363	--Day, gentlemen.
 21364	
 21365	They paused at the counter.
 21366	
 21367	--Who's standing? Paddy Leonard asked.
 21368	
 21369	--I'm sitting anyhow, Nosey Flynn answered.
 21370	
 21371	--Well, what'll it be? Paddy Leonard asked.
 21372	
 21373	--I'll take a stone ginger, Bantam Lyons said.
 21374	
 21375	--How much? Paddy Leonard cried. Since when, for God' sake? What's
 21376	yours, Tom?
 21377	
 21378	--How is the main drainage? Nosey Flynn asked, sipping.
 21379	
 21380	For answer Tom Rochford pressed his hand to his breastbone and
 21381	hiccupped.
 21382	
 21383	--Would I trouble you for a glass of fresh water, Mr Byrne? he said.
 21384	
 21385	--Certainly, sir.
 21386	
 21387	Paddy Leonard eyed his alemates.
 21388	
 21389	--Lord love a duck, he said. Look at what I'm standing drinks to! Cold
 21390	water and gingerpop! Two fellows that would suck whisky off a sore leg.
 21391	He has some bloody horse up his sleeve for the Gold cup. A dead snip.
 21392	
 21393	--Zinfandel is it? Nosey Flynn asked.
 21394	
 21395	Tom Rochford spilt powder from a twisted paper into the water set before
 21396	him.
 21397	
 21398	--That cursed dyspepsia, he said before drinking.
 21399	
 21400	--Breadsoda is very good, Davy Byrne said.
 21401	
 21402	Tom Rochford nodded and drank.
 21403	
 21404	--Is it Zinfandel?
 21405	
 21406	--Say nothing! Bantam Lyons winked. I'm going to plunge five bob on my
 21407	own.
 21408	
 21409	--Tell us if you're worth your salt and be damned to you, Paddy Leonard
 21410	said. Who gave it to you?
 21411	
 21412	Mr Bloom on his way out raised three fingers in greeting.
 21413	
 21414	--So long! Nosey Flynn said.
 21415	
 21416	The others turned.
 21417	
 21418	--That's the man now that gave it to me, Bantam Lyons whispered.
 21419	
 21420	--Prrwht! Paddy Leonard said with scorn. Mr Byrne, sir, we'll take two
 21421	of your small Jamesons after that and a...
 21422	
 21423	--Stone ginger, Davy Byrne added civilly.
 21424	
 21425	--Ay, Paddy Leonard said. A suckingbottle for the baby.
 21426	
 21427	Mr Bloom walked towards Dawson street, his tongue brushing his teeth
 21428	smooth. Something green it would have to be: spinach, say. Then with
 21429	those Rontgen rays searchlight you could.
 21430	
 21431	At Duke lane a ravenous terrier choked up a sick knuckly cud on the
 21432	cobblestones and lapped it with new zest. Surfeit. Returned with thanks
 21433	having fully digested the contents. First sweet then savoury. Mr Bloom
 21434	coasted warily. Ruminants. His second course. Their upper jaw they move.
 21435	Wonder if Tom Rochford will do anything with that invention of his?
 21436	Wasting time explaining it to Flynn's mouth. Lean people long mouths.
 21437	Ought to be a hall or a place where inventors could go in and invent
 21438	free. Course then you'd have all the cranks pestering.
 21439	
 21440	He hummed, prolonging in solemn echo the closes of the bars:
 21441	
 21442	_Don Giovanni, a cenar teco M'invitasti._
 21443	
 21444	Feel better. Burgundy. Good pick me up. Who distilled first? Some chap
 21445	in the blues. Dutch courage. That _Kilkenny People_ in the national
 21446	library now I must.
 21447	
 21448	Bare clean closestools waiting in the window of William Miller, plumber,
 21449	turned back his thoughts. They could: and watch it all the way down,
 21450	swallow a pin sometimes come out of the ribs years after, tour round the
 21451	body changing biliary duct spleen squirting liver gastric juice coils of
 21452	intestines like pipes. But the poor buffer would have to stand all the
 21453	time with his insides entrails on show. Science.
 21454	
 21455	--_A cenar teco._
 21456	
 21457	What does that _teco_ mean? Tonight perhaps.
 21458	
 21459	     _Don Giovanni, thou hast me invited
 21460	     To come to supper tonight,
 21461	     The rum the rumdum._
 21462	
 21463	Doesn't go properly.
 21464	
 21465	Keyes: two months if I get Nannetti to. That'll be two pounds ten about
 21466	two pounds eight. Three Hynes owes me. Two eleven. Prescott's dyeworks
 21467	van over there. If I get Billy Prescott's ad: two fifteen. Five guineas
 21468	about. On the pig's back.
 21469	
 21470	Could buy one of those silk petticoats for Molly, colour of her new
 21471	garters.
 21472	
 21473	Today. Today. Not think.
 21474	
 21475	Tour the south then. What about English wateringplaces? Brighton,
 21476	Margate. Piers by moonlight. Her voice floating out. Those lovely
 21477	seaside girls. Against John Long's a drowsing loafer lounged in heavy
 21478	thought, gnawing a crusted knuckle. Handy man wants job. Small wages.
 21479	Will eat anything.
 21480	
 21481	Mr Bloom turned at Gray's confectioner's window of unbought tarts and
 21482	passed the reverend Thomas Connellan's bookstore. _Why I left the church
 21483	of Rome? Birds' Nest._ Women run him. They say they used to give pauper
 21484	children soup to change to protestants in the time of the potato blight.
 21485	Society over the way papa went to for the conversion of poor jews. Same
 21486	bait. Why we left the church of Rome.
 21487	
 21488	A blind stripling stood tapping the curbstone with his slender cane. No
 21489	tram in sight. Wants to cross.
 21490	
 21491	--Do you want to cross? Mr Bloom asked.
 21492	
 21493	The blind stripling did not answer. His wallface frowned weakly. He
 21494	moved his head uncertainly.
 21495	
 21496	--You're in Dawson street, Mr Bloom said. Molesworth street is opposite.
 21497	Do you want to cross? There's nothing in the way.
 21498	
 21499	The cane moved out trembling to the left. Mr Bloom's eye followed its
 21500	line and saw again the dyeworks' van drawn up before Drago's. Where I
 21501	saw his brillantined hair just when I was. Horse drooping. Driver in
 21502	John Long's. Slaking his drouth.
 21503	
 21504	--There's a van there, Mr Bloom said, but it's not moving. I'll see you
 21505	across. Do you want to go to Molesworth street?
 21506	
 21507	--Yes, the stripling answered. South Frederick street.
 21508	
 21509	--Come, Mr Bloom said.
 21510	
 21511	He touched the thin elbow gently: then took the limp seeing hand to
 21512	guide it forward.
 21513	
 21514	Say something to him. Better not do the condescending. They mistrust
 21515	what you tell them. Pass a common remark.
 21516	
 21517	--The rain kept off.
 21518	
 21519	No answer.
 21520	
 21521	Stains on his coat. Slobbers his food, I suppose. Tastes all different
 21522	for him. Have to be spoonfed first. Like a child's hand, his hand. Like
 21523	Milly's was. Sensitive. Sizing me up I daresay from my hand. Wonder
 21524	if he has a name. Van. Keep his cane clear of the horse's legs: tired
 21525	drudge get his doze. That's right. Clear. Behind a bull: in front of a
 21526	horse.
 21527	
 21528	--Thanks, sir.
 21529	
 21530	Knows I'm a man. Voice.
 21531	
 21532	--Right now? First turn to the left.
 21533	
 21534	The blind stripling tapped the curbstone and went on his way, drawing
 21535	his cane back, feeling again.
 21536	
 21537	Mr Bloom walked behind the eyeless feet, a flatcut suit of herringbone
 21538	tweed. Poor young fellow! How on earth did he know that van was there?
 21539	Must have felt it. See things in their forehead perhaps: kind of sense
 21540	of volume. Weight or size of it, something blacker than the dark. Wonder
 21541	would he feel it if something was removed. Feel a gap. Queer idea of
 21542	Dublin he must have, tapping his way round by the stones. Could he walk
 21543	in a beeline if he hadn't that cane? Bloodless pious face like a fellow
 21544	going in to be a priest.
 21545	
 21546	Penrose! That was that chap's name.
 21547	
 21548	Look at all the things they can learn to do. Read with their fingers.
 21549	Tune pianos. Or we are surprised they have any brains. Why we think a
 21550	deformed person or a hunchback clever if he says something we might say.
 21551	Of course the other senses are more. Embroider. Plait baskets. People
 21552	ought to help. Workbasket I could buy for Molly's birthday. Hates
 21553	sewing. Might take an objection. Dark men they call them.
 21554	
 21555	Sense of smell must be stronger too. Smells on all sides, bunched
 21556	together. Each street different smell. Each person too. Then the spring,
 21557	the summer: smells. Tastes? They say you can't taste wines with your
 21558	eyes shut or a cold in the head. Also smoke in the dark they say get no
 21559	pleasure.
 21560	
 21561	And with a woman, for instance. More shameless not seeing. That girl
 21562	passing the Stewart institution, head in the air. Look at me. I have
 21563	them all on. Must be strange not to see her. Kind of a form in his
 21564	mind's eye. The voice, temperatures: when he touches her with his
 21565	fingers must almost see the lines, the curves. His hands on her hair,
 21566	for instance. Say it was black, for instance. Good. We call it black.
 21567	Then passing over her white skin. Different feel perhaps. Feeling of
 21568	white.
 21569	
 21570	Postoffice. Must answer. Fag today. Send her a postal order two
 21571	shillings, half a crown. Accept my little present. Stationer's just here
 21572	too. Wait. Think over it.
 21573	
 21574	With a gentle finger he felt ever so slowly the hair combed back above
 21575	his ears. Again. Fibres of fine fine straw. Then gently his finger felt
 21576	the skin of his right cheek. Downy hair there too. Not smooth enough.
 21577	The belly is the smoothest. No-one about. There he goes into Frederick
 21578	street. Perhaps to Levenston's dancing academy piano. Might be settling
 21579	my braces.
 21580	
 21581	Walking by Doran's publichouse he slid his hand between his waistcoat
 21582	and trousers and, pulling aside his shirt gently, felt a slack fold of
 21583	his belly. But I know it's whitey yellow. Want to try in the dark to
 21584	see.
 21585	
 21586	He withdrew his hand and pulled his dress to.
 21587	
 21588	Poor fellow! Quite a boy. Terrible. Really terrible. What dreams would
 21589	he have, not seeing? Life a dream for him. Where is the justice being
 21590	born that way? All those women and children excursion beanfeast burned
 21591	and drowned in New York. Holocaust. Karma they call that transmigration
 21592	for sins you did in a past life the reincarnation met him pike hoses.
 21593	Dear, dear, dear. Pity, of course: but somehow you can't cotton on to
 21594	them someway.
 21595	
 21596	Sir Frederick Falkiner going into the freemasons' hall. Solemn as Troy.
 21597	After his good lunch in Earlsfort terrace. Old legal cronies cracking
 21598	a magnum. Tales of the bench and assizes and annals of the bluecoat
 21599	school. I sentenced him to ten years. I suppose he'd turn up his nose
 21600	at that stuff I drank. Vintage wine for them, the year marked on a
 21601	dusty bottle. Has his own ideas of justice in the recorder's court.
 21602	Wellmeaning old man. Police chargesheets crammed with cases get their
 21603	percentage manufacturing crime. Sends them to the rightabout. The devil
 21604	on moneylenders. Gave Reuben J. a great strawcalling. Now he's really
 21605	what they call a dirty jew. Power those judges have. Crusty old topers
 21606	in wigs. Bear with a sore paw. And may the Lord have mercy on your soul.
 21607	
 21608	Hello, placard. Mirus bazaar. His Excellency the lord lieutenant.
 21609	Sixteenth. Today it is. In aid of funds for Mercer's hospital. _The
 21610	Messiah_ was first given for that. Yes. Handel. What about going out
 21611	there: Ballsbridge. Drop in on Keyes. No use sticking to him like a
 21612	leech. Wear out my welcome. Sure to know someone on the gate.
 21613	
 21614	Mr Bloom came to Kildare street. First I must. Library.
 21615	
 21616	Straw hat in sunlight. Tan shoes. Turnedup trousers. It is. It is.
 21617	
 21618	His heart quopped softly. To the right. Museum. Goddesses. He swerved to
 21619	the right.
 21620	
 21621	Is it? Almost certain. Won't look. Wine in my face. Why did I? Too
 21622	heady. Yes, it is. The walk. Not see. Get on.
 21623	
 21624	Making for the museum gate with long windy steps he lifted his eyes.
 21625	Handsome building. Sir Thomas Deane designed. Not following me?
 21626	
 21627	Didn't see me perhaps. Light in his eyes.
 21628	
 21629	The flutter of his breath came forth in short sighs. Quick. Cold
 21630	statues: quiet there. Safe in a minute.
 21631	
 21632	No. Didn't see me. After two. Just at the gate.
 21633	
 21634	My heart!
 21635	
 21636	His eyes beating looked steadfastly at cream curves of stone. Sir Thomas
 21637	Deane was the Greek architecture.
 21638	
 21639	Look for something I.
 21640	
 21641	His hasty hand went quick into a pocket, took out, read unfolded
 21642	Agendath Netaim. Where did I?
 21643	
 21644	Busy looking.
 21645	
 21646	He thrust back quick Agendath.
 21647	
 21648	Afternoon she said.
 21649	
 21650	I am looking for that. Yes, that. Try all pockets. Handker. _Freeman._
 21651	Where did I? Ah, yes. Trousers. Potato. Purse. Where?
 21652	
 21653	Hurry. Walk quietly. Moment more. My heart.
 21654	
 21655	His hand looking for the where did I put found in his hip pocket soap
 21656	lotion have to call tepid paper stuck. Ah soap there I yes. Gate.
 21657	
 21658	Safe!
 21659	
 21660	
 21661	Urbane, to comfort them, the quaker librarian purred:
 21662	
 21663	
 21664	--And we have, have we not, those priceless pages of _Wilhelm Meister_.
 21665	A great poet on a great brother poet. A hesitating soul taking arms
 21666	against a sea of troubles, torn by conflicting doubts, as one sees in
 21667	real life.
 21668	
 21669	He came a step a sinkapace forward on neatsleather creaking and a step
 21670	backward a sinkapace on the solemn floor.
 21671	
 21672	A noiseless attendant setting open the door but slightly made him a
 21673	noiseless beck.
 21674	
 21675	--Directly, said he, creaking to go, albeit lingering. The beautiful
 21676	ineffectual dreamer who comes to grief against hard facts. One always
 21677	feels that Goethe's judgments are so true. True in the larger analysis.
 21678	
 21679	Twicreakingly analysis he corantoed off. Bald, most zealous by the door
 21680	he gave his large ear all to the attendant's words: heard them: and was
 21681	gone.
 21682	
 21683	Two left.
 21684	
 21685	--Monsieur de la Palice, Stephen sneered, was alive fifteen minutes
 21686	before his death.
 21687	
 21688	--Have you found those six brave medicals, John Eglinton asked with
 21689	elder's gall, to write _Paradise Lost_ at your dictation? _The Sorrows
 21690	of Satan_ he calls it.
 21691	
 21692	Smile. Smile Cranly's smile.
 21693	
 21694	     _First he tickled her
 21695	     Then he patted her
 21696	     Then he passed the female catheter.
 21697	     For he was a medical
 21698	     Jolly old medi..._
 21699	
 21700	--I feel you would need one more for _Hamlet._ Seven is dear to the
 21701	mystic mind. The shining seven W.B. calls them.
 21702	
 21703	Glittereyed his rufous skull close to his greencapped desklamp sought
 21704	the face bearded amid darkgreener shadow, an ollav, holyeyed. He laughed
 21705	low: a sizar's laugh of Trinity: unanswered.
 21706	
 21707	     _Orchestral Satan, weeping many a rood
 21708	     Tears such as angels weep.
 21709	     Ed egli avea del cul fatto trombetta._
 21710	
 21711	He holds my follies hostage.
 21712	
 21713	Cranly's eleven true Wicklowmen to free their sireland. Gaptoothed
 21714	Kathleen, her four beautiful green fields, the stranger in her house.
 21715	And one more to hail him: _ave, rabbi_: the Tinahely twelve. In the
 21716	shadow of the glen he cooees for them. My soul's youth I gave him, night
 21717	by night. God speed. Good hunting.
 21718	
 21719	Mulligan has my telegram.
 21720	
 21721	Folly. Persist.
 21722	
 21723	--Our young Irish bards, John Eglinton censured, have yet to create a
 21724	figure which the world will set beside Saxon Shakespeare's Hamlet though
 21725	I admire him, as old Ben did, on this side idolatry.
 21726	
 21727	--All these questions are purely academic, Russell oracled out of his
 21728	shadow. I mean, whether Hamlet is Shakespeare or James I or Essex.
 21729	Clergymen's discussions of the historicity of Jesus. Art has to reveal
 21730	to us ideas, formless spiritual essences. The supreme question about a
 21731	work of art is out of how deep a life does it spring. The painting of
 21732	Gustave Moreau is the painting of ideas. The deepest poetry of Shelley,
 21733	the words of Hamlet bring our minds into contact with the eternal
 21734	wisdom, Plato's world of ideas. All the rest is the speculation of
 21735	schoolboys for schoolboys.
 21736	
 21737	A. E. has been telling some yankee interviewer. Wall, tarnation strike
 21738	me!
 21739	
 21740	--The schoolmen were schoolboys first, Stephen said superpolitely.
 21741	Aristotle was once Plato's schoolboy.
 21742	
 21743	--And has remained so, one should hope, John Eglinton sedately said. One
 21744	can see him, a model schoolboy with his diploma under his arm.
 21745	
 21746	He laughed again at the now smiling bearded face.
 21747	
 21748	Formless spiritual. Father, Word and Holy Breath. Allfather, the
 21749	heavenly man. Hiesos Kristos, magician of the beautiful, the Logos who
 21750	suffers in us at every moment. This verily is that. I am the fire upon
 21751	the altar. I am the sacrificial butter.
 21752	
 21753	Dunlop, Judge, the noblest Roman of them all, A.E., Arval, the Name
 21754	Ineffable, in heaven hight: K.H., their master, whose identity is no
 21755	secret to adepts. Brothers of the great white lodge always watching
 21756	to see if they can help. The Christ with the bridesister, moisture of
 21757	light, born of an ensouled virgin, repentant sophia, departed to the
 21758	plane of buddhi. The life esoteric is not for ordinary person. O.P.
 21759	must work off bad karma first. Mrs Cooper Oakley once glimpsed our very
 21760	illustrious sister H.P.B.'s elemental.
 21761	
 21762	O, fie! Out on't! _Pfuiteufel!_ You naughtn't to look, missus, so you
 21763	naughtn't when a lady's ashowing of her elemental.
 21764	
 21765	Mr Best entered, tall, young, mild, light. He bore in his hand with
 21766	grace a notebook, new, large, clean, bright.
 21767	
 21768	--That model schoolboy, Stephen said, would find Hamlet's musings about
 21769	the afterlife of his princely soul, the improbable, insignificant and
 21770	undramatic monologue, as shallow as Plato's.
 21771	
 21772	John Eglinton, frowning, said, waxing wroth:
 21773	
 21774	--Upon my word it makes my blood boil to hear anyone compare Aristotle
 21775	with Plato.
 21776	
 21777	--Which of the two, Stephen asked, would have banished me from his
 21778	commonwealth?
 21779	
 21780	Unsheathe your dagger definitions. Horseness is the whatness of
 21781	allhorse. Streams of tendency and eons they worship. God: noise in the
 21782	street: very peripatetic. Space: what you damn well have to see. Through
 21783	spaces smaller than red globules of man's blood they creepycrawl after
 21784	Blake's buttocks into eternity of which this vegetable world is but a
 21785	shadow. Hold to the now, the here, through which all future plunges to
 21786	the past.
 21787	
 21788	Mr Best came forward, amiable, towards his colleague.
 21789	
 21790	--Haines is gone, he said.
 21791	
 21792	--Is he?
 21793	
 21794	--I was showing him Jubainville's book. He's quite enthusiastic, don't
 21795	you know, about Hyde's _Lovesongs of Connacht._ I couldn't bring him in
 21796	to hear the discussion. He's gone to Gill's to buy it.
 21797	
 21798	     _Bound thee forth, my booklet, quick
 21799	     To greet the callous public.
 21800	     Writ, I ween, 'twas not my wish
 21801	     In lean unlovely English._
 21802	
 21803	--The peatsmoke is going to his head, John Eglinton opined.
 21804	
 21805	We feel in England. Penitent thief. Gone. I smoked his baccy. Green
 21806	twinkling stone. An emerald set in the ring of the sea.
 21807	
 21808	--People do not know how dangerous lovesongs can be, the auric egg of
 21809	Russell warned occultly. The movements which work revolutions in the
 21810	world are born out of the dreams and visions in a peasant's heart on the
 21811	hillside. For them the earth is not an exploitable ground but the
 21812	living mother. The rarefied air of the academy and the arena produce the
 21813	sixshilling novel, the musichall song. France produces the finest flower
 21814	of corruption in Mallarme but the desirable life is revealed only to the
 21815	poor of heart, the life of Homer's Phaeacians.
 21816	
 21817	From these words Mr Best turned an unoffending face to Stephen.
 21818	
 21819	--Mallarme, don't you know, he said, has written those wonderful prose
 21820	poems Stephen MacKenna used to read to me in Paris. The one about
 21821	_Hamlet._ He says: _il se promÃ¨ne, lisant au livre de lui-mÃªme_, don't
 21822	you know, _reading the book of himself_. He describes _Hamlet_ given in
 21823	a French town, don't you know, a provincial town. They advertised it.
 21824	
 21825	His free hand graciously wrote tiny signs in air.
 21826	
 21827	     _HAMLET
 21828	     ou
 21829	     LE DISTRAIT
 21830	     PiÃ¨ce de Shakespeare_
 21831	
 21832	He repeated to John Eglinton's newgathered frown:
 21833	
 21834	--_PiÃ¨ce de Shakespeare_, don't you know. It's so French. The French
 21835	point of view. _Hamlet ou_...
 21836	
 21837	--The absentminded beggar, Stephen ended.
 21838	
 21839	John Eglinton laughed.
 21840	
 21841	--Yes, I suppose it would be, he said. Excellent people, no doubt, but
 21842	distressingly shortsighted in some matters.
 21843	
 21844	Sumptuous and stagnant exaggeration of murder.
 21845	
 21846	--A deathsman of the soul Robert Greene called him, Stephen said. Not
 21847	for nothing was he a butcher's son, wielding the sledded poleaxe and
 21848	spitting in his palms. Nine lives are taken off for his father's one.
 21849	Our Father who art in purgatory. Khaki Hamlets don't hesitate to
 21850	shoot. The bloodboltered shambles in act five is a forecast of the
 21851	concentration camp sung by Mr Swinburne.
 21852	
 21853	Cranly, I his mute orderly, following battles from afar.
 21854	
 21855	_Whelps and dams of murderous foes whom none But we had spared..._
 21856	
 21857	Between the Saxon smile and yankee yawp. The devil and the deep sea.
 21858	
 21859	--He will have it that _Hamlet_ is a ghoststory, John Eglinton said
 21860	for Mr Best's behoof. Like the fat boy in Pickwick he wants to make our
 21861	flesh creep.
 21862	
 21863	_List! List! O List!_
 21864	
 21865	My flesh hears him: creeping, hears.
 21866	
 21867	_If thou didst ever..._
 21868	
 21869	--What is a ghost? Stephen said with tingling energy. One who has faded
 21870	into impalpability through death, through absence, through change of
 21871	manners. Elizabethan London lay as far from Stratford as corrupt Paris
 21872	lies from virgin Dublin. Who is the ghost from _limbo patrum_, returning
 21873	to the world that has forgotten him? Who is King Hamlet?
 21874	
 21875	John Eglinton shifted his spare body, leaning back to judge.
 21876	
 21877	Lifted.
 21878	
 21879	--It is this hour of a day in mid June, Stephen said, begging with
 21880	a swift glance their hearing. The flag is up on the playhouse by the
 21881	bankside. The bear Sackerson growls in the pit near it, Paris garden.
 21882	Canvasclimbers who sailed with Drake chew their sausages among the
 21883	groundlings.
 21884	
 21885	Local colour. Work in all you know. Make them accomplices.
 21886	
 21887	--Shakespeare has left the huguenot's house in Silver street and walks
 21888	by the swanmews along the riverbank. But he does not stay to feed the
 21889	pen chivying her game of cygnets towards the rushes. The swan of Avon
 21890	has other thoughts.
 21891	
 21892	Composition of place. Ignatius Loyola, make haste to help me!
 21893	
 21894	--The play begins. A player comes on under the shadow, made up in the
 21895	castoff mail of a court buck, a wellset man with a bass voice. It is the
 21896	ghost, the king, a king and no king, and the player is Shakespeare who
 21897	has studied _Hamlet_ all the years of his life which were not vanity in
 21898	order to play the part of the spectre. He speaks the words to Burbage,
 21899	the young player who stands before him beyond the rack of cerecloth,
 21900	calling him by a name:
 21901	
 21902	_Hamlet, I am thy father's spirit,_
 21903	
 21904	bidding him list. To a son he speaks, the son of his soul, the prince,
 21905	young Hamlet and to the son of his body, Hamnet Shakespeare, who has
 21906	died in Stratford that his namesake may live for ever.
 21907	
 21908	Is it possible that that player Shakespeare, a ghost by absence, and in
 21909	the vesture of buried Denmark, a ghost by death, speaking his own words
 21910	to his own son's name (had Hamnet Shakespeare lived he would have been
 21911	prince Hamlet's twin), is it possible, I want to know, or probable that
 21912	he did not draw or foresee the logical conclusion of those premises: you
 21913	are the dispossessed son: I am the murdered father: your mother is the
 21914	guilty queen, Ann Shakespeare, born Hathaway?
 21915	
 21916	--But this prying into the family life of a great man, Russell began
 21917	impatiently.
 21918	
 21919	Art thou there, truepenny?
 21920	
 21921	--Interesting only to the parish clerk. I mean, we have the plays. I
 21922	mean when we read the poetry of _King Lear_ what is it to us how the
 21923	poet lived? As for living our servants can do that for us, Villiers de
 21924	l'Isle has said. Peeping and prying into greenroom gossip of the day,
 21925	the poet's drinking, the poet's debts. We have _King Lear_: and it is
 21926	immortal.
 21927	
 21928	Mr Best's face, appealed to, agreed.
 21929	
 21930	_Flow over them with your waves and with your waters, Mananaan, Mananaan
 21931	MacLir..._
 21932	
 21933	How now, sirrah, that pound he lent you when you were hungry?
 21934	
 21935	Marry, I wanted it.
 21936	
 21937	Take thou this noble.
 21938	
 21939	Go to! You spent most of it in Georgina Johnson's bed, clergyman's
 21940	daughter. Agenbite of inwit.
 21941	
 21942	Do you intend to pay it back?
 21943	
 21944	O, yes.
 21945	
 21946	When? Now?
 21947	
 21948	Well... No.
 21949	
 21950	When, then?
 21951	
 21952	I paid my way. I paid my way.
 21953	
 21954	Steady on. He's from beyant Boyne water. The northeast corner. You owe
 21955	it.
 21956	
 21957	Wait. Five months. Molecules all change. I am other I now. Other I got
 21958	pound.
 21959	
 21960	Buzz. Buzz.
 21961	
 21962	But I, entelechy, form of forms, am I by memory because under
 21963	everchanging forms.
 21964	
 21965	I that sinned and prayed and fasted.
 21966	
 21967	A child Conmee saved from pandies.
 21968	
 21969	I, I and I. I.
 21970	
 21971	A.E.I.O.U.
 21972	
 21973	--Do you mean to fly in the face of the tradition of three centuries?
 21974	John Eglinton's carping voice asked. Her ghost at least has been laid
 21975	for ever. She died, for literature at least, before she was born.
 21976	
 21977	--She died, Stephen retorted, sixtyseven years after she was born. She
 21978	saw him into and out of the world. She took his first embraces. She bore
 21979	his children and she laid pennies on his eyes to keep his eyelids closed
 21980	when he lay on his deathbed.
 21981	
 21982	Mother's deathbed. Candle. The sheeted mirror. Who brought me into
 21983	this world lies there, bronzelidded, under few cheap flowers. _Liliata
 21984	rutilantium._
 21985	
 21986	I wept alone.
 21987	
 21988	John Eglinton looked in the tangled glowworm of his lamp.
 21989	
 21990	--The world believes that Shakespeare made a mistake, he said, and got
 21991	out of it as quickly and as best he could.
 21992	
 21993	--Bosh! Stephen said rudely. A man of genius makes no mistakes. His
 21994	errors are volitional and are the portals of discovery.
 21995	
 21996	Portals of discovery opened to let in the quaker librarian,
 21997	softcreakfooted, bald, eared and assiduous.
 21998	
 21999	--A shrew, John Eglinton said shrewdly, is not a useful portal of
 22000	discovery, one should imagine. What useful discovery did Socrates learn
 22001	from Xanthippe?
 22002	
 22003	--Dialectic, Stephen answered: and from his mother how to bring thoughts
 22004	into the world. What he learnt from his other wife Myrto (_absit
 22005	nomen!_), Socratididion's Epipsychidion, no man, not a woman, will ever
 22006	know. But neither the midwife's lore nor the caudlelectures saved him
 22007	from the archons of Sinn Fein and their naggin of hemlock.
 22008	
 22009	--But Ann Hathaway? Mr Best's quiet voice said forgetfully. Yes, we seem
 22010	to be forgetting her as Shakespeare himself forgot her.
 22011	
 22012	His look went from brooder's beard to carper's skull, to remind, to
 22013	chide them not unkindly, then to the baldpink lollard costard, guiltless
 22014	though maligned.
 22015	
 22016	--He had a good groatsworth of wit, Stephen said, and no truant memory.
 22017	He carried a memory in his wallet as he trudged to Romeville whistling
 22018	_The girl I left behind me._ If the earthquake did not time it we should
 22019	know where to place poor Wat, sitting in his form, the cry of hounds,
 22020	the studded bridle and her blue windows. That memory, _Venus and
 22021	Adonis_, lay in the bedchamber of every light-of-love in London.
 22022	Is Katharine the shrew illfavoured? Hortensio calls her young and
 22023	beautiful. Do you think the writer of _Antony and Cleopatra_, a
 22024	passionate pilgrim, had his eyes in the back of his head that he chose
 22025	the ugliest doxy in all Warwickshire to lie withal? Good: he left her
 22026	and gained the world of men. But his boywomen are the women of a boy.
 22027	Their life, thought, speech are lent them by males. He chose badly? He
 22028	was chosen, it seems to me. If others have their will Ann hath a way.
 22029	By cock, she was to blame. She put the comether on him, sweet and
 22030	twentysix. The greyeyed goddess who bends over the boy Adonis, stooping
 22031	to conquer, as prologue to the swelling act, is a boldfaced Stratford
 22032	wench who tumbles in a cornfield a lover younger than herself.
 22033	
 22034	And my turn? When?
 22035	
 22036	Come!
 22037	
 22038	--Ryefield, Mr Best said brightly, gladly, raising his new book, gladly,
 22039	brightly.
 22040	
 22041	He murmured then with blond delight for all:
 22042	
 22043	_Between the acres of the rye These pretty countryfolk would lie._
 22044	
 22045	Paris: the wellpleased pleaser.
 22046	
 22047	A tall figure in bearded homespun rose from shadow and unveiled its
 22048	cooperative watch.
 22049	
 22050	--I am afraid I am due at the _Homestead._
 22051	
 22052	Whither away? Exploitable ground.
 22053	
 22054	--Are you going? John Eglinton's active eyebrows asked. Shall we see you
 22055	at Moore's tonight? Piper is coming.
 22056	
 22057	--Piper! Mr Best piped. Is Piper back?
 22058	
 22059	Peter Piper pecked a peck of pick of peck of pickled pepper.
 22060	
 22061	--I don't know if I can. Thursday. We have our meeting. If I can get
 22062	away in time.
 22063	
 22064	Yogibogeybox in Dawson chambers. _Isis Unveiled._ Their Pali book we
 22065	tried to pawn. Crosslegged under an umbrel umbershoot he thrones an
 22066	Aztec logos, functioning on astral levels, their oversoul, mahamahatma.
 22067	The faithful hermetists await the light, ripe for chelaship,
 22068	ringroundabout him. Louis H. Victory. T. Caulfield Irwin. Lotus ladies
 22069	tend them i'the eyes, their pineal glands aglow. Filled with his god,
 22070	he thrones, Buddh under plantain. Gulfer of souls, engulfer. Hesouls,
 22071	shesouls, shoals of souls. Engulfed with wailing creecries, whirled,
 22072	whirling, they bewail.
 22073	
 22074	     _In quintessential triviality
 22075	     For years in this fleshcase a shesoul dwelt._
 22076	
 22077	--They say we are to have a literary surprise, the quaker librarian
 22078	said, friendly and earnest. Mr Russell, rumour has it, is gathering
 22079	together a sheaf of our younger poets' verses. We are all looking
 22080	forward anxiously.
 22081	
 22082	Anxiously he glanced in the cone of lamplight where three faces,
 22083	lighted, shone.
 22084	
 22085	See this. Remember.
 22086	
 22087	Stephen looked down on a wide headless caubeen, hung on his
 22088	ashplanthandle over his knee. My casque and sword. Touch lightly with
 22089	two index fingers. Aristotle's experiment. One or two? Necessity is that
 22090	in virtue of which it is impossible that one can be otherwise. Argal,
 22091	one hat is one hat.
 22092	
 22093	Listen.
 22094	
 22095	Young Colum and Starkey. George Roberts is doing the commercial part.
 22096	Longworth will give it a good puff in the _Express._ O, will he? I liked
 22097	Colum's _Drover._ Yes, I think he has that queer thing genius. Do you
 22098	think he has genius really? Yeats admired his line: _As in wild earth
 22099	a Grecian vase_. Did he? I hope you'll be able to come tonight. Malachi
 22100	Mulligan is coming too. Moore asked him to bring Haines. Did you hear
 22101	Miss Mitchell's joke about Moore and Martyn? That Moore is Martyn's
 22102	wild oats? Awfully clever, isn't it? They remind one of Don Quixote and
 22103	Sancho Panza. Our national epic has yet to be written, Dr Sigerson says.
 22104	Moore is the man for it. A knight of the rueful countenance here in
 22105	Dublin. With a saffron kilt? O'Neill Russell? O, yes, he must speak the
 22106	grand old tongue. And his Dulcinea? James Stephens is doing some clever
 22107	sketches. We are becoming important, it seems.
 22108	
 22109	Cordelia. _Cordoglio._ Lir's loneliest daughter.
 22110	
 22111	Nookshotten. Now your best French polish.
 22112	
 22113	--Thank you very much, Mr Russell, Stephen said, rising. If you will be
 22114	so kind as to give the letter to Mr Norman...
 22115	
 22116	--O, yes. If he considers it important it will go in. We have so much
 22117	correspondence.
 22118	
 22119	--I understand, Stephen said. Thanks.
 22120	
 22121	God ild you. The pigs' paper. Bullockbefriending.
 22122	
 22123	Synge has promised me an article for _Dana_ too. Are we going to be
 22124	read? I feel we are. The Gaelic league wants something in Irish. I hope
 22125	you will come round tonight. Bring Starkey.
 22126	
 22127	Stephen sat down.
 22128	
 22129	The quaker librarian came from the leavetakers. Blushing, his mask said:
 22130	
 22131	--Mr Dedalus, your views are most illuminating.
 22132	
 22133	He creaked to and fro, tiptoing up nearer heaven by the altitude of a
 22134	chopine, and, covered by the noise of outgoing, said low:
 22135	
 22136	--Is it your view, then, that she was not faithful to the poet?
 22137	
 22138	Alarmed face asks me. Why did he come? Courtesy or an inward light?
 22139	
 22140	--Where there is a reconciliation, Stephen said, there must have been
 22141	first a sundering.
 22142	
 22143	--Yes.
 22144	
 22145	Christfox in leather trews, hiding, a runaway in blighted treeforks,
 22146	from hue and cry. Knowing no vixen, walking lonely in the chase. Women
 22147	he won to him, tender people, a whore of Babylon, ladies of justices,
 22148	bully tapsters' wives. Fox and geese. And in New Place a slack
 22149	dishonoured body that once was comely, once as sweet, as fresh as
 22150	cinnamon, now her leaves falling, all, bare, frighted of the narrow
 22151	grave and unforgiven.
 22152	
 22153	--Yes. So you think...
 22154	
 22155	The door closed behind the outgoer.
 22156	
 22157	Rest suddenly possessed the discreet vaulted cell, rest of warm and
 22158	brooding air.
 22159	
 22160	A vestal's lamp.
 22161	
 22162	Here he ponders things that were not: what Caesar would have lived to do
 22163	had he believed the soothsayer: what might have been: possibilities of
 22164	the possible as possible: things not known: what name Achilles bore when
 22165	he lived among women.
 22166	
 22167	Coffined thoughts around me, in mummycases, embalmed in spice of words.
 22168	Thoth, god of libraries, a birdgod, moonycrowned. And I heard the
 22169	voice of that Egyptian highpriest. _In painted chambers loaded with
 22170	tilebooks._
 22171	
 22172	They are still. Once quick in the brains of men. Still: but an itch of
 22173	death is in them, to tell me in my ear a maudlin tale, urge me to wreak
 22174	their will.
 22175	
 22176	--Certainly, John Eglinton mused, of all great men he is the most
 22177	enigmatic. We know nothing but that he lived and suffered. Not even so
 22178	much. Others abide our question. A shadow hangs over all the rest.
 22179	
 22180	--But _Hamlet_ is so personal, isn't it? Mr Best pleaded. I mean, a kind
 22181	of private paper, don't you know, of his private life. I mean, I don't
 22182	care a button, don't you know, who is killed or who is guilty...
 22183	
 22184	He rested an innocent book on the edge of the desk, smiling his
 22185	defiance. His private papers in the original. _Ta an bad ar an tir. Taim
 22186	in mo shagart_. Put beurla on it, littlejohn.
 22187	
 22188	Quoth littlejohn Eglinton:
 22189	
 22190	--I was prepared for paradoxes from what Malachi Mulligan told us but
 22191	I may as well warn you that if you want to shake my belief that
 22192	Shakespeare is Hamlet you have a stern task before you.
 22193	
 22194	Bear with me.
 22195	
 22196	Stephen withstood the bane of miscreant eyes glinting stern under
 22197	wrinkled brows. A basilisk. _E quando vede l'uomo l'attosca_. Messer
 22198	Brunetto, I thank thee for the word.
 22199	
 22200	--As we, or mother Dana, weave and unweave our bodies, Stephen said,
 22201	from day to day, their molecules shuttled to and fro, so does the artist
 22202	weave and unweave his image. And as the mole on my right breast is where
 22203	it was when I was born, though all my body has been woven of new stuff
 22204	time after time, so through the ghost of the unquiet father the image
 22205	of the unliving son looks forth. In the intense instant of imagination,
 22206	when the mind, Shelley says, is a fading coal, that which I was is that
 22207	which I am and that which in possibility I may come to be. So in the
 22208	future, the sister of the past, I may see myself as I sit here now but
 22209	by reflection from that which then I shall be.
 22210	
 22211	Drummond of Hawthornden helped you at that stile.
 22212	
 22213	--Yes, Mr Best said youngly. I feel Hamlet quite young. The bitterness
 22214	might be from the father but the passages with Ophelia are surely from
 22215	the son.
 22216	
 22217	Has the wrong sow by the lug. He is in my father. I am in his son.
 22218	
 22219	--That mole is the last to go, Stephen said, laughing.
 22220	
 22221	John Eglinton made a nothing pleasing mow.
 22222	
 22223	--If that were the birthmark of genius, he said, genius would be a
 22224	drug in the market. The plays of Shakespeare's later years which Renan
 22225	admired so much breathe another spirit.
 22226	
 22227	--The spirit of reconciliation, the quaker librarian breathed.
 22228	
 22229	--There can be no reconciliation, Stephen said, if there has not been a
 22230	sundering.
 22231	
 22232	Said that.
 22233	
 22234	--If you want to know what are the events which cast their shadow over
 22235	the hell of time of _King Lear, Othello, Hamlet, Troilus and Cressida,_
 22236	look to see when and how the shadow lifts. What softens the heart of a
 22237	man, shipwrecked in storms dire, Tried, like another Ulysses, Pericles,
 22238	prince of Tyre?
 22239	
 22240	Head, redconecapped, buffeted, brineblinded.
 22241	
 22242	--A child, a girl, placed in his arms, Marina.
 22243	
 22244	--The leaning of sophists towards the bypaths of apocrypha is a constant
 22245	quantity, John Eglinton detected. The highroads are dreary but they lead
 22246	to the town.
 22247	
 22248	Good Bacon: gone musty. Shakespeare Bacon's wild oats. Cypherjugglers
 22249	going the highroads. Seekers on the great quest. What town, good
 22250	masters? Mummed in names: A. E., eon: Magee, John Eglinton. East of the
 22251	sun, west of the moon: _Tir na n-og_. Booted the twain and staved.
 22252	
 22253	_How many miles to Dublin? Three score and ten, sir. Will we be there by
 22254	candlelight?_
 22255	
 22256	--Mr Brandes accepts it, Stephen said, as the first play of the closing
 22257	period.
 22258	
 22259	--Does he? What does Mr Sidney Lee, or Mr Simon Lazarus as some aver his
 22260	name is, say of it?
 22261	
 22262	--Marina, Stephen said, a child of storm, Miranda, a wonder, Perdita,
 22263	that which was lost. What was lost is given back to him: his daughter's
 22264	child. _My dearest wife_, Pericles says, _was like this maid._ Will any
 22265	man love the daughter if he has not loved the mother?
 22266	
 22267	--The art of being a grandfather, Mr Best gan murmur. _l'art d'Ãªtre
 22268	grand_...
 22269	
 22270	--Will he not see reborn in her, with the memory of his own youth added,
 22271	another image?
 22272	
 22273	Do you know what you are talking about? Love, yes. Word known to all
 22274	men. Amor vero aliquid alicui bonum vult unde et ea quae concupiscimus
 22275	...
 22276	
 22277	--His own image to a man with that queer thing genius is the standard of
 22278	all experience, material and moral. Such an appeal will touch him. The
 22279	images of other males of his blood will repel him. He will see in them
 22280	grotesque attempts of nature to foretell or to repeat himself.
 22281	
 22282	The benign forehead of the quaker librarian enkindled rosily with hope.
 22283	
 22284	--I hope Mr Dedalus will work out his theory for the enlightenment of
 22285	the public. And we ought to mention another Irish commentator, Mr George
 22286	Bernard Shaw. Nor should we forget Mr Frank Harris. His articles on
 22287	Shakespeare in the _Saturday Review_ were surely brilliant. Oddly
 22288	enough he too draws for us an unhappy relation with the dark lady of the
 22289	sonnets. The favoured rival is William Herbert, earl of Pembroke. I own
 22290	that if the poet must be rejected such a rejection would seem more in
 22291	harmony with--what shall I say?--our notions of what ought not to have
 22292	been.
 22293	
 22294	Felicitously he ceased and held a meek head among them, auk's egg, prize
 22295	of their fray.
 22296	
 22297	He thous and thees her with grave husbandwords. Dost love, Miriam? Dost
 22298	love thy man?
 22299	
 22300	--That may be too, Stephen said. There's a saying of Goethe's which Mr
 22301	Magee likes to quote. Beware of what you wish for in youth because
 22302	you will get it in middle life. Why does he send to one who is
 22303	a _buonaroba,_ a bay where all men ride, a maid of honour with a
 22304	scandalous girlhood, a lordling to woo for him? He was himself a lord
 22305	of language and had made himself a coistrel gentleman and he had written
 22306	_Romeo and Juliet_. Why? Belief in himself has been untimely killed. He
 22307	was overborne in a cornfield first (ryefield, I should say) and he will
 22308	never be a victor in his own eyes after nor play victoriously the game
 22309	of laugh and lie down. Assumed dongiovannism will not save him. No later
 22310	undoing will undo the first undoing. The tusk of the boar has wounded
 22311	him there where love lies ableeding. If the shrew is worsted yet there
 22312	remains to her woman's invisible weapon. There is, I feel in the words,
 22313	some goad of the flesh driving him into a new passion, a darker shadow
 22314	of the first, darkening even his own understanding of himself. A like
 22315	fate awaits him and the two rages commingle in a whirlpool.
 22316	
 22317	They list. And in the porches of their ears I pour.
 22318	
 22319	--The soul has been before stricken mortally, a poison poured in the
 22320	porch of a sleeping ear. But those who are done to death in sleep cannot
 22321	know the manner of their quell unless their Creator endow their souls
 22322	with that knowledge in the life to come. The poisoning and the beast
 22323	with two backs that urged it King Hamlet's ghost could not know of were
 22324	he not endowed with knowledge by his creator. That is why the speech
 22325	(his lean unlovely English) is always turned elsewhere, backward.
 22326	Ravisher and ravished, what he would but would not, go with him from
 22327	Lucrece's bluecircled ivory globes to Imogen's breast, bare, with its
 22328	mole cinquespotted. He goes back, weary of the creation he has piled up
 22329	to hide him from himself, an old dog licking an old sore. But, because
 22330	loss is his gain, he passes on towards eternity in undiminished
 22331	personality, untaught by the wisdom he has written or by the laws he
 22332	has revealed. His beaver is up. He is a ghost, a shadow now, the wind by
 22333	Elsinore's rocks or what you will, the sea's voice, a voice heard
 22334	only in the heart of him who is the substance of his shadow, the son
 22335	consubstantial with the father.
 22336	
 22337	--Amen! was responded from the doorway.
 22338	
 22339	Hast thou found me, O mine enemy?
 22340	
 22341	_Entr'acte_.
 22342	
 22343	A ribald face, sullen as a dean's, Buck Mulligan came forward, then
 22344	blithe in motley, towards the greeting of their smiles. My telegram.
 22345	
 22346	--You were speaking of the gaseous vertebrate, if I mistake not? he
 22347	asked of Stephen.
 22348	
 22349	Primrosevested he greeted gaily with his doffed Panama as with a bauble.
 22350	
 22351	They make him welcome. _Was Du verlachst wirst Du noch dienen._
 22352	
 22353	Brood of mockers: Photius, pseudomalachi, Johann Most.
 22354	
 22355	He Who Himself begot middler the Holy Ghost and Himself sent Himself,
 22356	Agenbuyer, between Himself and others, Who, put upon by His fiends,
 22357	stripped and whipped, was nailed like bat to barndoor, starved on
 22358	crosstree, Who let Him bury, stood up, harrowed hell, fared into heaven
 22359	and there these nineteen hundred years sitteth on the right hand of His
 22360	Own Self but yet shall come in the latter day to doom the quick and dead
 22361	when all the quick shall be dead already.
 22362	
 22363	Glo--o--ri--a in ex--cel--sis De--o.
 22364	
 22365	He lifts his hands. Veils fall. O, flowers! Bells with bells with bells
 22366	aquiring.
 22367	
 22368	--Yes, indeed, the quaker librarian said. A most instructive discussion.
 22369	Mr Mulligan, I'll be bound, has his theory too of the play and of
 22370	Shakespeare. All sides of life should be represented.
 22371	
 22372	He smiled on all sides equally.
 22373	
 22374	Buck Mulligan thought, puzzled:
 22375	
 22376	--Shakespeare? he said. I seem to know the name.
 22377	
 22378	A flying sunny smile rayed in his loose features.
 22379	
 22380	--To be sure, he said, remembering brightly. The chap that writes like
 22381	Synge.
 22382	
 22383	Mr Best turned to him.
 22384	
 22385	--Haines missed you, he said. Did you meet him? He'll see you after at
 22386	the D. B. C. He's gone to Gill's to buy Hyde's _Lovesongs of Connacht_.
 22387	
 22388	--I came through the museum, Buck Mulligan said. Was he here?
 22389	
 22390	--The bard's fellowcountrymen, John Eglinton answered, are rather tired
 22391	perhaps of our brilliancies of theorising. I hear that an actress played
 22392	Hamlet for the fourhundredandeighth time last night in Dublin. Vining
 22393	held that the prince was a woman. Has no-one made him out to be an
 22394	Irishman? Judge Barton, I believe, is searching for some clues. He
 22395	swears (His Highness not His Lordship) by saint Patrick.
 22396	
 22397	--The most brilliant of all is that story of Wilde's, Mr Best said,
 22398	lifting his brilliant notebook. That _Portrait of Mr W. H._ where he
 22399	proves that the sonnets were written by a Willie Hughes, a man all hues.
 22400	
 22401	--For Willie Hughes, is it not? the quaker librarian asked.
 22402	
 22403	Or Hughie Wills? Mr William Himself. W. H.: who am I?
 22404	
 22405	--I mean, for Willie Hughes, Mr Best said, amending his gloss easily. Of
 22406	course it's all paradox, don't you know, Hughes and hews and hues,
 22407	the colour, but it's so typical the way he works it out. It's the very
 22408	essence of Wilde, don't you know. The light touch.
 22409	
 22410	His glance touched their faces lightly as he smiled, a blond ephebe.
 22411	Tame essence of Wilde.
 22412	
 22413	You're darned witty. Three drams of usquebaugh you drank with Dan
 22414	Deasy's ducats.
 22415	
 22416	How much did I spend? O, a few shillings.
 22417	
 22418	For a plump of pressmen. Humour wet and dry.
 22419	
 22420	Wit. You would give your five wits for youth's proud livery he pranks
 22421	in. Lineaments of gratified desire.
 22422	
 22423	There be many mo. Take her for me. In pairing time. Jove, a cool ruttime
 22424	send them. Yea, turtledove her.
 22425	
 22426	Eve. Naked wheatbellied sin. A snake coils her, fang in's kiss.
 22427	
 22428	--Do you think it is only a paradox? the quaker librarian was asking.
 22429	The mocker is never taken seriously when he is most serious.
 22430	
 22431	They talked seriously of mocker's seriousness.
 22432	
 22433	Buck Mulligan's again heavy face eyed Stephen awhile. Then, his head
 22434	wagging, he came near, drew a folded telegram from his pocket. His
 22435	mobile lips read, smiling with new delight.
 22436	
 22437	--Telegram! he said. Wonderful inspiration! Telegram! A papal bull!
 22438	
 22439	He sat on a corner of the unlit desk, reading aloud joyfully:
 22440	
 22441	--_The sentimentalist is he who would enjoy without incurring the
 22442	immense debtorship for a thing done._ Signed: Dedalus. Where did you
 22443	launch it from? The kips? No. College Green. Have you drunk the four
 22444	quid? The aunt is going to call on your unsubstantial father. Telegram!
 22445	Malachi Mulligan, The Ship, lower Abbey street. O, you peerless mummer!
 22446	O, you priestified Kinchite!
 22447	
 22448	Joyfully he thrust message and envelope into a pocket but keened in a
 22449	querulous brogue:
 22450	
 22451	--It's what I'm telling you, mister honey, it's queer and sick we were,
 22452	Haines and myself, the time himself brought it in. 'Twas murmur we did
 22453	for a gallus potion would rouse a friar, I'm thinking, and he limp with
 22454	leching. And we one hour and two hours and three hours in Connery's
 22455	sitting civil waiting for pints apiece.
 22456	
 22457	He wailed:
 22458	
 22459	--And we to be there, mavrone, and you to be unbeknownst sending us your
 22460	conglomerations the way we to have our tongues out a yard long like the
 22461	drouthy clerics do be fainting for a pussful.
 22462	
 22463	Stephen laughed.
 22464	
 22465	Quickly, warningfully Buck Mulligan bent down.
 22466	
 22467	--The tramper Synge is looking for you, he said, to murder you. He
 22468	heard you pissed on his halldoor in Glasthule. He's out in pampooties to
 22469	murder you.
 22470	
 22471	--Me! Stephen exclaimed. That was your contribution to literature.
 22472	
 22473	Buck Mulligan gleefully bent back, laughing to the dark eavesdropping
 22474	ceiling.
 22475	
 22476	--Murder you! he laughed.
 22477	
 22478	Harsh gargoyle face that warred against me over our mess of hash
 22479	of lights in rue Saint-AndrÃ©-des-Arts. In words of words for words,
 22480	palabras. Oisin with Patrick. Faunman he met in Clamart woods,
 22481	brandishing a winebottle. _C'est vendredi saint!_ Murthering Irish. His
 22482	image, wandering, he met. I mine. I met a fool i'the forest.
 22483	
 22484	--Mr Lyster, an attendant said from the door ajar.
 22485	
 22486	--... in which everyone can find his own. So Mr Justice Madden in his
 22487	_Diary of Master William Silence_ has found the hunting terms... Yes?
 22488	What is it?
 22489	
 22490	--There's a gentleman here, sir, the attendant said, coming forward and
 22491	offering a card. From the _Freeman._ He wants to see the files of the
 22492	_Kilkenny People_ for last year.
 22493	
 22494	--Certainly, certainly, certainly. Is the gentleman?...
 22495	
 22496	He took the eager card, glanced, not saw, laid down unglanced, looked,
 22497	asked, creaked, asked:
 22498	
 22499	--Is he?... O, there!
 22500	
 22501	Brisk in a galliard he was off, out. In the daylit corridor he talked
 22502	with voluble pains of zeal, in duty bound, most fair, most kind, most
 22503	honest broadbrim.
 22504	
 22505	--This gentleman? _Freeman's Journal? Kilkenny People?_ To be sure. Good
 22506	day, sir. _Kilkenny_... We have certainly...
 22507	
 22508	A patient silhouette waited, listening.
 22509	
 22510	--All the leading provincial... _Northern Whig, Cork Examiner,
 22511	Enniscorthy Guardian,_ 1903... Will you please?... Evans, conduct this
 22512	gentleman... If you just follow the atten... Or, please allow me...
 22513	This way... Please, sir...
 22514	
 22515	Voluble, dutiful, he led the way to all the provincial papers, a bowing
 22516	dark figure following his hasty heels.
 22517	
 22518	The door closed.
 22519	
 22520	--The sheeny! Buck Mulligan cried.
 22521	
 22522	He jumped up and snatched the card.
 22523	
 22524	--What's his name? Ikey Moses? Bloom.
 22525	
 22526	He rattled on:
 22527	
 22528	--Jehovah, collector of prepuces, is no more. I found him over in the
 22529	museum where I went to hail the foamborn Aphrodite. The Greek mouth that
 22530	has never been twisted in prayer. Every day we must do homage to her.
 22531	_Life of life, thy lips enkindle._
 22532	
 22533	Suddenly he turned to Stephen:
 22534	
 22535	--He knows you. He knows your old fellow. O, I fear me, he is Greeker
 22536	than the Greeks. His pale Galilean eyes were upon her mesial groove.
 22537	Venus Kallipyge. O, the thunder of those loins! _The god pursuing the
 22538	maiden hid_.
 22539	
 22540	--We want to hear more, John Eglinton decided with Mr Best's approval.
 22541	We begin to be interested in Mrs S. Till now we had thought of her, if
 22542	at all, as a patient Griselda, a Penelope stayathome.
 22543	
 22544	--Antisthenes, pupil of Gorgias, Stephen said, took the palm of beauty
 22545	from Kyrios Menelaus' brooddam, Argive Helen, the wooden mare of Troy
 22546	in whom a score of heroes slept, and handed it to poor Penelope. Twenty
 22547	years he lived in London and, during part of that time, he drew a salary
 22548	equal to that of the lord chancellor of Ireland. His life was rich. His
 22549	art, more than the art of feudalism as Walt Whitman called it, is the
 22550	art of surfeit. Hot herringpies, green mugs of sack, honeysauces, sugar
 22551	of roses, marchpane, gooseberried pigeons, ringocandies. Sir Walter
 22552	Raleigh, when they arrested him, had half a million francs on his
 22553	back including a pair of fancy stays. The gombeenwoman Eliza Tudor had
 22554	underlinen enough to vie with her of Sheba. Twenty years he dallied
 22555	there between conjugial love and its chaste delights and scortatory love
 22556	and its foul pleasures. You know Manningham's story of the burgher's
 22557	wife who bade Dick Burbage to her bed after she had seen him in _Richard
 22558	III_ and how Shakespeare, overhearing, without more ado about nothing,
 22559	took the cow by the horns and, when Burbage came knocking at the gate,
 22560	answered from the capon's blankets: _William the conqueror came before
 22561	Richard III_. And the gay lakin, mistress Fitton, mount and cry O,
 22562	and his dainty birdsnies, lady Penelope Rich, a clean quality woman is
 22563	suited for a player, and the punks of the bankside, a penny a time.
 22564	
 22565	Cours la Reine. _Encore vingt sous. Nous ferons de petites cochonneries.
 22566	Minette? Tu veux?_
 22567	
 22568	--The height of fine society. And sir William Davenant of oxford's
 22569	mother with her cup of canary for any cockcanary.
 22570	
 22571	Buck Mulligan, his pious eyes upturned, prayed:
 22572	
 22573	--Blessed Margaret Mary Anycock!
 22574	
 22575	--And Harry of six wives' daughter. And other lady friends from
 22576	neighbour seats as Lawn Tennyson, gentleman poet, sings. But all those
 22577	twenty years what do you suppose poor Penelope in Stratford was doing
 22578	behind the diamond panes?
 22579	
 22580	Do and do. Thing done. In a rosery of Fetter lane of Gerard, herbalist,
 22581	he walks, greyedauburn. An azured harebell like her veins. Lids of
 22582	Juno's eyes, violets. He walks. One life is all. One body. Do. But do.
 22583	Afar, in a reek of lust and squalor, hands are laid on whiteness.
 22584	
 22585	Buck Mulligan rapped John Eglinton's desk sharply.
 22586	
 22587	--Whom do you suspect? he challenged.
 22588	
 22589	--Say that he is the spurned lover in the sonnets. Once spurned twice
 22590	spurned. But the court wanton spurned him for a lord, his dearmylove.
 22591	
 22592	Love that dare not speak its name.
 22593	
 22594	--As an Englishman, you mean, John sturdy Eglinton put in, he loved a
 22595	lord.
 22596	
 22597	Old wall where sudden lizards flash. At Charenton I watched them.
 22598	
 22599	--It seems so, Stephen said, when he wants to do for him, and for all
 22600	other and singular uneared wombs, the holy office an ostler does for the
 22601	stallion. Maybe, like Socrates, he had a midwife to mother as he had a
 22602	shrew to wife. But she, the giglot wanton, did not break a bedvow. Two
 22603	deeds are rank in that ghost's mind: a broken vow and the dullbrained
 22604	yokel on whom her favour has declined, deceased husband's brother. Sweet
 22605	Ann, I take it, was hot in the blood. Once a wooer, twice a wooer.
 22606	
 22607	Stephen turned boldly in his chair.
 22608	
 22609	--The burden of proof is with you not with me, he said frowning. If you
 22610	deny that in the fifth scene of _Hamlet_ he has branded her with infamy
 22611	tell me why there is no mention of her during the thirtyfour years
 22612	between the day she married him and the day she buried him. All those
 22613	women saw their men down and under: Mary, her goodman John, Ann, her
 22614	poor dear Willun, when he went and died on her, raging that he was the
 22615	first to go, Joan, her four brothers, Judith, her husband and all her
 22616	sons, Susan, her husband too, while Susan's daughter, Elizabeth, to use
 22617	granddaddy's words, wed her second, having killed her first.
 22618	
 22619	O, yes, mention there is. In the years when he was living richly in
 22620	royal London to pay a debt she had to borrow forty shillings from her
 22621	father's shepherd. Explain you then. Explain the swansong too wherein he
 22622	has commended her to posterity.
 22623	
 22624	He faced their silence.
 22625	
 22626	     To whom thus Eglinton:
 22627	     You mean the will.
 22628	     But that has been explained, I believe, by jurists.
 22629	     She was entitled to her widow's dower
 22630	     At common law. His legal knowledge was great
 22631	     Our judges tell us.
 22632	     Him Satan fleers,
 22633	     Mocker:
 22634	     And therefore he left out her name
 22635	     From the first draft but he did not leave out
 22636	     The presents for his granddaughter, for his daughters,
 22637	     For his sister, for his old cronies in Stratford
 22638	     And in London. And therefore when he was urged,
 22639	     As I believe, to name her
 22640	     He left her his
 22641	     Secondbest
 22642	     Bed.
 22643	     _Punkt._
 22644	     Leftherhis
 22645	     Secondbest
 22646	     Leftherhis
 22647	     Bestabed
 22648	     Secabest
 22649	     Leftabed.
 22650	
 22651	
 22652	Woa!
 22653	
 22654	--Pretty countryfolk had few chattels then, John Eglinton observed, as
 22655	they have still if our peasant plays are true to type.
 22656	
 22657	--He was a rich country gentleman, Stephen said, with a coat of arms
 22658	and landed estate at Stratford and a house in Ireland yard, a capitalist
 22659	shareholder, a bill promoter, a tithefarmer. Why did he not leave her
 22660	his best bed if he wished her to snore away the rest of her nights in
 22661	peace?
 22662	
 22663	--It is clear that there were two beds, a best and a secondbest, Mr
 22664	Secondbest Best said finely.
 22665	
 22666	--_Separatio a mensa et a thalamo_, bettered Buck Mulligan and was
 22667	smiled on.
 22668	
 22669	--Antiquity mentions famous beds, Second Eglinton puckered, bedsmiling.
 22670	Let me think.
 22671	
 22672	--Antiquity mentions that Stagyrite schoolurchin and bald heathen sage,
 22673	Stephen said, who when dying in exile frees and endows his slaves, pays
 22674	tribute to his elders, wills to be laid in earth near the bones of his
 22675	dead wife and bids his friends be kind to an old mistress (don't forget
 22676	Nell Gwynn Herpyllis) and let her live in his villa.
 22677	
 22678	--Do you mean he died so? Mr Best asked with slight concern. I mean...
 22679	
 22680	--He died dead drunk, Buck Mulligan capped. A quart of ale is a dish for
 22681	a king. O, I must tell you what Dowden said!
 22682	
 22683	--What? asked Besteglinton.
 22684	
 22685	William Shakespeare and company, limited. The people's William. For
 22686	terms apply: E. Dowden, Highfield house...
 22687	
 22688	--Lovely! Buck Mulligan suspired amorously. I asked him what he thought
 22689	of the charge of pederasty brought against the bard. He lifted his hands
 22690	and said: _All we can say is that life ran very high in those days._
 22691	Lovely!
 22692	
 22693	Catamite.
 22694	
 22695	--The sense of beauty leads us astray, said beautifulinsadness Best to
 22696	ugling Eglinton.
 22697	
 22698	Steadfast John replied severe:
 22699	
 22700	--The doctor can tell us what those words mean. You cannot eat your cake
 22701	and have it.
 22702	
 22703	Sayest thou so? Will they wrest from us, from me, the palm of beauty?
 22704	
 22705	--And the sense of property, Stephen said. He drew Shylock out of his
 22706	own long pocket. The son of a maltjobber and moneylender he was himself
 22707	a cornjobber and moneylender, with ten tods of corn hoarded in the
 22708	famine riots. His borrowers are no doubt those divers of worship
 22709	mentioned by Chettle Falstaff who reported his uprightness of dealing.
 22710	He sued a fellowplayer for the price of a few bags of malt and exacted
 22711	his pound of flesh in interest for every money lent. How else could
 22712	Aubrey's ostler and callboy get rich quick? All events brought grist to
 22713	his mill. Shylock chimes with the jewbaiting that followed the hanging
 22714	and quartering of the queen's leech Lopez, his jew's heart being plucked
 22715	forth while the sheeny was yet alive: _Hamlet_ and _Macbeth_ with
 22716	the coming to the throne of a Scotch philosophaster with a turn for
 22717	witchroasting. The lost armada is his jeer in _Love's Labour Lost_.
 22718	His pageants, the histories, sail fullbellied on a tide of Mafeking
 22719	enthusiasm. Warwickshire jesuits are tried and we have a porter's theory
 22720	of equivocation. The _Sea Venture_ comes home from Bermudas and the play
 22721	Renan admired is written with Patsy Caliban, our American cousin.
 22722	The sugared sonnets follow Sidney's. As for fay Elizabeth, otherwise
 22723	carrotty Bess, the gross virgin who inspired _The Merry Wives of
 22724	Windsor_, let some meinherr from Almany grope his life long for deephid
 22725	meanings in the depths of the buckbasket.
 22726	
 22727	I think you're getting on very nicely. Just mix up a mixture of
 22728	theolologicophilolological. _Mingo, minxi, mictum, mingere._
 22729	
 22730	--Prove that he was a jew, John Eglinton dared,'expectantly. Your dean
 22731	of studies holds he was a holy Roman.
 22732	
 22733	_Sufflaminandus sum._
 22734	
 22735	--He was made in Germany, Stephen replied, as the champion French
 22736	polisher of Italian scandals.
 22737	
 22738	--A myriadminded man, Mr Best reminded. Coleridge called him
 22739	myriadminded.
 22740	
 22741	_Amplius. In societate humana hoc est maxime necessarium ut sit amicitia
 22742	inter multos._
 22743
