 22744	--Saint Thomas, Stephen began...
 22745	
 22746	--_Ora pro nobis_, Monk Mulligan groaned, sinking to a chair.
 22747	
 22748	There he keened a wailing rune.
 22749	
 22750	--_Pogue mahone! Acushla machree!_ It's destroyed we are from this day!
 22751	It's destroyed we are surely!
 22752	
 22753	All smiled their smiles.
 22754	
 22755	--Saint Thomas, Stephen smiling said, whose gorbellied works I enjoy
 22756	reading in the original, writing of incest from a standpoint different
 22757	from that of the new Viennese school Mr Magee spoke of, likens it in his
 22758	wise and curious way to an avarice of the emotions. He means that the
 22759	love so given to one near in blood is covetously withheld from some
 22760	stranger who, it may be, hungers for it. Jews, whom christians tax with
 22761	avarice, are of all races the most given to intermarriage. Accusations
 22762	are made in anger. The christian laws which built up the hoards of the
 22763	jews (for whom, as for the lollards, storm was shelter) bound their
 22764	affections too with hoops of steel. Whether these be sins or virtues old
 22765	Nobodaddy will tell us at doomsday leet. But a man who holds so tightly
 22766	to what he calls his rights over what he calls his debts will hold
 22767	tightly also to what he calls his rights over her whom he calls his
 22768	wife. No sir smile neighbour shall covet his ox or his wife or his
 22769	manservant or his maidservant or his jackass.
 22770	
 22771	--Or his jennyass, Buck Mulligan antiphoned.
 22772	
 22773	--Gentle Will is being roughly handled, gentle Mr Best said gently.
 22774	
 22775	--Which will? gagged sweetly Buck Mulligan. We are getting mixed.
 22776	
 22777	--The will to live, John Eglinton philosophised, for poor Ann, Will's
 22778	widow, is the will to die.
 22779	
 22780	_--Requiescat!_ Stephen prayed.
 22781	
 22782	     _What of all the will to do?
 22783	     It has vanished long ago..._
 22784	
 22785	--She lies laid out in stark stiffness in that secondbest bed, the
 22786	mobled queen, even though you prove that a bed in those days was as
 22787	rare as a motorcar is now and that its carvings were the wonder of seven
 22788	parishes. In old age she takes up with gospellers (one stayed with her
 22789	at New Place and drank a quart of sack the town council paid for but in
 22790	which bed he slept it skills not to ask) and heard she had a soul. She
 22791	read or had read to her his chapbooks preferring them to the _Merry
 22792	Wives_ and, loosing her nightly waters on the jordan, she thought
 22793	over _Hooks and Eyes for Believers' Breeches_ and _The most Spiritual
 22794	Snuffbox to Make the Most Devout Souls Sneeze_. Venus has twisted her
 22795	lips in prayer. Agenbite of inwit: remorse of conscience. It is an age
 22796	of exhausted whoredom groping for its god.
 22797	
 22798	--History shows that to be true, _inquit Eglintonus Chronolologos_. The
 22799	ages succeed one another. But we have it on high authority that a man's
 22800	worst enemies shall be those of his own house and family. I feel that
 22801	Russell is right. What do we care for his wife or father? I should say
 22802	that only family poets have family lives. Falstaff was not a family man.
 22803	I feel that the fat knight is his supreme creation.
 22804	
 22805	Lean, he lay back. Shy, deny thy kindred, the unco guid. Shy, supping
 22806	with the godless, he sneaks the cup. A sire in Ultonian Antrim bade it
 22807	him. Visits him here on quarter days. Mr Magee, sir, there's a gentleman
 22808	to see you. Me? Says he's your father, sir. Give me my Wordsworth. Enter
 22809	Magee Mor Matthew, a rugged rough rugheaded kern, in strossers with
 22810	a buttoned codpiece, his nether stocks bemired with clauber of ten
 22811	forests, a wand of wilding in his hand.
 22812	
 22813	Your own? He knows your old fellow. The widower.
 22814	
 22815	Hurrying to her squalid deathlair from gay Paris on the quayside I
 22816	touched his hand. The voice, new warmth, speaking. Dr Bob Kenny is
 22817	attending her. The eyes that wish me well. But do not know me.
 22818	
 22819	--A father, Stephen said, battling against hopelessness, is a necessary
 22820	evil. He wrote the play in the months that followed his father's death.
 22821	If you hold that he, a greying man with two marriageable daughters, with
 22822	thirtyfive years of life, _nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita_, with
 22823	fifty of experience, is the beardless undergraduate from Wittenberg then
 22824	you must hold that his seventyyear old mother is the lustful queen. No.
 22825	The corpse of John Shakespeare does not walk the night. From hour to
 22826	hour it rots and rots. He rests, disarmed of fatherhood, having devised
 22827	that mystical estate upon his son. Boccaccio's Calandrino was the first
 22828	and last man who felt himself with child. Fatherhood, in the sense of
 22829	conscious begetting, is unknown to man. It is a mystical estate, an
 22830	apostolic succession, from only begetter to only begotten. On that
 22831	mystery and not on the madonna which the cunning Italian intellect
 22832	flung to the mob of Europe the church is founded and founded irremovably
 22833	because founded, like the world, macro and microcosm, upon the void.
 22834	Upon incertitude, upon unlikelihood. _Amor matris_, subjective and
 22835	objective genitive, may be the only true thing in life. Paternity may be
 22836	a legal fiction. Who is the father of any son that any son should love
 22837	him or he any son?
 22838	
 22839	What the hell are you driving at?
 22840	
 22841	I know. Shut up. Blast you. I have reasons.
 22842	
 22843	_Amplius. Adhuc. Iterum. Postea._
 22844	
 22845	Are you condemned to do this?
 22846	
 22847	--They are sundered by a bodily shame so steadfast that the criminal
 22848	annals of the world, stained with all other incests and bestialities,
 22849	hardly record its breach. Sons with mothers, sires with daughters,
 22850	lesbic sisters, loves that dare not speak their name, nephews with
 22851	grandmothers, jailbirds with keyholes, queens with prize bulls. The son
 22852	unborn mars beauty: born, he brings pain, divides affection, increases
 22853	care. He is a new male: his growth is his father's decline, his youth
 22854	his father's envy, his friend his father's enemy.
 22855	
 22856	In rue Monsieur-le-Prince I thought it.
 22857	
 22858	--What links them in nature? An instant of blind rut.
 22859	
 22860	Am I a father? If I were?
 22861	
 22862	Shrunken uncertain hand.
 22863	
 22864	--Sabellius, the African, subtlest heresiarch of all the beasts of the
 22865	field, held that the Father was Himself His Own Son. The bulldog of
 22866	Aquin, with whom no word shall be impossible, refutes him. Well: if
 22867	the father who has not a son be not a father can the son who has not a
 22868	father be a son? When Rutlandbaconsouthamptonshakespeare or another poet
 22869	of the same name in the comedy of errors wrote _Hamlet_ he was not the
 22870	father of his own son merely but, being no more a son, he was and felt
 22871	himself the father of all his race, the father of his own grandfather,
 22872	the father of his unborn grandson who, by the same token, never was
 22873	born, for nature, as Mr Magee understands her, abhors perfection.
 22874	
 22875	Eglintoneyes, quick with pleasure, looked up shybrightly. Gladly
 22876	glancing, a merry puritan, through the twisted eglantine.
 22877	
 22878	Flatter. Rarely. But flatter.
 22879	
 22880	--Himself his own father, Sonmulligan told himself. Wait. I am big with
 22881	child. I have an unborn child in my brain. Pallas Athena! A play! The
 22882	play's the thing! Let me parturiate!
 22883	
 22884	He clasped his paunchbrow with both birthaiding hands.
 22885	
 22886	--As for his family, Stephen said, his mother's name lives in the
 22887	forest of Arden. Her death brought from him the scene with Volumnia in
 22888	_Coriolanus._ His boyson's death is the deathscene of young Arthur in
 22889	_King John._ Hamlet, the black prince, is Hamnet Shakespeare. Who the
 22890	girls in _The Tempest_, in _Pericles,_ in _Winter's Tale_ are we know.
 22891	Who Cleopatra, fleshpot of Egypt, and Cressid and Venus are we may
 22892	guess. But there is another member of his family who is recorded.
 22893	
 22894	--The plot thickens, John Eglinton said.
 22895	
 22896	The quaker librarian, quaking, tiptoed in, quake, his mask, quake, with
 22897	haste, quake, quack.
 22898	
 22899	Door closed. Cell. Day.
 22900	
 22901	They list. Three. They.
 22902	
 22903	I you he they.
 22904	
 22905	Come, mess.
 22906	
 22907	STEPHEN: He had three brothers, Gilbert, Edmund, Richard. Gilbert in his
 22908	old age told some cavaliers he got a pass for nowt from Maister Gatherer
 22909	one time mass he did and he seen his brud Maister Wull the playwriter up
 22910	in Lunnon in a wrastling play wud a man on's back. The playhouse sausage
 22911	filled Gilbert's soul. He is nowhere: but an Edmund and a Richard are
 22912	recorded in the works of sweet William.
 22913	
 22914	MAGEEGLINJOHN: Names! What's in a name?
 22915	
 22916	BEST: That is my name, Richard, don't you know. I hope you are going to
 22917	say a good word for Richard, don't you know, for my sake. _(Laughter)_
 22918	
 22919	
 22920	BUCKMULLIGAN: (_Piano, diminuendo_)
 22921	
 22922	     _Then outspoke medical Dick
 22923	     To his comrade medical Davy..._
 22924	
 22925	STEPHEN: In his trinity of black Wills, the villain shakebags, Iago,
 22926	Richard Crookback, Edmund in _King Lear_, two bear the wicked uncles'
 22927	names. Nay, that last play was written or being written while his
 22928	brother Edmund lay dying in Southwark.
 22929	
 22930	BEST: I hope Edmund is going to catch it. I don't want Richard, my name
 22931	...
 22932	
 22933	_(Laughter)_
 22934	
 22935	QUAKERLYSTER: (_A tempo_) But he that filches from me my good name...
 22936	
 22937	STEPHEN: _(Stringendo)_ He has hidden his own name, a fair name,
 22938	William, in the plays, a super here, a clown there, as a painter of old
 22939	Italy set his face in a dark corner of his canvas. He has revealed it in
 22940	the sonnets where there is Will in overplus. Like John o'Gaunt his name
 22941	is dear to him, as dear as the coat and crest he toadied for, on a bend
 22942	sable a spear or steeled argent, honorificabilitudinitatibus, dearer
 22943	than his glory of greatest shakescene in the country. What's in a name?
 22944	That is what we ask ourselves in childhood when we write the name that
 22945	we are told is ours. A star, a daystar, a firedrake, rose at his birth.
 22946	It shone by day in the heavens alone, brighter than Venus in the
 22947	night, and by night it shone over delta in Cassiopeia, the recumbent
 22948	constellation which is the signature of his initial among the stars. His
 22949	eyes watched it, lowlying on the horizon, eastward of the bear, as
 22950	he walked by the slumberous summer fields at midnight returning from
 22951	Shottery and from her arms.
 22952	
 22953	Both satisfied. I too.
 22954	
 22955	Don't tell them he was nine years old when it was quenched.
 22956	
 22957	And from her arms.
 22958	
 22959	Wait to be wooed and won. Ay, meacock. Who will woo you?
 22960	
 22961	Read the skies. _Autontimorumenos. Bous Stephanoumenos._ Where's your
 22962	configuration? Stephen, Stephen, cut the bread even. S. D: _sua donna.
 22963	GiÃ : di lui. gelindo risolve di non amare_ S. D.
 22964	
 22965	--What is that, Mr Dedalus? the quaker librarian asked. Was it a
 22966	celestial phenomenon?
 22967	
 22968	--A star by night, Stephen said. A pillar of the cloud by day.
 22969	
 22970	What more's to speak?
 22971	
 22972	Stephen looked on his hat, his stick, his boots.
 22973	
 22974	_Stephanos,_ my crown. My sword. His boots are spoiling the shape of my
 22975	feet. Buy a pair. Holes in my socks. Handkerchief too.
 22976	
 22977	--You make good use of the name, John Eglinton allowed. Your own name is
 22978	strange enough. I suppose it explains your fantastical humour.
 22979	
 22980	Me, Magee and Mulligan.
 22981	
 22982	Fabulous artificer. The hawklike man. You flew. Whereto?
 22983	Newhaven-Dieppe, steerage passenger. Paris and back. Lapwing. Icarus.
 22984	_Pater, ait._ Seabedabbled, fallen, weltering. Lapwing you are. Lapwing
 22985	be.
 22986	
 22987	Mr Best eagerquietly lifted his book to say:
 22988	
 22989	--That's very interesting because that brother motive, don't you know,
 22990	we find also in the old Irish myths. Just what you say. The three
 22991	brothers Shakespeare. In Grimm too, don't you know, the fairytales. The
 22992	third brother that always marries the sleeping beauty and wins the best
 22993	prize.
 22994	
 22995	Best of Best brothers. Good, better, best.
 22996	
 22997	The quaker librarian springhalted near.
 22998	
 22999	--I should like to know, he said, which brother you... I understand you
 23000	to suggest there was misconduct with one of the brothers... But perhaps
 23001	I am anticipating?
 23002	
 23003	He caught himself in the act: looked at all: refrained.
 23004	
 23005	An attendant from the doorway called:
 23006	
 23007	--Mr Lyster! Father Dineen wants...
 23008	
 23009	--O, Father Dineen! Directly.
 23010	
 23011	Swiftly rectly creaking rectly rectly he was rectly gone.
 23012	
 23013	John Eglinton touched the foil.
 23014	
 23015	--Come, he said. Let us hear what you have to say of Richard and Edmund.
 23016	You kept them for the last, didn't you?
 23017	
 23018	--In asking you to remember those two noble kinsmen nuncle Richie and
 23019	nuncle Edmund, Stephen answered, I feel I am asking too much perhaps. A
 23020	brother is as easily forgotten as an umbrella.
 23021	
 23022	Lapwing.
 23023	
 23024	Where is your brother? Apothecaries' hall. My whetstone. Him, then
 23025	Cranly, Mulligan: now these. Speech, speech. But act. Act speech. They
 23026	mock to try you. Act. Be acted on.
 23027	
 23028	Lapwing.
 23029	
 23030	I am tired of my voice, the voice of Esau. My kingdom for a drink.
 23031	
 23032	On.
 23033	
 23034	--You will say those names were already in the chronicles from which he
 23035	took the stuff of his plays. Why did he take them rather than others?
 23036	Richard, a whoreson crookback, misbegotten, makes love to a widowed Ann
 23037	(what's in a name?), woos and wins her, a whoreson merry widow. Richard
 23038	the conqueror, third brother, came after William the conquered. The
 23039	other four acts of that play hang limply from that first. Of all his
 23040	kings Richard is the only king unshielded by Shakespeare's reverence,
 23041	the angel of the world. Why is the underplot of _King Lear_ in which
 23042	Edmund figures lifted out of Sidney's _Arcadia_ and spatchcocked on to a
 23043	Celtic legend older than history?
 23044	
 23045	--That was Will's way, John Eglinton defended. We should not now combine
 23046	a Norse saga with an excerpt from a novel by George Meredith. _Que
 23047	voulez-vous?_ Moore would say. He puts Bohemia on the seacoast and makes
 23048	Ulysses quote Aristotle.
 23049	
 23050	--Why? Stephen answered himself. Because the theme of the false or
 23051	the usurping or the adulterous brother or all three in one is to
 23052	Shakespeare, what the poor are not, always with him. The note of
 23053	banishment, banishment from the heart, banishment from home, sounds
 23054	uninterruptedly from _The Two Gentlemen of Verona_ onward till Prospero
 23055	breaks his staff, buries it certain fathoms in the earth and drowns his
 23056	book. It doubles itself in the middle of his life, reflects itself in
 23057	another, repeats itself, protasis, epitasis, catastasis, catastrophe.
 23058	It repeats itself again when he is near the grave, when his married
 23059	daughter Susan, chip of the old block, is accused of adultery. But it
 23060	was the original sin that darkened his understanding, weakened his will
 23061	and left in him a strong inclination to evil. The words are those of
 23062	my lords bishops of Maynooth. An original sin and, like original sin,
 23063	committed by another in whose sin he too has sinned. It is between the
 23064	lines of his last written words, it is petrified on his tombstone under
 23065	which her four bones are not to be laid. Age has not withered it. Beauty
 23066	and peace have not done it away. It is in infinite variety everywhere in
 23067	the world he has created, in _Much Ado about Nothing_, twice in _As you
 23068	like It_, in _The Tempest_, in _Hamlet,_ in _Measure for Measure_--and
 23069	in all the other plays which I have not read.
 23070	
 23071	He laughed to free his mind from his mind's bondage.
 23072	
 23073	Judge Eglinton summed up.
 23074	
 23075	--The truth is midway, he affirmed. He is the ghost and the prince. He
 23076	is all in all.
 23077	
 23078	--He is, Stephen said. The boy of act one is the mature man of act five.
 23079	All in all. In _Cymbeline,_ in _Othello_ he is bawd and cuckold. He acts
 23080	and is acted on. Lover of an ideal or a perversion, like Jose he
 23081	kills the real Carmen. His unremitting intellect is the hornmad Iago
 23082	ceaselessly willing that the moor in him shall suffer.
 23083	
 23084	--Cuckoo! Cuckoo! Cuck Mulligan clucked lewdly. O word of fear!
 23085	
 23086	Dark dome received, reverbed.
 23087	
 23088	--And what a character is Iago! undaunted John Eglinton exclaimed. When
 23089	all is said Dumas _fils_ (or is it Dumas _pÃ¨re?)_ is right. After God
 23090	Shakespeare has created most.
 23091	
 23092	--Man delights him not nor woman neither, Stephen said. He returns after
 23093	a life of absence to that spot of earth where he was born, where he has
 23094	always been, man and boy, a silent witness and there, his journey of
 23095	life ended, he plants his mulberrytree in the earth. Then dies. The
 23096	motion is ended. Gravediggers bury Hamlet _(pÃ¨re?)_ and Hamlet _fils._
 23097	A king and a prince at last in death, with incidental music. And, what
 23098	though murdered and betrayed, bewept by all frail tender hearts for,
 23099	Dane or Dubliner, sorrow for the dead is the only husband from whom
 23100	they refuse to be divorced. If you like the epilogue look long on it:
 23101	prosperous Prospero, the good man rewarded, Lizzie, grandpa's lump of
 23102	love, and nuncle Richie, the bad man taken off by poetic justice to the
 23103	place where the bad niggers go. Strong curtain. He found in the world
 23104	without as actual what was in his world within as possible. Maeterlinck
 23105	says: _If Socrates leave his house today he will find the sage seated
 23106	on his doorstep. If Judas go forth tonight it is to Judas his steps
 23107	will tend._ Every life is many days, day after day. We walk through
 23108	ourselves, meeting robbers, ghosts, giants, old men, young men, wives,
 23109	widows, brothers-in-love, but always meeting ourselves. The playwright
 23110	who wrote the folio of this world and wrote it badly (He gave us light
 23111	first and the sun two days later), the lord of things as they are whom
 23112	the most Roman of catholics call _dio boia_, hangman god, is doubtless
 23113	all in all in all of us, ostler and butcher, and would be bawd and
 23114	cuckold too but that in the economy of heaven, foretold by Hamlet, there
 23115	are no more marriages, glorified man, an androgynous angel, being a wife
 23116	unto himself.
 23117	
 23118	_--Eureka!_ Buck Mulligan cried. _Eureka!_
 23119	
 23120	Suddenly happied he jumped up and reached in a stride John Eglinton's
 23121	desk.
 23122	
 23123	--May I? he said. The Lord has spoken to Malachi.
 23124	
 23125	He began to scribble on a slip of paper.
 23126	
 23127	Take some slips from the counter going out.
 23128	
 23129	--Those who are married, Mr Best, douce herald, said, all save one,
 23130	shall live. The rest shall keep as they are.
 23131	
 23132	He laughed, unmarried, at Eglinton Johannes, of arts a bachelor.
 23133	
 23134	Unwed, unfancied, ware of wiles, they fingerponder nightly each his
 23135	variorum edition of _The Taming of the Shrew._
 23136	
 23137	--You are a delusion, said roundly John Eglinton to Stephen. You have
 23138	brought us all this way to show us a French triangle. Do you believe
 23139	your own theory?
 23140	
 23141	--No, Stephen said promptly.
 23142	
 23143	--Are you going to write it? Mr Best asked. You ought to make it a
 23144	dialogue, don't you know, like the Platonic dialogues Wilde wrote.
 23145	
 23146	John Eclecticon doubly smiled.
 23147	
 23148	--Well, in that case, he said, I don't see why you should expect payment
 23149	for it since you don't believe it yourself. Dowden believes there is
 23150	some mystery in _Hamlet_ but will say no more. Herr Bleibtreu, the man
 23151	Piper met in Berlin, who is working up that Rutland theory, believes
 23152	that the secret is hidden in the Stratford monument. He is going to
 23153	visit the present duke, Piper says, and prove to him that his ancestor
 23154	wrote the plays. It will come as a surprise to his grace. But he
 23155	believes his theory.
 23156	
 23157	I believe, O Lord, help my unbelief. That is, help me to believe or help
 23158	me to unbelieve? Who helps to believe? _Egomen._ Who to unbelieve? Other
 23159	chap.
 23160	
 23161	--You are the only contributor to _Dana_ who asks for pieces of silver.
 23162	Then I don't know about the next number. Fred Ryan wants space for an
 23163	article on economics.
 23164	
 23165	Fraidrine. Two pieces of silver he lent me. Tide you over. Economics.
 23166	
 23167	--For a guinea, Stephen said, you can publish this interview.
 23168	
 23169	Buck Mulligan stood up from his laughing scribbling, laughing: and then
 23170	gravely said, honeying malice:
 23171	
 23172	--I called upon the bard Kinch at his summer residence in upper
 23173	Mecklenburgh street and found him deep in the study of the _Summa contra
 23174	Gentiles_ in the company of two gonorrheal ladies, Fresh Nelly and
 23175	Rosalie, the coalquay whore.
 23176	
 23177	He broke away.
 23178	
 23179	--Come, Kinch. Come, wandering Aengus of the birds.
 23180	
 23181	Come, Kinch. You have eaten all we left. Ay. I will serve you your orts
 23182	and offals.
 23183	
 23184	Stephen rose.
 23185	
 23186	Life is many days. This will end.
 23187	
 23188	--We shall see you tonight, John Eglinton said. _Notre ami_ Moore says
 23189	Malachi Mulligan must be there.
 23190	
 23191	Buck Mulligan flaunted his slip and panama.
 23192	
 23193	--Monsieur Moore, he said, lecturer on French letters to the youth of
 23194	Ireland. I'll be there. Come, Kinch, the bards must drink. Can you walk
 23195	straight?
 23196	
 23197	Laughing, he...
 23198	
 23199	Swill till eleven. Irish nights entertainment.
 23200	
 23201	Lubber...
 23202	
 23203	Stephen followed a lubber...
 23204	
 23205	One day in the national library we had a discussion. Shakes. After. His
 23206	lub back: I followed. I gall his kibe.
 23207	
 23208	Stephen, greeting, then all amort, followed a lubber jester, a wellkempt
 23209	head, newbarbered, out of the vaulted cell into a shattering daylight of
 23210	no thought.
 23211	
 23212	What have I learned? Of them? Of me?
 23213	
 23214	Walk like Haines now.
 23215	
 23216	The constant readers' room. In the readers' book Cashel Boyle O'Connor
 23217	Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell parafes his polysyllables. Item: was Hamlet
 23218	mad? The quaker's pate godlily with a priesteen in booktalk.
 23219	
 23220	--O please do, sir... I shall be most pleased...
 23221	
 23222	Amused Buck Mulligan mused in pleasant murmur with himself, selfnodding:
 23223	
 23224	--A pleased bottom.
 23225	
 23226	The turnstile.
 23227	
 23228	Is that?... Blueribboned hat... Idly writing... What? Looked?...
 23229	
 23230	The curving balustrade: smoothsliding Mincius.
 23231	
 23232	Puck Mulligan, panamahelmeted, went step by step, iambing, trolling:
 23233	
 23234	_John Eglinton, my jo, John, Why won't you wed a wife?_
 23235	
 23236	He spluttered to the air:
 23237	
 23238	--O, the chinless Chinaman! Chin Chon Eg Lin Ton. We went over to their
 23239	playbox, Haines and I, the plumbers' hall. Our players are creating a
 23240	new art for Europe like the Greeks or M. Maeterlinck. Abbey Theatre! I
 23241	smell the pubic sweat of monks.
 23242	
 23243	He spat blank.
 23244	
 23245	Forgot: any more than he forgot the whipping lousy Lucy gave him. And
 23246	left the _femme de trente ans._ And why no other children born? And his
 23247	first child a girl?
 23248	
 23249	Afterwit. Go back.
 23250	
 23251	The dour recluse still there (he has his cake) and the douce youngling,
 23252	minion of pleasure, Phedo's toyable fair hair.
 23253	
 23254	Eh... I just eh... wanted... I forgot... he...
 23255	
 23256	--Longworth and M'Curdy Atkinson were there...
 23257	
 23258	Puck Mulligan footed featly, trilling:
 23259	
 23260	     _I hardly hear the purlieu cry
 23261	     Or a tommy talk as I pass one by
 23262	     Before my thoughts begin to run
 23263	     On F. M'Curdy Atkinson,
 23264	     The same that had the wooden leg
 23265	     And that filibustering filibeg
 23266	     That never dared to slake his drouth,
 23267	     Magee that had the chinless mouth.
 23268	     Being afraid to marry on earth
 23269	     They masturbated for all they were worth._
 23270	
 23271	
 23272	Jest on. Know thyself.
 23273	
 23274	Halted, below me, a quizzer looks at me. I halt.
 23275	
 23276	--Mournful mummer, Buck Mulligan moaned. Synge has left off wearing
 23277	black to be like nature. Only crows, priests and English coal are black.
 23278	
 23279	A laugh tripped over his lips.
 23280	
 23281	--Longworth is awfully sick, he said, after what you wrote about that
 23282	old hake Gregory. O you inquisitional drunken jewjesuit! She gets you
 23283	a job on the paper and then you go and slate her drivel to Jaysus.
 23284	Couldn't you do the Yeats touch?
 23285	
 23286	He went on and down, mopping, chanting with waving graceful arms:
 23287	
 23288	--The most beautiful book that has come out of our country in my time.
 23289	One thinks of Homer.
 23290	
 23291	He stopped at the stairfoot.
 23292	
 23293	--I have conceived a play for the mummers, he said solemnly.
 23294	
 23295	The pillared Moorish hall, shadows entwined. Gone the nine men's morrice
 23296	with caps of indices.
 23297	
 23298	In sweetly varying voices Buck Mulligan read his tablet: _Everyman His
 23299	own Wife or A Honeymoon in the Hand (a national immorality in three
 23300	orgasms) by Ballocky Mulligan._
 23301	
 23302	
 23303	He turned a happy patch's smirk to Stephen, saying:
 23304	
 23305	--The disguise, I fear, is thin. But listen.
 23306	
 23307	He read, _marcato:_
 23308	
 23309	--Characters:
 23310	
 23311	     TODY TOSTOFF (a ruined Pole)
 23312	     CRAB (a bushranger)
 23313	     MEDICAL DICK )
 23314	     and          ) (two birds with one stone)
 23315	     MEDICAL DAVY )
 23316	     MOTHER GROGAN (a watercarrier)
 23317	     FRESH NELLY
 23318	     and
 23319	     ROSALIE (the coalquay whore).
 23320	
 23321	He laughed, lolling a to and fro head, walking on, followed by Stephen:
 23322	and mirthfully he told the shadows, souls of men:
 23323	
 23324	--O, the night in the Camden hall when the daughters of Erin had to
 23325	lift their skirts to step over you as you lay in your mulberrycoloured,
 23326	multicoloured, multitudinous vomit!
 23327	
 23328	--The most innocent son of Erin, Stephen said, for whom they ever lifted
 23329	them.
 23330	
 23331	About to pass through the doorway, feeling one behind, he stood aside.
 23332	
 23333	Part. The moment is now. Where then? If Socrates leave his house today,
 23334	if Judas go forth tonight. Why? That lies in space which I in time must
 23335	come to, ineluctably.
 23336	
 23337	My will: his will that fronts me. Seas between.
 23338	
 23339	A man passed out between them, bowing, greeting.
 23340	
 23341	--Good day again, Buck Mulligan said.
 23342	
 23343	The portico.
 23344	
 23345	Here I watched the birds for augury. Aengus of the birds. They go, they
 23346	come. Last night I flew. Easily flew. Men wondered. Street of harlots
 23347	after. A creamfruit melon he held to me. In. You will see.
 23348	
 23349	--The wandering jew, Buck Mulligan whispered with clown's awe. Did you
 23350	see his eye? He looked upon you to lust after you. I fear thee, ancient
 23351	mariner. O, Kinch, thou art in peril. Get thee a breechpad.
 23352	
 23353	Manner of Oxenford.
 23354	
 23355	Day. Wheelbarrow sun over arch of bridge.
 23356	
 23357	A dark back went before them, step of a pard, down, out by the gateway,
 23358	under portcullis barbs.
 23359	
 23360	They followed.
 23361	
 23362	Offend me still. Speak on.
 23363	
 23364	Kind air defined the coigns of houses in Kildare street. No birds. Frail
 23365	from the housetops two plumes of smoke ascended, pluming, and in a flaw
 23366	of softness softly were blown.
 23367	
 23368	Cease to strive. Peace of the druid priests of Cymbeline: hierophantic:
 23369	from wide earth an altar.
 23370	
 23371	     _Laud we the gods
 23372	     And let our crooked smokes climb to their nostrils
 23373	     From our bless'd altars._
 23374	
 23375	
 23376	The superior, the very reverend John Conmee S.J. reset his smooth watch
 23377	in his interior pocket as he came down the presbytery steps. Five to
 23378	three. Just nice time to walk to Artane. What was that boy's name again?
 23379	Dignam. Yes. _Vere dignum et iustum est._ Brother Swan was the person
 23380	to see. Mr Cunningham's letter. Yes. Oblige him, if possible. Good
 23381	practical catholic: useful at mission time.
 23382	
 23383	A onelegged sailor, swinging himself onward by lazy jerks of his
 23384	crutches, growled some notes. He jerked short before the convent of the
 23385	sisters of charity and held out a peaked cap for alms towards the very
 23386	reverend John Conmee S. J. Father Conmee blessed him in the sun for his
 23387	purse held, he knew, one silver crown.
 23388	
 23389	Father Conmee crossed to Mountjoy square. He thought, but not for long,
 23390	of soldiers and sailors, whose legs had been shot off by cannonballs,
 23391	ending their days in some pauper ward, and of cardinal Wolsey's words:
 23392	_If I had served my God as I have served my king He would not have
 23393	abandoned me in my old days._ He walked by the treeshade of sunnywinking
 23394	leaves: and towards him came the wife of Mr David Sheehy M.P.
 23395	
 23396	--Very well, indeed, father. And you, father?
 23397	
 23398	Father Conmee was wonderfully well indeed. He would go to Buxton
 23399	probably for the waters. And her boys, were they getting on well at
 23400	Belvedere? Was that so? Father Conmee was very glad indeed to hear that.
 23401	And Mr Sheehy himself? Still in London. The house was still sitting, to
 23402	be sure it was. Beautiful weather it was, delightful indeed. Yes, it was
 23403	very probable that Father Bernard Vaughan would come again to preach. O,
 23404	yes: a very great success. A wonderful man really.
 23405	
 23406	Father Conmee was very glad to see the wife of Mr David Sheehy M.P.
 23407	Iooking so well and he begged to be remembered to Mr David Sheehy M.P.
 23408	Yes, he would certainly call.
 23409	
 23410	--Good afternoon, Mrs Sheehy.
 23411	
 23412	Father Conmee doffed his silk hat and smiled, as he took leave, at the
 23413	jet beads of her mantilla inkshining in the sun. And smiled yet again,
 23414	in going. He had cleaned his teeth, he knew, with arecanut paste.
 23415	
 23416	Father Conmee walked and, walking, smiled for he thought on Father
 23417	Bernard Vaughan's droll eyes and cockney voice.
 23418	
 23419	--Pilate! Wy don't you old back that owlin mob?
 23420	
 23421	A zealous man, however. Really he was. And really did great good in his
 23422	way. Beyond a doubt. He loved Ireland, he said, and he loved the Irish.
 23423	Of good family too would one think it? Welsh, were they not?
 23424	
 23425	O, lest he forget. That letter to father provincial.
 23426	
 23427	Father Conmee stopped three little schoolboys at the corner of Mountjoy
 23428	square. Yes: they were from Belvedere. The little house. Aha. And were
 23429	they good boys at school? O. That was very good now. And what was his
 23430	name? Jack Sohan. And his name? Ger. Gallaher. And the other little man?
 23431	His name was Brunny Lynam. O, that was a very nice name to have.
 23432	
 23433	Father Conmee gave a letter from his breast to Master Brunny Lynam and
 23434	pointed to the red pillarbox at the corner of Fitzgibbon street.
 23435	
 23436	--But mind you don't post yourself into the box, little man, he said.
 23437	
 23438	The boys sixeyed Father Conmee and laughed:
 23439	
 23440	--O, sir.
 23441	
 23442	--Well, let me see if you can post a letter, Father Conmee said.
 23443	
 23444	Master Brunny Lynam ran across the road and put Father Conmee's letter
 23445	to father provincial into the mouth of the bright red letterbox. Father
 23446	Conmee smiled and nodded and smiled and walked along Mountjoy square
 23447	east.
 23448	
 23449	Mr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c, in silk hat, slate
 23450	frockcoat with silk facings, white kerchief tie, tight lavender
 23451	trousers, canary gloves and pointed patent boots, walking with grave
 23452	deportment most respectfully took the curbstone as he passed lady
 23453	Maxwell at the corner of Dignam's court.
 23454	
 23455	Was that not Mrs M'Guinness?
 23456	
 23457	Mrs M'Guinness, stately, silverhaired, bowed to Father Conmee from the
 23458	farther footpath along which she sailed. And Father Conmee smiled and
 23459	saluted. How did she do?
 23460	
 23461	A fine carriage she had. Like Mary, queen of Scots, something. And to
 23462	think that she was a pawnbroker! Well, now! Such a... what should he
 23463	say?... such a queenly mien.
 23464	
 23465	Father Conmee walked down Great Charles street and glanced at the shutup
 23466	free church on his left. The reverend T. R. Greene B.A. will (D.V.)
 23467	speak. The incumbent they called him. He felt it incumbent on him to say
 23468	a few words. But one should be charitable. Invincible ignorance. They
 23469	acted according to their lights.
 23470	
 23471	Father Conmee turned the corner and walked along the North Circular
 23472	road. It was a wonder that there was not a tramline in such an important
 23473	thoroughfare. Surely, there ought to be.
 23474	
 23475	A band of satchelled schoolboys crossed from Richmond street. All
 23476	raised untidy caps. Father Conmee greeted them more than once benignly.
 23477	Christian brother boys.
 23478	
 23479	Father Conmee smelt incense on his right hand as he walked. Saint
 23480	Joseph's church, Portland row. For aged and virtuous females.
 23481	Father Conmee raised his hat to the Blessed Sacrament. Virtuous: but
 23482	occasionally they were also badtempered.
 23483	
 23484	Near Aldborough house Father Conmee thought of that spendthrift
 23485	nobleman. And now it was an office or something.
 23486	
 23487	Father Conmee began to walk along the North Strand road and was saluted
 23488	by Mr William Gallagher who stood in the doorway of his shop. Father
 23489	Conmee saluted Mr William Gallagher and perceived the odours that came
 23490	from baconflitches and ample cools of butter. He passed Grogan's the
 23491	Tobacconist against which newsboards leaned and told of a dreadful
 23492	catastrophe in New York. In America those things were continually
 23493	happening. Unfortunate people to die like that, unprepared. Still, an
 23494	act of perfect contrition.
 23495	
 23496	Father Conmee went by Daniel Bergin's publichouse against the window of
 23497	which two unlabouring men lounged. They saluted him and were saluted.
 23498	
 23499	Father Conmee passed H. J. O'Neill's funeral establishment where Corny
 23500	Kelleher totted figures in the daybook while he chewed a blade of hay.
 23501	A constable on his beat saluted Father Conmee and Father Conmee saluted
 23502	the constable. In Youkstetter's, the porkbutcher's, Father Conmee
 23503	observed pig's puddings, white and black and red, lie neatly curled in
 23504	tubes.
 23505	
 23506	Moored under the trees of Charleville Mall Father Conmee saw a
 23507	turfbarge, a towhorse with pendent head, a bargeman with a hat of dirty
 23508	straw seated amidships, smoking and staring at a branch of poplar above
 23509	him. It was idyllic: and Father Conmee reflected on the providence of
 23510	the Creator who had made turf to be in bogs whence men might dig it
 23511	out and bring it to town and hamlet to make fires in the houses of poor
 23512	people.
 23513	
 23514	On Newcomen bridge the very reverend John Conmee S.J. of saint Francis
 23515	Xavier's church, upper Gardiner street, stepped on to an outward bound
 23516	tram.
 23517	
 23518	Off an inward bound tram stepped the reverend Nicholas Dudley C. C. of
 23519	saint Agatha's church, north William street, on to Newcomen bridge.
 23520	
 23521	At Newcomen bridge Father Conmee stepped into an outward bound tram for
 23522	he disliked to traverse on foot the dingy way past Mud Island.
 23523	
 23524	Father Conmee sat in a corner of the tramcar, a blue ticket tucked with
 23525	care in the eye of one plump kid glove, while four shillings, a sixpence
 23526	and five pennies chuted from his other plump glovepalm into his purse.
 23527	Passing the ivy church he reflected that the ticket inspector usually
 23528	made his visit when one had carelessly thrown away the ticket. The
 23529	solemnity of the occupants of the car seemed to Father Conmee excessive
 23530	for a journey so short and cheap. Father Conmee liked cheerful decorum.
 23531	
 23532	It was a peaceful day. The gentleman with the glasses opposite Father
 23533	Conmee had finished explaining and looked down. His wife, Father Conmee
 23534	supposed. A tiny yawn opened the mouth of the wife of the gentleman with
 23535	the glasses. She raised her small gloved fist, yawned ever so gently,
 23536	tiptapping her small gloved fist on her opening mouth and smiled tinily,
 23537	sweetly.
 23538	
 23539	Father Conmee perceived her perfume in the car. He perceived also that
 23540	the awkward man at the other side of her was sitting on the edge of the
 23541	seat.
 23542	
 23543	Father Conmee at the altarrails placed the host with difficulty in the
 23544	mouth of the awkward old man who had the shaky head.
 23545	
 23546	At Annesley bridge the tram halted and, when it was about to go, an old
 23547	woman rose suddenly from her place to alight. The conductor pulled the
 23548	bellstrap to stay the car for her. She passed out with her basket and
 23549	a marketnet: and Father Conmee saw the conductor help her and net and
 23550	basket down: and Father Conmee thought that, as she had nearly passed
 23551	the end of the penny fare, she was one of those good souls who had
 23552	always to be told twice _bless you, my child,_ that they have been
 23553	absolved, _pray for me._ But they had so many worries in life, so many
 23554	cares, poor creatures.
 23555	
 23556	From the hoardings Mr Eugene Stratton grimaced with thick niggerlips at
 23557	Father Conmee.
 23558	
 23559	Father Conmee thought of the souls of black and brown and yellow men and
 23560	of his sermon on saint Peter Claver S.J. and the African mission and of
 23561	the propagation of the faith and of the millions of black and brown and
 23562	yellow souls that had not received the baptism of water when their last
 23563	hour came like a thief in the night. That book by the Belgian jesuit,
 23564	_Le Nombre des Ãlus,_ seemed to Father Conmee a reasonable plea. Those
 23565	were millions of human souls created by God in His Own likeness to
 23566	whom the faith had not (D.V.) been brought. But they were God's souls,
 23567	created by God. It seemed to Father Conmee a pity that they should all
 23568	be lost, a waste, if one might say.
 23569	
 23570	At the Howth road stop Father Conmee alighted, was saluted by the
 23571	conductor and saluted in his turn.
 23572	
 23573	The Malahide road was quiet. It pleased Father Conmee, road and name.
 23574	The joybells were ringing in gay Malahide. Lord Talbot de Malahide,
 23575	immediate hereditary lord admiral of Malahide and the seas adjoining.
 23576	Then came the call to arms and she was maid, wife and widow in one day.
 23577	Those were old worldish days, loyal times in joyous townlands, old times
 23578	in the barony.
 23579	
 23580	Father Conmee, walking, thought of his little book _Old Times in the
 23581	Barony_ and of the book that might be written about jesuit houses and of
 23582	Mary Rochfort, daughter of lord Molesworth, first countess of Belvedere.
 23583	
 23584	A listless lady, no more young, walked alone the shore of lough Ennel,
 23585	Mary, first countess of Belvedere, listlessly walking in the evening,
 23586	not startled when an otter plunged. Who could know the truth? Not the
 23587	jealous lord Belvedere and not her confessor if she had not committed
 23588	adultery fully, _eiaculatio seminis inter vas naturale mulieris,_ with
 23589	her husband's brother? She would half confess if she had not all sinned
 23590	as women did. Only God knew and she and he, her husband's brother.
 23591	
 23592	Father Conmee thought of that tyrannous incontinence, needed however for
 23593	man's race on earth, and of the ways of God which were not our ways.
 23594	
 23595	Don John Conmee walked and moved in times of yore. He was humane and
 23596	honoured there. He bore in mind secrets confessed and he smiled at
 23597	smiling noble faces in a beeswaxed drawingroom, ceiled with full fruit
 23598	clusters. And the hands of a bride and of a bridegroom, noble to noble,
 23599	were impalmed by Don John Conmee.
 23600	
 23601	It was a charming day.
 23602	
 23603	The lychgate of a field showed Father Conmee breadths of cabbages,
 23604	curtseying to him with ample underleaves. The sky showed him a flock of
 23605	small white clouds going slowly down the wind. _Moutonner,_ the French
 23606	said. A just and homely word.
 23607	
 23608	Father Conmee, reading his office, watched a flock of muttoning clouds
 23609	over Rathcoffey. His thinsocked ankles were tickled by the stubble of
 23610	Clongowes field. He walked there, reading in the evening, and heard
 23611	the cries of the boys' lines at their play, young cries in the quiet
 23612	evening. He was their rector: his reign was mild.
 23613	
 23614	Father Conmee drew off his gloves and took his rededged breviary out. An
 23615	ivory bookmark told him the page.
 23616	
 23617	Nones. He should have read that before lunch. But lady Maxwell had come.
 23618	
 23619	Father Conmee read in secret _Pater_ and _Ave_ and crossed his breast.
 23620	_Deus in adiutorium._
 23621	
 23622	He walked calmly and read mutely the nones, walking and reading till he
 23623	came to _Res_ in _Beati immaculati: Principium verborum tuorum veritas:
 23624	in eternum omnia indicia iustitiae tuae._
 23625	
 23626	A flushed young man came from a gap of a hedge and after him came a
 23627	young woman with wild nodding daisies in her hand. The young man raised
 23628	his cap abruptly: the young woman abruptly bent and with slow care
 23629	detached from her light skirt a clinging twig.
 23630	
 23631	Father Conmee blessed both gravely and turned a thin page of his
 23632	breviary. _Sin: Principes persecuti sunt me gratis: et a verbis tuis
 23633	formidavit cor meum._
 23634	
 23635	* * * * *
 23636	
 23637	Corny Kelleher closed his long daybook and glanced with his drooping eye
 23638	at a pine coffinlid sentried in a corner. He pulled himself erect,
 23639	went to it and, spinning it on its axle, viewed its shape and brass
 23640	furnishings. Chewing his blade of hay he laid the coffinlid by and came
 23641	to the doorway. There he tilted his hatbrim to give shade to his eyes
 23642	and leaned against the doorcase, looking idly out.
 23643	
 23644	Father John Conmee stepped into the Dollymount tram on Newcomen bridge.
 23645	
 23646	Corny Kelleher locked his largefooted boots and gazed, his hat
 23647	downtilted, chewing his blade of hay.
 23648	
 23649	Constable 57C, on his beat, stood to pass the time of day.
 23650	
 23651	--That's a fine day, Mr Kelleher.
 23652	
 23653	--Ay, Corny Kelleher said.
 23654	
 23655	--It's very close, the constable said.
 23656	
 23657	Corny Kelleher sped a silent jet of hayjuice arching from his mouth
 23658	while a generous white arm from a window in Eccles street flung forth a
 23659	coin.
 23660	
 23661	--What's the best news? he asked.
 23662	
 23663	--I seen that particular party last evening, the constable said with
 23664	bated breath.
 23665	
 23666	* * * * *
 23667	
 23668	A onelegged sailor crutched himself round MacConnell's corner, skirting
 23669	Rabaiotti's icecream car, and jerked himself up Eccles street. Towards
 23670	Larry O'Rourke, in shirtsleeves in his doorway, he growled unamiably:
 23671	
 23672	--_For England_...
 23673	
 23674	He swung himself violently forward past Katey and Boody Dedalus, halted
 23675	and growled:
 23676	
 23677	--_home and beauty._
 23678	
 23679	J. J. O'Molloy's white careworn face was told that Mr Lambert was in the
 23680	warehouse with a visitor.
 23681	
 23682	A stout lady stopped, took a copper coin from her purse and dropped it
 23683	into the cap held out to her. The sailor grumbled thanks, glanced sourly
 23684	at the unheeding windows, sank his head and swung himself forward four
 23685	strides.
 23686	
 23687	He halted and growled angrily:
 23688	
 23689	--_For England_...
 23690	
 23691	Two barefoot urchins, sucking long liquorice laces, halted near him,
 23692	gaping at his stump with their yellowslobbered mouths.
 23693	
 23694	He swung himself forward in vigorous jerks, halted, lifted his head
 23695	towards a window and bayed deeply:
 23696	
 23697	--_home and beauty._
 23698	
 23699	The gay sweet chirping whistling within went on a bar or two, ceased.
 23700	The blind of the window was drawn aside. A card _Unfurnished Apartments_
 23701	slipped from the sash and fell. A plump bare generous arm shone, was
 23702	seen, held forth from a white petticoatbodice and taut shiftstraps. A
 23703	woman's hand flung forth a coin over the area railings. It fell on the
 23704	path.
 23705	
 23706	One of the urchins ran to it, picked it up and dropped it into the
 23707	minstrel's cap, saying:
 23708	
 23709	--There, sir.
 23710	
 23711	* * * * *
 23712	
 23713	Katey and Boody Dedalus shoved in the door of the closesteaming kitchen.
 23714	
 23715	--Did you put in the books? Boody asked.
 23716	
 23717	Maggy at the range rammed down a greyish mass beneath bubbling suds
 23718	twice with her potstick and wiped her brow.
 23719	
 23720	--They wouldn't give anything on them, she said.
 23721	
 23722	Father Conmee walked through Clongowes fields, his thinsocked ankles
 23723	tickled by stubble.
 23724	
 23725	--Where did you try? Boody asked.
 23726	
 23727	--M'Guinness's.
 23728	
 23729	Boody stamped her foot and threw her satchel on the table.
 23730	
 23731	--Bad cess to her big face! she cried.
 23732	
 23733	Katey went to the range and peered with squinting eyes.
 23734	
 23735	--What's in the pot? she asked.
 23736	
 23737	--Shirts, Maggy said.
 23738	
 23739	Boody cried angrily:
 23740	
 23741	--Crickey, is there nothing for us to eat?
 23742	
 23743	Katey, lifting the kettlelid in a pad of her stained skirt, asked:
 23744	
 23745	--And what's in this?
 23746	
 23747	A heavy fume gushed in answer.
 23748	
 23749	--Peasoup, Maggy said.
 23750	
 23751	--Where did you get it? Katey asked.
 23752	
 23753	--Sister Mary Patrick, Maggy said.
 23754	
 23755	The lacquey rang his bell.
 23756	
 23757	--Barang!
 23758	
 23759	Boody sat down at the table and said hungrily:
 23760	
 23761	--Give us it here.
 23762	
 23763	Maggy poured yellow thick soup from the kettle into a bowl. Katey,
 23764	sitting opposite Boody, said quietly, as her fingertip lifted to her
 23765	mouth random crumbs:
 23766	
 23767	--A good job we have that much. Where's Dilly?
 23768	
 23769	--Gone to meet father, Maggy said.
 23770	
 23771	Boody, breaking big chunks of bread into the yellow soup, added:
 23772	
 23773	--Our father who art not in heaven.
 23774	
 23775	Maggy, pouring yellow soup in Katey's bowl, exclaimed:
 23776	
 23777	--Boody! For shame!
 23778	
 23779	A skiff, a crumpled throwaway, Elijah is coming, rode lightly down the
 23780	Liffey, under Loopline bridge, shooting the rapids where water chafed
 23781	around the bridgepiers, sailing eastward past hulls and anchorchains,
 23782	between the Customhouse old dock and George's quay.
 23783	
 23784	* * * * *
 23785	
 23786	The blond girl in Thornton's bedded the wicker basket with rustling
 23787	fibre. Blazes Boylan handed her the bottle swathed in pink tissue paper
 23788	and a small jar.
 23789	
 23790	--Put these in first, will you? he said.
 23791	
 23792	--Yes, sir, the blond girl said. And the fruit on top.
 23793	
 23794	--That'll do, game ball, Blazes Boylan said.
 23795	
 23796	She bestowed fat pears neatly, head by tail, and among them ripe
 23797	shamefaced peaches.
 23798	
 23799	Blazes Boylan walked here and there in new tan shoes about the
 23800	fruitsmelling shop, lifting fruits, young juicy crinkled and plump red
 23801	tomatoes, sniffing smells.
 23802	
 23803	H. E. L. Y.'S filed before him, tallwhitehatted, past Tangier lane,
 23804	plodding towards their goal.
 23805	
 23806	He turned suddenly from a chip of strawberries, drew a gold watch from
 23807	his fob and held it at its chain's length.
 23808	
 23809	--Can you send them by tram? Now?
 23810	
 23811	A darkbacked figure under Merchants' arch scanned books on the hawker's
 23812	cart.
 23813	
 23814	--Certainly, sir. Is it in the city?
 23815	
 23816	--O, yes, Blazes Boylan said. Ten minutes.
 23817	
 23818	The blond girl handed him a docket and pencil.
 23819	
 23820	--Will you write the address, sir?
 23821	
 23822	Blazes Boylan at the counter wrote and pushed the docket to her.
 23823	
 23824	--Send it at once, will you? he said. It's for an invalid.
 23825	
 23826	--Yes, sir. I will, sir.
 23827	
 23828	Blazes Boylan rattled merry money in his trousers' pocket.
 23829	
 23830	--What's the damage? he asked.
 23831	
 23832	The blond girl's slim fingers reckoned the fruits.
 23833	
 23834	Blazes Boylan looked into the cut of her blouse. A young pullet. He took
 23835	a red carnation from the tall stemglass.
 23836	
 23837	--This for me? he asked gallantly.
 23838	
 23839	The blond girl glanced sideways at him, got up regardless, with his tie
 23840	a bit crooked, blushing.
 23841	
 23842	--Yes, sir, she said.
 23843	
 23844	Bending archly she reckoned again fat pears and blushing peaches.
 23845	
 23846	Blazes Boylan looked in her blouse with more favour, the stalk of the
 23847	red flower between his smiling teeth.
 23848	
 23849	--May I say a word to your telephone, missy? he asked roguishly.
 23850	
 23851	* * * * *
 23852	
 23853	_--Ma!_ Almidano Artifoni said.
 23854	
 23855	He gazed over Stephen's shoulder at Goldsmith's knobby poll.
 23856	
 23857	Two carfuls of tourists passed slowly, their women sitting fore,
 23858	gripping the handrests. Palefaces. Men's arms frankly round their
 23859	stunted forms. They looked from Trinity to the blind columned porch of
 23860	the bank of Ireland where pigeons roocoocooed.
 23861	
 23862	--_Anch'io ho avuto di queste idee, ALMIDANO ARTIFONI SAID, quand' ero
 23863	giovine come Lei. Eppoi mi sono convinto che il mondo Ã¨ una bestia.
 23864	Ã peccato. PerchÃ¨ la sua voce... sarebbe un cespite di rendita, via.
 23865	Invece, Lei si sacrifica._
 23866	
 23867	--_Sacrifizio incruento,_ Stephen said smiling, swaying his ashplant in
 23868	slow swingswong from its midpoint, lightly.
 23869	
 23870	_--Speriamo,_ the round mustachioed face said pleasantly. _Ma, dia retta
 23871	a me. Ci rifletta_.
 23872	
 23873	By the stern stone hand of Grattan, bidding halt, an Inchicore tram
 23874	unloaded straggling Highland soldiers of a band.
 23875	
 23876	--_Ci rifletterÃ²,_ Stephen said, glancing down the solid trouserleg.
 23877	
 23878	--_Ma, sul serio, eh?_ Almidano Artifoni said.
 23879	
 23880	His heavy hand took Stephen's firmly. Human eyes. They gazed curiously
 23881	an instant and turned quickly towards a Dalkey tram.
 23882	
 23883	_--Eccolo,_ Almidano Artifoni said in friendly haste. _Venga a trovarmi
 23884	e ci pensi. Addio, caro._
 23885	
 23886	--_Arrivederla, maestro,_ Stephen said, raising his hat when his hand
 23887	was freed. _E grazie._
 23888	
 23889	--_Di che?_ Almidano Artifoni said. _Scusi, eh? Tante belle cose!_
 23890	
 23891	Almidano Artifoni, holding up a baton of rolled music as a signal,
 23892	trotted on stout trousers after the Dalkey tram. In vain he trotted,
 23893	signalling in vain among the rout of barekneed gillies smuggling
 23894	implements of music through Trinity gates.
 23895	
 23896	* * * * *
 23897	
 23898	Miss Dunne hid the Capel street library copy of _The Woman in White_
 23899	far back in her drawer and rolled a sheet of gaudy notepaper into her
 23900	typewriter.
 23901	
 23902	Too much mystery business in it. Is he in love with that one, Marion?
 23903	Change it and get another by Mary Cecil Haye.
 23904	
 23905	The disk shot down the groove, wobbled a while, ceased and ogled them:
 23906	six.
 23907	
 23908	Miss Dunne clicked on the keyboard:
 23909	
 23910	--16 June 1904.
 23911	
 23912	Five tallwhitehatted sandwichmen between Monypeny's corner and the slab
 23913	where Wolfe Tone's statue was not, eeled themselves turning H. E. L.
 23914	Y.'S and plodded back as they had come.
 23915	
 23916	Then she stared at the large poster of Marie Kendall, charming
 23917	soubrette, and, listlessly lolling, scribbled on the jotter sixteens and
 23918	capital esses. Mustard hair and dauby cheeks. She's not nicelooking,
 23919	is she? The way she's holding up her bit of a skirt. Wonder will that
 23920	fellow be at the band tonight. If I could get that dressmaker to make a
 23921	concertina skirt like Susy Nagle's. They kick out grand. Shannon and
 23922	all the boatclub swells never took his eyes off her. Hope to goodness he
 23923	won't keep me here till seven.
 23924	
 23925	The telephone rang rudely by her ear.
 23926	
 23927	--Hello. Yes, sir. No, sir. Yes, sir. I'll ring them up after five. Only
 23928	those two, sir, for Belfast and Liverpool. All right, sir. Then I can go
 23929	after six if you're not back. A quarter after. Yes, sir. Twentyseven and
 23930	six. I'll tell him. Yes: one, seven, six.
 23931	
 23932	She scribbled three figures on an envelope.
 23933	
 23934	--Mr Boylan! Hello! That gentleman from SPORT was in looking for you. Mr
 23935	Lenehan, yes. He said he'll be in the Ormond at four. No, sir. Yes, sir.
 23936	I'll ring them up after five.
 23937	
 23938	* * * * *
 23939	
 23940	Two pink faces turned in the flare of the tiny torch.
 23941	
 23942	--Who's that? Ned Lambert asked. Is that Crotty?
 23943	
 23944	--Ringabella and Crosshaven, a voice replied groping for foothold.
 23945	
 23946	--Hello, Jack, is that yourself? Ned Lambert said, raising in salute his
 23947	pliant lath among the flickering arches. Come on. Mind your steps there.
 23948	
 23949	The vesta in the clergyman's uplifted hand consumed itself in a long
 23950	soft flame and was let fall. At their feet its red speck died: and
 23951	mouldy air closed round them.
 23952	
 23953	--How interesting! a refined accent said in the gloom.
 23954	
 23955	--Yes, sir, Ned Lambert said heartily. We are standing in the historic
 23956	council chamber of saint Mary's abbey where silken Thomas proclaimed
 23957	himself a rebel in 1534. This is the most historic spot in all Dublin.
 23958	O'Madden Burke is going to write something about it one of these days.
 23959	The old bank of Ireland was over the way till the time of the union and
 23960	the original jews' temple was here too before they built their synagogue
 23961	over in Adelaide road. You were never here before, Jack, were you?
 23962	
 23963	--No, Ned.
 23964	
 23965	--He rode down through Dame walk, the refined accent said, if my memory
 23966	serves me. The mansion of the Kildares was in Thomas court.
 23967	
 23968	--That's right, Ned Lambert said. That's quite right, sir.
 23969	
 23970	--If you will be so kind then, the clergyman said, the next time to
 23971	allow me perhaps...
 23972	
 23973	--Certainly, Ned Lambert said. Bring the camera whenever you like. I'll
 23974	get those bags cleared away from the windows. You can take it from here
 23975	or from here.
 23976	
 23977	In the still faint light he moved about, tapping with his lath the piled
 23978	seedbags and points of vantage on the floor.
 23979	
 23980	From a long face a beard and gaze hung on a chessboard.
 23981	
 23982	--I'm deeply obliged, Mr Lambert, the clergyman said. I won't trespass
 23983	on your valuable time...
 23984	
 23985	--You're welcome, sir, Ned Lambert said. Drop in whenever you like. Next
 23986	week, say. Can you see?
 23987	
 23988	--Yes, yes. Good afternoon, Mr Lambert. Very pleased to have met you.
 23989	
 23990	--Pleasure is mine, sir, Ned Lambert answered.
 23991	
 23992	He followed his guest to the outlet and then whirled his lath away among
 23993	the pillars. With J. J. O'Molloy he came forth slowly into Mary's abbey
 23994	where draymen were loading floats with sacks of carob and palmnut meal,
 23995	O'Connor, Wexford.
 23996	
 23997	He stood to read the card in his hand.
 23998	
 23999	--The reverend Hugh C. Love, Rathcoffey. Present address: Saint
 24000	Michael's, Sallins. Nice young chap he is. He's writing a book about the
 24001	Fitzgeralds he told me. He's well up in history, faith.
 24002	
 24003	The young woman with slow care detached from her light skirt a clinging
 24004	twig.
 24005	
 24006	--I thought you were at a new gunpowder plot, J. J. O'Molloy said.
 24007	
 24008	Ned Lambert cracked his fingers in the air.
 24009	
 24010	--God! he cried. I forgot to tell him that one about the earl of Kildare
 24011	after he set fire to Cashel cathedral. You know that one? _I'm bloody
 24012	sorry I did it,_ says he, _but I declare to God I thought the archbishop
 24013	was inside._ He mightn't like it, though. What? God, I'll tell him
 24014	anyhow. That was the great earl, the Fitzgerald Mor. Hot members they
 24015	were all of them, the Geraldines.
 24016	
 24017	The horses he passed started nervously under their slack harness. He
 24018	slapped a piebald haunch quivering near him and cried:
 24019	
 24020	--Woa, sonny!
 24021	
 24022	He turned to J. J. O'Molloy and asked:
 24023	
 24024	--Well, Jack. What is it? What's the trouble? Wait awhile. Hold hard.
 24025	
 24026	With gaping mouth and head far back he stood still and, after an
 24027	instant, sneezed loudly.
 24028	
 24029	--Chow! he said. Blast you!
 24030	
 24031	--The dust from those sacks, J. J. O'Molloy said politely.
 24032	
 24033	--No, Ned Lambert gasped, I caught a... cold night before... blast
 24034	your soul... night before last... and there was a hell of a lot of
 24035	draught...
 24036	
 24037	He held his handkerchief ready for the coming...
 24038	
 24039	--I was... Glasnevin this morning... poor little... what do you call
 24040	him... Chow!... Mother of Moses!
 24041	
 24042	* * * * *
 24043	
 24044	Tom Rochford took the top disk from the pile he clasped against his
 24045	claret waistcoat.
 24046	
 24047	--See? he said. Say it's turn six. In here, see. Turn Now On.
 24048	
 24049	He slid it into the left slot for them. It shot down the groove, wobbled
 24050	a while, ceased, ogling them: six.
 24051	
 24052	Lawyers of the past, haughty, pleading, beheld pass from the
 24053	consolidated taxing office to Nisi Prius court Richie Goulding carrying
 24054	the costbag of Goulding, Collis and Ward and heard rustling from the
 24055	admiralty division of king's bench to the court of appeal an elderly
 24056	female with false teeth smiling incredulously and a black silk skirt of
 24057	great amplitude.
 24058	
 24059	--See? he said. See now the last one I put in is over here: Turns Over.
 24060	The impact. Leverage, see?
 24061	
 24062	He showed them the rising column of disks on the right.
 24063	
 24064	--Smart idea, Nosey Flynn said, snuffling. So a fellow coming in late
 24065	can see what turn is on and what turns are over.
 24066	
 24067	--See? Tom Rochford said.
 24068	
 24069	He slid in a disk for himself: and watched it shoot, wobble, ogle, stop:
 24070	four. Turn Now On.
 24071	
 24072	--I'll see him now in the Ormond, Lenehan said, and sound him. One good
 24073	turn deserves another.
 24074	
 24075	--Do, Tom Rochford said. Tell him I'm Boylan with impatience.
 24076	
 24077	--Goodnight, M'Coy said abruptly. When you two begin
 24078	
 24079	Nosey Flynn stooped towards the lever, snuffling at it.
 24080	
 24081	--But how does it work here, Tommy? he asked.
 24082	
 24083	--Tooraloo, Lenehan said. See you later.
 24084	
 24085	He followed M'Coy out across the tiny square of Crampton court.
 24086	
 24087	--He's a hero, he said simply.
 24088	
 24089	--I know, M'Coy said. The drain, you mean.
 24090	
 24091	--Drain? Lenehan said. It was down a manhole.
 24092	
 24093	They passed Dan Lowry's musichall where Marie Kendall, charming
 24094	soubrette, smiled on them from a poster a dauby smile.
 24095	
 24096	Going down the path of Sycamore street beside the Empire musichall
 24097	Lenehan showed M'Coy how the whole thing was. One of those manholes like
 24098	a bloody gaspipe and there was the poor devil stuck down in it, half
 24099	choked with sewer gas. Down went Tom Rochford anyhow, booky's vest and
 24100	all, with the rope round him. And be damned but he got the rope round
 24101	the poor devil and the two were hauled up.
 24102	
 24103	--The act of a hero, he said.
 24104	
 24105	At the Dolphin they halted to allow the ambulance car to gallop past
 24106	them for Jervis street.
 24107	
 24108	--This way, he said, walking to the right. I want to pop into Lynam's
 24109	to see Sceptre's starting price. What's the time by your gold watch and
 24110	chain?
 24111	
 24112	M'Coy peered into Marcus Tertius Moses' sombre office, then at O'Neill's
 24113	clock.
 24114	
 24115	--After three, he said. Who's riding her?
 24116	
 24117	--O. Madden, Lenehan said. And a game filly she is.
 24118	
 24119	While he waited in Temple bar M'Coy dodged a banana peel with gentle
 24120	pushes of his toe from the path to the gutter. Fellow might damn easy
 24121	get a nasty fall there coming along tight in the dark.
 24122	
 24123	The gates of the drive opened wide to give egress to the viceregal
 24124	cavalcade.
 24125	
 24126	--Even money, Lenehan said returning. I knocked against Bantam Lyons
 24127	in there going to back a bloody horse someone gave him that hasn't an
 24128	earthly. Through here.
 24129	
 24130	They went up the steps and under Merchants' arch. A darkbacked figure
 24131	scanned books on the hawker's cart.
 24132	
 24133	--There he is, Lenehan said.
 24134	
 24135	--Wonder what he's buying, M'Coy said, glancing behind.
 24136	
 24137	--_Leopoldo or the Bloom is on the Rye,_ Lenehan said.
 24138	
 24139	--He's dead nuts on sales, M'Coy said. I was with him one day and he
 24140	bought a book from an old one in Liffey street for two bob. There were
 24141	fine plates in it worth double the money, the stars and the moon and
 24142	comets with long tails. Astronomy it was about.
 24143	
 24144	Lenehan laughed.
 24145	
 24146	--I'll tell you a damn good one about comets' tails, he said. Come over
 24147	in the sun.
 24148	
 24149	They crossed to the metal bridge and went along Wellington quay by the
 24150	riverwall.
 24151	
 24152	Master Patrick Aloysius Dignam came out of Mangan's, late Fehrenbach's,
 24153	carrying a pound and a half of porksteaks.
 24154	
 24155	--There was a long spread out at Glencree reformatory, Lenehan said
 24156	eagerly. The annual dinner, you know. Boiled shirt affair. The lord
 24157	mayor was there, Val Dillon it was, and sir Charles Cameron and Dan
 24158	Dawson spoke and there was music. Bartell d'Arcy sang and Benjamin
 24159	Dollard...
 24160	
 24161	--I know, M'Coy broke in. My missus sang there once.
 24162	
 24163	--Did she? Lenehan said.
 24164	
 24165	A card _Unfurnished Apartments_ reappeared on the windowsash of number 7
 24166	Eccles street.
 24167	
 24168	He checked his tale a moment but broke out in a wheezy laugh.
 24169	
 24170	--But wait till I tell you, he said. Delahunt of Camden street had the
 24171	catering and yours truly was chief bottlewasher. Bloom and the wife were
 24172	there. Lashings of stuff we put up: port wine and sherry and curacao to
 24173	which we did ample justice. Fast and furious it was. After liquids came
 24174	solids. Cold joints galore and mince pies...
 24175	
 24176	--I know, M'Coy said. The year the missus was there...
 24177	
 24178	Lenehan linked his arm warmly.
 24179	
 24180	--But wait till I tell you, he said. We had a midnight lunch too after
 24181	all the jollification and when we sallied forth it was blue o'clock the
 24182	morning after the night before. Coming home it was a gorgeous winter's
 24183	night on the Featherbed Mountain. Bloom and Chris Callinan were on one
 24184	side of the car and I was with the wife on the other. We started singing
 24185	glees and duets: _Lo, the early beam of morning_. She was well primed
 24186	with a good load of Delahunt's port under her bellyband. Every jolt the
 24187	bloody car gave I had her bumping up against me. Hell's delights! She
 24188	has a fine pair, God bless her. Like that.
 24189	
 24190	He held his caved hands a cubit from him, frowning:
 24191	
 24192	--I was tucking the rug under her and settling her boa all the time.
 24193	Know what I mean?
 24194	
 24195	His hands moulded ample curves of air. He shut his eyes tight in
 24196	delight, his body shrinking, and blew a sweet chirp from his lips.
 24197	
 24198	--The lad stood to attention anyhow, he said with a sigh. She's a gamey
 24199	mare and no mistake. Bloom was pointing out all the stars and the comets
 24200	in the heavens to Chris Callinan and the jarvey: the great bear and
 24201	Hercules and the dragon, and the whole jingbang lot. But, by God, I was
 24202	lost, so to speak, in the milky way. He knows them all, faith. At last
 24203	she spotted a weeny weeshy one miles away. _And what star is that,
 24204	Poldy?_ says she. By God, she had Bloom cornered. _That one, is it?_
 24205	says Chris Callinan, _sure that's only what you might call a pinprick._
 24206	By God, he wasn't far wide of the mark.
 24207	
 24208	Lenehan stopped and leaned on the riverwall, panting with soft laughter.
 24209	
 24210	--I'm weak, he gasped.
 24211	
 24212	M'Coy's white face smiled about it at instants and grew grave. Lenehan
 24213	walked on again. He lifted his yachtingcap and scratched his hindhead
 24214	rapidly. He glanced sideways in the sunlight at M'Coy.
 24215	
 24216	--He's a cultured allroundman, Bloom is, he said seriously. He's not one
 24217	of your common or garden... you know... There's a touch of the artist
 24218	about old Bloom.
 24219	
 24220	* * * * *
 24221	
 24222	Mr Bloom turned over idly pages of _The Awful Disclosures of Maria
 24223	Monk,_ then of Aristotle's _Masterpiece._ Crooked botched print. Plates:
 24224	infants cuddled in a ball in bloodred wombs like livers of slaughtered
 24225	cows. Lots of them like that at this moment all over the world. All
 24226	butting with their skulls to get out of it. Child born every minute
 24227	somewhere. Mrs Purefoy.
 24228	
 24229	He laid both books aside and glanced at the third: _Tales of the Ghetto_
 24230	by Leopold von Sacher Masoch.
 24231	
 24232	--That I had, he said, pushing it by.
 24233	
 24234	The shopman let two volumes fall on the counter.
 24235	
 24236	--Them are two good ones, he said.
 24237	
 24238	Onions of his breath came across the counter out of his ruined mouth.
 24239	He bent to make a bundle of the other books, hugged them against his
 24240	unbuttoned waistcoat and bore them off behind the dingy curtain.
 24241	
 24242	On O'Connell bridge many persons observed the grave deportment and gay
 24243	apparel of Mr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c.
 24244	
 24245	Mr Bloom, alone, looked at the titles. _Fair Tyrants_ by James
 24246	Lovebirch. Know the kind that is. Had it? Yes.
 24247	
 24248	He opened it. Thought so.
 24249	
 24250	A woman's voice behind the dingy curtain. Listen: the man.
 24251	
 24252	No: she wouldn't like that much. Got her it once.
 24253	
 24254	He read the other title: _Sweets of Sin_. More in her line. Let us see.
 24255	
 24256	He read where his finger opened.
 24257	
 24258	_--All the dollarbills her husband gave her were spent in the stores on
 24259	wondrous gowns and costliest frillies. For him! For raoul!_
 24260	
 24261	Yes. This. Here. Try.
 24262	
 24263	--_Her mouth glued on his in a luscious voluptuous kiss while his hands
 24264	felt for the opulent curves inside her deshabillÃ©._
 24265	
 24266	Yes. Take this. The end.
 24267	
 24268	--_You are late, he spoke hoarsely, eying her with a suspicious glare.
 24269	The beautiful woman threw off her sabletrimmed wrap, displaying her
 24270	queenly shoulders and heaving embonpoint. An imperceptible smile played
 24271	round her perfect lips as she turned to him calmly._
 24272	
 24273	Mr Bloom read again: _The beautiful woman._
 24274	
 24275	Warmth showered gently over him, cowing his flesh. Flesh yielded amply
 24276	amid rumpled clothes: whites of eyes swooning up. His nostrils arched
 24277	themselves for prey. Melting breast ointments (_for Him! For Raoul!_).
 24278	Armpits' oniony sweat. Fishgluey slime (_her heaving embonpoint!_).
 24279	Feel! Press! Crushed! Sulphur dung of lions!
 24280	
 24281	Young! Young!
 24282	
 24283	An elderly female, no more young, left the building of the courts of
 24284	chancery, king's bench, exchequer and common pleas, having heard in
 24285	the lord chancellor's court the case in lunacy of Potterton, in the
 24286	admiralty division the summons, exparte motion, of the owners of the
 24287	Lady Cairns versus the owners of the barque Mona, in the court of appeal
 24288	reservation of judgment in the case of Harvey versus the Ocean Accident
 24289	and Guarantee Corporation.
 24290	
 24291	Phlegmy coughs shook the air of the bookshop, bulging out the dingy
 24292	curtains. The shopman's uncombed grey head came out and his unshaven
 24293	reddened face, coughing. He raked his throat rudely, puked phlegm on the
 24294	floor. He put his boot on what he had spat, wiping his sole along it,
 24295	and bent, showing a rawskinned crown, scantily haired.
 24296	
 24297	Mr Bloom beheld it.
 24298	
 24299	Mastering his troubled breath, he said:
 24300	
 24301	--I'll take this one.
 24302	
 24303	The shopman lifted eyes bleared with old rheum.
 24304	
 24305	--_Sweets of Sin,_ he said, tapping on it. That's a good one.
 24306	
 24307	* * * * *
 24308	
 24309	The lacquey by the door of Dillon's auctionrooms shook his handbell
 24310	twice again and viewed himself in the chalked mirror of the cabinet.
 24311	
 24312	Dilly Dedalus, loitering by the curbstone, heard the beats of the
 24313	bell, the cries of the auctioneer within. Four and nine. Those lovely
 24314	curtains. Five shillings. Cosy curtains. Selling new at two guineas. Any
 24315	advance on five shillings? Going for five shillings.
 24316	
 24317	The lacquey lifted his handbell and shook it:
 24318	
 24319	--Barang!
 24320	
 24321	Bang of the lastlap bell spurred the halfmile wheelmen to their sprint.
 24322	J. A. Jackson, W. E. Wylie, A. Munro and H. T. Gahan, their stretched
 24323	necks wagging, negotiated the curve by the College library.
 24324	
 24325	Mr Dedalus, tugging a long moustache, came round from Williams's row. He
 24326	halted near his daughter.
 24327	
 24328	--It's time for you, she said.
 24329	
 24330	--Stand up straight for the love of the lord Jesus, Mr Dedalus said.
 24331	Are you trying to imitate your uncle John, the cornetplayer, head upon
 24332	shoulder? Melancholy God!
 24333	
 24334	Dilly shrugged her shoulders. Mr Dedalus placed his hands on them and
 24335	held them back.
 24336	
 24337	--Stand up straight, girl, he said. You'll get curvature of the spine.
 24338	Do you know what you look like?
 24339	
 24340	He let his head sink suddenly down and forward, hunching his shoulders
 24341	and dropping his underjaw.
 24342	
 24343	--Give it up, father, Dilly said. All the people are looking at you.
 24344	
 24345	Mr Dedalus drew himself upright and tugged again at his moustache.
 24346	
 24347	--Did you get any money? Dilly asked.
 24348	
 24349	--Where would I get money? Mr Dedalus said. There is no-one in Dublin
 24350	would lend me fourpence.
 24351	
 24352	--You got some, Dilly said, looking in his eyes.
 24353	
 24354	--How do you know that? Mr Dedalus asked, his tongue in his cheek.
 24355	
 24356	Mr Kernan, pleased with the order he had booked, walked boldly along
 24357	James's street.
 24358	
 24359	--I know you did, Dilly answered. Were you in the Scotch house now?
 24360	
 24361	--I was not, then, Mr Dedalus said, smiling. Was it the little nuns
 24362	taught you to be so saucy? Here.
 24363	
 24364	He handed her a shilling.
 24365	
 24366	--See if you can do anything with that, he said.
 24367	
 24368	--I suppose you got five, Dilly said. Give me more than that.
 24369	
 24370	--Wait awhile, Mr Dedalus said threateningly. You're like the rest of
 24371	them, are you? An insolent pack of little bitches since your poor mother
 24372	died. But wait awhile. You'll all get a short shrift and a long day from
 24373	me. Low blackguardism! I'm going to get rid of you. Wouldn't care if I
 24374	was stretched out stiff. He's dead. The man upstairs is dead.
 24375	
 24376	He left her and walked on. Dilly followed quickly and pulled his coat.
 24377	
 24378	--Well, what is it? he said, stopping.
 24379	
 24380	The lacquey rang his bell behind their backs.
 24381	
 24382	--Barang!
 24383	
 24384	--Curse your bloody blatant soul, Mr Dedalus cried, turning on him.
 24385	
 24386	The lacquey, aware of comment, shook the lolling clapper of his bell but
 24387	feebly:
 24388	
 24389	--Bang!
 24390	
 24391	Mr Dedalus stared at him.
 24392	
 24393	--Watch him, he said. It's instructive. I wonder will he allow us to
 24394	talk.
 24395	
 24396	--You got more than that, father, Dilly said.
 24397	
 24398	--I'm going to show you a little trick, Mr Dedalus said. I'll leave
 24399	you all where Jesus left the jews. Look, there's all I have. I got
 24400	two shillings from Jack Power and I spent twopence for a shave for the
 24401	funeral.
 24402	
 24403	He drew forth a handful of copper coins, nervously.
 24404	
 24405	--Can't you look for some money somewhere? Dilly said.
 24406	
 24407	Mr Dedalus thought and nodded.
 24408	
 24409	--I will, he said gravely. I looked all along the gutter in O'Connell
 24410	street. I'll try this one now.
 24411	
 24412	--You're very funny, Dilly said, grinning.
 24413	
 24414	--Here, Mr Dedalus said, handing her two pennies. Get a glass of milk
 24415	for yourself and a bun or a something. I'll be home shortly.
 24416	
 24417	He put the other coins in his pocket and started to walk on.
 24418	
 24419	The viceregal cavalcade passed, greeted by obsequious policemen, out of
 24420	Parkgate.
 24421	
 24422	--I'm sure you have another shilling, Dilly said.
 24423	
 24424	The lacquey banged loudly.
 24425	
 24426	Mr Dedalus amid the din walked off, murmuring to himself with a pursing
 24427	mincing mouth gently:
 24428	
 24429	--The little nuns! Nice little things! O, sure they wouldn't do
 24430	anything! O, sure they wouldn't really! Is it little sister Monica!
 24431	
 24432	* * * * *
 24433	
 24434	From the sundial towards James's gate walked Mr Kernan, pleased with the
 24435	order he had booked for Pulbrook Robertson, boldly along James's street,
 24436	past Shackleton's offices. Got round him all right. How do you do, Mr
 24437	Crimmins? First rate, sir. I was afraid you might be up in your other
 24438	establishment in Pimlico. How are things going? Just keeping alive.
 24439	Lovely weather we're having. Yes, indeed. Good for the country. Those
 24440	farmers are always grumbling. I'll just take a thimbleful of your best
 24441	gin, Mr Crimmins. A small gin, sir. Yes, sir. Terrible affair that
 24442	General Slocum explosion. Terrible, terrible! A thousand casualties. And
 24443	heartrending scenes. Men trampling down women and children. Most brutal
 24444	thing. What do they say was the cause? Spontaneous combustion. Most
 24445	scandalous revelation. Not a single lifeboat would float and the
 24446	firehose all burst. What I can't understand is how the inspectors ever
 24447	allowed a boat like that... Now, you're talking straight, Mr Crimmins.
 24448	You know why? Palm oil. Is that a fact? Without a doubt. Well now, look
 24449	at that. And America they say is the land of the free. I thought we were
 24450	bad here.
 24451	
 24452	I smiled at him. _America,_ I said quietly, just like that. _What is
 24453	it? The sweepings of every country including our own. Isn't that true?_
 24454	That's a fact.
 24455	
 24456	Graft, my dear sir. Well, of course, where there's money going there's
 24457	always someone to pick it up.
 24458	
 24459	Saw him looking at my frockcoat. Dress does it. Nothing like a dressy
 24460	appearance. Bowls them over.
 24461	
 24462	--Hello, Simon, Father Cowley said. How are things?
 24463	
 24464	--Hello, Bob, old man, Mr Dedalus answered, stopping.
 24465	
 24466	Mr Kernan halted and preened himself before the sloping mirror of Peter
