 24467	Kennedy, hairdresser. Stylish coat, beyond a doubt. Scott of Dawson
 24468	street. Well worth the half sovereign I gave Neary for it. Never built
 24469	under three guineas. Fits me down to the ground. Some Kildare street
 24470	club toff had it probably. John Mulligan, the manager of the Hibernian
 24471	bank, gave me a very sharp eye yesterday on Carlisle bridge as if he
 24472	remembered me.
 24473	
 24474	Aham! Must dress the character for those fellows. Knight of the road.
 24475	Gentleman. And now, Mr Crimmins, may we have the honour of your custom
 24476	again, sir. The cup that cheers but not inebriates, as the old saying
 24477	has it.
 24478	
 24479	North wall and sir John Rogerson's quay, with hulls and anchorchains,
 24480	sailing westward, sailed by a skiff, a crumpled throwaway, rocked on the
 24481	ferrywash, Elijah is coming.
 24482	
 24483	Mr Kernan glanced in farewell at his image. High colour, of course.
 24484	Grizzled moustache. Returned Indian officer. Bravely he bore his stumpy
 24485	body forward on spatted feet, squaring his shoulders. Is that Ned
 24486	Lambert's brother over the way, Sam? What? Yes. He's as like it as damn
 24487	it. No. The windscreen of that motorcar in the sun there. Just a flash
 24488	like that. Damn like him.
 24489	
 24490	Aham! Hot spirit of juniper juice warmed his vitals and his breath. Good
 24491	drop of gin, that was. His frocktails winked in bright sunshine to his
 24492	fat strut.
 24493	
 24494	Down there Emmet was hanged, drawn and quartered. Greasy black rope.
 24495	Dogs licking the blood off the street when the lord lieutenant's wife
 24496	drove by in her noddy.
 24497	
 24498	Bad times those were. Well, well. Over and done with. Great topers too.
 24499	Fourbottle men.
 24500	
 24501	Let me see. Is he buried in saint Michan's? Or no, there was a midnight
 24502	burial in Glasnevin. Corpse brought in through a secret door in the
 24503	wall. Dignam is there now. Went out in a puff. Well, well. Better turn
 24504	down here. Make a detour.
 24505	
 24506	Mr Kernan turned and walked down the slope of Watling street by
 24507	the corner of Guinness's visitors' waitingroom. Outside the Dublin
 24508	Distillers Company's stores an outside car without fare or jarvey stood,
 24509	the reins knotted to the wheel. Damn dangerous thing. Some Tipperary
 24510	bosthoon endangering the lives of the citizens. Runaway horse.
 24511	
 24512	Denis Breen with his tomes, weary of having waited an hour in John
 24513	Henry Menton's office, led his wife over O'Connell bridge, bound for the
 24514	office of Messrs Collis and Ward.
 24515	
 24516	Mr Kernan approached Island street.
 24517	
 24518	Times of the troubles. Must ask Ned Lambert to lend me those
 24519	reminiscences of sir Jonah Barrington. When you look back on it all
 24520	now in a kind of retrospective arrangement. Gaming at Daly's. No
 24521	cardsharping then. One of those fellows got his hand nailed to the table
 24522	by a dagger. Somewhere here lord Edward Fitzgerald escaped from major
 24523	Sirr. Stables behind Moira house.
 24524	
 24525	Damn good gin that was.
 24526	
 24527	Fine dashing young nobleman. Good stock, of course. That ruffian, that
 24528	sham squire, with his violet gloves gave him away. Course they were
 24529	on the wrong side. They rose in dark and evil days. Fine poem that
 24530	is: Ingram. They were gentlemen. Ben Dollard does sing that ballad
 24531	touchingly. Masterly rendition.
 24532	
 24533	_At the siege of Ross did my father fall._
 24534	
 24535	A cavalcade in easy trot along Pembroke quay passed, outriders leaping,
 24536	leaping in their, in their saddles. Frockcoats. Cream sunshades.
 24537	
 24538	Mr Kernan hurried forward, blowing pursily.
 24539	
 24540	His Excellency! Too bad! Just missed that by a hair. Damn it! What a
 24541	pity!
 24542	
 24543	* * * * *
 24544	
 24545	Stephen Dedalus watched through the webbed window the lapidary's fingers
 24546	prove a timedulled chain. Dust webbed the window and the showtrays. Dust
 24547	darkened the toiling fingers with their vulture nails. Dust slept
 24548	on dull coils of bronze and silver, lozenges of cinnabar, on rubies,
 24549	leprous and winedark stones.
 24550	
 24551	Born all in the dark wormy earth, cold specks of fire, evil, lights
 24552	shining in the darkness. Where fallen archangels flung the stars of
 24553	their brows. Muddy swinesnouts, hands, root and root, gripe and wrest
 24554	them.
 24555	
 24556	She dances in a foul gloom where gum bums with garlic. A sailorman,
 24557	rustbearded, sips from a beaker rum and eyes her. A long and seafed
 24558	silent rut. She dances, capers, wagging her sowish haunches and her
 24559	hips, on her gross belly flapping a ruby egg.
 24560	
 24561	Old Russell with a smeared shammy rag burnished again his gem, turned it
 24562	and held it at the point of his Moses' beard. Grandfather ape gloating
 24563	on a stolen hoard.
 24564	
 24565	And you who wrest old images from the burial earth? The brainsick words
 24566	of sophists: Antisthenes. A lore of drugs. Orient and immortal wheat
 24567	standing from everlasting to everlasting.
 24568	
 24569	Two old women fresh from their whiff of the briny trudged through
 24570	Irishtown along London bridge road, one with a sanded tired umbrella,
 24571	one with a midwife's bag in which eleven cockles rolled.
 24572	
 24573	The whirr of flapping leathern bands and hum of dynamos from the
 24574	powerhouse urged Stephen to be on. Beingless beings. Stop! Throb always
 24575	without you and the throb always within. Your heart you sing of. I
 24576	between them. Where? Between two roaring worlds where they swirl, I.
 24577	Shatter them, one and both. But stun myself too in the blow. Shatter me
 24578	you who can. Bawd and butcher were the words. I say! Not yet awhile. A
 24579	look around.
 24580	
 24581	Yes, quite true. Very large and wonderful and keeps famous time. You say
 24582	right, sir. A Monday morning, 'twas so, indeed.
 24583	
 24584	Stephen went down Bedford row, the handle of the ash clacking against
 24585	his shoulderblade. In Clohissey's window a faded 1860 print of Heenan
 24586	boxing Sayers held his eye. Staring backers with square hats stood
 24587	round the roped prizering. The heavyweights in tight loincloths proposed
 24588	gently each to other his bulbous fists. And they are throbbing: heroes'
 24589	hearts.
 24590	
 24591	He turned and halted by the slanted bookcart.
 24592	
 24593	--Twopence each, the huckster said. Four for sixpence.
 24594	
 24595	Tattered pages. _The Irish Beekeeper. Life and Miracles of the CurÃ© of
 24596	Ars. Pocket Guide to Killarney._
 24597	
 24598	I might find here one of my pawned schoolprizes. _Stephano Dedalo,
 24599	alumno optimo, palmam ferenti._
 24600	
 24601	Father Conmee, having read his little hours, walked through the hamlet
 24602	of Donnycarney, murmuring vespers.
 24603	
 24604	Binding too good probably. What is this? Eighth and ninth book of Moses.
 24605	Secret of all secrets. Seal of King David. Thumbed pages: read and read.
 24606	Who has passed here before me? How to soften chapped hands. Recipe for
 24607	white wine vinegar. How to win a woman's love. For me this. Say the
 24608	following talisman three times with hands folded:
 24609	
 24610	--_Se el yilo nebrakada femininum! Amor me solo! Sanktus! Amen._
 24611	
 24612	Who wrote this? Charms and invocations of the most blessed abbot Peter
 24613	Salanka to all true believers divulged. As good as any other abbot's
 24614	charms, as mumbling Joachim's. Down, baldynoddle, or we'll wool your
 24615	wool.
 24616	
 24617	--What are you doing here, Stephen?
 24618	
 24619	Dilly's high shoulders and shabby dress.
 24620	
 24621	Shut the book quick. Don't let see.
 24622	
 24623	--What are you doing? Stephen said.
 24624	
 24625	A Stuart face of nonesuch Charles, lank locks falling at its sides. It
 24626	glowed as she crouched feeding the fire with broken boots. I told her
 24627	of Paris. Late lieabed under a quilt of old overcoats, fingering a
 24628	pinchbeck bracelet, Dan Kelly's token. _Nebrakada femininum._
 24629	
 24630	--What have you there? Stephen asked.
 24631	
 24632	--I bought it from the other cart for a penny, Dilly said, laughing
 24633	nervously. Is it any good?
 24634	
 24635	My eyes they say she has. Do others see me so? Quick, far and daring.
 24636	Shadow of my mind.
 24637	
 24638	He took the coverless book from her hand. Chardenal's French primer.
 24639	
 24640	--What did you buy that for? he asked. To learn French?
 24641	
 24642	She nodded, reddening and closing tight her lips.
 24643	
 24644	Show no surprise. Quite natural.
 24645	
 24646	--Here, Stephen said. It's all right. Mind Maggy doesn't pawn it on you.
 24647	I suppose all my books are gone.
 24648	
 24649	--Some, Dilly said. We had to.
 24650	
 24651	She is drowning. Agenbite. Save her. Agenbite. All against us. She will
 24652	drown me with her, eyes and hair. Lank coils of seaweed hair around me,
 24653	my heart, my soul. Salt green death.
 24654	
 24655	We.
 24656	
 24657	Agenbite of inwit. Inwit's agenbite.
 24658	
 24659	Misery! Misery!
 24660	
 24661	* * * * *
 24662	
 24663	--Hello, Simon, Father Cowley said. How are things?
 24664	
 24665	--Hello, Bob, old man, Mr Dedalus answered, stopping.
 24666	
 24667	They clasped hands loudly outside Reddy and Daughter's. Father Cowley
 24668	brushed his moustache often downward with a scooping hand.
 24669	
 24670	--What's the best news? Mr Dedalus said.
 24671	
 24672	--Why then not much, Father Cowley said. I'm barricaded up, Simon, with
 24673	two men prowling around the house trying to effect an entrance.
 24674	
 24675	--Jolly, Mr Dedalus said. Who is it?
 24676	
 24677	--O, Father Cowley said. A certain gombeen man of our acquaintance.
 24678	
 24679	--With a broken back, is it? Mr Dedalus asked.
 24680	
 24681	--The same, Simon, Father Cowley answered. Reuben of that ilk. I'm just
 24682	waiting for Ben Dollard. He's going to say a word to long John to get
 24683	him to take those two men off. All I want is a little time.
 24684	
 24685	He looked with vague hope up and down the quay, a big apple bulging in
 24686	his neck.
 24687	
 24688	--I know, Mr Dedalus said, nodding. Poor old bockedy Ben! He's always
 24689	doing a good turn for someone. Hold hard!
 24690	
 24691	He put on his glasses and gazed towards the metal bridge an instant.
 24692	
 24693	--There he is, by God, he said, arse and pockets.
 24694	
 24695	Ben Dollard's loose blue cutaway and square hat above large slops
 24696	crossed the quay in full gait from the metal bridge. He came towards
 24697	them at an amble, scratching actively behind his coattails.
 24698	
 24699	As he came near Mr Dedalus greeted:
 24700	
 24701	--Hold that fellow with the bad trousers.
 24702	
 24703	--Hold him now, Ben Dollard said.
 24704	
 24705	Mr Dedalus eyed with cold wandering scorn various points of Ben
 24706	Dollard's figure. Then, turning to Father Cowley with a nod, he muttered
 24707	sneeringly:
 24708	
 24709	--That's a pretty garment, isn't it, for a summer's day?
 24710	
 24711	--Why, God eternally curse your soul, Ben Dollard growled furiously, I
 24712	threw out more clothes in my time than you ever saw.
 24713	
 24714	He stood beside them beaming, on them first and on his roomy clothes
 24715	from points of which Mr Dedalus flicked fluff, saying:
 24716	
 24717	--They were made for a man in his health, Ben, anyhow.
 24718	
 24719	--Bad luck to the jewman that made them, Ben Dollard said. Thanks be to
 24720	God he's not paid yet.
 24721	
 24722	--And how is that _basso profondo_, Benjamin? Father Cowley asked.
 24723	
 24724	Cashel Boyle O'Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, murmuring,
 24725	glassyeyed, strode past the Kildare street club.
 24726	
 24727	Ben Dollard frowned and, making suddenly a chanter's mouth, gave forth a
 24728	deep note.
 24729	
 24730	--Aw! he said.
 24731	
 24732	--That's the style, Mr Dedalus said, nodding to its drone.
 24733	
 24734	--What about that? Ben Dollard said. Not too dusty? What?
 24735	
 24736	He turned to both.
 24737	
 24738	--That'll do, Father Cowley said, nodding also.
 24739	
 24740	The reverend Hugh C. Love walked from the old chapterhouse of saint
 24741	Mary's abbey past James and Charles Kennedy's, rectifiers, attended by
 24742	Geraldines tall and personable, towards the Tholsel beyond the ford of
 24743	hurdles.
 24744	
 24745	Ben Dollard with a heavy list towards the shopfronts led them forward,
 24746	his joyful fingers in the air.
 24747	
 24748	--Come along with me to the subsheriff's office, he said. I want to
 24749	show you the new beauty Rock has for a bailiff. He's a cross between
 24750	Lobengula and Lynchehaun. He's well worth seeing, mind you. Come along.
 24751	I saw John Henry Menton casually in the Bodega just now and it will cost
 24752	me a fall if I don't... Wait awhile... We're on the right lay, Bob,
 24753	believe you me.
 24754	
 24755	--For a few days tell him, Father Cowley said anxiously.
 24756	
 24757	Ben Dollard halted and stared, his loud orifice open, a dangling button
 24758	of his coat wagging brightbacked from its thread as he wiped away the
 24759	heavy shraums that clogged his eyes to hear aright.
 24760	
 24761	--What few days? he boomed. Hasn't your landlord distrained for rent?
 24762	
 24763	--He has, Father Cowley said.
 24764	
 24765	--Then our friend's writ is not worth the paper it's printed on, Ben
 24766	Dollard said. The landlord has the prior claim. I gave him all the
 24767	particulars. 29 Windsor avenue. Love is the name?
 24768	
 24769	--That's right, Father Cowley said. The reverend Mr Love. He's a
 24770	minister in the country somewhere. But are you sure of that?
 24771	
 24772	--You can tell Barabbas from me, Ben Dollard said, that he can put that
 24773	writ where Jacko put the nuts.
 24774	
 24775	He led Father Cowley boldly forward, linked to his bulk.
 24776	
 24777	--Filberts I believe they were, Mr Dedalus said, as he dropped his
 24778	glasses on his coatfront, following them.
 24779	
 24780	* * * * *
 24781	
 24782	--The youngster will be all right, Martin Cunningham said, as they
 24783	passed out of the Castleyard gate.
 24784	
 24785	The policeman touched his forehead.
 24786	
 24787	--God bless you, Martin Cunningham said, cheerily.
 24788	
 24789	He signed to the waiting jarvey who chucked at the reins and set on
 24790	towards Lord Edward street.
 24791	
 24792	Bronze by gold, Miss Kennedy's head by Miss Douce's head, appeared above
 24793	the crossblind of the Ormond hotel.
 24794	
 24795	--Yes, Martin Cunningham said, fingering his beard. I wrote to Father
 24796	Conmee and laid the whole case before him.
 24797	
 24798	--You could try our friend, Mr Power suggested backward.
 24799	
 24800	--Boyd? Martin Cunningham said shortly. Touch me not.
 24801	
 24802	John Wyse Nolan, lagging behind, reading the list, came after them
 24803	quickly down Cork hill.
 24804	
 24805	On the steps of the City hall Councillor Nannetti, descending, hailed
 24806	Alderman Cowley and Councillor Abraham Lyon ascending.
 24807	
 24808	The castle car wheeled empty into upper Exchange street.
 24809	
 24810	--Look here, Martin, John Wyse Nolan said, overtaking them at the _Mail_
 24811	office. I see Bloom put his name down for five shillings.
 24812	
 24813	--Quite right, Martin Cunningham said, taking the list. And put down the
 24814	five shillings too.
 24815	
 24816	--Without a second word either, Mr Power said.
 24817	
 24818	--Strange but true, Martin Cunningham added.
 24819	
 24820	John Wyse Nolan opened wide eyes.
 24821	
 24822	--I'll say there is much kindness in the jew, he quoted, elegantly.
 24823	
 24824	They went down Parliament street.
 24825	
 24826	--There's Jimmy Henry, Mr Power said, just heading for Kavanagh's.
 24827	
 24828	--Righto, Martin Cunningham said. Here goes.
 24829	
 24830	Outside _la Maison Claire_ Blazes Boylan waylaid Jack Mooney's
 24831	brother-in-law, humpy, tight, making for the liberties.
 24832	
 24833	John Wyse Nolan fell back with Mr Power, while Martin Cunningham took
 24834	the elbow of a dapper little man in a shower of hail suit, who walked
 24835	uncertainly, with hasty steps past Micky Anderson's watches.
 24836	
 24837	--The assistant town clerk's corns are giving him some trouble, John
 24838	Wyse Nolan told Mr Power.
 24839	
 24840	They followed round the corner towards James Kavanagh's winerooms. The
 24841	empty castle car fronted them at rest in Essex gate. Martin Cunningham,
 24842	speaking always, showed often the list at which Jimmy Henry did not
 24843	glance.
 24844	
 24845	--And long John Fanning is here too, John Wyse Nolan said, as large as
 24846	life.
 24847	
 24848	The tall form of long John Fanning filled the doorway where he stood.
 24849	
 24850	--Good day, Mr Subsheriff, Martin Cunningham said, as all halted and
 24851	greeted.
 24852	
 24853	Long John Fanning made no way for them. He removed his large Henry Clay
 24854	decisively and his large fierce eyes scowled intelligently over all
 24855	their faces.
 24856	
 24857	--Are the conscript fathers pursuing their peaceful deliberations? he
 24858	said with rich acrid utterance to the assistant town clerk.
 24859	
 24860	Hell open to christians they were having, Jimmy Henry said pettishly,
 24861	about their damned Irish language. Where was the marshal, he wanted
 24862	to know, to keep order in the council chamber. And old Barlow the
 24863	macebearer laid up with asthma, no mace on the table, nothing in order,
 24864	no quorum even, and Hutchinson, the lord mayor, in Llandudno and little
 24865	Lorcan Sherlock doing _locum tenens_ for him. Damned Irish language,
 24866	language of our forefathers.
 24867	
 24868	Long John Fanning blew a plume of smoke from his lips.
 24869	
 24870	Martin Cunningham spoke by turns, twirling the peak of his beard, to the
 24871	assistant town clerk and the subsheriff, while John Wyse Nolan held his
 24872	peace.
 24873	
 24874	--What Dignam was that? long John Fanning asked.
 24875	
 24876	Jimmy Henry made a grimace and lifted his left foot.
 24877	
 24878	--O, my corns! he said plaintively. Come upstairs for goodness' sake
 24879	till I sit down somewhere. Uff! Ooo! Mind!
 24880	
 24881	Testily he made room for himself beside long John Fanning's flank and
 24882	passed in and up the stairs.
 24883	
 24884	--Come on up, Martin Cunningham said to the subsheriff. I don't think
 24885	you knew him or perhaps you did, though.
 24886	
 24887	With John Wyse Nolan Mr Power followed them in.
 24888	
 24889	--Decent little soul he was, Mr Power said to the stalwart back of long
 24890	John Fanning ascending towards long John Fanning in the mirror.
 24891	
 24892	--Rather lowsized. Dignam of Menton's office that was, Martin Cunningham
 24893	said.
 24894	
 24895	Long John Fanning could not remember him.
 24896	
 24897	Clatter of horsehoofs sounded from the air.
 24898	
 24899	--What's that? Martin Cunningham said.
 24900	
 24901	All turned where they stood. John Wyse Nolan came down again. From the
 24902	cool shadow of the doorway he saw the horses pass Parliament street,
 24903	harness and glossy pasterns in sunlight shimmering. Gaily they went past
 24904	before his cool unfriendly eyes, not quickly. In saddles of the leaders,
 24905	leaping leaders, rode outriders.
 24906	
 24907	--What was it? Martin Cunningham asked, as they went on up the
 24908	staircase.
 24909	
 24910	--The lord lieutenantgeneral and general governor of Ireland, John Wyse
 24911	Nolan answered from the stairfoot.
 24912	
 24913	* * * * *
 24914	
 24915	As they trod across the thick carpet Buck Mulligan whispered behind his
 24916	Panama to Haines:
 24917	
 24918	--Parnell's brother. There in the corner.
 24919	
 24920	They chose a small table near the window, opposite a longfaced man whose
 24921	beard and gaze hung intently down on a chessboard.
 24922	
 24923	--Is that he? Haines asked, twisting round in his seat.
 24924	
 24925	--Yes, Mulligan said. That's John Howard, his brother, our city marshal.
 24926	
 24927	John Howard Parnell translated a white bishop quietly and his grey claw
 24928	went up again to his forehead whereat it rested. An instant after, under
 24929	its screen, his eyes looked quickly, ghostbright, at his foe and fell
 24930	once more upon a working corner.
 24931	
 24932	--I'll take a _mÃ©lange,_ Haines said to the waitress.
 24933	
 24934	--Two _mÃ©langes,_ Buck Mulligan said. And bring us some scones and
 24935	butter and some cakes as well.
 24936	
 24937	When she had gone he said, laughing:
 24938	
 24939	--We call it D.B.C. because they have damn bad cakes. O, but you missed
 24940	Dedalus on _Hamlet._
 24941	
 24942	Haines opened his newbought book.
 24943	
 24944	--I'm sorry, he said. Shakespeare is the happy huntingground of all
 24945	minds that have lost their balance.
 24946	
 24947	The onelegged sailor growled at the area of 14 Nelson street:
 24948	
 24949	--_England expects_...
 24950	
 24951	Buck Mulligan's primrose waistcoat shook gaily to his laughter.
 24952	
 24953	--You should see him, he said, when his body loses its balance.
 24954	Wandering Aengus I call him.
 24955	
 24956	--I am sure he has an _idÃ©e fixe,_ Haines said, pinching his chin
 24957	thoughtfully with thumb and forefinger. Now I am speculating what it
 24958	would be likely to be. Such persons always have.
 24959	
 24960	Buck Mulligan bent across the table gravely.
 24961	
 24962	--They drove his wits astray, he said, by visions of hell. He will never
 24963	capture the Attic note. The note of Swinburne, of all poets, the white
 24964	death and the ruddy birth. That is his tragedy. He can never be a poet.
 24965	The joy of creation...
 24966	
 24967	--Eternal punishment, Haines said, nodding curtly. I see. I tackled him
 24968	this morning on belief. There was something on his mind, I saw.
 24969	It's rather interesting because professor Pokorny of Vienna makes an
 24970	interesting point out of that.
 24971	
 24972	Buck Mulligan's watchful eyes saw the waitress come. He helped her to
 24973	unload her tray.
 24974	
 24975	--He can find no trace of hell in ancient Irish myth, Haines said, amid
 24976	the cheerful cups. The moral idea seems lacking, the sense of destiny,
 24977	of retribution. Rather strange he should have just that fixed idea. Does
 24978	he write anything for your movement?
 24979	
 24980	He sank two lumps of sugar deftly longwise through the whipped cream.
 24981	Buck Mulligan slit a steaming scone in two and plastered butter over its
 24982	smoking pith. He bit off a soft piece hungrily.
 24983	
 24984	--Ten years, he said, chewing and laughing. He is going to write
 24985	something in ten years.
 24986	
 24987	--Seems a long way off, Haines said, thoughtfully lifting his spoon.
 24988	Still, I shouldn't wonder if he did after all.
 24989	
 24990	He tasted a spoonful from the creamy cone of his cup.
 24991	
 24992	--This is real Irish cream I take it, he said with forbearance. I don't
 24993	want to be imposed on.
 24994	
 24995	Elijah, skiff, light crumpled throwaway, sailed eastward by flanks of
 24996	ships and trawlers, amid an archipelago of corks, beyond new Wapping
 24997	street past Benson's ferry, and by the threemasted schooner _Rosevean_
 24998	from Bridgwater with bricks.
 24999	
 25000	* * * * *
 25001	
 25002	Almidano Artifoni walked past Holles street, past Sewell's yard.
 25003	Behind him Cashel Boyle O'Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, with
 25004	stickumbrelladustcoat dangling, shunned the lamp before Mr Law Smith's
 25005	house and, crossing, walked along Merrion square. Distantly behind him a
 25006	blind stripling tapped his way by the wall of College park.
 25007	
 25008	Cashel Boyle O'Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell walked as far as
 25009	Mr Lewis Werner's cheerful windows, then turned and strode back along
 25010	Merrion square, his stickumbrelladustcoat dangling.
 25011	
 25012	At the corner of Wilde's house he halted, frowned at Elijah's name
 25013	announced on the Metropolitan hall, frowned at the distant pleasance of
 25014	duke's lawn. His eyeglass flashed frowning in the sun. With ratsteeth
 25015	bared he muttered:
 25016	
 25017	--_Coactus volui._
 25018	
 25019	He strode on for Clare street, grinding his fierce word.
 25020	
 25021	As he strode past Mr Bloom's dental windows the sway of his dustcoat
 25022	brushed rudely from its angle a slender tapping cane and swept onwards,
 25023	having buffeted a thewless body. The blind stripling turned his sickly
 25024	face after the striding form.
 25025	
 25026	--God's curse on you, he said sourly, whoever you are! You're blinder
 25027	nor I am, you bitch's bastard!
 25028	
 25029	* * * * *
 25030	
 25031	Opposite Ruggy O'Donohoe's Master Patrick Aloysius Dignam, pawing the
 25032	pound and a half of Mangan's, late Fehrenbach's, porksteaks he had been
 25033	sent for, went along warm Wicklow street dawdling. It was too blooming
 25034	dull sitting in the parlour with Mrs Stoer and Mrs Quigley and Mrs
 25035	MacDowell and the blind down and they all at their sniffles and sipping
 25036	sups of the superior tawny sherry uncle Barney brought from Tunney's.
 25037	And they eating crumbs of the cottage fruitcake, jawing the whole
 25038	blooming time and sighing.
 25039	
 25040	After Wicklow lane the window of Madame Doyle, courtdress milliner,
 25041	stopped him. He stood looking in at the two puckers stripped to their
 25042	pelts and putting up their props. From the sidemirrors two mourning
 25043	Masters Dignam gaped silently. Myler Keogh, Dublin's pet lamb, will
 25044	meet sergeantmajor Bennett, the Portobello bruiser, for a purse of fifty
 25045	sovereigns. Gob, that'd be a good pucking match to see. Myler Keogh,
 25046	that's the chap sparring out to him with the green sash. Two bar
 25047	entrance, soldiers half price. I could easy do a bunk on ma. Master
 25048	Dignam on his left turned as he turned. That's me in mourning. When
 25049	is it? May the twentysecond. Sure, the blooming thing is all over. He
 25050	turned to the right and on his right Master Dignam turned, his cap awry,
 25051	his collar sticking up. Buttoning it down, his chin lifted, he saw the
 25052	image of Marie Kendall, charming soubrette, beside the two puckers. One
 25053	of them mots that do be in the packets of fags Stoer smokes that his old
 25054	fellow welted hell out of him for one time he found out.
 25055	
 25056	Master Dignam got his collar down and dawdled on. The best pucker going
 25057	for strength was Fitzsimons. One puck in the wind from that fellow would
 25058	knock you into the middle of next week, man. But the best pucker for
 25059	science was Jem Corbet before Fitzsimons knocked the stuffings out of
 25060	him, dodging and all.
 25061	
 25062	In Grafton street Master Dignam saw a red flower in a toff's mouth and
 25063	a swell pair of kicks on him and he listening to what the drunk was
 25064	telling him and grinning all the time.
 25065	
 25066	No Sandymount tram.
 25067	
 25068	Master Dignam walked along Nassau street, shifted the porksteaks to
 25069	his other hand. His collar sprang up again and he tugged it down. The
 25070	blooming stud was too small for the buttonhole of the shirt, blooming
 25071	end to it. He met schoolboys with satchels. I'm not going tomorrow
 25072	either, stay away till Monday. He met other schoolboys. Do they notice
 25073	I'm in mourning? Uncle Barney said he'd get it into the paper tonight.
 25074	Then they'll all see it in the paper and read my name printed and pa's
 25075	name.
 25076	
 25077	His face got all grey instead of being red like it was and there was a
 25078	fly walking over it up to his eye. The scrunch that was when they
 25079	were screwing the screws into the coffin: and the bumps when they were
 25080	bringing it downstairs.
 25081	
 25082	Pa was inside it and ma crying in the parlour and uncle Barney telling
 25083	the men how to get it round the bend. A big coffin it was, and high and
 25084	heavylooking. How was that? The last night pa was boosed he was standing
 25085	on the landing there bawling out for his boots to go out to Tunney's for
 25086	to boose more and he looked butty and short in his shirt. Never see him
 25087	again. Death, that is. Pa is dead. My father is dead. He told me to be
 25088	a good son to ma. I couldn't hear the other things he said but I saw
 25089	his tongue and his teeth trying to say it better. Poor pa. That was
 25090	Mr Dignam, my father. I hope he's in purgatory now because he went to
 25091	confession to Father Conroy on Saturday night.
 25092	
 25093	* * * * *
 25094	
 25095	William Humble, earl of Dudley, and lady Dudley, accompanied by
 25096	lieutenantcolonel Heseltine, drove out after luncheon from the viceregal
 25097	lodge. In the following carriage were the honourable Mrs Paget, Miss de
 25098	Courcy and the honourable Gerald Ward A.D.C. in attendance.
 25099	
 25100	The cavalcade passed out by the lower gate of Phoenix park saluted by
 25101	obsequious policemen and proceeded past Kingsbridge along the northern
 25102	quays. The viceroy was most cordially greeted on his way through the
 25103	metropolis. At Bloody bridge Mr Thomas Kernan beyond the river greeted
 25104	him vainly from afar Between Queen's and Whitworth bridges lord Dudley's
 25105	viceregal carriages passed and were unsaluted by Mr Dudley White, B.
 25106	L., M. A., who stood on Arran quay outside Mrs M. E. White's, the
 25107	pawnbroker's, at the corner of Arran street west stroking his nose with
 25108	his forefinger, undecided whether he should arrive at Phibsborough
 25109	more quickly by a triple change of tram or by hailing a car or on foot
 25110	through Smithfield, Constitution hill and Broadstone terminus. In the
 25111	porch of Four Courts Richie Goulding with the costbag of Goulding,
 25112	Collis and Ward saw him with surprise. Past Richmond bridge at the
 25113	doorstep of the office of Reuben J Dodd, solicitor, agent for the
 25114	Patriotic Insurance Company, an elderly female about to enter changed
 25115	her plan and retracing her steps by King's windows smiled credulously
 25116	on the representative of His Majesty. From its sluice in Wood quay wall
 25117	under Tom Devan's office Poddle river hung out in fealty a tongue of
 25118	liquid sewage. Above the crossblind of the Ormond hotel, gold by bronze,
 25119	Miss Kennedy's head by Miss Douce's head watched and admired. On Ormond
 25120	quay Mr Simon Dedalus, steering his way from the greenhouse for the
 25121	subsheriff's office, stood still in midstreet and brought his hat low.
 25122	His Excellency graciously returned Mr Dedalus' greeting. From Cahill's
 25123	corner the reverend Hugh C. Love, M.A., made obeisance unperceived,
 25124	mindful of lords deputies whose hands benignant had held of yore rich
 25125	advowsons. On Grattan bridge Lenehan and M'Coy, taking leave of each
 25126	other, watched the carriages go by. Passing by Roger Greene's office and
 25127	Dollard's big red printinghouse Gerty MacDowell, carrying the Catesby's
 25128	cork lino letters for her father who was laid up, knew by the style
 25129	it was the lord and lady lieutenant but she couldn't see what Her
 25130	Excellency had on because the tram and Spring's big yellow furniture van
 25131	had to stop in front of her on account of its being the lord lieutenant.
 25132	Beyond Lundy Foot's from the shaded door of Kavanagh's winerooms
 25133	John Wyse Nolan smiled with unseen coldness towards the lord
 25134	lieutenantgeneral and general governor of Ireland. The Right Honourable
 25135	William Humble, earl of Dudley, G. C. V. O., passed Micky Anderson's all
 25136	times ticking watches and Henry and James's wax smartsuited freshcheeked
 25137	models, the gentleman Henry, _dernier cri_ James. Over against Dame gate
 25138	Tom Rochford and Nosey Flynn watched the approach of the cavalcade. Tom
 25139	Rochford, seeing the eyes of lady Dudley fixed on him, took his thumbs
 25140	quickly out of the pockets of his claret waistcoat and doffed his cap to
 25141	her. A charming _soubrette,_ great Marie Kendall, with dauby cheeks and
 25142	lifted skirt smiled daubily from her poster upon William Humble, earl
 25143	of Dudley, and upon lieutenantcolonel H. G. Heseltine, and also upon
 25144	the honourable Gerald Ward A. D. C. From the window of the D. B. C. Buck
 25145	Mulligan gaily, and Haines gravely, gazed down on the viceregal equipage
 25146	over the shoulders of eager guests, whose mass of forms darkened the
 25147	chessboard whereon John Howard Parnell looked intently. In Fownes's
 25148	street Dilly Dedalus, straining her sight upward from Chardenal's first
 25149	French primer, saw sunshades spanned and wheelspokes spinning in the
 25150	glare. John Henry Menton, filling the doorway of Commercial Buildings,
 25151	stared from winebig oyster eyes, holding a fat gold hunter watch not
 25152	looked at in his fat left hand not feeling it. Where the foreleg of King
 25153	Billy's horse pawed the air Mrs Breen plucked her hastening husband
 25154	back from under the hoofs of the outriders. She shouted in his ear the
 25155	tidings. Understanding, he shifted his tomes to his left breast
 25156	and saluted the second carriage. The honourable Gerald Ward A.D.C.,
 25157	agreeably surprised, made haste to reply. At Ponsonby's corner a jaded
 25158	white flagon H. halted and four tallhatted white flagons halted behind
 25159	him, E.L.Y'S, while outriders pranced past and carriages. Opposite
 25160	Pigott's music warerooms Mr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c,
 25161	gaily apparelled, gravely walked, outpassed by a viceroy and unobserved.
 25162	By the provost's wall came jauntily Blazes Boylan, stepping in tan shoes
 25163	and socks with skyblue clocks to the refrain of _My girl's a Yorkshire
 25164	girl._
 25165	
 25166	Blazes Boylan presented to the leaders' skyblue frontlets and high
 25167	action a skyblue tie, a widebrimmed straw hat at a rakish angle and a
 25168	suit of indigo serge. His hands in his jacket pockets forgot to salute
 25169	but he offered to the three ladies the bold admiration of his eyes and
 25170	the red flower between his lips. As they drove along Nassau street His
 25171	Excellency drew the attention of his bowing consort to the programme of
 25172	music which was being discoursed in College park. Unseen brazen highland
 25173	laddies blared and drumthumped after the _cortÃ¨ge_:
 25174	
 25175	     _But though she's a factory lass
 25176	     And wears no fancy clothes.
 25177	     Baraabum.
 25178	     Yet I've a sort of a
 25179	     Yorkshire relish for
 25180	     My little Yorkshire rose.
 25181	     Baraabum._
 25182	
 25183	Thither of the wall the quartermile flat handicappers, M. C. Green, H.
 25184	Shrift, T. M. Patey, C. Scaife, J. B. Jeffs, G. N. Morphy, F. Stevenson,
 25185	C. Adderly and W. C. Huggard, started in pursuit. Striding past Finn's
 25186	hotel Cashel Boyle O'Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell stared through a
 25187	fierce eyeglass across the carriages at the head of Mr M. E. Solomons
 25188	in the window of the Austro-Hungarian viceconsulate. Deep in Leinster
 25189	street by Trinity's postern a loyal king's man, Hornblower, touched
 25190	his tallyho cap. As the glossy horses pranced by Merrion square Master
 25191	Patrick Aloysius Dignam, waiting, saw salutes being given to the gent
 25192	with the topper and raised also his new black cap with fingers greased
 25193	by porksteak paper. His collar too sprang up. The viceroy, on his way to
 25194	inaugurate the Mirus bazaar in aid of funds for Mercer's hospital,
 25195	drove with his following towards Lower Mount street. He passed a blind
 25196	stripling opposite Broadbent's. In Lower Mount street a pedestrian in a
 25197	brown macintosh, eating dry bread, passed swiftly and unscathed across
 25198	the viceroy's path. At the Royal Canal bridge, from his hoarding,
 25199	Mr Eugene Stratton, his blub lips agrin, bade all comers welcome to
 25200	Pembroke township. At Haddington road corner two sanded women halted
 25201	themselves, an umbrella and a bag in which eleven cockles rolled to view
 25202	with wonder the lord mayor and lady mayoress without his golden chain.
 25203	On Northumberland and Lansdowne roads His Excellency acknowledged
 25204	punctually salutes from rare male walkers, the salute of two small
 25205	schoolboys at the garden gate of the house said to have been admired
 25206	by the late queen when visiting the Irish capital with her husband, the
 25207	prince consort, in 1849 and the salute of Almidano Artifoni's sturdy
 25208	trousers swallowed by a closing door.

 25334	Bronze by gold, miss Douce's head by miss Kennedy's head, over the
 25335	crossblind of the Ormond bar heard the viceregal hoofs go by, ringing
 25336	steel.
 25337	
 25338	--Is that her? asked miss Kennedy.
 25339	
 25340	Miss Douce said yes, sitting with his ex, pearl grey and _eau de Nil._
 25341	
 25342	--Exquisite contrast, miss Kennedy said.
 25343	
 25344	When all agog miss Douce said eagerly:
 25345	
 25346	--Look at the fellow in the tall silk.
 25347	
 25348	--Who? Where? gold asked more eagerly.
 25349	
 25350	--In the second carriage, miss Douce's wet lips said, laughing in the
 25351	sun.
 25352	
 25353	He's looking. Mind till I see.
 25354	
 25355	She darted, bronze, to the backmost corner, flattening her face against
 25356	the pane in a halo of hurried breath.
 25357	
 25358	Her wet lips tittered:
 25359	
 25360	--He's killed looking back.
 25361	
 25362	She laughed:
 25363	
 25364	--O wept! Aren't men frightful idiots?
 25365	
 25366	With sadness.
 25367	
 25368	Miss Kennedy sauntered sadly from bright light, twining a loose hair
 25369	behind an ear. Sauntering sadly, gold no more, she twisted twined a
 25370	hair.
 25371	
 25372	Sadly she twined in sauntering gold hair behind a curving ear.
 25373	
 25374	--It's them has the fine times, sadly then she said.
 25375	
 25376	A man.
 25377	
 25378	Bloowho went by by Moulang's pipes bearing in his breast the sweets
 25379	of sin, by Wine's antiques, in memory bearing sweet sinful words, by
 25380	Carroll's dusky battered plate, for Raoul.
 25381	
 25382	The boots to them, them in the bar, them barmaids came. For them
 25383	unheeding him he banged on the counter his tray of chattering china. And
 25384	
 25385	--There's your teas, he said.
 25386	
 25387	Miss Kennedy with manners transposed the teatray down to an upturned
 25388	lithia crate, safe from eyes, low.
 25389	
 25390	--What is it? loud boots unmannerly asked.
 25391	
 25392	--Find out, miss Douce retorted, leaving her spyingpoint.
 25393	
 25394	--Your _beau,_ is it?
 25395	
 25396	A haughty bronze replied:
 25397	
 25398	--I'll complain to Mrs de Massey on you if I hear any more of your
 25399	impertinent insolence.
 25400	
 25401	--Imperthnthn thnthnthn, bootssnout sniffed rudely, as he retreated as
 25402	she threatened as he had come.
 25403	
 25404	Bloom.
 25405	
 25406	On her flower frowning miss Douce said:
 25407	
 25408	--Most aggravating that young brat is. If he doesn't conduct himself
 25409	I'll wring his ear for him a yard long.
 25410	
 25411	Ladylike in exquisite contrast.
 25412	
 25413	--Take no notice, miss Kennedy rejoined.
 25414	
 25415	She poured in a teacup tea, then back in the teapot tea. They cowered
 25416	under their reef of counter, waiting on footstools, crates upturned,
 25417	waiting for their teas to draw. They pawed their blouses, both of black
 25418	satin, two and nine a yard, waiting for their teas to draw, and two and
 25419	seven.
 25420	
 25421	Yes, bronze from anear, by gold from afar, heard steel from anear, hoofs
 25422	ring from afar, and heard steelhoofs ringhoof ringsteel.
 25423	
 25424	--Am I awfully sunburnt?
 25425	
 25426	Miss bronze unbloused her neck.
 25427	
 25428	--No, said miss Kennedy. It gets brown after. Did you try the borax with
 25429	the cherry laurel water?
 25430	
 25431	Miss Douce halfstood to see her skin askance in the barmirror
 25432	gildedlettered where hock and claret glasses shimmered and in their
 25433	midst a shell.
 25434	
 25435	--And leave it to my hands, she said.
 25436	
 25437	--Try it with the glycerine, miss Kennedy advised.
 25438	
 25439	Bidding her neck and hands adieu miss Douce
 25440	
 25441	--Those things only bring out a rash, replied, reseated. I asked that
 25442	old fogey in Boyd's for something for my skin.
 25443	
 25444	Miss Kennedy, pouring now a fulldrawn tea, grimaced and prayed:
 25445	
 25446	--O, don't remind me of him for mercy' sake!
 25447	
 25448	--But wait till I tell you, miss Douce entreated.
 25449	
 25450	Sweet tea miss Kennedy having poured with milk plugged both two ears
 25451	with little fingers.
 25452	
 25453	--No, don't, she cried.
 25454	
 25455	--I won't listen, she cried.
 25456	
 25457	But Bloom?
 25458	
 25459	Miss Douce grunted in snuffy fogey's tone:
 25460	
 25461	--For your what? says he.
 25462	
 25463	Miss Kennedy unplugged her ears to hear, to speak: but said, but prayed
 25464	again:
 25465	
 25466	--Don't let me think of him or I'll expire. The hideous old wretch! That
 25467	night in the Antient Concert Rooms.
 25468	
 25469	She sipped distastefully her brew, hot tea, a sip, sipped, sweet tea.
 25470	
 25471	--Here he was, miss Douce said, cocking her bronze head three quarters,
 25472	ruffling her nosewings. Hufa! Hufa!
 25473	
 25474	Shrill shriek of laughter sprang from miss Kennedy's throat. Miss Douce
 25475	huffed and snorted down her nostrils that quivered imperthnthn like a
 25476	snout in quest.
 25477	
 25478	--O! shrieking, miss Kennedy cried. Will you ever forget his goggle eye?
 25479	
 25480	Miss Douce chimed in in deep bronze laughter, shouting:
 25481	
 25482	--And your other eye!
 25483	
 25484	Bloowhose dark eye read Aaron Figatner's name. Why do I always think
 25485	Figather? Gathering figs, I think. And Prosper Lore's huguenot name.
 25486	By Bassi's blessed virgins Bloom's dark eyes went by. Bluerobed, white
 25487	under, come to me. God they believe she is: or goddess. Those today. I
 25488	could not see. That fellow spoke. A student. After with Dedalus' son.
 25489	He might be Mulligan. All comely virgins. That brings those rakes of
 25490	fellows in: her white.
 25491	
 25492	By went his eyes. The sweets of sin. Sweet are the sweets.
 25493	
 25494	Of sin.
 25495	
 25496	In a giggling peal young goldbronze voices blended, Douce with Kennedy
 25497	your other eye. They threw young heads back, bronze gigglegold, to let
 25498	freefly their laughter, screaming, your other, signals to each other,
 25499	high piercing notes.
 25500	
 25501	Ah, panting, sighing, sighing, ah, fordone, their mirth died down.
 25502	
 25503	Miss Kennedy lipped her cup again, raised, drank a sip and
 25504	gigglegiggled. Miss Douce, bending over the teatray, ruffled again her
 25505	nose and rolled droll fattened eyes. Again Kennygiggles, stooping,
 25506	her fair pinnacles of hair, stooping, her tortoise napecomb showed,
 25507	spluttered out of her mouth her tea, choking in tea and laughter,
 25508	coughing with choking, crying:
 25509	
 25510	--O greasy eyes! Imagine being married to a man like that! she cried.
 25511	With his bit of beard!
 25512	
 25513	Douce gave full vent to a splendid yell, a full yell of full woman,
 25514	delight, joy, indignation.
 25515	
 25516	--Married to the greasy nose! she yelled.
 25517	
 25518	Shrill, with deep laughter, after, gold after bronze, they urged each
 25519	each to peal after peal, ringing in changes, bronzegold, goldbronze,
 25520	shrilldeep, to laughter after laughter. And then laughed more. Greasy I
 25521	knows. Exhausted, breathless, their shaken heads they laid, braided and
 25522	pinnacled by glossycombed, against the counterledge. All flushed (O!),
 25523	panting, sweating (O!), all breathless.
 25524	
 25525	Married to Bloom, to greaseabloom.
 25526	
 25527	--O saints above! miss Douce said, sighed above her jumping rose. I
 25528	wished
 25529	
 25530	I hadn't laughed so much. I feel all wet.
 25531	
 25532	--O, miss Douce! miss Kennedy protested. You horrid thing!
 25533	
 25534	And flushed yet more (you horrid!), more goldenly.
 25535	
 25536	By Cantwell's offices roved Greaseabloom, by Ceppi's virgins, bright of
 25537	their oils. Nannetti's father hawked those things about, wheedling at
 25538	doors as I. Religion pays. Must see him for that par. Eat first. I want.
 25539	Not yet. At four, she said. Time ever passing. Clockhands turning. On.
 25540	Where eat? The Clarence, Dolphin. On. For Raoul. Eat. If I net five
 25541	guineas with those ads. The violet silk petticoats. Not yet. The sweets
 25542	of sin.
 25543	
 25544	Flushed less, still less, goldenly paled.
 25545	
 25546	Into their bar strolled Mr Dedalus. Chips, picking chips off one of his
 25547	rocky thumbnails. Chips. He strolled.
 25548	
 25549	--O, welcome back, miss Douce.
 25550	
 25551	He held her hand. Enjoyed her holidays?
 25552	
 25553	--Tiptop.
 25554	
 25555	He hoped she had nice weather in Rostrevor.
 25556	
 25557	--Gorgeous, she said. Look at the holy show I am. Lying out on the
 25558	strand all day.
 25559	
 25560	Bronze whiteness.
 25561	
 25562	--That was exceedingly naughty of you, Mr Dedalus told her and pressed
 25563	her hand indulgently. Tempting poor simple males.
 25564	
 25565	Miss Douce of satin douced her arm away.
 25566	
 25567	--O go away! she said. You're very simple, I don't think.
 25568	
 25569	He was.
 25570	
 25571	--Well now I am, he mused. I looked so simple in the cradle they
 25572	christened me simple Simon.
 25573	
 25574	--You must have been a doaty, miss Douce made answer. And what did the
 25575	doctor order today?
 25576	
 25577	--Well now, he mused, whatever you say yourself. I think I'll trouble
 25578	you for some fresh water and a half glass of whisky.
 25579	
 25580	Jingle.
 25581	
 25582	--With the greatest alacrity, miss Douce agreed.
 25583	
 25584	With grace of alacrity towards the mirror gilt Cantrell and Cochrane's
 25585	she turned herself. With grace she tapped a measure of gold whisky from
 25586	her crystal keg. Forth from the skirt of his coat Mr Dedalus brought
 25587	pouch and pipe. Alacrity she served. He blew through the flue two husky
 25588	fifenotes.
 25589	
 25590	--By Jove, he mused, I often wanted to see the Mourne mountains. Must
 25591	be a great tonic in the air down there. But a long threatening comes at
 25592	last, they say. Yes. Yes.
 25593	
 25594	Yes. He fingered shreds of hair, her maidenhair, her mermaid's, into the
 25595	bowl. Chips. Shreds. Musing. Mute.
 25596	
 25597	None nought said nothing. Yes.
 25598	
 25599	Gaily miss Douce polished a tumbler, trilling:
 25600	
 25601	--_O, Idolores, queen of the eastern seas!_
 25602	
 25603	--Was Mr Lidwell in today?
 25604	
 25605	In came Lenehan. Round him peered Lenehan. Mr Bloom reached Essex
 25606	bridge. Yes, Mr Bloom crossed bridge of Yessex. To Martha I must write.
 25607	Buy paper. Daly's. Girl there civil. Bloom. Old Bloom. Blue bloom is on
 25608	the rye.
 25609	
 25610	--He was in at lunchtime, miss Douce said.
 25611	
 25612	Lenehan came forward.
 25613	
 25614	--Was Mr Boylan looking for me?
 25615	
 25616	He asked. She answered:
 25617	
 25618	--Miss Kennedy, was Mr Boylan in while I was upstairs?
 25619	
 25620	She asked. Miss voice of Kennedy answered, a second teacup poised, her
 25621	gaze upon a page:
 25622	
 25623	--No. He was not.
 25624	
 25625	Miss gaze of Kennedy, heard, not seen, read on. Lenehan round the
 25626	sandwichbell wound his round body round.
 25627	
 25628	--Peep! Who's in the corner?
 25629	
 25630	No glance of Kennedy rewarding him he yet made overtures. To mind her
 25631	stops. To read only the black ones: round o and crooked ess.
 25632	
 25633	Jingle jaunty jingle.
 25634	
 25635	Girlgold she read and did not glance. Take no notice. She took no notice
 25636	while he read by rote a solfa fable for her, plappering flatly:
 25637	
 25638	--Ah fox met ah stork. Said thee fox too thee stork: Will you put your
 25639	bill down inn my troath and pull upp ah bone?
 25640	
 25641	He droned in vain. Miss Douce turned to her tea aside.
 25642	
 25643	He sighed aside:
 25644	
 25645	--Ah me! O my!
 25646	
 25647	He greeted Mr Dedalus and got a nod.
 25648	
 25649	--Greetings from the famous son of a famous father.
 25650	
 25651	--Who may he be? Mr Dedalus asked.
 25652	
 25653	Lenehan opened most genial arms. Who?
 25654	
 25655	--Who may he be? he asked. Can you ask? Stephen, the youthful bard.
 25656	
 25657	Dry.
 25658	
 25659	Mr Dedalus, famous father, laid by his dry filled pipe.
 25660	
 25661	--I see, he said. I didn't recognise him for the moment. I hear he is
 25662	keeping very select company. Have you seen him lately?
 25663	
 25664	He had.
 25665	
 25666	--I quaffed the nectarbowl with him this very day, said Lenehan. In
 25667	Mooney's _en ville_ and in Mooney's _sur mer._ He had received the rhino
 25668	for the labour of his muse.
 25669	
 25670	He smiled at bronze's teabathed lips, at listening lips and eyes:
 25671	
 25672	--The _Ã©lite_ of Erin hung upon his lips. The ponderous pundit, Hugh
 25673	
 25674	MacHugh, Dublin's most brilliant scribe and editor and that minstrel boy
 25675	of the wild wet west who is known by the euphonious appellation of the
 25676	O'Madden Burke.
 25677	
 25678	After an interval Mr Dedalus raised his grog and
 25679	
 25680	--That must have been highly diverting, said he. I see.
 25681	
 25682	He see. He drank. With faraway mourning mountain eye. Set down his
 25683	glass.
 25684	
 25685	He looked towards the saloon door.
 25686	
 25687	--I see you have moved the piano.
 25688	
 25689	--The tuner was in today, miss Douce replied, tuning it for the smoking
 25690	concert and I never heard such an exquisite player.
 25691	
 25692	--Is that a fact?
 25693	
 25694	--Didn't he, miss Kennedy? The real classical, you know. And blind too,
 25695	poor fellow. Not twenty I'm sure he was.
 25696	
 25697	--Is that a fact? Mr Dedalus said.
 25698	
 25699	He drank and strayed away.
 25700	
 25701	--So sad to look at his face, miss Douce condoled.
 25702	
 25703	God's curse on bitch's bastard.
 25704	
 25705	Tink to her pity cried a diner's bell. To the door of the bar and
 25706	diningroom came bald Pat, came bothered Pat, came Pat, waiter of Ormond.
 25707	Lager for diner. Lager without alacrity she served.
 25708	
 25709	With patience Lenehan waited for Boylan with impatience, for
 25710	jinglejaunty blazes boy.
 25711	
 25712	Upholding the lid he (who?) gazed in the coffin (coffin?) at the oblique
 25713	triple (piano!) wires. He pressed (the same who pressed indulgently her
 25714	hand), soft pedalling, a triple of keys to see the thicknesses of felt
 25715	advancing, to hear the muffled hammerfall in action.
 25716	
 25717	Two sheets cream vellum paper one reserve two envelopes when I was in
 25718	Wisdom Hely's wise Bloom in Daly's Henry Flower bought. Are you not
 25719	happy in your home? Flower to console me and a pin cuts lo. Means
 25720	something, language of flow. Was it a daisy? Innocence that is.
 25721	Respectable girl meet after mass. Thanks awfully muchly. Wise Bloom eyed
 25722	on the door a poster, a swaying mermaid smoking mid nice waves. Smoke
 25723	mermaids, coolest whiff of all. Hair streaming: lovelorn. For some man.
 25724	For Raoul. He eyed and saw afar on Essex bridge a gay hat riding on a
 25725	jaunting car. It is. Again. Third time. Coincidence.
 25726	
 25727	Jingling on supple rubbers it jaunted from the bridge to Ormond quay.
 25728	Follow. Risk it. Go quick. At four. Near now. Out.
 25729

 25733

 25735

 25737	Ternoon. Think you're the only pebble on the beach? Does that to all.
 25738	
 25739	For men.
 25740	
 25741	In drowsy silence gold bent on her page.
 25742	
 25743	From the saloon a call came, long in dying. That was a tuningfork the
 25744	tuner had that he forgot that he now struck. A call again. That he now
 25745	poised that it now throbbed. You hear? It throbbed, pure, purer, softly
 25746	and softlier, its buzzing prongs. Longer in dying call.
 25747	
 25748	Pat paid for diner's popcorked bottle: and over tumbler, tray and
 25749	popcorked bottle ere he went he whispered, bald and bothered, with miss
 25750	
 25751	Douce.
 25752	
 25753	--_The bright stars fade_...
 25754	
 25755	A voiceless song sang from within, singing:
 25756	
 25757	--... _the morn is breaking._
 25758	
 25759	A duodene of birdnotes chirruped bright treble answer under sensitive
 25760	hands. Brightly the keys, all twinkling, linked, all harpsichording,
 25761	called to a voice to sing the strain of dewy morn, of youth, of love's
 25762	leavetaking, life's, love's morn.

 25774

 25780	
 25781	Like lady, ladylike.
 25782

 25801	Smart Boylan bespoke potions.

 25948	
 25949	--How do you do, Mr Dollard?

 25951	--Eh? How do? How do? Ben Dollard's vague bass answered, turning an
 25952	instant from Father Cowley's woe. He won't give you any trouble, Bob.
 25953	Alf Bergan will speak to the long fellow. We'll put a barleystraw in
 25954	that Judas Iscariot's ear this time.
 25955	
 25956	Sighing Mr Dedalus came through the saloon, a finger soothing an eyelid.
 25957

 25959	ditty. We heard the piano.
 25960	
 25961	Bald Pat, bothered waiter, waited for drink orders. Power for Richie.
 25962	And Bloom? Let me see. Not make him walk twice. His corns. Four now. How
 25963	warm this black is. Course nerves a bit. Refracts (is it?) heat. Let me
 25964	see. Cider. Yes, bottle of cider.

 25985	Miss Douce's brave eyes, unregarded, turned from the crossblind, smitten

 25993	--Poor old Goodwin was the pianist that night, Father Cowley reminded

 25998	
 25999	--A symposium all his own, Mr Dedalus said. The devil wouldn't stop him.
 26000	He was a crotchety old fellow in the primary stage of drink.
 26001

 26003	punished keyboard. And by Japers I had no wedding garment.

 26013

 26015

 26020	Tight trou. Brilliant ide.
 26021	
 26022	--I knew he was on the rocks, he said. The wife was playing the piano in
 26023	the coffee palace on Saturdays for a very trifling consideration and
 26024	who was it gave me the wheeze she was doing the other business? Do you
 26025	remember? We had to search all Holles street to find them till the
 26026	chap in Keogh's gave us the number. Remember? Ben remembered, his broad
 26027	visage wondering.

 26032

 26111	
 26112	Miss Kennedy served two gentlemen with tankards of cool stout. She
 26113	passed a remark. It was indeed, first gentleman said, beautiful weather.
 26114	They drank cool stout. Did she know where the lord lieutenant was going?
 26115	And heard steelhoofs ringhoof ring. No, she couldn't say. But it would
 26116	be in the paper. O, she need not trouble. No trouble. She waved about

 26119	first gentleman said. O, not in the least. Way he looked that. Lord
 26120	lieutenant. Gold by bronze heard iron steel.

 26124	
 26125	In liver gravy Bloom mashed mashed potatoes. Love and War someone is.
 26126	Ben Dollard's famous. Night he ran round to us to borrow a dress suit
 26127	for that concert. Trousers tight as a drum on him. Musical porkers.
 26128	Molly did laugh when he went out. Threw herself back across the bed,
 26129	screaming, kicking. With all his belongings on show. O saints above,
 26130	I'm drenched! O, the women in the front row! O, I never laughed so many!
 26131	Well, of course that's what gives him the base barreltone. For instance
 26132	eunuchs. Wonder who's playing. Nice touch. Must be Cowley. Musical.
 26133	Knows whatever note you play. Bad breath he has, poor chap. Stopped.

 26147	Best value in Dub.
 26148	
 26149	Piano again. Cowley it is. Way he sits in to it, like one together,
 26150	mutual understanding. Tiresome shapers scraping fiddles, eye on the
 26151	bowend, sawing the cello, remind you of toothache. Her high long snore.
 26152	Night we were in the box. Trombone under blowing like a grampus, between
 26153	the acts, other brass chap unscrewing, emptying spittle. Conductor's
 26154	legs too, bagstrousers, jiggedy jiggedy. Do right to hide them.
 26155	
 26156	Jiggedy jingle jaunty jaunty.
 26157	
 26158	Only the harp. Lovely. Gold glowering light. Girl touched it. Poop of a
 26159	lovely. Gravy's rather good fit for a. Golden ship. Erin. The harp that

 26163	--Ah, I couldn't, man, Mr Dedalus said, shy, listless.
 26164	
 26165	Strongly.
 26166	
 26167	--Go on, blast you! Ben Dollard growled. Get it out in bits.
 26168	
 26169	--_M'appari,_ Simon, Father Cowley said.
 26170	
 26171	Down stage he strode some paces, grave, tall in affliction, his long
 26172	arms outheld. Hoarsely the apple of his throat hoarsed softly. Softly he
 26173	sang to a dusty seascape there: _A Last Farewell._ A headland, a ship, a
 26174	sail upon the billows. Farewell. A lovely girl, her veil awave upon the

 26183	wind, love, speeding sail, return.
 26184	
 26185	--Go on, Simon.
 26186	
 26187	--Ah, sure, my dancing days are done, Ben... Well...
 26188	
 26189	Mr Dedalus laid his pipe to rest beside the tuningfork and, sitting,
 26190	touched the obedient keys.
 26191	
 26192	--No, Simon, Father Cowley turned. Play it in the original. One flat.
 26193	
 26194	The keys, obedient, rose higher, told, faltered, confessed, confused.
 26195	
 26196	Up stage strode Father Cowley.
 26197	
 26198	--Here, Simon, I'll accompany you, he said. Get up.
 26199	
 26200	By Graham Lemon's pineapple rock, by Elvery's elephant jingly jogged.
 26201	Steak, kidney, liver, mashed, at meat fit for princes sat princes Bloom
 26202	and Goulding. Princes at meat they raised and drank, Power and cider.
 26203	
 26204	Most beautiful tenor air ever written, Richie said: _Sonnambula._ He
 26205	heard Joe Maas sing that one night. Ah, what M'Guckin! Yes. In his way.
 26206	Choirboy style. Maas was the boy. Massboy. A lyrical tenor if you like.
 26207	Never forget it. Never.
 26208	
 26209	Tenderly Bloom over liverless bacon saw the tightened features strain.
 26210	Backache he. Bright's bright eye. Next item on the programme. Paying the
 26211	piper. Pills, pounded bread, worth a guinea a box. Stave it off awhile.
 26212	Sings too: _Down among the dead men._ Appropriate. Kidney pie. Sweets to
 26213	the. Not making much hand of it. Best value in. Characteristic of him.
 26214	Power. Particular about his drink. Flaw in the glass, fresh Vartry
 26215	water. Fecking matches from counters to save. Then squander a sovereign
 26216	in dribs and drabs. And when he's wanted not a farthing. Screwed
 26217	refusing to pay his fare. Curious types.
 26218	
 26219	Never would Richie forget that night. As long as he lived: never. In the
 26220	gods of the old Royal with little Peake. And when the first note.
 26221	
 26222	Speech paused on Richie's lips.
 26223	
 26224	Coming out with a whopper now. Rhapsodies about damn all.
 26225	
 26226	Believes his own lies. Does really. Wonderful liar. But want a good
 26227	memory.
 26228	
 26229	--Which air is that? asked Leopold Bloom.
 26230	
 26231	--_All is lost now_.
 26232	
 26233	Richie cocked his lips apout. A low incipient note sweet banshee
 26234	murmured: all. A thrush. A throstle. His breath, birdsweet, good teeth
 26235	he's proud of, fluted with plaintive woe. Is lost. Rich sound. Two
 26236	notes in one there. Blackbird I heard in the hawthorn valley. Taking my
 26237	motives he twined and turned them. All most too new call is lost in all.
 26238	Echo. How sweet the answer. How is that done? All lost now. Mournful he
 26239	whistled. Fall, surrender, lost.
 26240	
 26241	Bloom bent leopold ear, turning a fringe of doyley down under the vase.
 26242	Order. Yes, I remember. Lovely air. In sleep she went to him. Innocence
 26243	in the moon. Brave. Don't know their danger. Still hold her back. Call
 26244	name. Touch water. Jingle jaunty. Too late. She longed to go. That's
 26245	why. Woman. As easy stop the sea. Yes: all is lost.
 26246	
 26247	--A beautiful air, said Bloom lost Leopold. I know it well.
 26248	
 26249	Never in all his life had Richie Goulding.
 26250	
 26251	He knows it well too. Or he feels. Still harping on his daughter. Wise
 26252	child that knows her father, Dedalus said. Me?
 26253	
 26254	Bloom askance over liverless saw. Face of the all is lost. Rollicking
 26255	Richie once. Jokes old stale now. Wagging his ear. Napkinring in his
 26256	eye. Now begging letters he sends his son with. Crosseyed Walter sir I
 26257	did sir. Wouldn't trouble only I was expecting some money. Apologise.
 26258	
 26259	Piano again. Sounds better than last time I heard. Tuned probably.
 26260	Stopped again.
 26261	
 26262	Dollard and Cowley still urged the lingering singer out with it.
 26263	
 26264	--With it, Simon.
 26265	
 26266	--It, Simon.
 26267	
 26268	--Ladies and gentlemen, I am most deeply obliged by your kind
 26269	solicitations.
 26270	
 26271	--It, Simon.
 26272	
 26273	--I have no money but if you will lend me your attention I shall
 26274	endeavour to sing to you of a heart bowed down.
 26275	
 26276	By the sandwichbell in screening shadow Lydia, her bronze and rose, a
 26277	lady's grace, gave and withheld: as in cool glaucous _eau de Nil_ Mina
 26278	to tankards two her pinnacles of gold.
 26279	
 26280	The harping chords of prelude closed. A chord, longdrawn, expectant,
 26281	drew a voice away.
 26282	
 26283	--_When first I saw that form endearing_...
 26284	
 26285	Richie turned.
 26286	
 26287	--Si Dedalus' voice, he said.
 26288	
 26289	Braintipped, cheek touched with flame, they listened feeling that flow
 26290	endearing flow over skin limbs human heart soul spine. Bloom signed to
 26291	Pat, bald Pat is a waiter hard of hearing, to set ajar the door of the
 26292	bar. The door of the bar. So. That will do. Pat, waiter, waited, waiting
 26293	to hear, for he was hard of hear by the door.
 26294	
 26295	--_Sorrow from me seemed to depart._
 26296	
 26297	Through the hush of air a voice sang to them, low, not rain, not leaves
 26298	in murmur, like no voice of strings or reeds or whatdoyoucallthem
 26299	dulcimers touching their still ears with words, still hearts of their
 26300	each his remembered lives. Good, good to hear: sorrow from them each
 26301	seemed to from both depart when first they heard. When first they saw,
 26302	lost Richie Poldy, mercy of beauty, heard from a person wouldn't expect
 26303	it in the least, her first merciful lovesoft oftloved word.
 26304	
 26305	Love that is singing: love's old sweet song. Bloom unwound slowly the
 26306	elastic band of his packet. Love's old sweet _sonnez la_ gold. Bloom
 26307	wound a skein round four forkfingers, stretched it, relaxed, and wound
 26308	it round his troubled double, fourfold, in octave, gyved them fast.
 26309	
 26310	--_Full of hope and all delighted_...
 26311	
 26312	Tenors get women by the score. Increase their flow. Throw flower at his
 26313	feet. When will we meet? My head it simply. Jingle all delighted. He
 26314	can't sing for tall hats. Your head it simply swurls. Perfumed for him.
 26315	What perfume does your wife? I want to know. Jing. Stop. Knock. Last
 26316	look at mirror always before she answers the door. The hall. There? How
 26317	do you? I do well. There? What? Or? Phial of cachous, kissing comfits,
 26318	in her satchel. Yes? Hands felt for the opulent.
 26319	
 26320	Alas the voice rose, sighing, changed: loud, full, shining, proud.
 26321	
 26322	--_But alas, 'twas idle dreaming_...
 26323	
 26324	Glorious tone he has still. Cork air softer also their brogue. Silly
 26325	man! Could have made oceans of money. Singing wrong words. Wore out
 26326	his wife: now sings. But hard to tell. Only the two themselves. If he
 26327	doesn't break down. Keep a trot for the avenue. His hands and feet sing
 26328	too. Drink. Nerves overstrung. Must be abstemious to sing. Jenny Lind
 26329	soup: stock, sage, raw eggs, half pint of cream. For creamy dreamy.
 26330	
 26331	Tenderness it welled: slow, swelling, full it throbbed. That's the chat.
 26332	Ha, give! Take! Throb, a throb, a pulsing proud erect.
 26333	
 26334	Words? Music? No: it's what's behind.
 26335	
 26336	Bloom looped, unlooped, noded, disnoded.
 26337	
 26338	Bloom. Flood of warm jamjam lickitup secretness flowed to flow in music
 26339	out, in desire, dark to lick flow invading. Tipping her tepping her
 26340	tapping her topping her. Tup. Pores to dilate dilating. Tup. The joy
 26341	the feel the warm the. Tup. To pour o'er sluices pouring gushes. Flood,
 26342	gush, flow, joygush, tupthrob. Now! Language of love.
 26343

 26348	
 26349	_Martha_ it is. Coincidence. Just going to write. Lionel's song.
 26350	Lovely name you have. Can't write. Accept my little pres. Play on her
 26351	heartstrings pursestrings too. She's a. I called you naughty boy. Still
 26352	the name: Martha. How strange! Today.
 26353	
 26354	The voice of Lionel returned, weaker but unwearied. It sang again to
 26355	Richie Poldy Lydia Lidwell also sang to Pat open mouth ear waiting to
 26356	wait. How first he saw that form endearing, how sorrow seemed to part,

 26358	
 26359	Wish I could see his face, though. Explain better. Why the barber in
 26360	Drago's always looked my face when I spoke his face in the glass. Still
 26361	hear it better here than in the bar though farther.
 26362	
 26363	--_Each graceful look_...
 26364	
 26365	First night when first I saw her at Mat Dillon's in Terenure. Yellow,
 26366	black lace she wore. Musical chairs. We two the last. Fate. After her.
 26367	Fate.
 26368	
 26369	Round and round slow. Quick round. We two. All looked. Halt. Down she

 26372	--_Charmed my eye_...

 26374	Singing. _Waiting_ she sang. I turned her music. Full voice of perfume

 26377	eyes. Under a peartree alone patio this hour in old Madrid one side in

 26379	
 26380	--_Martha! Ah, Martha!_
 26381	
 26382	Quitting all languor Lionel cried in grief, in cry of passion dominant
 26383	to love to return with deepening yet with rising chords of harmony. In
 26384	cry of lionel loneliness that she should know, must martha feel. For
 26385	only her he waited. Where? Here there try there here all try where.

 26388	     --_Co-ome, thou lost one!
 26389	     Co-ome, thou dear one!_

 26392

 26394

 26437	
 26438	Admiring.
 26439	
 26440	Richie, admiring, descanted on that man's glorious voice. He remembered
 26441	one night long ago. Never forget that night. Si sang _'Twas rank and
 26442	fame_: in Ned Lambert's 'twas. Good God he never heard in all his life a
 26443	note like that he never did _then false one we had better part_ so clear
 26444	so God he never heard _since love lives not_ a clinking voice lives not
 26445	ask Lambert he can tell you too.

 26449	
 26450	He, Mr Bloom, listened while he, Richie Goulding, told him, Mr Bloom, of
 26451	the night he, Richie, heard him, Si Dedalus, sing 'TWAS RANK AND FAME in
 26452	his, Ned Lambert's, house.
 26453	
 26454	Brothers-in-law: relations. We never speak as we pass by. Rift in the
 26455	lute I think. Treats him with scorn. See. He admires him all the more.
 26456	The night Si sang. The human voice, two tiny silky chords, wonderful,
 26457	more than all others.
 26458	
 26459	That voice was a lamentation. Calmer now. It's in the silence after you
 26460	feel you hear. Vibrations. Now silent air.
 26461	
 26462	Bloom ungyved his crisscrossed hands and with slack fingers plucked the
 26463	slender catgut thong. He drew and plucked. It buzz, it twanged. While
 26464	Goulding talked of Barraclough's voice production, while Tom Kernan,
 26465	harking back in a retrospective sort of arrangement talked to listening
 26466	Father Cowley, who played a voluntary, who nodded as he played. While
 26467	big Ben Dollard talked with Simon Dedalus, lighting, who nodded as he
 26468	smoked, who smoked.
 26469	
 26470	Thou lost one. All songs on that theme. Yet more Bloom stretched his
 26471	string. Cruel it seems. Let people get fond of each other: lure them on.
 26472	Then tear asunder. Death. Explos. Knock on the head. Outtohelloutofthat.
 26473	Human life. Dignam. Ugh, that rat's tail wriggling! Five bob I gave.
 26474	_Corpus paradisum._ Corncrake croaker: belly like a poisoned pup. Gone.
 26475	They sing. Forgotten. I too; And one day she with. Leave her: get
 26476	tired. Suffer then. Snivel. Big spanishy eyes goggling at nothing. Her
 26477	wavyavyeavyheavyeavyevyevyhair un comb:'d.
 26478	
 26479	Yet too much happy bores. He stretched more, more. Are you not happy in
 26480	your? Twang. It snapped.

 26482	Jingle into Dorset street.
 26483	
 26484	Miss Douce withdrew her satiny arm, reproachful, pleased.
 26485	
 26486	--Don't make half so free, said she, till we are better acquainted.

 26488	George Lidwell told her really and truly: but she did not believe.

 26498	Better write it here. Quills in the postoffice chewed and twisted.
 26499	
 26500	Bald Pat at a sign drew nigh. A pen and ink. He went. A pad. He went. A
 26501	pad to blot. He heard, deaf Pat.
 26502	
 26503	--Yes, Mr Bloom said, teasing the curling catgut line. It certainly is.
 26504	Few lines will do. My present. All that Italian florid music is. Who
 26505	is this wrote? Know the name you know better. Take out sheet notepaper,
 26506	envelope: unconcerned. It's so characteristic.
 26507	
 26508	--Grandest number in the whole opera, Goulding said.
 26509	
 26510	--It is, Bloom said.
 26511	
 26512	Numbers it is. All music when you come to think. Two multiplied by two
 26513	divided by half is twice one. Vibrations: chords those are. One plus two
 26514	plus six is seven. Do anything you like with figures juggling. Always
 26515	find out this equal to that. Symmetry under a cemetery wall. He doesn't
 26516	see my mourning. Callous: all for his own gut. Musemathematics. And you
 26517	think you're listening to the etherial. But suppose you said it like:
 26518	Martha, seven times nine minus x is thirtyfive thousand. Fall quite
 26519	flat. It's on account of the sounds it is.
 26520	
 26521	Instance he's playing now. Improvising. Might be what you like, till you
 26522	hear the words. Want to listen sharp. Hard. Begin all right: then hear
 26523	chords a bit off: feel lost a bit. In and out of sacks, over barrels,
 26524	through wirefences, obstacle race. Time makes the tune. Question of mood
 26525	you're in. Still always nice to hear. Except scales up and down, girls
 26526	learning. Two together nextdoor neighbours. Ought to invent dummy pianos
 26527	for that. _Blumenlied_ I bought for her. The name. Playing it slow,
 26528	a girl, night I came home, the girl. Door of the stables near Cecilia
 26529	street. Milly no taste. Queer because we both, I mean.
 26530	
 26531	Bald deaf Pat brought quite flat pad ink. Pat set with ink pen quite
 26532	flat pad. Pat took plate dish knife fork. Pat went.
 26533	
 26534	It was the only language Mr Dedalus said to Ben. He heard them as a
 26535	boy in Ringabella, Crosshaven, Ringabella, singing their barcaroles.
 26536	Queenstown harbour full of Italian ships. Walking, you know, Ben, in the
 26537	moonlight with those earthquake hats. Blending their voices. God, such
 26538	music, Ben. Heard as a boy. Cross Ringabella haven mooncarole.
 26539	
 26540	Sour pipe removed he held a shield of hand beside his lips that cooed a
 26541	moonlight nightcall, clear from anear, a call from afar, replying.
 26542	
 26543	Down the edge of his _Freeman_ baton ranged Bloom's, your other eye,

 26545	Heigho! Heigho! Fawcett. Aha! Just I was looking...

 26547	Hope he's not looking, cute as a rat. He held unfurled his _Freeman._

 26568	found out. Card in my high grade ha. No, not tell all. Useless pain. If

 26630	seahorn that he, George Lidwell, solicitor, might hear.

 26632	--Listen! she bade him.
 26633	
 26634	Under Tom Kernan's ginhot words the accompanist wove music slow.
 26635	Authentic fact. How Walter Bapty lost his voice. Well, sir, the husband
 26636	took him by the throat. _Scoundrel,_ said he, _You'll sing no more
 26637	lovesongs._ He did, faith, sir Tom. Bob Cowley wove. Tenors get wom.
 26638	Cowley lay back.
 26639	
 26640	Ah, now he heard, she holding it to his ear. Hear! He heard.
 26641	
 26642	Wonderful. She held it to her own. And through the sifted light pale
 26643	gold in contrast glided. To hear.
 26644	
 26645	Tap.
 26646	
 26647	Bloom through the bardoor saw a shell held at their ears. He heard more
 26648	faintly that that they heard, each for herself alone, then each for
 26649	other, hearing the plash of waves, loudly, a silent roar.
 26650	
 26651	Bronze by a weary gold, anear, afar, they listened.
 26652	
 26653	Her ear too is a shell, the peeping lobe there. Been to the seaside.
 26654	Lovely seaside girls. Skin tanned raw. Should have put on coldcream
 26655	first make it brown. Buttered toast. O and that lotion mustn't forget.
 26656	Fever near her mouth. Your head it simply. Hair braided over: shell with
 26657	seaweed. Why do they hide their ears with seaweed hair? And Turks the
 26658	mouth, why? Her eyes over the sheet. Yashmak. Find the way in. A cave.
 26659	No admittance except on business.
 26660	
 26661	The sea they think they hear. Singing. A roar. The blood it is. Souse in
 26662	the ear sometimes. Well, it's a sea. Corpuscle islands.
 26663	
 26664	Wonderful really. So distinct. Again. George Lidwell held its murmur,
 26665	hearing: then laid it by, gently.
 26666	
 26667	--What are the wild waves saying? he asked her, smiled.
 26668	
 26669	Charming, seasmiling and unanswering Lydia on Lidwell smiled.
 26670	
 26671	Tap.
 26672	
 26673	By Larry O'Rourke's, by Larry, bold Larry O', Boylan swayed and Boylan
 26674	turned.
 26675	
 26676	From the forsaken shell miss Mina glided to her tankards waiting. No,
 26677	she was not so lonely archly miss Douce's head let Mr Lidwell know.
 26678	Walks in the moonlight by the sea. No, not alone. With whom? She nobly
 26679	answered: with a gentleman friend.
 26680	
 26681	Bob Cowley's twinkling fingers in the treble played again. The landlord
 26682	has the prior. A little time. Long John. Big Ben. Lightly he played a
 26683	light bright tinkling measure for tripping ladies, arch and smiling,
 26684	and for their gallants, gentlemen friends. One: one, one, one, one, one:
 26685	two, one, three, four.
 26686	
 26687	Sea, wind, leaves, thunder, waters, cows lowing, the cattlemarket,
 26688	cocks, hens don't crow, snakes hissss. There's music everywhere.
 26689	Ruttledge's door: ee creaking. No, that's noise. Minuet of _Don
 26690	Giovanni_ he's playing now. Court dresses of all descriptions in castle
 26691	chambers dancing. Misery. Peasants outside. Green starving faces eating
 26692	dockleaves. Nice that is. Look: look, look, look, look, look: you look
 26693	at us.
 26694	
 26695	That's joyful I can feel. Never have written it. Why? My joy is other
 26696	joy. But both are joys. Yes, joy it must be. Mere fact of music shows
 26697	you are. Often thought she was in the dumps till she began to lilt. Then
 26698	know.
 26699	
 26700	M'Coy valise. My wife and your wife. Squealing cat. Like tearing silk.
 26701	Tongue when she talks like the clapper of a bellows. They can't manage
 26702	men's intervals. Gap in their voices too. Fill me. I'm warm, dark, open.
 26703	Molly in _quis est homo_: Mercadante. My ear against the wall to hear.
 26704	Want a woman who can deliver the goods.
 26705	
 26706	Jog jig jogged stopped. Dandy tan shoe of dandy Boylan socks skyblue
 26707	clocks came light to earth.
 26708	
 26709	O, look we are so! Chamber music. Could make a kind of pun on that.
 26710	It is a kind of music I often thought when she. Acoustics that is.
 26711	Tinkling. Empty vessels make most noise. Because the acoustics, the
 26712	resonance changes according as the weight of the water is equal to
 26713	the law of falling water. Like those rhapsodies of Liszt's, Hungarian,
 26714	gipsyeyed. Pearls. Drops. Rain. Diddleiddle addleaddle ooddleooddle.
 26715	Hissss. Now. Maybe now. Before.
 26716	
 26717	One rapped on a door, one tapped with a knock, did he knock Paul de Kock
 26718	with a loud proud knocker with a cock carracarracarra cock. Cockcock.
 26719	
 26720	Tap.
 26721	
 26722	--_Qui sdegno,_ Ben, said Father Cowley.
 26723	
 26724	--No, Ben, Tom Kernan interfered. _The Croppy Boy._ Our native Doric.
 26725	
 26726	--Ay do, Ben, Mr Dedalus said. Good men and true.
 26727	
 26728	--Do, do, they begged in one.
 26729	
 26730	I'll go. Here, Pat, return. Come. He came, he came, he did not stay. To
 26731	me. How much?
 26732	
 26733	--What key? Six sharps?
 26734	
 26735	--F sharp major, Ben Dollard said.
 26736	
 26737	Bob Cowley's outstretched talons griped the black deepsounding chords.
 26738	
 26739	Must go prince Bloom told Richie prince. No, Richie said. Yes, must. Got
 26740	money somewhere. He's on for a razzle backache spree. Much? He seehears
 26741	lipspeech. One and nine. Penny for yourself. Here. Give him twopence
 26742	tip. Deaf, bothered. But perhaps he has wife and family waiting, waiting
 26743	Patty come home. Hee hee hee hee. Deaf wait while they wait.
 26744	
 26745	But wait. But hear. Chords dark. Lugugugubrious. Low. In a cave of the
 26746	dark middle earth. Embedded ore. Lumpmusic.
 26747	
 26748	The voice of dark age, of unlove, earth's fatigue made grave approach
 26749	and painful, come from afar, from hoary mountains, called on good men
 26750	and true. The priest he sought. With him would he speak a word.
 26751	
 26752	Tap.
 26753	
 26754	Ben Dollard's voice. Base barreltone. Doing his level best to say it.
 26755	Croak of vast manless moonless womoonless marsh. Other comedown. Big
 26756	ships' chandler's business he did once. Remember: rosiny ropes, ships'
 26757	lanterns. Failed to the tune of ten thousand pounds. Now in the Iveagh
