 26758	home. Cubicle number so and so. Number one Bass did that for him.
 26759	
 26760	The priest's at home. A false priest's servant bade him welcome. Step
 26761	in. The holy father. With bows a traitor servant. Curlycues of chords.
 26762	
 26763	Ruin them. Wreck their lives. Then build them cubicles to end their days
 26764	in. Hushaby. Lullaby. Die, dog. Little dog, die.
 26765	
 26766	The voice of warning, solemn warning, told them the youth had entered
 26767	a lonely hall, told them how solemn fell his footsteps there, told them
 26768	the gloomy chamber, the vested priest sitting to shrive.
 26769	
 26770	Decent soul. Bit addled now. Thinks he'll win in _Answers,_ poets'
 26771	picture puzzle. We hand you crisp five pound note. Bird sitting hatching
 26772	in a nest. Lay of the last minstrel he thought it was. See blank tee
 26773	what domestic animal? Tee dash ar most courageous mariner. Good voice he
 26774	has still. No eunuch yet with all his belongings.
 26775	
 26776	Listen. Bloom listened. Richie Goulding listened. And by the door deaf
 26777	Pat, bald Pat, tipped Pat, listened. The chords harped slower.
 26778	
 26779	The voice of penance and of grief came slow, embellished, tremulous.
 26780	Ben's contrite beard confessed. _in nomine Domini,_ in God's name he
 26781	knelt. He beat his hand upon his breast, confessing: _mea culpa._
 26782	
 26783	Latin again. That holds them like birdlime. Priest with the communion
 26784	corpus for those women. Chap in the mortuary, coffin or coffey,
 26785	_corpusnomine._ Wonder where that rat is by now. Scrape.
 26786	
 26787	Tap.
 26788	
 26789	They listened. Tankards and miss Kennedy. George Lidwell, eyelid well
 26790	expressive, fullbusted satin. Kernan. Si.
 26791	
 26792	The sighing voice of sorrow sang. His sins. Since Easter he had cursed
 26793	three times. You bitch's bast. And once at masstime he had gone to play.
 26794	Once by the churchyard he had passed and for his mother's rest he had
 26795	not prayed. A boy. A croppy boy.
 26796	
 26797	Bronze, listening, by the beerpull gazed far away. Soulfully. Doesn't
 26798	half know I'm. Molly great dab at seeing anyone looking.
 26799	
 26800	Bronze gazed far sideways. Mirror there. Is that best side of her face?
 26801	They always know. Knock at the door. Last tip to titivate.
 26802	
 26803	Cockcarracarra.
 26804	
 26805	What do they think when they hear music? Way to catch rattlesnakes.
 26806	Night Michael Gunn gave us the box. Tuning up. Shah of Persia liked
 26807	that best. Remind him of home sweet home. Wiped his nose in curtain too.
 26808	Custom his country perhaps. That's music too. Not as bad as it sounds.
 26809	Tootling. Brasses braying asses through uptrunks. Doublebasses helpless,
 26810	gashes in their sides. Woodwinds mooing cows. Semigrand open crocodile
 26811	music hath jaws. Woodwind like Goodwin's name.
 26812	
 26813	She looked fine. Her crocus dress she wore lowcut, belongings on show.
 26814	Clove her breath was always in theatre when she bent to ask a question.
 26815	Told her what Spinoza says in that book of poor papa's. Hypnotised,
 26816	listening. Eyes like that. She bent. Chap in dresscircle staring down
 26817	into her with his operaglass for all he was worth. Beauty of music you
 26818	must hear twice. Nature woman half a look. God made the country man the
 26819	tune. Met him pike hoses. Philosophy. O rocks!
 26820	
 26821	All gone. All fallen. At the siege of Ross his father, at Gorey all his
 26822	brothers fell. To Wexford, we are the boys of Wexford, he would. Last of
 26823	his name and race.
 26824	
 26825	I too. Last of my race. Milly young student. Well, my fault perhaps. No
 26826	son. Rudy. Too late now. Or if not? If not? If still?
 26827	
 26828	He bore no hate.
 26829	
 26830	Hate. Love. Those are names. Rudy. Soon I am old. Big Ben his voice
 26831	unfolded. Great voice Richie Goulding said, a flush struggling in his
 26832	pale, to Bloom soon old. But when was young?
 26833	
 26834	Ireland comes now. My country above the king. She listens. Who fears to
 26835	speak of nineteen four? Time to be shoving. Looked enough.
 26836	
 26837	--_Bless me, father,_ Dollard the croppy cried. _Bless me and let me
 26838	go._
 26839	
 26840	Tap.
 26841	
 26842	Bloom looked, unblessed to go. Got up to kill: on eighteen bob a week.
 26843	Fellows shell out the dibs. Want to keep your weathereye open. Those
 26844	girls, those lovely. By the sad sea waves. Chorusgirl's romance. Letters
 26845	read out for breach of promise. From Chickabiddy's owny Mumpsypum.
 26846	Laughter in court. Henry. I never signed it. The lovely name you.
 26847	
 26848	Low sank the music, air and words. Then hastened. The false priest
 26849	rustling soldier from his cassock. A yeoman captain. They know it all by
 26850	heart. The thrill they itch for. Yeoman cap.
 26851	
 26852	Tap. Tap.
 26853	
 26854	Thrilled she listened, bending in sympathy to hear.
 26855	
 26856	Blank face. Virgin should say: or fingered only. Write something on it:
 26857	page. If not what becomes of them? Decline, despair. Keeps them young.
 26858	Even admire themselves. See. Play on her. Lip blow. Body of white woman,
 26859	a flute alive. Blow gentle. Loud. Three holes, all women. Goddess I
 26860	didn't see. They want it. Not too much polite. That's why he gets them.
 26861	Gold in your pocket, brass in your face. Say something. Make her hear.
 26862	With look to look. Songs without words. Molly, that hurdygurdy boy.
 26863	She knew he meant the monkey was sick. Or because so like the Spanish.
 26864	Understand animals too that way. Solomon did. Gift of nature.
 26865	
 26866	Ventriloquise. My lips closed. Think in my stom. What?
 26867	
 26868	Will? You? I. Want. You. To.
 26869	
 26870	With hoarse rude fury the yeoman cursed, swelling in apoplectic bitch's
 26871	bastard. A good thought, boy, to come. One hour's your time to live,
 26872	your last.
 26873	
 26874	Tap. Tap.
 26875	
 26876	Thrill now. Pity they feel. To wipe away a tear for martyrs that want
 26877	to, dying to, die. For all things dying, for all things born. Poor Mrs
 26878	Purefoy. Hope she's over. Because their wombs.
 26879	
 26880	A liquid of womb of woman eyeball gazed under a fence of lashes, calmly,
 26881	hearing. See real beauty of the eye when she not speaks. On yonder
 26882	river. At each slow satiny heaving bosom's wave (her heaving embon) red
 26883	rose rose slowly sank red rose. Heartbeats: her breath: breath that is
 26884	life. And all the tiny tiny fernfoils trembled of maidenhair.
 26885	
 26886	But look. The bright stars fade. O rose! Castile. The morn. Ha. Lidwell.
 26887	For him then not for. Infatuated. I like that? See her from here though.
 26888	Popped corks, splashes of beerfroth, stacks of empties.
 26889	
 26890	On the smooth jutting beerpull laid Lydia hand, lightly, plumply, leave
 26891	it to my hands. All lost in pity for croppy. Fro, to: to, fro: over
 26892	the polished knob (she knows his eyes, my eyes, her eyes) her thumb and
 26893	finger passed in pity: passed, reposed and, gently touching, then slid
 26894	so smoothly, slowly down, a cool firm white enamel baton protruding
 26895	through their sliding ring.
 26896	
 26897	With a cock with a carra.
 26898	
 26899	Tap. Tap. Tap.
 26900	
 26901	I hold this house. Amen. He gnashed in fury. Traitors swing.
 26902	
 26903	The chords consented. Very sad thing. But had to be. Get out before the
 26904	end. Thanks, that was heavenly. Where's my hat. Pass by her. Can leave
 26905	that Freeman. Letter I have. Suppose she were the? No. Walk, walk,
 26906	walk. Like Cashel Boylo Connoro Coylo Tisdall Maurice Tisntdall Farrell.
 26907	Waaaaaaalk.
 26908	
 26909	Well, I must be. Are you off? Yrfmstbyes. Blmstup. O'er ryehigh blue.
 26910	Ow. Bloom stood up. Soap feeling rather sticky behind. Must have
 26911	sweated: music. That lotion, remember. Well, so long. High grade. Card
 26912	inside. Yes.
 26913	
 26914	By deaf Pat in the doorway straining ear Bloom passed.
 26915	
 26916	At Geneva barrack that young man died. At Passage was his body laid.
 26917	Dolor! O, he dolores! The voice of the mournful chanter called to
 26918	dolorous prayer.
 26919	
 26920	By rose, by satiny bosom, by the fondling hand, by slops, by empties,
 26921	by popped corks, greeting in going, past eyes and maidenhair, bronze and
 26922	faint gold in deepseashadow, went Bloom, soft Bloom, I feel so lonely
 26923	Bloom.
 26924	
 26925	Tap. Tap. Tap.
 26926	
 26927	Pray for him, prayed the bass of Dollard. You who hear in peace. Breathe
 26928	a prayer, drop a tear, good men, good people. He was the croppy boy.
 26929	
 26930	Scaring eavesdropping boots croppy bootsboy Bloom in the Ormond hallway
 26931	heard the growls and roars of bravo, fat backslapping, their boots all
 26932	treading, boots not the boots the boy. General chorus off for a swill to
 26933	wash it down. Glad I avoided.
 26934	
 26935	--Come on, Ben, Simon Dedalus cried. By God, you're as good as ever you
 26936	were.
 26937	
 26938	--Better, said Tomgin Kernan. Most trenchant rendition of that ballad,
 26939	upon my soul and honour It is.
 26940	
 26941	--Lablache, said Father Cowley.
 26942	
 26943	Ben Dollard bulkily cachuchad towards the bar, mightily praisefed
 26944	and all big roseate, on heavyfooted feet, his gouty fingers nakkering
 26945	castagnettes in the air.
 26946	
 26947	Big Benaben Dollard. Big Benben. Big Benben.
 26948	
 26949	Rrr.
 26950	
 26951	And deepmoved all, Simon trumping compassion from foghorn nose, all
 26952	laughing they brought him forth, Ben Dollard, in right good cheer.
 26953	
 26954	--You're looking rubicund, George Lidwell said.
 26955	
 26956	Miss Douce composed her rose to wait.
 26957	
 26958	--Ben machree, said Mr Dedalus, clapping Ben's fat back shoulderblade.
 26959	Fit as a fiddle only he has a lot of adipose tissue concealed about his
 26960	person.
 26961	
 26962	Rrrrrrrsss.
 26963	
 26964	--Fat of death, Simon, Ben Dollard growled.
 26965	
 26966	Richie rift in the lute alone sat: Goulding, Collis, Ward. Uncertainly
 26967	he waited. Unpaid Pat too.
 26968	
 26969	Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap.
 26970	
 26971	Miss Mina Kennedy brought near her lips to ear of tankard one.
 26972	
 26973	--Mr Dollard, they murmured low.
 26974	
 26975	--Dollard, murmured tankard.
 26976	
 26977	Tank one believed: miss Kenn when she: that doll he was: she doll: the
 26978	tank.
 26979	
 26980	He murmured that he knew the name. The name was familiar to him, that
 26981	is to say. That was to say he had heard the name of. Dollard, was it?
 26982	Dollard, yes.
 26983	
 26984	Yes, her lips said more loudly, Mr Dollard. He sang that song lovely,
 26985	murmured Mina. Mr Dollard. And _The last rose of summer_ was a lovely
 26986	song. Mina loved that song. Tankard loved the song that Mina.
 26987	
 26988	'Tis the last rose of summer dollard left bloom felt wind wound round
 26989	inside.
 26990	
 26991	Gassy thing that cider: binding too. Wait. Postoffice near Reuben J's
 26992	one and eightpence too. Get shut of it. Dodge round by Greek street.
 26993	Wish I hadn't promised to meet. Freer in air. Music. Gets on your
 26994	nerves. Beerpull. Her hand that rocks the cradle rules the. Ben Howth.
 26995	That rules the world.
 26996	
 26997	Far. Far. Far. Far.
 26998	
 26999	Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap.
 27000	
 27001	Up the quay went Lionelleopold, naughty Henry with letter for Mady, with
 27002	sweets of sin with frillies for Raoul with met him pike hoses went Poldy
 27003	on.
 27004	
 27005	Tap blind walked tapping by the tap the curbstone tapping, tap by tap.
 27006	
 27007	Cowley, he stuns himself with it: kind of drunkenness. Better give way
 27008	only half way the way of a man with a maid. Instance enthusiasts. All
 27009	ears. Not lose a demisemiquaver. Eyes shut. Head nodding in time. Dotty.
 27010	You daren't budge. Thinking strictly prohibited. Always talking shop.
 27011	Fiddlefaddle about notes.
 27012	
 27013	All a kind of attempt to talk. Unpleasant when it stops because you
 27014	never know exac. Organ in Gardiner street. Old Glynn fifty quid a year.
 27015	Queer up there in the cockloft, alone, with stops and locks and keys.
 27016	Seated all day at the organ. Maunder on for hours, talking to himself or
 27017	the other fellow blowing the bellows. Growl angry, then shriek cursing
 27018	(want to have wadding or something in his no don't she cried), then all
 27019	of a soft sudden wee little wee little pipy wind.
 27020	
 27021	Pwee! A wee little wind piped eeee. In Bloom's little wee.
 27022	
 27023	--Was he? Mr Dedalus said, returning with fetched pipe. I was with him
 27024	this morning at poor little Paddy Dignam's...
 27025	
 27026	--Ay, the Lord have mercy on him.
 27027	
 27028	--By the bye there's a tuningfork in there on the...
 27029	
 27030	Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap.
 27031	
 27032	--The wife has a fine voice. Or had. What? Lidwell asked.
 27033	
 27034	--O, that must be the tuner, Lydia said to Simonlionel first I saw,
 27035	forgot it when he was here.
 27036	
 27037	Blind he was she told George Lidwell second I saw. And played so
 27038	exquisitely, treat to hear. Exquisite contrast: bronzelid, minagold.
 27039	
 27040	--Shout! Ben Dollard shouted, pouring. Sing out!
 27041	
 27042	--'lldo! cried Father Cowley.
 27043	
 27044	Rrrrrr.
 27045	
 27046	I feel I want...
 27047	
 27048	Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap
 27049	
 27050	--Very, Mr Dedalus said, staring hard at a headless sardine.
 27051	
 27052	Under the sandwichbell lay on a bier of bread one last, one lonely, last
 27053	sardine of summer. Bloom alone.
 27054	
 27055	--Very, he stared. The lower register, for choice.
 27056	
 27057	Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap. Tap.
 27058	
 27059	Bloom went by Barry's. Wish I could. Wait. That wonderworker if I had.
 27060	Twentyfour solicitors in that one house. Counted them. Litigation. Love
 27061	one another. Piles of parchment. Messrs Pick and Pocket have power of
 27062	attorney. Goulding, Collis, Ward.
 27063	
 27064	But for example the chap that wallops the big drum. His vocation: Mickey
 27065	Rooney's band. Wonder how it first struck him. Sitting at home after
 27066	pig's cheek and cabbage nursing it in the armchair. Rehearsing his band
 27067	part. Pom. Pompedy. Jolly for the wife. Asses' skins. Welt them through
 27068	life, then wallop after death. Pom. Wallop. Seems to be what you call
 27069	yashmak or I mean kismet. Fate.
 27070	
 27071	Tap. Tap. A stripling, blind, with a tapping cane came taptaptapping by
 27072	Daly's window where a mermaid hair all streaming (but he couldn't see)
 27073	blew whiffs of a mermaid (blind couldn't), mermaid, coolest whiff of
 27074	all.
 27075	
 27076	Instruments. A blade of grass, shell of her hands, then blow. Even
 27077	comb and tissuepaper you can knock a tune out of. Molly in her shift in
 27078	Lombard street west, hair down. I suppose each kind of trade made its
 27079	own, don't you see? Hunter with a horn. Haw. Have you the? _Cloche.
 27080	Sonnez la._ Shepherd his pipe. Pwee little wee. Policeman a whistle.
 27081	Locks and keys! Sweep! Four o'clock's all's well! Sleep! All is lost
 27082	now. Drum? Pompedy. Wait. I know. Towncrier, bumbailiff. Long John.
 27083	Waken the dead. Pom. Dignam. Poor little _nominedomine._ Pom. It is
 27084	music. I mean of course it's all pom pom pom very much what they call
 27085	_da capo._ Still you can hear. As we march, we march along, march along.
 27086	Pom.
 27087	
 27088	I must really. Fff. Now if I did that at a banquet. Just a question of
 27089	custom shah of Persia. Breathe a prayer, drop a tear. All the same
 27090	he must have been a bit of a natural not to see it was a yeoman cap.
 27091	Muffled up. Wonder who was that chap at the grave in the brown macin. O,
 27092	the whore of the lane!
 27093	
 27094	A frowsy whore with black straw sailor hat askew came glazily in the day
 27095	along the quay towards Mr Bloom. When first he saw that form endearing?
 27096	Yes, it is. I feel so lonely. Wet night in the lane. Horn. Who had
 27097	the? Heehaw shesaw. Off her beat here. What is she? Hope she. Psst! Any
 27098	chance of your wash. Knew Molly. Had me decked. Stout lady does be with
 27099	you in the brown costume. Put you off your stroke, that. Appointment
 27100	we made knowing we'd never, well hardly ever. Too dear too near to home
 27101	sweet home. Sees me, does she? Looks a fright in the day. Face like dip.
 27102	Damn her. O, well, she has to live like the rest. Look in here.
 27103	
 27104	In Lionel Marks's antique saleshop window haughty Henry Lionel Leopold
 27105	dear Henry Flower earnestly Mr Leopold Bloom envisaged battered
 27106	candlesticks melodeon oozing maggoty blowbags. Bargain: six bob. Might
 27107	learn to play. Cheap. Let her pass. Course everything is dear if you
 27108	don't want it. That's what good salesman is. Make you buy what he wants
 27109	to sell. Chap sold me the Swedish razor he shaved me with. Wanted to
 27110	charge me for the edge he gave it. She's passing now. Six bob.
 27111	
 27112	Must be the cider or perhaps the burgund.
 27113	
 27114	Near bronze from anear near gold from afar they chinked their clinking
 27115	glasses all, brighteyed and gallant, before bronze Lydia's tempting last
 27116	rose of summer, rose of Castile. First Lid, De, Cow, Ker, Doll, a fifth:
 27117	Lidwell, Si Dedalus, Bob Cowley, Kernan and big Ben Dollard.
 27118	
 27119	Tap. A youth entered a lonely Ormond hall.
 27120	
 27121	Bloom viewed a gallant pictured hero in Lionel Marks's window. Robert
 27122	Emmet's last words. Seven last words. Of Meyerbeer that is.
 27123	
 27124	--True men like you men.
 27125	
 27126	--Ay, ay, Ben.
 27127	
 27128	--Will lift your glass with us.
 27129	
 27130	They lifted.
 27131	
 27132	Tschink. Tschunk.
 27133	
 27134	Tip. An unseeing stripling stood in the door. He saw not bronze. He saw
 27135	not gold. Nor Ben nor Bob nor Tom nor Si nor George nor tanks nor Richie
 27136	nor Pat. Hee hee hee hee. He did not see.
 27137	
 27138	Seabloom, greaseabloom viewed last words. Softly. _When my country takes
 27139	her place among._
 27140	
 27141	Prrprr.
 27142	
 27143	Must be the bur.
 27144	
 27145	Fff! Oo. Rrpr.
 27146	
 27147	_Nations of the earth._ No-one behind. She's passed. _Then and not till
 27148	then._ Tram kran kran kran. Good oppor. Coming. Krandlkrankran. I'm
 27149	sure it's the burgund. Yes. One, two. _Let my epitaph be._ Kraaaaaa.
 27150	_Written. I have._
 27151	
 27152	Pprrpffrrppffff.
 27153	
 27154	_Done._
 27155	
 27156	
 27157	
 27158	I was just passing the time of day with old Troy of the D. M. P. at the
 27159	corner of Arbour hill there and be damned but a bloody sweep came along
 27160	and he near drove his gear into my eye. I turned around to let him have
 27161	the weight of my tongue when who should I see dodging along Stony Batter
 27162	only Joe Hynes.
 27163	
 27164	--Lo, Joe, says I. How are you blowing? Did you see that bloody
 27165	chimneysweep near shove my eye out with his brush?
 27166	
 27167	--Soot's luck, says Joe. Who's the old ballocks you were talking to?
 27168	
 27169	--Old Troy, says I, was in the force. I'm on two minds not to give that
 27170	fellow in charge for obstructing the thoroughfare with his brooms and
 27171	ladders.
 27172	
 27173	--What are you doing round those parts? says Joe.
 27174	
 27175	--Devil a much, says I. There's a bloody big foxy thief beyond by the
 27176	garrison church at the corner of Chicken lane--old Troy was just giving
 27177	me a wrinkle about him--lifted any God's quantity of tea and sugar
 27178	to pay three bob a week said he had a farm in the county Down off a
 27179	hop-of-my-thumb by the name of Moses Herzog over there near Heytesbury
 27180	street.
 27181	
 27182	--Circumcised? says Joe.
 27183	
 27184	--Ay, says I. A bit off the top. An old plumber named Geraghty. I'm
 27185	hanging on to his taw now for the past fortnight and I can't get a penny
 27186	out of him.
 27187	
 27188	--That the lay you're on now? says Joe.
 27189	
 27190	--Ay, says I. How are the mighty fallen! Collector of bad and doubtful
 27191	debts. But that's the most notorious bloody robber you'd meet in a day's
 27192	walk and the face on him all pockmarks would hold a shower of rain.
 27193	_Tell him,_ says he, _I dare him,_ says he, _and I doubledare him
 27194	to send you round here again or if he does,_ says he, _I'll have
 27195	him summonsed up before the court, so I will, for trading without a
 27196	licence._ And he after stuffing himself till he's fit to burst. Jesus,
 27197	I had to laugh at the little jewy getting his shirt out. _He drink me my
 27198	teas. He eat me my sugars. Because he no pay me my moneys?_
 27199	
 27200	For nonperishable goods bought of Moses Herzog, of 13 Saint Kevin's
 27201	parade in the city of Dublin, Wood quay ward, merchant, hereinafter
 27202	called the vendor, and sold and delivered to Michael E. Geraghty,
 27203	esquire, of 29 Arbour hill in the city of Dublin, Arran quay ward,
 27204	gentleman, hereinafter called the purchaser, videlicet, five pounds
 27205	avoirdupois of first choice tea at three shillings and no pence per
 27206	pound avoirdupois and three stone avoirdupois of sugar, crushed crystal,
 27207	at threepence per pound avoirdupois, the said purchaser debtor to the
 27208	said vendor of one pound five shillings and sixpence sterling for value
 27209	received which amount shall be paid by said purchaser to said vendor in
 27210	weekly instalments every seven calendar days of three shillings and no
 27211	pence sterling: and the said nonperishable goods shall not be pawned or
 27212	pledged or sold or otherwise alienated by the said purchaser but shall
 27213	be and remain and be held to be the sole and exclusive property of the
 27214	said vendor to be disposed of at his good will and pleasure until the
 27215	said amount shall have been duly paid by the said purchaser to the said
 27216	vendor in the manner herein set forth as this day hereby agreed between
 27217	the said vendor, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the one
 27218	part and the said purchaser, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns
 27219	of the other part.
 27220	
 27221	--Are you a strict t.t.? says Joe.
 27222	
 27223	--Not taking anything between drinks, says I.
 27224	
 27225	--What about paying our respects to our friend? says Joe.
 27226	
 27227	--Who? says I. Sure, he's out in John of God's off his head, poor man.
 27228	
 27229	--Drinking his own stuff? says Joe.
 27230	
 27231	--Ay, says I. Whisky and water on the brain.
 27232	
 27233	--Come around to Barney Kiernan's, says Joe. I want to see the citizen.
 27234	
 27235	--Barney mavourneen's be it, says I. Anything strange or wonderful, Joe?
 27236	
 27237	--Not a word, says Joe. I was up at that meeting in the City Arms.
 27238	
 27239	---What was that, Joe? says I.
 27240	
 27241	--Cattle traders, says Joe, about the foot and mouth disease. I want to
 27242	give the citizen the hard word about it.
 27243	
 27244	So we went around by the Linenhall barracks and the back of the
 27245	courthouse talking of one thing or another. Decent fellow Joe when he
 27246	has it but sure like that he never has it. Jesus, I couldn't get over
 27247	that bloody foxy Geraghty, the daylight robber. For trading without a
 27248	licence, says he.
 27249	
 27250	In Inisfail the fair there lies a land, the land of holy Michan. There
 27251	rises a watchtower beheld of men afar. There sleep the mighty dead as in
 27252	life they slept, warriors and princes of high renown. A pleasant land
 27253	it is in sooth of murmuring waters, fishful streams where sport the
 27254	gurnard, the plaice, the roach, the halibut, the gibbed haddock, the
 27255	grilse, the dab, the brill, the flounder, the pollock, the mixed coarse
 27256	fish generally and other denizens of the aqueous kingdom too numerous to
 27257	be enumerated. In the mild breezes of the west and of the east the lofty
 27258	trees wave in different directions their firstclass foliage, the wafty
 27259	sycamore, the Lebanonian cedar, the exalted planetree, the eugenic
 27260	eucalyptus and other ornaments of the arboreal world with which
 27261	that region is thoroughly well supplied. Lovely maidens sit in close
 27262	proximity to the roots of the lovely trees singing the most lovely songs
 27263	while they play with all kinds of lovely objects as for example golden
 27264	ingots, silvery fishes, crans of herrings, drafts of eels, codlings,
 27265	creels of fingerlings, purple seagems and playful insects. And heroes
 27266	voyage from afar to woo them, from Eblana to Slievemargy, the peerless
 27267	princes of unfettered Munster and of Connacht the just and of smooth
 27268	sleek Leinster and of Cruahan's land and of Armagh the splendid and of
 27269	the noble district of Boyle, princes, the sons of kings.
 27270	
 27271	And there rises a shining palace whose crystal glittering roof is seen
 27272	by mariners who traverse the extensive sea in barks built expressly for
 27273	that purpose, and thither come all herds and fatlings and firstfruits
 27274	of that land for O'Connell Fitzsimon takes toll of them, a chieftain
 27275	descended from chieftains. Thither the extremely large wains bring
 27276	foison of the fields, flaskets of cauliflowers, floats of spinach,
 27277	pineapple chunks, Rangoon beans, strikes of tomatoes, drums of figs,
 27278	drills of Swedes, spherical potatoes and tallies of iridescent kale,
 27279	York and Savoy, and trays of onions, pearls of the earth, and punnets of
 27280	mushrooms and custard marrows and fat vetches and bere and rape and red
 27281	green yellow brown russet sweet big bitter ripe pomellated apples and
 27282	chips of strawberries and sieves of gooseberries, pulpy and pelurious,
 27283	and strawberries fit for princes and raspberries from their canes.
 27284	
 27285	I dare him, says he, and I doubledare him. Come out here, Geraghty, you
 27286	notorious bloody hill and dale robber!
 27287	
 27288	And by that way wend the herds innumerable of bellwethers and flushed
 27289	ewes and shearling rams and lambs and stubble geese and medium steers
 27290	and roaring mares and polled calves and longwoods and storesheep and
 27291	Cuffe's prime springers and culls and sowpigs and baconhogs and the
 27292	various different varieties of highly distinguished swine and Angus
 27293	heifers and polly bulllocks of immaculate pedigree together with prime
 27294	premiated milchcows and beeves: and there is ever heard a trampling,
 27295	cackling, roaring, lowing, bleating, bellowing, rumbling, grunting,
 27296	champing, chewing, of sheep and pigs and heavyhooved kine from
 27297	pasturelands of Lusk and Rush and Carrickmines and from the streamy
 27298	vales of Thomond, from the M'Gillicuddy's reeks the inaccessible and
 27299	lordly Shannon the unfathomable, and from the gentle declivities of the
 27300	place of the race of Kiar, their udders distended with superabundance of
 27301	milk and butts of butter and rennets of cheese and farmer's firkins and
 27302	targets of lamb and crannocks of corn and oblong eggs in great hundreds,
 27303	various in size, the agate with this dun.
 27304	
 27305	So we turned into Barney Kiernan's and there, sure enough, was the
 27306	citizen up in the corner having a great confab with himself and that
 27307	bloody mangy mongrel, Garryowen, and he waiting for what the sky would
 27308	drop in the way of drink.
 27309	
 27310	--There he is, says I, in his gloryhole, with his cruiskeen lawn and his
 27311	load of papers, working for the cause.
 27312	
 27313	The bloody mongrel let a grouse out of him would give you the creeps. Be
 27314	a corporal work of mercy if someone would take the life of that bloody
 27315	dog. I'm told for a fact he ate a good part of the breeches off a
 27316	constabulary man in Santry that came round one time with a blue paper
 27317	about a licence.
 27318	
 27319	--Stand and deliver, says he.
 27320	
 27321	--That's all right, citizen, says Joe. Friends here.
 27322	
 27323	--Pass, friends, says he.
 27324	
 27325	Then he rubs his hand in his eye and says he:
 27326	
 27327	--What's your opinion of the times?
 27328	
 27329	Doing the rapparee and Rory of the hill. But, begob, Joe was equal to
 27330	the occasion.
 27331	
 27332	--I think the markets are on a rise, says he, sliding his hand down his
 27333	fork.
 27334	
 27335	So begob the citizen claps his paw on his knee and he says:
 27336	
 27337	--Foreign wars is the cause of it.
 27338	
 27339	And says Joe, sticking his thumb in his pocket:
 27340	
 27341	--It's the Russians wish to tyrannise.
 27342	
 27343	--Arrah, give over your bloody codding, Joe, says I. I've a thirst on me
 27344	I wouldn't sell for half a crown.
 27345	
 27346	--Give it a name, citizen, says Joe.
 27347	
 27348	--Wine of the country, says he.
 27349	
 27350	--What's yours? says Joe.
 27351	
 27352	--Ditto MacAnaspey, says I.
 27353	
 27354	--Three pints, Terry, says Joe. And how's the old heart, citizen? says
 27355	he.
 27356	
 27357	--Never better, _a chara_, says he. What Garry? Are we going to win? Eh?
 27358	
 27359	And with that he took the bloody old towser by the scruff of the neck
 27360	and, by Jesus, he near throttled him.
 27361	
 27362	The figure seated on a large boulder at the foot of a round tower was
 27363	that of a broadshouldered deepchested stronglimbed frankeyed redhaired
 27364	freelyfreckled shaggybearded widemouthed largenosed longheaded
 27365	deepvoiced barekneed brawnyhanded hairylegged ruddyfaced sinewyarmed
 27366	hero. From shoulder to shoulder he measured several ells and his
 27367	rocklike mountainous knees were covered, as was likewise the rest of his
 27368	body wherever visible, with a strong growth of tawny prickly hair in
 27369	hue and toughness similar to the mountain gorse (_Ulex Europeus_).
 27370	The widewinged nostrils, from which bristles of the same tawny hue
 27371	projected, were of such capaciousness that within their cavernous
 27372	obscurity the fieldlark might easily have lodged her nest. The eyes
 27373	in which a tear and a smile strove ever for the mastery were of the
 27374	dimensions of a goodsized cauliflower. A powerful current of warm breath
 27375	issued at regular intervals from the profound cavity of his mouth
 27376	while in rhythmic resonance the loud strong hale reverberations of his
 27377	formidable heart thundered rumblingly causing the ground, the summit of
 27378	the lofty tower and the still loftier walls of the cave to vibrate and
 27379	tremble.
 27380	
 27381	He wore a long unsleeved garment of recently flayed oxhide reaching
 27382	to the knees in a loose kilt and this was bound about his middle by
 27383	a girdle of plaited straw and rushes. Beneath this he wore trews of
 27384	deerskin, roughly stitched with gut. His nether extremities were encased
 27385	in high Balbriggan buskins dyed in lichen purple, the feet being shod
 27386	with brogues of salted cowhide laced with the windpipe of the same
 27387	beast. From his girdle hung a row of seastones which jangled at every
 27388	movement of his portentous frame and on these were graven with rude
 27389	yet striking art the tribal images of many Irish heroes and heroines of
 27390	antiquity, Cuchulin, Conn of hundred battles, Niall of nine hostages,
 27391	Brian of Kincora, the ardri Malachi, Art MacMurragh, Shane O'Neill,
 27392	Father John Murphy, Owen Roe, Patrick Sarsfield, Red Hugh O'Donnell,
 27393	Red Jim MacDermott, Soggarth Eoghan O'Growney, Michael Dwyer, Francy
 27394	Higgins, Henry Joy M'Cracken, Goliath, Horace Wheatley, Thomas Conneff,
 27395	Peg Woffington, the Village Blacksmith, Captain Moonlight, Captain
 27396	Boycott, Dante Alighieri, Christopher Columbus, S. Fursa, S. Brendan,
 27397	Marshal MacMahon, Charlemagne, Theobald Wolfe Tone, the Mother of the
 27398	Maccabees, the Last of the Mohicans, the Rose of Castile, the Man for
 27399	Galway, The Man that Broke the Bank at Monte Carlo, The Man in the Gap,
 27400	The Woman Who Didn't, Benjamin Franklin, Napoleon Bonaparte, John L.
 27401	Sullivan, Cleopatra, Savourneen Deelish, Julius Caesar, Paracelsus, sir
 27402	Thomas Lipton, William Tell, Michelangelo Hayes, Muhammad, the Bride of
 27403	Lammermoor, Peter the Hermit, Peter the Packer, Dark Rosaleen, Patrick
 27404	W. Shakespeare, Brian Confucius, Murtagh Gutenberg, Patricio Velasquez,
 27405	Captain Nemo, Tristan and Isolde, the first Prince of Wales, Thomas
 27406	Cook and Son, the Bold Soldier Boy, Arrah na Pogue, Dick Turpin, Ludwig
 27407	Beethoven, the Colleen Bawn, Waddler Healy, Angus the Culdee, Dolly
 27408	Mount, Sidney Parade, Ben Howth, Valentine Greatrakes, Adam and Eve,
 27409	Arthur Wellesley, Boss Croker, Herodotus, Jack the Giantkiller, Gautama
 27410	Buddha, Lady Godiva, The Lily of Killarney, Balor of the Evil Eye,
 27411	the Queen of Sheba, Acky Nagle, Joe Nagle, Alessandro Volta, Jeremiah
 27412	O'Donovan Rossa, Don Philip O'Sullivan Beare. A couched spear of
 27413	acuminated granite rested by him while at his feet reposed a savage
 27414	animal of the canine tribe whose stertorous gasps announced that he was
 27415	sunk in uneasy slumber, a supposition confirmed by hoarse growls and
 27416	spasmodic movements which his master repressed from time to time
 27417	by tranquilising blows of a mighty cudgel rudely fashioned out of
 27418	paleolithic stone.
 27419	
 27420	So anyhow Terry brought the three pints Joe was standing and begob the
 27421	sight nearly left my eyes when I saw him land out a quid O, as true as
 27422	I'm telling you. A goodlooking sovereign.
 27423	
 27424	--And there's more where that came from, says he.
 27425	
 27426	--Were you robbing the poorbox, Joe? says I.
 27427	
 27428	--Sweat of my brow, says Joe. 'Twas the prudent member gave me the
 27429	wheeze.
 27430	
 27431	--I saw him before I met you, says I, sloping around by Pill lane and
 27432	Greek street with his cod's eye counting up all the guts of the fish.
 27433	
 27434	Who comes through Michan's land, bedight in sable armour? O'Bloom,
 27435	the son of Rory: it is he. Impervious to fear is Rory's son: he of the
 27436	prudent soul.
 27437	
 27438	--For the old woman of Prince's street, says the citizen, the subsidised
 27439	organ. The pledgebound party on the floor of the house. And look at this
 27440	blasted rag, says he. Look at this, says he. _The Irish Independent,_ if
 27441	you please, founded by Parnell to be the workingman's friend. Listen to
 27442	the births and deaths in the _Irish all for Ireland Independent,_ and
 27443	I'll thank you and the marriages.
 27444	
 27445	And he starts reading them out:
 27446	
 27447	--Gordon, Barnfield crescent, Exeter; Redmayne of Iffley, Saint Anne's
 27448	on Sea: the wife of William T Redmayne of a son. How's that, eh? Wright
 27449	and Flint, Vincent and Gillett to Rotha Marion daughter of Rosa and the
 27450	late George Alfred Gillett, 179 Clapham road, Stockwell, Playwood and
 27451	Ridsdale at Saint Jude's, Kensington by the very reverend Dr Forrest,
 27452	dean of Worcester. Eh? Deaths. Bristow, at Whitehall lane, London: Carr,
 27453	Stoke Newington, of gastritis and heart disease: Cockburn, at the Moat
 27454	house, Chepstow...
 27455	
 27456	--I know that fellow, says Joe, from bitter experience.
 27457	
 27458	--Cockburn. Dimsey, wife of David Dimsey, late of the admiralty: Miller,
 27459	Tottenham, aged eightyfive: Welsh, June 12, at 35 Canning street,
 27460	Liverpool, Isabella Helen. How's that for a national press, eh, my brown
 27461	son! How's that for Martin Murphy, the Bantry jobber?
 27462	
 27463	--Ah, well, says Joe, handing round the boose. Thanks be to God they had
 27464	the start of us. Drink that, citizen.
 27465	
 27466	--I will, says he, honourable person.
 27467	
 27468	--Health, Joe, says I. And all down the form.
 27469	
 27470	Ah! Ow! Don't be talking! I was blue mouldy for the want of that pint.
 27471	Declare to God I could hear it hit the pit of my stomach with a click.
 27472	
 27473	And lo, as they quaffed their cup of joy, a godlike messenger came
 27474	swiftly in, radiant as the eye of heaven, a comely youth and behind him
 27475	there passed an elder of noble gait and countenance, bearing the sacred
 27476	scrolls of law and with him his lady wife a dame of peerless lineage,
 27477	fairest of her race.
 27478	
 27479	Little Alf Bergan popped in round the door and hid behind Barney's
 27480	snug, squeezed up with the laughing. And who was sitting up there in
 27481	the corner that I hadn't seen snoring drunk blind to the world only Bob
 27482	Doran. I didn't know what was up and Alf kept making signs out of the
 27483	door. And begob what was it only that bloody old pantaloon Denis Breen
 27484	in his bathslippers with two bloody big books tucked under his oxter and
 27485	the wife hotfoot after him, unfortunate wretched woman, trotting like a
 27486	poodle. I thought Alf would split.
 27487	
 27488	--Look at him, says he. Breen. He's traipsing all round Dublin with a
 27489	postcard someone sent him with U. p: up on it to take a li...
 27490	
 27491	And he doubled up.
 27492	
 27493	--Take a what? says I.
 27494	
 27495	--Libel action, says he, for ten thousand pounds.
 27496	
 27497	--O hell! says I.
 27498	
 27499	The bloody mongrel began to growl that'd put the fear of God in you
 27500	seeing something was up but the citizen gave him a kick in the ribs.
 27501	
 27502	_--Bi i dho husht,_ says he.
 27503	
 27504	--Who? says Joe.
 27505	
 27506	--Breen, says Alf. He was in John Henry Menton's and then he went round
 27507	to Collis and Ward's and then Tom Rochford met him and sent him round to
 27508	the subsheriff's for a lark. O God, I've a pain laughing. U. p: up. The
 27509	long fellow gave him an eye as good as a process and now the bloody old
 27510	lunatic is gone round to Green street to look for a G man.
 27511	
 27512	--When is long John going to hang that fellow in Mountjoy? says Joe.
 27513	
 27514	--Bergan, says Bob Doran, waking up. Is that Alf Bergan?
 27515	
 27516	--Yes, says Alf. Hanging? Wait till I show you. Here, Terry, give us a
 27517	pony. That bloody old fool! Ten thousand pounds. You should have seen
 27518	long John's eye. U. p...
 27519	
 27520	And he started laughing.
 27521	
 27522	--Who are you laughing at? says Bob Doran. Is that Bergan?
 27523	
 27524	--Hurry up, Terry boy, says Alf.
 27525	
 27526	Terence O'Ryan heard him and straightway brought him a crystal cup
 27527	full of the foamy ebon ale which the noble twin brothers Bungiveagh and
 27528	Bungardilaun brew ever in their divine alevats, cunning as the sons of
 27529	deathless Leda. For they garner the succulent berries of the hop and
 27530	mass and sift and bruise and brew them and they mix therewith sour
 27531	juices and bring the must to the sacred fire and cease not night or day
 27532	from their toil, those cunning brothers, lords of the vat.
 27533	
 27534	Then did you, chivalrous Terence, hand forth, as to the manner born,
 27535	that nectarous beverage and you offered the crystal cup to him that
 27536	thirsted, the soul of chivalry, in beauty akin to the immortals.
 27537	
 27538	But he, the young chief of the O'Bergan's, could ill brook to be outdone
 27539	in generous deeds but gave therefor with gracious gesture a testoon of
 27540	costliest bronze. Thereon embossed in excellent smithwork was seen
 27541	the image of a queen of regal port, scion of the house of Brunswick,
 27542	Victoria her name, Her Most Excellent Majesty, by grace of God of the
 27543	United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and of the British dominions
 27544	beyond the sea, queen, defender of the faith, Empress of India, even
 27545	she, who bore rule, a victress over many peoples, the wellbeloved, for
 27546	they knew and loved her from the rising of the sun to the going down
 27547	thereof, the pale, the dark, the ruddy and the ethiop.
 27548	
 27549	--What's that bloody freemason doing, says the citizen, prowling up and
 27550	down outside?
 27551	
 27552	--What's that? says Joe.
 27553	
 27554	--Here you are, says Alf, chucking out the rhino. Talking about hanging,
 27555	I'll show you something you never saw. Hangmen's letters. Look at here.
 27556	
 27557	So he took a bundle of wisps of letters and envelopes out of his pocket.
 27558	
 27559	--Are you codding? says I.
 27560	
 27561	--Honest injun, says Alf. Read them.
 27562	
 27563	So Joe took up the letters.
 27564	
 27565	--Who are you laughing at? says Bob Doran.
 27566	
 27567	So I saw there was going to be a bit of a dust Bob's a queer chap when
 27568	the porter's up in him so says I just to make talk:
 27569	
 27570	--How's Willy Murray those times, Alf?
 27571	
 27572	--I don't know, says Alf I saw him just now in Capel street with Paddy
 27573	Dignam. Only I was running after that...
 27574	
 27575	--You what? says Joe, throwing down the letters. With who?
 27576	
 27577	--With Dignam, says Alf.
 27578	
 27579	--Is it Paddy? says Joe.
 27580	
 27581	--Yes, says Alf. Why?
 27582	
 27583	--Don't you know he's dead? says Joe.
 27584	
 27585	--Paddy Dignam dead! says Alf.
 27586	
 27587	--Ay, says Joe.
 27588	
 27589	--Sure I'm after seeing him not five minutes ago, says Alf, as plain as
 27590	a pikestaff.
 27591	
 27592	--Who's dead? says Bob Doran.
 27593	
 27594	--You saw his ghost then, says Joe, God between us and harm.
 27595	
 27596	--What? says Alf. Good Christ, only five... What?... And Willy Murray
 27597	with him, the two of them there near whatdoyoucallhim's... What? Dignam
 27598	dead?
 27599	
 27600	--What about Dignam? says Bob Doran. Who's talking about...?
 27601	
 27602	--Dead! says Alf. He's no more dead than you are.
 27603	
 27604	--Maybe so, says Joe. They took the liberty of burying him this morning
 27605	anyhow.
 27606	
 27607	--Paddy? says Alf.
 27608	
 27609	--Ay, says Joe. He paid the debt of nature, God be merciful to him.
 27610	
 27611	--Good Christ! says Alf.
 27612	
 27613	Begob he was what you might call flabbergasted.
 27614	
 27615	In the darkness spirit hands were felt to flutter and when prayer by
 27616	tantras had been directed to the proper quarter a faint but increasing
 27617	luminosity of ruby light became gradually visible, the apparition of
 27618	the etheric double being particularly lifelike owing to the discharge
 27619	of jivic rays from the crown of the head and face. Communication was
 27620	effected through the pituitary body and also by means of the orangefiery
 27621	and scarlet rays emanating from the sacral region and solar plexus.
 27622	Questioned by his earthname as to his whereabouts in the heavenworld he
 27623	stated that he was now on the path of pr l ya or return but was still
 27624	submitted to trial at the hands of certain bloodthirsty entities on the
 27625	lower astral levels. In reply to a question as to his first sensations
 27626	in the great divide beyond he stated that previously he had seen as in a
 27627	glass darkly but that those who had passed over had summit possibilities
 27628	of atmic development opened up to them. Interrogated as to whether life
 27629	there resembled our experience in the flesh he stated that he had heard
 27630	from more favoured beings now in the spirit that their abodes were
 27631	equipped with every modern home comfort such as talafana, alavatar,
 27632	hatakalda, wataklasat and that the highest adepts were steeped in
 27633	waves of volupcy of the very purest nature. Having requested a quart of
 27634	buttermilk this was brought and evidently afforded relief. Asked if he
 27635	had any message for the living he exhorted all who were still at the
 27636	wrong side of Maya to acknowledge the true path for it was reported
 27637	in devanic circles that Mars and Jupiter were out for mischief on the
 27638	eastern angle where the ram has power. It was then queried whether there
 27639	were any special desires on the part of the defunct and the reply was:
 27640	_We greet you, friends of earth, who are still in the body. Mind C. K.
 27641	doesn't pile it on._ It was ascertained that the reference was to Mr
 27642	Cornelius Kelleher, manager of Messrs H. J. O'Neill's popular
 27643	funeral establishment, a personal friend of the defunct, who had been
 27644	responsible for the carrying out of the interment arrangements. Before
 27645	departing he requested that it should be told to his dear son Patsy that
 27646	the other boot which he had been looking for was at present under the
 27647	commode in the return room and that the pair should be sent to Cullen's
 27648	to be soled only as the heels were still good. He stated that this had
 27649	greatly perturbed his peace of mind in the other region and earnestly
 27650	requested that his desire should be made known.
 27651	
 27652	Assurances were given that the matter would be attended to and it was
 27653	intimated that this had given satisfaction.
 27654	
 27655	He is gone from mortal haunts: O'Dignam, sun of our morning. Fleet was
 27656	his foot on the bracken: Patrick of the beamy brow. Wail, Banba, with
 27657	your wind: and wail, O ocean, with your whirlwind.
 27658	
 27659	--There he is again, says the citizen, staring out.
 27660	
 27661	--Who? says I.
 27662	
 27663	--Bloom, says he. He's on point duty up and down there for the last ten
 27664	minutes.
 27665	
 27666	And, begob, I saw his physog do a peep in and then slidder off again.
 27667	
 27668	Little Alf was knocked bawways. Faith, he was.
 27669	
 27670	--Good Christ! says he. I could have sworn it was him.
 27671	
 27672	And says Bob Doran, with the hat on the back of his poll, lowest
 27673	blackguard in Dublin when he's under the influence:
 27674	
 27675	--Who said Christ is good?
 27676	
 27677	--I beg your parsnips, says Alf.
 27678	
 27679	--Is that a good Christ, says Bob Doran, to take away poor little Willy
 27680	Dignam?
 27681	
 27682	--Ah, well, says Alf, trying to pass it off. He's over all his troubles.
 27683	
 27684	But Bob Doran shouts out of him.
 27685	
 27686	--He's a bloody ruffian, I say, to take away poor little Willy Dignam.
 27687	
 27688	Terry came down and tipped him the wink to keep quiet, that they didn't
 27689	want that kind of talk in a respectable licensed premises. And Bob Doran
 27690	starts doing the weeps about Paddy Dignam, true as you're there.
 27691	
 27692	--The finest man, says he, snivelling, the finest purest character.
 27693	
 27694	The tear is bloody near your eye. Talking through his bloody hat. Fitter
 27695	for him go home to the little sleepwalking bitch he married, Mooney, the
 27696	bumbailiff's daughter, mother kept a kip in Hardwicke street, that
 27697	used to be stravaging about the landings Bantam Lyons told me that was
 27698	stopping there at two in the morning without a stitch on her, exposing
 27699	her person, open to all comers, fair field and no favour.
 27700	
 27701	--The noblest, the truest, says he. And he's gone, poor little Willy,
 27702	poor little Paddy Dignam.
 27703	
 27704	And mournful and with a heavy heart he bewept the extinction of that
 27705	beam of heaven.
 27706	
 27707	Old Garryowen started growling again at Bloom that was skeezing round
 27708	the door.
 27709	
 27710	--Come in, come on, he won't eat you, says the citizen.
 27711	
 27712	So Bloom slopes in with his cod's eye on the dog and he asks Terry was
 27713	Martin Cunningham there.
 27714	
 27715	--O, Christ M'Keown, says Joe, reading one of the letters. Listen to
 27716	this, will you?
 27717	
 27718	And he starts reading out one.
 27719	
 27720	_7 Hunter Street, Liverpool. To the High Sheriff of Dublin, Dublin._
 27721	
 27722	_Honoured sir i beg to offer my services in the abovementioned painful
 27723	case i hanged Joe Gann in Bootle jail on the 12 of Febuary 1900 and i
 27724	hanged..._
 27725	
 27726	--Show us, Joe, says I.
 27727	
 27728	--_... private Arthur Chace for fowl murder of Jessie Tilsit in
 27729	Pentonville prison and i was assistant when..._
 27730	
 27731	--Jesus, says I.
 27732	
 27733	--_... Billington executed the awful murderer Toad Smith..._
 27734	
 27735	The citizen made a grab at the letter.
 27736	
 27737	--Hold hard, says Joe, _i have a special nack of putting the noose once
 27738	in he can't get out hoping to be favoured i remain, honoured sir, my
 27739	terms is five ginnees._
 27740	
 27741	_H. RUMBOLD, MASTER BARBER._
 27742	
 27743	--And a barbarous bloody barbarian he is too, says the citizen.
 27744	
 27745	--And the dirty scrawl of the wretch, says Joe. Here, says he, take them
 27746	to hell out of my sight, Alf. Hello, Bloom, says he, what will you have?
 27747	
 27748	So they started arguing about the point, Bloom saying he wouldn't and he
 27749	couldn't and excuse him no offence and all to that and then he said well
 27750	he'd just take a cigar. Gob, he's a prudent member and no mistake.
 27751	
 27752	--Give us one of your prime stinkers, Terry, says Joe.
 27753	
 27754	And Alf was telling us there was one chap sent in a mourning card with a
 27755	black border round it.
 27756	
 27757	--They're all barbers, says he, from the black country that would hang
 27758	their own fathers for five quid down and travelling expenses.
 27759	
 27760	And he was telling us there's two fellows waiting below to pull his
 27761	heels down when he gets the drop and choke him properly and then they
 27762	chop up the rope after and sell the bits for a few bob a skull.
 27763	
 27764	In the dark land they bide, the vengeful knights of the razor. Their
 27765	deadly coil they grasp: yea, and therein they lead to Erebus whatsoever
 27766	wight hath done a deed of blood for I will on nowise suffer it even so
 27767	saith the Lord.
 27768	
 27769	So they started talking about capital punishment and of course Bloom
 27770	comes out with the why and the wherefore and all the codology of the
 27771	business and the old dog smelling him all the time I'm told those jewies
 27772	does have a sort of a queer odour coming off them for dogs about I don't
 27773	know what all deterrent effect and so forth and so on.
 27774	
 27775	--There's one thing it hasn't a deterrent effect on, says Alf.
 27776	
 27777	--What's that? says Joe.
 27778	
 27779	--The poor bugger's tool that's being hanged, says Alf.
 27780	
 27781	--That so? says Joe.
 27782	
 27783	--God's truth, says Alf. I heard that from the head warder that was in
 27784	
 27785	Kilmainham when they hanged Joe Brady, the invincible. He told me when
 27786	they cut him down after the drop it was standing up in their faces like
 27787	a poker.
 27788	
 27789	--Ruling passion strong in death, says Joe, as someone said.
 27790	
 27791	--That can be explained by science, says Bloom. It's only a natural
 27792	phenomenon, don't you see, because on account of the...
 27793	
 27794	And then he starts with his jawbreakers about phenomenon and science and
 27795	this phenomenon and the other phenomenon.
 27796	
 27797	The distinguished scientist Herr Professor Luitpold Blumenduft tendered
 27798	medical evidence to the effect that the instantaneous fracture of the
 27799	cervical vertebrae and consequent scission of the spinal cord would,
 27800	according to the best approved tradition of medical science, be
 27801	calculated to inevitably produce in the human subject a violent
 27802	ganglionic stimulus of the nerve centres of the genital apparatus,
 27803	thereby causing the elastic pores of the _corpora cavernosa_ to rapidly
 27804	dilate in such a way as to instantaneously facilitate the flow of blood
 27805	to that part of the human anatomy known as the penis or male organ
 27806	resulting in the phenomenon which has been denominated by the faculty
 27807	a morbid upwards and outwards philoprogenitive erection _in articulo
 27808	mortis per diminutionem capitis._
 27809	
 27810	So of course the citizen was only waiting for the wink of the word and
 27811	he starts gassing out of him about the invincibles and the old guard and
 27812	the men of sixtyseven and who fears to speak of ninetyeight and Joe with
 27813	him about all the fellows that were hanged, drawn and transported for
 27814	the cause by drumhead courtmartial and a new Ireland and new this, that
 27815	and the other. Talking about new Ireland he ought to go and get a new
 27816	dog so he ought. Mangy ravenous brute sniffing and sneezing all round
 27817	the place and scratching his scabs. And round he goes to Bob Doran that
 27818	was standing Alf a half one sucking up for what he could get. So of
 27819	course Bob Doran starts doing the bloody fool with him:
 27820	
 27821	--Give us the paw! Give the paw, doggy! Good old doggy! Give the paw
 27822	here! Give us the paw!
 27823	
 27824	Arrah, bloody end to the paw he'd paw and Alf trying to keep him from
 27825	tumbling off the bloody stool atop of the bloody old dog and he talking
 27826	all kinds of drivel about training by kindness and thoroughbred dog and
 27827	intelligent dog: give you the bloody pip. Then he starts scraping a few
 27828	bits of old biscuit out of the bottom of a Jacobs' tin he told Terry to
 27829	bring. Gob, he golloped it down like old boots and his tongue hanging
 27830	out of him a yard long for more. Near ate the tin and all, hungry bloody
 27831	mongrel.
 27832	
 27833	And the citizen and Bloom having an argument about the point, the
 27834	brothers Sheares and Wolfe Tone beyond on Arbour Hill and Robert Emmet
 27835	and die for your country, the Tommy Moore touch about Sara Curran and
 27836	she's far from the land. And Bloom, of course, with his knockmedown
 27837	cigar putting on swank with his lardy face. Phenomenon! The fat heap he
 27838	married is a nice old phenomenon with a back on her like a ballalley.
 27839	Time they were stopping up in the _City Arms_ pisser Burke told me there
 27840	was an old one there with a cracked loodheramaun of a nephew and Bloom
 27841	trying to get the soft side of her doing the mollycoddle playing bÃ©zique
 27842	to come in for a bit of the wampum in her will and not eating meat of a
 27843	Friday because the old one was always thumping her craw and taking the
 27844	lout out for a walk. And one time he led him the rounds of Dublin and,
 27845	by the holy farmer, he never cried crack till he brought him home as
 27846	drunk as a boiled owl and he said he did it to teach him the evils of
 27847	alcohol and by herrings, if the three women didn't near roast him, it's
 27848	a queer story, the old one, Bloom's wife and Mrs O'Dowd that kept the
 27849	hotel. Jesus, I had to laugh at pisser Burke taking them off chewing
 27850	the fat. And Bloom with his _but don't you see?_ and _but on the other
 27851	hand_. And sure, more be token, the lout I'm told was in Power's after,
 27852	the blender's, round in Cope street going home footless in a cab five
 27853	times in the week after drinking his way through all the samples in the
 27854	bloody establishment. Phenomenon!
 27855	
 27856	--The memory of the dead, says the citizen taking up his pintglass and
 27857	glaring at Bloom.
 27858	
 27859	--Ay, ay, says Joe.
 27860	
 27861	--You don't grasp my point, says Bloom. What I mean is...
 27862	
 27863	--_Sinn Fein!_ says the citizen. _Sinn Fein amhain!_ The friends we love
 27864	are by our side and the foes we hate before us.
 27865	
 27866	The last farewell was affecting in the extreme. From the belfries far
 27867	and near the funereal deathbell tolled unceasingly while all around the
 27868	gloomy precincts rolled the ominous warning of a hundred muffled drums
 27869	punctuated by the hollow booming of pieces of ordnance. The deafening
 27870	claps of thunder and the dazzling flashes of lightning which lit up
 27871	the ghastly scene testified that the artillery of heaven had lent its
 27872	supernatural pomp to the already gruesome spectacle. A torrential rain
 27873	poured down from the floodgates of the angry heavens upon the
 27874	bared heads of the assembled multitude which numbered at the
 27875	lowest computation five hundred thousand persons. A posse of Dublin
 27876	Metropolitan police superintended by the Chief Commissioner in person
 27877	maintained order in the vast throng for whom the York street brass and
 27878	reed band whiled away the intervening time by admirably rendering on
 27879	their blackdraped instruments the matchless melody endeared to us from
 27880	the cradle by Speranza's plaintive muse. Special quick excursion trains
 27881	and upholstered charabancs had been provided for the comfort of our
 27882	country cousins of whom there were large contingents. Considerable
 27883	amusement was caused by the favourite Dublin streetsingers L-n-h-n and
 27884	M-ll-g-n who sang _The Night before Larry was stretched_ in their usual
 27885	mirth-provoking fashion. Our two inimitable drolls did a roaring trade
 27886	with their broadsheets among lovers of the comedy element and nobody
 27887	who has a corner in his heart for real Irish fun without vulgarity
 27888	will grudge them their hardearned pennies. The children of the Male and
 27889	Female Foundling Hospital who thronged the windows overlooking the scene
 27890	were delighted with this unexpected addition to the day's entertainment
 27891	and a word of praise is due to the Little Sisters of the Poor for their
 27892	excellent idea of affording the poor fatherless and motherless children
 27893	a genuinely instructive treat. The viceregal houseparty which included
 27894	many wellknown ladies was chaperoned by Their Excellencies to the most
 27895	favourable positions on the grandstand while the picturesque foreign
 27896	delegation known as the Friends of the Emerald Isle was accommodated
 27897	on a tribune directly opposite. The delegation, present in full force,
 27898	consisted of Commendatore Bacibaci Beninobenone (the semiparalysed
 27899	_doyen_ of the party who had to be assisted to his seat by the aid of a
 27900	powerful steam crane), Monsieur Pierrepaul PetitÃ©patant, the Grandjoker
 27901	Vladinmire Pokethankertscheff, the Archjoker Leopold Rudolph von
 27902	Schwanzenbad-Hodenthaler, Countess Marha VirÃ¡ga KisÃ¡szony PutrÃ¡pesthi,
 27903	Hiram Y. Bomboost, Count Athanatos Karamelopulos, Ali Baba Backsheesh
 27904	Rahat Lokum Effendi, Senor Hidalgo Caballero Don Pecadillo y Palabras
 27905	y Paternoster de la Malora de la Malaria, Hokopoko Harakiri, Hi Hung
 27906	Chang, Olaf Kobberkeddelsen, Mynheer Trik van Trumps, Pan Poleaxe
 27907	Paddyrisky, Goosepond Prhklstr Kratchinabritchisitch, Borus
 27908	Hupinkoff, Herr Hurhausdirektorpresident Hans Chuechli-Steuerli,
 27909	Nationalgymnasiummuseumsanatoriumandsuspensoriumsordinaryprivatdocent
 27910	-generalhistoryspecialprofessordoctor Kriegfried Ueberallgemein. All the
 27911	delegates without exception expressed themselves in the strongest
 27912	possible heterogeneous terms concerning the nameless barbarity which
 27913	they had been called upon to witness. An animated altercation (in which
 27914	all took part) ensued among the F. O. T. E. I. as to whether the eighth
 27915	or the ninth of March was the correct date of the birth of Ireland's
 27916	patron saint. In the course of the argument cannonballs, scimitars,
 27917	boomerangs, blunderbusses, stinkpots, meatchoppers, umbrellas,
 27918	catapults, knuckledusters, sandbags, lumps of pig iron were resorted to
 27919	and blows were freely exchanged. The baby policeman, Constable
 27920	MacFadden, summoned by special courier from Booterstown, quickly
 27921	restored order and with lightning promptitude proposed the seventeenth
 27922	of the month as a solution equally honourable for both contending
 27923	parties. The readywitted ninefooter's suggestion at once appealed to all
 27924	and was unanimously accepted. Constable MacFadden was heartily
 27925	congratulated by all the F.O.T.E.I., several of whom were bleeding
 27926	profusely. Commendatore Beninobenone having been extricated from
 27927	underneath the presidential armchair, it was explained by his legal
 27928	adviser Avvocato Pagamimi that the various articles secreted in his
 27929	thirtytwo pockets had been abstracted by him during the affray from the
 27930	pockets of his junior colleagues in the hope of bringing them to their
 27931	senses. The objects (which included several hundred ladies' and
 27932	gentlemen's gold and silver watches) were promptly restored to their
 27933	rightful owners and general harmony reigned supreme.
 27934	
 27935	Quietly, unassumingly Rumbold stepped on to the scaffold in faultless
 27936	morning dress and wearing his favourite flower, the _Gladiolus
 27937	Cruentus_. He announced his presence by that gentle Rumboldian cough
 27938	which so many have tried (unsuccessfully) to imitate--short,
 27939	painstaking yet withal so characteristic of the man. The arrival of the
 27940	worldrenowned headsman was greeted by a roar of acclamation from the
 27941	huge concourse, the viceregal ladies waving their handkerchiefs in
 27942	their excitement while the even more excitable foreign delegates
 27943	cheered vociferously in a medley of cries, _hoch, banzai, eljen, zivio,
 27944	chinchin, polla kronia, hiphip, vive, Allah_, amid which the ringing
 27945	_evviva_ of the delegate of the land of song (a high double F recalling
 27946	those piercingly lovely notes with which the eunuch Catalani beglamoured
 27947	our greatgreatgrandmothers) was easily distinguishable. It was exactly
 27948	seventeen o'clock. The signal for prayer was then promptly given by
 27949	megaphone and in an instant all heads were bared, the commendatore's
 27950	patriarchal sombrero, which has been in the possession of his family
 27951	since the revolution of Rienzi, being removed by his medical adviser
 27952	in attendance, Dr Pippi. The learned prelate who administered the last
 27953	comforts of holy religion to the hero martyr when about to pay the death
 27954	penalty knelt in a most christian spirit in a pool of rainwater, his
 27955	cassock above his hoary head, and offered up to the throne of grace
 27956	fervent prayers of supplication. Hand by the block stood the grim figure
 27957	of the executioner, his visage being concealed in a tengallon pot
 27958	with two circular perforated apertures through which his eyes glowered
 27959	furiously. As he awaited the fatal signal he tested the edge of his
 27960	horrible weapon by honing it upon his brawny forearm or decapitated
 27961	in rapid succession a flock of sheep which had been provided by the
 27962	admirers of his fell but necessary office. On a handsome mahogany table
 27963	near him were neatly arranged the quartering knife, the various
 27964	finely tempered disembowelling appliances (specially supplied by the
 27965	worldfamous firm of cutlers, Messrs John Round and Sons, Sheffield),
 27966	a terra cotta saucepan for the reception of the duodenum, colon,
 27967	blind intestine and appendix etc when successfully extracted and two
 27968	commodious milkjugs destined to receive the most precious blood of the
 27969	most precious victim. The housesteward of the amalgamated cats' and
 27970	dogs' home was in attendance to convey these vessels when replenished
 27971	to that beneficent institution. Quite an excellent repast consisting of
 27972	rashers and eggs, fried steak and onions, done to a nicety, delicious
 27973	hot breakfast rolls and invigorating tea had been considerately provided
 27974	by the authorities for the consumption of the central figure of the
 27975	tragedy who was in capital spirits when prepared for death and evinced
 27976	the keenest interest in the proceedings from beginning to end but he,
 27977	with an abnegation rare in these our times, rose nobly to the occasion
 27978	and expressed the dying wish (immediately acceded to) that the meal
 27979	should be divided in aliquot parts among the members of the sick and
 27980	indigent roomkeepers' association as a token of his regard and esteem.
 27981	The _nec_ and _non plus ultra_ of emotion were reached when the blushing
 27982	bride elect burst her way through the serried ranks of the bystanders
 27983	and flung herself upon the muscular bosom of him who was about to be
 27984	launched into eternity for her sake. The hero folded her willowy form in
 27985	a loving embrace murmuring fondly _Sheila, my own_. Encouraged by
 27986	this use of her christian name she kissed passionately all the various
 27987	suitable areas of his person which the decencies of prison garb
 27988	permitted her ardour to reach. She swore to him as they mingled the salt
 27989	streams of their tears that she would ever cherish his memory, that she
 27990	would never forget her hero boy who went to his death with a song on his
 27991	lips as if he were but going to a hurling match in Clonturk park. She
 27992	brought back to his recollection the happy days of blissful childhood
 27993	together on the banks of Anna Liffey when they had indulged in the
 27994	innocent pastimes of the young and, oblivious of the dreadful present,
 27995	they both laughed heartily, all the spectators, including the venerable
 27996	pastor, joining in the general merriment. That monster audience simply
 27997	rocked with delight. But anon they were overcome with grief and clasped
 27998	their hands for the last time. A fresh torrent of tears burst from their
 27999	lachrymal ducts and the vast concourse of people, touched to the inmost
 28000	core, broke into heartrending sobs, not the least affected being the
 28001	aged prebendary himself. Big strong men, officers of the peace and
 28002	genial giants of the royal Irish constabulary, were making frank use of
 28003	their handkerchiefs and it is safe to say that there was not a dry eye
 28004	in that record assemblage. A most romantic incident occurred when a
 28005	handsome young Oxford graduate, noted for his chivalry towards the fair
 28006	sex, stepped forward and, presenting his visiting card, bankbook
 28007	and genealogical tree, solicited the hand of the hapless young lady,
 28008	requesting her to name the day, and was accepted on the spot. Every lady
 28009	in the audience was presented with a tasteful souvenir of the occasion
 28010	in the shape of a skull and crossbones brooch, a timely and generous
 28011	act which evoked a fresh outburst of emotion: and when the gallant young
 28012	Oxonian (the bearer, by the way, of one of the most timehonoured names
 28013	in Albion's history) placed on the finger of his blushing _fiancÃ©e_ an
 28014	expensive engagement ring with emeralds set in the form of a
 28015	fourleaved shamrock the excitement knew no bounds. Nay, even the
 28016	ster provostmarshal, lieutenantcolonel Tomkin-Maxwell ffrenchmullan
 28017	Tomlinson, who presided on the sad occasion, he who had blown a
 28018	considerable number of sepoys from the cannonmouth without flinching,
 28019	could not now restrain his natural emotion. With his mailed gauntlet
 28020	he brushed away a furtive tear and was overheard, by those privileged
 28021	burghers who happened to be in his immediate _entourage,_ to murmur to
 28022	himself in a faltering undertone:
 28023	
 28024	--God blimey if she aint a clinker, that there bleeding tart. Blimey it
 28025	makes me kind of bleeding cry, straight, it does, when I sees her cause
 28026	I thinks of my old mashtub what's waiting for me down Limehouse way.
 28027	
 28028	So then the citizen begins talking about the Irish language and the
 28029	corporation meeting and all to that and the shoneens that can't speak
 28030	their own language and Joe chipping in because he stuck someone for a
 28031	quid and Bloom putting in his old goo with his twopenny stump that
 28032	he cadged off of Joe and talking about the Gaelic league and the
 28033	antitreating league and drink, the curse of Ireland. Antitreating is
 28034	about the size of it. Gob, he'd let you pour all manner of drink down
 28035	his throat till the Lord would call him before you'd ever see the froth
 28036	of his pint. And one night I went in with a fellow into one of their
 28037	musical evenings, song and dance about she could get up on a truss of
 28038	hay she could my Maureen Lay and there was a fellow with a Ballyhooly
 28039	blue ribbon badge spiffing out of him in Irish and a lot of colleen
 28040	bawns going about with temperance beverages and selling medals
 28041	and oranges and lemonade and a few old dry buns, gob, flahoolagh
 28042	entertainment, don't be talking. Ireland sober is Ireland free. And
 28043	then an old fellow starts blowing into his bagpipes and all the gougers
 28044	shuffling their feet to the tune the old cow died of. And one or two
 28045	sky pilots having an eye around that there was no goings on with the
 28046	females, hitting below the belt.
 28047	
 28048	So howandever, as I was saying, the old dog seeing the tin was empty
 28049	starts mousing around by Joe and me. I'd train him by kindness, so I
 28050	would, if he was my dog. Give him a rousing fine kick now and again
 28051	where it wouldn't blind him.
 28052	
 28053	--Afraid he'll bite you? says the citizen, jeering.
 28054	
 28055	--No, says I. But he might take my leg for a lamppost.
 28056	
 28057	So he calls the old dog over.
 28058	
 28059	--What's on you, Garry? says he.
 28060	
 28061	Then he starts hauling and mauling and talking to him in Irish and the
 28062	old towser growling, letting on to answer, like a duet in the opera.
 28063	Such growling you never heard as they let off between them. Someone that
 28064	has nothing better to do ought to write a letter _pro bono publico_ to
 28065	the papers about the muzzling order for a dog the like of that. Growling
 28066	and grousing and his eye all bloodshot from the drouth is in it and the
 28067	hydrophobia dropping out of his jaws.
 28068	
 28069	All those who are interested in the spread of human culture among the
 28070	lower animals (and their name is legion) should make a point of not
 28071	missing the really marvellous exhibition of cynanthropy given by the
 28072	famous old Irish red setter wolfdog formerly known by the _sobriquet_ of
 28073	Garryowen and recently rechristened by his large circle of friends and
 28074	acquaintances Owen Garry. The exhibition, which is the result of years
 28075	of training by kindness and a carefully thoughtout dietary system,
 28076	comprises, among other achievements, the recitation of verse. Our
 28077	greatest living phonetic expert (wild horses shall not drag it from us!)
 28078	has left no stone unturned in his efforts to delucidate and compare
 28079	the verse recited and has found it bears a _striking_ resemblance (the
 28080	italics are ours) to the ranns of ancient Celtic bards. We are not
 28081	speaking so much of those delightful lovesongs with which the writer who
 28082	conceals his identity under the graceful pseudonym of the Little
 28083	Sweet Branch has familiarised the bookloving world but rather (as
 28084	a contributor D. O. C. points out in an interesting communication
 28085	published by an evening contemporary) of the harsher and more personal
 28086	note which is found in the satirical effusions of the famous Raftery and
 28087	of Donal MacConsidine to say nothing of a more modern lyrist at present
 28088	very much in the public eye. We subjoin a specimen which has been
 28089	rendered into English by an eminent scholar whose name for the moment we
 28090	are not at liberty to disclose though we believe that our readers will
 28091	find the topical allusion rather more than an indication. The metrical
 28092	system of the canine original, which recalls the intricate alliterative
 28093	and isosyllabic rules of the Welsh englyn, is infinitely more
 28094	complicated but we believe our readers will agree that the spirit has
 28095	been well caught. Perhaps it should be added that the effect is greatly
 28096	increased if Owen's verse be spoken somewhat slowly and indistinctly in
 28097	a tone suggestive of suppressed rancour.
 28098	
 28099	     _The curse of my curses
 28100	     Seven days every day
 28101	     And seven dry Thursdays
 28102	     On you, Barney Kiernan,
 28103	     Has no sup of water
 28104	     To cool my courage,
 28105	     And my guts red roaring
 28106	     After Lowry's lights._
 28107	
 28108	So he told Terry to bring some water for the dog and, gob, you could
 28109	hear him lapping it up a mile off. And Joe asked him would he have
 28110	another.
 28111	
 28112	--I will, says he, _a chara_, to show there's no ill feeling.
 28113	
 28114	Gob, he's not as green as he's cabbagelooking. Arsing around from one
 28115	pub to another, leaving it to your own honour, with old Giltrap's dog
 28116	and getting fed up by the ratepayers and corporators. Entertainment for
 28117	man and beast. And says Joe:
 28118	
 28119	--Could you make a hole in another pint?
 28120	
 28121	--Could a swim duck? says I.
 28122	
 28123	--Same again, Terry, says Joe. Are you sure you won't have anything in
 28124	the way of liquid refreshment? says he.
 28125	
 28126	--Thank you, no, says Bloom. As a matter of fact I just wanted to meet
 28127	Martin Cunningham, don't you see, about this insurance of poor Dignam's.
 28128	Martin asked me to go to the house. You see, he, Dignam, I mean, didn't
 28129	serve any notice of the assignment on the company at the time and
 28130	nominally under the act the mortgagee can't recover on the policy.
 28131	
 28132	--Holy Wars, says Joe, laughing, that's a good one if old Shylock is
 28133	landed. So the wife comes out top dog, what?
 28134	
 28135	--Well, that's a point, says Bloom, for the wife's admirers.
 28136	
 28137	--Whose admirers? says Joe.
 28138	
 28139	--The wife's advisers, I mean, says Bloom.
 28140	
 28141	Then he starts all confused mucking it up about mortgagor under the act
 28142	like the lord chancellor giving it out on the bench and for the benefit
 28143	of the wife and that a trust is created but on the other hand that
 28144	Dignam owed Bridgeman the money and if now the wife or the widow
 28145	contested the mortgagee's right till he near had the head of me addled
 28146	with his mortgagor under the act. He was bloody safe he wasn't run in
 28147	himself under the act that time as a rogue and vagabond only he had a
 28148	friend in court. Selling bazaar tickets or what do you call it royal
 28149	Hungarian privileged lottery. True as you're there. O, commend me to an
 28150	israelite! Royal and privileged Hungarian robbery.
 28151	
 28152	So Bob Doran comes lurching around asking Bloom to tell Mrs Dignam he
 28153	was sorry for her trouble and he was very sorry about the funeral and
 28154	to tell her that he said and everyone who knew him said that there was
 28155	never a truer, a finer than poor little Willy that's dead to tell her.
 28156	Choking with bloody foolery. And shaking Bloom's hand doing the tragic
 28157	to tell her that. Shake hands, brother. You're a rogue and I'm another.
 28158	
 28159	--Let me, said he, so far presume upon our acquaintance which, however
 28160	slight it may appear if judged by the standard of mere time, is founded,
 28161	as I hope and believe, on a sentiment of mutual esteem as to request of
 28162	you this favour. But, should I have overstepped the limits of reserve
 28163	let the sincerity of my feelings be the excuse for my boldness.
 28164	
 28165	--No, rejoined the other, I appreciate to the full the motives which
 28166	actuate your conduct and I shall discharge the office you entrust to
 28167	me consoled by the reflection that, though the errand be one of sorrow,
 28168	this proof of your confidence sweetens in some measure the bitterness of
 28169	the cup.
 28170	
 28171	--Then suffer me to take your hand, said he. The goodness of your heart,
 28172	I feel sure, will dictate to you better than my inadequate words
 28173	the expressions which are most suitable to convey an emotion whose
 28174	poignancy, were I to give vent to my feelings, would deprive me even of
 28175	speech.
 28176	
 28177	And off with him and out trying to walk straight. Boosed at five
 28178	o'clock. Night he was near being lagged only Paddy Leonard knew the
 28179	bobby, 14A. Blind to the world up in a shebeen in Bride street after
 28180	closing time, fornicating with two shawls and a bully on guard, drinking
 28181	porter out of teacups. And calling himself a Frenchy for the shawls,
 28182	Joseph Manuo, and talking against the Catholic religion, and he serving
 28183	mass in Adam and Eve's when he was young with his eyes shut, who wrote
 28184	the new testament, and the old testament, and hugging and smugging. And
 28185	the two shawls killed with the laughing, picking his pockets, the bloody
 28186	fool and he spilling the porter all over the bed and the two shawls
 28187	screeching laughing at one another. _How is your testament? Have you got
 28188	an old testament?_ Only Paddy was passing there, I tell you what. Then
 28189	see him of a Sunday with his little concubine of a wife, and she wagging
 28190	her tail up the aisle of the chapel with her patent boots on her, no
 28191	less, and her violets, nice as pie, doing the little lady. Jack Mooney's
 28192	sister. And the old prostitute of a mother procuring rooms to street
 28193	couples. Gob, Jack made him toe the line. Told him if he didn't patch up
 28194	the pot, Jesus, he'd kick the shite out of him.
 28195	
 28196	So Terry brought the three pints.
 28197	
 28198	--Here, says Joe, doing the honours. Here, citizen.
 28199	
 28200	--_Slan leat_, says he.
 28201	
 28202	--Fortune, Joe, says I. Good health, citizen.
 28203	
 28204	Gob, he had his mouth half way down the tumbler already. Want a small
 28205	fortune to keep him in drinks.
 28206	
 28207	--Who is the long fellow running for the mayoralty, Alf? says Joe.
 28208	
 28209	--Friend of yours, says Alf.
 28210	
 28211	--Nannan? says Joe. The mimber?
 28212	
 28213	--I won't mention any names, says Alf.
 28214	
 28215	--I thought so, says Joe. I saw him up at that meeting now with William
 28216	Field, M. P., the cattle traders.
 28217
