 28218	--Hairy Iopas, says the citizen, that exploded volcano, the darling of
 28219	all countries and the idol of his own.
 28220	
 28221	So Joe starts telling the citizen about the foot and mouth disease
 28222	and the cattle traders and taking action in the matter and the citizen
 28223	sending them all to the rightabout and Bloom coming out with his
 28224	sheepdip for the scab and a hoose drench for coughing calves and the
 28225	guaranteed remedy for timber tongue. Because he was up one time in a
 28226	knacker's yard. Walking about with his book and pencil here's my head
 28227	and my heels are coming till Joe Cuffe gave him the order of the boot
 28228	for giving lip to a grazier. Mister Knowall. Teach your grandmother how
 28229	to milk ducks. Pisser Burke was telling me in the hotel the wife used
 28230	to be in rivers of tears some times with Mrs O'Dowd crying her eyes out
 28231	with her eight inches of fat all over her. Couldn't loosen her farting
 28232	strings but old cod's eye was waltzing around her showing her how to do
 28233	it. What's your programme today? Ay. Humane methods. Because the poor
 28234	animals suffer and experts say and the best known remedy that doesn't
 28235	cause pain to the animal and on the sore spot administer gently. Gob,
 28236	he'd have a soft hand under a hen.
 28237	
 28238	Ga Ga Gara. Klook Klook Klook. Black Liz is our hen. She lays eggs for
 28239	us. When she lays her egg she is so glad. Gara. Klook Klook Klook. Then
 28240	comes good uncle Leo. He puts his hand under black Liz and takes her
 28241	fresh egg. Ga ga ga ga Gara. Klook Klook Klook.
 28242	
 28243	--Anyhow, says Joe, Field and Nannetti are going over tonight to London
 28244	to ask about it on the floor of the house of commons.
 28245	
 28246	--Are you sure, says Bloom, the councillor is going? I wanted to see
 28247	him, as it happens.
 28248	
 28249	--Well, he's going off by the mailboat, says Joe, tonight.
 28250	
 28251	--That's too bad, says Bloom. I wanted particularly. Perhaps only Mr
 28252	Field is going. I couldn't phone. No. You're sure?
 28253	
 28254	--Nannan's going too, says Joe. The league told him to ask a question
 28255	tomorrow about the commissioner of police forbidding Irish games in the
 28256	park. What do you think of that, citizen? _The Sluagh na h-Eireann_.
 28257	
 28258	Mr Cowe Conacre (Multifarnham. Nat.): Arising out of the question of
 28259	my honourable friend, the member for Shillelagh, may I ask the right
 28260	honourable gentleman whether the government has issued orders that these
 28261	animals shall be slaughtered though no medical evidence is forthcoming
 28262	as to their pathological condition?
 28263	
 28264	Mr Allfours (Tamoshant. Con.): Honourable members are already in
 28265	possession of the evidence produced before a committee of the whole
 28266	house. I feel I cannot usefully add anything to that. The answer to the
 28267	honourable member's question is in the affirmative.
 28268	
 28269	Mr Orelli O'Reilly (Montenotte. Nat.): Have similar orders been issued
 28270	for the slaughter of human animals who dare to play Irish games in the
 28271	Phoenix park?
 28272	
 28273	Mr Allfours: The answer is in the negative.
 28274	
 28275	Mr Cowe Conacre: Has the right honourable gentleman's famous
 28276	Mitchelstown telegram inspired the policy of gentlemen on the Treasury
 28277	bench? (O! O!)
 28278	
 28279	Mr Allfours: I must have notice of that question.
 28280	
 28281	Mr Staylewit (Buncombe. Ind.): Don't hesitate to shoot.
 28282	
 28283	(Ironical opposition cheers.)
 28284	
 28285	The speaker: Order! Order!
 28286	
 28287	(The house rises. Cheers.)
 28288	
 28289	--There's the man, says Joe, that made the Gaelic sports revival. There
 28290	he is sitting there. The man that got away James Stephens. The champion
 28291	of all Ireland at putting the sixteen pound shot. What was your best
 28292	throw, citizen?
 28293	
 28294	--_Na bacleis_, says the citizen, letting on to be modest. There was a
 28295	time I was as good as the next fellow anyhow.
 28296	
 28297	--Put it there, citizen, says Joe. You were and a bloody sight better.
 28298	
 28299	--Is that really a fact? says Alf.
 28300	
 28301	--Yes, says Bloom. That's well known. Did you not know that?
 28302	
 28303	So off they started about Irish sports and shoneen games the like of
 28304	lawn tennis and about hurley and putting the stone and racy of the soil
 28305	and building up a nation once again and all to that. And of course Bloom
 28306	had to have his say too about if a fellow had a rower's heart violent
 28307	exercise was bad. I declare to my antimacassar if you took up a straw
 28308	from the bloody floor and if you said to Bloom: _Look at, Bloom. Do you
 28309	see that straw? That's a straw_. Declare to my aunt he'd talk about it
 28310	for an hour so he would and talk steady.
 28311	
 28312	A most interesting discussion took place in the ancient hall of _Brian
 28313	O'ciarnain's_ in _Sraid na Bretaine Bheag_, under the auspices of
 28314	_Sluagh na h-Eireann_, on the revival of ancient Gaelic sports and the
 28315	importance of physical culture, as understood in ancient Greece and
 28316	ancient Rome and ancient Ireland, for the development of the race.
 28317	The venerable president of the noble order was in the chair and the
 28318	attendance was of large dimensions. After an instructive discourse by
 28319	the chairman, a magnificent oration eloquently and forcibly expressed,
 28320	a most interesting and instructive discussion of the usual high standard
 28321	of excellence ensued as to the desirability of the revivability of
 28322	the ancient games and sports of our ancient Panceltic forefathers. The
 28323	wellknown and highly respected worker in the cause of our old tongue, Mr
 28324	Joseph M'Carthy Hynes, made an eloquent appeal for the resuscitation of
 28325	the ancient Gaelic sports and pastimes, practised morning and evening
 28326	by Finn MacCool, as calculated to revive the best traditions of manly
 28327	strength and prowess handed down to us from ancient ages. L. Bloom, who
 28328	met with a mixed reception of applause and hisses, having espoused the
 28329	negative the vocalist chairman brought the discussion to a close, in
 28330	response to repeated requests and hearty plaudits from all parts of
 28331	a bumper house, by a remarkably noteworthy rendering of the immortal
 28332	Thomas Osborne Davis' evergreen verses (happily too familiar to need
 28333	recalling here) _A nation once again_ in the execution of which the
 28334	veteran patriot champion may be said without fear of contradiction
 28335	to have fairly excelled himself. The Irish Caruso-Garibaldi was in
 28336	superlative form and his stentorian notes were heard to the greatest
 28337	advantage in the timehonoured anthem sung as only our citizen can sing
 28338	it. His superb highclass vocalism, which by its superquality greatly
 28339	enhanced his already international reputation, was vociferously
 28340	applauded by the large audience among which were to be noticed many
 28341	prominent members of the clergy as well as representatives of the press
 28342	and the bar and the other learned professions. The proceedings then
 28343	terminated.
 28344	
 28345	Amongst the clergy present were the very rev. William Delany, S. J., L.
 28346	L. D.; the rt rev. Gerald Molloy, D. D.; the rev. P. J. Kavanagh, C. S.
 28347	Sp.; the rev. T. Waters, C. C.; the rev. John M. Ivers, P. P.; the rev.
 28348	P. J. Cleary, O. S. F.; the rev. L. J. Hickey, O. P.; the very rev. Fr.
 28349	Nicholas, O. S. F. C.; the very rev. B. Gorman, O. D. C.; the rev. T.
 28350	Maher, S. J.; the very rev. James Murphy, S. J.; the rev. John Lavery,
 28351	V. F.; the very rev. William Doherty, D. D.; the rev. Peter Fagan, O.
 28352	M.; the rev. T. Brangan, O. S. A.; the rev. J. Flavin, C. C.; the
 28353	rev. M. A. Hackett, C. C.; the rev. W. Hurley, C. C.; the rt rev. Mgr
 28354	M'Manus, V. G.; the rev. B. R. Slattery, O. M. I.; the very rev. M.
 28355	D. Scally, P. P.; the rev. F. T. Purcell, O. P.; the very rev. Timothy
 28356	canon Gorman, P. P.; the rev. J. Flanagan, C. C. The laity included P.
 28357	Fay, T. Quirke, etc., etc.
 28358	
 28359	--Talking about violent exercise, says Alf, were you at that
 28360	Keogh-Bennett match?
 28361	
 28362	--No, says Joe.
 28363	
 28364	--I heard So and So made a cool hundred quid over it, says Alf.
 28365	
 28366	--Who? Blazes? says Joe.
 28367	
 28368	And says Bloom:
 28369	
 28370	--What I meant about tennis, for example, is the agility and training
 28371	the eye.
 28372	
 28373	--Ay, Blazes, says Alf. He let out that Myler was on the beer to run up
 28374	the odds and he swatting all the time.
 28375	
 28376	--We know him, says the citizen. The traitor's son. We know what put
 28377	English gold in his pocket.
 28378	
 28379	---True for you, says Joe.
 28380	
 28381	And Bloom cuts in again about lawn tennis and the circulation of the
 28382	blood, asking Alf:
 28383	
 28384	--Now, don't you think, Bergan?
 28385	
 28386	--Myler dusted the floor with him, says Alf. Heenan and Sayers was only
 28387	a bloody fool to it. Handed him the father and mother of a beating. See
 28388	the little kipper not up to his navel and the big fellow swiping. God,
 28389	he gave him one last puck in the wind, Queensberry rules and all, made
 28390	him puke what he never ate.
 28391	
 28392	It was a historic and a hefty battle when Myler and Percy were scheduled
 28393	to don the gloves for the purse of fifty sovereigns. Handicapped as he
 28394	was by lack of poundage, Dublin's pet lamb made up for it by superlative
 28395	skill in ringcraft. The final bout of fireworks was a gruelling for both
 28396	champions. The welterweight sergeantmajor had tapped some lively claret
 28397	in the previous mixup during which Keogh had been receivergeneral of
 28398	rights and lefts, the artilleryman putting in some neat work on the
 28399	pet's nose, and Myler came on looking groggy. The soldier got to
 28400	business, leading off with a powerful left jab to which the Irish
 28401	gladiator retaliated by shooting out a stiff one flush to the point of
 28402	Bennett's jaw. The redcoat ducked but the Dubliner lifted him with a
 28403	left hook, the body punch being a fine one. The men came to handigrips.
 28404	Myler quickly became busy and got his man under, the bout ending with
 28405	the bulkier man on the ropes, Myler punishing him. The Englishman, whose
 28406	right eye was nearly closed, took his corner where he was liberally
 28407	drenched with water and when the bell went came on gamey and brimful of
 28408	pluck, confident of knocking out the fistic Eblanite in jigtime. It was
 28409	a fight to a finish and the best man for it. The two fought like tigers
 28410	and excitement ran fever high. The referee twice cautioned Pucking Percy
 28411	for holding but the pet was tricky and his footwork a treat to watch.
 28412	After a brisk exchange of courtesies during which a smart upper cut of
 28413	the military man brought blood freely from his opponent's mouth the
 28414	lamb suddenly waded in all over his man and landed a terrific left to
 28415	Battling Bennett's stomach, flooring him flat. It was a knockout clean
 28416	and clever. Amid tense expectation the Portobello bruiser was being
 28417	counted out when Bennett's second Ole Pfotts Wettstein threw in the
 28418	towel and the Santry boy was declared victor to the frenzied cheers of
 28419	the public who broke through the ringropes and fairly mobbed him with
 28420	delight.
 28421	
 28422	--He knows which side his bread is buttered, says Alf. I hear he's
 28423	running a concert tour now up in the north.
 28424	
 28425	--He is, says Joe. Isn't he?
 28426	
 28427	--Who? says Bloom. Ah, yes. That's quite true. Yes, a kind of summer
 28428	tour, you see. Just a holiday.
 28429	
 28430	--Mrs B. is the bright particular star, isn't she? says Joe.
 28431	
 28432	--My wife? says Bloom. She's singing, yes. I think it will be a success
 28433	too.
 28434	
 28435	He's an excellent man to organise. Excellent.
 28436	
 28437	Hoho begob says I to myself says I. That explains the milk in the
 28438	cocoanut and absence of hair on the animal's chest. Blazes doing the
 28439	tootle on the flute. Concert tour. Dirty Dan the dodger's son off Island
 28440	bridge that sold the same horses twice over to the government to fight
 28441	the Boers. Old Whatwhat. I called about the poor and water rate, Mr
 28442	Boylan. You what? The water rate, Mr Boylan. You whatwhat? That's the
 28443	bucko that'll organise her, take my tip. 'Twixt me and you Caddareesh.
 28444	
 28445	Pride of Calpe's rocky mount, the ravenhaired daughter of Tweedy. There
 28446	grew she to peerless beauty where loquat and almond scent the air. The
 28447	gardens of Alameda knew her step: the garths of olives knew and bowed.
 28448	The chaste spouse of Leopold is she: Marion of the bountiful bosoms.
 28449	
 28450	And lo, there entered one of the clan of the O'Molloy's, a comely hero
 28451	of white face yet withal somewhat ruddy, his majesty's counsel learned
 28452	in the law, and with him the prince and heir of the noble line of
 28453	Lambert.
 28454	
 28455	--Hello, Ned.
 28456	
 28457	--Hello, Alf.
 28458	
 28459	--Hello, Jack.
 28460	
 28461	--Hello, Joe.
 28462	
 28463	--God save you, says the citizen.
 28464	
 28465	--Save you kindly, says J. J. What'll it be, Ned?
 28466	
 28467	--Half one, says Ned.
 28468	
 28469	So J. J. ordered the drinks.
 28470	
 28471	--Were you round at the court? says Joe.
 28472	
 28473	--Yes, says J. J. He'll square that, Ned, says he.
 28474	
 28475	--Hope so, says Ned.
 28476	
 28477	Now what were those two at? J. J. getting him off the grand jury list
 28478	and the other give him a leg over the stile. With his name in Stubbs's.
 28479	Playing cards, hobnobbing with flash toffs with a swank glass in their
 28480	eye, adrinking fizz and he half smothered in writs and garnishee orders.
 28481	Pawning his gold watch in Cummins of Francis street where no-one would
 28482	know him in the private office when I was there with Pisser releasing
 28483	his boots out of the pop. What's your name, sir? Dunne, says he. Ay, and
 28484	done says I. Gob, he'll come home by weeping cross one of those days,
 28485	I'm thinking.
 28486	
 28487	--Did you see that bloody lunatic Breen round there? says Alf. U. p: up.
 28488	
 28489	--Yes, says J. J. Looking for a private detective.
 28490	
 28491	--Ay, says Ned. And he wanted right go wrong to address the court only
 28492	Corny Kelleher got round him telling him to get the handwriting examined
 28493	first.
 28494	
 28495	--Ten thousand pounds, says Alf, laughing. God, I'd give anything to
 28496	hear him before a judge and jury.
 28497	
 28498	--Was it you did it, Alf? says Joe. The truth, the whole truth and
 28499	nothing but the truth, so help you Jimmy Johnson.
 28500	
 28501	--Me? says Alf. Don't cast your nasturtiums on my character.
 28502	
 28503	--Whatever statement you make, says Joe, will be taken down in evidence
 28504	against you.
 28505	
 28506	--Of course an action would lie, says J. J. It implies that he is not
 28507	_compos mentis_. U. p: up.
 28508	
 28509	_--Compos_ your eye! says Alf, laughing. Do you know that he's balmy?
 28510	Look at his head. Do you know that some mornings he has to get his hat
 28511	on with a shoehorn.
 28512	
 28513	--Yes, says J. J., but the truth of a libel is no defence to an
 28514	indictment for publishing it in the eyes of the law.
 28515	
 28516	--Ha ha, Alf, says Joe.
 28517	
 28518	--Still, says Bloom, on account of the poor woman, I mean his wife.
 28519	
 28520	--Pity about her, says the citizen. Or any other woman marries a half
 28521	and half.
 28522	
 28523	--How half and half? says Bloom. Do you mean he...
 28524	
 28525	--Half and half I mean, says the citizen. A fellow that's neither fish
 28526	nor flesh.
 28527	
 28528	--Nor good red herring, says Joe.
 28529	
 28530	--That what's I mean, says the citizen. A pishogue, if you know what
 28531	that is.
 28532	
 28533	Begob I saw there was trouble coming. And Bloom explaining he meant on
 28534	account of it being cruel for the wife having to go round after the
 28535	old stuttering fool. Cruelty to animals so it is to let that bloody
 28536	povertystricken Breen out on grass with his beard out tripping him,
 28537	bringing down the rain. And she with her nose cockahoop after she
 28538	married him because a cousin of his old fellow's was pewopener to the
 28539	pope. Picture of him on the wall with his Smashall Sweeney's moustaches,
 28540	the signior Brini from Summerhill, the eyetallyano, papal Zouave to the
 28541	Holy Father, has left the quay and gone to Moss street. And who was
 28542	he, tell us? A nobody, two pair back and passages, at seven shillings a
 28543	week, and he covered with all kinds of breastplates bidding defiance to
 28544	the world.
 28545	
 28546	--And moreover, says J. J., a postcard is publication. It was held to
 28547	be sufficient evidence of malice in the testcase Sadgrove v. Hole. In my
 28548	opinion an action might lie.
 28549	
 28550	Six and eightpence, please. Who wants your opinion? Let us drink our
 28551	pints in peace. Gob, we won't be let even do that much itself.
 28552	
 28553	--Well, good health, Jack, says Ned.
 28554	
 28555	--Good health, Ned, says J. J.
 28556	
 28557	---There he is again, says Joe.
 28558	
 28559	--Where? says Alf.
 28560	
 28561	And begob there he was passing the door with his books under his oxter
 28562	and the wife beside him and Corny Kelleher with his wall eye looking in
 28563	as they went past, talking to him like a father, trying to sell him a
 28564	secondhand coffin.
 28565	
 28566	--How did that Canada swindle case go off? says Joe.
 28567	
 28568	--Remanded, says J. J.
 28569	
 28570	One of the bottlenosed fraternity it was went by the name of James
 28571	Wought alias Saphiro alias Spark and Spiro, put an ad in the papers
 28572	saying he'd give a passage to Canada for twenty bob. What? Do you see
 28573	any green in the white of my eye? Course it was a bloody barney. What?
 28574	Swindled them all, skivvies and badhachs from the county Meath, ay, and
 28575	his own kidney too. J. J. was telling us there was an ancient Hebrew
 28576	Zaretsky or something weeping in the witnessbox with his hat on him,
 28577	swearing by the holy Moses he was stuck for two quid.
 28578	
 28579	--Who tried the case? says Joe.
 28580	
 28581	--Recorder, says Ned.
 28582	
 28583	--Poor old sir Frederick, says Alf, you can cod him up to the two eyes.
 28584	
 28585	--Heart as big as a lion, says Ned. Tell him a tale of woe about arrears
 28586	of rent and a sick wife and a squad of kids and, faith, he'll dissolve
 28587	in tears on the bench.
 28588	
 28589	--Ay, says Alf. Reuben J was bloody lucky he didn't clap him in the dock
 28590	the other day for suing poor little Gumley that's minding stones, for
 28591	the corporation there near Butt bridge.
 28592	
 28593	And he starts taking off the old recorder letting on to cry:
 28594	
 28595	--A most scandalous thing! This poor hardworking man! How many children?
 28596	Ten, did you say?
 28597	
 28598	--Yes, your worship. And my wife has the typhoid.
 28599	
 28600	--And the wife with typhoid fever! Scandalous! Leave the court
 28601	immediately, sir. No, sir, I'll make no order for payment. How dare you,
 28602	sir, come up before me and ask me to make an order! A poor hardworking
 28603	industrious man! I dismiss the case.
 28604	
 28605	And whereas on the sixteenth day of the month of the oxeyed goddess and
 28606	in the third week after the feastday of the Holy and Undivided Trinity,
 28607	the daughter of the skies, the virgin moon being then in her first
 28608	quarter, it came to pass that those learned judges repaired them to the
 28609	halls of law. There master Courtenay, sitting in his own chamber, gave
 28610	his rede and master Justice Andrews, sitting without a jury in the
 28611	probate court, weighed well and pondered the claim of the first
 28612	chargeant upon the property in the matter of the will propounded and
 28613	final testamentary disposition _in re_ the real and personal estate of
 28614	the late lamented Jacob Halliday, vintner, deceased, versus Livingstone,
 28615	an infant, of unsound mind, and another. And to the solemn court of
 28616	Green street there came sir Frederick the Falconer. And he sat him there
 28617	about the hour of five o'clock to administer the law of the brehons at
 28618	the commission for all that and those parts to be holden in and for the
 28619	county of the city of Dublin. And there sat with him the high sinhedrim
 28620	of the twelve tribes of Iar, for every tribe one man, of the tribe of
 28621	Patrick and of the tribe of Hugh and of the tribe of Owen and of the
 28622	tribe of Conn and of the tribe of Oscar and of the tribe of Fergus and
 28623	of the tribe of Finn and of the tribe of Dermot and of the tribe of
 28624	Cormac and of the tribe of Kevin and of the tribe of Caolte and of the
 28625	tribe of Ossian, there being in all twelve good men and true. And he
 28626	conjured them by Him who died on rood that they should well and
 28627	truly try and true deliverance make in the issue joined between their
 28628	sovereign lord the king and the prisoner at the bar and true verdict
 28629	give according to the evidence so help them God and kiss the book. And
 28630	they rose in their seats, those twelve of Iar, and they swore by
 28631	the name of Him Who is from everlasting that they would do His
 28632	rightwiseness. And straightway the minions of the law led forth from
 28633	their donjon keep one whom the sleuthhounds of justice had apprehended
 28634	in consequence of information received. And they shackled him hand and
 28635	foot and would take of him ne bail ne mainprise but preferred a charge
 28636	against him for he was a malefactor.
 28637	
 28638	--Those are nice things, says the citizen, coming over here to Ireland
 28639	filling the country with bugs.
 28640	
 28641	So Bloom lets on he heard nothing and he starts talking with Joe,
 28642	telling him he needn't trouble about that little matter till the first
 28643	but if he would just say a word to Mr Crawford. And so Joe swore high
 28644	and holy by this and by that he'd do the devil and all.
 28645	
 28646	--Because, you see, says Bloom, for an advertisement you must have
 28647	repetition. That's the whole secret.
 28648	
 28649	--Rely on me, says Joe.
 28650	
 28651	--Swindling the peasants, says the citizen, and the poor of Ireland. We
 28652	want no more strangers in our house.
 28653	
 28654	--O, I'm sure that will be all right, Hynes, says Bloom. It's just that
 28655	Keyes, you see.
 28656	
 28657	--Consider that done, says Joe.
 28658	
 28659	--Very kind of you, says Bloom.
 28660	
 28661	--The strangers, says the citizen. Our own fault. We let them come in.
 28662	We brought them in. The adulteress and her paramour brought the Saxon
 28663	robbers here.
 28664	
 28665	--Decree _nisi,_ says J. J.
 28666	
 28667	And Bloom letting on to be awfully deeply interested in nothing, a
 28668	spider's web in the corner behind the barrel, and the citizen scowling
 28669	after him and the old dog at his feet looking up to know who to bite and
 28670	when.
 28671	
 28672	--A dishonoured wife, says the citizen, that's what's the cause of all
 28673	our misfortunes.
 28674	
 28675	--And here she is, says Alf, that was giggling over the _Police Gazette_
 28676	with Terry on the counter, in all her warpaint.
 28677	
 28678	--Give us a squint at her, says I.
 28679	
 28680	And what was it only one of the smutty yankee pictures Terry borrows off
 28681	of Corny Kelleher. Secrets for enlarging your private parts. Misconduct
 28682	of society belle. Norman W. Tupper, wealthy Chicago contractor, finds
 28683	pretty but faithless wife in lap of officer Taylor. Belle in her
 28684	bloomers misconducting herself, and her fancyman feeling for her tickles
 28685	and Norman W. Tupper bouncing in with his peashooter just in time to be
 28686	late after she doing the trick of the loop with officer Taylor.
 28687	
 28688	--O jakers, Jenny, says Joe, how short your shirt is!
 28689	
 28690	--There's hair, Joe, says I. Get a queer old tailend of corned beef off
 28691	of that one, what?
 28692	
 28693	So anyhow in came John Wyse Nolan and Lenehan with him with a face on
 28694	him as long as a late breakfast.
 28695	
 28696	--Well, says the citizen, what's the latest from the scene of action?
 28697	What did those tinkers in the city hall at their caucus meeting decide
 28698	about the Irish language?
 28699	
 28700	O'Nolan, clad in shining armour, low bending made obeisance to the
 28701	puissant and high and mighty chief of all Erin and did him to wit of
 28702	that which had befallen, how that the grave elders of the most obedient
 28703	city, second of the realm, had met them in the tholsel, and there, after
 28704	due prayers to the gods who dwell in ether supernal, had taken solemn
 28705	counsel whereby they might, if so be it might be, bring once more into
 28706	honour among mortal men the winged speech of the seadivided Gael.
 28707	
 28708	--It's on the march, says the citizen. To hell with the bloody brutal
 28709	Sassenachs and their _patois._
 28710	
 28711	So J. J. puts in a word, doing the toff about one story was good till
 28712	you heard another and blinking facts and the Nelson policy, putting your
 28713	blind eye to the telescope and drawing up a bill of attainder to impeach
 28714	a nation, and Bloom trying to back him up moderation and botheration and
 28715	their colonies and their civilisation.
 28716	
 28717	--Their syphilisation, you mean, says the citizen. To hell with
 28718	them! The curse of a goodfornothing God light sideways on the bloody
 28719	thicklugged sons of whores' gets! No music and no art and no literature
 28720	worthy of the name. Any civilisation they have they stole from us.
 28721	Tonguetied sons of bastards' ghosts.
 28722	
 28723	--The European family, says J. J....
 28724	
 28725	--They're not European, says the citizen. I was in Europe with Kevin
 28726	Egan of Paris. You wouldn't see a trace of them or their language
 28727	anywhere in Europe except in a _cabinet d'aisance._
 28728	
 28729	And says John Wyse:
 28730	
 28731	--Full many a flower is born to blush unseen.
 28732	
 28733	And says Lenehan that knows a bit of the lingo:
 28734	
 28735	--_Conspuez les Anglais! Perfide Albion!_
 28736	
 28737	He said and then lifted he in his rude great brawny strengthy hands the
 28738	medher of dark strong foamy ale and, uttering his tribal slogan _Lamh
 28739	Dearg Abu_, he drank to the undoing of his foes, a race of mighty
 28740	valorous heroes, rulers of the waves, who sit on thrones of alabaster
 28741	silent as the deathless gods.
 28742	
 28743	--What's up with you, says I to Lenehan. You look like a fellow that had
 28744	lost a bob and found a tanner.
 28745	
 28746	--Gold cup, says he.
 28747	
 28748	--Who won, Mr Lenehan? says Terry.
 28749	
 28750	_--Throwaway,_ says he, at twenty to one. A rank outsider. And the rest
 28751	nowhere.
 28752	
 28753	--And Bass's mare? says Terry.
 28754	
 28755	--Still running, says he. We're all in a cart. Boylan plunged two quid
 28756	on my tip _Sceptre_ for himself and a lady friend.
 28757	
 28758	--I had half a crown myself, says Terry, on _Zinfandel_ that Mr Flynn
 28759	gave me. Lord Howard de Walden's.
 28760	
 28761	--Twenty to one, says Lenehan. Such is life in an outhouse. _Throwaway,_
 28762	says he. Takes the biscuit, and talking about bunions. Frailty, thy name
 28763	is _Sceptre._
 28764	
 28765	So he went over to the biscuit tin Bob Doran left to see if there was
 28766	anything he could lift on the nod, the old cur after him backing his
 28767	luck with his mangy snout up. Old Mother Hubbard went to the cupboard.
 28768	
 28769	--Not there, my child, says he.
 28770	
 28771	--Keep your pecker up, says Joe. She'd have won the money only for the
 28772	other dog.
 28773	
 28774	And J. J. and the citizen arguing about law and history with Bloom
 28775	sticking in an odd word.
 28776	
 28777	--Some people, says Bloom, can see the mote in others' eyes but they
 28778	can't see the beam in their own.
 28779	
 28780	--_Raimeis_, says the citizen. There's no-one as blind as the fellow
 28781	that won't see, if you know what that means. Where are our missing
 28782	twenty millions of Irish should be here today instead of four, our lost
 28783	tribes? And our potteries and textiles, the finest in the whole world!
 28784	And our wool that was sold in Rome in the time of Juvenal and our flax
 28785	and our damask from the looms of Antrim and our Limerick lace, our
 28786	tanneries and our white flint glass down there by Ballybough and our
 28787	Huguenot poplin that we have since Jacquard de Lyon and our woven silk
 28788	and our Foxford tweeds and ivory raised point from the Carmelite convent
 28789	in New Ross, nothing like it in the whole wide world. Where are the
 28790	Greek merchants that came through the pillars of Hercules, the Gibraltar
 28791	now grabbed by the foe of mankind, with gold and Tyrian purple to
 28792	sell in Wexford at the fair of Carmen? Read Tacitus and Ptolemy, even
 28793	Giraldus Cambrensis. Wine, peltries, Connemara marble, silver from
 28794	Tipperary, second to none, our farfamed horses even today, the Irish
 28795	hobbies, with king Philip of Spain offering to pay customs duties for
 28796	the right to fish in our waters. What do the yellowjohns of Anglia owe
 28797	us for our ruined trade and our ruined hearths? And the beds of the
 28798	Barrow and Shannon they won't deepen with millions of acres of marsh and
 28799	bog to make us all die of consumption?
 28800	
 28801	--As treeless as Portugal we'll be soon, says John Wyse, or Heligoland
 28802	with its one tree if something is not done to reafforest the land.
 28803	Larches, firs, all the trees of the conifer family are going fast. I was
 28804	reading a report of lord Castletown's...
 28805	
 28806	--Save them, says the citizen, the giant ash of Galway and the chieftain
 28807	elm of Kildare with a fortyfoot bole and an acre of foliage. Save the
 28808	trees of Ireland for the future men of Ireland on the fair hills of
 28809	Eire, O.
 28810	
 28811	--Europe has its eyes on you, says Lenehan.
 28812	
 28813	The fashionable international world attended EN MASSE this afternoon
 28814	at the wedding of the chevalier Jean Wyse de Neaulan, grand high chief
 28815	ranger of the Irish National Foresters, with Miss Fir Conifer of Pine
 28816	Valley. Lady Sylvester Elmshade, Mrs Barbara Lovebirch, Mrs Poll Ash,
 28817	Mrs Holly Hazeleyes, Miss Daphne Bays, Miss Dorothy Canebrake, Mrs Clyde
 28818	Twelvetrees, Mrs Rowan Greene, Mrs Helen Vinegadding, Miss Virginia
 28819	Creeper, Miss Gladys Beech, Miss Olive Garth, Miss Blanche Maple, Mrs
 28820	Maud Mahogany, Miss Myra Myrtle, Miss Priscilla Elderflower, Miss
 28821	Bee Honeysuckle, Miss Grace Poplar, Miss O Mimosa San, Miss Rachel
 28822	Cedarfrond, the Misses Lilian and Viola Lilac, Miss Timidity Aspenall,
 28823	Mrs Kitty Dewey-Mosse, Miss May Hawthorne, Mrs Gloriana Palme, Mrs Liana
 28824	Forrest, Mrs Arabella Blackwood and Mrs Norma Holyoake of Oakholme Regis
 28825	graced the ceremony by their presence. The bride who was given away by
 28826	her father, the M'Conifer of the Glands, looked exquisitely charming in
 28827	a creation carried out in green mercerised silk, moulded on an underslip
 28828	of gloaming grey, sashed with a yoke of broad emerald and finished with
 28829	a triple flounce of darkerhued fringe, the scheme being relieved by
 28830	bretelles and hip insertions of acorn bronze. The maids of honour, Miss
 28831	Larch Conifer and Miss Spruce Conifer, sisters of the bride, wore very
 28832	becoming costumes in the same tone, a dainty _motif_ of plume rose being
 28833	worked into the pleats in a pinstripe and repeated capriciously in the
 28834	jadegreen toques in the form of heron feathers of paletinted coral.
 28835	Senhor Enrique Flor presided at the organ with his wellknown ability
 28836	and, in addition to the prescribed numbers of the nuptial mass, played
 28837	a new and striking arrangement of _Woodman, spare that tree_ at the
 28838	conclusion of the service. On leaving the church of Saint Fiacre _in
 28839	Horto_ after the papal blessing the happy pair were subjected to a
 28840	playful crossfire of hazelnuts, beechmast, bayleaves, catkins of willow,
 28841	ivytod, hollyberries, mistletoe sprigs and quicken shoots. Mr and Mrs
 28842	Wyse Conifer Neaulan will spend a quiet honeymoon in the Black Forest.
 28843	
 28844	--And our eyes are on Europe, says the citizen. We had our trade with
 28845	Spain and the French and with the Flemings before those mongrels were
 28846	pupped, Spanish ale in Galway, the winebark on the winedark waterway.
 28847	
 28848	--And will again, says Joe.
 28849	
 28850	--And with the help of the holy mother of God we will again, says the
 28851	citizen, clapping his thigh, our harbours that are empty will be full
 28852	again, Queenstown, Kinsale, Galway, Blacksod Bay, Ventry in the kingdom
 28853	of Kerry, Killybegs, the third largest harbour in the wide world with
 28854	a fleet of masts of the Galway Lynches and the Cavan O'Reillys and the
 28855	O'Kennedys of Dublin when the earl of Desmond could make a treaty with
 28856	the emperor Charles the Fifth himself. And will again, says he, when the
 28857	first Irish battleship is seen breasting the waves with our own flag to
 28858	the fore, none of your Henry Tudor's harps, no, the oldest flag afloat,
 28859	the flag of the province of Desmond and Thomond, three crowns on a blue
 28860	field, the three sons of Milesius.
 28861	
 28862	And he took the last swig out of the pint. Moya. All wind and piss like
 28863	a tanyard cat. Cows in Connacht have long horns. As much as his bloody
 28864	life is worth to go down and address his tall talk to the assembled
 28865	multitude in Shanagolden where he daren't show his nose with the Molly
 28866	Maguires looking for him to let daylight through him for grabbing the
 28867	holding of an evicted tenant.
 28868	
 28869	--Hear, hear to that, says John Wyse. What will you have?
 28870	
 28871	--An imperial yeomanry, says Lenehan, to celebrate the occasion.
 28872	
 28873	--Half one, Terry, says John Wyse, and a hands up. Terry! Are you
 28874	asleep?
 28875	
 28876	--Yes, sir, says Terry. Small whisky and bottle of Allsop. Right, sir.
 28877	
 28878	Hanging over the bloody paper with Alf looking for spicy bits instead of
 28879	attending to the general public. Picture of a butting match, trying to
 28880	crack their bloody skulls, one chap going for the other with his head
 28881	down like a bull at a gate. And another one: _Black Beast Burned in
 28882	Omaha, Ga_. A lot of Deadwood Dicks in slouch hats and they firing at a
 28883	Sambo strung up in a tree with his tongue out and a bonfire under
 28884	him. Gob, they ought to drown him in the sea after and electrocute and
 28885	crucify him to make sure of their job.
 28886	
 28887	--But what about the fighting navy, says Ned, that keeps our foes at
 28888	bay?
 28889	
 28890	--I'll tell you what about it, says the citizen. Hell upon earth it is.
 28891	Read the revelations that's going on in the papers about flogging on
 28892	the training ships at Portsmouth. A fellow writes that calls himself
 28893	_Disgusted One_.
 28894	
 28895	So he starts telling us about corporal punishment and about the crew
 28896	of tars and officers and rearadmirals drawn up in cocked hats and the
 28897	parson with his protestant bible to witness punishment and a young lad
 28898	brought out, howling for his ma, and they tie him down on the buttend of
 28899	a gun.
 28900	
 28901	--A rump and dozen, says the citizen, was what that old ruffian sir John
 28902	Beresford called it but the modern God's Englishman calls it caning on
 28903	the breech.
 28904	
 28905	And says John Wyse:
 28906	
 28907	--'Tis a custom more honoured in the breach than in the observance.
 28908	
 28909	Then he was telling us the master at arms comes along with a long cane
 28910	and he draws out and he flogs the bloody backside off of the poor lad
 28911	till he yells meila murder.
 28912	
 28913	--That's your glorious British navy, says the citizen, that bosses the
 28914	earth.
 28915	
 28916	The fellows that never will be slaves, with the only hereditary chamber
 28917	on the face of God's earth and their land in the hands of a dozen
 28918	gamehogs and cottonball barons. That's the great empire they boast about
 28919	of drudges and whipped serfs.
 28920	
 28921	--On which the sun never rises, says Joe.
 28922	
 28923	--And the tragedy of it is, says the citizen, they believe it. The
 28924	unfortunate yahoos believe it.
 28925	
 28926	They believe in rod, the scourger almighty, creator of hell upon earth,
 28927	and in Jacky Tar, the son of a gun, who was conceived of unholy boast,
 28928	born of the fighting navy, suffered under rump and dozen, was scarified,
 28929	flayed and curried, yelled like bloody hell, the third day he arose
 28930	again from the bed, steered into haven, sitteth on his beamend till
 28931	further orders whence he shall come to drudge for a living and be paid.
 28932	
 28933	--But, says Bloom, isn't discipline the same everywhere. I mean wouldn't
 28934	it be the same here if you put force against force?
 28935	
 28936	Didn't I tell you? As true as I'm drinking this porter if he was at his
 28937	last gasp he'd try to downface you that dying was living.
 28938	
 28939	--We'll put force against force, says the citizen. We have our greater
 28940	Ireland beyond the sea. They were driven out of house and home in the
 28941	black 47. Their mudcabins and their shielings by the roadside were laid
 28942	low by the batteringram and the _Times_ rubbed its hands and told the
 28943	whitelivered Saxons there would soon be as few Irish in Ireland as
 28944	redskins in America. Even the Grand Turk sent us his piastres. But the
 28945	Sassenach tried to starve the nation at home while the land was full
 28946	of crops that the British hyenas bought and sold in Rio de Janeiro. Ay,
 28947	they drove out the peasants in hordes. Twenty thousand of them died in
 28948	the coffinships. But those that came to the land of the free remember
 28949	the land of bondage. And they will come again and with a vengeance, no
 28950	cravens, the sons of Granuaile, the champions of Kathleen ni Houlihan.
 28951	
 28952	--Perfectly true, says Bloom. But my point was...
 28953	
 28954	--We are a long time waiting for that day, citizen, says Ned. Since the
 28955	poor old woman told us that the French were on the sea and landed at
 28956	Killala.
 28957	
 28958	--Ay, says John Wyse. We fought for the royal Stuarts that reneged us
 28959	against the Williamites and they betrayed us. Remember Limerick and the
 28960	broken treatystone. We gave our best blood to France and Spain, the
 28961	wild geese. Fontenoy, eh? And Sarsfield and O'Donnell, duke of Tetuan
 28962	in Spain, and Ulysses Browne of Camus that was fieldmarshal to Maria
 28963	Teresa. But what did we ever get for it?
 28964	
 28965	--The French! says the citizen. Set of dancing masters! Do you know
 28966	what it is? They were never worth a roasted fart to Ireland. Aren't they
 28967	trying to make an _Entente cordiale_ now at Tay Pay's dinnerparty with
 28968	perfidious Albion? Firebrands of Europe and they always were.
 28969	
 28970	--_Conspuez les FranÃ§ais_, says Lenehan, nobbling his beer.
 28971	
 28972	--And as for the Prooshians and the Hanoverians, says Joe, haven't we
 28973	had enough of those sausageeating bastards on the throne from George the
 28974	elector down to the German lad and the flatulent old bitch that's dead?
 28975	
 28976	Jesus, I had to laugh at the way he came out with that about the old one
 28977	with the winkers on her, blind drunk in her royal palace every night of
 28978	God, old Vic, with her jorum of mountain dew and her coachman carting
 28979	her up body and bones to roll into bed and she pulling him by the
 28980	whiskers and singing him old bits of songs about _Ehren on the Rhine_
 28981	and come where the boose is cheaper.
 28982	
 28983	--Well, says J. J. We have Edward the peacemaker now.
 28984	
 28985	--Tell that to a fool, says the citizen. There's a bloody sight more pox
 28986	than pax about that boyo. Edward Guelph-Wettin!
 28987	
 28988	--And what do you think, says Joe, of the holy boys, the priests
 28989	and bishops of Ireland doing up his room in Maynooth in His Satanic
 28990	Majesty's racing colours and sticking up pictures of all the horses his
 28991	jockeys rode. The earl of Dublin, no less.
 28992	
 28993	--They ought to have stuck up all the women he rode himself, says little
 28994	Alf.
 28995	
 28996	And says J. J.:
 28997	
 28998	--Considerations of space influenced their lordships' decision.
 28999	
 29000	--Will you try another, citizen? says Joe.
 29001	
 29002	--Yes, sir, says he. I will.
 29003	
 29004	--You? says Joe.
 29005	
 29006	--Beholden to you, Joe, says I. May your shadow never grow less.
 29007	
 29008	--Repeat that dose, says Joe.
 29009	
 29010	Bloom was talking and talking with John Wyse and he quite excited with
 29011	his dunducketymudcoloured mug on him and his old plumeyes rolling about.
 29012	
 29013	--Persecution, says he, all the history of the world is full of it.
 29014	Perpetuating national hatred among nations.
 29015	
 29016	--But do you know what a nation means? says John Wyse.
 29017	
 29018	--Yes, says Bloom.
 29019	
 29020	--What is it? says John Wyse.
 29021	
 29022	--A nation? says Bloom. A nation is the same people living in the same
 29023	place.
 29024	
 29025	--By God, then, says Ned, laughing, if that's so I'm a nation for I'm
 29026	living in the same place for the past five years.
 29027	
 29028	So of course everyone had the laugh at Bloom and says he, trying to muck
 29029	out of it:
 29030	
 29031	--Or also living in different places.
 29032	
 29033	--That covers my case, says Joe.
 29034	
 29035	--What is your nation if I may ask? says the citizen.
 29036	
 29037	--Ireland, says Bloom. I was born here. Ireland.
 29038	
 29039	The citizen said nothing only cleared the spit out of his gullet and,
 29040	gob, he spat a Red bank oyster out of him right in the corner.
 29041	
 29042	--After you with the push, Joe, says he, taking out his handkerchief to
 29043	swab himself dry.
 29044	
 29045	--Here you are, citizen, says Joe. Take that in your right hand and
 29046	repeat after me the following words.
 29047	
 29048	The muchtreasured and intricately embroidered ancient Irish facecloth
 29049	attributed to Solomon of Droma and Manus Tomaltach og MacDonogh, authors
 29050	of the Book of Ballymote, was then carefully produced and called forth
 29051	prolonged admiration. No need to dwell on the legendary beauty of the
 29052	cornerpieces, the acme of art, wherein one can distinctly discern each
 29053	of the four evangelists in turn presenting to each of the four masters
 29054	his evangelical symbol, a bogoak sceptre, a North American puma (a far
 29055	nobler king of beasts than the British article, be it said in passing),
 29056	a Kerry calf and a golden eagle from Carrantuohill. The scenes depicted
 29057	on the emunctory field, showing our ancient duns and raths and cromlechs
 29058	and grianauns and seats of learning and maledictive stones, are as
 29059	wonderfully beautiful and the pigments as delicate as when the Sligo
 29060	illuminators gave free rein to their artistic fantasy long long ago in
 29061	the time of the Barmecides. Glendalough, the lovely lakes of Killarney,
 29062	the ruins of Clonmacnois, Cong Abbey, Glen Inagh and the Twelve Pins,
 29063	Ireland's Eye, the Green Hills of Tallaght, Croagh Patrick, the brewery
 29064	of Messrs Arthur Guinness, Son and Company (Limited), Lough Neagh's
 29065	banks, the vale of Ovoca, Isolde's tower, the Mapas obelisk, Sir Patrick
 29066	Dun's hospital, Cape Clear, the glen of Aherlow, Lynch's castle, the
 29067	Scotch house, Rathdown Union Workhouse at Loughlinstown, Tullamore jail,
 29068	Castleconnel rapids, Kilballymacshonakill, the cross at Monasterboice,
 29069	Jury's Hotel, S. Patrick's Purgatory, the Salmon Leap, Maynooth college
 29070	refectory, Curley's hole, the three birthplaces of the first duke of
 29071	Wellington, the rock of Cashel, the bog of Allen, the Henry Street
 29072	Warehouse, Fingal's Cave--all these moving scenes are still there for us
 29073	today rendered more beautiful still by the waters of sorrow which have
 29074	passed over them and by the rich incrustations of time.
 29075	
 29076	--Show us over the drink, says I. Which is which?
 29077	
 29078	--That's mine, says Joe, as the devil said to the dead policeman.
 29079	
 29080	--And I belong to a race too, says Bloom, that is hated and persecuted.
 29081	Also now. This very moment. This very instant.
 29082	
 29083	Gob, he near burnt his fingers with the butt of his old cigar.
 29084	
 29085	--Robbed, says he. Plundered. Insulted. Persecuted. Taking what belongs
 29086	to us by right. At this very moment, says he, putting up his fist, sold
 29087	by auction in Morocco like slaves or cattle.
 29088	
 29089	--Are you talking about the new Jerusalem? says the citizen.
 29090	
 29091	--I'm talking about injustice, says Bloom.
 29092	
 29093	--Right, says John Wyse. Stand up to it then with force like men.
 29094	
 29095	That's an almanac picture for you. Mark for a softnosed bullet. Old
 29096	lardyface standing up to the business end of a gun. Gob, he'd adorn a
 29097	sweepingbrush, so he would, if he only had a nurse's apron on him. And
 29098	then he collapses all of a sudden, twisting around all the opposite, as
 29099	limp as a wet rag.
 29100	
 29101	--But it's no use, says he. Force, hatred, history, all that. That's not
 29102	life for men and women, insult and hatred. And everybody knows that it's
 29103	the very opposite of that that is really life.
 29104	
 29105	--What? says Alf.
 29106	
 29107	--Love, says Bloom. I mean the opposite of hatred. I must go now, says
 29108	he to John Wyse. Just round to the court a moment to see if Martin is
 29109	there. If he comes just say I'll be back in a second. Just a moment.
 29110	
 29111	Who's hindering you? And off he pops like greased lightning.
 29112	
 29113	--A new apostle to the gentiles, says the citizen. Universal love.
 29114	
 29115	--Well, says John Wyse. Isn't that what we're told. Love your neighbour.
 29116	
 29117	--That chap? says the citizen. Beggar my neighbour is his motto. Love,
 29118	moya! He's a nice pattern of a Romeo and Juliet.
 29119	
 29120	Love loves to love love. Nurse loves the new chemist. Constable 14A
 29121	loves Mary Kelly. Gerty MacDowell loves the boy that has the bicycle. M.
 29122	B. loves a fair gentleman. Li Chi Han lovey up kissy Cha Pu Chow. Jumbo,
 29123	the elephant, loves Alice, the elephant. Old Mr Verschoyle with the ear
 29124	trumpet loves old Mrs Verschoyle with the turnedin eye. The man in the
 29125	brown macintosh loves a lady who is dead. His Majesty the King loves Her
 29126	Majesty the Queen. Mrs Norman W. Tupper loves officer Taylor. You love
 29127	a certain person. And this person loves that other person because
 29128	everybody loves somebody but God loves everybody.
 29129	
 29130	--Well, Joe, says I, your very good health and song. More power,
 29131	citizen.
 29132	
 29133	--Hurrah, there, says Joe.
 29134	
 29135	--The blessing of God and Mary and Patrick on you, says the citizen.
 29136	
 29137	And he ups with his pint to wet his whistle.
 29138	
 29139	--We know those canters, says he, preaching and picking your pocket.
 29140	What about sanctimonious Cromwell and his ironsides that put the women
 29141	and children of Drogheda to the sword with the bible text _God is love_
 29142	pasted round the mouth of his cannon? The bible! Did you read that skit
 29143	in the _United Irishman_ today about that Zulu chief that's visiting
 29144	England?
 29145	
 29146	--What's that? says Joe.
 29147	
 29148	So the citizen takes up one of his paraphernalia papers and he starts
 29149	reading out:
 29150	
 29151	--A delegation of the chief cotton magnates of Manchester was presented
 29152	yesterday to His Majesty the Alaki of Abeakuta by Gold Stick in Waiting,
 29153	Lord Walkup of Walkup on Eggs, to tender to His Majesty the heartfelt
 29154	thanks of British traders for the facilities afforded them in his
 29155	dominions. The delegation partook of luncheon at the conclusion of which
 29156	the dusky potentate, in the course of a happy speech, freely translated
 29157	by the British chaplain, the reverend Ananias Praisegod Barebones,
 29158	tendered his best thanks to Massa Walkup and emphasised the cordial
 29159	relations existing between Abeakuta and the British empire, stating that
 29160	he treasured as one of his dearest possessions an illuminated bible,
 29161	the volume of the word of God and the secret of England's greatness,
 29162	graciously presented to him by the white chief woman, the great squaw
 29163	Victoria, with a personal dedication from the august hand of the Royal
 29164	Donor. The Alaki then drank a lovingcup of firstshot usquebaugh to the
 29165	toast _Black and White_ from the skull of his immediate predecessor in
 29166	the dynasty Kakachakachak, surnamed Forty Warts, after which he visited
 29167	the chief factory of Cottonopolis and signed his mark in the visitors'
 29168	book, subsequently executing a charming old Abeakutic wardance, in the
 29169	course of which he swallowed several knives and forks, amid hilarious
 29170	applause from the girl hands.
 29171	
 29172	--Widow woman, says Ned. I wouldn't doubt her. Wonder did he put that
 29173	bible to the same use as I would.
 29174	
 29175	--Same only more so, says Lenehan. And thereafter in that fruitful land
 29176	the broadleaved mango flourished exceedingly.
 29177	
 29178	--Is that by Griffith? says John Wyse.
 29179	
 29180	--No, says the citizen. It's not signed Shanganagh. It's only
 29181	initialled: P.
 29182	
 29183	--And a very good initial too, says Joe.
 29184	
 29185	--That's how it's worked, says the citizen. Trade follows the flag.
 29186	
 29187	--Well, says J. J., if they're any worse than those Belgians in the
 29188	Congo Free State they must be bad. Did you read that report by a man
 29189	what's this his name is?
 29190	
 29191	--Casement, says the citizen. He's an Irishman.
 29192	
 29193	--Yes, that's the man, says J. J. Raping the women and girls and
 29194	flogging the natives on the belly to squeeze all the red rubber they can
 29195	out of them.
 29196	
 29197	--I know where he's gone, says Lenehan, cracking his fingers.
 29198	
 29199	--Who? says I.
 29200	
 29201	--Bloom, says he. The courthouse is a blind. He had a few bob on
 29202	_Throwaway_ and he's gone to gather in the shekels.
 29203	
 29204	--Is it that whiteeyed kaffir? says the citizen, that never backed a
 29205	horse in anger in his life?
 29206	
 29207	--That's where he's gone, says Lenehan. I met Bantam Lyons going to back
 29208	that horse only I put him off it and he told me Bloom gave him the tip.
 29209	Bet you what you like he has a hundred shillings to five on. He's the
 29210	only man in Dublin has it. A dark horse.
 29211	
 29212	--He's a bloody dark horse himself, says Joe.
 29213	
 29214	--Mind, Joe, says I. Show us the entrance out.
 29215	
 29216	--There you are, says Terry.
 29217	
 29218	Goodbye Ireland I'm going to Gort. So I just went round the back of
 29219	the yard to pumpship and begob (hundred shillings to five) while I was
 29220	letting off my _(Throwaway_ twenty to) letting off my load gob says I
 29221	to myself I knew he was uneasy in his (two pints off of Joe and one in
 29222	Slattery's off) in his mind to get off the mark to (hundred shillings
 29223	is five quid) and when they were in the (dark horse) pisser Burke was
 29224	telling me card party and letting on the child was sick (gob, must have
 29225	done about a gallon) flabbyarse of a wife speaking down the tube _she's
 29226	better_ or _she's_ (ow!) all a plan so he could vamoose with the pool if
 29227	he won or (Jesus, full up I was) trading without a licence (ow!) Ireland
 29228	my nation says he (hoik! phthook!) never be up to those bloody (there's
 29229	the last of it) Jerusalem (ah!) cuckoos.
 29230	
 29231	So anyhow when I got back they were at it dingdong, John Wyse saying it
 29232	was Bloom gave the ideas for Sinn Fein to Griffith to put in his paper
 29233	all kinds of jerrymandering, packed juries and swindling the taxes off
 29234	of the government and appointing consuls all over the world to walk
 29235	about selling Irish industries. Robbing Peter to pay Paul. Gob, that
 29236	puts the bloody kybosh on it if old sloppy eyes is mucking up the show.
 29237	Give us a bloody chance. God save Ireland from the likes of that bloody
 29238	mouseabout. Mr Bloom with his argol bargol. And his old fellow before
 29239	him perpetrating frauds, old Methusalem Bloom, the robbing bagman, that
 29240	poisoned himself with the prussic acid after he swamping the country
 29241	with his baubles and his penny diamonds. Loans by post on easy terms.
 29242	Any amount of money advanced on note of hand. Distance no object. No
 29243	security. Gob, he's like Lanty MacHale's goat that'd go a piece of the
 29244	road with every one.
 29245	
 29246	--Well, it's a fact, says John Wyse. And there's the man now that'll
 29247	tell you all about it, Martin Cunningham.
 29248	
 29249	Sure enough the castle car drove up with Martin on it and Jack Power
 29250	with him and a fellow named Crofter or Crofton, pensioner out of
 29251	the collector general's, an orangeman Blackburn does have on the
 29252	registration and he drawing his pay or Crawford gallivanting around the
 29253	country at the king's expense.
 29254	
 29255	Our travellers reached the rustic hostelry and alighted from their
 29256	palfreys.
 29257	
 29258	--Ho, varlet! cried he, who by his mien seemed the leader of the party.
 29259	Saucy knave! To us!
 29260	
 29261	So saying he knocked loudly with his swordhilt upon the open lattice.
 29262	
 29263	Mine host came forth at the summons, girding him with his tabard.
 29264	
 29265	--Give you good den, my masters, said he with an obsequious bow.
 29266	
 29267	--Bestir thyself, sirrah! cried he who had knocked. Look to our steeds.
 29268	And for ourselves give us of your best for ifaith we need it.
 29269	
 29270	--Lackaday, good masters, said the host, my poor house has but a bare
 29271	larder. I know not what to offer your lordships.
 29272	
 29273	--How now, fellow? cried the second of the party, a man of pleasant
 29274	countenance, So servest thou the king's messengers, master Taptun?
 29275	
 29276	An instantaneous change overspread the landlord's visage.
 29277	
 29278	--Cry you mercy, gentlemen, he said humbly. An you be the king's
 29279	messengers (God shield His Majesty!) you shall not want for aught. The
 29280	king's friends (God bless His Majesty!) shall not go afasting in my
 29281	house I warrant me.
 29282	
 29283	--Then about! cried the traveller who had not spoken, a lusty
 29284	trencherman by his aspect. Hast aught to give us?
 29285	
 29286	Mine host bowed again as he made answer:
 29287	
 29288	--What say you, good masters, to a squab pigeon pasty, some collops of
 29289	venison, a saddle of veal, widgeon with crisp hog's bacon, a boar's head
 29290	with pistachios, a bason of jolly custard, a medlar tansy and a flagon
 29291	of old Rhenish?
 29292	
 29293	--Gadzooks! cried the last speaker. That likes me well. Pistachios!
 29294	
 29295	--Aha! cried he of the pleasant countenance. A poor house and a bare
 29296	larder, quotha! 'Tis a merry rogue.
 29297	
 29298	So in comes Martin asking where was Bloom.
 29299	
 29300	--Where is he? says Lenehan. Defrauding widows and orphans.
 29301	
 29302	--Isn't that a fact, says John Wyse, what I was telling the citizen
 29303	about Bloom and the Sinn Fein?
 29304	
 29305	--That's so, says Martin. Or so they allege.
 29306	
 29307	--Who made those allegations? says Alf.
 29308	
 29309	--I, says Joe. I'm the alligator.
 29310	
 29311	--And after all, says John Wyse, why can't a jew love his country like
 29312	the next fellow?
 29313	
 29314	--Why not? says J. J., when he's quite sure which country it is.
 29315	
 29316	--Is he a jew or a gentile or a holy Roman or a swaddler or what the
 29317	hell is he? says Ned. Or who is he? No offence, Crofton.
 29318	
 29319	--Who is Junius? says J. J.
 29320	
 29321	--We don't want him, says Crofter the Orangeman or presbyterian.
 29322	
 29323	--He's a perverted jew, says Martin, from a place in Hungary and it was
 29324	he drew up all the plans according to the Hungarian system. We know that
 29325	in the castle.
 29326	
 29327	--Isn't he a cousin of Bloom the dentist? says Jack Power.
 29328	
 29329	--Not at all, says Martin. Only namesakes. His name was Virag, the
 29330	father's name that poisoned himself. He changed it by deedpoll, the
 29331	father did.
 29332	
 29333	--That's the new Messiah for Ireland! says the citizen. Island of saints
 29334	and sages!
 29335	
 29336	--Well, they're still waiting for their redeemer, says Martin. For that
 29337	matter so are we.
 29338	
 29339	--Yes, says J. J., and every male that's born they think it may be their
 29340	Messiah. And every jew is in a tall state of excitement, I believe, till
 29341	he knows if he's a father or a mother.
 29342	
 29343	--Expecting every moment will be his next, says Lenehan.
 29344	
 29345	--O, by God, says Ned, you should have seen Bloom before that son of his
 29346	that died was born. I met him one day in the south city markets buying a
 29347	tin of Neave's food six weeks before the wife was delivered.
 29348	
 29349	--_En ventre sa mÃ¨re_, says J. J.
 29350	
 29351	--Do you call that a man? says the citizen.
 29352	
 29353	--I wonder did he ever put it out of sight, says Joe.
 29354	
 29355	--Well, there were two children born anyhow, says Jack Power.
 29356	
 29357	--And who does he suspect? says the citizen.
 29358	
 29359	Gob, there's many a true word spoken in jest. One of those mixed
 29360	middlings he is. Lying up in the hotel Pisser was telling me once a
 29361	month with headache like a totty with her courses. Do you know what I'm
 29362	telling you? It'd be an act of God to take a hold of a fellow the like
 29363	of that and throw him in the bloody sea. Justifiable homicide, so it
 29364	would. Then sloping off with his five quid without putting up a pint of
 29365	stuff like a man. Give us your blessing. Not as much as would blind your
 29366	eye.
 29367	
 29368	--Charity to the neighbour, says Martin. But where is he? We can't wait.
 29369	
 29370	--A wolf in sheep's clothing, says the citizen. That's what he is. Virag
 29371	from Hungary! Ahasuerus I call him. Cursed by God.
 29372	
 29373	--Have you time for a brief libation, Martin? says Ned.
 29374	
 29375	--Only one, says Martin. We must be quick. J. J. and S.
 29376	
 29377	--You, Jack? Crofton? Three half ones, Terry.
 29378	
 29379	--Saint Patrick would want to land again at Ballykinlar and convert us,
 29380	says the citizen, after allowing things like that to contaminate our
 29381	shores.
 29382	
 29383	--Well, says Martin, rapping for his glass. God bless all here is my
 29384	prayer.
 29385	
 29386	--Amen, says the citizen.
 29387	
 29388	--And I'm sure He will, says Joe.
 29389	
 29390	And at the sound of the sacring bell, headed by a crucifer with
 29391	acolytes, thurifers, boatbearers, readers, ostiarii, deacons and
 29392	subdeacons, the blessed company drew nigh of mitred abbots and priors
 29393	and guardians and monks and friars: the monks of Benedict of Spoleto,
 29394	Carthusians and Camaldolesi, Cistercians and Olivetans, Oratorians
 29395	and Vallombrosans, and the friars of Augustine, Brigittines,
 29396	Premonstratensians, Servi, Trinitarians, and the children of Peter
 29397	Nolasco: and therewith from Carmel mount the children of Elijah prophet
 29398	led by Albert bishop and by Teresa of Avila, calced and other: and
 29399	friars, brown and grey, sons of poor Francis, capuchins, cordeliers,
 29400	minimes and observants and the daughters of Clara: and the sons of
 29401	Dominic, the friars preachers, and the sons of Vincent: and the monks
 29402	of S. Wolstan: and Ignatius his children: and the confraternity of the
 29403	christian brothers led by the reverend brother Edmund Ignatius Rice. And
 29404	after came all saints and martyrs, virgins and confessors: S. Cyr and
 29405	S. Isidore Arator and S. James the Less and S. Phocas of Sinope and S.
 29406	Julian Hospitator and S. Felix de Cantalice and S. Simon Stylites and
 29407	S. Stephen Protomartyr and S. John of God and S. Ferreol and S. Leugarde
 29408	and S. Theodotus and S. Vulmar and S. Richard and S. Vincent de Paul and
 29409	S. Martin of Todi and S. Martin of Tours and S. Alfred and S. Joseph and
 29410	S. Denis and S. Cornelius and S. Leopold and S. Bernard and S. Terence
 29411	and S. Edward and S. Owen Caniculus and S. Anonymous and S. Eponymous
 29412	and S. Pseudonymous and S. Homonymous and S. Paronymous and S.
 29413	Synonymous and S. Laurence O'Toole and S. James of Dingle and
 29414	Compostella and S. Columcille and S. Columba and S. Celestine and S.
 29415	Colman and S. Kevin and S. Brendan and S. Frigidian and S. Senan and S.
 29416	Fachtna and S. Columbanus and S. Gall and S. Fursey and S. Fintan and S.
 29417	Fiacre and S. John Nepomuc and S. Thomas Aquinas and S. Ives of Brittany
 29418	and S. Michan and S. Herman-Joseph and the three patrons of holy youth
 29419	S. Aloysius Gonzaga and S. Stanislaus Kostka and S. John Berchmans
 29420	and the saints Gervasius, Servasius and Bonifacius and S. Bride and S.
 29421	Kieran and S. Canice of Kilkenny and S. Jarlath of Tuam and S. Finbarr
 29422	and S. Pappin of Ballymun and Brother Aloysius Pacificus and Brother
 29423	Louis Bellicosus and the saints Rose of Lima and of Viterbo and S.
 29424	Martha of Bethany and S. Mary of Egypt and S. Lucy and S. Brigid and
 29425	S. Attracta and S. Dympna and S. Ita and S. Marion Calpensis and
 29426	the Blessed Sister Teresa of the Child Jesus and S. Barbara and S.
 29427	Scholastica and S. Ursula with eleven thousand virgins. And all came
 29428	with nimbi and aureoles and gloriae, bearing palms and harps and swords
 29429	and olive crowns, in robes whereon were woven the blessed symbols of
 29430	their efficacies, inkhorns, arrows, loaves, cruses, fetters, axes,
 29431	trees, bridges, babes in a bathtub, shells, wallets, shears, keys,
 29432	dragons, lilies, buckshot, beards, hogs, lamps, bellows, beehives,
 29433	soupladles, stars, snakes, anvils, boxes of vaseline, bells, crutches,
 29434	forceps, stags' horns, watertight boots, hawks, millstones, eyes on a
 29435	dish, wax candles, aspergills, unicorns. And as they wended their way by
 29436	Nelson's Pillar, Henry street, Mary street, Capel street, Little Britain
 29437	street chanting the introit in _Epiphania Domini_ which beginneth
 29438	_Surge, illuminare_ and thereafter most sweetly the gradual _Omnes_
 29439	which saith _de Saba venient_ they did divers wonders such as casting
 29440	out devils, raising the dead to life, multiplying fishes, healing the
 29441	halt and the blind, discovering various articles which had been mislaid,
 29442	interpreting and fulfilling the scriptures, blessing and prophesying.
 29443	And last, beneath a canopy of cloth of gold came the reverend Father
 29444	O'Flynn attended by Malachi and Patrick. And when the good fathers
 29445	had reached the appointed place, the house of Bernard Kiernan and Co,
 29446	limited, 8, 9 and 10 little Britain street, wholesale grocers, wine
 29447	and brandy shippers, licensed fo the sale of beer, wine and spirits for
 29448	consumption on the premises, the celebrant blessed the house and censed
 29449	the mullioned windows and the groynes and the vaults and the arrises and
 29450	the capitals and the pediments and the cornices and the engrailed arches
 29451	and the spires and the cupolas and sprinkled the lintels thereof with
 29452	blessed water and prayed that God might bless that house as he had
 29453	blessed the house of Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and make the angels of
 29454	His light to inhabit therein. And entering he blessed the viands and the
 29455	beverages and the company of all the blessed answered his prayers.
 29456	
 29457	--_Adiutorium nostrum in nomine Domini._
 29458	
 29459	--_Qui fecit coelum et terram._
 29460	
 29461	--_Dominus vobiscum._
 29462	
 29463	--_Et cum spiritu tuo._
 29464	
 29465	And he laid his hands upon that he blessed and gave thanks and he prayed
 29466	and they all with him prayed:
 29467	
 29468	--_Deus, cuius verbo sanctificantur omnia, benedictionem tuam effunde
 29469	super creaturas istas: et praesta ut quisquis eis secundum legem et
 29470	voluntatem Tuam cum gratiarum actione usus fuerit per invocationem
 29471	sanctissimi nominis Tui corporis sanitatem et animae tutelam Te auctore
 29472	percipiat per Christum Dominum nostrum._
 29473	
 29474	--And so say all of us, says Jack.
 29475	
 29476	--Thousand a year, Lambert, says Crofton or Crawford.
 29477	
 29478	--Right, says Ned, taking up his John Jameson. And butter for fish.
 29479	
 29480	I was just looking around to see who the happy thought would strike when
 29481	be damned but in he comes again letting on to be in a hell of a hurry.
 29482	
 29483	--I was just round at the courthouse, says he, looking for you. I hope
 29484	I'm not...
 29485	
 29486	--No, says Martin, we're ready.
 29487	
 29488	Courthouse my eye and your pockets hanging down with gold and silver.
 29489	Mean bloody scut. Stand us a drink itself. Devil a sweet fear! There's
 29490	a jew for you! All for number one. Cute as a shithouse rat. Hundred to
 29491	five.
 29492	
 29493	--Don't tell anyone, says the citizen,
 29494	
 29495	--Beg your pardon, says he.
 29496	
 29497	--Come on boys, says Martin, seeing it was looking blue. Come along now.
 29498	
 29499	--Don't tell anyone, says the citizen, letting a bawl out of him. It's a
 29500	secret.
 29501	
 29502	And the bloody dog woke up and let a growl.
 29503	
 29504	--Bye bye all, says Martin.
 29505	
 29506	And he got them out as quick as he could, Jack Power and Crofton or
 29507	whatever you call him and him in the middle of them letting on to be all
 29508	at sea and up with them on the bloody jaunting car.
 29509	
 29510	---Off with you, says
 29511	
 29512	Martin to the jarvey.
 29513	
 29514	The milkwhite dolphin tossed his mane and, rising in the golden poop the
 29515	helmsman spread the bellying sail upon the wind and stood off forward
 29516	with all sail set, the spinnaker to larboard. A many comely nymphs drew
 29517	nigh to starboard and to larboard and, clinging to the sides of
 29518	the noble bark, they linked their shining forms as doth the cunning
 29519	wheelwright when he fashions about the heart of his wheel the
 29520	equidistant rays whereof each one is sister to another and he binds them
 29521	all with an outer ring and giveth speed to the feet of men whenas they
 29522	ride to a hosting or contend for the smile of ladies fair. Even so did
 29523	they come and set them, those willing nymphs, the undying sisters. And
 29524	they laughed, sporting in a circle of their foam: and the bark clave the
 29525	waves.
 29526	
 29527	But begob I was just lowering the heel of the pint when I saw the
 29528	citizen getting up to waddle to the door, puffing and blowing with the
 29529	dropsy, and he cursing the curse of Cromwell on him, bell, book and
 29530	candle in Irish, spitting and spatting out of him and Joe and little Alf
 29531	round him like a leprechaun trying to peacify him.
 29532	
 29533	--Let me alone, says he.
 29534	
 29535	And begob he got as far as the door and they holding him and he bawls
 29536	out of him:
 29537	
 29538	--Three cheers for Israel!
 29539	
 29540	Arrah, sit down on the parliamentary side of your arse for Christ' sake
 29541	and don't be making a public exhibition of yourself. Jesus, there's
 29542	always some bloody clown or other kicking up a bloody murder about
 29543	bloody nothing. Gob, it'd turn the porter sour in your guts, so it
 29544	would.
 29545	
 29546	And all the ragamuffins and sluts of the nation round the door and
 29547	Martin telling the jarvey to drive ahead and the citizen bawling and Alf
 29548	and Joe at him to whisht and he on his high horse about the jews and
 29549	the loafers calling for a speech and Jack Power trying to get him to sit
 29550	down on the car and hold his bloody jaw and a loafer with a patch over
 29551	his eye starts singing _If the man in the moon was a jew, jew, jew_ and
 29552	a slut shouts out of her:
 29553	
 29554	--Eh, mister! Your fly is open, mister!
 29555	
 29556	And says he:
 29557	
 29558	--Mendelssohn was a jew and Karl Marx and Mercadante and Spinoza. And
 29559	the Saviour was a jew and his father was a jew. Your God.
 29560	
 29561	--He had no father, says Martin. That'll do now. Drive ahead.
 29562	
 29563	--Whose God? says the citizen.
 29564	
 29565	--Well, his uncle was a jew, says he. Your God was a jew. Christ was a
 29566	jew like me.
 29567	
 29568	Gob, the citizen made a plunge back into the shop.
 29569	
 29570	--By Jesus, says he, I'll brain that bloody jewman for using the holy
 29571	name.
 29572	
 29573	By Jesus, I'll crucify him so I will. Give us that biscuitbox here.
 29574	
 29575	--Stop! Stop! says Joe.
 29576	
 29577	A large and appreciative gathering of friends and acquaintances from
 29578	the metropolis and greater Dublin assembled in their thousands to bid
 29579	farewell to Nagyasagos uram Lipoti Virag, late of Messrs Alexander
 29580	Thom's, printers to His Majesty, on the occasion of his departure
 29581	for the distant clime of Szazharminczbrojugulyas-Dugulas (Meadow of
 29582	Murmuring Waters). The ceremony which went off with great _Ã©clat_ was
 29583	characterised by the most affecting cordiality. An illuminated scroll
 29584	of ancient Irish vellum, the work of Irish artists, was presented to
 29585	the distinguished phenomenologist on behalf of a large section of the
 29586	community and was accompanied by the gift of a silver casket, tastefully
 29587	executed in the style of ancient Celtic ornament, a work which reflects
 29588	every credit on the makers, Messrs Jacob _agus_ Jacob. The departing
 29589	guest was the recipient of a hearty ovation, many of those who were
 29590	present being visibly moved when the select orchestra of Irish pipes
 29591	struck up the wellknown strains of _Come back to Erin_, followed
 29592	immediately by _Rakoczsy's March_. Tarbarrels and bonfires were lighted
 29593	along the coastline of the four seas on the summits of the Hill of
 29594	Howth, Three Rock Mountain, Sugarloaf, Bray Head, the mountains of
 29595	Mourne, the Galtees, the Ox and Donegal and Sperrin peaks, the Nagles
 29596	and the Bograghs, the Connemara hills, the reeks of M Gillicuddy, Slieve
 29597	Aughty, Slieve Bernagh and Slieve Bloom. Amid cheers that rent the
 29598	welkin, responded to by answering cheers from a big muster of
 29599	henchmen on the distant Cambrian and Caledonian hills, the mastodontic
 29600	pleasureship slowly moved away saluted by a final floral tribute from
 29601	the representatives of the fair sex who were present in large numbers
 29602	while, as it proceeded down the river, escorted by a flotilla of barges,
 29603	the flags of the Ballast office and Custom House were dipped in salute
 29604	as were also those of the electrical power station at the
 29605	Pigeonhouse and the Poolbeg Light. _VisszontlÃ¡tÃ¡sra, kedves barÃ¡ton!
 29606	VisszontlÃ¡tÃ¡sra!_ Gone but not forgotten.
 29607	
 29608	Gob, the devil wouldn't stop him till he got hold of the bloody tin
 29609	anyhow and out with him and little Alf hanging on to his elbow and he
 29610	shouting like a stuck pig, as good as any bloody play in the Queen's
 29611	royal theatre:
 29612	
 29613	--Where is he till I murder him?
 29614	
 29615	And Ned and J. J. paralysed with the laughing.
 29616	
 29617	--Bloody wars, says I, I'll be in for the last gospel.
 29618	
 29619	But as luck would have it the jarvey got the nag's head round the other
 29620	way and off with him.
 29621	
 29622	--Hold on, citizen, says Joe. Stop!
 29623	
 29624	Begob he drew his hand and made a swipe and let fly. Mercy of God the
 29625	sun was in his eyes or he'd have left him for dead. Gob, he near sent it
 29626	into the county Longford. The bloody nag took fright and the old
 29627	mongrel after the car like bloody hell and all the populace shouting and
 29628	laughing and the old tinbox clattering along the street.
 29629	
 29630	The catastrophe was terrific and instantaneous in its effect. The
 29631	observatory of Dunsink registered in all eleven shocks, all of the fifth
 29632	grade of Mercalli's scale, and there is no record extant of a similar
 29633	seismic disturbance in our island since the earthquake of 1534, the year
 29634	of the rebellion of Silken Thomas. The epicentre appears to have been
 29635	that part of the metropolis which constitutes the Inn's Quay ward and
 29636	parish of Saint Michan covering a surface of fortyone acres, two roods
 29637	and one square pole or perch. All the lordly residences in the vicinity
 29638	of the palace of justice were demolished and that noble edifice itself,
 29639	in which at the time of the catastrophe important legal debates were in
 29640	progress, is literally a mass of ruins beneath which it is to be
 29641	feared all the occupants have been buried alive. From the reports of
 29642	eyewitnesses it transpires that the seismic waves were accompanied by
 29643	a violent atmospheric perturbation of cyclonic character. An article of
 29644	headgear since ascertained to belong to the much respected clerk of the
 29645	crown and peace Mr George Fottrell and a silk umbrella with gold handle
 29646	with the engraved initials, crest, coat of arms and house number of
 29647	the erudite and worshipful chairman of quarter sessions sir Frederick
 29648	Falkiner, recorder of Dublin, have been discovered by search parties
 29649	in remote parts of the island respectively, the former on the third
 29650	basaltic ridge of the giant's causeway, the latter embedded to the
 29651	extent of one foot three inches in the sandy beach of Holeopen bay near
 29652	the old head of Kinsale. Other eyewitnesses depose that they observed
 29653	an incandescent object of enormous proportions hurtling through the
 29654	atmosphere at a terrifying velocity in a trajectory directed southwest
 29655	by west. Messages of condolence and sympathy are being hourly received
 29656	from all parts of the different continents and the sovereign pontiff has
 29657	been graciously pleased to decree that a special _missa pro defunctis_
 29658	shall be celebrated simultaneously by the ordinaries of each and every
 29659	cathedral church of all the episcopal dioceses subject to the spiritual
 29660	authority of the Holy See in suffrage of the souls of those faithful
 29661	departed who have been so unexpectedly called away from our midst.
 29662	The work of salvage, removal of _dÃ©bris,_ human remains etc has been
 29663	entrusted to Messrs Michael Meade and Son, 159 Great Brunswick street,
 29664	and Messrs T. and C. Martin, 77, 78, 79 and 80 North Wall, assisted by
 29665	the men and officers of the Duke of Cornwall's light infantry under the
 29666	general supervision of H. R. H., rear admiral, the right honourable sir
 29667	Hercules Hannibal Habeas Corpus Anderson, K. G., K. P., K. T., P. C., K.
 29668	C. B., M. P, J. P., M. B., D. S. O., S. O. D., M. F. H., M. R. I. A., B.
 29669	L., Mus. Doc., P. L. G., F. T. C. D., F. R. U. I., F. R. C. P. I. and F.
 29670	R. C. S. I.
 29671	
 29672	You never saw the like of it in all your born puff. Gob, if he got that
 29673	lottery ticket on the side of his poll he'd remember the gold cup, he
 29674	would so, but begob the citizen would have been lagged for assault and
 29675	battery and Joe for aiding and abetting. The jarvey saved his life by
 29676	furious driving as sure as God made Moses. What? O, Jesus, he did. And
 29677	he let a volley of oaths after him.
 29678	
 29679	--Did I kill him, says he, or what?
 29680	
 29681	And he shouting to the bloody dog:
 29682	
 29683	--After him, Garry! After him, boy!
 29684	
 29685	And the last we saw was the bloody car rounding the corner and old
 29686	sheepsface on it gesticulating and the bloody mongrel after it with his
 29687	lugs back for all he was bloody well worth to tear him limb from limb.
 29688	Hundred to five! Jesus, he took the value of it out of him, I promise
 29689	you.
 29690	
 29691	When, lo, there came about them all a great brightness and they beheld
 29692	the chariot wherein He stood ascend to heaven. And they beheld Him in
 29693	the chariot, clothed upon in the glory of the brightness, having raiment
 29694	as of the sun, fair as the moon and terrible that for awe they durst not
 29695	look upon Him. And there came a voice out of heaven, calling: _Elijah!
 29696	Elijah!_ And He answered with a main cry: _Abba! Adonai!_ And they
 29697	beheld Him even Him, ben Bloom Elijah, amid clouds of angels ascend
 29698	to the glory of the brightness at an angle of fortyfive degrees over
 29699	Donohoe's in Little Green street like a shot off a shovel.
 29700	
 29701	
 29702	
 29703	The summer evening had begun to fold the world in its mysterious
 29704	embrace. Far away in the west the sun was setting and the last glow of
