 29705	all too fleeting day lingered lovingly on sea and strand, on the proud
 29706	promontory of dear old Howth guarding as ever the waters of the bay, on
 29707	the weedgrown rocks along Sandymount shore and, last but not least, on
 29708	the quiet church whence there streamed forth at times upon the stillness
 29709	the voice of prayer to her who is in her pure radiance a beacon ever to
 29710	the stormtossed heart of man, Mary, star of the sea.
 29711	
 29712	The three girl friends were seated on the rocks, enjoying the evening
 29713	scene and the air which was fresh but not too chilly. Many a time and
 29714	oft were they wont to come there to that favourite nook to have a cosy
 29715	chat beside the sparkling waves and discuss matters feminine, Cissy
 29716	Caffrey and Edy Boardman with the baby in the pushcar and Tommy and
 29717	Jacky Caffrey, two little curlyheaded boys, dressed in sailor suits with
 29718	caps to match and the name H.M.S. Belleisle printed on both. For Tommy
 29719	and Jacky Caffrey were twins, scarce four years old and very noisy and
 29720	spoiled twins sometimes but for all that darling little fellows with
 29721	bright merry faces and endearing ways about them. They were dabbling in
 29722	the sand with their spades and buckets, building castles as children do,
 29723	or playing with their big coloured ball, happy as the day was long. And
 29724	Edy Boardman was rocking the chubby baby to and fro in the pushcar while
 29725	that young gentleman fairly chuckled with delight. He was but eleven
 29726	months and nine days old and, though still a tiny toddler, was just
 29727	beginning to lisp his first babyish words. Cissy Caffrey bent over to
 29728	him to tease his fat little plucks and the dainty dimple in his chin.
 29729	
 29730	--Now, baby, Cissy Caffrey said. Say out big, big. I want a drink of
 29731	water.
 29732	
 29733	And baby prattled after her:
 29734	
 29735	--A jink a jink a jawbo.
 29736	
 29737	Cissy Caffrey cuddled the wee chap for she was awfully fond of children,
 29738	so patient with little sufferers and Tommy Caffrey could never be got to
 29739	take his castor oil unless it was Cissy Caffrey that held his nose and
 29740	promised him the scatty heel of the loaf or brown bread with golden
 29741	syrup on. What a persuasive power that girl had! But to be sure baby
 29742	Boardman was as good as gold, a perfect little dote in his new fancy
 29743	bib. None of your spoilt beauties, Flora MacFlimsy sort, was Cissy
 29744	Caffrey. A truerhearted lass never drew the breath of life, always with
 29745	a laugh in her gipsylike eyes and a frolicsome word on her cherryripe
 29746	red lips, a girl lovable in the extreme. And Edy Boardman laughed too at
 29747	the quaint language of little brother.
 29748	
 29749	But just then there was a slight altercation between Master Tommy and
 29750	Master Jacky. Boys will be boys and our two twins were no exception
 29751	to this golden rule. The apple of discord was a certain castle of sand
 29752	which Master Jacky had built and Master Tommy would have it right go
 29753	wrong that it was to be architecturally improved by a frontdoor like the
 29754	Martello tower had. But if Master Tommy was headstrong Master Jacky was
 29755	selfwilled too and, true to the maxim that every little Irishman's house
 29756	is his castle, he fell upon his hated rival and to such purpose that the
 29757	wouldbe assailant came to grief and (alas to relate!) the coveted castle
 29758	too. Needless to say the cries of discomfited Master Tommy drew the
 29759	attention of the girl friends.
 29760	
 29761	--Come here, Tommy, his sister called imperatively. At once! And you,
 29762	Jacky, for shame to throw poor Tommy in the dirty sand. Wait till I
 29763	catch you for that.
 29764	
 29765	His eyes misty with unshed tears Master Tommy came at her call for their
 29766	big sister's word was law with the twins. And in a sad plight he was
 29767	too after his misadventure. His little man-o'-war top and unmentionables
 29768	were full of sand but Cissy was a past mistress in the art of smoothing
 29769	over life's tiny troubles and very quickly not one speck of sand was to
 29770	be seen on his smart little suit. Still the blue eyes were glistening
 29771	with hot tears that would well up so she kissed away the hurtness and
 29772	shook her hand at Master Jacky the culprit and said if she was near him
 29773	she wouldn't be far from him, her eyes dancing in admonition.
 29774	
 29775	--Nasty bold Jacky! she cried.
 29776	
 29777	She put an arm round the little mariner and coaxed winningly:
 29778	
 29779	--What's your name? Butter and cream?
 29780	
 29781	--Tell us who is your sweetheart, spoke Edy Boardman. Is Cissy your
 29782	sweetheart?
 29783	
 29784	--Nao, tearful Tommy said.
 29785	
 29786	--Is Edy Boardman your sweetheart? Cissy queried.
 29787	
 29788	--Nao, Tommy said.
 29789	
 29790	--I know, Edy Boardman said none too amiably with an arch glance from
 29791	her shortsighted eyes. I know who is Tommy's sweetheart. Gerty is
 29792	Tommy's sweetheart.
 29793	
 29794	--Nao, Tommy said on the verge of tears.
 29795	
 29796	Cissy's quick motherwit guessed what was amiss and she whispered to
 29797	Edy Boardman to take him there behind the pushcar where the gentleman
 29798	couldn't see and to mind he didn't wet his new tan shoes.
 29799	
 29800	But who was Gerty?
 29801	
 29802	Gerty MacDowell who was seated near her companions, lost in thought,
 29803	gazing far away into the distance was, in very truth, as fair a specimen
 29804	of winsome Irish girlhood as one could wish to see. She was pronounced
 29805	beautiful by all who knew her though, as folks often said, she was
 29806	more a Giltrap than a MacDowell. Her figure was slight and graceful,
 29807	inclining even to fragility but those iron jelloids she had been taking
 29808	of late had done her a world of good much better than the Widow Welch's
 29809	female pills and she was much better of those discharges she used to
 29810	get and that tired feeling. The waxen pallor of her face was almost
 29811	spiritual in its ivorylike purity though her rosebud mouth was a genuine
 29812	Cupid's bow, Greekly perfect. Her hands were of finely veined alabaster
 29813	with tapering fingers and as white as lemonjuice and queen of ointments
 29814	could make them though it was not true that she used to wear kid gloves
 29815	in bed or take a milk footbath either. Bertha Supple told that once to
 29816	Edy Boardman, a deliberate lie, when she was black out at daggers drawn
 29817	with Gerty (the girl chums had of course their little tiffs from time to
 29818	time like the rest of mortals) and she told her not to let on whatever
 29819	she did that it was her that told her or she'd never speak to her
 29820	again. No. Honour where honour is due. There was an innate refinement,
 29821	a languid queenly _hauteur_ about Gerty which was unmistakably evidenced
 29822	in her delicate hands and higharched instep. Had kind fate but willed
 29823	her to be born a gentlewoman of high degree in her own right and had
 29824	she only received the benefit of a good education Gerty MacDowell might
 29825	easily have held her own beside any lady in the land and have seen
 29826	herself exquisitely gowned with jewels on her brow and patrician suitors
 29827	at her feet vying with one another to pay their devoirs to her.
 29828	Mayhap it was this, the love that might have been, that lent to her
 29829	softlyfeatured face at whiles a look, tense with suppressed meaning,
 29830	that imparted a strange yearning tendency to the beautiful eyes, a charm
 29831	few could resist. Why have women such eyes of witchery? Gerty's were of
 29832	the bluest Irish blue, set off by lustrous lashes and dark expressive
 29833	brows. Time was when those brows were not so silkily seductive. It
 29834	was Madame Vera Verity, directress of the Woman Beautiful page of the
 29835	Princess Novelette, who had first advised her to try eyebrowleine which
 29836	gave that haunting expression to the eyes, so becoming in leaders
 29837	of fashion, and she had never regretted it. Then there was blushing
 29838	scientifically cured and how to be tall increase your height and you
 29839	have a beautiful face but your nose? That would suit Mrs Dignam because
 29840	she had a button one. But Gerty's crowning glory was her wealth of
 29841	wonderful hair. It was dark brown with a natural wave in it. She had cut
 29842	it that very morning on account of the new moon and it nestled about
 29843	her pretty head in a profusion of luxuriant clusters and pared her nails
 29844	too, Thursday for wealth. And just now at Edy's words as a telltale
 29845	flush, delicate as the faintest rosebloom, crept into her cheeks she
 29846	looked so lovely in her sweet girlish shyness that of a surety God's
 29847	fair land of Ireland did not hold her equal.
 29848	
 29849	For an instant she was silent with rather sad downcast eyes. She
 29850	was about to retort but something checked the words on her tongue.
 29851	Inclination prompted her to speak out: dignity told her to be silent.
 29852	The pretty lips pouted awhile but then she glanced up and broke out into
 29853	a joyous little laugh which had in it all the freshness of a young May
 29854	morning. She knew right well, no-one better, what made squinty Edy
 29855	say that because of him cooling in his attentions when it was simply a
 29856	lovers' quarrel. As per usual somebody's nose was out of joint about the
 29857	boy that had the bicycle off the London bridge road always riding up
 29858	and down in front of her window. Only now his father kept him in in the
 29859	evenings studying hard to get an exhibition in the intermediate that was
 29860	on and he was going to go to Trinity college to study for a doctor when
 29861	he left the high school like his brother W. E. Wylie who was racing
 29862	in the bicycle races in Trinity college university. Little recked he
 29863	perhaps for what she felt, that dull aching void in her heart sometimes,
 29864	piercing to the core. Yet he was young and perchance he might learn
 29865	to love her in time. They were protestants in his family and of course
 29866	Gerty knew Who came first and after Him the Blessed Virgin and then
 29867	Saint Joseph. But he was undeniably handsome with an exquisite nose and
 29868	he was what he looked, every inch a gentleman, the shape of his head too
 29869	at the back without his cap on that she would know anywhere something
 29870	off the common and the way he turned the bicycle at the lamp with his
 29871	hands off the bars and also the nice perfume of those good cigarettes
 29872	and besides they were both of a size too he and she and that was why Edy
 29873	Boardman thought she was so frightfully clever because he didn't go and
 29874	ride up and down in front of her bit of a garden.
 29875	
 29876	Gerty was dressed simply but with the instinctive taste of a votary of
 29877	Dame Fashion for she felt that there was just a might that he might be
 29878	out. A neat blouse of electric blue selftinted by dolly dyes (because it
 29879	was expected in the _Lady's Pictorial_ that electric blue would be worn)
 29880	with a smart vee opening down to the division and kerchief pocket (in
 29881	which she always kept a piece of cottonwool scented with her
 29882	favourite perfume because the handkerchief spoiled the sit) and a navy
 29883	threequarter skirt cut to the stride showed off her slim graceful figure
 29884	to perfection. She wore a coquettish little love of a hat of wideleaved
 29885	nigger straw contrast trimmed with an underbrim of eggblue chenille and
 29886	at the side a butterfly bow of silk to tone. All Tuesday week afternoon
 29887	she was hunting to match that chenille but at last she found what she
 29888	wanted at Clery's summer sales, the very it, slightly shopsoiled but you
 29889	would never notice, seven fingers two and a penny. She did it up all by
 29890	herself and what joy was hers when she tried it on then, smiling at the
 29891	lovely reflection which the mirror gave back to her! And when she put
 29892	it on the waterjug to keep the shape she knew that that would take the
 29893	shine out of some people she knew. Her shoes were the newest thing in
 29894	footwear (Edy Boardman prided herself that she was very _petite_ but she
 29895	never had a foot like Gerty MacDowell, a five, and never would ash,
 29896	oak or elm) with patent toecaps and just one smart buckle over
 29897	her higharched instep. Her wellturned ankle displayed its perfect
 29898	proportions beneath her skirt and just the proper amount and no more of
 29899	her shapely limbs encased in finespun hose with highspliced heels and
 29900	wide garter tops. As for undies they were Gerty's chief care and who
 29901	that knows the fluttering hopes and fears of sweet seventeen (though
 29902	Gerty would never see seventeen again) can find it in his heart to
 29903	blame her? She had four dinky sets with awfully pretty stitchery,
 29904	three garments and nighties extra, and each set slotted with different
 29905	coloured ribbons, rosepink, pale blue, mauve and peagreen, and she aired
 29906	them herself and blued them when they came home from the wash and ironed
 29907	them and she had a brickbat to keep the iron on because she wouldn't
 29908	trust those washerwomen as far as she'd see them scorching the things.
 29909	She was wearing the blue for luck, hoping against hope, her own colour
 29910	and lucky too for a bride to have a bit of blue somewhere on her because
 29911	the green she wore that day week brought grief because his father
 29912	brought him in to study for the intermediate exhibition and because
 29913	she thought perhaps he might be out because when she was dressing that
 29914	morning she nearly slipped up the old pair on her inside out and that
 29915	was for luck and lovers' meeting if you put those things on inside
 29916	out or if they got untied that he was thinking about you so long as it
 29917	wasn't of a Friday.
 29918	
 29919	And yet and yet! That strained look on her face! A gnawing sorrow is
 29920	there all the time. Her very soul is in her eyes and she would give
 29921	worlds to be in the privacy of her own familiar chamber where,
 29922	giving way to tears, she could have a good cry and relieve her pentup
 29923	feelingsthough not too much because she knew how to cry nicely before
 29924	the mirror. You are lovely, Gerty, it said. The paly light of evening
 29925	falls upon a face infinitely sad and wistful. Gerty MacDowell yearns
 29926	in vain. Yes, she had known from the very first that her daydream of a
 29927	marriage has been arranged and the weddingbells ringing for Mrs Reggy
 29928	Wylie T. C. D. (because the one who married the elder brother would be
 29929	Mrs Wylie) and in the fashionable intelligence Mrs Gertrude Wylie was
 29930	wearing a sumptuous confection of grey trimmed with expensive blue fox
 29931	was not to be. He was too young to understand. He would not believe in
 29932	love, a woman's birthright. The night of the party long ago in Stoer's
 29933	(he was still in short trousers) when they were alone and he stole
 29934	an arm round her waist she went white to the very lips. He called her
 29935	little one in a strangely husky voice and snatched a half kiss (the
 29936	first!) but it was only the end of her nose and then he hastened from
 29937	the room with a remark about refreshments. Impetuous fellow! Strength of
 29938	character had never been Reggy Wylie's strong point and he who would
 29939	woo and win Gerty MacDowell must be a man among men. But waiting, always
 29940	waiting to be asked and it was leap year too and would soon be over. No
 29941	prince charming is her beau ideal to lay a rare and wondrous love at her
 29942	feet but rather a manly man with a strong quiet face who had not found
 29943	his ideal, perhaps his hair slightly flecked with grey, and who would
 29944	understand, take her in his sheltering arms, strain her to him in all
 29945	the strength of his deep passionate nature and comfort her with a long
 29946	long kiss. It would be like heaven. For such a one she yearns this balmy
 29947	summer eve. With all the heart of her she longs to be his only, his
 29948	affianced bride for riches for poor, in sickness in health, till death
 29949	us two part, from this to this day forward.
 29950	
 29951	And while Edy Boardman was with little Tommy behind the pushcar she was
 29952	just thinking would the day ever come when she could call herself his
 29953	little wife to be. Then they could talk about her till they went blue in
 29954	the face, Bertha Supple too, and Edy, little spitfire, because she would
 29955	be twentytwo in November. She would care for him with creature comforts
 29956	too for Gerty was womanly wise and knew that a mere man liked that
 29957	feeling of hominess. Her griddlecakes done to a goldenbrown hue and
 29958	queen Ann's pudding of delightful creaminess had won golden opinions
 29959	from all because she had a lucky hand also for lighting a fire, dredge
 29960	in the fine selfraising flour and always stir in the same direction,
 29961	then cream the milk and sugar and whisk well the white of eggs though
 29962	she didn't like the eating part when there were any people that made her
 29963	shy and often she wondered why you couldn't eat something poetical like
 29964	violets or roses and they would have a beautifully appointed drawingroom
 29965	with pictures and engravings and the photograph of grandpapa Giltrap's
 29966	lovely dog Garryowen that almost talked it was so human and chintz
 29967	covers for the chairs and that silver toastrack in Clery's summer
 29968	jumble sales like they have in rich houses. He would be tall with
 29969	broad shoulders (she had always admired tall men for a husband) with
 29970	glistening white teeth under his carefully trimmed sweeping moustache
 29971	and they would go on the continent for their honeymoon (three wonderful
 29972	weeks!) and then, when they settled down in a nice snug and cosy little
 29973	homely house, every morning they would both have brekky, simple but
 29974	perfectly served, for their own two selves and before he went out to
 29975	business he would give his dear little wifey a good hearty hug and gaze
 29976	for a moment deep down into her eyes.
 29977	
 29978	Edy Boardman asked Tommy Caffrey was he done and he said yes so then she
 29979	buttoned up his little knickerbockers for him and told him to run off
 29980	and play with Jacky and to be good now and not to fight. But Tommy said
 29981	he wanted the ball and Edy told him no that baby was playing with the
 29982	ball and if he took it there'd be wigs on the green but Tommy said it
 29983	was his ball and he wanted his ball and he pranced on the ground, if
 29984	you please. The temper of him! O, he was a man already was little Tommy
 29985	Caffrey since he was out of pinnies. Edy told him no, no and to be off
 29986	now with him and she told Cissy Caffrey not to give in to him.
 29987	
 29988	--You're not my sister, naughty Tommy said. It's my ball.
 29989	
 29990	But Cissy Caffrey told baby Boardman to look up, look up high at her
 29991	finger and she snatched the ball quickly and threw it along the sand and
 29992	Tommy after it in full career, having won the day.
 29993	
 29994	--Anything for a quiet life, laughed Ciss.
 29995	
 29996	And she tickled tiny tot's two cheeks to make him forget and played
 29997	here's the lord mayor, here's his two horses, here's his gingerbread
 29998	carriage and here he walks in, chinchopper, chinchopper, chinchopper
 29999	chin. But Edy got as cross as two sticks about him getting his own way
 30000	like that from everyone always petting him.
 30001	
 30002	--I'd like to give him something, she said, so I would, where I won't
 30003	say.
 30004	
 30005	--On the beeoteetom, laughed Cissy merrily.
 30006	
 30007	Gerty MacDowell bent down her head and crimsoned at the idea of Cissy
 30008	saying an unladylike thing like that out loud she'd be ashamed of her
 30009	life to say, flushing a deep rosy red, and Edy Boardman said she was
 30010	sure the gentleman opposite heard what she said. But not a pin cared
 30011	Ciss.
 30012	
 30013	--Let him! she said with a pert toss of her head and a piquant tilt of
 30014	her nose. Give it to him too on the same place as quick as I'd look at
 30015	him.
 30016	
 30017	Madcap Ciss with her golliwog curls. You had to laugh at her sometimes.
 30018	For instance when she asked you would you have some more Chinese tea and
 30019	jaspberry ram and when she drew the jugs too and the men's faces on her
 30020	nails with red ink make you split your sides or when she wanted to go
 30021	where you know she said she wanted to run and pay a visit to the Miss
 30022	White. That was just like Cissycums. O, and will you ever forget her the
 30023	evening she dressed up in her father's suit and hat and the burned cork
 30024	moustache and walked down Tritonville road, smoking a cigarette. There
 30025	was none to come up to her for fun. But she was sincerity itself, one of
 30026	the bravest and truest hearts heaven ever made, not one of your twofaced
 30027	things, too sweet to be wholesome.
 30028	
 30029	And then there came out upon the air the sound of voices and the pealing
 30030	anthem of the organ. It was the men's temperance retreat conducted
 30031	by the missioner, the reverend John Hughes S. J., rosary, sermon and
 30032	benediction of the Most Blessed Sacrament. They were there gathered
 30033	together without distinction of social class (and a most edifying
 30034	spectacle it was to see) in that simple fane beside the waves, after the
 30035	storms of this weary world, kneeling before the feet of the immaculate,
 30036	reciting the litany of Our Lady of Loreto, beseeching her to intercede
 30037	for them, the old familiar words, holy Mary, holy virgin of virgins. How
 30038	sad to poor Gerty's ears! Had her father only avoided the clutches of
 30039	the demon drink, by taking the pledge or those powders the drink habit
 30040	cured in Pearson's Weekly, she might now be rolling in her carriage,
 30041	second to none. Over and over had she told herself that as she mused by
 30042	the dying embers in a brown study without the lamp because she hated two
 30043	lights or oftentimes gazing out of the window dreamily by the hour at
 30044	the rain falling on the rusty bucket, thinking. But that vile decoction
 30045	which has ruined so many hearths and homes had cist its shadow over her
 30046	childhood days. Nay, she had even witnessed in the home circle deeds of
 30047	violence caused by intemperance and had seen her own father, a prey to
 30048	the fumes of intoxication, forget himself completely for if there was
 30049	one thing of all things that Gerty knew it was that the man who lifts
 30050	his hand to a woman save in the way of kindness, deserves to be branded
 30051	as the lowest of the low.
 30052	
 30053	And still the voices sang in supplication to the Virgin most powerful,
 30054	Virgin most merciful. And Gerty, rapt in thought, scarce saw or heard
 30055	her companions or the twins at their boyish gambols or the gentleman
 30056	off Sandymount green that Cissy Caffrey called the man that was so like
 30057	himself passing along the strand taking a short walk. You never saw him
 30058	any way screwed but still and for all that she would not like him for a
 30059	father because he was too old or something or on account of his face
 30060	(it was a palpable case of Doctor Fell) or his carbuncly nose with the
 30061	pimples on it and his sandy moustache a bit white under his nose. Poor
 30062	father! With all his faults she loved him still when he sang _Tell me,
 30063	Mary, how to woo thee_ or _My love and cottage near Rochelle_ and they
 30064	had stewed cockles and lettuce with Lazenby's salad dressing for
 30065	supper and when he sang _The moon hath raised_ with Mr Dignam that
 30066	died suddenly and was buried, God have mercy on him, from a stroke. Her
 30067	mother's birthday that was and Charley was home on his holidays and Tom
 30068	and Mr Dignam and Mrs and Patsy and Freddy Dignam and they were to have
 30069	had a group taken. No-one would have thought the end was so near. Now he
 30070	was laid to rest. And her mother said to him to let that be a warning to
 30071	him for the rest of his days and he couldn't even go to the funeral on
 30072	account of the gout and she had to go into town to bring him the
 30073	letters and samples from his office about Catesby's cork lino, artistic,
 30074	standard designs, fit for a palace, gives tiptop wear and always bright
 30075	and cheery in the home.
 30076	
 30077	A sterling good daughter was Gerty just like a second mother in the
 30078	house, a ministering angel too with a little heart worth its weight in
 30079	gold. And when her mother had those raging splitting headaches who was
 30080	it rubbed the menthol cone on her forehead but Gerty though she didn't
 30081	like her mother's taking pinches of snuff and that was the only single
 30082	thing they ever had words about, taking snuff. Everyone thought the
 30083	world of her for her gentle ways. It was Gerty who turned off the gas at
 30084	the main every night and it was Gerty who tacked up on the wall of that
 30085	place where she never forgot every fortnight the chlorate of lime Mr
 30086	Tunney the grocer's christmas almanac, the picture of halcyon days
 30087	where a young gentleman in the costume they used to wear then with a
 30088	threecornered hat was offering a bunch of flowers to his ladylove with
 30089	oldtime chivalry through her lattice window. You could see there was a
 30090	story behind it. The colours were done something lovely. She was in
 30091	a soft clinging white in a studied attitude and the gentleman was in
 30092	chocolate and he looked a thorough aristocrat. She often looked at them
 30093	dreamily when she went there for a certain purpose and felt her own
 30094	arms that were white and soft just like hers with the sleeves back
 30095	and thought about those times because she had found out in Walker's
 30096	pronouncing dictionary that belonged to grandpapa Giltrap about the
 30097	halcyon days what they meant.
 30098	
 30099	The twins were now playing in the most approved brotherly fashion
 30100	till at last Master Jacky who was really as bold as brass there was
 30101	no getting behind that deliberately kicked the ball as hard as ever he
 30102	could down towards the seaweedy rocks. Needless to say poor Tommy was
 30103	not slow to voice his dismay but luckily the gentleman in black who was
 30104	sitting there by himself came gallantly to the rescue and intercepted
 30105	the ball. Our two champions claimed their plaything with lusty cries and
 30106	to avoid trouble Cissy Caffrey called to the gentleman to throw it to
 30107	her please. The gentleman aimed the ball once or twice and then threw
 30108	it up the strand towards Cissy Caffrey but it rolled down the slope and
 30109	stopped right under Gerty's skirt near the little pool by the rock. The
 30110	twins clamoured again for it and Cissy told her to kick it away and
 30111	let them fight for it so Gerty drew back her foot but she wished their
 30112	stupid ball hadn't come rolling down to her and she gave a kick but she
 30113	missed and Edy and Cissy laughed.
 30114	
 30115	--If you fail try again, Edy Boardman said.
 30116	
 30117	Gerty smiled assent and bit her lip. A delicate pink crept into her
 30118	pretty cheek but she was determined to let them see so she just lifted
 30119	her skirt a little but just enough and took good aim and gave the ball a
 30120	jolly good kick and it went ever so far and the two twins after it down
 30121	towards the shingle. Pure jealousy of course it was nothing else to draw
 30122	attention on account of the gentleman opposite looking. She felt the
 30123	warm flush, a danger signal always with Gerty MacDowell, surging and
 30124	flaming into her cheeks. Till then they had only exchanged glances of
 30125	the most casual but now under the brim of her new hat she ventured a
 30126	look at him and the face that met her gaze there in the twilight, wan
 30127	and strangely drawn, seemed to her the saddest she had ever seen.
 30128	
 30129	Through the open window of the church the fragrant incense was wafted
 30130	and with it the fragrant names of her who was conceived without stain of
 30131	original sin, spiritual vessel, pray for us, honourable vessel, pray
 30132	for us, vessel of singular devotion, pray for us, mystical rose. And
 30133	careworn hearts were there and toilers for their daily bread and many
 30134	who had erred and wandered, their eyes wet with contrition but for all
 30135	that bright with hope for the reverend father Father Hughes had told
 30136	them what the great saint Bernard said in his famous prayer of Mary, the
 30137	most pious Virgin's intercessory power that it was not recorded in any
 30138	age that those who implored her powerful protection were ever abandoned
 30139	by her.
 30140	
 30141	The twins were now playing again right merrily for the troubles of
 30142	childhood are but as fleeting summer showers. Cissy Caffrey played with
 30143	baby Boardman till he crowed with glee, clapping baby hands in air. Peep
 30144	she cried behind the hood of the pushcar and Edy asked where was Cissy
 30145	gone and then Cissy popped up her head and cried ah! and, my word,
 30146	didn't the little chap enjoy that! And then she told him to say papa.
 30147	
 30148	--Say papa, baby. Say pa pa pa pa pa pa pa.
 30149	
 30150	And baby did his level best to say it for he was very intelligent for
 30151	eleven months everyone said and big for his age and the picture of
 30152	health, a perfect little bunch of love, and he would certainly turn out
 30153	to be something great, they said.
 30154	
 30155	--Haja ja ja haja.
 30156	
 30157	Cissy wiped his little mouth with the dribbling bib and wanted him to
 30158	sit up properly and say pa pa pa but when she undid the strap she cried
 30159	out, holy saint Denis, that he was possing wet and to double the half
 30160	blanket the other way under him. Of course his infant majesty was most
 30161	obstreperous at such toilet formalities and he let everyone know it:
 30162	
 30163	--Habaa baaaahabaaa baaaa.
 30164	
 30165	And two great big lovely big tears coursing down his cheeks. It was all
 30166	no use soothering him with no, nono, baby, no and telling him about the
 30167	geegee and where was the puffpuff but Ciss, always readywitted, gave
 30168	him in his mouth the teat of the suckingbottle and the young heathen was
 30169	quickly appeased.
 30170	
 30171	Gerty wished to goodness they would take their squalling baby home out
 30172	of that and not get on her nerves, no hour to be out, and the little
 30173	brats of twins. She gazed out towards the distant sea. It was like the
 30174	paintings that man used to do on the pavement with all the coloured
 30175	chalks and such a pity too leaving them there to be all blotted out, the
 30176	evening and the clouds coming out and the Bailey light on Howth and to
 30177	hear the music like that and the perfume of those incense they burned
 30178	in the church like a kind of waft. And while she gazed her heart went
 30179	pitapat. Yes, it was her he was looking at, and there was meaning in his
 30180	look. His eyes burned into her as though they would search her through
 30181	and through, read her very soul. Wonderful eyes they were, superbly
 30182	expressive, but could you trust them? People were so queer. She could
 30183	see at once by his dark eyes and his pale intellectual face that he
 30184	was a foreigner, the image of the photo she had of Martin Harvey, the
 30185	matinee idol, only for the moustache which she preferred because she
 30186	wasn't stagestruck like Winny Rippingham that wanted they two to always
 30187	dress the same on account of a play but she could not see whether he had
 30188	an aquiline nose or a slightly _retroussÃ©_ from where he was sitting.
 30189	He was in deep mourning, she could see that, and the story of a haunting
 30190	sorrow was written on his face. She would have given worlds to know what
 30191	it was. He was looking up so intently, so still, and he saw her kick the
 30192	ball and perhaps he could see the bright steel buckles of her shoes if
 30193	she swung them like that thoughtfully with the toes down. She was glad
 30194	that something told her to put on the transparent stockings thinking
 30195	Reggy Wylie might be out but that was far away. Here was that of which
 30196	she had so often dreamed. It was he who mattered and there was joy on
 30197	her face because she wanted him because she felt instinctively that he
 30198	was like no-one else. The very heart of the girlwoman went out to him,
 30199	her dreamhusband, because she knew on the instant it was him. If he had
 30200	suffered, more sinned against than sinning, or even, even, if he had
 30201	been himself a sinner, a wicked man, she cared not. Even if he was a
 30202	protestant or methodist she could convert him easily if he truly loved
 30203	her. There were wounds that wanted healing with heartbalm. She was a
 30204	womanly woman not like other flighty girls unfeminine he had known,
 30205	those cyclists showing off what they hadn't got and she just yearned to
 30206	know all, to forgive all if she could make him fall in love with her,
 30207	make him forget the memory of the past. Then mayhap he would embrace her
 30208	gently, like a real man, crushing her soft body to him, and love her,
 30209	his ownest girlie, for herself alone.
 30210	
 30211	Refuge of sinners. Comfortress of the afflicted. _Ora pro nobis_. Well
 30212	has it been said that whosoever prays to her with faith and constancy
 30213	can never be lost or cast away: and fitly is she too a haven of refuge
 30214	for the afflicted because of the seven dolours which transpierced
 30215	her own heart. Gerty could picture the whole scene in the church, the
 30216	stained glass windows lighted up, the candles, the flowers and the blue
 30217	banners of the blessed Virgin's sodality and Father Conroy was helping
 30218	Canon O'Hanlon at the altar, carrying things in and out with his eyes
 30219	cast down. He looked almost a saint and his confessionbox was so quiet
 30220	and clean and dark and his hands were just like white wax and if ever
 30221	she became a Dominican nun in their white habit perhaps he might come to
 30222	the convent for the novena of Saint Dominic. He told her that time when
 30223	she told him about that in confession, crimsoning up to the roots of her
 30224	hair for fear he could see, not to be troubled because that was only the
 30225	voice of nature and we were all subject to nature's laws, he said, in
 30226	this life and that that was no sin because that came from the nature of
 30227	woman instituted by God, he said, and that Our Blessed Lady herself said
 30228	to the archangel Gabriel be it done unto me according to Thy Word. He
 30229	was so kind and holy and often and often she thought and thought could
 30230	she work a ruched teacosy with embroidered floral design for him as a
 30231	present or a clock but they had a clock she noticed on the mantelpiece
 30232	white and gold with a canarybird that came out of a little house to tell
 30233	the time the day she went there about the flowers for the forty hours'
 30234	adoration because it was hard to know what sort of a present to give or
 30235	perhaps an album of illuminated views of Dublin or some place.
 30236	
 30237	The exasperating little brats of twins began to quarrel again and Jacky
 30238	threw the ball out towards the sea and they both ran after it. Little
 30239	monkeys common as ditchwater. Someone ought to take them and give them
 30240	a good hiding for themselves to keep them in their places, the both of
 30241	them. And Cissy and Edy shouted after them to come back because they
 30242	were afraid the tide might come in on them and be drowned.
 30243	
 30244	--Jacky! Tommy!
 30245	
 30246	Not they! What a great notion they had! So Cissy said it was the very
 30247	last time she'd ever bring them out. She jumped up and called them and
 30248	she ran down the slope past him, tossing her hair behind her which had
 30249	a good enough colour if there had been more of it but with all the
 30250	thingamerry she was always rubbing into it she couldn't get it to grow
 30251	long because it wasn't natural so she could just go and throw her hat at
 30252	it. She ran with long gandery strides it was a wonder she didn't rip up
 30253	her skirt at the side that was too tight on her because there was a lot
 30254	of the tomboy about Cissy Caffrey and she was a forward piece whenever
 30255	she thought she had a good opportunity to show and just because she was
 30256	a good runner she ran like that so that he could see all the end of her
 30257	petticoat running and her skinny shanks up as far as possible. It
 30258	would have served her just right if she had tripped up over something
 30259	accidentally on purpose with her high crooked French heels on her to
 30260	make her look tall and got a fine tumble. _Tableau!_ That would have
 30261	been a very charming expose for a gentleman like that to witness.
 30262	
 30263	Queen of angels, queen of patriarchs, queen of prophets, of all saints,
 30264	they prayed, queen of the most holy rosary and then Father Conroy handed
 30265	the thurible to Canon O'Hanlon and he put in the incense and censed the
 30266	Blessed Sacrament and Cissy Caffrey caught the two twins and she was
 30267	itching to give them a ringing good clip on the ear but she didn't
 30268	because she thought he might be watching but she never made a bigger
 30269	mistake in all her life because Gerty could see without looking that
 30270	he never took his eyes off of her and then Canon O'Hanlon handed the
 30271	thurible back to Father Conroy and knelt down looking up at the Blessed
 30272	Sacrament and the choir began to sing the _Tantum ergo_ and she just
 30273	swung her foot in and out in time as the music rose and fell to
 30274	the _Tantumer gosa cramen tum_. Three and eleven she paid for those
 30275	stockings in Sparrow's of George's street on the Tuesday, no the Monday
 30276	before Easter and there wasn't a brack on them and that was what he
 30277	was looking at, transparent, and not at her insignificant ones that had
 30278	neither shape nor form (the cheek of her!) because he had eyes in his
 30279	head to see the difference for himself.
 30280	
 30281	Cissy came up along the strand with the two twins and their ball with
 30282	her hat anyhow on her to one side after her run and she did look a
 30283	streel tugging the two kids along with the flimsy blouse she bought only
 30284	a fortnight before like a rag on her back and a bit of her petticoat
 30285	hanging like a caricature. Gerty just took off her hat for a moment to
 30286	settle her hair and a prettier, a daintier head of nutbrown tresses was
 30287	never seen on a girl's shoulders--a radiant little vision, in sooth,
 30288	almost maddening in its sweetness. You would have to travel many a long
 30289	mile before you found a head of hair the like of that. She could almost
 30290	see the swift answering flash of admiration in his eyes that set her
 30291	tingling in every nerve. She put on her hat so that she could see from
 30292	underneath the brim and swung her buckled shoe faster for her breath
 30293	caught as she caught the expression in his eyes. He was eying her as a
 30294	snake eyes its prey. Her woman's instinct told her that she had raised
 30295	the devil in him and at the thought a burning scarlet swept from throat
 30296	to brow till the lovely colour of her face became a glorious rose.
 30297	
 30298	Edy Boardman was noticing it too because she was squinting at Gerty,
 30299	half smiling, with her specs like an old maid, pretending to nurse the
 30300	baby. Irritable little gnat she was and always would be and that was why
 30301	no-one could get on with her poking her nose into what was no concern of
 30302	hers. And she said to Gerty:
 30303	
 30304	--A penny for your thoughts.
 30305	
 30306	--What? replied Gerty with a smile reinforced by the whitest of teeth. I
 30307	was only wondering was it late.
 30308	
 30309	Because she wished to goodness they'd take the snottynosed twins and
 30310	their babby home to the mischief out of that so that was why she just
 30311	gave a gentle hint about its being late. And when Cissy came up Edy
 30312	asked her the time and Miss Cissy, as glib as you like, said it was half
 30313	past kissing time, time to kiss again. But Edy wanted to know because
 30314	they were told to be in early.
 30315	
 30316	--Wait, said Cissy, I'll run ask my uncle Peter over there what's the
 30317	time by his conundrum.
 30318	
 30319	So over she went and when he saw her coming she could see him take his
 30320	hand out of his pocket, getting nervous, and beginning to play with his
 30321	watchchain, looking up at the church. Passionate nature though he was
 30322	Gerty could see that he had enormous control over himself. One moment he
 30323	had been there, fascinated by a loveliness that made him gaze, and the
 30324	next moment it was the quiet gravefaced gentleman, selfcontrol expressed
 30325	in every line of his distinguishedlooking figure.
 30326	
 30327	Cissy said to excuse her would he mind please telling her what was the
 30328	right time and Gerty could see him taking out his watch, listening to it
 30329	and looking up and clearing his throat and he said he was very sorry his
 30330	watch was stopped but he thought it must be after eight because the
 30331	sun was set. His voice had a cultured ring in it and though he spoke in
 30332	measured accents there was a suspicion of a quiver in the mellow tones.
 30333	Cissy said thanks and came back with her tongue out and said uncle said
 30334	his waterworks were out of order.
 30335	
 30336	Then they sang the second verse of the _Tantum ergo_ and Canon O'Hanlon
 30337	got up again and censed the Blessed Sacrament and knelt down and he told
 30338	Father Conroy that one of the candles was just going to set fire to the
 30339	flowers and Father Conroy got up and settled it all right and she could
 30340	see the gentleman winding his watch and listening to the works and she
 30341	swung her leg more in and out in time. It was getting darker but he
 30342	could see and he was looking all the time that he was winding the watch
 30343	or whatever he was doing to it and then he put it back and put his hands
 30344	back into his pockets. She felt a kind of a sensation rushing all over
 30345	her and she knew by the feel of her scalp and that irritation against
 30346	her stays that that thing must be coming on because the last time too
 30347	was when she clipped her hair on account of the moon. His dark eyes
 30348	fixed themselves on her again drinking in her every contour, literally
 30349	worshipping at her shrine. If ever there was undisguised admiration in a
 30350	man's passionate gaze it was there plain to be seen on that man's face.
 30351	It is for you, Gertrude MacDowell, and you know it.
 30352	
 30353	Edy began to get ready to go and it was high time for her and Gerty
 30354	noticed that that little hint she gave had had the desired effect
 30355	because it was a long way along the strand to where there was the place
 30356	to push up the pushcar and Cissy took off the twins' caps and tidied
 30357	their hair to make herself attractive of course and Canon O'Hanlon stood
 30358	up with his cope poking up at his neck and Father Conroy handed him the
 30359	card to read off and he read out _Panem de coelo praestitisti eis_ and
 30360	Edy and Cissy were talking about the time all the time and asking her
 30361	but Gerty could pay them back in their own coin and she just answered
 30362	with scathing politeness when Edy asked her was she heartbroken about
 30363	her best boy throwing her over. Gerty winced sharply. A brief cold blaze
 30364	shone from her eyes that spoke volumes of scorn immeasurable. It hurt--O
 30365	yes, it cut deep because Edy had her own quiet way of saying things
 30366	like that she knew would wound like the confounded little cat she was.
 30367	Gerty's lips parted swiftly to frame the word but she fought back
 30368	the sob that rose to her throat, so slim, so flawless, so beautifully
 30369	moulded it seemed one an artist might have dreamed of. She had loved him
 30370	better than he knew. Lighthearted deceiver and fickle like all his sex
 30371	he would never understand what he had meant to her and for an instant
 30372	there was in the blue eyes a quick stinging of tears. Their eyes were
 30373	probing her mercilessly but with a brave effort she sparkled back in
 30374	sympathy as she glanced at her new conquest for them to see.
 30375	
 30376	--O, responded Gerty, quick as lightning, laughing, and the proud head
 30377	flashed up. I can throw my cap at who I like because it's leap year.
 30378	
 30379	Her words rang out crystalclear, more musical than the cooing of the
 30380	ringdove, but they cut the silence icily. There was that in her young
 30381	voice that told that she was not a one to be lightly trifled with. As
 30382	for Mr Reggy with his swank and his bit of money she could just chuck
 30383	him aside as if he was so much filth and never again would she cast as
 30384	much as a second thought on him and tear his silly postcard into a dozen
 30385	pieces. And if ever after he dared to presume she could give him one
 30386	look of measured scorn that would make him shrivel up on the spot. Miss
 30387	puny little Edy's countenance fell to no slight extent and Gerty could
 30388	see by her looking as black as thunder that she was simply in a towering
 30389	rage though she hid it, the little kinnatt, because that shaft had
 30390	struck home for her petty jealousy and they both knew that she was
 30391	something aloof, apart, in another sphere, that she was not of them and
 30392	never would be and there was somebody else too that knew it and saw it
 30393	so they could put that in their pipe and smoke it.
 30394	
 30395	Edy straightened up baby Boardman to get ready to go and Cissy tucked in
 30396	the ball and the spades and buckets and it was high time too because the
 30397	sandman was on his way for Master Boardman junior. And Cissy told him
 30398	too that billy winks was coming and that baby was to go deedaw and baby
 30399	looked just too ducky, laughing up out of his gleeful eyes, and Cissy
 30400	poked him like that out of fun in his wee fat tummy and baby, without as
 30401	much as by your leave, sent up his compliments to all and sundry on to
 30402	his brandnew dribbling bib.
 30403	
 30404	--O my! Puddeny pie! protested Ciss. He has his bib destroyed.
 30405	
 30406	The slight _contretemps_ claimed her attention but in two twos she set
 30407	that little matter to rights.
 30408	
 30409	Gerty stifled a smothered exclamation and gave a nervous cough and Edy
 30410	asked what and she was just going to tell her to catch it while it was
 30411	flying but she was ever ladylike in her deportment so she simply passed
 30412	it off with consummate tact by saying that that was the benediction
 30413	because just then the bell rang out from the steeple over the quiet
 30414	seashore because Canon O'Hanlon was up on the altar with the veil that
 30415	Father Conroy put round his shoulders giving the benediction with the
 30416	Blessed Sacrament in his hands.
 30417	
 30418	How moving the scene there in the gathering twilight, the last glimpse
 30419	of Erin, the touching chime of those evening bells and at the same
 30420	time a bat flew forth from the ivied belfry through the dusk, hither,
 30421	thither, with a tiny lost cry. And she could see far away the lights of
 30422	the lighthouses so picturesque she would have loved to do with a box of
 30423	paints because it was easier than to make a man and soon the lamplighter
 30424	would be going his rounds past the presbyterian church grounds and along
 30425	by shady Tritonville avenue where the couples walked and lighting the
 30426	lamp near her window where Reggy Wylie used to turn his freewheel like
 30427	she read in that book _The Lamplighter_ by Miss Cummins, author of
 30428	_Mabel Vaughan_ and other tales. For Gerty had her dreams that no-one
 30429	knew of. She loved to read poetry and when she got a keepsake from
 30430	Bertha Supple of that lovely confession album with the coralpink cover
 30431	to write her thoughts in she laid it in the drawer of her toilettable
 30432	which, though it did not err on the side of luxury, was scrupulously
 30433	neat and clean. It was there she kept her girlish treasure trove, the
 30434	tortoiseshell combs, her child of Mary badge, the whiterose scent, the
 30435	eyebrowleine, her alabaster pouncetbox and the ribbons to change
 30436	when her things came home from the wash and there were some beautiful
 30437	thoughts written in it in violet ink that she bought in Hely's of Dame
 30438	Street for she felt that she too could write poetry if she could only
 30439	express herself like that poem that appealed to her so deeply that
 30440	she had copied out of the newspaper she found one evening round the
 30441	potherbs. _Art thou real, my ideal?_ it was called by Louis J Walsh,
 30442	Magherafelt, and after there was something about _twilight, wilt thou
 30443	ever?_ and ofttimes the beauty of poetry, so sad in its transient
 30444	loveliness, had misted her eyes with silent tears for she felt that
 30445	the years were slipping by for her, one by one, and but for that one
 30446	shortcoming she knew she need fear no competition and that was an
 30447	accident coming down Dalkey hill and she always tried to conceal it.
 30448	But it must end, she felt. If she saw that magic lure in his eyes there
 30449	would be no holding back for her. Love laughs at locksmiths. She
 30450	would make the great sacrifice. Her every effort would be to share his
 30451	thoughts. Dearer than the whole world would she be to him and gild his
 30452	days with happiness. There was the allimportant question and she was
 30453	dying to know was he a married man or a widower who had lost his wife
 30454	or some tragedy like the nobleman with the foreign name from the land
 30455	of song had to have her put into a madhouse, cruel only to be kind.
 30456	But even if--what then? Would it make a very great difference? From
 30457	everything in the least indelicate her finebred nature instinctively
 30458	recoiled. She loathed that sort of person, the fallen women off the
 30459	accommodation walk beside the Dodder that went with the soldiers and
 30460	coarse men with no respect for a girl's honour, degrading the sex and
 30461	being taken up to the police station. No, no: not that. They would be
 30462	just good friends like a big brother and sister without all that other
 30463	in spite of the conventions of Society with a big ess. Perhaps it was
 30464	an old flame he was in mourning for from the days beyond recall. She
 30465	thought she understood. She would try to understand him because men were
 30466	so different. The old love was waiting, waiting with little white
 30467	hands stretched out, with blue appealing eyes. Heart of mine! She would
 30468	follow, her dream of love, the dictates of her heart that told her he
 30469	was her all in all, the only man in all the world for her for love was
 30470	the master guide. Nothing else mattered. Come what might she would be
 30471	wild, untrammelled, free.
 30472	
 30473	Canon O'Hanlon put the Blessed Sacrament back into the tabernacle and
 30474	genuflected and the choir sang _Laudate Dominum omnes gentes_ and then
 30475	he locked the tabernacle door because the benediction was over and
 30476	Father Conroy handed him his hat to put on and crosscat Edy asked wasn't
 30477	she coming but Jacky Caffrey called out:
 30478	
 30479	--O, look, Cissy!
 30480	
 30481	And they all looked was it sheet lightning but Tommy saw it too over the
 30482	trees beside the church, blue and then green and purple.
 30483	
 30484	--It's fireworks, Cissy Caffrey said.
 30485	
 30486	And they all ran down the strand to see over the houses and the church,
 30487	helterskelter, Edy with the pushcar with baby Boardman in it and Cissy
 30488	holding Tommy and Jacky by the hand so they wouldn't fall running.
 30489	
 30490	--Come on, Gerty, Cissy called. It's the bazaar fireworks.
 30491	
 30492	But Gerty was adamant. She had no intention of being at their beck and
 30493	call. If they could run like rossies she could sit so she said she could
 30494	see from where she was. The eyes that were fastened upon her set her
 30495	pulses tingling. She looked at him a moment, meeting his glance, and
 30496	a light broke in upon her. Whitehot passion was in that face, passion
 30497	silent as the grave, and it had made her his. At last they were left
 30498	alone without the others to pry and pass remarks and she knew he could
 30499	be trusted to the death, steadfast, a sterling man, a man of inflexible
 30500	honour to his fingertips. His hands and face were working and a tremour
 30501	went over her. She leaned back far to look up where the fireworks were
 30502	and she caught her knee in her hands so as not to fall back looking up
 30503	and there was no-one to see only him and her when she revealed all her
 30504	graceful beautifully shaped legs like that, supply soft and delicately
 30505	rounded, and she seemed to hear the panting of his heart, his hoarse
 30506	breathing, because she knew too about the passion of men like that,
 30507	hotblooded, because Bertha Supple told her once in dead secret and made
 30508	her swear she'd never about the gentleman lodger that was staying with
 30509	them out of the Congested Districts Board that had pictures cut out of
 30510	papers of those skirtdancers and highkickers and she said he used to do
 30511	something not very nice that you could imagine sometimes in the bed. But
 30512	this was altogether different from a thing like that because there was
 30513	all the difference because she could almost feel him draw her face to
 30514	his and the first quick hot touch of his handsome lips. Besides there
 30515	was absolution so long as you didn't do the other thing before being
 30516	married and there ought to be women priests that would understand
 30517	without your telling out and Cissy Caffrey too sometimes had that dreamy
 30518	kind of dreamy look in her eyes so that she too, my dear, and Winny
 30519	Rippingham so mad about actors' photographs and besides it was on
 30520	account of that other thing coming on the way it did.
 30521	
 30522	And Jacky Caffrey shouted to look, there was another and she leaned back
 30523	and the garters were blue to match on account of the transparent and
 30524	they all saw it and they all shouted to look, look, there it was and
 30525	she leaned back ever so far to see the fireworks and something queer was
 30526	flying through the air, a soft thing, to and fro, dark. And she saw a
 30527	long Roman candle going up over the trees, up, up, and, in the tense
 30528	hush, they were all breathless with excitement as it went higher and
 30529	higher and she had to lean back more and more to look up after it, high,
 30530	high, almost out of sight, and her face was suffused with a divine, an
 30531	entrancing blush from straining back and he could see her other things
 30532	too, nainsook knickers, the fabric that caresses the skin, better than
 30533	those other pettiwidth, the green, four and eleven, on account of being
 30534	white and she let him and she saw that he saw and then it went so high
 30535	it went out of sight a moment and she was trembling in every limb from
 30536	being bent so far back that he had a full view high up above her knee
 30537	where no-one ever not even on the swing or wading and she wasn't ashamed
 30538	and he wasn't either to look in that immodest way like that because he
 30539	couldn't resist the sight of the wondrous revealment half offered like
 30540	those skirtdancers behaving so immodest before gentlemen looking and he
 30541	kept on looking, looking. She would fain have cried to him chokingly,
 30542	held out her snowy slender arms to him to come, to feel his lips laid on
 30543	her white brow, the cry of a young girl's love, a little strangled cry,
 30544	wrung from her, that cry that has rung through the ages. And then a
 30545	rocket sprang and bang shot blind blank and O! then the Roman candle
 30546	burst and it was like a sigh of O! and everyone cried O! O! in raptures
 30547	and it gushed out of it a stream of rain gold hair threads and they
 30548	shed and ah! they were all greeny dewy stars falling with golden, O so
 30549	lovely, O, soft, sweet, soft!
 30550	
 30551	Then all melted away dewily in the grey air: all was silent. Ah! She
 30552	glanced at him as she bent forward quickly, a pathetic little glance of
 30553	piteous protest, of shy reproach under which he coloured like a girl He
 30554	was leaning back against the rock behind. Leopold Bloom (for it is he)
 30555	stands silent, with bowed head before those young guileless eyes. What a
 30556	brute he had been! At it again? A fair unsullied soul had called to him
 30557	and, wretch that he was, how had he answered? An utter cad he had been!
 30558	He of all men! But there was an infinite store of mercy in those eyes,
 30559	for him too a word of pardon even though he had erred and sinned and
 30560	wandered. Should a girl tell? No, a thousand times no. That was their
 30561	secret, only theirs, alone in the hiding twilight and there was none to
 30562	know or tell save the little bat that flew so softly through the evening
 30563	to and fro and little bats don't tell.
 30564	
 30565	Cissy Caffrey whistled, imitating the boys in the football field to show
 30566	what a great person she was: and then she cried:
 30567	
 30568	--Gerty! Gerty! We're going. Come on. We can see from farther up.
 30569	
 30570	Gerty had an idea, one of love's little ruses. She slipped a hand into
 30571	her kerchief pocket and took out the wadding and waved in reply of
 30572	course without letting him and then slipped it back. Wonder if he's too
 30573	far to. She rose. Was it goodbye? No. She had to go but they would meet
 30574	again, there, and she would dream of that till then, tomorrow, of her
 30575	dream of yester eve. She drew herself up to her full height. Their souls
 30576	met in a last lingering glance and the eyes that reached her heart, full
 30577	of a strange shining, hung enraptured on her sweet flowerlike face. She
 30578	half smiled at him wanly, a sweet forgiving smile, a smile that verged
 30579	on tears, and then they parted.
 30580	
 30581	Slowly, without looking back she went down the uneven strand to Cissy,
 30582	to Edy to Jacky and Tommy Caffrey, to little baby Boardman. It was
 30583	darker now and there were stones and bits of wood on the strand and
 30584	slippy seaweed. She walked with a certain quiet dignity characteristic
 30585	of her but with care and very slowly because--because Gerty MacDowell
 30586	was...
 30587	
 30588	Tight boots? No. She's lame! O!
 30589	
 30590	Mr Bloom watched her as she limped away. Poor girl! That's why she's
 30591	left on the shelf and the others did a sprint. Thought something was
 30592	wrong by the cut of her jib. Jilted beauty. A defect is ten times worse
 30593	in a woman. But makes them polite. Glad I didn't know it when she was on
 30594	show. Hot little devil all the same. I wouldn't mind. Curiosity like a
 30595	nun or a negress or a girl with glasses. That squinty one is delicate.
 30596	Near her monthlies, I expect, makes them feel ticklish. I have such
 30597	a bad headache today. Where did I put the letter? Yes, all right. All
 30598	kinds of crazy longings. Licking pennies. Girl in Tranquilla convent
 30599	that nun told me liked to smell rock oil. Virgins go mad in the end I
 30600	suppose. Sister? How many women in Dublin have it today? Martha, she.
 30601	Something in the air. That's the moon. But then why don't all women
 30602	menstruate at the same time with the same moon, I mean? Depends on the
 30603	time they were born I suppose. Or all start scratch then get out of
 30604	step. Sometimes Molly and Milly together. Anyhow I got the best of that.
 30605	Damned glad I didn't do it in the bath this morning over her silly I
 30606	will punish you letter. Made up for that tramdriver this morning. That
 30607	gouger M'Coy stopping me to say nothing. And his wife engagement in the
 30608	country valise, voice like a pickaxe. Thankful for small mercies.
 30609	Cheap too. Yours for the asking. Because they want it themselves. Their
 30610	natural craving. Shoals of them every evening poured out of offices.
 30611	Reserve better. Don't want it they throw it at you. Catch em alive, O.
 30612	Pity they can't see themselves. A dream of wellfilled hose. Where was
 30613	that? Ah, yes. Mutoscope pictures in Capel street: for men only. Peeping
 30614	Tom. Willy's hat and what the girls did with it. Do they snapshot those
 30615	girls or is it all a fake? _Lingerie_ does it. Felt for the curves
 30616	inside her _deshabillÃ©._ Excites them also when they're. I'm all clean
 30617	come and dirty me. And they like dressing one another for the sacrifice.
 30618	Milly delighted with Molly's new blouse. At first. Put them all on to
 30619	take them all off. Molly. Why I bought her the violet garters. Us too:
 30620	the tie he wore, his lovely socks and turnedup trousers. He wore a pair
 30621	of gaiters the night that first we met. His lovely shirt was shining
 30622	beneath his what? of jet. Say a woman loses a charm with every pin she
 30623	takes out. Pinned together. O, Mairy lost the pin of her. Dressed up to
 30624	the nines for somebody. Fashion part of their charm. Just changes when
 30625	you're on the track of the secret. Except the east: Mary, Martha: now as
 30626	then. No reasonable offer refused. She wasn't in a hurry either. Always
 30627	off to a fellow when they are. They never forget an appointment. Out on
 30628	spec probably. They believe in chance because like themselves. And the
 30629	others inclined to give her an odd dig. Girl friends at school, arms
 30630	round each other's necks or with ten fingers locked, kissing and
 30631	whispering secrets about nothing in the convent garden. Nuns with
 30632	whitewashed faces, cool coifs and their rosaries going up and down,
 30633	vindictive too for what they can't get. Barbed wire. Be sure now and
 30634	write to me. And I'll write to you. Now won't you? Molly and Josie
 30635	Powell. Till Mr Right comes along, then meet once in a blue moon.
 30636	_Tableau!_ O, look who it is for the love of God! How are you at all?
 30637	What have you been doing with yourself? Kiss and delighted to, kiss,
 30638	to see you. Picking holes in each other's appearance. You're looking
 30639	splendid. Sister souls. Showing their teeth at one another. How many
 30640	have you left? Wouldn't lend each other a pinch of salt.
 30641	
 30642	Ah!
 30643	
 30644	Devils they are when that's coming on them. Dark devilish appearance.
 30645	Molly often told me feel things a ton weight. Scratch the sole of my
 30646	foot. O that way! O, that's exquisite! Feel it myself too. Good to rest
 30647	once in a way. Wonder if it's bad to go with them then. Safe in one way.
 30648	Turns milk, makes fiddlestrings snap. Something about withering plants I
 30649	read in a garden. Besides they say if the flower withers she wears she's
 30650	a flirt. All are. Daresay she felt 1. When you feel like that you often
 30651	meet what you feel. Liked me or what? Dress they look at. Always know a
 30652	fellow courting: collars and cuffs. Well cocks and lions do the same
 30653	and stags. Same time might prefer a tie undone or something. Trousers?
 30654	Suppose I when I was? No. Gently does it. Dislike rough and tumble. Kiss
 30655	in the dark and never tell. Saw something in me. Wonder what. Sooner
 30656	have me as I am than some poet chap with bearsgrease plastery hair,
 30657	lovelock over his dexter optic. To aid gentleman in literary. Ought to
 30658	attend to my appearance my age. Didn't let her see me in profile. Still,
 30659	you never know. Pretty girls and ugly men marrying. Beauty and the
 30660	beast. Besides I can't be so if Molly. Took off her hat to show her
 30661	hair. Wide brim. Bought to hide her face, meeting someone might know
 30662	her, bend down or carry a bunch of flowers to smell. Hair strong in rut.
 30663	Ten bob I got for Molly's combings when we were on the rocks in Holles
 30664	street. Why not? Suppose he gave her money. Why not? All a prejudice.
 30665	She's worth ten, fifteen, more, a pound. What? I think so. All that for
 30666	nothing. Bold hand: Mrs Marion. Did I forget to write address on
 30667	that letter like the postcard I sent to Flynn? And the day I went to
 30668	Drimmie's without a necktie. Wrangle with Molly it was put me off. No,
 30669	I remember. Richie Goulding: he's another. Weighs on his mind. Funny
 30670	my watch stopped at half past four. Dust. Shark liver oil they use to
 30671	clean. Could do it myself. Save. Was that just when he, she?
 30672	
 30673	O, he did. Into her. She did. Done.
 30674	
 30675	Ah!
 30676	
 30677	Mr Bloom with careful hand recomposed his wet shirt. O Lord, that little
 30678	limping devil. Begins to feel cold and clammy. Aftereffect not pleasant.
 30679	Still you have to get rid of it someway. They don't care. Complimented
 30680	perhaps. Go home to nicey bread and milky and say night prayers with the
 30681	kiddies. Well, aren't they? See her as she is spoil all. Must have
 30682	the stage setting, the rouge, costume, position, music. The name too.
 30683	_Amours_ of actresses. Nell Gwynn, Mrs Bracegirdle, Maud Branscombe.
 30684	Curtain up. Moonlight silver effulgence. Maiden discovered with pensive
 30685	bosom. Little sweetheart come and kiss me. Still, I feel. The strength
 30686	it gives a man. That's the secret of it. Good job I let off there behind
 30687	the wall coming out of Dignam's. Cider that was. Otherwise I couldn't
 30688	have. Makes you want to sing after. _Lacaus esant taratara_. Suppose I
 30689	spoke to her. What about? Bad plan however if you don't know how to end
 30690	the conversation. Ask them a question they ask you another. Good idea if
 30691	you're stuck. Gain time. But then you're in a cart. Wonderful of course
 30692	if you say: good evening, and you see she's on for it: good evening. O
 30693	but the dark evening in the Appian way I nearly spoke to Mrs Clinch O
 30694	thinking she was. Whew! Girl in Meath street that night. All the dirty
 30695	things I made her say. All wrong of course. My arks she called it. It's
 30696	so hard to find one who. Aho! If you don't answer when they solicit must
 30697	be horrible for them till they harden. And kissed my hand when I gave
 30698	her the extra two shillings. Parrots. Press the button and the bird will
 30699	squeak. Wish she hadn't called me sir. O, her mouth in the dark! And you
 30700	a married man with a single girl! That's what they enjoy. Taking a man
 30701	from another woman. Or even hear of it. Different with me. Glad to get
 30702	away from other chap's wife. Eating off his cold plate. Chap in the
 30703	Burton today spitting back gumchewed gristle. French letter still in
 30704	my pocketbook. Cause of half the trouble. But might happen sometime,
 30705	I don't think. Come in, all is prepared. I dreamt. What? Worst is
 30706	beginning. How they change the venue when it's not what they like. Ask
 30707	you do you like mushrooms because she once knew a gentleman who. Or ask
 30708	you what someone was going to say when he changed his mind and stopped.
 30709	Yet if I went the whole hog, say: I want to, something like that.
 30710	Because I did. She too. Offend her. Then make it up. Pretend to want
 30711	something awfully, then cry off for her sake. Flatters them. She must
 30712	have been thinking of someone else all the time. What harm? Must since
 30713	she came to the use of reason, he, he and he. First kiss does the trick.
 30714	The propitious moment. Something inside them goes pop. Mushy like, tell
 30715	by their eye, on the sly. First thoughts are best. Remember that till
 30716	their dying day. Molly, lieutenant Mulvey that kissed her under the
 30717	Moorish wall beside the gardens. Fifteen she told me. But her breasts
 30718	were developed. Fell asleep then. After Glencree dinner that was when we
 30719	drove home. Featherbed mountain. Gnashing her teeth in sleep. Lord mayor
 30720	had his eye on her too. Val Dillon. Apoplectic.
 30721	
 30722	There she is with them down there for the fireworks. My fireworks. Up
 30723	like a rocket, down like a stick. And the children, twins they must
 30724	be, waiting for something to happen. Want to be grownups. Dressing in
 30725	mother's clothes. Time enough, understand all the ways of the world. And
 30726	the dark one with the mop head and the nigger mouth. I knew she could
 30727	whistle. Mouth made for that. Like Molly. Why that highclass whore in
 30728	Jammet's wore her veil only to her nose. Would you mind, please, telling
 30729	me the right time? I'll tell you the right time up a dark lane.
 30730	Say prunes and prisms forty times every morning, cure for fat lips.
 30731	Caressing the little boy too. Onlookers see most of the game. Of course
 30732	they understand birds, animals, babies. In their line.
 30733	
 30734	Didn't look back when she was going down the strand. Wouldn't give that
 30735	satisfaction. Those girls, those girls, those lovely seaside girls. Fine
 30736	eyes she had, clear. It's the white of the eye brings that out not so
 30737	much the pupil. Did she know what I? Course. Like a cat sitting beyond
 30738	a dog's jump. Women never meet one like that Wilkins in the high school
 30739	drawing a picture of Venus with all his belongings on show. Call that
 30740	innocence? Poor idiot! His wife has her work cut out for her. Never see
 30741	them sit on a bench marked _Wet Paint_. Eyes all over them. Look under
 30742	the bed for what's not there. Longing to get the fright of their lives.
 30743	Sharp as needles they are. When I said to Molly the man at the corner of
 30744	Cuffe street was goodlooking, thought she might like, twigged at once he
 30745	had a false arm. Had, too. Where do they get that? Typist going up Roger
 30746	Greene's stairs two at a time to show her understandings. Handed down
 30747	from father to, mother to daughter, I mean. Bred in the bone. Milly for
 30748	example drying her handkerchief on the mirror to save the ironing. Best
 30749	place for an ad to catch a woman's eye on a mirror. And when I sent
 30750	her for Molly's Paisley shawl to Prescott's by the way that ad I must,
 30751	carrying home the change in her stocking! Clever little minx. I never
 30752	told her. Neat way she carries parcels too. Attract men, small thing
 30753	like that. Holding up her hand, shaking it, to let the blood flow back
 30754	when it was red. Who did you learn that from? Nobody. Something the
 30755	nurse taught me. O, don't they know! Three years old she was in front of
 30756	Molly's dressingtable, just before we left Lombard street west. Me have
 30757	a nice pace. Mullingar. Who knows? Ways of the world. Young student.
 30758	Straight on her pins anyway not like the other. Still she was game.
 30759	Lord, I am wet. Devil you are. Swell of her calf. Transparent stockings,
 30760	stretched to breaking point. Not like that frump today. A. E. Rumpled
 30761	stockings. Or the one in Grafton street. White. Wow! Beef to the heel.
 30762	
 30763	A monkey puzzle rocket burst, spluttering in darting crackles. Zrads and
 30764	zrads, zrads, zrads. And Cissy and Tommy and Jacky ran out to see and
 30765	Edy after with the pushcar and then Gerty beyond the curve of the rocks.
 30766	Will she? Watch! Watch! See! Looked round. She smelt an onion. Darling,
 30767	I saw, your. I saw all.
 30768	
 30769	Lord!
 30770	
 30771	Did me good all the same. Off colour after Kiernan's, Dignam's. For
 30772	this relief much thanks. In _Hamlet,_ that is. Lord! It was all things
 30773	combined. Excitement. When she leaned back, felt an ache at the butt
 30774	of my tongue. Your head it simply swirls. He's right. Might have made a
 30775	worse fool of myself however. Instead of talking about nothing. Then
 30776	I will tell you all. Still it was a kind of language between us. It
 30777	couldn't be? No, Gerty they called her. Might be false name however like
 30778	my name and the address Dolphin's barn a blind.
 30779	
 30780	_Her maiden name was Jemina Brown And she lived with her mother in
 30781	Irishtown._
 30782	
 30783	Place made me think of that I suppose. All tarred with the same brush
 30784	Wiping pens in their stockings. But the ball rolled down to her as if
 30785	it understood. Every bullet has its billet. Course I never could throw
 30786	anything straight at school. Crooked as a ram's horn. Sad however
 30787	because it lasts only a few years till they settle down to potwalloping
 30788	and papa's pants will soon fit Willy and fuller's earth for the baby
 30789	when they hold him out to do ah ah. No soft job. Saves them. Keeps
 30790	them out of harm's way. Nature. Washing child, washing corpse. Dignam.
 30791	Children's hands always round them. Cocoanut skulls, monkeys, not even
 30792	closed at first, sour milk in their swaddles and tainted curds. Oughtn't
 30793	to have given that child an empty teat to suck. Fill it up with wind.
 30794	Mrs Beaufoy, Purefoy. Must call to the hospital. Wonder is nurse Callan
 30795	there still. She used to look over some nights when Molly was in the
 30796	Coffee Palace. That young doctor O'Hare I noticed her brushing his coat.
 30797	And Mrs Breen and Mrs Dignam once like that too, marriageable. Worst
 30798	of all at night Mrs Duggan told me in the City Arms. Husband rolling in
 30799	drunk, stink of pub off him like a polecat. Have that in your nose in
 30800	the dark, whiff of stale boose. Then ask in the morning: was I drunk
 30801	last night? Bad policy however to fault the husband. Chickens come home
 30802	to roost. They stick by one another like glue. Maybe the women's fault
 30803	also. That's where Molly can knock spots off them. It's the blood of the
 30804	south. Moorish. Also the form, the figure. Hands felt for the opulent.
 30805	Just compare for instance those others. Wife locked up at home, skeleton
 30806	in the cupboard. Allow me to introduce my. Then they trot you out some
 30807	kind of a nondescript, wouldn't know what to call her. Always see a
 30808	fellow's weak point in his wife. Still there's destiny in it, falling
 30809	in love. Have their own secrets between them. Chaps that would go to the
 30810	dogs if some woman didn't take them in hand. Then little chits of girls,
 30811	height of a shilling in coppers, with little hubbies. As God made them
 30812	he matched them. Sometimes children turn out well enough. Twice nought
 30813	makes one. Or old rich chap of seventy and blushing bride. Marry in May
 30814	and repent in December. This wet is very unpleasant. Stuck. Well the
 30815	foreskin is not back. Better detach.
 30816	
 30817	Ow!
 30818	
 30819	Other hand a sixfooter with a wifey up to his watchpocket. Long and
 30820	the short of it. Big he and little she. Very strange about my watch.
 30821	Wristwatches are always going wrong. Wonder is there any magnetic
 30822	influence between the person because that was about the time he. Yes, I
 30823	suppose, at once. Cat's away, the mice will play. I remember looking
 30824	in Pill lane. Also that now is magnetism. Back of everything magnetism.
 30825	Earth for instance pulling this and being pulled. That causes movement.
 30826	And time, well that's the time the movement takes. Then if one thing
 30827	stopped the whole ghesabo would stop bit by bit. Because it's all
 30828	arranged. Magnetic needle tells you what's going on in the sun, the
 30829	stars. Little piece of steel iron. When you hold out the fork. Come.
 30830	Come. Tip. Woman and man that is. Fork and steel. Molly, he. Dress up
 30831	and look and suggest and let you see and see more and defy you if you're
 30832	a man to see that and, like a sneeze coming, legs, look, look and if you
 30833	have any guts in you. Tip. Have to let fly.
 30834	
 30835	Wonder how is she feeling in that region. Shame all put on before third
 30836	person. More put out about a hole in her stocking. Molly, her underjaw
 30837	stuck out, head back, about the farmer in the ridingboots and spurs at
 30838	the horse show. And when the painters were in Lombard street west.
 30839	Fine voice that fellow had. How Giuglini began. Smell that I did. Like
 30840	flowers. It was too. Violets. Came from the turpentine probably in the
 30841	paint. Make their own use of everything. Same time doing it scraped her
 30842	slipper on the floor so they wouldn't hear. But lots of them can't kick
 30843	the beam, I think. Keep that thing up for hours. Kind of a general all
 30844	round over me and half down my back.
 30845	
 30846	Wait. Hm. Hm. Yes. That's her perfume. Why she waved her hand. I leave
 30847	you this to think of me when I'm far away on the pillow. What is it?
 30848	Heliotrope? No. Hyacinth? Hm. Roses, I think. She'd like scent of that
 30849	kind. Sweet and cheap: soon sour. Why Molly likes opoponax. Suits her,
 30850	with a little jessamine mixed. Her high notes and her low notes. At the
 30851	dance night she met him, dance of the hours. Heat brought it out. She
 30852	was wearing her black and it had the perfume of the time before. Good
 30853	conductor, is it? Or bad? Light too. Suppose there's some connection.
 30854	For instance if you go into a cellar where it's dark. Mysterious thing
 30855	too. Why did I smell it only now? Took its time in coming like herself,
 30856	slow but sure. Suppose it's ever so many millions of tiny grains
