 33371	chortling, trumming, twanging, they diddle diddle cakewalk dance away.)_
 33372	
 33373	BLOOM: _(With a sour tenderish smile)_ A little frivol, shall we, if
 33374	you are so inclined? Would you like me perhaps to embrace you just for a
 33375	fraction of a second?
 33376	
 33377	MRS BREEN: _(Screams gaily)_ O, you ruck! You ought to see yourself!
 33378	
 33379	BLOOM: For old sake' sake. I only meant a square party, a mixed marriage
 33380	mingling of our different little conjugials. You know I had a soft
 33381	corner for you. _(Gloomily)_ 'Twas I sent you that valentine of the dear
 33382	gazelle.
 33383	
 33384	MRS BREEN: Glory Alice, you do look a holy show! Killing simply. _(She
 33385	puts out her hand inquisitively)_ What are you hiding behind your back?
 33386	Tell us, there's a dear.
 33387	
 33388	BLOOM: _(Seizes her wrist with his free hand)_ Josie Powell that was,
 33389	prettiest deb in Dublin. How time flies by! Do you remember, harking
 33390	back in a retrospective arrangement, Old Christmas night, Georgina
 33391	Simpson's housewarming while they were playing the Irving Bishop game,
 33392	finding the pin blindfold and thoughtreading? Subject, what is in this
 33393	snuffbox?
 33394	
 33395	MRS BREEN: You were the lion of the night with your seriocomic
 33396	recitation and you looked the part. You were always a favourite with the
 33397	ladies.
 33398	
 33399	BLOOM: _(Squire of dames, in dinner jacket with wateredsilk facings,
 33400	blue masonic badge in his buttonhole, black bow and mother-of-pearl
 33401	studs, a prismatic champagne glass tilted in his hand)_ Ladies and
 33402	gentlemen, I give you Ireland, home and beauty.
 33403	
 33404	MRS BREEN: The dear dead days beyond recall. Love's old sweet song.
 33405	
 33406	BLOOM: _(Meaningfully dropping his voice)_ I confess I'm teapot with
 33407	curiosity to find out whether some person's something is a little teapot
 33408	at present.
 33409	
 33410	MRS BREEN: _(Gushingly)_ Tremendously teapot! London's teapot and I'm
 33411	simply teapot all over me! _(She rubs sides with him)_ After the parlour
 33412	mystery games and the crackers from the tree we sat on the staircase
 33413	ottoman. Under the mistletoe. Two is company.
 33414	
 33415	BLOOM: _(Wearing a purple Napoleon hat with an amber halfmoon, his
 33416	fingers and thumb passing slowly down to her soft moist meaty palm which
 33417	she surrenders gently)_ The witching hour of night. I took the splinter
 33418	out of this hand, carefully, slowly. _(Tenderly, as he slips on her
 33419	finger a ruby ring) LÃ  ci darem la mano._
 33420	
 33421	MRS BREEN: _(In a onepiece evening frock executed in moonlight blue, a
 33422	tinsel sylph's diadem on her brow with her dancecard fallen beside
 33423	her moonblue satin slipper, curves her palm softly, breathing quickly)
 33424	Voglio e non._ You're hot! You're scalding! The left hand nearest the
 33425	heart.
 33426	
 33427	BLOOM: When you made your present choice they said it was beauty and
 33428	the beast. I can never forgive you for that. _(His clenched fist at
 33429	his brow)_ Think what it means. All you meant to me then. _(Hoarsely)_
 33430	Woman, it's breaking me!
 33431	
 33432	_(Denis Breen, whitetallhatted, with Wisdom Hely's sandwich-boards,
 33433	shuffles past them in carpet slippers, his dull beard thrust out,
 33434	muttering to right and left. Little Alf Bergan, cloaked in the pall of
 33435	the ace of spades, dogs him to left and right, doubled in laughter.)_
 33436	
 33437	ALF BERGAN: _(Points jeering at the sandwichboards)_ U. p: Up.
 33438	
 33439	MRS BREEN: _(To Bloom)_ High jinks below stairs. _(She gives him the
 33440	glad eye)_ Why didn't you kiss the spot to make it well? You wanted to.
 33441	
 33442	BLOOM: _(Shocked)_ Molly's best friend! Could you?
 33443	
 33444	MRS BREEN: _(Her pulpy tongue between her lips, offers a pigeon kiss)_
 33445	Hnhn. The answer is a lemon. Have you a little present for me there?
 33446	
 33447	BLOOM: _(Offhandedly)_ Kosher. A snack for supper. The home without
 33448	potted meat is incomplete. I was at _Leah._ Mrs Bandmann Palmer.
 33449	Trenchant exponent of Shakespeare. Unfortunately threw away the
 33450	programme. Rattling good place round there for pigs' feet. Feel.
 33451	
 33452	_(Richie Goulding, three ladies' hats pinned on his head, appears
 33453	weighted to one side by the black legal bag of Collis and Ward on which
 33454	a skull and crossbones are painted in white limewash. He opens it
 33455	and shows it full of polonies, kippered herrings, Findon haddies and
 33456	tightpacked pills.)_
 33457	
 33458	RICHIE: Best value in Dub.
 33459	
 33460	_(Bald Pat, bothered beetle, stands on the curbstone, folding his
 33461	napkin, waiting to wait.)_
 33462	
 33463	PAT: _(Advances with a tilted dish of spillspilling gravy)_ Steak and
 33464	kidney. Bottle of lager. Hee hee hee. Wait till I wait.
 33465	
 33466	RICHIE: Goodgod. Inev erate inall...
 33467	
 33468	_(With hanging head he marches doggedly forward. The navvy, lurching by,
 33469	gores him with his flaming pronghorn.)_
 33470	
 33471	RICHIE: _(With a cry of pain, his hand to his back)_ Ah! Bright's!
 33472	Lights!
 33473	
 33474	BLOOM: _(Ooints to the navvy)_ A spy. Don't attract attention. I hate
 33475	stupid crowds. I am not on pleasure bent. I am in a grave predicament.
 33476	
 33477	MRS BREEN: Humbugging and deluthering as per usual with your cock and
 33478	bull story.
 33479	
 33480	BLOOM: I want to tell you a little secret about how I came to be here.
 33481	But you must never tell. Not even Molly. I have a most particular
 33482	reason.
 33483	
 33484	MRS BREEN: _(All agog)_ O, not for worlds.
 33485	
 33486	BLOOM: Let's walk on. Shall us?
 33487	
 33488	MRS BREEN: Let's.
 33489	
 33490	_(The bawd makes an unheeded sign. Bloom walks on with Mrs Breen. The
 33491	terrier follows, whining piteously, wagging his tail.)_
 33492	
 33493	THE BAWD: Jewman's melt!
 33494	
 33495	BLOOM: _(In an oatmeal sporting suit, a sprig of woodbine in the lapel,
 33496	tony buff shirt, shepherd's plaid Saint Andrew's cross scarftie, white
 33497	spats, fawn dustcoat on his arm, tawny red brogues, fieldglasses in
 33498	bandolier and a grey billycock hat)_ Do you remember a long long time,
 33499	years and years ago, just after Milly, Marionette we called her, was
 33500	weaned when we all went together to Fairyhouse races, was it?
 33501	
 33502	MRS BREEN: _(In smart Saxe tailormade, white velours hat and spider
 33503	veil)_ Leopardstown.
 33504	
 33505	BLOOM: I mean, Leopardstown. And Molly won seven shillings on a three
 33506	year old named Nevertell and coming home along by Foxrock in that old
 33507	fiveseater shanderadan of a waggonette you were in your heyday then and
 33508	you had on that new hat of white velours with a surround of molefur that
 33509	Mrs Hayes advised you to buy because it was marked down to nineteen and
 33510	eleven, a bit of wire and an old rag of velveteen, and I'll lay you what
 33511	you like she did it on purpose...
 33512	
 33513	MRS BREEN: She did, of course, the cat! Don't tell me! Nice adviser!
 33514	
 33515	BLOOM: Because it didn't suit you one quarter as well as the other ducky
 33516	little tammy toque with the bird of paradise wing in it that I admired
 33517	on you and you honestly looked just too fetching in it though it was a
 33518	pity to kill it, you cruel naughty creature, little mite of a thing with
 33519	a heart the size of a fullstop.
 33520	
 33521	MRS BREEN: _(Squeezes his arm, simpers)_ Naughty cruel I was!
 33522	
 33523	BLOOM: _(Low, secretly, ever more rapidly)_ And Molly was eating a
 33524	sandwich of spiced beef out of Mrs Joe Gallaher's lunch basket. Frankly,
 33525	though she had her advisers or admirers, I never cared much for her
 33526	style. She was...
 33527	
 33528	MRS BREEN: Too...
 33529	
 33530	BLOOM: Yes. And Molly was laughing because Rogers and Maggot O'Reilly
 33531	were mimicking a cock as we passed a farmhouse and Marcus Tertius Moses,
 33532	the tea merchant, drove past us in a gig with his daughter, Dancer Moses
 33533	was her name, and the poodle in her lap bridled up and you asked me if I
 33534	ever heard or read or knew or came across...
 33535	
 33536	MRS BREEN: _(Eagerly)_ Yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes.
 33537	
 33538	_(She fades from his side. Followed by the whining dog he walks on
 33539	towards hellsgates. In an archway a standing woman, bent forward, her
 33540	feet apart, pisses cowily. Outside a shuttered pub a bunch of loiterers
 33541	listen to a tale which their brokensnouted gaffer rasps out with raucous
 33542	humour. An armless pair of them flop wrestling, growling, in maimed
 33543	sodden playfight.)_
 33544	
 33545	THE GAFFER: _(Crouches, his voice twisted in his snout)_ And when Cairns
 33546	came down from the scaffolding in Beaver street what was he after doing
 33547	it into only into the bucket of porter that was there waiting on the
 33548	shavings for Derwan's plasterers.
 33549	
 33550	THE LOITERERS: _(Guffaw with cleft palates)_ O jays!
 33551	
 33552	_(Their paintspeckled hats wag. Spattered with size and lime of their
 33553	lodges they frisk limblessly about him.)_
 33554	
 33555	BLOOM: Coincidence too. They think it funny. Anything but that. Broad
 33556	daylight. Trying to walk. Lucky no woman.
 33557	
 33558	THE LOITERERS: Jays, that's a good one. Glauber salts. O jays, into the
 33559	men's porter.
 33560	
 33561	_(Bloom passes. Cheap whores, singly, coupled, shawled, dishevelled,
 33562	call from lanes, doors, corners.)_
 33563	
 33564	THE WHORES:
 33565	
 33566	     Are you going far, queer fellow?
 33567	     How's your middle leg?
 33568	     Got a match on you?
 33569	     Eh, come here till I stiffen it for you.
 33570	
 33571	
 33572	_(He plodges through their sump towards the lighted street beyond. From
 33573	a bulge of window curtains a gramophone rears a battered brazen trunk.
 33574	In the shadow a shebeenkeeper haggles with the navvy and the two
 33575	redcoats.)_
 33576	
 33577	THE NAVVY: _(Belching)_ Where's the bloody house?
 33578	
 33579	THE SHEBEENKEEPER: Purdon street. Shilling a bottle of stout.
 33580	Respectable woman.
 33581	
 33582	THE NAVVY: _(Gripping the two redcoats, staggers forward with them)_
 33583	Come on, you British army!
 33584	
 33585	PRIVATE CARR: _(Behind his back)_ He aint half balmy.
 33586	
 33587	PRIVATE COMPTON: _(Laughs)_ What ho!
 33588	
 33589	PRIVATE CARR: _(To the navvy)_ Portobello barracks canteen. You ask for
 33590	Carr. Just Carr.
 33591	
 33592	THE NAVVY: _(Shouts)_
 33593	
 33594	We are the boys. Of Wexford.
 33595	
 33596	PRIVATE COMPTON: Say! What price the sergeantmajor?
 33597	
 33598	PRIVATE CARR: Bennett? He's my pal. I love old Bennett.
 33599	
 33600	THE NAVVY: _(Shouts)_
 33601	
 33602	     The galling chain.
 33603	     And free our native land.
 33604	
 33605	_(He staggers forward, dragging them with him. Bloom stops, at fault.
 33606	The dog approaches, his tongue outlolling, panting)_
 33607	
 33608	BLOOM: Wildgoose chase this. Disorderly houses. Lord knows where they
 33609	are gone. Drunks cover distance double quick. Nice mixup. Scene at
 33610	Westland row. Then jump in first class with third ticket. Then too far.
 33611	Train with engine behind. Might have taken me to Malahide or a siding
 33612	for the night or collision. Second drink does it. Once is a dose. What
 33613	am I following him for? Still, he's the best of that lot. If I hadn't
 33614	heard about Mrs Beaufoy Purefoy I wouldn't have gone and wouldn't have
 33615	met. Kismet. He'll lose that cash. Relieving office here. Good biz for
 33616	cheapjacks, organs. What do ye lack? Soon got, soon gone. Might have
 33617	lost my life too with that mangongwheeltracktrolleyglarejuggernaut only
 33618	for presence of mind. Can't always save you, though. If I had passed
 33619	Truelock's window that day two minutes later would have been shot.
 33620	Absence of body. Still if bullet only went through my coat get damages
 33621	for shock, five hundred pounds. What was he? Kildare street club toff.
 33622	God help his gamekeeper.
 33623	
 33624	_(He gazes ahead, reading on the wall a scrawled chalk legend_ Wet Dream
 33625	_and a phallic design._) Odd! Molly drawing on the frosted carriagepane
 33626	at Kingstown. What's that like? _(Gaudy dollwomen loll in the lighted
 33627	doorways, in window embrasures, smoking birdseye cigarettes. The
 33628	odour of the sicksweet weed floats towards him in slow round ovalling
 33629	wreaths.)_
 33630	
 33631	THE WREATHS: Sweet are the sweets. Sweets of sin.
 33632	
 33633	BLOOM: My spine's a bit limp. Go or turn? And this food? Eat it and get
 33634	all pigsticky. Absurd I am. Waste of money. One and eightpence too
 33635	much. _(The retriever drives a cold snivelling muzzle against his hand,
 33636	wagging his tail.)_ Strange how they take to me. Even that brute today.
 33637	Better speak to him first. Like women they like _rencontres._ Stinks
 33638	like a polecat. _Chacun son gout_. He might be mad. Dogdays. Uncertain
 33639	in his movements. Good fellow! Fido! Good fellow! Garryowen! _(The
 33640	wolfdog sprawls on his back, wriggling obscenely with begging paws, his
 33641	long black tongue lolling out.)_ Influence of his surroundings. Give
 33642	and have done with it. Provided nobody. _(Calling encouraging words he
 33643	shambles back with a furtive poacher's tread, dogged by the setter into
 33644	a dark stalestunk corner. He unrolls one parcel and goes to dump the
 33645	crubeen softly but holds back and feels the trotter.)_ Sizeable for
 33646	threepence. But then I have it in my left hand. Calls for more effort.
 33647	Why? Smaller from want of use. O, let it slide. Two and six.
 33648	
 33649	_(With regret he lets the unrolled crubeen and trotter slide. The
 33650	mastiff mauls the bundle clumsily and gluts himself with growling greed,
 33651	crunching the bones. Two raincaped watch approach, silent, vigilant.
 33652	They murmur together.)_
 33653	
 33654	THE WATCH: Bloom. Of Bloom. For Bloom. Bloom.
 33655	
 33656	_(Each lays hand on Bloom's shoulder.)_
 33657	
 33658	FIRST WATCH: Caught in the act. Commit no nuisance.
 33659	
 33660	BLOOM: _(Stammers)_ I am doing good to others.
 33661	
 33662	_(A covey of gulls, storm petrels, rises hungrily from Liffey slime with
 33663	Banbury cakes in their beaks.)_
 33664	
 33665	THE GULLS: Kaw kave kankury kake.
 33666	
 33667	BLOOM: The friend of man. Trained by kindness.
 33668	
 33669	_(He points. Bob Doran, toppling from a high barstool, sways over the
 33670	munching spaniel.)_
 33671	
 33672	BOB DORAN: Towser. Give us the paw. Give the paw.
 33673	
 33674	_(The bulldog growls, his scruff standing, a gobbet of pig's knuckle
 33675	between his molars through which rabid scumspittle dribbles. Bob Doran
 33676	fills silently into an area.)_
 33677	
 33678	SECOND WATCH: Prevention of cruelty to animals.
 33679	
 33680	BLOOM: _(Enthusiastically)_ A noble work! I scolded that tramdriver on
 33681	Harold's cross bridge for illusing the poor horse with his harness scab.
 33682	Bad French I got for my pains. Of course it was frosty and the last
 33683	tram. All tales of circus life are highly demoralising.
 33684	
 33685	_(Signor Maffei, passionpale, in liontamer's costume with diamond studs
 33686	in his shirtfront, steps forward, holding a circus paperhoop, a
 33687	curling carriagewhip and a revolver with which he covers the gorging
 33688	boarhound.)_
 33689	
 33690	SIGNOR MAFFEI: _(With a sinister smile)_ Ladies and gentlemen, my
 33691	educated greyhound. It was I broke in the bucking broncho Ajax with my
 33692	patent spiked saddle for carnivores. Lash under the belly with a knotted
 33693	thong. Block tackle and a strangling pulley will bring your lion to
 33694	heel, no matter how fractious, even _Leo ferox_ there, the Libyan
 33695	maneater. A redhot crowbar and some liniment rubbing on the burning part
 33696	produced Fritz of Amsterdam, the thinking hyena. _(He glares)_ I possess
 33697	the Indian sign. The glint of my eye does it with these breastsparklers.
 33698	_(With a bewitching smile)_ I now introduce Mademoiselle Ruby, the pride
 33699	of the ring.
 33700	
 33701	FIRST WATCH: Come. Name and address.
 33702	
 33703	BLOOM: I have forgotten for the moment. Ah, yes! _(He takes off his high
 33704	grade hat, saluting)_ Dr Bloom, Leopold, dental surgeon. You have heard
 33705	of von Blum Pasha. Umpteen millions. _Donnerwetter!_ Owns half Austria.
 33706	Egypt. Cousin.
 33707	
 33708	FIRST WATCH: Proof.
 33709	
 33710	_(A card falls from inside the leather headband of Bloom's hat.)_
 33711	
 33712	BLOOM: _(In red fez, cadi's dress coat with broad green sash, wearing
 33713	a false badge of the Legion of Honour, picks up the card hastily and
 33714	offers it)_ Allow me. My club is the Junior Army and Navy. Solicitors:
 33715	Messrs John Henry Menton, 27 Bachelor's Walk.
 33716	
 33717	FIRST WATCH: _(Reads)_ Henry Flower. No fixed abode. Unlawfully watching
 33718	and besetting.
 33719	
 33720	SECOND WATCH: An alibi. You are cautioned.
 33721	
 33722	BLOOM: _(Produces from his heartpocket a crumpled yellow flower)_ This
 33723	is the flower in question. It was given me by a man I don't know his
 33724	name. _(Plausibly)_ You know that old joke, rose of Castile. Bloom. The
 33725	change of name. Virag. _(He murmurs privately and confidentially)_ We
 33726	are engaged you see, sergeant. Lady in the case. Love entanglement. _(He
 33727	shoulders the second watch gently)_ Dash it all. It's a way we gallants
 33728	have in the navy. Uniform that does it. _(He turns gravely to the first
 33729	watch)_ Still, of course, you do get your Waterloo sometimes. Drop in
 33730	some evening and have a glass of old Burgundy. _(To the second watch
 33731	gaily)_ I'll introduce you, inspector. She's game. Do it in the shake of
 33732	a lamb's tail.
 33733	
 33734	_(A dark mercurialised face appears, leading a veiled figure.)_
 33735	
 33736	THE DARK MERCURY: The Castle is looking for him. He was drummed out of
 33737	the army.
 33738	
 33739	MARTHA: _(Thickveiled, a crimson halter round her neck, a copy of
 33740	the_ Irish Times _in her hand, in tone of reproach, pointing)_ Henry!
 33741	Leopold! Lionel, thou lost one! Clear my name.
 33742	
 33743	FIRST WATCH: _(Sternly)_ Come to the station.
 33744	
 33745	BLOOM: _(Scared, hats himself, steps back, then, plucking at his heart
 33746	and lifting his right forearm on the square, he gives the sign and
 33747	dueguard of fellowcraft)_ No, no, worshipful master, light of love.
 33748	Mistaken identity. The Lyons mail. Lesurques and Dubosc. You remember
 33749	the Childs fratricide case. We medical men. By striking him dead with
 33750	a hatchet. I am wrongfully accused. Better one guilty escape than
 33751	ninetynine wrongfully condemned.
 33752	
 33753	MARTHA: _(Sobbing behind her veil)_ Breach of promise. My real name
 33754	is Peggy Griffin. He wrote to me that he was miserable. I'll tell my
 33755	brother, the Bective rugger fullback, on you, heartless flirt.
 33756	
 33757	BLOOM: _(Behind his hand)_ She's drunk. The woman is inebriated. _(He
 33758	murmurs vaguely the pass of Ephraim)_ Shitbroleeth.
 33759	
 33760	SECOND WATCH: _(Tears in his eyes, to Bloom)_ You ought to be thoroughly
 33761	well ashamed of yourself.
 33762	
 33763	BLOOM: Gentlemen of the jury, let me explain. A pure mare's nest. I am
 33764	a man misunderstood. I am being made a scapegoat of. I am a respectable
 33765	married man, without a stain on my character. I live in Eccles street.
 33766	My wife, I am the daughter of a most distinguished commander, a gallant
 33767	upstanding gentleman, what do you call him, Majorgeneral Brian Tweedy,
 33768	one of Britain's fighting men who helped to win our battles. Got his
 33769	majority for the heroic defence of Rorke's Drift.
 33770	
 33771	FIRST WATCH: Regiment.
 33772	
 33773	BLOOM: _(Turns to the gallery)_ The royal Dublins, boys, the salt of the
 33774	earth, known the world over. I think I see some old comrades in arms
 33775	up there among you. The R. D. F., with our own Metropolitan police,
 33776	guardians of our homes, the pluckiest lads and the finest body of men,
 33777	as physique, in the service of our sovereign.
 33778	
 33779	A VOICE: Turncoat! Up the Boers! Who booed Joe Chamberlain?
 33780	
 33781	BLOOM: _(His hand on the shoulder of the first watch)_ My old dad too
 33782	was a J. P. I'm as staunch a Britisher as you are, sir. I fought with
 33783	the colours for king and country in the absentminded war under general
 33784	Gough in the park and was disabled at Spion Kop and Bloemfontein, was
 33785	mentioned in dispatches. I did all a white man could. _(With quiet
 33786	feeling)_ Jim Bludso. Hold her nozzle again the bank.
 33787	
 33788	FIRST WATCH: Profession or trade.
 33789	
 33790	BLOOM: Well, I follow a literary occupation, author-journalist. In fact
 33791	we are just bringing out a collection of prize stories of which I am the
 33792	inventor, something that is an entirely new departure. I am connected
 33793	with the British and Irish press. If you ring up...
 33794	
 33795	_(Myles Crawford strides out jerkily, a quill between his teeth. His
 33796	scarlet beak blazes within the aureole of his straw hat. He dangles
 33797	a hank of Spanish onions in one hand and holds with the other hand a
 33798	telephone receiver nozzle to his ear.)_
 33799	
 33800	MYLES CRAWFORD: _(His cock's wattles wagging)_ Hello, seventyseven
 33801	eightfour. Hello. _Freeman's Urinal_ and _Weekly Arsewipe_ here.
 33802	Paralyse Europe. You which? Bluebags? Who writes? Is it Bloom?
 33803	
 33804	_(Mr Philip Beaufoy, palefaced, stands in the witnessbox, in accurate
 33805	morning dress, outbreast pocket with peak of handkerchief showing,
 33806	creased lavender trousers and patent boots. He carries a large portfolio
 33807	labelled_ Matcham's Masterstrokes.)
 33808	
 33809	BEAUFOY: _(Drawls)_ No, you aren't. Not by a long shot if I know it.
 33810	I don't see it that's all. No born gentleman, no-one with the most
 33811	rudimentary promptings of a gentleman would stoop to such particularly
 33812	loathsome conduct. One of those, my lord. A plagiarist. A soapy sneak
 33813	masquerading as a litterateur. It's perfectly obvious that with the most
 33814	inherent baseness he has cribbed some of my bestselling copy, really
 33815	gorgeous stuff, a perfect gem, the love passages in which are beneath
 33816	suspicion. The Beaufoy books of love and great possessions, with which
 33817	your lordship is doubtless familiar, are a household word throughout the
 33818	kingdom.
 33819	
 33820	BLOOM: _(Murmurs with hangdog meekness glum)_ That bit about the
 33821	laughing witch hand in hand I take exception to, if I may...
 33822	
 33823	BEAUFOY: _(His lip upcurled, smiles superciliously on the court)_ You
 33824	funny ass, you! You're too beastly awfully weird for words! I don't
 33825	think you need over excessively disincommodate yourself in that regard.
 33826	My literary agent Mr J. B. Pinker is in attendance. I presume, my
 33827	lord, we shall receive the usual witnesses' fees, shan't we? We are
 33828	considerably out of pocket over this bally pressman johnny, this jackdaw
 33829	of Rheims, who has not even been to a university.
 33830	
 33831	BLOOM: _(Indistinctly)_ University of life. Bad art.
 33832	
 33833	BEAUFOY: _(Shouts)_ It's a damnably foul lie, showing the moral
 33834	rottenness of the man! _(He extends his portfolio)_ We have here damning
 33835	evidence, the _corpus delicti_, my lord, a specimen of my maturer work
 33836	disfigured by the hallmark of the beast.
 33837	
 33838	A VOICE FROM THE GALLERY:
 33839	
 33840	Moses, Moses, king of the jews, Wiped his arse in the Daily News.
 33841	
 33842	BLOOM: _(Bravely)_ Overdrawn.
 33843	
 33844	BEAUFOY: You low cad! You ought to be ducked in the horsepond, you
 33845	rotter! _(To the court)_ Why, look at the man's private life! Leading
 33846	a quadruple existence! Street angel and house devil. Not fit to be
 33847	mentioned in mixed society! The archconspirator of the age!
 33848	
 33849	BLOOM: _(To the court)_ And he, a bachelor, how...
 33850	
 33851	FIRST WATCH: The King versus Bloom. Call the woman Driscoll.
 33852	
 33853	THE CRIER: Mary Driscoll, scullerymaid!
 33854	
 33855	_(Mary Driscoll, a slipshod servant girl, approaches. She has a bucket
 33856	on the crook of her arm and a scouringbrush in her hand.)_
 33857	
 33858	SECOND WATCH: Another! Are you of the unfortunate class?
 33859	
 33860	MARY DRISCOLL: _(Indignantly)_ I'm not a bad one. I bear a respectable
 33861	character and was four months in my last place. I was in a situation,
 33862	six pounds a year and my chances with Fridays out and I had to leave
 33863	owing to his carryings on.
 33864	
 33865	FIRST WATCH: What do you tax him with?
 33866	
 33867	MARY DRISCOLL: He made a certain suggestion but I thought more of myself
 33868	as poor as I am.
 33869	
 33870	BLOOM: _(In housejacket of ripplecloth, flannel trousers, heelless
 33871	slippers, unshaven, his hair rumpled: softly)_ I treated you white.
 33872	I gave you mementos, smart emerald garters far above your station.
 33873	Incautiously I took your part when you were accused of pilfering.
 33874	There's a medium in all things. Play cricket.
 33875	
 33876	MARY DRISCOLL: _(Excitedly)_ As God is looking down on me this night if
 33877	ever I laid a hand to them oysters!
 33878	
 33879	FIRST WATCH: The offence complained of? Did something happen?
 33880	
 33881	MARY DRISCOLL: He surprised me in the rere of the premises, Your honour,
 33882	when the missus was out shopping one morning with a request for a safety
 33883	pin. He held me and I was discoloured in four places as a result. And he
 33884	interfered twict with my clothing.
 33885	
 33886	BLOOM: She counterassaulted.
 33887	
 33888	MARY DRISCOLL: _(Scornfully)_ I had more respect for the scouringbrush,
 33889	so I had. I remonstrated with him, Your lord, and he remarked: keep it
 33890	quiet.
 33891	
 33892	_(General laughter.)_
 33893	
 33894	GEORGE FOTTRELL: _(Clerk of the crown and peace, resonantly)_ Order in
 33895	court! The accused will now make a bogus statement.
 33896	
 33897	_(Bloom, pleading not guilty and holding a fullblown waterlily, begins
 33898	a long unintelligible speech. They would hear what counsel had to say in
 33899	his stirring address to the grand jury. He was down and out but, though
 33900	branded as a black sheep, if he might say so, he meant to reform, to
 33901	retrieve the memory of the past in a purely sisterly way and return to
 33902	nature as a purely domestic animal. A sevenmonths' child, he had been
 33903	carefully brought up and nurtured by an aged bedridden parent. There
 33904	might have been lapses of an erring father but he wanted to turn over
 33905	a new leaf and now, when at long last in sight of the whipping post,
 33906	to lead a homely life in the evening of his days, permeated by the
 33907	affectionate surroundings of the heaving bosom of the family. An
 33908	acclimatised Britisher, he had seen that summer eve from the footplate
 33909	of an engine cab of the Loop line railway company while the rain
 33910	refrained from falling glimpses, as it were, through the windows of
 33911	loveful households in Dublin city and urban district of scenes truly
 33912	rural of happiness of the better land with Dockrell's wallpaper at one
 33913	and ninepence a dozen, innocent Britishborn bairns lisping prayers to
 33914	the Sacred Infant, youthful scholars grappling with their pensums or
 33915	model young ladies playing on the pianoforte or anon all with fervour
 33916	reciting the family rosary round the crackling Yulelog while in the
 33917	boreens and green lanes the colleens with their swains strolled what
 33918	times the strains of the organtoned melodeon Britannia metalbound with
 33919	four acting stops and twelvefold bellows, a sacrifice, greatest bargain
 33920	ever..._
 33921	
 33922	_(Renewed laughter. He mumbles incoherently. Reporters complain that
 33923	they cannot hear.)_
 33924	
 33925	LONGHAND AND SHORTHAND: _(Without looking up from their notebooks)_
 33926	Loosen his boots.
 33927	
 33928	PROFESSOR MACHUGH: _(From the presstable, coughs and calls)_ Cough it
 33929	up, man. Get it out in bits.
 33930	
 33931	_(The crossexamination proceeds re Bloom and the bucket. A large bucket.
 33932	Bloom himself. Bowel trouble. In Beaver street Gripe, yes. Quite bad.
 33933	A plasterer's bucket. By walking stifflegged. Suffered untold misery.
 33934	Deadly agony. About noon. Love or burgundy. Yes, some spinach. Crucial
 33935	moment. He did not look in the bucket Nobody. Rather a mess. Not
 33936	completely._ A Titbits _back number_.)
 33937	
 33938	_(Uproar and catcalls. Bloom in a torn frockcoat stained with whitewash,
 33939	dinged silk hat sideways on his head, a strip of stickingplaster across
 33940	his nose, talks inaudibly.)_
 33941	
 33942	J. J. O'MOLLOY: _(In barrister's grey wig and stuffgown, speaking with
 33943	a voice of pained protest)_ This is no place for indecent levity at
 33944	the expense of an erring mortal disguised in liquor. We are not in a
 33945	beargarden nor at an Oxford rag nor is this a travesty of justice. My
 33946	client is an infant, a poor foreign immigrant who started scratch as
 33947	a stowaway and is now trying to turn an honest penny. The trumped up
 33948	misdemeanour was due to a momentary aberration of heredity, brought on
 33949	by hallucination, such familiarities as the alleged guilty occurrence
 33950	being quite permitted in my client's native place, the land of the
 33951	Pharaoh. _Prima facie_, I put it to you that there was no attempt at
 33952	carnally knowing. Intimacy did not occur and the offence complained of
 33953	by Driscoll, that her virtue was solicited, was not repeated. I would
 33954	deal in especial with atavism. There have been cases of shipwreck and
 33955	somnambulism in my client's family. If the accused could speak he could
 33956	a tale unfold--one of the strangest that have ever been narrated between
 33957	the covers of a book. He himself, my lord, is a physical wreck from
 33958	cobbler's weak chest. His submission is that he is of Mongolian
 33959	extraction and irresponsible for his actions. Not all there, in fact.
 33960	
 33961	BLOOM: _(Barefoot, pigeonbreasted, in lascar's vest and trousers,
 33962	apologetic toes turned in, opens his tiny mole's eyes and looks about
 33963	him dazedly, passing a slow hand across his forehead. Then he hitches
 33964	his belt sailor fashion and with a shrug of oriental obeisance salutes
 33965	the court, pointing one thumb heavenward.)_ Him makee velly muchee fine
 33966	night. _(He begins to lilt simply)_
 33967	
 33968	     Li li poo lil chile
 33969	     Blingee pigfoot evly night
 33970	     Payee two shilly...
 33971	
 33972	_(He is howled down.)_
 33973	
 33974	J. J. O'MOLLOY: _(Hotly to the populace)_ This is a lonehand fight. By
 33975	Hades, I will not have any client of mine gagged and badgered in this
 33976	fashion by a pack of curs and laughing hyenas. The Mosaic code has
 33977	superseded the law of the jungle. I say it and I say it emphatically,
 33978	without wishing for one moment to defeat the ends of justice, accused
 33979	was not accessory before the act and prosecutrix has not been tampered
 33980	with. The young person was treated by defendant as if she were his very
 33981	own daughter. _(Bloom takes J. J. O'Molloy's hand and raises it to his
 33982	lips.)_ I shall call rebutting evidence to prove up to the hilt that the
 33983	hidden hand is again at its old game. When in doubt persecute Bloom. My
 33984	client, an innately bashful man, would be the last man in the world to
 33985	do anything ungentlemanly which injured modesty could object to or
 33986	cast a stone at a girl who took the wrong turning when some dastard,
 33987	responsible for her condition, had worked his own sweet will on her. He
 33988	wants to go straight. I regard him as the whitest man I know. He is down
 33989	on his luck at present owing to the mortgaging of his extensive property
 33990	at Agendath Netaim in faraway Asia Minor, slides of which will now be
 33991	shown. _(To Bloom)_ I suggest that you will do the handsome thing.
 33992	
 33993	BLOOM: A penny in the pound.
 33994	
 33995	_(The image of the lake of Kinnereth with blurred cattle cropping in
 33996	silver haze is projected on the wall. Moses Dlugacz, ferreteyed albino,
 33997	in blue dungarees, stands up in the gallery, holding in each hand an
 33998	orange citron and a pork kidney.)_
 33999	
 34000	DLUGACZ: _(Hoarsely)_ Bleibtreustrasse, Berlin, W.13.
 34001	
 34002	_(J. J. O'Molloy steps on to a low plinth and holds the lapel of his
 34003	coat with solemnity. His face lengthens, grows pale and bearded, with
 34004	sunken eyes, the blotches of phthisis and hectic cheekbones of John F.
 34005	Taylor. He applies his handkerchief to his mouth and scrutinises the
 34006	galloping tide of rosepink blood.)_
 34007	
 34008	J.J.O'MOLLOY: _(Almost voicelessly)_ Excuse me. I am suffering from a
 34009	severe chill, have recently come from a sickbed. A few wellchosen words.
 34010	_(He assumes the avine head, foxy moustache and proboscidal eloquence of
 34011	Seymour Bushe.)_ When the angel's book comes to be opened if aught
 34012	that the pensive bosom has inaugurated of soultransfigured and of
 34013	soultransfiguring deserves to live I say accord the prisoner at the bar
 34014	the sacred benefit of the doubt. _(A paper with something written on it
 34015	is handed into court._)
 34016	
 34017	BLOOM: _(In court dress)_ Can give best references. Messrs Callan,
 34018	Coleman. Mr Wisdom Hely J. P. My old chief Joe Cuffe. Mr V. B. Dillon,
 34019	ex lord mayor of Dublin. I have moved in the charmed circle of the
 34020	highest... Queens of Dublin society. _(Carelessly)_ I was just chatting
 34021	this afternoon at the viceregal lodge to my old pals, sir Robert and
 34022	lady Ball, astronomer royal at the levee. Sir Bob, I said...
 34023	
 34024	MRS YELVERTON BARRY: _(In lowcorsaged opal balldress and elbowlength
 34025	ivory gloves, wearing a sabletrimmed brickquilted dolman, a comb of
 34026	brilliants and panache of osprey in her hair)_ Arrest him, constable. He
 34027	wrote me an anonymous letter in prentice backhand when my husband was
 34028	in the North Riding of Tipperary on the Munster circuit, signed James
 34029	Lovebirch. He said that he had seen from the gods my peerless globes as
 34030	I sat in a box of the _Theatre Royal_ at a command performance of _La
 34031	Cigale_. I deeply inflamed him, he said. He made improper overtures
 34032	to me to misconduct myself at half past four p.m. on the following
 34033	Thursday, Dunsink time. He offered to send me through the post a work
 34034	of fiction by Monsieur Paul de Kock, entitled _The Girl with the Three
 34035	Pairs of Stays_.
 34036	
 34037	MRS BELLINGHAM: _(In cap and seal coney mantle, wrapped up to the
 34038	nose, steps out of her brougham and scans through tortoiseshell
 34039	quizzing-glasses which she takes from inside her huge opossum muff)_
 34040	Also to me. Yes, I believe it is the same objectionable person. Because
 34041	he closed my carriage door outside sir Thornley Stoker's one sleety day
 34042	during the cold snap of February ninetythree when even the grid of the
 34043	wastepipe and the ballstop in my bath cistern were frozen. Subsequently
 34044	he enclosed a bloom of edelweiss culled on the heights, as he said,
 34045	in my honour. I had it examined by a botanical expert and elicited the
 34046	information that it was ablossom of the homegrown potato plant purloined
 34047	from a forcingcase of the model farm.
 34048	
 34049	MRS YELVERTON BARRY: Shame on him!
 34050	
 34051	_(A crowd of sluts and ragamuffins surges forward)_
 34052	
 34053	THE SLUTS AND RAGAMUFFINS: _(Screaming)_ Stop thief! Hurrah there,
 34054	Bluebeard! Three cheers for Ikey Mo!
 34055	
 34056	SECOND WATCH: _(Produces handcuffs)_ Here are the darbies.
 34057	
 34058	MRS BELLINGHAM: He addressed me in several handwritings with fulsome
 34059	compliments as a Venus in furs and alleged profound pity for my
 34060	frostbound coachman Palmer while in the same breath he expressed himself
 34061	as envious of his earflaps and fleecy sheepskins and of his fortunate
 34062	proximity to my person, when standing behind my chair wearing my livery
 34063	and the armorial bearings of the Bellingham escutcheon garnished sable,
 34064	a buck's head couped or. He lauded almost extravagantly my nether
 34065	extremities, my swelling calves in silk hose drawn up to the limit, and
 34066	eulogised glowingly my other hidden treasures in priceless lace which,
 34067	he said, he could conjure up. He urged me (stating that he felt it
 34068	his mission in life to urge me) to defile the marriage bed, to commit
 34069	adultery at the earliest possible opportunity.
 34070	
 34071	THE HONOURABLE MRS MERVYN TALBOYS: _(In amazon costume, hard hat,
 34072	jackboots cockspurred, vermilion waistcoat, fawn musketeer gauntlets
 34073	with braided drums, long train held up and hunting crop with which she
 34074	strikes her welt constantly)_ Also me. Because he saw me on the polo
 34075	ground of the Phoenix park at the match All Ireland versus the Rest of
 34076	Ireland. My eyes, I know, shone divinely as I watched Captain Slogger
 34077	Dennehy of the Inniskillings win the final chukkar on his darling cob
 34078	_Centaur._ This plebeian Don Juan observed me from behind a hackney car
 34079	and sent me in double envelopes an obscene photograph, such as are sold
 34080	after dark on Paris boulevards, insulting to any lady. I have it still.
 34081	It represents a partially nude seÃ±orita, frail and lovely (his wife, as
 34082	he solemnly assured me, taken by him from nature), practising illicit
 34083	intercourse with a muscular torero, evidently a blackguard. He urged me
 34084	to do likewise, to misbehave, to sin with officers of the garrison. He
 34085	implored me to soil his letter in an unspeakable manner, to chastise
 34086	him as he richly deserves, to bestride and ride him, to give him a most
 34087	vicious horsewhipping.
 34088	
 34089	MRS BELLINGHAM: Me too.
 34090	
 34091	MRS YELVERTON BARRY: Me too.
 34092	
 34093	_(Several highly respectable Dublin ladies hold up improper letters
 34094	received from Bloom.)_
 34095	
 34096	THE HONOURABLE MRS MERVYN TALBOYS: _(Stamps her jingling spurs in a
 34097	sudden paroxysm of fury)_ I will, by the God above me. I'll scourge the
 34098	pigeonlivered cur as long as I can stand over him. I'll flay him alive.
 34099	
 34100	BLOOM: _(His eyes closing, quails expectantly)_ Here? _(He squirms)_
 34101	Again! _(He pants cringing)_ I love the danger.
 34102	
 34103	THE HONOURABLE MRS MERVYN TALBOYS: Very much so! I'll make it hot for
 34104	you. I'll make you dance Jack Latten for that.
 34105	
 34106	MRS BELLINGHAM: Tan his breech well, the upstart! Write the stars and
 34107	stripes on it!
 34108	
 34109	MRS YELVERTON BARRY: Disgraceful! There's no excuse for him! A married
 34110	man!
 34111	
 34112	BLOOM: All these people. I meant only the spanking idea. A warm tingling
 34113	glow without effusion. Refined birching to stimulate the circulation.
 34114	
 34115	THE HONOURABLE MRS MERVYN TALBOYS: _(Laughs derisively)_ O, did you, my
 34116	fine fellow? Well, by the living God, you'll get the surprise of your
 34117	life now, believe me, the most unmerciful hiding a man ever bargained
 34118	for. You have lashed the dormant tigress in my nature into fury.
 34119	
 34120	MRS BELLINGHAM: _(Shakes her muff and quizzing-glasses vindictively)_
 34121	Make him smart, Hanna dear. Give him ginger. Thrash the mongrel within
 34122	an inch of his life. The cat-o'-nine-tails. Geld him. Vivisect him.
 34123	
 34124	BLOOM: _(Shuddering, shrinking, joins his hands: with hangdog mien)_ O
 34125	cold! O shivery! It was your ambrosial beauty. Forget, forgive. Kismet.
 34126	Let me off this once. _(He offers the other cheek)_
 34127	
 34128	MRS YELVERTON BARRY: _(Severely)_ Don't do so on any account, Mrs
 34129	Talboys! He should be soundly trounced!
 34130	
 34131	THE HONOURABLE MRS MERVYN TALBOYS: _(Unbuttoning her gauntlet
 34132	violently)_ I'll do no such thing. Pigdog and always was ever since
 34133	he was pupped! To dare address me! I'll flog him black and blue in
 34134	the public streets. I'll dig my spurs in him up to the rowel. He is a
 34135	wellknown cuckold. _(She swishes her huntingcrop savagely in the air)_
 34136	Take down his trousers without loss of time. Come here, sir! Quick!
 34137	Ready?
 34138	
 34139	BLOOM: _(Trembling, beginning to obey)_ The weather has been so warm.
 34140	
 34141	_(Davy Stephens, ringletted, passes with a bevy of barefoot newsboys.)_
 34142	
 34143	DAVY STEPHENS: _Messenger of the Sacred Heart and Evening Telegraph_
 34144	with Saint Patrick's Day supplement. Containing the new addresses of all
 34145	the cuckolds in Dublin.
 34146	
 34147	_(The very reverend Canon O'Hanlon in cloth of gold cope elevates and
 34148	exposes a marble timepiece. Before him Father Conroy and the reverend
 34149	John Hughes S.J. bend low.)_
 34150	
 34151	THE TIMEPIECE: _(Unportalling)_
 34152	
 34153	     Cuckoo.
 34154	     Cuckoo.
 34155	     Cuckoo.
 34156	
 34157	_(The brass quoits of a bed are heard to jingle.)_
 34158	
 34159	THE QUOITS: Jigjag. Jigajiga. Jigjag.
 34160	
 34161	_(A panel of fog rolls back rapidly, revealing rapidly in the jurybox
 34162	the faces of Martin Cunningham, foreman, silkhatted, Jack Power, Simon
 34163	Dedalus, Tom Kernan, Ned Lambert, John Henry Menton Myles Crawford,
 34164	Lenehan, Paddy Leonard, Nosey Flynn, M'Coy and the featureless face of a
 34165	Nameless One.)_
 34166	
 34167	THE NAMELESS ONE: Bareback riding. Weight for age. Gob, he organised
 34168	her.
 34169	
 34170	THE JURORS: _(All their heads turned to his voice)_ Really?
 34171	
 34172	THE NAMELESS ONE: _(Snarls)_ Arse over tip. Hundred shillings to five.
 34173	
 34174	THE JURORS: _(All their heads lowered in assent)_ Most of us thought as
 34175	much.
 34176	
 34177	FIRST WATCH: He is a marked man. Another girl's plait cut. Wanted: Jack
 34178	the Ripper. A thousand pounds reward.
 34179	
 34180	SECOND WATCH: _(Awed, whispers)_ And in black. A mormon. Anarchist.
 34181	
 34182	THE CRIER: _(Loudly)_ Whereas Leopold Bloom of no fixed abode is a
 34183	wellknown dynamitard, forger, bigamist, bawd and cuckold and a public
 34184	nuisance to the citizens of Dublin and whereas at this commission of
 34185	assizes the most honourable...
 34186	
 34187	_(His Honour, sir Frederick Falkiner, recorder of Dublin, in judicial
 34188	garb of grey stone rises from the bench, stonebearded. He bears in his
 34189	arms an umbrella sceptre. From his forehead arise starkly the Mosaic
 34190	ramshorns.)_
 34191	
 34192	THE RECORDER: I will put an end to this white slave traffic and rid
 34193	Dublin of this odious pest. Scandalous! _(He dons the black cap)_ Let
 34194	him be taken, Mr Subsheriff, from the dock where he now stands and
 34195	detained in custody in Mountjoy prison during His Majesty's pleasure
 34196	and there be hanged by the neck until he is dead and therein fail not
 34197	at your peril or may the Lord have mercy on your soul. Remove him. _(A
 34198	black skullcap descends upon his head.)_
 34199	
 34200	_(The subsheriff Long John Fanning appears, smoking a pungent Henry
 34201	Clay.)_
 34202	
 34203	LONG JOHN FANNING: _(Scowls and calls with rich rolling utterance)_
 34204	Who'll hang Judas Iscariot?
 34205	
 34206	_(H. Rumbold, master barber, in a bloodcoloured jerkin and tanner's
 34207	apron, a rope coiled over his shoulder, mounts the block. A life
 34208	preserver and a nailstudded bludgeon are stuck in his belt. He rubs
 34209	grimly his grappling hands, knobbed with knuckledusters.)_
 34210	
 34211	RUMBOLD: _(To the recorder with sinister familiarity)_ Hanging Harry,
 34212	your Majesty, the Mersey terror. Five guineas a jugular. Neck or
 34213	nothing.
 34214	
 34215	_(The bells of George's church toll slowly, loud dark iron.)_
 34216	
 34217	THE BELLS: Heigho! Heigho!
 34218	
 34219	BLOOM: _(Desperately)_ Wait. Stop. Gulls. Good heart. I saw. Innocence.
 34220	Girl in the monkeyhouse. Zoo. Lewd chimpanzee. _(Breathlessly)_ Pelvic
 34221	basin. Her artless blush unmanned me. _(Overcome with emotion)_ I left
 34222	the precincts. (He turns to a figure in the crowd, appealing) Hynes, may
 34223	I speak to you? You know me. That three shillings you can keep. If you
 34224	want a little more...
 34225	
 34226	HYNES: _(Coldly)_ You are a perfect stranger.
 34227	
 34228	SECOND WATCH: _(Points to the corner)_ The bomb is here.
 34229	
 34230	FIRST WATCH: Infernal machine with a time fuse.
 34231	
 34232	BLOOM: No, no. Pig's feet. I was at a funeral.
 34233	
 34234	FIRST WATCH: _(Draws his truncheon)_ Liar!
 34235	
 34236	_(The beagle lifts his snout, showing the grey scorbutic face of Paddy
 34237	Dignam. He has gnawed all. He exhales a putrid carcasefed breath.
 34238	He grows to human size and shape. His dachshund coat becomes a brown
 34239	mortuary habit. His green eye flashes bloodshot. Half of one ear, all
 34240	the nose and both thumbs are ghouleaten.)_
 34241	
 34242	PADDY DIGNAM: _(In a hollow voice)_ It is true. It was my funeral.
 34243	Doctor Finucane pronounced life extinct when I succumbed to the disease
 34244	from natural causes.
 34245	
 34246	_(He lifts his mutilated ashen face moonwards and bays lugubriously.)_
 34247	
 34248	BLOOM: _(In triumph)_ You hear?
 34249	
 34250	PADDY DIGNAM: Bloom, I am Paddy Dignam's spirit. List, list, O list!
 34251	
 34252	BLOOM: The voice is the voice of Esau.
 34253	
 34254	SECOND WATCH: _(Blesses himself)_ How is that possible?
 34255	
 34256	FIRST WATCH: It is not in the penny catechism.
 34257	
 34258	PADDY DIGNAM: By metempsychosis. Spooks.
 34259	
 34260	A VOICE: O rocks.
 34261	
 34262	PADDY DIGNAM: _(Earnestly)_ Once I was in the employ of Mr J. H. Menton,
 34263	solicitor, commissioner for oaths and affidavits, of 27 Bachelor's Walk.
 34264	Now I am defunct, the wall of the heart hypertrophied. Hard lines. The
 34265	poor wife was awfully cut up. How is she bearing it? Keep her off that
 34266	bottle of sherry. _(He looks round him)_ A lamp. I must satisfy an
 34267	animal need. That buttermilk didn't agree with me.
 34268	
 34269	_(The portly figure of John O'Connell, caretaker, stands forth, holding
 34270	a bunch of keys tied with crape. Beside him stands Father Coffey,
 34271	chaplain, toadbellied, wrynecked, in a surplice and bandanna nightcap,
 34272	holding sleepily a staff twisted poppies.)_
 34273	
 34274	FATHER COFFEY: _(Yawns, then chants with a hoarse croak)_ Namine.
 34275	Jacobs. Vobiscuits. Amen.
 34276	
 34277	JOHN O'CONNELL: _(Foghorns stormily through his megaphone)_ Dignam,
 34278	Patrick T, deceased.
 34279	
 34280	PADDY DIGNAM: _(With pricked up ears, winces)_ Overtones. _(He wriggles
 34281	forward and places an ear to the ground)_ My master's voice!
 34282	
 34283	JOHN O'CONNELL: Burial docket letter number U. P. eightyfive thousand.
 34284	Field seventeen. House of Keys. Plot, one hundred and one.
 34285	
 34286	_(Paddy Dignam listens with visible effort, thinking, his tail
 34287	stiffpointcd, his ears cocked.)_
 34288	
 34289	PADDY DIGNAM: Pray for the repose of his soul.
 34290	
 34291	_(He worms down through a coalhole, his brown habit trailing its tether
 34292	over rattling pebbles. After him toddles an obese grandfather rat on
 34293	fungus turtle paws under a grey carapace. Dignam's voice, muffled, is
 34294	heard baying under ground:_ Dignam's dead and gone below. _Tom Rochford,
 34295	robinredbreasted, in cap and breeches, jumps from his twocolumned
 34296	machine.)_
 34297	
 34298	TOM ROCHFORD: _(A hand to his breastbone, bows)_ Reuben J. A florin I
 34299	find him. _(He fixes the manhole with a resolute stare)_ My turn now on.
 34300	Follow me up to Carlow.
 34301	
 34302	_(He executes a daredevil salmon leap in the air and is engulfed in the
 34303	coalhole. Two discs on the columns wobble, eyes of nought. All recedes.
 34304	Bloom plodges forward again through the sump. Kisses chirp amid
 34305	the rifts of fog a piano sounds. He stands before a lighted house,
 34306	listening. The kisses, winging from their bowers fly about him,
 34307	twittering, warbling, cooing.)_
 34308	
 34309	THE KISSES: _(Warbling)_ Leo! _(Twittering)_ Icky licky micky sticky for
 34310	Leo! _(Cooing)_ Coo coocoo! Yummyyum, Womwom! _(Warbling)_ Big comebig!
 34311	Pirouette! Leopopold! _(Twittering)_ Leeolee! _(Warbling)_ O Leo!
 34312	
 34313	_(They rustle, flutter upon his garments, alight, bright giddy flecks,
 34314	silvery sequins.)_
 34315	
 34316	BLOOM: A man's touch. Sad music. Church music. Perhaps here.
 34317	
 34318	_(Zoe Higgins, a young whore in a sapphire slip, closed with three
 34319	bronze buckles, a slim black velvet fillet round her throat, nods, trips
 34320	down the steps and accosts him.)_
 34321	
 34322	ZOE: Are you looking for someone? He's inside with his friend.
 34323	
 34324	BLOOM: Is this Mrs Mack's?
 34325	
 34326	ZOE: No, eightyone. Mrs Cohen's. You might go farther and fare worse.
 34327	Mother Slipperslapper. _(Familiarly)_ She's on the job herself tonight
 34328	with the vet her tipster that gives her all the winners and pays for
 34329	her son in Oxford. Working overtime but her luck's turned today.
 34330	_(Suspiciously)_ You're not his father, are you?
 34331	
 34332	BLOOM: Not I!
 34333	
 34334	ZOE: You both in black. Has little mousey any tickles tonight?
 34335	
 34336	_(His skin, alert, feels her fingertips approach. A hand glides over his
 34337	left thigh.)_
 34338	
 34339	ZOE: How's the nuts?
 34340	
 34341	BLOOM: Off side. Curiously they are on the right. Heavier, I suppose.
 34342	One in a million my tailor, Mesias, says.
 34343	
 34344	ZOE: _(In sudden alarm)_ You've a hard chancre.
 34345	
 34346	BLOOM: Not likely.
 34347	
 34348	ZOE: I feel it.
 34349	
 34350	_(Her hand slides into his left trouser pocket and brings out a hard
 34351	black shrivelled potato. She regards it and Bloom with dumb moist
 34352	lips.)_
 34353	
 34354	BLOOM: A talisman. Heirloom.
 34355	
 34356	ZOE: For Zoe? For keeps? For being so nice, eh?
 34357	
 34358	_(She puts the potato greedily into a pocket then links his arm,
 34359	cuddling him with supple warmth. He smiles uneasily. Slowly, note by
 34360	note, oriental music is played. He gazes in the tawny crystal of her
 34361	eyes, ringed with kohol. His smile softens.)_
 34362	
 34363	ZOE: You'll know me the next time.
 34364	
 34365	BLOOM: _(Forlornly)_ I never loved a dear gazelle but it was sure to...
 34366	
 34367	_(Gazelles are leaping, feeding on the mountains. Near are lakes. Round
 34368	their shores file shadows black of cedargroves. Aroma rises, a strong
 34369	hairgrowth of resin. It burns, the orient, a sky of sapphire, cleft by
 34370	the bronze flight of eagles. Under it lies the womancity nude, white,
 34371	still, cool, in luxury. A fountain murmurs among damask roses. Mammoth
 34372	roses murmur of scarlet winegrapes. A wine of shame, lust, blood exudes,
 34373	strangely murmuring.)_
 34374	
 34375	ZOE: _(Murmuring singsong with the music, her odalisk lips lusciously
 34376	smeared with salve of swinefat and rosewater) Schorach ani wenowach,
 34377	benoith Hierushaloim._
 34378	
 34379	BLOOM: _(Fascinated)_ I thought you were of good stock by your accent.
 34380	
 34381	ZOE: And you know what thought did?
 34382	
 34383	_(She bites his ear gently with little goldstopped teeth, sending on
 34384	him a cloying breath of stale garlic. The roses draw apart, disclose a
 34385	sepulchre of the gold of kings and their mouldering bones.)_
 34386	
 34387	BLOOM: _(Draws back, mechanically caressing her right bub with a flat
 34388	awkward hand)_ Are you a Dublin girl?
 34389	
 34390	ZOE: _(Catches a stray hair deftly and twists it to her coil)_ No bloody
 34391	fear. I'm English. Have you a swaggerroot?
 34392	
 34393	BLOOM: _(As before)_ Rarely smoke, dear. Cigar now and then. Childish
 34394	device. _(Lewdly)_ The mouth can be better engaged than with a cylinder
 34395	of rank weed.
 34396	
 34397	ZOE: Go on. Make a stump speech out of it.
 34398	
 34399	BLOOM: _(In workman's corduroy overalls, black gansy with red floating
 34400	tie and apache cap)_ Mankind is incorrigible. Sir Walter Ralegh brought
 34401	from the new world that potato and that weed, the one a killer of
 34402	pestilence by absorption, the other a poisoner of the ear, eye, heart,
 34403	memory, will understanding, all. That is to say he brought the poison
 34404	a hundred years before another person whose name I forget brought the
 34405	food. Suicide. Lies. All our habits. Why, look at our public life!
 34406	
 34407	_(Midnight chimes from distant steeples.)_
 34408	
 34409	THE CHIMES: Turn again, Leopold! Lord mayor of Dublin!
 34410	
 34411	BLOOM: _(In alderman's gown and chain)_ Electors of Arran Quay, Inns
 34412	Quay, Rotunda, Mountjoy and North Dock, better run a tramline, I say,
 34413	from the cattlemarket to the river. That's the music of the future.
 34414	That's my programme. _Cui bono_? But our bucaneering Vanderdeckens in
 34415	their phantom ship of finance...
 34416	
 34417	AN ELECTOR: Three times three for our future chief magistrate!
 34418	
 34419	_(The aurora borealis of the torchlight procession leaps.)_
 34420	
 34421	THE TORCHBEARERS: Hooray!
 34422	
 34423	_(Several wellknown burgesses, city magnates and freemen of the city
 34424	shake hands with Bloom and congratulate him. Timothy Harrington, late
 34425	thrice Lord Mayor of Dublin, imposing in mayoral scarlet, gold chain and
 34426	white silk tie, confers with councillor Lorcan Sherlock, locum tenens.
 34427	They nod vigorously in agreement.)_
 34428	
 34429	LATE LORD MAYOR HARRINGTON: _(In scarlet robe with mace, gold mayoral
 34430	chain and large white silk scarf)_ That alderman sir Leo Bloom's speech
 34431	be printed at the expense of the ratepayers. That the house in which
 34432	he was born be ornamented with a commemorative tablet and that the
 34433	thoroughfare hitherto known as Cow Parlour off Cork street be henceforth
 34434	designated Boulevard Bloom.
 34435	
 34436	COUNCILLOR LORCAN SHERLOCK: Carried unanimously.
 34437	
 34438	BLOOM: _(Impassionedly)_ These flying Dutchmen or lying Dutchmen as
 34439	they recline in their upholstered poop, casting dice, what reck they?
 34440	Machines is their cry, their chimera, their panacea. Laboursaving
 34441	apparatuses, supplanters, bugbears, manufactured monsters for mutual
 34442	murder, hideous hobgoblins produced by a horde of capitalistic lusts
 34443	upon our prostituted labour. The poor man starves while they are
 34444	grassing their royal mountain stags or shooting peasants and phartridges
 34445	in their purblind pomp of pelf and power. But their reign is rover for
 34446	rever and ever and ev...
 34447	
 34448	_(Prolonged applause. Venetian masts, maypoles and festal arches spring
 34449	up. A streamer bearing the legends_ Cead Mile Failte _and_ Mah Ttob
 34450	Melek Israel _Spans the street. All the windows are thronged with
 34451	sightseers, chiefly ladies. Along the route the regiments of the
 34452	royal Dublin Fusiliers, the King's own Scottish Borderers, the Cameron
 34453	Highlanders and the Welsh Fusiliers standing to attention, keep back
 34454	the crowd. Boys from High school are perched on the lampposts,
 34455	telegraph poles, windowsills, cornices, gutters, chimneypots, railings,
 34456	rainspouts, whistling and cheering the pillar of the cloud appears. A
 34457	fife and drum band is heard in the distance playing the Kol Nidre. The
 34458	beaters approach with imperial eagles hoisted, trailing banners and
 34459	waving oriental palms. The chryselephantine papal standard rises high,
 34460	surrounded by pennons of the civic flag. The van of the procession
 34461	appears headed by John Howard Parnell, city marshal, in a chessboard
 34462	tabard, the Athlone Poursuivant and Ulster King of Arms. They are
 34463	followed by the Right Honourable Joseph Hutchinson, lord mayor of
 34464	Dublin, his lordship the lord mayor of Cork, their worships the
 34465	mayors of Limerick, Galway, Sligo and Waterford, twentyeight Irish
 34466	representative peers, sirdars, grandees and maharajahs bearing the cloth
 34467	of estate, the Dublin Metropolitan Fire Brigade, the chapter of the
 34468	saints of finance in their plutocratic order of precedence, the bishop
 34469	of Down and Connor, His Eminence Michael cardinal Logue, archbishop of
 34470	Armagh, primate of all Ireland, His Grace, the most reverend Dr William
 34471	Alexander, archbishop of Armagh, primate of all Ireland, the chief
 34472	rabbi, the presbyterian moderator, the heads of the baptist, anabaptist,
 34473	methodist and Moravian chapels and the honorary secretary of the society
 34474	of friends. After them march the guilds and trades and trainbands
 34475	with flying colours: coopers, bird fanciers, millwrights, newspaper
 34476	canvassers, law scriveners, masseurs, vintners, trussmakers,
 34477	chimneysweeps, lard refiners, tabinet and poplin weavers, farriers,
 34478	Italian warehousemen, church decorators, bootjack manufacturers,
 34479	undertakers, silk mercers, lapidaries, salesmasters, corkcutters,
 34480	assessors of fire losses, dyers and cleaners, export bottlers,
 34481	fellmongers, ticketwriters, heraldic seal engravers, horse repository
 34482	hands, bullion brokers, cricket and archery outfitters, riddlemakers,
 34483	egg and potato factors, hosiers and glovers, plumbing contractors. After
 34484	them march gentlemen of the bedchamber, Black Rod, Deputy Garter,
 34485	Gold Stick, the master of horse, the lord great chamberlain, the earl
 34486	marshal, the high constable carrying the sword of state, saint Stephen's
 34487	iron crown, the chalice and bible. Four buglers on foot blow a sennet.
 34488	Beefeaters reply, winding clarions of welcome. Under an arch of triumph
 34489	Bloom appears, bareheaded, in a crimson velvet mantle trimmed with
 34490	ermine, bearing Saint Edward's staff the orb and sceptre with the dove,
 34491	the curtana. He is seated on a milkwhite horse with long flowing crimson
 34492	tail, richly caparisoned, with golden headstall. Wild excitement. The
 34493	ladies from their balconies throw down rosepetals. The air is perfumed
 34494	with essences. The men cheer. Bloom's boys run amid the bystanders with
 34495	branches of hawthorn and wrenbushes.)_
 34496	
 34497	BLOOM'S BOYS:
 34498	
 34499	     The wren, the wren,
 34500	     The king of all birds,
 34501	     Saint Stephen's his day
 34502	     Was caught in the furze.
 34503	
 34504	
 34505	A BLACKSMITH: _(Murmurs)_ For the honour of God! And is that Bloom? He
 34506	scarcely looks thirtyone.
 34507	
 34508	A PAVIOR AND FLAGGER: That's the famous Bloom now, the world's greatest
 34509	reformer. Hats off!
 34510	
 34511	_(All uncover their heads. Women whisper eagerly.)_
 34512	
 34513	A MILLIONAIRESS: _(Richly)_ Isn't he simply wonderful?
 34514	
 34515	A NOBLEWOMAN: _(Nobly)_ All that man has seen!
 34516	
 34517	A FEMINIST: _(Masculinely)_ And done!
 34518	
 34519	A BELLHANGER: A classic face! He has the forehead of a thinker.
 34520	
 34521	_(Bloom's weather. A sunburst appears in the northwest.)_
 34522	
 34523	THE BISHOP OF DOWN AND CONNOR: I here present your undoubted
 34524	emperor-president and king-chairman, the most serene and potent and very
 34525	puissant ruler of this realm. God save Leopold the First!
 34526	
 34527	ALL: God save Leopold the First!
 34528	
 34529	BLOOM: _(In dalmatic and purple mantle, to the bishop of Down and
 34530	Connor, with dignity)_ Thanks, somewhat eminent sir.
 34531	
 34532	WILLIAM, ARCHBISHOP OF ARMAGH: _(In purple stock and shovel hat)_
 34533	Will you to your power cause law and mercy to be executed in all your
 34534	judgments in Ireland and territories thereunto belonging?
 34535	
 34536	BLOOM: _(Placing his right hand on his testicles, swears)_ So may the
 34537	Creator deal with me. All this I promise to do.
 34538	
 34539	MICHAEL, ARCHBISHOP OF ARMAGH: _(Pours a cruse of hairoil over Bloom's
 34540	head) Gaudium magnum annuntio vobis. Habemus carneficem._ Leopold,
 34541	Patrick, Andrew, David, George, be thou anointed!
 34542	
 34543	_(Bloom assumes a mantle of cloth of gold and puts on a ruby ring. He
 34544	ascends and stands on the stone of destiny. The representative peers put
 34545	on at the same time their twentyeight crowns. Joybells ring in Christ
 34546	church, Saint Patrick's, George's and gay Malahide. Mirus bazaar
 34547	fireworks go up from all sides with symbolical phallopyrotechnic
 34548	designs. The peers do homage, one by one, approaching and
 34549	genuflecting.)_
 34550	
 34551	THE PEERS: I do become your liege man of life and limb to earthly
 34552	worship.
 34553	
 34554	_(Bloom holds up his right hand on which sparkles the Koh-i-Noor
 34555	diamond. His palfrey neighs. Immediate silence. Wireless
 34556	intercontinental and interplanetary transmitters are set for reception
 34557	of message.)_
 34558	
 34559	BLOOM: My subjects! We hereby nominate our faithful charger Copula Felix
 34560	hereditary Grand Vizier and announce that we have this day repudiated
 34561	our former spouse and have bestowed our royal hand upon the princess
 34562	Selene, the splendour of night.
 34563	
 34564	_(The former morganatic spouse of Bloom is hastily removed in the Black
 34565	Maria. The princess Selene, in moonblue robes, a silver crescent on her
 34566	head, descends from a Sedan chair, borne by two giants. An outburst of
 34567	cheering.)_
 34568	
 34569	JOHN HOWARD PARNELL: _(Raises the royal standard)_ Illustrious Bloom!
 34570	Successor to my famous brother!
 34571	
 34572	BLOOM: _(Embraces John Howard Parnell)_ We thank you from our heart,
 34573	John, for this right royal welcome to green Erin, the promised land of
 34574	our common ancestors.
 34575	
 34576	_(The freedom of the city is presented to him embodied in a charter. The
 34577	keys of Dublin, crossed on a crimson cushion, are given to him. He shows
 34578	all that he is wearing green socks.)_
 34579	
 34580	TOM KERNAN: You deserve it, your honour.
 34581	
 34582	BLOOM: On this day twenty years ago we overcame the hereditary enemy at
 34583	Ladysmith. Our howitzers and camel swivel guns played on his lines with
 34584	telling effect. Half a league onward! They charge! All is lost now! Do
 34585	we yield? No! We drive them headlong! Lo! We charge! Deploying to the
 34586	left our light horse swept across the heights of Plevna and, uttering
 34587	their warcry _Bonafide Sabaoth_, sabred the Saracen gunners to a man.
 34588	
 34589	THE CHAPEL OF FREEMAN TYPESETTERS: Hear! Hear!
 34590	
 34591	JOHN WYSE NOLAN: There's the man that got away James Stephens.
 34592	
 34593	A BLUECOAT SCHOOLBOY: Bravo!
 34594	
 34595	AN OLD RESIDENT: You're a credit to your country, sir, that's what you
 34596	are.
 34597	
 34598	AN APPLEWOMAN: He's a man like Ireland wants.
 34599	
 34600	BLOOM: My beloved subjects, a new era is about to dawn. I, Bloom, tell
 34601	you verily it is even now at hand. Yea, on the word of a Bloom, ye shall
 34602	ere long enter into the golden city which is to be, the new Bloomusalem
 34603	in the Nova Hibernia of the future.
 34604	
 34605	_(Thirtytwo workmen, wearing rosettes, from all the counties of Ireland,
 34606	under the guidance of Derwan the builder, construct the new Bloomusalem.
 34607	It is a colossal edifice with crystal roof, built in the shape of a
 34608	huge pork kidney, containing forty thousand rooms. In the course of its
 34609	extension several buildings and monuments are demolished. Government
 34610	offices are temporarily transferred to railway sheds. Numerous houses
 34611	are razed to the ground. The inhabitants are lodged in barrels and
 34612	boxes, all marked in red with the letters: L. B. several paupers
 34613	fill from a ladder. A part of the walls of Dublin, crowded with loyal
 34614	sightseers, collapses.)_
 34615	
 34616	THE SIGHTSEERS: _(Dying) Morituri te salutant. (They die)_
 34617	
 34618	_(A man in a brown macintosh springs up through a trapdoor. He points an
 34619	elongated finger at Bloom.)_
 34620	
 34621	THE MAN IN THE MACINTOSH: Don't you believe a word he says. That man is
 34622	Leopold M'Intosh, the notorious fireraiser. His real name is Higgins.
 34623	
 34624	BLOOM: Shoot him! Dog of a christian! So much for M'Intosh!
 34625	
 34626	_(A cannonshot. The man in the macintosh disappears. Bloom with his
 34627	sceptre strikes down poppies. The instantaneous deaths of many
 34628	powerful enemies, graziers, members of parliament, members of standing
 34629	committees, are reported. Bloom's bodyguard distribute Maundy money,
 34630	commemoration medals, loaves and fishes, temperance badges, expensive
 34631	Henry Clay cigars, free cowbones for soup, rubber preservatives in
 34632	sealed envelopes tied with gold thread, butter scotch, pineapple rock,_
 34633	billets doux _in the form of cocked hats, readymade suits, porringers
 34634	of toad in the hole, bottles of Jeyes' Fluid, purchase stamps, 40 days'
 34635	indulgences, spurious coins, dairyfed pork sausages, theatre passes,
 34636	season tickets available for all tramlines, coupons of the royal and
 34637	privileged Hungarian lottery, penny dinner counters, cheap reprints of
 34638	the World's Twelve Worst Books: Froggy And Fritz (politic), Care of the
 34639	Baby (infantilic), 50 Meals for 7/6 (culinic), Was Jesus a Sun Myth?
 34640	(historic), Expel that Pain (medic), Infant's Compendium of the
 34641	Universe (cosmic), Let's All Chortle (hilaric), Canvasser's Vade Mecum
 34642	(journalic), Loveletters of Mother Assistant (erotic), Who's Who in
 34643	Space (astric), Songs that Reached Our Heart (melodic), Pennywise's Way
 34644	to Wealth (parsimonic). A general rush and scramble. Women press forward
 34645	to touch the hem of Bloom's robe. The Lady Gwendolen Dubedat bursts
 34646	through the throng, leaps on his horse and kisses him on both cheeks
 34647	amid great acclamation. A magnesium flashlight photograph is taken.
 34648	Babes and sucklings are held up.)_
 34649	
 34650	THE WOMEN: Little father! Little father!
 34651	
 34652	THE BABES AND SUCKLINGS:
 34653	
 34654	     Clap clap hands till Poldy comes home,
 34655	     Cakes in his pocket for Leo alone.
 34656	
 34657	
 34658	_(Bloom, bending down, pokes Baby Boardman gently in the stomach.)_
 34659	
 34660	BABY BOARDMAN: _(Hiccups, curdled milk flowing from his mouth)_
 34661	Hajajaja.
 34662	
 34663	BLOOM: _(Shaking hands with a blind stripling)_ My more than Brother!
 34664	_(Placing his arms round the shoulders of an old couple)_ Dear old
 34665	friends! _(He plays pussy fourcorners with ragged boys and girls)_
 34666	Peep! Bopeep! _(He wheels twins in a perambulator)_ Ticktacktwo
 34667	wouldyousetashoe? _(He performs juggler's tricks, draws red, orange,
 34668	yellow, green, blue, indigo and violet silk handkerchiefs from his
 34669	mouth)_ Roygbiv. 32 feet per second. _(He consoles a widow)_ Absence
 34670	makes the heart grow younger. _(He dances the Highland fling with
 34671	grotesque antics)_ Leg it, ye devils! _(He kisses the bedsores of a
 34672	palsied veteran_) Honourable wounds! _(He trips up a fit policeman)_
 34673	U. p: up. U. p: up. _(He whispers in the ear of a blushing waitress and
 34674	laughs kindly)_ Ah, naughty, naughty! _(He eats a raw turnip offered
 34675	him by Maurice Butterly, farmer)_ Fine! Splendid! _(He refuses to
 34676	accept three shillings offered him by Joseph Hynes, journalist)_ My dear
 34677	fellow, not at all! (He gives his coat to a beggar) Please accept. _(He
 34678	takes part in a stomach race with elderly male and female cripples)_
 34679	Come on, boys! Wriggle it, girls!
 34680	
 34681	THE CITIZEN: _(Choked with emotion, brushes aside a tear in his emerald
 34682	muffler)_ May the good God bless him!
 34683	
 34684	_(The rams' horns sound for silence. The standard of Zion is hoisted.)_
 34685	
 34686	BLOOM: _(Uncloaks impressively, revealing obesity, unrolls a paper and
 34687	reads solemnly)_ Aleph Beth Ghimel Daleth Hagadah Tephilim Kosher Yom
 34688	Kippur Hanukah Roschaschana Beni Brith Bar Mitzvah Mazzoth Askenazim
 34689	Meshuggah Talith.
 34690	
 34691	_(An official translation is read by Jimmy Henry, assistant town
 34692	clerk.)_
 34693	
 34694	JIMMY HENRY: The Court of Conscience is now open. His Most Catholic
 34695	Majesty will now administer open air justice. Free medical and legal
 34696	advice, solution of doubles and other problems. All cordially invited.
 34697	Given at this our loyal city of Dublin in the year I of the Paradisiacal
 34698	Era.
 34699	
 34700	PADDY LEONARD: What am I to do about my rates and taxes?
 34701	
 34702	BLOOM: Pay them, my friend.
 34703	
 34704	PADDY LEONARD: Thank you.
 34705	
 34706	NOSEY FLYNN: Can I raise a mortgage on my fire insurance?
 34707	
 34708	BLOOM: _(Obdurately)_ Sirs, take notice that by the law of torts you are
 34709	bound over in your own recognisances for six months in the sum of five
 34710	pounds.
 34711	
 34712	J. J. O'MOLLOY: A Daniel did I say? Nay! A Peter O'Brien!
 34713	
 34714	NOSEY FLYNN: Where do I draw the five pounds?
 34715	
 34716	PISSER BURKE: For bladder trouble?
 34717	
 34718	BLOOM:
 34719	
 34720	     _Acid. nit. hydrochlor. dil.,_ 20 minims
 34721	     _Tinct. nux vom.,_ 5 minims
 34722	     _Extr. taraxel. iiq.,_ 30 minims.
 34723	     _Aq. dis. ter in die._
 34724	
 34725	CHRIS CALLINAN: What is the parallax of the subsolar ecliptic of
 34726	Aldebaran?
 34727	
 34728	BLOOM: Pleased to hear from you, Chris. K. II.
 34729	
 34730	JOE HYNES: Why aren't you in uniform?
 34731	
 34732	BLOOM: When my progenitor of sainted memory wore the uniform of the
 34733	Austrian despot in a dank prison where was yours?
 34734	
 34735	BEN DOLLARD: Pansies?
 34736	
 34737	BLOOM: Embellish (beautify) suburban gardens.
 34738	
 34739	BEN DOLLARD: When twins arrive?
 34740	
 34741	BLOOM: Father (pater, dad) starts thinking.
 34742	
 34743	LARRY O'ROURKE: An eightday licence for my new premises. You remember
 34744	me, sir Leo, when you were in number seven. I'm sending around a dozen
 34745	of stout for the missus.
 34746	
 34747	BLOOM: _(Coldly)_ You have the advantage of me. Lady Bloom accepts no
 34748	presents.
 34749	
 34750	CROFTON: This is indeed a festivity.
 34751	
 34752	BLOOM: _(Solemnly)_ You call it a festivity. I call it a sacrament.
 34753	
 34754	ALEXANDER KEYES: When will we have our own house of keys?
 34755	
 34756	BLOOM: I stand for the reform of municipal morals and the plain ten
 34757	commandments. New worlds for old. Union of all, jew, moslem and gentile.
 34758	Three acres and a cow for all children of nature. Saloon motor hearses.
 34759	Compulsory manual labour for all. All parks open to the public day and
 34760	night. Electric dishscrubbers. Tuberculosis, lunacy, war and mendicancy
 34761	must now cease. General amnesty, weekly carnival with masked licence,
 34762	bonuses for all, esperanto the universal language with universal
 34763	brotherhood. No more patriotism of barspongers and dropsical impostors.
 34764	Free money, free rent, free love and a free lay church in a free lay
 34765	state.
 34766	
 34767	O'MADDEN BURKE: Free fox in a free henroost.
 34768	
 34769	DAVY BYRNE: _(Yawning)_ Iiiiiiiiiaaaaaaach!
 34770	
 34771	BLOOM: Mixed races and mixed marriage.
 34772	
 34773	LENEHAN: What about mixed bathing?
 34774	
 34775	_(bloom explains to those near him his schemes for social regeneration.
 34776	All agree with him. The keeper of the Kildare Street Museum appears,
 34777	dragging a lorry on which are the shaking statues of several naked
 34778	goddesses, Venus Callipyge, Venus Pandemos, Venus Metempsychosis, and
 34779	plaster figures, also naked, representing the new nine muses, Commerce,
 34780	Operatic Music, Amor, Publicity, Manufacture, Liberty of Speech, Plural
 34781	Voting, Gastronomy, Private Hygiene, Seaside Concert Entertainments,
 34782	Painless Obstetrics and Astronomy for the People.)_
 34783	
 34784	FATHER FARLEY: He is an episcopalian, an agnostic, an anythingarian
 34785	seeking to overthrow our holy faith.
 34786	
 34787	MRS RIORDAN: _(Tears up her will)_ I'm disappointed in you! You bad man!
 34788	
 34789	MOTHER GROGAN: _(Removes her boot to throw it at Bloom)_ You beast! You
 34790	abominable person!
 34791	
 34792	NOSEY FLYNN: Give us a tune, Bloom. One of the old sweet songs.
 34793	
 34794	BLOOM: _(With rollicking humour)_
 34795	
 34796	     I vowed that I never would leave her,
 34797	     She turned out a cruel deceiver.
 34798	     With my tooraloom tooraloom tooraloom tooraloom.
 34799	
 34800	HOPPY HOLOHAN: Good old Bloom! There's nobody like him after all.
 34801	
 34802	PADDY LEONARD: Stage Irishman!
 34803	
 34804	BLOOM: What railway opera is like a tramline in Gibraltar? The Rows of
 34805	Casteele._(Laughter.)_
 34806	
 34807	LENEHAN: Plagiarist! Down with Bloom!
 34808	
 34809	THE VEILED SIBYL: _(Enthusiastically)_ I'm a Bloomite and I glory in it.
 34810	I believe in him in spite of all. I'd give my life for him, the funniest
 34811	man on earth.
 34812	
 34813	BLOOM: _(Winks at the bystanders)_ I bet she's a bonny lassie.
 34814	
 34815	THEODORE PUREFOY: _(In fishingcap and oilskin jacket)_ He employs a
 34816	mechanical device to frustrate the sacred ends of nature.
 34817	
 34818	THE VEILED SIBYL: _(Stabs herself)_ My hero god! _(She dies)_
 34819	
 34820	_(Many most attractive and enthusiastic women also commit suicide by
 34821	stabbing, drowning, drinking prussic acid, aconite, arsenic, opening
 34822	their veins, refusing food, casting themselves under steamrollers, from
 34823	the top of Nelson's Pillar, into the great vat of Guinness's brewery,
 34824	asphyxiating themselves by placing their heads in gasovens, hanging
 34825	themselves in stylish garters, leaping from windows of different
 34826	storeys.)_
 34827	
 34828	ALEXANDER J DOWIE: _(Violently)_ Fellowchristians and antiBloomites, the
 34829	man called Bloom is from the roots of hell, a disgrace to christian
 34830	men. A fiendish libertine from his earliest years this stinking goat
 34831	of Mendes gave precocious signs of infantile debauchery, recalling the
 34832	cities of the plain, with a dissolute granddam. This vile hypocrite,
 34833	bronzed with infamy, is the white bull mentioned in the Apocalypse.
 34834	A worshipper of the Scarlet Woman, intrigue is the very breath of his
 34835	nostrils. The stake faggots and the caldron of boiling oil are for him.
 34836	Caliban!
 34837	
 34838	THE MOB: Lynch him! Roast him! He's as bad as Parnell was. Mr Fox!
 34839	
 34840	_(Mother Grogan throws her boot at Bloom. Several shopkeepers from upper
 34841	and lower Dorset street throw objects of little or no commercial value,
 34842	hambones, condensed milk tins, unsaleable cabbage, stale bread, sheep's
 34843	tails, odd pieces of fat.)_
 34844	
 34845	BLOOM: _(Excitedly)_ This is midsummer madness, some ghastly joke again.
 34846	By heaven, I am guiltless as the unsunned snow! It was my brother Henry.
 34847	He is my double. He lives in number 2 Dolphin's Barn. Slander, the
 34848	viper, has wrongfully accused me. Fellowcountrymen, _sgenl inn ban bata
 34849	coisde gan capall._ I call on my old friend, Dr Malachi Mulligan, sex
 34850	specialist, to give medical testimony on my behalf.
 34851	
 34852	DR MULLIGAN: _(In motor jerkin, green motorgoggles on his brow)_ Dr
 34853	Bloom is bisexually abnormal. He has recently escaped from Dr Eustace's
 34854	private asylum for demented gentlemen. Born out of bedlock hereditary
 34855	epilepsy is present, the consequence of unbridled lust. Traces of
 34856	elephantiasis have been discovered among his ascendants. There are
 34857	marked symptoms of chronic exhibitionism. Ambidexterity is also
 34858	latent. He is prematurely bald from selfabuse, perversely idealistic in
 34859	consequence, a reformed rake, and has metal teeth. In consequence of a
 34860	family complex he has temporarily lost his memory and I believe him
 34861	to be more sinned against than sinning. I have made a pervaginal
 34862	examination and, after application of the acid test to 5427 anal,
 34863	axillary, pectoral and pubic hairs, I declare him to be _virgo intacta._
 34864	
 34865	_(Bloom holds his high grade hat over his genital organs.)_
 34866	
 34867	DR MADDEN: Hypsospadia is also marked. In the interest of coming
 34868	generations I suggest that the parts affected should be preserved in
 34869	spirits of wine in the national teratological museum.
 34870	
 34871	DR CROTTHERS: I have examined the patient's urine. It is albuminoid.
 34872	Salivation is insufficient, the patellar reflex intermittent.
 34873	
 34874	DR PUNCH COSTELLO: The _fetor judaicus_ is most perceptible.
 34875	
 34876	DR DIXON: _(Reads a bill of health)_ Professor Bloom is a finished
 34877	example of the new womanly man. His moral nature is simple and lovable.
 34878	Many have found him a dear man, a dear person. He is a rather quaint
 34879	fellow on the whole, coy though not feebleminded in the medical sense.
 34880	He has written a really beautiful letter, a poem in itself, to the court
 34881	missionary of the Reformed Priests' Protection Society which clears up
 34882	everything. He is practically a total abstainer and I can affirm that
 34883	he sleeps on a straw litter and eats the most Spartan food, cold dried
 34884	grocer's peas. He wears a hairshirt of pure Irish manufacture winter and
 34885	summer and scourges himself every Saturday. He was, I understand, at one
 34886	time a firstclass misdemeanant in Glencree reformatory. Another report
