 38165	CORNY KELLEHER: _(To the watch, with drawling eye)_ That's all right.
 38166	I know him. Won a bit on the races. Gold cup. Throwaway. _(He laughs)_
 38167	Twenty to one. Do you follow me?
 38168	
 38169	FIRST WATCH: _(Turns to the crowd)_ Here, what are you all gaping at?
 38170	Move on out of that.
 38171	
 38172	_(The crowd disperses slowly, muttering, down the lane.)_
 38173	
 38174	CORNY KELLEHER: Leave it to me, sergeant. That'll be all right. _(He
 38175	laughs, shaking his head)_ We were often as bad ourselves, ay or worse.
 38176	What? Eh, what?
 38177	
 38178	FIRST WATCH: _(Laughs)_ I suppose so.
 38179	
 38180	CORNY KELLEHER: _(Nudges the second watch)_ Come and wipe your name off
 38181	the slate. _(He lilts, wagging his head)_ With my tooraloom tooraloom
 38182	tooraloom tooraloom. What, eh, do you follow me?
 38183	
 38184	SECOND WATCH: _(Genially)_ Ah, sure we were too.
 38185	
 38186	CORNY KELLEHER: _(Winking)_ Boys will be boys. I've a car round there.
 38187	
 38188	SECOND WATCH: All right, Mr Kelleher. Good night.
 38189	
 38190	CORNY KELLEHER: I'll see to that.
 38191	
 38192	BLOOM: _(Shakes hands with both of the watch in turn)_ Thank you very
 38193	much, gentlemen. Thank you. _(He mumbles confidentially)_ We don't want
 38194	any scandal, you understand. Father is a wellknown highly respected
 38195	citizen. Just a little wild oats, you understand.
 38196	
 38197	FIRST WATCH: O. I understand, sir.
 38198	
 38199	SECOND WATCH: That's all right, sir.
 38200	
 38201	FIRST WATCH: It was only in case of corporal injuries I'd have to report
 38202	it at the station.
 38203	
 38204	BLOOM: _(Nods rapidly)_ Naturally. Quite right. Only your bounden duty.
 38205	
 38206	SECOND WATCH: It's our duty.
 38207	
 38208	CORNY KELLEHER: Good night, men.
 38209	
 38210	THE WATCH: _(Saluting together)_ Night, gentlemen. _(They move off with
 38211	slow heavy tread)_
 38212	
 38213	BLOOM: _(Blows)_ Providential you came on the scene. You have a car?...
 38214	
 38215	CORNY KELLEHER: _(Laughs, pointing his thumb over his right shoulder to
 38216	the car brought up against the scaffolding)_ Two commercials that were
 38217	standing fizz in Jammet's. Like princes, faith. One of them lost two
 38218	quid on the race. Drowning his grief. And were on for a go with the
 38219	jolly girls. So I landed them up on Behan's car and down to nighttown.
 38220	
 38221	BLOOM: I was just going home by Gardiner street when I happened to...
 38222	
 38223	CORNY KELLEHER: _(Laughs)_ Sure they wanted me to join in with the mots.
 38224	No, by God, says I. Not for old stagers like myself and yourself. _(He
 38225	laughs again and leers with lacklustre eye)_ Thanks be to God we have it
 38226	in the house, what, eh, do you follow me? Hah, hah, hah!
 38227	
 38228	BLOOM: _(Tries to laugh)_ He, he, he! Yes. Matter of fact I was just
 38229	visiting an old friend of mine there, Virag, you don't know him (poor
 38230	fellow, he's laid up for the past week) and we had a liquor together and
 38231	I was just making my way home...
 38232	
 38233	_(The horse neighs.)_
 38234	
 38235	THE HORSE: Hohohohohohoh! Hohohohome!
 38236	
 38237	CORNY KELLEHER: Sure it was Behan our jarvey there that told me after
 38238	we left the two commercials in Mrs Cohen's and I told him to pull up and
 38239	got off to see. _(He laughs)_ Sober hearsedrivers a speciality. Will I
 38240	give him a lift home? Where does he hang out? Somewhere in Cabra, what?
 38241	
 38242	BLOOM: No, in Sandycove, I believe, from what he let drop.
 38243	
 38244	_(Stephen, prone, breathes to the stars. Corny Kelleher, asquint, drawls
 38245	at the horse. Bloom, in gloom, looms down.)_
 38246	
 38247	CORNY KELLEHER: _(Scratches his nape)_ Sandycove! _(He bends down and
 38248	calls to Stephen)_ Eh! _(He calls again)_ Eh! He's covered with shavings
 38249	anyhow. Take care they didn't lift anything off him.
 38250	
 38251	BLOOM: No, no, no. I have his money and his hat here and stick.
 38252	
 38253	CORNY KELLEHER: Ah, well, he'll get over it. No bones broken. Well, I'll
 38254	shove along. _(He laughs)_ I've a rendezvous in the morning. Burying the
 38255	dead. Safe home!
 38256	
 38257	THE HORSE: _(Neighs)_ Hohohohohome.
 38258	
 38259	BLOOM: Good night. I'll just wait and take him along in a few...
 38260	
 38261	_(Corny Kelleher returns to the outside car and mounts it. The horse
 38262	harness jingles.)_
 38263	
 38264	CORNY KELLEHER: _(From the car, standing)_ Night.
 38265	
 38266	BLOOM: Night.
 38267	
 38268	_(The jarvey chucks the reins and raises his whip encouragingly. The
 38269	car and horse back slowly, awkwardly, and turn. Corny Kelleher on the
 38270	sideseat sways his head to and fro in sign of mirth at Bloom's plight.
 38271	The jarvey joins in the mute pantomimic merriment nodding from the
 38272	farther seat. Bloom shakes his head in mute mirthful reply. With thumb
 38273	and palm Corny Kelleher reassures that the two bobbies will allow the
 38274	sleep to continue for what else is to be done. With a slow nod Bloom
 38275	conveys his gratitude as that is exactly what Stephen needs. The car
 38276	jingles tooraloom round the corner of the tooraloom lane. Corny Kelleher
 38277	again reassuralooms with his hand. Bloom with his hand assuralooms Corny
 38278	Kelleher that he is reassuraloomtay. The tinkling hoofs and jingling
 38279	harness grow fainter with their tooralooloo looloo lay. Bloom, holding
 38280	in his hand Stephen's hat, festooned with shavings, and ashplant, stands
 38281	irresolute. Then he bends to him and shakes him by the shoulder.)_
 38282	
 38283	BLOOM: Eh! Ho! _(There is no answer; he bends again)_ Mr Dedalus!
 38284	_(There is no answer)_ The name if you call. Somnambulist. _(He bends
 38285	again and hesitating, brings his mouth near the face of the prostrate
 38286	form)_ Stephen! _(There is no answer. He calls again.)_ Stephen!
 38287	
 38288	STEPHEN: _(Groans)_ Who? Black panther. Vampire. _(He sighs and
 38289	stretches himself, then murmurs thickly with prolonged vowels)_
 38290	
 38291	     Who... drive... Fergus now
 38292	     And pierce... wood's woven shade?...
 38293	
 38294	_(He turns on his left side, sighing, doubling himself together.)_
 38295	
 38296	BLOOM: Poetry. Well educated. Pity. _(He bends again and undoes
 38297	the buttons of Stephen's waistcoat)_ To breathe. _(He brushes the
 38298	woodshavings from Stephen's clothes with light hand and fingers)_ One
 38299	pound seven. Not hurt anyhow. _(He listens)_ What?
 38300	
 38301	STEPHEN: _(Murmurs)_
 38302	
 38303	    ... shadows... the woods
 38304	    ... white breast... dim sea.
 38305	
 38306	_(He stretches out his arms, sighs again and curls his body. Bloom,
 38307	holding the hat and ashplant, stands erect. A dog barks in the distance.
 38308	Bloom tightens and loosens his grip on the ashplant. He looks down on
 38309	Stephen's face and form.)_
 38310	
 38311	BLOOM: _(Communes with the night)_ Face reminds me of his poor mother.
 38312	In the shady wood. The deep white breast. Ferguson, I think I caught. A
 38313	girl. Some girl. Best thing could happen him. _(He murmurs)_... swear
 38314	that I will always hail, ever conceal, never reveal, any part or parts,
 38315	art or arts... _(He murmurs)_... in the rough sands of the sea... a
 38316	cabletow's length from the shore... where the tide ebbs... and flows
 38317	...
 38318	
 38319	_(Silent, thoughtful, alert he stands on guard, his fingers at his lips
 38320	in the attitude of secret master. Against the dark wall a figure appears
 38321	slowly, a fairy boy of eleven, a changeling, kidnapped, dressed in an
 38322	eton suit with glass shoes and a little bronze helmet, holding a book
 38323	in his hand. He reads from right to left inaudibly, smiling, kissing the
 38324	page.)_
 38325	
 38326	BLOOM: _(Wonderstruck, calls inaudibly)_ Rudy!
 38327	
 38328	RUDY: _(Gazes, unseeing, into Bloom's eyes and goes on reading, kissing,
 38329	smiling. He has a delicate mauve face. On his suit he has diamond and
 38330	ruby buttons. In his free left hand he holds a slim ivory cane with a
 38331	violet bowknot. A white lambkin peeps out of his waistcoat pocket.)_
 38332	
 38333	
 38334	
 38335	
 38336	-- III --
 38337	
 38338	Preparatory to anything else Mr Bloom brushed off the greater bulk of
 38339	the shavings and handed Stephen the hat and ashplant and bucked him up
 38340	generally in orthodox Samaritan fashion which he very badly needed. His
 38341	(Stephen's) mind was not exactly what you would call wandering but a bit
 38342	unsteady and on his expressed desire for some beverage to drink Mr
 38343	Bloom in view of the hour it was and there being no pump of Vartry water
 38344	available for their ablutions let alone drinking purposes hit upon an
 38345	expedient by suggesting, off the reel, the propriety of the cabman's
 38346	shelter, as it was called, hardly a stonesthrow away near Butt bridge
 38347	where they might hit upon some drinkables in the shape of a milk and
 38348	soda or a mineral. But how to get there was the rub. For the nonce he
 38349	was rather nonplussed but inasmuch as the duty plainly devolved upon him
 38350	to take some measures on the subject he pondered suitable ways and means
 38351	during which Stephen repeatedly yawned. So far as he could see he was
 38352	rather pale in the face so that it occurred to him as highly advisable
 38353	to get a conveyance of some description which would answer in their
 38354	then condition, both of them being e.d.ed, particularly Stephen, always
 38355	assuming that there was such a thing to be found. Accordingly after a
 38356	few such preliminaries as brushing, in spite of his having forgotten
 38357	to take up his rather soapsuddy handkerchief after it had done yeoman
 38358	service in the shaving line, they both walked together along Beaver
 38359	street or, more properly, lane as far as the farrier's and the
 38360	distinctly fetid atmosphere of the livery stables at the corner of
 38361	Montgomery street where they made tracks to the left from thence
 38362	debouching into Amiens street round by the corner of Dan Bergin's. But
 38363	as he confidently anticipated there was not a sign of a Jehu plying for
 38364	hire anywhere to be seen except a fourwheeler, probably engaged by some
 38365	fellows inside on the spree, outside the North Star hotel and there was
 38366	no symptom of its budging a quarter of an inch when Mr Bloom, who was
 38367	anything but a professional whistler, endeavoured to hail it by emitting
 38368	a kind of a whistle, holding his arms arched over his head, twice.
 38369	
 38370	This was a quandary but, bringing common sense to bear on it, evidently
 38371	there was nothing for it but put a good face on the matter and foot it
 38372	which they accordingly did. So, bevelling around by Mullett's and the
 38373	Signal House which they shortly reached, they proceeded perforce in the
 38374	direction of Amiens street railway terminus, Mr Bloom being handicapped
 38375	by the circumstance that one of the back buttons of his trousers had,
 38376	to vary the timehonoured adage, gone the way of all buttons though,
 38377	entering thoroughly into the spirit of the thing, he heroically made
 38378	light of the mischance. So as neither of them were particularly pressed
 38379	for time, as it happened, and the temperature refreshing since it
 38380	cleared up after the recent visitation of Jupiter Pluvius, they dandered
 38381	along past by where the empty vehicle was waiting without a fare or a
 38382	jarvey. As it so happened a Dublin United Tramways Company's sandstrewer
 38383	happened to be returning and the elder man recounted to his companion _Ã 
 38384	propos_ of the incident his own truly miraculous escape of some little
 38385	while back. They passed the main entrance of the Great Northern railway
 38386	station, the starting point for Belfast, where of course all traffic was
 38387	suspended at that late hour and passing the backdoor of the morgue
 38388	(a not very enticing locality, not to say gruesome to a degree, more
 38389	especially at night) ultimately gained the Dock Tavern and in due course
 38390	turned into Store street, famous for its C division police station.
 38391	Between this point and the high at present unlit warehouses of Beresford
 38392	place Stephen thought to think of Ibsen, associated with Baird's the
 38393	stonecutter's in his mind somehow in Talbot place, first turning on the
 38394	right, while the other who was acting as his _fidus Achates_ inhaled
 38395	with internal satisfaction the smell of James Rourke's city bakery,
 38396	situated quite close to where they were, the very palatable odour indeed
 38397	of our daily bread, of all commodities of the public the primary and
 38398	most indispensable. Bread, the staff of life, earn your bread, O tell me
 38399	where is fancy bread, at Rourke's the baker's it is said.
 38400	
 38401	_En route_ to his taciturn and, not to put too fine a point on it, not
 38402	yet perfectly sober companion Mr Bloom who at all events was in complete
 38403	possession of his faculties, never more so, in fact disgustingly sober,
 38404	spoke a word of caution re the dangers of nighttown, women of ill fame
 38405	and swell mobsmen, which, barely permissible once in a while though not
 38406	as a habitual practice, was of the nature of a regular deathtrap for
 38407	young fellows of his age particularly if they had acquired drinking
 38408	habits under the influence of liquor unless you knew a little jiujitsu
 38409	for every contingency as even a fellow on the broad of his back could
 38410	administer a nasty kick if you didn't look out. Highly providential
 38411	was the appearance on the scene of Corny Kelleher when Stephen was
 38412	blissfully unconscious but for that man in the gap turning up at the
 38413	eleventh hour the finis might have been that he might have been a
 38414	candidate for the accident ward or, failing that, the bridewell and
 38415	an appearance in the court next day before Mr Tobias or, he being the
 38416	solicitor rather, old Wall, he meant to say, or Mahony which simply
 38417	spelt ruin for a chap when it got bruited about. The reason he mentioned
 38418	the fact was that a lot of those policemen, whom he cordially disliked,
 38419	were admittedly unscrupulous in the service of the Crown and, as Mr
 38420	Bloom put it, recalling a case or two in the A division in Clanbrassil
 38421	street, prepared to swear a hole through a ten gallon pot. Never on
 38422	the spot when wanted but in quiet parts of the city, Pembroke road for
 38423	example, the
 38424	
 38425	guardians of the law were well in evidence, the obvious reason being
 38426	they were paid to protect the upper classes. Another thing he commented
 38427	on was equipping soldiers with firearms or sidearms of any description
 38428	liable to go off at any time which was tantamount to inciting them
 38429	against civilians should by any chance they fall out over anything. You
 38430	frittered away your time, he very sensibly maintained, and health and
 38431	also character besides which, the squandermania of the thing, fast women
 38432	of the _demimonde_ ran away with a lot of l s. d. into the bargain and
 38433	the greatest danger of all was who you got drunk with though, touching
 38434	the much vexed question of stimulants, he relished a glass of choice old
 38435	wine in season as both
 38436	
 38437	nourishing and bloodmaking and possessing aperient virtues (notably a
 38438	good burgundy which he was a staunch believer in) still never beyond
 38439	a certain point where he invariably drew the line as it simply led to
 38440	trouble all round to say nothing of your being at the tender mercy of
 38441	others practically. Most of all he commented adversely on the desertion
 38442	of Stephen by all his pubhunting _confreres_ but one, a most glaring
 38443	piece of ratting on the part of his brother medicos under all the circs.
 38444	
 38445	--And that one was Judas, Stephen said, who up to then had said nothing
 38446	whatsoever of any kind.
 38447	
 38448	Discussing these and kindred topics they made a beeline across the back
 38449	of the Customhouse and passed under the Loop Line bridge where a brazier
 38450	of coke burning in front of a sentrybox or something like one attracted
 38451	their rather lagging footsteps. Stephen of his own accord stopped for
 38452	no special reason to look at the heap of barren cobblestones and by
 38453	the light emanating from the brazier he could just make out the darker
 38454	figure of the corporation watchman inside the gloom of the sentrybox. He
 38455	began to remember that this had happened or had been mentioned as having
 38456	happened before but it cost him no small effort before he remembered
 38457	that he recognised in the sentry a quondam friend of his father's,
 38458	Gumley. To avoid a meeting he drew nearer to the pillars of the railway
 38459	bridge.
 38460	
 38461	--Someone saluted you, Mr Bloom said.
 38462	
 38463	A figure of middle height on the prowl evidently under the arches
 38464	saluted again, calling:
 38465	
 38466	--_Night!_
 38467	
 38468	Stephen of course started rather dizzily and stopped to return the
 38469	compliment. Mr Bloom actuated by motives of inherent delicacy inasmuch
 38470	as he always believed in minding his own business moved off but
 38471	nevertheless remained on the _qui vive_ with just a shade of anxiety
 38472	though not funkyish in the least. Though unusual in the Dublin area he
 38473	knew that it was not by any means unknown for desperadoes who had next
 38474	to nothing to live on to be abroad waylaying and generally terrorising
 38475	peaceable pedestrians by placing a pistol at their head in some
 38476	secluded spot outside the city proper, famished loiterers of the
 38477	Thames embankment category they might be hanging about there or simply
 38478	marauders ready to decamp with whatever boodle they could in one fell
 38479	swoop at a moment's notice, your money or your life, leaving you there
 38480	to point a moral, gagged and garrotted.
 38481	
 38482	Stephen, that is when the accosting figure came to close quarters,
 38483	though he was not in an over sober state himself recognised Corley's
 38484	breath redolent of rotten cornjuice. Lord John Corley some called him
 38485	and his genealogy came about in this wise. He was the eldest son of
 38486	inspector Corley of the G division, lately deceased, who had married
 38487	a certain Katherine Brophy, the daughter of a Louth farmer. His
 38488	grandfather Patrick Michael Corley of New Ross had married the widow
 38489	of a publican there whose maiden name had been Katherine (also) Talbot.
 38490	Rumour had it (though not proved) that she descended from the house of
 38491	the lords Talbot de Malahide in whose mansion, really an unquestionably
 38492	fine residence of its kind and well worth seeing, her mother or aunt or
 38493	some relative, a woman, as the tale went, of extreme beauty, had enjoyed
 38494	the distinction of being in service in the washkitchen. This therefore
 38495	was the reason why the still comparatively young though dissolute
 38496	man who now addressed Stephen was spoken of by some with facetious
 38497	proclivities as Lord John Corley.
 38498	
 38499	Taking Stephen on one side he had the customary doleful ditty to tell.
 38500	Not as much as a farthing to purchase a night's lodgings. His friends
 38501	had all deserted him. Furthermore he had a row with Lenehan and called
 38502	him to Stephen a mean bloody swab with a sprinkling of a number of other
 38503	uncalledfor expressions. He was out of a job and implored of Stephen to
 38504	tell him where on God's earth he could get something, anything at all,
 38505	to do. No, it was the daughter of the mother in the washkitchen that
 38506	was fostersister to the heir of the house or else they were connected
 38507	through the mother in some way, both occurrences happening at the same
 38508	time if the whole thing wasn't a complete fabrication from start to
 38509	finish. Anyhow he was all in.
 38510	
 38511	--I wouldn't ask you only, pursued he, on my solemn oath and God knows
 38512	I'm on the rocks.
 38513	
 38514	--There'll be a job tomorrow or next day, Stephen told him, in a boys'
 38515	school at Dalkey for a gentleman usher. Mr Garrett Deasy. Try it. You
 38516	may mention my name.
 38517	
 38518	--Ah, God, Corley replied, sure I couldn't teach in a school, man. I was
 38519	never one of your bright ones, he added with a half laugh. I got stuck
 38520	twice in the junior at the christian brothers.
 38521	
 38522	--I have no place to sleep myself, Stephen informed him.
 38523	
 38524	Corley at the first go-off was inclined to suspect it was something to
 38525	do with Stephen being fired out of his digs for bringing in a bloody
 38526	tart off the street. There was a dosshouse in Marlborough street, Mrs
 38527	Maloney's, but it was only a tanner touch and full of undesirables but
 38528	M'Conachie told him you got a decent enough do in the Brazen Head over
 38529	in Winetavern street (which was distantly suggestive to the person
 38530	addressed of friar Bacon) for a bob. He was starving too though he
 38531	hadn't said a word about it.
 38532	
 38533	Though this sort of thing went on every other night or very near it
 38534	still Stephen's feelings got the better of him in a sense though he knew
 38535	that Corley's brandnew rigmarole on a par with the others was hardly
 38536	deserving of much credence. However _haud ignarus malorum miseris
 38537	succurrere disco_ etcetera as the Latin poet remarks especially as luck
 38538	would have it he got paid his screw after every middle of the month on
 38539	the sixteenth which was the date of the month as a matter of fact though
 38540	a good bit of the wherewithal was demolished. But the cream of the joke
 38541	was nothing would get it out of Corley's head that he was living in
 38542	affluence and hadn't a thing to do but hand out the needful. Whereas.
 38543	He put his hand in a pocket anyhow not with the idea of finding any food
 38544	there but thinking he might lend him anything up to a bob or so in lieu
 38545	so that he might endeavour at all events and get sufficient to eat but
 38546	the result was in the negative for, to his chagrin, he found his cash
 38547	missing. A few broken biscuits were all the result of his investigation.
 38548	He tried his hardest to recollect for the moment whether he had lost
 38549	as well he might have or left because in that contingency it was not a
 38550	pleasant lookout, very much the reverse in fact. He was altogether too
 38551	fagged out to institute a thorough search though he tried to recollect.
 38552	About biscuits he dimly remembered. Who now exactly gave them he
 38553	wondered or where was or did he buy. However in another pocket he came
 38554	across what he surmised in the dark were pennies, erroneously however,
 38555	as it turned out.
 38556	
 38557	--Those are halfcrowns, man, Corley corrected him.
 38558	
 38559	And so in point of fact they turned out to be. Stephen anyhow lent him
 38560	one of them.
 38561	
 38562	--Thanks, Corley answered, you're a gentleman. I'll pay you back one
 38563	time. Who's that with you? I saw him a few times in the Bleeding Horse
 38564	in Camden street with Boylan, the billsticker. You might put in a good
 38565	word for us to get me taken on there. I'd carry a sandwichboard only
 38566	the girl in the office told me they're full up for the next three weeks,
 38567	man. God, you've to book ahead, man, you'd think it was for the Carl
 38568	Rosa. I don't give a shite anyway so long as I get a job, even as a
 38569	crossing sweeper.
 38570	
 38571	Subsequently being not quite so down in the mouth after the two and six
 38572	he got he informed Stephen about a fellow by the name of Bags Comisky
 38573	that he said Stephen knew well out of Fullam's, the shipchandler's,
 38574	bookkeeper there that used to be often round in Nagle's back with O'Mara
 38575	and a little chap with a stutter the name of Tighe. Anyhow he was lagged
 38576	the night before last and fined ten bob for a drunk and disorderly and
 38577	refusing to go with the constable.
 38578	
 38579	210
 38580	
 38581	Mr Bloom in the meanwhile kept dodging about in the vicinity of the
 38582	cobblestones near the brazier of coke in front of the corporation
 38583	watchman's sentrybox who evidently a glutton for work, it struck him,
 38584	was having a quiet forty winks for all intents and purposes on his own
 38585	private account while Dublin slept. He threw an odd eye at the same time
 38586	now and then at Stephen's anything but immaculately attired interlocutor
 38587	as if he had seen that nobleman somewhere or other though where he was
 38588	not in a position to truthfully state nor had he the remotest idea when.
 38589	Being a levelheaded individual who could give points to not a few in
 38590	point of shrewd observation he also remarked on his very dilapidated
 38591	hat and slouchy wearing apparel generally testifying to a chronic
 38592	impecuniosity. Palpably he was one of his hangerson but for the
 38593	matter of that it was merely a question of one preying on his nextdoor
 38594	neighbour all round, in every deep, so to put it, a deeper depth and for
 38595	the matter of that if the man in the street chanced to be in the dock
 38596	himself penal servitude with or without the option of a fine would be
 38597	a very rara avis altogether. In any case he had a consummate amount of
 38598	cool assurance intercepting people at that hour of the night or morning.
 38599	Pretty thick that was certainly.
 38600	
 38601	The pair parted company and Stephen rejoined Mr Bloom who, with his
 38602	practised eye, was not without perceiving that he had succumbed to the
 38603	blandiloquence of the other parasite. Alluding to the encounter he said,
 38604	laughingly, Stephen, that is:
 38605	
 38606	--He is down on his luck. He asked me to ask you to ask somebody named
 38607	Boylan, a billsticker, to give him a job as a sandwichman.
 38608	
 38609	At this intelligence, in which he seemingly evinced little interest, Mr
 38610	Bloom gazed abstractedly for the space of a half a second or so in the
 38611	direction of a bucketdredger, rejoicing in the farfamed name of Eblana,
 38612	moored alongside Customhouse quay and quite possibly out of repair,
 38613	whereupon he observed evasively:
 38614	
 38615	--Everybody gets their own ration of luck, they say. Now you mention it
 38616	his face was familiar to me. But, leaving that for the moment, how much
 38617	did you part with, he queried, if I am not too inquisitive?
 38618	
 38619	--Half a crown, Stephen responded. I daresay he needs it to sleep
 38620	somewhere.
 38621	
 38622	--Needs! Mr Bloom ejaculated, professing not the least surprise at
 38623	the intelligence, I can quite credit the assertion and I guarantee he
 38624	invariably does. Everyone according to his needs or everyone according
 38625	to his deeds. But, talking about things in general, where, added he with
 38626	a smile, will you sleep yourself? Walking to Sandycove is out of
 38627	the question. And even supposing you did you won't get in after what
 38628	occurred at Westland Row station. Simply fag out there for nothing. I
 38629	don't mean to presume to dictate to you in the slightest degree but why
 38630	did you leave your father's house?
 38631	
 38632	--To seek misfortune, was Stephen's answer.
 38633	
 38634	--I met your respected father on a recent occasion, Mr Bloom
 38635	diplomatically returned, today in fact, or to be strictly accurate, on
 38636	yesterday. Where does he live at present? I gathered in the course of
 38637	conversation that he had moved.
 38638	
 38639	--I believe he is in Dublin somewhere, Stephen answered unconcernedly.
 38640	Why?
 38641	
 38642	--A gifted man, Mr Bloom said of Mr Dedalus senior, in more respects
 38643	than one and a born _raconteur_ if ever there was one. He takes great
 38644	pride, quite legitimate, out of you. You could go back perhaps, he
 38645	hasarded, still thinking of the very unpleasant scene at Westland Row
 38646	terminus when it was perfectly evident that the other two, Mulligan,
 38647	that is, and that English tourist friend of his, who eventually euchred
 38648	their third companion, were patently trying as if the whole bally
 38649	station belonged to them to give Stephen the slip in the confusion,
 38650	which they did.
 38651	
 38652	There was no response forthcoming to the suggestion however, such as it
 38653	was, Stephen's mind's eye being too busily engaged in repicturing his
 38654	family hearth the last time he saw it with his sister Dilly sitting by
 38655	the ingle, her hair hanging down, waiting for some weak Trinidad shell
 38656	cocoa that was in the sootcoated kettle to be done so that she and he
 38657	could drink it with the oatmealwater for milk after the Friday herrings
 38658	they had eaten at two a penny with an egg apiece for Maggy, Boody and
 38659	Katey, the cat meanwhile under the mangle devouring a mess of eggshells
 38660	and charred fish heads and bones on a square of brown paper, in
 38661	accordance with the third precept of the church to fast and abstain
 38662	on the days commanded, it being quarter tense or if not, ember days or
 38663	something like that.
 38664	
 38665	--No, Mr Bloom repeated again, I wouldn't personally repose much trust
 38666	in that boon companion of yours who contributes the humorous element, Dr
 38667	Mulligan, as a guide, philosopher and friend if I were in your shoes. He
 38668	knows which side his bread is buttered on though in all probability he
 38669	never realised what it is to be without regular meals. Of course you
 38670	didn't notice as much as I did. But it wouldn't occasion me the least
 38671	surprise to learn that a pinch of tobacco or some narcotic was put in
 38672	your drink for some ulterior object.
 38673	
 38674	He understood however from all he heard that Dr Mulligan was a versatile
 38675	allround man, by no means confined to medicine only, who was rapidly
 38676	coming to the fore in his line and, if the report was verified, bade
 38677	fair to enjoy a flourishing practice in the not too distant future as
 38678	a tony medical practitioner drawing a handsome fee for his services
 38679	in addition to which professional status his rescue of that man from
 38680	certain drowning by artificial respiration and what they call first
 38681	aid at Skerries, or Malahide was it?, was, he was bound to admit, an
 38682	exceedingly plucky deed which he could not too highly praise, so that
 38683	frankly he was utterly at a loss to fathom what earthly reason could be
 38684	at the back of it except he put it down to sheer cussedness or jealousy,
 38685	pure and simple.
 38686	
 38687	--Except it simply amounts to one thing and he is what they call picking
 38688	your brains, he ventured to throw out.
 38689	
 38690	The guarded glance of half solicitude half curiosity augmented by
 38691	friendliness which he gave at Stephen's at present morose expression
 38692	of features did not throw a flood of light, none at all in fact on the
 38693	problem as to whether he had let himself be badly bamboozled to judge by
 38694	two or three lowspirited remarks he let drop or the other way about saw
 38695	through the affair and for some reason or other best known to himself
 38696	allowed matters to more or less. Grinding poverty did have that effect
 38697	and he more than conjectured that, high educational abilities though he
 38698	possessed, he experienced no little difficulty in making both ends meet.
 38699	
 38700	Adjacent to the men's public urinal they perceived an icecream car round
 38701	which a group of presumably Italians in heated altercation were getting
 38702	rid of voluble expressions in their vivacious language in a particularly
 38703	animated way, there being some little differences between the parties.
 38704	
 38705	--_Puttana madonna, che ci dia i quattrini! Ho ragione? Culo rotto!_
 38706	
 38707	_--Intendiamoci. Mezzo sovrano piu..._
 38708	
 38709	_--Dice lui, pero!_
 38710	
 38711	_--Mezzo._
 38712	
 38713	_--Farabutto! Mortacci sui!_
 38714	
 38715	_--Ma ascolta! Cinque la testa piu..._
 38716	
 38717	Mr Bloom and Stephen entered the cabman's shelter, an unpretentious
 38718	wooden structure, where, prior to then, he had rarely if ever been
 38719	before, the former having previously whispered to the latter a few
 38720	hints anent the keeper of it said to be the once famous Skin-the-Goat
 38721	Fitzharris, the invincible, though he could not vouch for the actual
 38722	facts which quite possibly there was not one vestige of truth in. A few
 38723	moments later saw our two noctambules safely seated in a discreet corner
 38724	only to be greeted by stares from the decidedly miscellaneous collection
 38725	of waifs and strays and other nondescript specimens of the genus _homo_
 38726	already there engaged in eating and drinking diversified by conversation
 38727	for whom they seemingly formed an object of marked curiosity.
 38728	
 38729	--Now touching a cup of coffee, Mr Bloom ventured to plausibly suggest
 38730	to break the ice, it occurs to me you ought to sample something in the
 38731	shape of solid food, say, a roll of some description.
 38732	
 38733	Accordingly his first act was with characteristic _sangfroid_ to order
 38734	these commodities quietly. The _hoi polloi_ of jarvies or stevedores
 38735	or whatever they were after a cursory examination turned their eyes
 38736	apparently dissatisfied, away though one redbearded bibulous individual
 38737	portion of whose hair was greyish, a sailor probably, still stared for
 38738	some appreciable time before transferring his rapt attention to the
 38739	floor. Mr Bloom, availing himself of the right of free speech, he having
 38740	just a bowing acquaintance with the language in dispute, though, to be
 38741	sure, rather in a quandary over _voglio_, remarked to his _protÃ©gÃ©_ in
 38742	an audible tone of voice _a propos_ of the battle royal in the street
 38743	which was still raging fast and furious:
 38744	
 38745	--A beautiful language. I mean for singing purposes. Why do you not
 38746	write your poetry in that language? _Bella Poetria_! It is so melodious
 38747	and full. _Belladonna. Voglio._
 38748	
 38749	Stephen, who was trying his dead best to yawn if he could, suffering
 38750	from lassitude generally, replied:
 38751	
 38752	--To fill the ear of a cow elephant. They were haggling over money.
 38753	
 38754	--Is that so? Mr Bloom asked. Of course, he subjoined pensively, at the
 38755	inward reflection of there being more languages to start with than were
 38756	absolutely necessary, it may be only the southern glamour that surrounds
 38757	it.
 38758	
 38759	The keeper of the shelter in the middle of this _tÃªte-Ã¢-tÃªte_ put a
 38760	boiling swimming cup of a choice concoction labelled coffee on the table
 38761	and a rather antediluvian specimen of a bun, or so it seemed. After
 38762	which he beat a retreat to his counter, Mr Bloom determining to have
 38763	a good square look at him later on so as not to appear to. For which
 38764	reason he encouraged Stephen to proceed with his eyes while he did
 38765	the honours by surreptitiously pushing the cup of what was temporarily
 38766	supposed to be called coffee gradually nearer him.
 38767	
 38768	--Sounds are impostures, Stephen said after a pause of some little time,
 38769	like names. Cicero, Podmore. Napoleon, Mr Goodbody. Jesus, Mr Doyle.
 38770	Shakespeares were as common as Murphies. What's in a name?
 38771	
 38772	--Yes, to be sure, Mr Bloom unaffectedly concurred. Of course. Our name
 38773	was changed too, he added, pushing the socalled roll across.
 38774	
 38775	The redbearded sailor who had his weather eye on the newcomers boarded
 38776	Stephen, whom he had singled out for attention in particular, squarely
 38777	by asking:
 38778	
 38779	--And what might your name be?
 38780	
 38781	Just in the nick of time Mr Bloom touched his companion's boot but
 38782	Stephen, apparently disregarding the warm pressure from an unexpected
 38783	quarter, answered:
 38784	
 38785	--Dedalus.
 38786	
 38787	The sailor stared at him heavily from a pair of drowsy baggy eyes,
 38788	rather bunged up from excessive use of boose, preferably good old
 38789	Hollands and water.
 38790	
 38791	--You know Simon Dedalus? he asked at length.
 38792	
 38793	--I've heard of him, Stephen said.
 38794	
 38795	Mr Bloom was all at sea for a moment, seeing the others evidently
 38796	eavesdropping too.
 38797	
 38798	--He's Irish, the seaman bold affirmed, staring still in much the same
 38799	way and nodding. All Irish.
 38800	
 38801	--All too Irish, Stephen rejoined.
 38802	
 38803	As for Mr Bloom he could neither make head or tail of the whole business
 38804	and he was just asking himself what possible connection when the sailor
 38805	of his own accord turned to the other occupants of the shelter with the
 38806	remark:
 38807	
 38808	--I seen him shoot two eggs off two bottles at fifty yards over his
 38809	shoulder. The lefthand dead shot.
 38810	
 38811	Though he was slightly hampered by an occasional stammer and his
 38812	gestures being also clumsy as it was still he did his best to explain.
 38813	
 38814	--Bottles out there, say. Fifty yards measured. Eggs on the bottles.
 38815	Cocks his gun over his shoulder. Aims.
 38816	
 38817	He turned his body half round, shut up his right eye completely. Then he
 38818	screwed his features up someway sideways and glared out into the night
 38819	with an unprepossessing cast of countenance.
 38820	
 38821	--Pom! he then shouted once.
 38822	
 38823	The entire audience waited, anticipating an additional detonation, there
 38824	being still a further egg.
 38825	
 38826	--Pom! he shouted twice.
 38827	
 38828	Egg two evidently demolished, he nodded and winked, adding
 38829	bloodthirstily:
 38830	
 38831	_--Buffalo Bill shoots to kill, Never missed nor he never will._
 38832	
 38833	A silence ensued till Mr Bloom for agreeableness' sake just felt like
 38834	asking him whether it was for a marksmanship competition like the
 38835	Bisley.
 38836	
 38837	--Beg pardon, the sailor said.
 38838	
 38839	--Long ago? Mr Bloom pursued without flinching a hairsbreadth.
 38840	
 38841	--Why, the sailor replied, relaxing to a certain extent under the magic
 38842	influence of diamond cut diamond, it might be a matter of ten years. He
 38843	toured the wide world with Hengler's Royal Circus. I seen him do that in
 38844	Stockholm.
 38845	
 38846	--Curious coincidence, Mr Bloom confided to Stephen unobtrusively.
 38847	
 38848	--Murphy's my name, the sailor continued. D. B. Murphy of Carrigaloe.
 38849	Know where that is?
 38850	
 38851	--Queenstown harbour, Stephen replied.
 38852	
 38853	--That's right, the sailor said. Fort Camden and Fort Carlisle. That's
 38854	where I hails from. I belongs there. That's where I hails from. My
 38855	little woman's down there. She's waiting for me, I know. _For England,
 38856	home and beauty_. She's my own true wife I haven't seen for seven years
 38857	now, sailing about.
 38858	
 38859	Mr Bloom could easily picture his advent on this scene, the homecoming
 38860	to the mariner's roadside shieling after having diddled Davy Jones,
 38861	a rainy night with a blind moon. Across the world for a wife. Quite a
 38862	number of stories there were on that particular Alice Ben Bolt topic,
 38863	Enoch Arden and Rip van Winkle and does anybody hereabouts remember Caoc
 38864	O'Leary, a favourite and most trying declamation piece by the way of
 38865	poor John Casey and a bit of perfect poetry in its own small way.
 38866	Never about the runaway wife coming back, however much devoted to the
 38867	absentee. The face at the window! Judge of his astonishment when he
 38868	finally did breast the tape and the awful truth dawned upon him anent
 38869	his better half, wrecked in his affections. You little expected me but
 38870	I've come to stay and make a fresh start. There she sits, a grasswidow,
 38871	at the selfsame fireside. Believes me dead, rocked in the cradle of the
 38872	deep. And there sits uncle Chubb or Tomkin, as the case might be, the
 38873	publican of the Crown and Anchor, in shirtsleeves, eating rumpsteak and
 38874	onions. No chair for father. Broo! The wind! Her brandnew arrival is on
 38875	her knee, _post mortem_ child. With a high ro! and a randy ro! and my
 38876	galloping tearing tandy, O! Bow to the inevitable. Grin and bear it. I
 38877	remain with much love your brokenhearted husband D B Murphy.
 38878	
 38879	The sailor, who scarcely seemed to be a Dublin resident, turned to one
 38880	of the jarvies with the request:
 38881	
 38882	--You don't happen to have such a thing as a spare chaw about you?
 38883	
 38884	The jarvey addressed as it happened had not but the keeper took a die of
 38885	plug from his good jacket hanging on a nail and the desired object was
 38886	passed from hand to hand.
 38887	
 38888	--Thank you, the sailor said.
 38889	
 38890	He deposited the quid in his gob and, chewing and with some slow
 38891	stammers, proceeded:
 38892	
 38893	--We come up this morning eleven o'clock. The threemaster _Rosevean_
 38894	from Bridgwater with bricks. I shipped to get over. Paid off this
 38895	afternoon. There's my discharge. See? D. B. Murphy. A. B. S.
 38896	
 38897	In confirmation of which statement he extricated from an inside pocket
 38898	and handed to his neighbour a not very cleanlooking folded document.
 38899	
 38900	--You must have seen a fair share of the world, the keeper remarked,
 38901	leaning on the counter.
 38902	
 38903	--Why, the sailor answered upon reflection upon it, I've circumnavigated
 38904	a bit since I first joined on. I was in the Red Sea. I was in China and
 38905	North America and South America. We was chased by pirates one voyage.
 38906	I seen icebergs plenty, growlers. I was in Stockholm and the Black Sea,
 38907	the Dardanelles under Captain Dalton, the best bloody man that ever
 38908	scuttled a ship. I seen Russia. _Gospodi pomilyou_. That's how the
 38909	Russians prays.
 38910	
 38911	--You seen queer sights, don't be talking, put in a jarvey.
 38912	
 38913	--Why, the sailor said, shifting his partially chewed plug. I seen
 38914	queer things too, ups and downs. I seen a crocodile bite the fluke of an
 38915	anchor same as I chew that quid.
 38916	
 38917	He took out of his mouth the pulpy quid and, lodging it between his
 38918	teeth, bit ferociously:
 38919	
 38920	--Khaan! Like that. And I seen maneaters in Peru that eats corpses and
 38921	the livers of horses. Look here. Here they are. A friend of mine sent
 38922	me.
 38923	
 38924	He fumbled out a picture postcard from his inside pocket which seemed to
 38925	be in its way a species of repository and pushed it along the table. The
 38926	printed matter on it stated: _Choza de Indios. Beni, Bolivia._
 38927	
 38928	All focussed their attention at the scene exhibited, a group of savage
 38929	women in striped loincloths, squatted, blinking, suckling, frowning,
 38930	sleeping amid a swarm of infants (there must have been quite a score of
 38931	them) outside some primitive shanties of osier.
 38932	
 38933	--Chews coca all day, the communicative tarpaulin added. Stomachs
 38934	like breadgraters. Cuts off their diddies when they can't bear no more
 38935	children.
 38936	
 38937	See them sitting there stark ballocknaked eating a dead horse's liver
 38938	raw.
 38939	
 38940	His postcard proved a centre of attraction for Messrs the greenhorns for
 38941	several minutes if not more.
 38942	
 38943	--Know how to keep them off? he inquired generally.
 38944	
 38945	Nobody volunteering a statement he winked, saying:
 38946	
 38947	--Glass. That boggles 'em. Glass.
 38948	
 38949	Mr Bloom, without evincing surprise, unostentatiously turned over the
 38950	card to peruse the partially obliterated address and postmark. It ran
 38951	as follows: _Tarjeta Postal, SeÃ±or A Boudin, Galeria Becche, Santiago,
 38952	Chile._ There was no message evidently, as he took particular notice.
 38953	Though not an implicit believer in the lurid story narrated (or the
 38954	eggsniping transaction for that matter despite William Tell and the
 38955	Lazarillo-Don Cesar de Bazan incident depicted in _Maritana_ on which
 38956	occasion the former's ball passed through the latter's hat) having
 38957	detected a discrepancy between his name (assuming he was the person
 38958	he represented himself to be and not sailing under false colours
 38959	after having boxed the compass on the strict q.t. somewhere) and
 38960	the fictitious addressee of the missive which made him nourish some
 38961	suspicions of our friend's _bona fides_ nevertheless it reminded him in
 38962	a way of a longcherished plan he meant to one day realise some Wednesday
 38963	or Saturday of travelling to London via long sea not to say that he had
 38964	ever travelled extensively to any great extent but he was at heart a
 38965	born adventurer though by a trick of fate he had consistently remained
 38966	a landlubber except you call going to Holyhead which was his longest.
 38967	Martin Cunningham frequently said he would work a pass through Egan but
 38968	some deuced hitch or other eternally cropped up with the net result that
 38969	the scheme fell through. But even suppose it did come to planking
 38970	down the needful and breaking Boyd's heart it was not so dear, purse
 38971	permitting, a few guineas at the outside considering the fare to
 38972	Mullingar where he figured on going was five and six, there and back.
 38973	The trip would benefit health on account of the bracing ozone and be in
 38974	every way thoroughly pleasurable, especially for a chap whose liver was
 38975	out of order, seeing the different places along the route, Plymouth,
 38976	Falmouth, Southampton and so on culminating in an instructive tour of
 38977	the sights of the great metropolis, the spectacle of our modern Babylon
 38978	where doubtless he would see the greatest improvement, tower, abbey,
 38979	wealth of Park lane to renew acquaintance with. Another thing just
 38980	struck him as a by no means bad notion was he might have a gaze around
 38981	on the spot to see about trying to make arrangements about a concert
 38982	tour of summer music embracing the most prominent pleasure resorts,
 38983	Margate with mixed bathing and firstrate hydros and spas, Eastbourne,
 38984	Scarborough, Margate and so on, beautiful Bournemouth, the Channel
 38985	islands and similar bijou spots, which might prove highly remunerative.
 38986	Not, of course, with a hole and corner scratch company or local ladies
 38987	on the job, witness Mrs C P M'Coy type lend me your valise and I'll post
 38988	you the ticket. No, something top notch, an all star Irish caste, the
 38989	Tweedy-Flower grand opera company with his own legal consort as leading
 38990	lady as a sort of counterblast to the Elster Grimes and Moody-Manners,
 38991	perfectly simple matter and he was quite sanguine of success, providing
 38992	puffs in the local papers could be managed by some fellow with a bit of
 38993	bounce who could pull the indispensable wires and thus combine business
 38994	with pleasure. But who? That was the rub. Also, without being actually
 38995	positive, it struck him a great field was to be opened up in the line
 38996	of opening up new routes to keep pace with the times _apropos_ of the
 38997	Fishguard-Rosslare route which, it was mooted, was once more on the
 38998	_tapis_ in the circumlocution departments with the usual quantity of red
 38999	tape and dillydallying of effete fogeydom and dunderheads generally. A
 39000	great opportunity there certainly was for push and enterprise to meet
 39001	the travelling needs of the public at large, the average man, i.e.
 39002	Brown, Robinson and Co.
 39003	
 39004	It was a subject of regret and absurd as well on the face of it and no
 39005	small blame to our vaunted society that the man in the street, when the
 39006	system really needed toning up, for the matter of a couple of paltry
 39007	pounds was debarred from seeing more of the world they lived in instead
 39008	of being always and ever cooped up since my old stick-in-the-mud took me
 39009	for a wife. After all, hang it, they had their eleven and more humdrum
 39010	months of it and merited a radical change of _venue_ after the grind
 39011	of city life in the summertime for choice when dame Nature is at her
 39012	spectacular best constituting nothing short of a new lease of life.
 39013	There were equally excellent opportunities for vacationists in the home
 39014	island, delightful sylvan spots for rejuvenation, offering a plethora
 39015	of attractions as well as a bracing tonic for the system in and around
 39016	Dublin and its picturesque environs even, Poulaphouca to which there was
 39017	a steamtram, but also farther away from the madding crowd in Wicklow,
 39018	rightly termed the garden of Ireland, an ideal neighbourhood for elderly
 39019	wheelmen so long as it didn't come down, and in the wilds of Donegal
 39020	where if report spoke true the _coup d'oeil_ was exceedingly grand
 39021	though the lastnamed locality was not easily getatable so that the
 39022	influx of visitors was not as yet all that it might be considering the
 39023	signal benefits to be derived from it while Howth with its historic
 39024	associations and otherwise, Silken Thomas, Grace O'Malley, George IV,
 39025	rhododendrons several hundred feet above sealevel was a favourite haunt
 39026	with all sorts and conditions of men especially in the spring when young
 39027	men's fancy, though it had its own toll of deaths by falling off the
 39028	cliffs by design or accidentally, usually, by the way, on their left
 39029	leg, it being only about three quarters of an hour's run from the
 39030	pillar. Because of course uptodate tourist travelling was as yet merely
 39031	in its infancy, so to speak, and the accommodation left much to be
 39032	desired. Interesting to fathom it seemed to him from a motive of
 39033	curiosity, pure and simple, was whether it was the traffic that created
 39034	the route or viceversa or the two sides in fact. He turned back the
 39035	other side of the card, picture, and passed it along to Stephen.
 39036	
 39037	--I seen a Chinese one time, related the doughty narrator, that had
 39038	little pills like putty and he put them in the water and they opened and
 39039	every pill was something different. One was a ship, another was a house,
 39040	another was a flower. Cooks rats in your soup, he appetisingly added,
 39041	the chinks does.
 39042	
 39043	Possibly perceiving an expression of dubiosity on their faces the
 39044	globetrotter went on, adhering to his adventures.
 39045	
 39046	--And I seen a man killed in Trieste by an Italian chap. Knife in his
 39047	back. Knife like that.
 39048	
 39049	Whilst speaking he produced a dangerouslooking claspknife quite in
 39050	keeping with his character and held it in the striking position.
 39051	
 39052	--In a knockingshop it was count of a tryon between two smugglers.
 39053	Fellow hid behind a door, come up behind him. Like that. _Prepare to
 39054	meet your God_, says he. Chuk! It went into his back up to the butt.
 39055	
 39056	His heavy glance drowsily roaming about kind of defied their further
 39057	questions even should they by any chance want to.
 39058	
 39059	--That's a good bit of steel, repeated he, examining his formidable
 39060	_stiletto_.
 39061	
 39062	After which harrowing _denouement_ sufficient to appal the stoutest he
 39063	snapped the blade to and stowed the weapon in question away as before in
 39064	his chamber of horrors, otherwise pocket.
 39065	
 39066	--They're great for the cold steel, somebody who was evidently quite in
 39067	the dark said for the benefit of them all. That was why they thought
 39068	the park murders of the invincibles was done by foreigners on account of
 39069	them using knives.
 39070	
 39071	At this remark passed obviously in the spirit of _where ignorance
 39072	is bliss_ Mr B. and Stephen, each in his own particular way, both
 39073	instinctively exchanged meaning glances, in a religious silence of the
 39074	strictly _entre nous_ variety however, towards where Skin-the-Goat,
 39075	_alias_ the keeper, not turning a hair, was drawing spurts of liquid
 39076	from his boiler affair. His inscrutable face which was really a work
 39077	of art, a perfect study in itself, beggaring description, conveyed
 39078	the impression that he didn't understand one jot of what was going on.
 39079	Funny, very!
 39080	
 39081	There ensued a somewhat lengthy pause. One man was reading in fits and
 39082	starts a stained by coffee evening journal, another the card with the
 39083	natives _choza de_, another the seaman's discharge. Mr Bloom, so far
 39084	as he was personally concerned, was just pondering in pensive mood. He
 39085	vividly recollected when the occurrence alluded to took place as well
 39086	as yesterday, roughly some score of years previously in the days of the
 39087	land troubles, when it took the civilised world by storm, figuratively
 39088	speaking, early in the eighties, eightyone to be correct, when he was
 39089	just turned fifteen.
 39090	
 39091	--Ay, boss, the sailor broke in. Give us back them papers.
 39092	
 39093	The request being complied with he clawed them up with a scrape.
 39094	
 39095	--Have you seen the rock of Gibraltar? Mr Bloom inquired.
 39096	
 39097	The sailor grimaced, chewing, in a way that might be read as yes, ay or
 39098	no.
 39099	
 39100	--Ah, you've touched there too, Mr Bloom said, Europa point, thinking he
 39101	had, in the hope that the rover might possibly by some reminiscences but
 39102	he failed to do so, simply letting spirt a jet of spew into the sawdust,
 39103	and shook his head with a sort of lazy scorn.
 39104	
 39105	--What year would that be about? Mr B interrogated. Can you recall the
 39106	boats?
 39107	
 39108	Our _soi-disant_ sailor munched heavily awhile hungrily before
 39109	answering:
 39110	
 39111	--I'm tired of all them rocks in the sea, he said, and boats and ships.
 39112	Salt junk all the time.
 39113	
 39114	Tired seemingly, he ceased. His questioner perceiving that he was not
 39115	likely to get a great deal of change out of such a wily old customer,
 39116	fell to woolgathering on the enormous dimensions of the water about the
 39117	globe, suffice it to say that, as a casual glance at the map revealed,
 39118	it covered fully three fourths of it and he fully realised accordingly
 39119	what it meant to rule the waves. On more than one occasion, a dozen
 39120	at the lowest, near the North Bull at Dollymount he had remarked a
 39121	superannuated old salt, evidently derelict, seated habitually near the
 39122	not particularly redolent sea on the wall, staring quite obliviously at
 39123	it and it at him, dreaming of fresh woods and pastures new as someone
 39124	somewhere sings. And it left him wondering why. Possibly he had tried to
 39125	find out the secret for himself, floundering up and down the antipodes
 39126	and all that sort of thing and over and under, well, not exactly under,
 39127	tempting the fates. And the odds were twenty to nil there was really no
 39128	secret about it at all. Nevertheless, without going into the _minutiae_
 39129	of the business, the eloquent fact remained that the sea was there in
 39130	all its glory and in the natural course of things somebody or other had
 39131	to sail on it and fly in the face of providence though it merely went
 39132	to show how people usually contrived to load that sort of onus on to the
 39133	other fellow like the hell idea and the lottery and insurance which were
 39134	run on identically the same lines so that for that very reason if no
 39135	other lifeboat Sunday was a highly laudable institution to which the
 39136	public at large, no matter where living inland or seaside, as the case
 39137	might be, having it brought home to them like that should extend its
 39138	gratitude also to the harbourmasters and coastguard service who had
 39139	to man the rigging and push off and out amid the elements whatever the
 39140	season when duty called _Ireland expects that every man_ and so on and
 39141	sometimes had a terrible time of it in the wintertime not forgetting the
 39142	Irish lights, Kish and others, liable to capsize at any moment, rounding
 39143	which he once with his daughter had experienced some remarkably choppy,
 39144	not to say stormy, weather.
 39145	
 39146	--There was a fellow sailed with me in the Rover, the old seadog,
 39147	himself a rover, proceeded, went ashore and took up a soft job as
 39148	gentleman's valet at six quid a month. Them are his trousers I've on
 39149	me and he gave me an oilskin and that jackknife. I'm game for that job,
 39150	shaving and brushup. I hate roaming about. There's my son now, Danny,
 39151	run off to sea and his mother got him took in a draper's in Cork where
 39152	he could be drawing easy money.
 39153	
 39154	--What age is he? queried one hearer who, by the way, seen from the
 39155	side, bore a distant resemblance to Henry Campbell, the townclerk, away
 39156	from the carking cares of office, unwashed of course and in a seedy
 39157	getup and a strong suspicion of nosepaint about the nasal appendage.
 39158	
 39159	--Why, the sailor answered with a slow puzzled utterance, my son, Danny?
 39160	He'd be about eighteen now, way I figure it.
 39161	
 39162	The Skibbereen father hereupon tore open his grey or unclean anyhow
 39163	shirt with his two hands and scratched away at his chest on which was to
 39164	be seen an image tattooed in blue Chinese ink intended to represent an
 39165	anchor.
 39166	
 39167	--There was lice in that bunk in Bridgwater, he remarked, sure as nuts.
 39168	I must get a wash tomorrow or next day. It's them black lads I objects
 39169	to. I hate those buggers. Suck your blood dry, they does.
 39170	
 39171	Seeing they were all looking at his chest he accommodatingly dragged
 39172	his shirt more open so that on top of the timehonoured symbol of the
 39173	mariner's hope and rest they had a full view of the figure 16 and a
 39174	young man's sideface looking frowningly rather.
 39175	
 39176	--Tattoo, the exhibitor explained. That was done when we were Iying
 39177	becalmed off Odessa in the Black Sea under Captain Dalton. Fellow, the
 39178	name of Antonio, done that. There he is himself, a Greek.
 39179	
 39180	--Did it hurt much doing it? one asked the sailor.
 39181	
 39182	That worthy, however, was busily engaged in collecting round the.
 39183	Someway in his. Squeezing or.
 39184	
 39185	--See here, he said, showing Antonio. There he is cursing the mate. And
 39186	there he is now, he added, the same fellow, pulling the skin with his
 39187	fingers, some special knack evidently, and he laughing at a yarn.
 39188	
 39189	And in point of fact the young man named Antonio's livid face did
 39190	actually look like forced smiling and the curious effect excited the
 39191	unreserved admiration of everybody including Skin-the-Goat, who this
 39192	time stretched over.
 39193	
 39194	--Ay, ay, sighed the sailor, looking down on his manly chest. He's gone
 39195	too. Ate by sharks after. Ay, ay.
 39196	
 39197	He let go of the skin so that the profile resumed the normal expression
 39198	of before.
 39199	
 39200	--Neat bit of work, one longshoreman said.
 39201	
 39202	--And what's the number for? loafer number two queried.
 39203	
 39204	--Eaten alive? a third asked the sailor.
 39205	
 39206	--Ay, ay, sighed again the latter personage, more cheerily this
 39207	time with some sort of a half smile for a brief duration only in the
 39208	direction of the questioner about the number. Ate. A Greek he was.
 39209	
 39210	And then he added with rather gallowsbird humour considering his alleged
 39211	end:
 39212	
 39213	_--As bad as old Antonio, For he left me on my ownio._
 39214	
 39215	The face of a streetwalker glazed and haggard under a black straw hat
 39216	peered askew round the door of the shelter palpably reconnoitring on
 39217	her own with the object of bringing more grist to her mill. Mr
 39218	Bloom, scarcely knowing which way to look, turned away on the moment
 39219	flusterfied but outwardly calm, and, picking up from the table the pink
 39220	sheet of the Abbey street organ which the jarvey, if such he was, had
 39221	laid aside, he picked it up and looked at the pink of the paper though
 39222	why pink. His reason for so doing was he recognised on the moment
 39223	round the door the same face he had caught a fleeting glimpse of that
 39224	afternoon on Ormond quay, the partially idiotic female, namely, of the
 39225	lane who knew the lady in the brown costume does be with you (Mrs B.)
 39226	and begged the chance of his washing. Also why washing which seemed
 39227	rather vague than not, your washing. Still candour compelled him to
 39228	admit he had washed his wife's undergarments when soiled in Holles
 39229	street and women would and did too a man's similar garments initialled
 39230	with Bewley and Draper's marking ink (hers were, that is) if they really
 39231	loved him, that is to say, love me, love my dirty shirt. Still just
 39232	then, being on tenterhooks, he desired the female's room more than her
 39233	company so it came as a genuine relief when the keeper made her a rude
 39234	sign to take herself off. Round the side of the Evening Telegraph he
 39235	just caught a fleeting glimpse of her face round the side of the door
 39236	with a kind of demented glassy grin showing that she was not exactly all
 39237	there, viewing with evident amusement the group of gazers round skipper
 39238	Murphy's nautical chest and then there was no more of her.
 39239	
 39240	--The gunboat, the keeper said.
 39241	
 39242	--It beats me, Mr Bloom confided to Stephen, medically I am speaking,
 39243	how a wretched creature like that from the Lock hospital reeking with
 39244	disease can be barefaced enough to solicit or how any man in his sober
 39245	senses, if he values his health in the least. Unfortunate creature! Of
 39246	course I suppose some man is ultimately responsible for her condition.
 39247	Still no matter what the cause is from...
 39248	
 39249	Stephen had not noticed her and shrugged his shoulders, merely
 39250	remarking:
 39251	
 39252	--In this country people sell much more than she ever had and do a
 39253	roaring trade. Fear not them that sell the body but have not power to
 39254	buy the soul. She is a bad merchant. She buys dear and sells cheap.
 39255	
 39256	The elder man, though not by any manner of means an old maid or a prude,
 39257	said it was nothing short of a crying scandal that ought to be put a
 39258	stop to _instanter_ to say that women of that stamp (quite apart from
 39259	any oldmaidish squeamishness on the subject), a necessary evil, w ere
 39260	not licensed and medically inspected by the proper authorities, a thing,
 39261	he could truthfully state, he, as a _paterfamilias_, was a stalwart
 39262	advocate of from the very first start. Whoever embarked on a policy of
 39263	the sort, he said, and ventilated the matter thoroughly would confer a
 39264	lasting boon on everybody concerned.
 39265	
 39266	--You as a good catholic, he observed, talking of body and soul, believe
 39267	in the soul. Or do you mean the intelligence, the brainpower as such,
 39268	as distinct from any outside object, the table, let us say, that cup. I
 39269	believe in that myself because it has been explained by competent men as
 39270	the convolutions of the grey matter. Otherwise we would never have such
 39271	inventions as X rays, for instance. Do you?
 39272	
 39273	Thus cornered, Stephen had to make a superhuman effort of memory to try
 39274	and concentrate and remember before he could say:
 39275	
 39276	--They tell me on the best authority it is a simple substance and
 39277	therefore incorruptible. It would be immortal, I understand, but for the
 39278	possibility of its annihilation by its First Cause Who, from all I
 39279	can hear, is quite capable of adding that to the number of His other
 39280	practical jokes, _corruptio per se_ and _corruptio per accidens_ both
 39281	being excluded by court etiquette.
 39282	
 39283	Mr Bloom thoroughly acquiesced in the general gist of this though the
 39284	mystical finesse involved was a bit out of his sublunary depth still
 39285	he felt bound to enter a demurrer on the head of simple, promptly
 39286	rejoining:
 39287	
 39288	--Simple? I shouldn't think that is the proper word. Of course, I grant
 39289	you, to concede a point, you do knock across a simple soul once in a
 39290	blue moon. But what I am anxious to arrive at is it is one thing for
 39291	instance to invent those rays Rontgen did or the telescope like Edison,
 39292	though I believe it was before his time Galileo was the man, I mean,
 39293	and the same applies to the laws, for example, of a farreaching natural
 39294	phenomenon such as electricity but it's a horse of quite another colour
 39295	to say you believe in the existence of a supernatural God.
 39296	
 39297	--O that, Stephen expostulated, has been proved conclusively by several
 39298	of the bestknown passages in Holy Writ, apart from circumstantial
 39299	evidence.
 39300	
 39301	On this knotty point however the views of the pair, poles apart as they
 39302	were both in schooling and everything else with the marked difference in
 39303	their respective ages, clashed.
 39304	
 39305	--Has been? the more experienced of the two objected, sticking to his
 39306	original point with a smile of unbelief. I'm not so sure about that.
 39307	That's a matter for everyman's opinion and, without dragging in the
 39308	sectarian side of the business, I beg to differ with you _in toto_
 39309	there. My belief is, to tell you the candid truth, that those bits were
 39310	genuine forgeries all of them put in by monks most probably or it's the
 39311	big question of our national poet over again, who precisely wrote them
 39312	like _Hamlet_ and Bacon, as, you who know your Shakespeare infinitely
 39313	better than I, of course I needn't tell you. Can't you drink that
 39314	coffee, by the way? Let me stir it. And take a piece of that bun. It's
 39315	like one of our skipper's bricks disguised. Still no-one can give what
 39316	he hasn't got. Try a bit.
 39317	
 39318	--Couldn't, Stephen contrived to get out, his mental organs for the
 39319	moment refusing to dictate further.
 39320	
 39321	Faultfinding being a proverbially bad hat Mr Bloom thought well to stir
 39322	or try to the clotted sugar from the bottom and reflected with something
 39323	approaching acrimony on the Coffee Palace and its temperance (and
 39324	lucrative) work. To be sure it was a legitimate object and beyond yea or
 39325	nay did a world of good, shelters such as the present one they were in
 39326	run on teetotal lines for vagrants at night, concerts, dramatic evenings
 39327	and useful lectures (admittance free) by qualified men for the lower
 39328	orders. On the other hand he had a distinct and painful recollection
 39329	they paid his wife, Madam Marion Tweedy who had been prominently
 39330	associated with it at one time, a very modest remuneration indeed for
 39331	her pianoplaying. The idea, he was strongly inclined to believe, was
 39332	to do good and net a profit, there being no competition to speak
 39333	of. Sulphate of copper poison SO4 or something in some dried peas he
 39334	remembered reading of in a cheap eatinghouse somewhere but he couldn't
 39335	remember when it was or where. Anyhow inspection, medical inspection,
 39336	of all eatables seemed to him more than ever necessary which possibly
 39337	accounted for the vogue of Dr Tibble's Vi-Cocoa on account of the
 39338	medical analysis involved.
 39339	
 39340	--Have a shot at it now, he ventured to say of the coffee after being
 39341	stirred.
 39342	
 39343	Thus prevailed on to at any rate taste it Stephen lifted the heavy mug
 39344	from the brown puddle it clopped out of when taken up by the handle and
 39345	took a sip of the offending beverage.
 39346	
 39347	--Still it's solid food, his good genius urged, I'm a stickler for solid
 39348	food, his one and only reason being not gormandising in the least but
 39349	regular meals as the _sine qua non_ for any kind of proper work, mental
 39350	or manual. You ought to eat more solid food. You would feel a different
 39351	man.
 39352	
 39353	--Liquids I can eat, Stephen said. But O, oblige me by taking away that
 39354	knife. I can't look at the point of it. It reminds me of Roman history.
 39355	
 39356	Mr Bloom promptly did as suggested and removed the incriminated article,
 39357	a blunt hornhandled ordinary knife with nothing particularly Roman or
 39358	antique about it to the lay eye, observing that the point was the least
 39359	conspicuous point about it.
 39360	
 39361	--Our mutual friend's stories are like himself, Mr Bloom _apropos_ of
 39362	knives remarked to his _confidante sotto voce_. Do you think they are
 39363	genuine? He could spin those yarns for hours on end all night long and
 39364	lie like old boots. Look at him.
 39365	
 39366	Yet still though his eyes were thick with sleep and sea air life was
 39367	full of a host of things and coincidences of a terrible nature and it
 39368	was quite within the bounds of possibility that it was not an
 39369	entire fabrication though at first blush there was not much inherent
 39370	probability in all the spoof he got off his chest being strictly
 39371	accurate gospel.
 39372	
 39373	He had been meantime taking stock of the individual in front of him and
 39374	Sherlockholmesing him up ever since he clapped eyes on him. Though a
 39375	wellpreserved man of no little stamina, if a trifle prone to baldness,
 39376	there was something spurious in the cut of his jib that suggested a jail
 39377	delivery and it required no violent stretch of imagination to associate
 39378	such a weirdlooking specimen with the oakum and treadmill fraternity. He
 39379	might even have done for his man supposing it was his own case he told,
 39380	as people often did about others, namely, that he killed him himself
 39381	and had served his four or five goodlooking years in durance vile to say
 39382	nothing of the Antonio personage (no relation to the dramatic personage
 39383	of identical name who sprang from the pen of our national poet) who
 39384	expiated his crimes in the melodramatic manner above described. On the
 39385	other hand he might be only bluffing, a pardonable weakness because
 39386	meeting unmistakable mugs, Dublin residents, like those jarvies waiting
 39387	news from abroad would tempt any ancient mariner who sailed the ocean
 39388	seas to draw the long bow about the schooner _Hesperus_ and etcetera.
 39389	And when all was said and done the lies a fellow told about himself
 39390	couldn't probably hold a proverbial candle to the wholesale whoppers
 39391	other fellows coined about him.
 39392	
 39393	--Mind you, I'm not saying that it's all a pure invention, he resumed.
 39394	Analogous scenes are occasionally, if not often, met with. Giants,
 39395	though that is rather a far cry, you see once in a way, Marcella the
 39396	midget queen. In those waxworks in Henry street I myself saw some
 39397	Aztecs, as they are called, sitting bowlegged, they couldn't straighten
 39398	their legs if you paid them because the muscles here, you see, he
 39399	proceeded, indicating on his companion the brief outline of the sinews
 39400	or whatever you like to call them behind the right knee, were utterly
 39401	powerless from sitting that way so long cramped up, being adored as
 39402	gods. There's an example again of simple souls.
 39403	
 39404	However reverting to friend Sinbad and his horrifying adventures (who
 39405	reminded him a bit of Ludwig, _alias_ Ledwidge, when he occupied
 39406	the boards of the Gaiety when Michael Gunn was identified with the
 39407	management in the _Flying Dutchman_, a stupendous success, and his host
 39408	of admirers came in large numbers, everyone simply flocking to hear him
 39409	though ships of any sort, phantom or the reverse, on the stage usually
 39410	fell a bit flat as also did trains) there was nothing intrinsically
 39411	incompatible about it, he conceded. On the contrary that stab in the
 39412	back touch was quite in keeping with those italianos though candidly he
 39413	was none the less free to admit those icecreamers and friers in the fish
 39414	way not to mention the chip potato variety and so forth over in little
 39415	Italy there near the Coombe were sober thrifty hardworking fellows
 39416	except perhaps a bit too given to pothunting the harmless necessary
 39417	animal of the feline persuasion of others at night so as to have a good
 39418	old succulent tuckin with garlic _de rigueur_ off him or her next day on
 39419	the quiet and, he added, on the cheap.
 39420	
 39421	--Spaniards, for instance, he continued, passionate temperaments like
 39422	that, impetuous as Old Nick, are given to taking the law into their own
 39423	hands and give you your quietus doublequick with those poignards they
 39424	carry in the abdomen. It comes from the great heat, climate generally.
 39425	My wife is, so to speak, Spanish, half that is. Point of fact she could
 39426	actually claim Spanish nationality if she wanted, having been born in
 39427	(technically) Spain, i.e. Gibraltar. She has the Spanish type. Quite
 39428	dark, regular brunette, black. I for one certainly believe climate
 39429	accounts for character. That's why I asked you if you wrote your poetry
 39430	in Italian.
 39431	
 39432	--The temperaments at the door, Stephen interposed with, were very
 39433	passionate about ten shillings. _Roberto ruba roba sua_.
 39434	
 39435	--Quite so, Mr Bloom dittoed.
 39436	
 39437	--Then, Stephen said staring and rambling on to himself or some unknown
 39438	listener somewhere, we have the impetuosity of Dante and the isosceles
 39439	triangle miss Portinari he fell in love with and Leonardo and san
 39440	Tommaso Mastino.
 39441	
 39442	--It's in the blood, Mr Bloom acceded at once. All are washed in the
 39443	blood of the sun. Coincidence I just happened to be in the Kildare
 39444	street museum 890 today, shortly prior to our meeting if I can so call
 39445	it, and I was just looking at those antique statues there. The splendid
 39446	proportions of hips, bosom. You simply don't knock against those kind of
 39447	women here. An exception here and there. Handsome yes, pretty in a way
 39448	you find but what I'm talking about is the female form. Besides they
 39449	have so little taste in dress, most of them, which greatly enhances a
 39450	woman's natural beauty, no matter what you say. Rumpled stockings, it
 39451	may be, possibly is, a foible of mine but still it's a thing I simply
 39452	hate to see.
 39453	
 39454	Interest, however, was starting to flag somewhat all round and then the
 39455	others got on to talking about accidents at sea, ships lost in a fog,
 39456	goo collisions with icebergs, all that sort of thing. Shipahoy of course
 39457	had his own say to say. He had doubled the cape a few odd times and
 39458	weathered a monsoon, a kind of wind, in the China seas and through all
 39459	those perils of the deep there was one thing, he declared, stood to him
 39460	or words to that effect, a pious medal he had that saved him.
 39461	
 39462	So then after that they drifted on to the wreck off Daunt's rock, wreck
 39463	of that illfated Norwegian barque nobody could think of her name for
 39464	the moment till the jarvey who had really quite a look of Henry Campbell
 39465	remembered it _Palme_ on Booterstown strand. That was the talk of the
 39466	town that year (Albert William Quill wrote a fine piece of original
 39467	verse of 910 distinctive merit on the topic for the Irish _Times_),
 39468	breakers running over her and crowds and crowds on the shore in
 39469	commotion petrified with horror. Then someone said something about the
 39470	case of the s. s. _Lady Cairns_ of Swansea run into by the _Mona_ which
 39471	was on an opposite tack in rather muggyish weather and lost with all
 39472	hands on deck. No aid was given. Her master, the _Mona's_, said he
 39473	was afraid his collision bulkhead would give way. She had no water, it
 39474	appears, in her hold.
 39475	
 39476	At this stage an incident happened. It having become necessary for him
 39477	to unfurl a reef the sailor vacated his seat.
 39478	
 39479	--Let me cross your bows mate, he said to his neighbour who was just
 39480	gently dropping off into a peaceful doze.
 39481	
 39482	He made tracks heavily, slowly with a dumpy sort of a gait to the door,
 39483	stepped heavily down the one step there was out of the shelter and bore
 39484	due left. While he was in the act of getting his bearings Mr Bloom who
 39485	noticed when he stood up that he had two flasks of presumably ship's
 39486	rum sticking one out of each pocket for the private consumption of his
 39487	burning interior, saw him produce a bottle and uncork it or unscrew and,
 39488	applying its nozz1e to his lips, take a good old delectable swig out of
 39489	it with a gurgling noise. The irrepressible Bloom, who also had a
 39490	shrewd suspicion that the old stager went out on a manoeuvre after the
 39491	counterattraction in the shape of a female who however had disappeared
 39492	to all intents and purposes, could by straining just perceive him, when
 39493	duly refreshed by his rum puncheon exploit, gaping up at the piers and
 39494	girders of the Loop line rather out of his depth as of course it was all
 39495	radically altered since his last visit and greatly improved. Some person
 39496	or persons invisible directed him to the male urinal erected by the
