 40683	railway carriages of suburban lines. In 1888 frequently with major Brian
 40684	Tweedy and his daughter Miss Marion Tweedy, together and separately on
 40685	the lounge in Matthew Dillon's house in Roundtown. Once in 1892 and once
 40686	in 1893 with Julius (Juda) Mastiansky, on both occasions in the parlour
 40687	of his (Bloom's) house in Lombard street, west.
 40688	
 40689	
 40690	What reflection concerning the irregular sequence of dates 1884, 1885,
 40691	1886, 1888, 1892, 1893, 1904 did Bloom make before their arrival at
 40692	their destination?
 40693	
 40694	He reflected that the progressive extension of the field of individual
 40695	development and experience was regressively accompanied by a restriction
 40696	of the converse domain of interindividual relations.
 40697	
 40698	
 40699	As in what ways?
 40700	
 40701	From inexistence to existence he came to many and was as one received:
 40702	existence with existence he was with any as any with any: from existence
 40703	to nonexistence gone he would be by all as none perceived.
 40704	
 40705	What act did Bloom make on their arrival at their destination?
 40706	
 40707	At the housesteps of the 4th Of the equidifferent uneven numbers, number
 40708	7 Eccles street, he inserted his hand mechanically into the back pocket
 40709	of his trousers to obtain his latchkey.
 40710	
 40711	
 40712	Was it there?
 40713	
 40714	It was in the corresponding pocket of the trousers which he had worn on
 40715	the day but one preceding.
 40716	
 40717	
 40718	Why was he doubly irritated?
 40719	
 40720	Because he had forgotten and because he remembered that he had reminded
 40721	himself twice not to forget.
 40722	
 40723	
 40724	What were then the alternatives before the, premeditatedly
 40725	(respectively) and inadvertently, keyless couple?
 40726	
 40727	To enter or not to enter. To knock or not to knock.
 40728	
 40729	
 40730	Bloom's decision?
 40731	
 40732	A stratagem. Resting his feet on the dwarf wall, he climbed over the
 40733	area railings, compressed his hat on his head, grasped two points at
 40734	the lower union of rails and stiles, lowered his body gradually by its
 40735	length of five feet nine inches and a half to within two feet ten inches
 40736	of the area pavement and allowed his body to move freely in space by
 40737	separating himself from the railings and crouching in preparation for
 40738	the impact of the fall.
 40739	
 40740	
 40741	Did he fall?
 40742	
 40743	By his body's known weight of eleven stone and four pounds in
 40744	avoirdupois measure, as certified by the graduated machine for
 40745	periodical selfweighing in the premises of Francis Froedman,
 40746	pharmaceutical chemist of 19 Frederick street, north, on the last feast
 40747	of the Ascension, to wit, the twelfth day of May of the bissextile year
 40748	one thousand nine hundred and four of the christian era (jewish era five
 40749	thousand six hundred and sixtyfour, mohammadan era one thousand three
 40750	hundred and twentytwo), golden number 5, epact 13, solar cycle 9,
 40751	dominical letters C B, Roman indiction 2, Julian period 6617, MCMIV.
 40752	
 40753	
 40754	Did he rise uninjured by concussion?
 40755	
 40756	Regaining new stable equilibrium he rose uninjured though concussed by
 40757	the impact, raised the latch of the area door by the exertion of force
 40758	at its freely moving flange and by leverage of the first kind applied
 40759	at its fulcrum, gained retarded access to the kitchen through the
 40760	subadjacent scullery, ignited a lucifer match by friction, set free
 40761	inflammable coal gas by turningon the ventcock, lit a high flame which,
 40762	by regulating, he reduced to quiescent candescence and lit finally a
 40763	portable candle.
 40764	
 40765	
 40766	What discrete succession of images did Stephen meanwhile perceive?
 40767	
 40768	Reclined against the area railings he perceived through the transparent
 40769	kitchen panes a man regulating a gasflame of 14 CP, a man lighting a
 40770	candle of 1 CP, a man removing in turn each of his two boots, a man
 40771	leaving the kitchen holding a candle.
 40772	
 40773	
 40774	Did the man reappear elsewhere?
 40775	
 40776	After a lapse of four minutes the glimmer of his candle was discernible
 40777	through the semitransparent semicircular glass fanlight over the
 40778	halldoor. The halldoor turned gradually on its hinges. In the open space
 40779	of the doorway the man reappeared without his hat, with his candle.
 40780	
 40781	
 40782	Did Stephen obey his sign?
 40783	
 40784	Yes, entering softly, he helped to close and chain the door and followed
 40785	softly along the hallway the man's back and listed feet and lighted
 40786	candle past a lighted crevice of doorway on the left and carefully down
 40787	a turning staircase of more than five steps into the kitchen of Bloom's
 40788	house.
 40789	
 40790	
 40791	What did Bloom do?
 40792	
 40793	He extinguished the candle by a sharp expiration of breath upon its
 40794	flame, drew two spoonseat deal chairs to the hearthstone, one for
 40795	Stephen with its back to the area window, the other for himself when
 40796	necessary, knelt on one knee, composed in the grate a pyre of crosslaid
 40797	resintipped sticks and various coloured papers and irregular polygons
 40798	of best Abram coal at twentyone shillings a ton from the yard of Messrs
 40799	Flower and M'Donald of 14 D'Olier street, kindled it at three projecting
 40800	points of paper with one ignited lucifer match, thereby releasing
 40801	the potential energy contained in the fuel by allowing its carbon and
 40802	hydrogen elements to enter into free union with the oxygen of the air.
 40803	
 40804	
 40805	Of what similar apparitions did Stephen think?
 40806	
 40807	Of others elsewhere in other times who, kneeling on one knee or on two,
 40808	had kindled fires for him, of Brother Michael in the infirmary of the
 40809	college of the Society of Jesus at Clongowes Wood, Sallins, in the
 40810	county of Kildare: of his father, Simon Dedalus, in an unfurnished room
 40811	of his first residence in Dublin, number thirteen Fitzgibbon street:
 40812	of his godmother Miss Kate Morkan in the house of her dying sister Miss
 40813	Julia Morkan at 15 Usher's Island: of his aunt Sara, wife of Richie
 40814	(Richard) Goulding, in the kitchen of their lodgings at 62 Clanbrassil
 40815	street: of his mother Mary, wife of Simon Dedalus, in the kitchen of
 40816	number twelve North Richmond street on the morning of the feast of
 40817	Saint Francis Xavier 1898: of the dean of studies, Father Butt, in the
 40818	physics' theatre of university College, 16 Stephen's Green, north: of
 40819	his sister Dilly (Delia) in his father's house in Cabra.
 40820	
 40821	
 40822	What did Stephen see on raising his gaze to the height of a yard from
 40823	the fire towards the opposite wall?
 40824	
 40825	Under a row of five coiled spring housebells a curvilinear rope,
 40826	stretched between two holdfasts athwart across the recess beside the
 40827	chimney pier, from which hung four smallsized square handkerchiefs
 40828	folded unattached consecutively in adjacent rectangles and one pair of
 40829	ladies' grey hose with Lisle suspender tops and feet in their habitual
 40830	position clamped by three erect wooden pegs two at their outer
 40831	extremities and the third at their point of junction.
 40832	
 40833	
 40834	What did Bloom see on the range?
 40835	
 40836	On the right (smaller) hob a blue enamelled saucepan: on the left
 40837	(larger) hob a black iron kettle.
 40838	
 40839	
 40840	What did Bloom do at the range?
 40841	
 40842	He removed the saucepan to the left hob, rose and carried the iron
 40843	kettle to the sink in order to tap the current by turning the faucet to
 40844	let it flow.
 40845	
 40846	
 40847	Did it flow?
 40848	
 40849	Yes. From Roundwood reservoir in county Wicklow of a cubic capacity of
 40850	2400 million gallons, percolating through a subterranean aqueduct of
 40851	filter mains of single and double pipeage constructed at an initial
 40852	plant cost of 5 pounds per linear yard by way of the Dargle, Rathdown,
 40853	Glen of the Downs and Callowhill to the 26 acre reservoir at Stillorgan,
 40854	a distance of 22 statute miles, and thence, through a system of
 40855	relieving tanks, by a gradient of 250 feet to the city boundary at
 40856	Eustace bridge, upper Leeson street, though from prolonged summer drouth
 40857	and daily supply of 12 1/2 million gallons the water had fallen below
 40858	the sill of the overflow weir for which reason the borough surveyor and
 40859	waterworks engineer, Mr Spencer Harty, C. E., on the instructions of
 40860	the waterworks committee had prohibited the use of municipal water for
 40861	purposes other than those of consumption (envisaging the possibility of
 40862	recourse being had to the impotable water of the Grand and Royal canals
 40863	as in 1893) particularly as the South Dublin Guardians, notwithstanding
 40864	their ration of 15 gallons per day per pauper supplied through a 6 inch
 40865	meter, had been convicted of a wastage of 20,000 gallons per night by
 40866	a reading of their meter on the affirmation of the law agent of
 40867	the corporation, Mr Ignatius Rice, solicitor, thereby acting to the
 40868	detriment of another section of the public, selfsupporting taxpayers,
 40869	solvent, sound.
 40870	
 40871	What in water did Bloom, waterlover, drawer of water, watercarrier,
 40872	returning to the range, admire?
 40873	
 40874	Its universality: its democratic equality and constancy to its nature
 40875	in seeking its own level: its vastness in the ocean of Mercator's
 40876	projection: its unplumbed profundity in the Sundam trench of the Pacific
 40877	exceeding 8000 fathoms: the restlessness of its waves and surface
 40878	particles visiting in turn all points of its seaboard: the independence
 40879	of its units: the variability of states of sea: its hydrostatic
 40880	quiescence in calm: its hydrokinetic turgidity in neap and spring tides:
 40881	its subsidence after devastation: its sterility in the circumpolar
 40882	icecaps, arctic and antarctic: its climatic and commercial significance:
 40883	its preponderance of 3 to 1 over the dry land of the globe: its
 40884	indisputable hegemony extending in square leagues over all the region
 40885	below the subequatorial tropic of Capricorn: the multisecular stability
 40886	of its primeval basin: its luteofulvous bed: its capacity to dissolve
 40887	and hold in solution all soluble substances including millions of
 40888	tons of the most precious metals: its slow erosions of peninsulas and
 40889	islands, its persistent formation of homothetic islands, peninsulas
 40890	and downwardtending promontories: its alluvial deposits: its weight and
 40891	volume and density: its imperturbability in lagoons and highland tarns:
 40892	its gradation of colours in the torrid and temperate and frigid zones:
 40893	its vehicular ramifications in continental lakecontained streams and
 40894	confluent oceanflowing rivers with their tributaries and transoceanic
 40895	currents, gulfstream, north and south equatorial courses: its violence
 40896	in seaquakes, waterspouts, Artesian wells, eruptions, torrents, eddies,
 40897	freshets, spates, groundswells, watersheds, waterpartings, geysers,
 40898	cataracts, whirlpools, maelstroms, inundations, deluges, cloudbursts:
 40899	its vast circumterrestrial ahorizontal curve: its secrecy in springs and
 40900	latent humidity, revealed by rhabdomantic or hygrometric instruments
 40901	and exemplified by the well by the hole in the wall at Ashtown
 40902	gate, saturation of air, distillation of dew: the simplicity of its
 40903	composition, two constituent parts of hydrogen with one constituent part
 40904	of oxygen: its healing virtues: its buoyancy in the waters of the Dead
 40905	Sea: its persevering penetrativeness in runnels, gullies, inadequate
 40906	dams, leaks on shipboard: its properties for cleansing, quenching thirst
 40907	and fire, nourishing vegetation: its infallibility as paradigm and
 40908	paragon: its metamorphoses as vapour, mist, cloud, rain, sleet, snow,
 40909	hail: its strength in rigid hydrants: its variety of forms in loughs
 40910	and bays and gulfs and bights and guts and lagoons and atolls and
 40911	archipelagos and sounds and fjords and minches and tidal estuaries and
 40912	arms of sea: its solidity in glaciers, icebergs, icefloes: its docility
 40913	in working hydraulic millwheels, turbines, dynamos, electric power
 40914	stations, bleachworks, tanneries, scutchmills: its utility in canals,
 40915	rivers, if navigable, floating and graving docks: its potentiality
 40916	derivable from harnessed tides or watercourses falling from level
 40917	to level: its submarine fauna and flora (anacoustic, photophobe),
 40918	numerically, if not literally, the inhabitants of the globe: its
 40919	ubiquity as constituting 90 percent of the human body: the noxiousness
 40920	of its effluvia in lacustrine marshes, pestilential fens, faded
 40921	flowerwater, stagnant pools in the waning moon.
 40922	
 40923	
 40924	Having set the halffilled kettle on the now burning coals, why did he
 40925	return to the stillflowing tap?
 40926	
 40927	To wash his soiled hands with a partially consumed tablet of
 40928	Barrington's lemonflavoured soap, to which paper still adhered, (bought
 40929	thirteen hours previously for fourpence and still unpaid for), in fresh
 40930	cold neverchanging everchanging water and dry them, face and hands, in a
 40931	long redbordered holland cloth passed over a wooden revolving roller.
 40932	
 40933	
 40934	What reason did Stephen give for declining Bloom's offer?
 40935	
 40936	That he was hydrophobe, hating partial contact by immersion or total by
 40937	submersion in cold water, (his last bath having taken place in the month
 40938	of October of the preceding year), disliking the aqueous substances of
 40939	glass and crystal, distrusting aquacities of thought and language.
 40940	
 40941	
 40942	What impeded Bloom from giving Stephen counsels of hygiene and
 40943	prophylactic to which should be added suggestions concerning a
 40944	preliminary wetting of the head and contraction of the muscles with
 40945	rapid splashing of the face and neck and thoracic and epigastric region
 40946	in case of sea or river bathing, the parts of the human anatomy most
 40947	sensitive to cold being the nape, stomach and thenar or sole of foot?
 40948	
 40949	The incompatibility of aquacity with the erratic originality of genius.
 40950	
 40951	
 40952	What additional didactic counsels did he similarly repress?
 40953	
 40954	Dietary: concerning the respective percentage of protein and caloric
 40955	energy in bacon, salt ling and butter, the absence of the former in the
 40956	lastnamed and the abundance of the latter in the firstnamed.
 40957	
 40958	
 40959	Which seemed to the host to be the predominant qualities of his guest?
 40960	
 40961	Confidence in himself, an equal and opposite power of abandonment and
 40962	recuperation.
 40963	
 40964	
 40965	What concomitant phenomenon took place in the vessel of liquid by the
 40966	agency of fire?
 40967	
 40968	The phenomenon of ebullition. Fanned by a constant updraught of
 40969	ventilation between the kitchen and the chimneyflue, ignition was
 40970	communicated from the faggots of precombustible fuel to polyhedral
 40971	masses of bituminous coal, containing in compressed mineral form the
 40972	foliated fossilised decidua of primeval forests which had in turn
 40973	derived their vegetative existence from the sun, primal source of heat
 40974	(radiant), transmitted through omnipresent luminiferous diathermanous
 40975	ether. Heat (convected), a mode of motion developed by such
 40976	combustion, was constantly and increasingly conveyed from the source
 40977	of calorification to the liquid contained in the vessel, being radiated
 40978	through the uneven unpolished dark surface of the metal iron, in part
 40979	reflected, in part absorbed, in part transmitted, gradually raising
 40980	the temperature of the water from normal to boiling point, a rise in
 40981	temperature expressible as the result of an expenditure of 72 thermal
 40982	units needed to raise 1 pound of water from 50 degrees to 212 degrees
 40983	Fahrenheit.
 40984	
 40985	
 40986	What announced the accomplishment of this rise in temperature?
 40987	
 40988	A double falciform ejection of water vapour from under the kettlelid at
 40989	both sides simultaneously.
 40990	
 40991	
 40992	For what personal purpose could Bloom have applied the water so boiled?
 40993	
 40994	To shave himself.
 40995	
 40996	
 40997	What advantages attended shaving by night?
 40998	
 40999	A softer beard: a softer brush if intentionally allowed to remain from
 41000	shave to shave in its agglutinated lather: a softer skin if unexpectedly
 41001	encountering female acquaintances in remote places at incustomary hours:
 41002	quiet reflections upon the course of the day: a cleaner sensation when
 41003	awaking after a fresher sleep since matutinal noises, premonitions and
 41004	perturbations, a clattered milkcan, a postman's double knock, a paper
 41005	read, reread while lathering, relathering the same spot, a shock, a
 41006	shoot, with thought of aught he sought though fraught with nought might
 41007	cause a faster rate of shaving and a nick on which incision plaster with
 41008	precision cut and humected and applied adhered: which was to be done.
 41009	
 41010	
 41011	Why did absence of light disturb him less than presence of noise?
 41012	
 41013	Because of the surety of the sense of touch in his firm full masculine
 41014	feminine passive active hand.
 41015	
 41016	
 41017	What quality did it (his hand) possess but with what counteracting
 41018	influence?
 41019	
 41020	The operative surgical quality but that he was reluctant to shed human
 41021	blood even when the end justified the means, preferring, in their
 41022	natural order, heliotherapy, psychophysicotherapeutics, osteopathic
 41023	surgery.
 41024	
 41025	
 41026	What lay under exposure on the lower, middle and upper shelves of the
 41027	kitchen dresser, opened by Bloom?
 41028	
 41029	On the lower shelf five vertical breakfast plates, six horizontal
 41030	breakfast saucers on which rested inverted breakfast cups, a
 41031	moustachecup, uninverted, and saucer of Crown Derby, four white
 41032	goldrimmed eggcups, an open shammy purse displaying coins, mostly
 41033	copper, and a phial of aromatic (violet) comfits. On the middle shelf
 41034	a chipped eggcup containing pepper, a drum of table salt, four
 41035	conglomerated black olives in oleaginous paper, an empty pot of
 41036	Plumtree's potted meat, an oval wicker basket bedded with fibre and
 41037	containing one Jersey pear, a halfempty bottle of William Gilbey and
 41038	Co's white invalid port, half disrobed of its swathe of coralpink tissue
 41039	paper, a packet of Epps's soluble cocoa, five ounces of Anne Lynch's
 41040	choice tea at 2/- per lb in a crinkled leadpaper bag, a cylindrical
 41041	canister containing the best crystallised lump sugar, two onions, one,
 41042	the larger, Spanish, entire, the other, smaller, Irish, bisected with
 41043	augmented surface and more redolent, a jar of Irish Model Dairy's cream,
 41044	a jug of brown crockery containing a naggin and a quarter of soured
 41045	adulterated milk, converted by heat into water, acidulous serum and
 41046	semisolidified curds, which added to the quantity subtracted for Mr
 41047	Bloom's and Mrs Fleming's breakfasts, made one imperial pint, the total
 41048	quantity originally delivered, two cloves, a halfpenny and a small dish
 41049	containing a slice of fresh ribsteak. On the upper shelf a battery of
 41050	jamjars (empty) of various sizes and proveniences.
 41051	
 41052	
 41053	What attracted his attention lying on the apron of the dresser?
 41054	
 41055	Four polygonal fragments of two lacerated scarlet betting tickets,
 41056	numbered 8 87, 88 6.
 41057	
 41058	
 41059	What reminiscences temporarily corrugated his brow?
 41060	
 41061	Reminiscences of coincidences, truth stranger than fiction,
 41062	preindicative of the result of the Gold Cup flat handicap, the official
 41063	and definitive result of which he had read in the _Evening Telegraph_,
 41064	late pink edition, in the cabman's shelter, at Butt bridge.
 41065	
 41066	
 41067	Where had previous intimations of the result, effected or projected,
 41068	been received by him?
 41069	
 41070	In Bernard Kiernan's licensed premises 8, 9 and 10 little Britain
 41071	street: in David Byrne's licensed premises, 14 Duke street: in O'Connell
 41072	street lower, outside Graham Lemon's when a dark man had placed in
 41073	his hand a throwaway (subsequently thrown away), advertising Elijah,
 41074	restorer of the church in Zion: in Lincoln place outside the premises of
 41075	F. W. Sweny and Co (Limited), dispensing chemists, when, when Frederick
 41076	M. (Bantam) Lyons had rapidly and successively requested, perused and
 41077	restituted the copy of the current issue of the _Freeman's Journal and
 41078	National Press_ which he had been about to throw away (subsequently
 41079	thrown away), he had proceeded towards the oriental edifice of
 41080	the Turkish and Warm Baths, 11 Leinster street, with the light of
 41081	inspiration shining in his countenance and bearing in his arms the
 41082	secret of the race, graven in the language of prediction.
 41083	
 41084	What qualifying considerations allayed his perturbations?
 41085	
 41086	The difficulties of interpretation since the significance of any event
 41087	followed its occurrence as variably as the acoustic report followed the
 41088	electrical discharge and of counterestimating against an actual loss
 41089	by failure to interpret the total sum of possible losses proceeding
 41090	originally from a successful interpretation.
 41091	
 41092	
 41093	His mood?
 41094	
 41095	He had not risked, he did not expect, he had not been disappointed, he
 41096	was satisfied.
 41097	
 41098	
 41099	What satisfied him?
 41100	
 41101	To have sustained no positive loss. To have brought a positive gain to
 41102	others. Light to the gentiles.
 41103	
 41104	
 41105	How did Bloom prepare a collation for a gentile?
 41106	
 41107	He poured into two teacups two level spoonfuls, four in all, of Epps's
 41108	soluble cocoa and proceeded according to the directions for use printed
 41109	on the label, to each adding after sufficient time for infusion the
 41110	prescribed ingredients for diffusion in the manner and in the quantity
 41111	prescribed.
 41112	
 41113	
 41114	What supererogatory marks of special hospitality did the host show his
 41115	guest?
 41116	
 41117	Relinquishing his symposiarchal right to the moustache cup of imitation
 41118	Crown Derby presented to him by his only daughter, Millicent (Milly),
 41119	he substituted a cup identical with that of his guest and served
 41120	extraordinarily to his guest and, in reduced measure, to himself the
 41121	viscous cream ordinarily reserved for the breakfast of his wife Marion
 41122	(Molly).
 41123	
 41124	
 41125	Was the guest conscious of and did he acknowledge these marks of
 41126	hospitality?
 41127	
 41128	His attention was directed to them by his host jocosely, and he accepted
 41129	them seriously as they drank in jocoserious silence Epps's massproduct,
 41130	the creature cocoa.
 41131	
 41132	
 41133	Were there marks of hospitality which he contemplated but suppressed,
 41134	reserving them for another and for himself on future occasions to
 41135	complete the act begun?
 41136	
 41137	The reparation of a fissure of the length of 1 1/2 inches in the right
 41138	side of his guest's jacket. A gift to his guest of one of the four
 41139	lady's handkerchiefs, if and when ascertained to be in a presentable
 41140	condition.
 41141	
 41142	
 41143	Who drank more quickly?
 41144	
 41145	Bloom, having the advantage of ten seconds at the initiation and taking,
 41146	from the concave surface of a spoon along the handle of which a steady
 41147	flow of heat was conducted, three sips to his opponent's one, six to
 41148	two, nine to three.
 41149	
 41150	
 41151	What cerebration accompanied his frequentative act?
 41152	
 41153	Concluding by inspection but erroneously that his silent companion was
 41154	engaged in mental composition he reflected on the pleasures derived from
 41155	literature of instruction rather than of amusement as he himself had
 41156	applied to the works of William Shakespeare more than once for the
 41157	solution of difficult problems in imaginary or real life.
 41158	
 41159	
 41160	Had he found their solution?
 41161	
 41162	In spite of careful and repeated reading of certain classical passages,
 41163	aided by a glossary, he had derived imperfect conviction from the text,
 41164	the answers not bearing in all points.
 41165	
 41166	
 41167	What lines concluded his first piece of original verse written by him,
 41168	potential poet, at the age of 11 in 1877 on the occasion of the offering
 41169	of three prizes of 10/-, 5/- and 2/6 respectively for competition by the
 41170	_Shamrock_, a weekly newspaper?
 41171	
 41172	     _An ambition to squint
 41173	     At my verses in print
 41174	     Makes me hope that for these you'll find room?.
 41175	     If you so condescend
 41176	     Then please place at the end
 41177	     The name of yours truly, L. Bloom._
 41178	
 41179	Did he find four separating forces between his temporary guest and him?
 41180	
 41181	Name, age, race, creed.
 41182	
 41183	
 41184	What anagrams had he made on his name in youth?
 41185	
 41186	     Leopold Bloom
 41187	     Ellpodbomool
 41188	     Molldopeloob
 41189	     Bollopedoom
 41190	     Old Ollebo, M. P.
 41191	
 41192	
 41193	What acrostic upon the abbreviation of his first name had he (kinetic
 41194	poet) sent to Miss Marion (Molly) Tweedy on the 14 February 1888?
 41195	
 41196	     _Poets oft have sung in rhyme
 41197	     Of music sweet their praise divine.
 41198	     Let them hymn it nine times nine.
 41199	     Dearer far than song or wine.
 41200	     You are mine. The world is mine._
 41201	
 41202	
 41203	What had prevented him from completing a topical song (music by R. G.
 41204	Johnston) on the events of the past, or fixtures for the actual, years,
 41205	entitled _If Brian Boru could but come back and see old Dublin now_,
 41206	commissioned by Michael Gunn, lessee of the Gaiety Theatre, 46, 47, 48,
 41207	49 South King street, and to be introduced into the sixth scene, the
 41208	valley of diamonds, of the second edition (30 January 1893) of the grand
 41209	annual Christmas pantomime _Sinbad the Sailor_ (produced by R Shelton
 41210	26 December 1892, written by Greenleaf Whittier, scenery by George
 41211	A. Jackson and Cecil Hicks, costumes by Mrs and Miss Whelan under
 41212	the personal supervision of Mrs Michael Gunn, ballets by Jessie Noir,
 41213	harlequinade by Thomas Otto) and sung by Nelly Bouverist, principal
 41214	girl?
 41215	
 41216	Firstly, oscillation between events of imperial and of local interest,
 41217	the anticipated diamond jubilee of Queen Victoria (born 1820, acceded
 41218	1837) and the posticipated opening of the new municipal fish market:
 41219	secondly, apprehension of opposition from extreme circles on the
 41220	questions of the respective visits of Their Royal Highnesses the
 41221	duke and duchess of York (real) and of His Majesty King Brian Boru
 41222	(imaginary): thirdly, a conflict between professional etiquette and
 41223	professional emulation concerning the recent erections of the Grand
 41224	Lyric Hall on Burgh Quay and the Theatre Royal in Hawkins street:
 41225	fourthly, distraction resultant from compassion for Nelly Bouverist's
 41226	non-intellectual, non-political, non-topical expression of countenance
 41227	and concupiscence caused by Nelly Bouverist's revelations of white
 41228	articles of non-intellectual, non-political, non-topical underclothing
 41229	while she (Nelly Bouverist) was in the articles: fifthly, the
 41230	difficulties of the selection of appropriate music and humorous
 41231	allusions from _Everybody's Book of Jokes_ (1000 pages and a laugh in
 41232	every one): sixthly, the rhymes, homophonous and cacophonous, associated
 41233	with the names of the new lord mayor, Daniel Tallon, the new high
 41234	sheriff, Thomas Pile and the new solicitorgeneral, Dunbar Plunket
 41235	Barton.
 41236	
 41237	
 41238	What relation existed between their ages?
 41239	
 41240	16 years before in 1888 when Bloom was of Stephen's present age Stephen
 41241	was 6. 16 years after in 1920 when Stephen would be of Bloom's present
 41242	age Bloom would be 54. In 1936 when Bloom would be 70 and Stephen 54
 41243	their ages initially in the ratio of 16 to 0 would be as 17 1/2 to 13
 41244	1/2, the proportion increasing and the disparity diminishing according
 41245	as arbitrary future years were added, for if the proportion existing in
 41246	1883 had continued immutable, conceiving that to be possible, till then
 41247	1904 when Stephen was 22 Bloom would be 374 and in 1920 when Stephen
 41248	would be 38, as Bloom then was, Bloom would be 646 while in 1952 when
 41249	Stephen would have attained the maximum postdiluvian age of 70 Bloom,
 41250	being 1190 years alive having been born in the year 714, would have
 41251	surpassed by 221 years the maximum antediluvian age, that of Methusalah,
 41252	969 years, while, if Stephen would continue to live until he would
 41253	attain that age in the year 3072 A.D., Bloom would have been obliged to
 41254	have been alive 83,300 years, having been obliged to have been born in
 41255	the year 81,396 B.C.
 41256	
 41257	
 41258	What events might nullify these calculations?
 41259	
 41260	The cessation of existence of both or either, the inauguration of a
 41261	new era or calendar, the annihilation of the world and consequent
 41262	extermination of the human species, inevitable but impredictable.
 41263	
 41264	
 41265	How many previous encounters proved their preexisting acquaintance?
 41266	
 41267	Two. The first in the lilacgarden of Matthew Dillon's house, Medina
 41268	Villa, Kimmage road, Roundtown, in 1887, in the company of Stephen's
 41269	mother, Stephen being then of the age of 5 and reluctant to give his
 41270	hand in salutation. The second in the coffeeroom of Breslin's hotel on a
 41271	rainy Sunday in the January of 1892, in the company of Stephen's father
 41272	and Stephen's granduncle, Stephen being then 5 years older.
 41273	
 41274	
 41275	Did Bloom accept the invitation to dinner given then by the son and
 41276	afterwards seconded by the father?
 41277	
 41278	Very gratefully, with grateful appreciation, with sincere appreciative
 41279	gratitude, in appreciatively grateful sincerity of regret, he declined.
 41280	
 41281	
 41282	Did their conversation on the subject of these reminiscences reveal a
 41283	third connecting link between them?
 41284	
 41285	Mrs Riordan (Dante), a widow of independent means, had resided in the
 41286	house of Stephen's parents from 1 September 1888 to 29 December 1891 and
 41287	had also resided during the years 1892, 1893 and 1894 in the City Arms
 41288	Hotel owned by Elizabeth O'Dowd of 54 Prussia street where, during parts
 41289	of the years 1893 and 1894, she had been a constant informant of Bloom
 41290	who resided also in the same hotel, being at that time a clerk in the
 41291	employment of Joseph Cuffe of 5 Smithfield for the superintendence of
 41292	sales in the adjacent Dublin Cattle market on the North Circular road.
 41293	
 41294	
 41295	Had he performed any special corporal work of mercy for her?
 41296	
 41297	He had sometimes propelled her on warm summer evenings, an infirm widow
 41298	of independent, if limited, means, in her convalescent bathchair
 41299	with slow revolutions of its wheels as far as the corner of the North
 41300	Circular road opposite Mr Gavin Low's place of business where she had
 41301	remained for a certain time scanning through his onelensed binocular
 41302	fieldglasses unrecognisable citizens on tramcars, roadster bicycles
 41303	equipped with inflated pneumatic tyres, hackney carriages, tandems,
 41304	private and hired landaus, dogcarts, ponytraps and brakes passing from
 41305	the city to the Phoenix Park and vice versa.
 41306	
 41307	
 41308	Why could he then support that his vigil with the greater equanimity?
 41309	
 41310	Because in middle youth he had often sat observing through a rondel
 41311	of bossed glass of a multicoloured pane the spectacle offered with
 41312	continual changes of the thoroughfare without, pedestrians, quadrupeds,
 41313	velocipedes, vehicles, passing slowly, quickly, evenly, round and round
 41314	and round the rim of a round and round precipitous globe.
 41315	
 41316	
 41317	What distinct different memories had each of her now eight years
 41318	deceased?
 41319	
 41320	The older, her bezique cards and counters, her Skye terrier, her
 41321	suppositious wealth, her lapses of responsiveness and incipient
 41322	catarrhal deafness: the younger, her lamp of colza oil before the statue
 41323	of the Immaculate Conception, her green and maroon brushes for Charles
 41324	Stewart Parnell and for Michael Davitt, her tissue papers.
 41325	
 41326	
 41327	Were there no means still remaining to him to achieve the rejuvenation
 41328	which these reminiscences divulged to a younger companion rendered the
 41329	more desirable?
 41330	
 41331	The indoor exercises, formerly intermittently practised, subsequently
 41332	abandoned, prescribed in Eugen Sandow's _Physical Strength and How to
 41333	Obtain It_ which, designed particularly for commercial men engaged in
 41334	sedentary occupations, were to be made with mental concentration in
 41335	front of a mirror so as to bring into play the various families of
 41336	muscles and produce successively a pleasant rigidity, a more pleasant
 41337	relaxation and the most pleasant repristination of juvenile agility.
 41338	
 41339	
 41340	Had any special agility been his in earlier youth?
 41341	
 41342	Though ringweight lifting had been beyond his strength and the full
 41343	circle gyration beyond his courage yet as a High school scholar he
 41344	had excelled in his stable and protracted execution of the half lever
 41345	movement on the parallel bars in consequence of his abnormally developed
 41346	abdominal muscles.
 41347	
 41348	
 41349	Did either openly allude to their racial difference?
 41350	
 41351	Neither.
 41352	
 41353	
 41354	What, reduced to their simplest reciprocal form, were Bloom's thoughts
 41355	about Stephen's thoughts about Bloom and about Stephen's thoughts about
 41356	Bloom's thoughts about Stephen?
 41357	
 41358	He thought that he thought that he was a jew whereas he knew that he
 41359	knew that he knew that he was not.
 41360	
 41361	
 41362	What, the enclosures of reticence removed, were their respective
 41363	parentages?
 41364	
 41365	Bloom, only born male transubstantial heir of Rudolf Virag (subsequently
 41366	Rudolph Bloom) of Szombathely, Vienna, Budapest, Milan, London and
 41367	Dublin and of Ellen Higgins, second daughter of Julius Higgins (born
 41368	Karoly) and Fanny Higgins (born Hegarty). Stephen, eldest surviving male
 41369	consubstantial heir of Simon Dedalus of Cork and Dublin and of Mary,
 41370	daughter of Richard and Christina Goulding (born Grier).
 41371	
 41372	
 41373	Had Bloom and Stephen been baptised, and where and by whom, cleric or
 41374	layman?
 41375	
 41376	Bloom (three times), by the reverend Mr Gilmer Johnston M. A., alone,
 41377	in the protestant church of Saint Nicholas Without, Coombe, by James
 41378	O'Connor, Philip Gilligan and James Fitzpatrick, together, under a pump
 41379	in the village of Swords, and by the reverend Charles Malone C. C., in
 41380	the church of the Three Patrons, Rathgar. Stephen (once) by the reverend
 41381	Charles Malone C. C., alone, in the church of the Three Patrons,
 41382	Rathgar.
 41383	
 41384	
 41385	Did they find their educational careers similar?
 41386	
 41387	Substituting Stephen for Bloom Stoom would have passed successively
 41388	through a dame's school and the high school. Substituting Bloom for
 41389	Stephen Blephen would have passed successively through the preparatory,
 41390	junior, middle and senior grades of the intermediate and through the
 41391	matriculation, first arts, second arts and arts degree courses of the
 41392	royal university.
 41393	
 41394	
 41395	Why did Bloom refrain from stating that he had frequented the university
 41396	of life?
 41397	
 41398	Because of his fluctuating incertitude as to whether this observation
 41399	had or had not been already made by him to Stephen or by Stephen to him.
 41400	
 41401	
 41402	What two temperaments did they individually represent?
 41403	
 41404	The scientific. The artistic.
 41405	
 41406	
 41407	What proofs did Bloom adduce to prove that his tendency was towards
 41408	applied, rather than towards pure, science?
 41409	
 41410	Certain possible inventions of which he had cogitated when reclining
 41411	in a state of supine repletion to aid digestion, stimulated by his
 41412	appreciation of the importance of inventions now common but once
 41413	revolutionary, for example, the aeronautic parachute, the reflecting
 41414	telescope, the spiral corkscrew, the safety pin, the mineral water
 41415	siphon, the canal lock with winch and sluice, the suction pump.
 41416	
 41417	
 41418	Were these inventions principally intended for an improved scheme of
 41419	kindergarten?
 41420	
 41421	Yes, rendering obsolete popguns, elastic airbladders, games of hazard,
 41422	catapults. They comprised astronomical kaleidoscopes exhibiting the
 41423	twelve constellations of the zodiac from Aries to Pisces, miniature
 41424	mechanical orreries, arithmetical gelatine lozenges, geometrical
 41425	to correspond with zoological biscuits, globemap playing balls,
 41426	historically costumed dolls.
 41427	
 41428	
 41429	What also stimulated him in his cogitations?
 41430	
 41431	The financial success achieved by Ephraim Marks and Charles A. James,
 41432	the former by his 1d bazaar at 42 George's street, south, the latter
 41433	at his 6 1/2d shop and world's fancy fair and waxwork exhibition at 30
 41434	Henry street, admission 2d, children 1d: and the infinite possibilities
 41435	hitherto unexploited of the modern art of advertisement if condensed
 41436	in triliteral monoideal symbols, vertically of maximum visibility
 41437	(divined), horizontally of maximum legibility (deciphered) and of
 41438	magnetising efficacy to arrest involuntary attention, to interest, to
 41439	convince, to decide.
 41440	
 41441	
 41442	Such as?
 41443	
 41444	K. II. Kino's 11/- Trousers. House of Keys. Alexander J. Keyes.
 41445	
 41446	
 41447	Such as not?
 41448	
 41449	Look at this long candle. Calculate when it burns out and you receive
 41450	gratis 1 pair of our special non-compo boots, guaranteed 1 candle power.
 41451	Address: Barclay and Cook, 18 Talbot street.
 41452	
 41453	Bacilikil (Insect Powder). Veribest (Boot Blacking). Uwantit (Combined
 41454	pocket twoblade penknife with corkscrew, nailfile and pipecleaner).
 41455	
 41456	
 41457	Such as never?
 41458	
 41459	What is home without Plumtree's Potted Meat?
 41460	
 41461	Incomplete.
 41462	
 41463	With it an abode of bliss.
 41464	
 41465	Manufactured by George Plumtree, 23 Merchants' quay, Dublin, put up in
 41466	4 oz pots, and inserted by Councillor Joseph P. Nannetti, M. P., Rotunda
 41467	Ward, 19 Hardwicke street, under the obituary notices and anniversaries
 41468	of deceases. The name on the label is Plumtree. A plumtree in a meatpot,
 41469	registered trade mark. Beware of imitations. Peatmot. Trumplee. Moutpat.
 41470	Plamtroo.
 41471	
 41472	
 41473	Which example did he adduce to induce Stephen to deduce that
 41474	originality, though producing its own reward, does not invariably
 41475	conduce to success?
 41476	
 41477	His own ideated and rejected project of an illuminated showcart, drawn
 41478	by a beast of burden, in which two smartly dressed girls were to be
 41479	seated engaged in writing.
 41480	
 41481	
 41482	What suggested scene was then constructed by Stephen?
 41483	
 41484	Solitary hotel in mountain pass. Autumn. Twilight. Fire lit. In dark
 41485	corner young man seated. Young woman enters. Restless. Solitary. She
 41486	sits. She goes to window. She stands. She sits. Twilight. She thinks.
 41487	On solitary hotel paper she writes. She thinks. She writes. She sighs.
 41488	Wheels and hoofs. She hurries out. He comes from his dark corner. He
 41489	seizes solitary paper. He holds it towards fire. Twilight. He reads.
 41490	Solitary.
 41491	
 41492	
 41493	What?
 41494	
 41495	In sloping, upright and backhands: Queen's Hotel, Queen's Hotel, Queen's
 41496	Hotel. Queen's Ho...
 41497	
 41498	
 41499	What suggested scene was then reconstructed by Bloom?
 41500	
 41501	The Queen's Hotel, Ennis, county Clare, where Rudolph Bloom (Rudolf
 41502	Virag) died on the evening of the 27 June 1886, at some hour unstated,
 41503	in consequence of an overdose of monkshood (aconite) selfadministered in
 41504	the form of a neuralgic liniment composed of 2 parts of aconite liniment
 41505	to I of chloroform liniment (purchased by him at 10.20 a.m. on the
 41506	morning of 27 June 1886 at the medical hall of Francis Dennehy, 17
 41507	Church street, Ennis) after having, though not in consequence of having,
 41508	purchased at 3.15 p.m. on the afternoon of 27 June 1886 a new boater
 41509	straw hat, extra smart (after having, though not in consequence of
 41510	having, purchased at the hour and in the place aforesaid, the toxin
 41511	aforesaid), at the general drapery store of James Cullen, 4 Main street,
 41512	Ennis.
 41513	
 41514	
 41515	Did he attribute this homonymity to information or coincidence or
 41516	intuition?
 41517	
 41518	Coincidence.
 41519	
 41520	
 41521	Did he depict the scene verbally for his guest to see?
 41522	
 41523	He preferred himself to see another's face and listen to another's
 41524	words by which potential narration was realised and kinetic temperament
 41525	relieved.
 41526	
 41527	
 41528	Did he see only a second coincidence in the second scene narrated to
 41529	him, described by the narrator as _A Pisgah Sight of Palestine or The
 41530	Parable of the Plums_?
 41531	
 41532	It, with the preceding scene and with others unnarrated but existent by
 41533	implication, to which add essays on various subjects or moral apothegms
 41534	(e.g. _My Favourite Hero or Procrastination is the Thief of Time_)
 41535	composed during schoolyears, seemed to him to contain in itself and
 41536	in conjunction with the personal equation certain possibilities of
 41537	financial, social, personal and sexual success, whether specially
 41538	collected and selected as model pedagogic themes (of cent per cent
 41539	merit) for the use of preparatory and junior grade students or
 41540	contributed in printed form, following the precedent of Philip Beaufoy
 41541	or Doctor Dick or Heblon's _Studies in Blue_, to a publication of
 41542	certified circulation and solvency or employed verbally as intellectual
 41543	stimulation for sympathetic auditors, tacitly appreciative of successful
 41544	narrative and confidently augurative of successful achievement, during
 41545	the increasingly longer nights gradually following the summer solstice
 41546	on the day but three following, videlicet, Tuesday, 21 June (S. Aloysius
 41547	Gonzaga), sunrise 3.33 a.m., sunset 8.29 p.m.
 41548	
 41549	
 41550	Which domestic problem as much as, if not more than, any other
 41551	frequently engaged his mind?
 41552	
 41553	What to do with our wives.
 41554	
 41555	
 41556	What had been his hypothetical singular solutions?
 41557	
 41558	Parlour games (dominos, halma, tiddledywinks, spilikins, cup and ball,
 41559	nap, spoil five, bezique, twentyfive, beggar my neighbour, draughts,
 41560	chess or backgammon): embroidery, darning or knitting for the
 41561	policeaided clothing society: musical duets, mandoline and guitar, piano
 41562	and flute, guitar and piano: legal scrivenery or envelope addressing:
 41563	biweekly visits to variety entertainments: commercial activity as
 41564	pleasantly commanding and pleasingly obeyed mistress proprietress in
 41565	a cool dairy shop or warm cigar divan: the clandestine satisfaction of
 41566	erotic irritation in masculine brothels, state inspected and medically
 41567	controlled: social visits, at regular infrequent prevented intervals
 41568	and with regular frequent preventive superintendence, to and from female
 41569	acquaintances of recognised respectability in the vicinity: courses of
 41570	evening instruction specially designed to render liberal instruction
 41571	agreeable.
 41572	
 41573	
 41574	What instances of deficient mental development in his wife inclined him
 41575	in favour of the lastmentioned (ninth) solution?
 41576	
 41577	In disoccupied moments she had more than once covered a sheet of paper
 41578	with signs and hieroglyphics which she stated were Greek and Irish and
 41579	Hebrew characters. She had interrogated constantly at varying intervals
 41580	as to the correct method of writing the capital initial of the name of
 41581	a city in Canada, Quebec. She understood little of political
 41582	complications, internal, or balance of power, external. In calculating
 41583	the addenda of bills she frequently had recourse to digital aid.
 41584	After completion of laconic epistolary compositions she abandoned
 41585	the implement of calligraphy in the encaustic pigment, exposed to
 41586	the corrosive action of copperas, green vitriol and nutgall. Unusual
 41587	polysyllables of foreign origin she interpreted phonetically or by false
 41588	analogy or by both: metempsychosis (met him pike hoses), _alias_ (a
 41589	mendacious person mentioned in sacred scripture).
 41590	
 41591	
 41592	What compensated in the false balance of her intelligence for these and
 41593	such deficiencies of judgment regarding persons, places and things?
 41594	
 41595	The false apparent parallelism of all perpendicular arms of all
 41596	balances, proved true by construction. The counterbalance of her
 41597	proficiency of judgment regarding one person, proved true by experiment.
 41598	
 41599	
 41600	How had he attempted to remedy this state of comparative ignorance?
 41601	
 41602	Variously. By leaving in a conspicuous place a certain book open at a
 41603	certain page: by assuming in her, when alluding explanatorily, latent
 41604	knowledge: by open ridicule in her presence of some absent other's
 41605	ignorant lapse.
 41606	
 41607	
 41608	With what success had he attempted direct instruction?
 41609	
 41610	She followed not all, a part of the whole, gave attention with interest
 41611	comprehended with surprise, with care repeated, with greater difficulty
 41612	remembered, forgot with ease, with misgiving reremembered, rerepeated
 41613	with error.
 41614	
 41615	
 41616	What system had proved more effective?
 41617	
 41618	Indirect suggestion implicating selfinterest.
 41619	
 41620	
 41621	Example?
 41622	
 41623	She disliked umbrella with rain, he liked woman with umbrella, she
 41624	disliked new hat with rain, he liked woman with new hat, he bought new
 41625	hat with rain, she carried umbrella with new hat.
 41626	
 41627	
 41628	Accepting the analogy implied in his guest's parable which examples of
 41629	postexilic eminence did he adduce?
 41630	
 41631	Three seekers of the pure truth, Moses of Egypt, Moses Maimonides,
 41632	author of _More Nebukim_ (Guide of the Perplexed) and Moses Mendelssohn
 41633	of such eminence that from Moses (of Egypt) to Moses (Mendelssohn) there
 41634	arose none like Moses (Maimonides).
 41635	
 41636	
 41637	What statement was made, under correction, by Bloom concerning a fourth
 41638	seeker of pure truth, by name Aristotle, mentioned, with permission, by
 41639	Stephen?
 41640	
 41641	That the seeker mentioned had been a pupil of a rabbinical philosopher,
 41642	name uncertain.
 41643	
 41644	
 41645	Were other anapocryphal illustrious sons of the law and children of a
 41646	selected or rejected race mentioned?
 41647	
 41648	Felix Bartholdy Mendelssohn (composer), Baruch Spinoza (philosopher),
 41649	Mendoza (pugilist), Ferdinand Lassalle (reformer, duellist).
 41650	
 41651	
 41652	What fragments of verse from the ancient Hebrew and ancient Irish
 41653	languages were cited with modulations of voice and translation of texts
 41654	by guest to host and by host to guest?
 41655	
 41656	By Stephen: _suil, suil, suil arun, suil go siocair agus suil go cuin_
 41657	(walk, walk, walk your way, walk in safety, walk with care).
 41658	
 41659	
 41660	By Bloom: _Kkifeloch, harimon rakatejch m'baad l'zamatejch_ (thy temple
 41661	amid thy hair is as a slice of pomegranate).
 41662	
 41663	
 41664	How was a glyphic comparison of the phonic symbols of both languages
 41665	made in substantiation of the oral comparison?
 41666	
 41667	By juxtaposition. On the penultimate blank page of a book of inferior
 41668	literary style, entituled _Sweets of Sin_ (produced by Bloom and so
 41669	manipulated that its front cover came in contact with the surface of
 41670	the table) with a pencil (supplied by Stephen) Stephen wrote the Irish
 41671	characters for gee, eh, dee, em, simple and modified, and Bloom in turn
 41672	wrote the Hebrew characters ghimel, aleph, daleth and (in the absence of
 41673	mem) a substituted qoph, explaining their arithmetical values as ordinal
 41674	and cardinal numbers, videlicet 3, 1, 4, and 100.
 41675	
 41676	
 41677	Was the knowledge possessed by both of each of these languages, the
 41678	extinct and the revived, theoretical or practical?
 41679	
 41680	Theoretical, being confined to certain grammatical rules of accidence
 41681	and syntax and practically excluding vocabulary.
 41682	
 41683	
 41684	What points of contact existed between these languages and between the
 41685	peoples who spoke them?
 41686	
 41687	The presence of guttural sounds, diacritic aspirations, epenthetic and
 41688	servile letters in both languages: their antiquity, both having been
 41689	taught on the plain of Shinar 242 years after the deluge in the seminary
 41690	instituted by Fenius Farsaigh, descendant of Noah, progenitor of Israel,
 41691	and ascendant of Heber and Heremon, progenitors of Ireland: their
 41692	archaeological, genealogical, hagiographical, exegetical, homiletic,
 41693	toponomastic, historical and religious literatures comprising the works
 41694	of rabbis and culdees, Torah, Talmud (Mischna and Ghemara), Massor,
 41695	Pentateuch, Book of the Dun Cow, Book of Ballymote, Garland of Howth,
 41696	Book of Kells: their dispersal, persecution, survival and revival: the
 41697	isolation of their synagogical and ecclesiastical rites in ghetto (S.
 41698	Mary's Abbey) and masshouse (Adam and Eve's tavern): the proscription
 41699	of their national costumes in penal laws and jewish dress acts: the
 41700	restoration in Chanah David of Zion and the possibility of Irish
 41701	political autonomy or devolution.
 41702	
 41703	
 41704	What anthem did Bloom chant partially in anticipation of that multiple,
 41705	ethnically irreducible consummation?
 41706	
 41707	     _Kolod balejwaw pnimah
 41708	     Nefesch, jehudi, homijah._
 41709	
 41710	
 41711	Why was the chant arrested at the conclusion of this first distich?
 41712	
 41713	In consequence of defective mnemotechnic.
 41714	
 41715	
 41716	How did the chanter compensate for this deficiency?
 41717	
 41718	By a periphrastic version of the general text.
 41719	
 41720	
 41721	In what common study did their mutual reflections merge?
 41722	
 41723	The increasing simplification traceable from the Egyptian epigraphic
 41724	hieroglyphs to the Greek and Roman alphabets and the anticipation of
 41725	modern stenography and telegraphic code in the cuneiform inscriptions
 41726	(Semitic) and the virgular quinquecostate ogham writing (Celtic). Did
 41727	the guest comply with his host's request?
 41728	
 41729	Doubly, by appending his signature in Irish and Roman characters.
 41730	
 41731	What was Stephen's auditive sensation?
 41732	
 41733	He heard in a profound ancient male unfamiliar melody the accumulation
 41734	of the past.
 41735	
 41736	
 41737	What was Bloom's visual sensation?
 41738	
 41739	He saw in a quick young male familiar form the predestination of a
 41740	future.
 41741	
 41742	
 41743	What were Stephen's and Bloom's quasisimultaneous volitional
 41744	quasisensations of concealed identities?
 41745	
 41746	Visually, Stephen's: The traditional figure of hypostasis, depicted
 41747	by Johannes Damascenus, Lentulus Romanus and Epiphanius Monachus as
 41748	leucodermic, sesquipedalian with winedark hair. Auditively, Bloom's: The
 41749	traditional accent of the ecstasy of catastrophe.
 41750	
 41751	
 41752	What future careers had been possible for Bloom in the past and with
 41753	what exemplars?
 41754	
 41755	In the church, Roman, Anglican or Nonconformist: exemplars, the very
 41756	reverend John Conmee S. J., the reverend T. Salmon, D. D., provost of
 41757	Trinity college, Dr Alexander J. Dowie. At the bar, English or Irish:
 41758	exemplars, Seymour Bushe, K. C., Rufus Isaacs, K. C. On the stage modern
 41759	or Shakespearean: exemplars, Charles Wyndham, high comedian Osmond
 41760	Tearle (died 1901), exponent of Shakespeare.
 41761	
 41762	
 41763	Did the host encourage his guest to chant in a modulated voice a strange
 41764	legend on an allied theme?
 41765	
 41766	Reassuringly, their place, where none could hear them talk, being
 41767	secluded, reassured, the decocted beverages, allowing for subsolid
 41768	residual sediment of a mechanical mixture, water plus sugar plus cream
 41769	plus cocoa, having been consumed.
 41770	
 41771	
 41772	Recite the first (major) part of this chanted legend.
 41773	
 41774	     _Little Harry Hughes and his schoolfellows all
 41775	     Went out for to play ball.
 41776	     And the very first ball little Harry Hughes played
 41777	     He drove it o'er the jew's garden wall.
 41778	     And the very second ball little Harry Hughes played
 41779	     He broke the jew's windows all._
 41780	
 41781	
 41782	
 41783	How did the son of Rudolph receive this first part?
 41784	
 41785	
 41786	With unmixed feeling. Smiling, a jew he heard with pleasure and saw the
 41787	unbroken kitchen window.
 41788	
 41789	
 41790	Recite the second part (minor) of the legend.
 41791	
 41792	     _Then out there came the jew's daughter
 41793	     And she all dressed in green.
 41794	     "Come back, come back, you pretty little boy,
 41795	     And play your ball again."
 41796	
 41797	     "I can't come back and I won't come back
 41798	     Without my schoolfellows all.
 41799	     For if my master he did hear
 41800	     He'd make it a sorry ball."
 41801	
 41802	     She took him by the lilywhite hand
 41803	     And led him along the hall
 41804	     Until she led him to a room
 41805	     Where none could hear him call.
 41806	
 41807	     She took a penknife out of her pocket
 41808	     And cut off his little head.
 41809	     And now he'll play his ball no more
 41810	     For he lies among the dead._
 41811	
 41812	
 41813	How did the father of Millicent receive this second part?
 41814	
 41815	With mixed feelings. Unsmiling, he heard and saw with wonder a jew's
 41816	daughter, all dressed in green.
 41817	
 41818	
 41819	Condense Stephen's commentary.
 41820	
 41821	One of all, the least of all, is the victim predestined. Once by
 41822	inadvertence twice by design he challenges his destiny. It comes when he
 41823	is abandoned and challenges him reluctant and, as an apparition of hope
 41824	and youth, holds him unresisting. It leads him to a strange habitation,
 41825	to a secret infidel apartment, and there, implacable, immolates him,
 41826	consenting.
 41827	
 41828	
 41829	Why was the host (victim predestined) sad?
 41830	
 41831	He wished that a tale of a deed should be told of a deed not by him
 41832	should by him not be told.
 41833	
 41834	
 41835	Why was the host (reluctant, unresisting) still?
 41836	
 41837	In accordance with the law of the conservation of energy.
 41838	
 41839	
 41840	Why was the host (secret infidel) silent?
 41841	
 41842	He weighed the possible evidences for and against ritual murder: the
 41843	incitations of the hierarchy, the superstition of the populace, the
 41844	propagation of rumour in continued fraction of veridicity, the envy of
 41845	opulence, the influence of retaliation, the sporadic reappearance of
 41846	atavistic delinquency, the mitigating circumstances of fanaticism,
 41847	hypnotic suggestion and somnambulism.
 41848	
 41849	
 41850	From which (if any) of these mental or physical disorders was he not
 41851	totally immune?
 41852	
 41853	From hypnotic suggestion: once, waking, he had not recognised his
 41854	sleeping apartment: more than once, waking, he had been for an
 41855	indefinite time incapable of moving or uttering sounds. From
 41856	somnambulism: once, sleeping, his body had risen, crouched and
 41857	crawled in the direction of a heatless fire and, having attained
 41858	its destination, there, curled, unheated, in night attire had lain,
 41859	sleeping.
 41860	
 41861	
 41862	Had this latter or any cognate phenomenon declared itself in any member
 41863	of his family?
 41864	
 41865	Twice, in Holles street and in Ontario terrace, his daughter Millicent
 41866	(Milly) at the ages of 6 and 8 years had uttered in sleep an exclamation
 41867	of terror and had replied to the interrogations of two figures in night
 41868	attire with a vacant mute expression.
 41869	
 41870	
 41871	What other infantile memories had he of her?
 41872	
 41873	15 June 1889. A querulous newborn female infant crying to cause and
 41874	lessen congestion. A child renamed Padney Socks she shook with shocks
 41875	her moneybox: counted his three free moneypenny buttons, one, tloo,
 41876	tlee: a doll, a boy, a sailor she cast away: blond, born of two dark,
 41877	she had blond ancestry, remote, a violation, Herr Hauptmann Hainau,
 41878	Austrian army, proximate, a hallucination, lieutenant Mulvey, British
 41879	navy.
 41880	
 41881	
 41882	What endemic characteristics were present?
 41883	
 41884	Conversely the nasal and frontal formation was derived in a direct
 41885	line of lineage which, though interrupted, would continue at distant
 41886	intervals to more distant intervals to its most distant intervals.
 41887	
 41888	
 41889	What memories had he of her adolescence?
 41890	
 41891	She relegated her hoop and skippingrope to a recess. On the duke's lawn,
 41892	entreated by an English visitor, she declined to permit him to make and
 41893	take away her photographic image (objection not stated). On the South
 41894	Circular road in the company of Elsa Potter, followed by an individual
 41895	of sinister aspect, she went half way down Stamer street and turned
 41896	abruptly back (reason of change not stated). On the vigil of the 15th
 41897	anniversary of her birth she wrote a letter from Mullingar, county
 41898	Westmeath, making a brief allusion to a local student (faculty and year
 41899	not stated).
 41900	
 41901	
 41902	Did that first division, portending a second division, afflict him?
 41903	
 41904	Less than he had imagined, more than he had hoped.
 41905	
 41906	
 41907	What second departure was contemporaneously perceived by him similarly,
 41908	if differently?
 41909	
 41910	A temporary departure of his cat.
 41911	
 41912	
 41913	Why similarly, why differently?
 41914	
 41915	Similarly, because actuated by a secret purpose the quest of a new male
 41916	
 41917	(Mullingar student) or of a healing herb (valerian). Differently,
 41918	because of different possible returns to the inhabitants or to the
 41919	habitation.
 41920	
 41921	
 41922	In other respects were their differences similar?
 41923	
 41924	In passivity, in economy, in the instinct of tradition, in
 41925	unexpectedness.
 41926	
 41927	
 41928	As?
 41929	
 41930	Inasmuch as leaning she sustained her blond hair for him to ribbon it
 41931	for her (cf neckarching cat). Moreover, on the free surface of the lake
 41932	in Stephen's green amid inverted reflections of trees her uncommented
 41933	spit, describing concentric circles of waterrings, indicated by the
 41934	constancy of its permanence the locus of a somnolent prostrate fish (cf
 41935	mousewatching cat).
 41936	
 41937	Again, in order to remember the date, combatants, issue and consequences
 41938	of a famous military engagement she pulled a plait of her hair (cf
 41939	earwashing cat). Furthermore, silly Milly, she dreamed of having had
 41940	an unspoken unremembered conversation with a horse whose name had been
 41941	Joseph to whom (which) she had offered a tumblerful of lemonade which
 41942	it (he) had appeared to have accepted (cf hearthdreaming cat). Hence, in
 41943	passivity, in economy, in the instinct of tradition, in unexpectedness,
 41944	their differences were similar.
 41945	
 41946	
 41947	In what way had he utilised gifts (1) an owl, (2) a clock, given as
 41948	matrimonial auguries, to interest and to instruct her?
 41949	
 41950	As object lessons to explain: 1) the nature and habits of oviparous
 41951	animals, the possibility of aerial flight, certain abnormalities of
 41952	vision, the secular process of imbalsamation: 2) the principle of the
 41953	pendulum, exemplified in bob, wheelgear and regulator, the translation
 41954	in terms of human or social regulation of the various positions of
 41955	clockwise moveable indicators on an unmoving dial, the exactitude of the
 41956	recurrence per hour of an instant in each hour when the longer and the
 41957	shorter indicator were at the same angle of inclination, _videlicet_, 5
 41958	5/11 minutes past each hour per hour in arithmetical progression.
 41959	
 41960	
 41961	In what manners did she reciprocate?
 41962	
 41963	She remembered: on the 27th anniversary of his birth she presented to
 41964	him a breakfast moustachecup of imitation Crown Derby porcelain ware.
 41965	She provided: at quarter day or thereabouts if or when purchases
 41966	had been made by him not for her she showed herself attentive to his
 41967	necessities, anticipating his desires. She admired: a natural phenomenon
 41968	having been explained by him to her she expressed the immediate desire
 41969	to possess without gradual acquisition a fraction of his science, the
 41970	moiety, the quarter, a thousandth part.
 41971	
 41972	
 41973	What proposal did Bloom, diambulist, father of Milly, somnambulist, make
 41974	to Stephen, noctambulist?
 41975	
 41976	To pass in repose the hours intervening between Thursday (proper) and
 41977	Friday (normal) on an extemporised cubicle in the apartment immediately
 41978	above the kitchen and immediately adjacent to the sleeping apartment of
 41979	his host and hostess.
 41980	
 41981	
 41982	What various advantages would or might have resulted from a prolongation
 41983	of such an extemporisation?
 41984	
 41985	For the guest: security of domicile and seclusion of study. For the
 41986	host: rejuvenation of intelligence, vicarious satisfaction. For the
 41987	hostess: disintegration of obsession, acquisition of correct Italian
 41988	pronunciation.
 41989	
 41990	
 41991	Why might these several provisional contingencies between a guest and
 41992	a hostess not necessarily preclude or be precluded by a permanent
 41993	eventuality of reconciliatory union between a schoolfellow and a jew's
 41994	daughter?
 41995	
 41996	Because the way to daughter led through mother, the way to mother
 41997	through daughter.
 41998	
 41999	
 42000	To what inconsequent polysyllabic question of his host did the guest
 42001	return a monosyllabic negative answer?
 42002	
 42003	If he had known the late Mrs Emily Sinico, accidentally killed at Sydney
 42004	Parade railway station, 14 October 1903.
 42005	
 42006	
 42007	What inchoate corollary statement was consequently suppressed by the
 42008	host?
 42009	
 42010	A statement explanatory of his absence on the occasion of the interment
 42011	of Mrs Mary Dedalus (born Goulding), 26 June 1903, vigil of the
 42012	anniversary of the decease of Rudolph Bloom (born Virag).
 42013	
 42014	
 42015	Was the proposal of asylum accepted?
 42016	
 42017	Promptly, inexplicably, with amicability, gratefully it was declined.
 42018	What exchange of money took place between host and guest?
 42019	
 42020	The former returned to the latter, without interest, a sum of money
 42021	(1-7-0), one pound seven shillings sterling, advanced by the latter to
 42022	the former.
 42023	
 42024	
 42025	What counterproposals were alternately advanced, accepted, modified,
 42026	declined, restated in other terms, reaccepted, ratified, reconfirmed?
 42027	
 42028	To inaugurate a prearranged course of Italian instruction, place
 42029	the residence of the instructed. To inaugurate a course of vocal
 42030	instruction, place the residence of the instructress. To inaugurate
 42031	a series of static semistatic and peripatetic intellectual dialogues,
 42032	places the residence of both speakers (if both speakers were resident in
 42033	the same place), the Ship hotel and tavern, 6 Lower Abbey street (W. and
 42034	E. Connery, proprietors), the National Library of Ireland, 10 Kildare
 42035	street, the National Maternity Hospital, 29, 30 and 31 Holles street, a
 42036	public garden, the vicinity of a place of worship, a conjunction of two
 42037	or more public thoroughfares, the point of bisection of a right line
 42038	drawn between their residences (if both speakers were resident in
 42039	different places).
 42040	
 42041	
 42042	What rendered problematic for Bloom the realisation of these mutually
 42043	selfexcluding propositions?
 42044	
 42045	The irreparability of the past: once at a performance of Albert
 42046	Hengler's circus in the Rotunda, Rutland square, Dublin, an intuitive
 42047	particoloured clown in quest of paternity had penetrated from the ring
 42048	to a place in the auditorium where Bloom, solitary, was seated and had
 42049	publicly declared to an exhilarated audience that he (Bloom) was his
 42050	(the clown's) papa. The imprevidibility of the future: once in the
 42051	summer of 1898 he (Bloom) had marked a florin (2/-) with three notches
 42052	on the milled edge and tendered it m payment of an account due to and
 42053	received by J. and T. Davy, family grocers, 1 Charlemont Mall, Grand
 42054	Canal, for circulation on the waters of civic finance, for possible,
 42055	circuitous or direct, return.
 42056	
 42057	
 42058	Was the clown Bloom's son?
 42059	
 42060	No.
 42061	
 42062	
 42063	Had Bloom's coin returned?
 42064	
 42065	Never.
 42066	
 42067	
 42068	Why would a recurrent frustration the more depress him?
 42069	
 42070	Because at the critical turningpoint of human existence he desired to
 42071	amend many social conditions, the product of inequality and avarice and
 42072	international animosity. He believed then that human life was infinitely
 42073	perfectible, eliminating these conditions?
 42074	
 42075	There remained the generic conditions imposed by natural, as distinct
 42076	from human law, as integral parts of the human whole: the necessity of
 42077	destruction to procure alimentary sustenance: the painful character of
 42078	the ultimate functions of separate existence, the agonies of birth and
 42079	death: the monotonous menstruation of simian and (particularly) human
 42080	females extending from the age of puberty to the menopause: inevitable
 42081	accidents at sea, in mines and factories: certain very painful maladies
 42082	and their resultant surgical operations, innate lunacy and congenital
 42083	criminality, decimating epidemics: catastrophic cataclysms which make
 42084	terror the basis of human mentality: seismic upheavals the epicentres
 42085	of which are located in densely populated regions: the fact of vital
 42086	growth, through convulsions of metamorphosis, from infancy through
 42087	maturity to decay.
 42088	
 42089	
 42090	Why did he desist from speculation?
 42091	
 42092	Because it was a task for a superior intelligence to substitute other
 42093	more acceptable phenomena in the place of the less acceptable phenomena
 42094	to be removed.
 42095	
 42096	
 42097	Did Stephen participate in his dejection?
 42098	
 42099	He affirmed his significance as a conscious rational animal proceeding
 42100	syllogistically from the known to the unknown and a conscious rational
 42101	reagent between a micro and a macrocosm ineluctably constructed upon the
 42102	incertitude of the void.
 42103	
 42104	
 42105	Was this affirmation apprehended by Bloom?
 42106	
 42107	Not verbally. Substantially.
 42108	
 42109	
 42110	What comforted his misapprehension?
 42111	
 42112	That as a competent keyless citizen he had proceeded energetically from
 42113	the unknown to the known through the incertitude of the void.
 42114	
 42115	
 42116	In what order of precedence, with what attendant ceremony was the exodus
 42117	from the house of bondage to the wilderness of inhabitation effected?
 42118	
 42119	Lighted Candle in Stick borne by
 42120	
 42121	BLOOM
 42122	
 42123	Diaconal Hat on Ashplant borne by
 42124	
 42125	STEPHEN:
 42126	
 42127	
 42128	With what intonation secreto of what commemorative psalm?
 42129	
 42130	The 113th, _modus peregrinus: In exitu Israel de Egypto: domus Jacob de
 42131	populo barbaro_.
 42132	
 42133	
 42134	What did each do at the door of egress?
 42135	
 42136	Bloom set the candlestick on the floor. Stephen put the hat on his head.
 42137	
 42138	
 42139	For what creature was the door of egress a door of ingress?
 42140	
 42141	For a cat.
 42142	
 42143	
 42144	What spectacle confronted them when they, first the host, then the
 42145	guest, emerged silently, doubly dark, from obscurity by a passage from
 42146	the rere of the house into the penumbra of the garden?
 42147	
 42148	The heaventree of stars hung with humid nightblue fruit.
 42149	
 42150	
 42151	With what meditations did Bloom accompany his demonstration to his
 42152	companion of various constellations?
 42153	
 42154	Meditations of evolution increasingly vaster: of the moon invisible in
 42155	incipient lunation, approaching perigee: of the infinite lattiginous
 42156	scintillating uncondensed milky way, discernible by daylight by an
 42157	observer placed at the lower end of a cylindrical vertical shaft 5000
 42158	ft deep sunk from the surface towards the centre of the earth: of Sirius
 42159	(alpha in Canis Maior) 10 lightyears (57,000,000,000,000 miles) distant
 42160	and in volume 900 times the dimension of our planet: of Arcturus: of the
 42161	precession of equinoxes: of Orion with belt and sextuple sun theta and
 42162	nebula in which 100 of our solar systems could be contained: of moribund
 42163	and of nascent new stars such as Nova in 1901: of our system plunging
 42164	towards the constellation of Hercules: of the parallax or parallactic
 42165	drift of socalled fixed stars, in reality evermoving wanderers from
 42166	immeasurably remote eons to infinitely remote futures in comparison with
 42167	which the years, threescore and ten, of allotted human life formed a
 42168	parenthesis of infinitesimal brevity.
 42169	
 42170	
 42171	Were there obverse meditations of involution increasingly less vast?
 42172	
 42173	Of the eons of geological periods recorded in the stratifications of the
 42174	earth: of the myriad minute entomological organic existences concealed
 42175	in cavities of the earth, beneath removable stones, in hives and mounds,
 42176	of microbes, germs, bacteria, bacilli, spermatozoa: of the incalculable
 42177	trillions of billions of millions of imperceptible molecules contained
 42178	by cohesion of molecular affinity in a single pinhead: of the universe
 42179	of human serum constellated with red and white bodies, themselves
 42180	universes of void space constellated with other bodies, each, in
 42181	continuity, its universe of divisible component bodies of which each was
 42182	again divisible in divisions of redivisible component bodies, dividends
 42183	and divisors ever diminishing without actual division till, if the
 42184	progress were carried far enough, nought nowhere was never reached.
 42185	
 42186	
 42187	Why did he not elaborate these calculations to a more precise result?
 42188	
 42189	Because some years previously in 1886 when occupied with the problem
 42190	of the quadrature of the circle he had learned of the existence of a
 42191	number computed to a relative degree of accuracy to be of such magnitude
 42192	and of so many places, e.g., the 9th power of the 9th power of 9, that,
 42193	the result having been obtained, 33 closely printed volumes of 1000
 42194	pages each of innumerable quires and reams of India paper would have to
 42195	be requisitioned in order to contain the complete tale of its printed
 42196	integers of units, tens, hundreds, thousands, tens of thousands,
 42197	hundreds of thousands, millions, tens of millions, hundreds of millions,
 42198	billions, the nucleus of the nebula of every digit of every series
 42199	containing succinctly the potentiality of being raised to the utmost
 42200	kinetic elaboration of any power of any of its powers.
 42201	
 42202	
 42203	Did he find the problems of the inhabitability of the planets and their
 42204	satellites by a race, given in species, and of the possible social and
 42205	moral redemption of said race by a redeemer, easier of solution?
 42206	
 42207	Of a different order of difficulty. Conscious that the human organism,
 42208	normally capable of sustaining an atmospheric pressure of 19 tons,
 42209	when elevated to a considerable altitude in the terrestrial atmosphere
 42210	suffered with arithmetical progression of intensity, according as
 42211	the line of demarcation between troposphere and stratosphere was
 42212	approximated from nasal hemorrhage, impeded respiration and vertigo,
 42213	when proposing this problem for solution, he had conjectured as a
 42214	working hypothesis which could not be proved impossible that a more
 42215	adaptable and differently anatomically constructed race of beings might
 42216	subsist otherwise under Martian, Mercurial, Veneral, Jovian, Saturnian,
 42217	Neptunian or Uranian sufficient and equivalent conditions, though
 42218	an apogean humanity of beings created in varying forms with finite
 42219	differences resulting similar to the whole and to one another would
 42220	probably there as here remain inalterably and inalienably attached to
 42221	vanities, to vanities of vanities and to all that is vanity.
 42222	
 42223	     And the problem of possible redemption?
 42224	     The minor was proved by the major.
 42225	
 42226	
 42227	Which various features of the constellations were in turn considered?
 42228	
 42229	The various colours significant of various degrees of vitality (white,
 42230	yellow, crimson, vermilion, cinnabar): their degrees of brilliancy:
 42231	their magnitudes revealed up to and including the 7th: their positions:
 42232	the waggoner's star: Walsingham way: the chariot of David: the annular
 42233	cinctures of Saturn: the condensation of spiral nebulae into suns: the
 42234	interdependent gyrations of double suns: the independent synchronous
 42235	discoveries of Galileo, Simon Marius, Piazzi, Le Verrier, Herschel,
 42236	Galle: the systematisations attempted by Bode and Kepler of cubes
 42237	of distances and squares of times of revolution: the almost infinite
 42238	compressibility of hirsute comets and their vast elliptical egressive
 42239	and reentrant orbits from perihelion to aphelion: the sidereal origin of
 42240	meteoric stones: the Libyan floods on Mars about the period of the birth
 42241	of the younger astroscopist: the annual recurrence of meteoric showers
 42242	about the period of the feast of S. Lawrence (martyr, lo August): the
 42243	monthly recurrence known as the new moon with the old moon in her arms:
 42244	the posited influence of celestial on human bodies: the appearance of a
 42245	star (1st magnitude) of exceeding brilliancy dominating by night and
 42246	day (a new luminous sun generated by the collision and amalgamation in
 42247	incandescence of two nonluminous exsuns) about the period of the
 42248	birth of William Shakespeare over delta in the recumbent neversetting
 42249	constellation of Cassiopeia and of a star (2nd magnitude) of similar
 42250	origin but of lesser brilliancy which had appeared in and disappeared
 42251	from the constellation of the Corona Septentrionalis about the period
 42252	of the birth of Leopold Bloom and of other stars of (presumably) similar
 42253	origin which had (effectively or presumably) appeared in and disappeared
 42254	from the constellation of Andromeda about the period of the birth of
 42255	Stephen Dedalus, and in and from the constellation of Auriga some years
 42256	after the birth and death of Rudolph Bloom, junior, and in and from
 42257	other constellations some years before or after the birth or death of
 42258	other persons: the attendant phenomena of eclipses, solar and lunar,
 42259	from immersion to emersion, abatement of wind, transit of shadow,
 42260	taciturnity of winged creatures, emergence of nocturnal or crepuscular
 42261	animals, persistence of infernal light, obscurity of terrestrial waters,
 42262	pallor of human beings.
 42263	
 42264	
 42265	His (Bloom's) logical conclusion, having weighed the matter and allowing
