 42266	for possible error?
 42267	
 42268	That it was not a heaventree, not a heavengrot, not a heavenbeast, not
 42269	a heavenman. That it was a Utopia, there being no known method from
 42270	the known to the unknown: an infinity renderable equally finite by the
 42271	suppositious apposition of one or more bodies equally of the same and of
 42272	different magnitudes: a mobility of illusory forms immobilised in space,
 42273	remobilised in air: a past which possibly had ceased to exist as a
 42274	present before its probable spectators had entered actual present
 42275	existence.
 42276	
 42277	
 42278	Was he more convinced of the esthetic value of the spectacle?
 42279	
 42280	Indubitably in consequence of the reiterated examples of poets in the
 42281	delirium of the frenzy of attachment or in the abasement of rejection
 42282	invoking ardent sympathetic constellations or the frigidity of the
 42283	satellite of their planet.
 42284	
 42285	
 42286	Did he then accept as an article of belief the theory of astrological
 42287	influences upon sublunary disasters?
 42288	
 42289	It seemed to him as possible of proof as of confutation and the
 42290	nomenclature employed in its selenographical charts as attributable to
 42291	verifiable intuition as to fallacious analogy: the lake of dreams, the
 42292	sea of rains, the gulf of dews, the ocean of fecundity.
 42293	
 42294	
 42295	What special affinities appeared to him to exist between the moon and
 42296	woman?
 42297	
 42298	Her antiquity in preceding and surviving successive tellurian
 42299	generations: her nocturnal predominance: her satellitic dependence:
 42300	her luminary reflection: her constancy under all her phases, rising
 42301	and setting by her appointed times, waxing and waning: the forced
 42302	invariability of her aspect: her indeterminate response to inaffirmative
 42303	interrogation: her potency over effluent and refluent waters: her power
 42304	to enamour, to mortify, to invest with beauty, to render insane, to
 42305	incite to and aid delinquency: the tranquil inscrutability of her
 42306	visage: the terribility of her isolated dominant implacable resplendent
 42307	propinquity: her omens of tempest and of calm: the stimulation of her
 42308	light, her motion and her presence: the admonition of her craters, her
 42309	arid seas, her silence: her splendour, when visible: her attraction,
 42310	when invisible.
 42311	
 42312	
 42313	What visible luminous sign attracted Bloom's, who attracted Stephen's,
 42314	gaze?
 42315	
 42316	In the second storey (rere) of his (Bloom's) house the light of a
 42317	paraffin oil lamp with oblique shade projected on a screen of roller
 42318	blind supplied by Frank O'Hara, window blind, curtain pole and revolving
 42319	shutter manufacturer, 16 Aungier street.
 42320	
 42321	
 42322	How did he elucidate the mystery of an invisible attractive person, his
 42323	wife Marion (Molly) Bloom, denoted by a visible splendid sign, a lamp?
 42324	
 42325	With indirect and direct verbal allusions or affirmations: with subdued
 42326	affection and admiration: with description: with impediment: with
 42327	suggestion.
 42328	
 42329	
 42330	Both then were silent?
 42331	
 42332	Silent, each contemplating the other in both mirrors of the reciprocal
 42333	flesh of theirhisnothis fellowfaces.
 42334	
 42335	
 42336	Were they indefinitely inactive?
 42337	
 42338	At Stephen's suggestion, at Bloom's instigation both, first Stephen,
 42339	then Bloom, in penumbra urinated, their sides contiguous, their organs
 42340	of micturition reciprocally rendered invisible by manual circumposition,
 42341	their gazes, first Bloom's, then Stephen's, elevated to the projected
 42342	luminous and semiluminous shadow.
 42343	
 42344	
 42345	Similarly?
 42346	
 42347	The trajectories of their, first sequent, then simultaneous, urinations
 42348	were dissimilar: Bloom's longer, less irruent, in the incomplete form of
 42349	the bifurcated penultimate alphabetical letter, who in his ultimate
 42350	year at High School (1880) had been capable of attaining the point
 42351	of greatest altitude against the whole concurrent strength of the
 42352	institution, 210 scholars: Stephen's higher, more sibilant, who in the
 42353	ultimate hours of the previous day had augmented by diuretic consumption
 42354	an insistent vesical pressure.
 42355	
 42356	
 42357	What different problems presented themselves to each concerning the
 42358	invisible audible collateral organ of the other?
 42359	
 42360	To Bloom: the problems of irritability, tumescence, rigidity,
 42361	reactivity, dimension, sanitariness, pilosity.
 42362	
 42363	To Stephen: the problem of the sacerdotal integrity of Jesus circumcised
 42364	(I January, holiday of obligation to hear mass and abstain from
 42365	unnecessary servile work) and the problem as to whether the divine
 42366	prepuce, the carnal bridal ring of the holy Roman catholic apostolic
 42367	church, conserved in Calcata, were deserving of simple hyperduly or of
 42368	the fourth degree of latria accorded to the abscission of such divine
 42369	excrescences as hair and toenails.
 42370	
 42371	
 42372	What celestial sign was by both simultaneously observed?
 42373	
 42374	A star precipitated with great apparent velocity across the firmament
 42375	from Vega in the Lyre above the zenith beyond the stargroup of the Tress
 42376	of Berenice towards the zodiacal sign of Leo.
 42377	
 42378	
 42379	How did the centripetal remainer afford egress to the centrifugal
 42380	departer?
 42381	
 42382	By inserting the barrel of an arruginated male key in the hole of an
 42383	unstable female lock, obtaining a purchase on the bow of the key and
 42384	turning its wards from right to left, withdrawing a bolt from its
 42385	staple, pulling inward spasmodically an obsolescent unhinged door and
 42386	revealing an aperture for free egress and free ingress.
 42387	
 42388	
 42389	How did they take leave, one of the other, in separation?
 42390	
 42391	Standing perpendicular at the same door and on different sides of its
 42392	base, the lines of their valedictory arms, meeting at any point and
 42393	forming any angle less than the sum of two right angles.
 42394	
 42395	
 42396	What sound accompanied the union of their tangent, the disunion of their
 42397	(respectively) centrifugal and centripetal hands?
 42398	
 42399	The sound of the peal of the hour of the night by the chime of the bells
 42400	in the church of Saint George.
 42401	
 42402	
 42403	What echoes of that sound were by both and each heard?
 42404	
 42405	By Stephen:
 42406	
 42407	_Liliata rutilantium. Turma circumdet. Iubilantium te virginum. Chorus
 42408	excipiat._
 42409	
 42410	By Bloom:
 42411	
 42412	     _Heigho, heigho,
 42413	     Heigho, heigho._
 42414	
 42415	
 42416	Where were the several members of the company which with Bloom that day
 42417	at the bidding of that peal had travelled from Sandymount in the south
 42418	to Glasnevin in the north?
 42419	
 42420	Martin Cunningham (in bed), Jack Power (in bed), Simon Dedalus (in bed),
 42421	Ned Lambert (in bed), Tom Kernan (in bed), Joe Hynes (in bed), John
 42422	Henry Menton (in bed), Bernard Corrigan (in bed), Patsy Dignam (in bed),
 42423	Paddy Dignam (in the grave).
 42424	
 42425	
 42426	Alone, what did Bloom hear?
 42427	
 42428	The double reverberation of retreating feet on the heavenborn earth, the
 42429	double vibration of a jew's harp in the resonant lane.
 42430	
 42431	
 42432	Alone, what did Bloom feel?
 42433	
 42434	The cold of interstellar space, thousands of degrees below freezing
 42435	point or the absolute zero of Fahrenheit, Centigrade or Reaumur: the
 42436	incipient intimations of proximate dawn.
 42437	
 42438	
 42439	Of what did bellchime and handtouch and footstep and lonechill remind
 42440	him?
 42441	
 42442	Of companions now in various manners in different places defunct: Percy
 42443	Apjohn (killed in action, Modder River), Philip Gilligan (phthisis,
 42444	Jervis Street hospital), Matthew F. Kane (accidental drowning, Dublin
 42445	Bay), Philip Moisel (pyemia, Heytesbury street), Michael Hart (phthisis,
 42446	Mater Misericordiae hospital), Patrick Dignam (apoplexy, Sandymount).
 42447	
 42448	
 42449	What prospect of what phenomena inclined him to remain?
 42450	
 42451	The disparition of three final stars, the diffusion of daybreak, the
 42452	apparition of a new solar disk.
 42453	
 42454	
 42455	Had he ever been a spectator of those phenomena?
 42456	
 42457	Once, in 1887, after a protracted performance of charades in the house
 42458	of Luke Doyle, Kimmage, he had awaited with patience the apparition
 42459	of the diurnal phenomenon, seated on a wall, his gaze turned in the
 42460	direction of Mizrach, the east.
 42461	
 42462	
 42463	He remembered the initial paraphenomena?
 42464	
 42465	More active air, a matutinal distant cock, ecclesiastical clocks at
 42466	various points, avine music, the isolated tread of an early wayfarer,
 42467	the visible diffusion of the light of an invisible luminous body, the
 42468	first golden limb of the resurgent sun perceptible low on the horizon.
 42469	
 42470	
 42471	Did he remain?
 42472	
 42473	With deep inspiration he returned, retraversing the garden, reentering
 42474	the passage, reclosing the door. With brief suspiration he reassumed the
 42475	candle, reascended the stairs, reapproached the door of the front room,
 42476	hallfloor, and reentered.
 42477	
 42478	
 42479	What suddenly arrested his ingress?
 42480	
 42481	The right temporal lobe of the hollow sphere of his cranium came into
 42482	contact with a solid timber angle where, an infinitesimal but sensible
 42483	fraction of a second later, a painful sensation was located in
 42484	consequence of antecedent sensations transmitted and registered.
 42485	
 42486	
 42487	Describe the alterations effected in the disposition of the articles of
 42488	furniture.
 42489	
 42490	A sofa upholstered in prune plush had been translocated from opposite
 42491	the door to the ingleside near the compactly furled Union Jack (an
 42492	alteration which he had frequently intended to execute): the blue and
 42493	white checker inlaid majolicatopped table had been placed opposite the
 42494	door in the place vacated by the prune plush sofa: the walnut sideboard
 42495	(a projecting angle of which had momentarily arrested his ingress) had
 42496	been moved from its position beside the door to a more advantageous but
 42497	more perilous position in front of the door: two chairs had been moved
 42498	from right and left of the ingleside to the position originally occupied
 42499	by the blue and white checker inlaid majolicatopped table.
 42500	
 42501	
 42502	Describe them.
 42503	
 42504	One: a squat stuffed easychair, with stout arms extended and back
 42505	slanted to the rere, which, repelled in recoil, had then upturned an
 42506	irregular fringe of a rectangular rug and now displayed on its amply
 42507	upholstered seat a centralised diffusing and diminishing discolouration.
 42508	The other: a slender splayfoot chair of glossy cane curves, placed
 42509	directly opposite the former, its frame from top to seat and from seat
 42510	to base being varnished dark brown, its seat being a bright circle of
 42511	white plaited rush.
 42512	
 42513	
 42514	What significances attached to these two chairs?
 42515	
 42516	Significances of similitude, of posture, of symbolism, of circumstantial
 42517	evidence, of testimonial supermanence.
 42518	
 42519	
 42520	What occupied the position originally occupied by the sideboard?
 42521	
 42522	A vertical piano (Cadby) with exposed keyboard, its closed coffin
 42523	supporting a pair of long yellow ladies' gloves and an emerald ashtray
 42524	containing four consumed matches, a partly consumed cigarette and two
 42525	discoloured ends of cigarettes, its musicrest supporting the music in
 42526	the key of G natural for voice and piano of _Love's Old Sweet Song_
 42527	(words by G. Clifton Bingham, composed by J. L. Molloy, sung by Madam
 42528	Antoinette Sterling) open at the last page with the final indications
 42529	_ad libitum, forte_, pedal, _animato_, sustained pedal, _ritirando_,
 42530	close.
 42531	
 42532	
 42533	With what sensations did Bloom contemplate in rotation these objects?
 42534	
 42535	With strain, elevating a candlestick: with pain, feeling on his right
 42536	temple a contused tumescence: with attention, focussing his gaze on
 42537	a large dull passive and a slender bright active: with solicitation,
 42538	bending and downturning the upturned rugfringe: with amusement,
 42539	remembering Dr Malachi Mulligan's scheme of colour containing the
 42540	gradation of green: with pleasure, repeating the words and antecedent
 42541	act and perceiving through various channels of internal sensibility
 42542	the consequent and concomitant tepid pleasant diffusion of gradual
 42543	discolouration.
 42544	
 42545	
 42546	His next proceeding?
 42547	
 42548	From an open box on the majolicatopped table he extracted a black
 42549	diminutive cone, one inch in height, placed it on its circular base on
 42550	a small tin plate, placed his candlestick on the right corner of the
 42551	mantelpiece, produced from his waistcoat a folded page of prospectus
 42552	(illustrated) entitled Agendath Netaim, unfolded the same, examined
 42553	it superficially, rolled it into a thin cylinder, ignited it in the
 42554	candleflame, applied it when ignited to the apex of the cone till the
 42555	latter reached the stage of rutilance, placed the cylinder in the basin
 42556	of the candlestick disposing its unconsumed part in such a manner as to
 42557	facilitate total combustion.
 42558	
 42559	
 42560	What followed this operation?
 42561	
 42562	The truncated conical crater summit of the diminutive volcano emitted a
 42563	vertical and serpentine fume redolent of aromatic oriental incense.
 42564	
 42565	
 42566	What homothetic objects, other than the candlestick, stood on the
 42567	mantelpiece?
 42568	
 42569	A timepiece of striated Connemara marble, stopped at the hour of 4.46
 42570	a.m. on the 21 March 1896, matrimonial gift of Matthew Dillon: a dwarf
 42571	tree of glacial arborescence under a transparent bellshade, matrimonial
 42572	gift of Luke and Caroline Doyle: an embalmed owl, matrimonial gift of
 42573	Alderman John Hooper.
 42574	
 42575	
 42576	What interchanges of looks took place between these three objects and
 42577	Bloom?
 42578	
 42579	In the mirror of the giltbordered pierglass the undecorated back of the
 42580	dwarf tree regarded the upright back of the embalmed owl. Before
 42581	the mirror the matrimonial gift of Alderman John Hooper with a clear
 42582	melancholy wise bright motionless compassionate gaze regarded Bloom
 42583	while Bloom with obscure tranquil profound motionless compassionated
 42584	gaze regarded the matrimonial gift of Luke and Caroline Doyle.
 42585	
 42586	
 42587	What composite asymmetrical image in the mirror then attracted his
 42588	attention?
 42589	
 42590	The image of a solitary (ipsorelative) mutable (aliorelative) man.
 42591	
 42592	
 42593	Why solitary (ipsorelative)?
 42594	
 42595	_Brothers and sisters had he none. Yet that man's father was his
 42596	grandfather's son._
 42597	
 42598	
 42599	Why mutable (aliorelative)?
 42600	
 42601	From infancy to maturity he had resembled his maternal procreatrix.
 42602	From maturity to senility he would increasingly resemble his paternal
 42603	procreator.
 42604	
 42605	
 42606	What final visual impression was communicated to him by the mirror?
 42607	
 42608	The optical reflection of several inverted volumes improperly arranged
 42609	and not in the order of their common letters with scintillating titles
 42610	on the two bookshelves opposite.
 42611	
 42612	
 42613	Catalogue these books.
 42614	
 42615	_Thom's Dublin Post Office Directory, 1886_. Denis Florence M'Carthy's
 42616	_Poetical Works_ (copper beechleaf bookmark at p. 5). Shakespeare's
 42617	_Works_ (dark crimson morocco, goldtooled).
 42618	
 42619	_The Useful Ready Reckoner_ (brown cloth).
 42620	
 42621	_The Secret History of the Court of Charles II_ (red cloth, tooled
 42622	binding). _The Child's Guide_ (blue cloth).
 42623	
 42624	_The Beauties of Killarney_ (wrappers).
 42625	
 42626	_When We Were Boys_ by William O'Brien M. P. (green cloth, slightly
 42627	faded, envelope bookmark at p. 217).
 42628	
 42629	_Thoughts from Spinoza_ (maroon leather).
 42630	
 42631	_The Story of the Heavens_ by Sir Robert Ball (blue cloth). Ellis's
 42632	_Three Trips to Madagascar_ (brown cloth, title obliterated).
 42633	
 42634	_The Stark-Munro Letters_ by A. Conan Doyle, property of the City of
 42635	Dublin Public Library, 106 Capel street, lent 21 May (Whitsun Eve) 1904,
 42636	due 4 June 1904, 13 days overdue (black cloth binding, bearing white
 42637	letternumber ticket).
 42638	
 42639	_Voyages in China_ by "Viator" (recovered with brown paper, red ink
 42640	title).
 42641	
 42642	_Philosophy of the Talmud_ (sewn pamphlet). Lockhart's _Life of
 42643	Napoleon_ (cover wanting, marginal annotations, minimising victories,
 42644	aggrandising defeats of the protagonist).
 42645	
 42646	_Soll und Haben_ by Gustav Freytag (black boards, Gothic characters,
 42647	cigarette coupon bookmark at p. 24). Hozier's _History of the
 42648	Russo-Turkish War_ (brown cloth, a volumes, with gummed label, Garrison
 42649	Library, Governor's Parade, Gibraltar, on verso of cover).
 42650	
 42651	_Laurence Bloomfield in Ireland_ by William Allingham (second edition,
 42652	green cloth, gilt trefoil design, previous owner's name on recto of
 42653	flyleaf erased).
 42654	
 42655	_A Handbook of Astronomy_ (cover, brown leather, detached, S plates,
 42656	antique letterpress long primer, author's footnotes nonpareil, marginal
 42657	clues brevier, captions small pica).
 42658	
 42659	_The Hidden Life of Christ_ (black boards).
 42660	
 42661	_In the Track of the Sun_ (yellow cloth, titlepage missing, recurrent
 42662	title intestation).
 42663	
 42664	_Physical Strength and How to Obtain It_ by Eugen Sandow (red cloth).
 42665	
 42666	_Short but yet Plain Elements of Geometry_ written in French by F.
 42667	Ignat. Pardies and rendered into English by John Harris D. D. London,
 42668	printed for R. Knaplock at the Bifhop's Head, MDCCXI, with dedicatory
 42669	epiftle to his worthy friend Charles Cox, efquire, Member of Parliament
 42670	for the burgh of Southwark and having ink calligraphed statement on the
 42671	flyleaf certifying that the book was the property of Michael Gallagher,
 42672	dated this 10th day of May 1822 and requefting the perfon who should
 42673	find it, if the book should be loft or go aftray, to reftore it to
 42674	Michael Gallagher, carpenter, Dufery Gate, Ennifcorthy, county Wicklow,
 42675	the fineft place in the world.
 42676	
 42677	
 42678	What reflections occupied his mind during the process of reversion of
 42679	the inverted volumes?
 42680	
 42681	The necessity of order, a place for everything and everything in its
 42682	place: the deficient appreciation of literature possessed by females:
 42683	the incongruity of an apple incuneated in a tumbler and of an umbrella
 42684	inclined in a closestool: the insecurity of hiding any secret document
 42685	behind, beneath or between the pages of a book.
 42686	
 42687	
 42688	Which volume was the largest in bulk?
 42689	
 42690	Hozier's _History of the Russo-Turkish war._
 42691	
 42692	
 42693	What among other data did the second volume of the work in question
 42694	contain?
 42695	
 42696	The name of a decisive battle (forgotten), frequently remembered by a
 42697	decisive officer, major Brian Cooper Tweedy (remembered).
 42698	
 42699	
 42700	Why, firstly and secondly, did he not consult the work in question?
 42701	
 42702	Firstly, in order to exercise mnemotechnic: secondly, because after an
 42703	interval of amnesia, when, seated at the central table, about to consult
 42704	the work in question, he remembered by mnemotechnic the name of the
 42705	military engagement, Plevna.
 42706	
 42707	
 42708	What caused him consolation in his sitting posture?
 42709	
 42710	The candour, nudity, pose, tranquility, youth, grace, sex, counsel of a
 42711	statue erect in the centre of the table, an image of Narcissus purchased
 42712	by auction from P. A. Wren, 9 Bachelor's Walk.
 42713	
 42714	
 42715	What caused him irritation in his sitting posture? Inhibitory pressure
 42716	of collar (size 17) and waistcoat (5 buttons), two articles of clothing
 42717	superfluous in the costume of mature males and inelastic to alterations
 42718	of mass by expansion.
 42719	
 42720	
 42721	How was the irritation allayed?
 42722	
 42723	He removed his collar, with contained black necktie and collapsible
 42724	stud, from his neck to a position on the left of the table. He
 42725	unbuttoned successively in reversed direction waistcoat, trousers, shirt
 42726	and vest along the medial line of irregular incrispated black hairs
 42727	extending in triangular convergence from the pelvic basin over the
 42728	circumference of the abdomen and umbilicular fossicle along the medial
 42729	line of nodes to the intersection of the sixth pectoral vertebrae,
 42730	thence produced both ways at right angles and terminating in circles
 42731	described about two equidistant points, right and left, on the summits
 42732	of the mammary prominences. He unbraced successively each of six minus
 42733	one braced trouser buttons, arranged in pairs, of which one incomplete.
 42734	
 42735	
 42736	What involuntary actions followed?
 42737	
 42738	He compressed between 2 fingers the flesh circumjacent to a cicatrice in
 42739	the left infracostal region below the diaphragm resulting from a sting
 42740	inflicted 2 weeks and 3 days previously (23 May 1904) by a bee.
 42741	He scratched imprecisely with his right hand, though insensible of
 42742	prurition, various points and surfaces of his partly exposed, wholly
 42743	abluted skin. He inserted his left hand into the left lower pocket of
 42744	his waistcoat and extracted and replaced a silver coin (I shilling),
 42745	placed there (presumably) on the occasion (17 October 1903) of the
 42746	interment of Mrs Emily Sinico, Sydney Parade.
 42747	
 42748	
 42749	Compile the budget for 16 June 1904. DEBIT
 42750	
 42751	     1 Pork Kidney
 42752	     1 Copy FREEMAN'S JOURNAL
 42753	     1 Bath And Gratification
 42754	     Tramfare
 42755	     1 In Memoriam Patrick Dignam
 42756	     2 Banbury cakes
 42757	     1 Lunch
 42758	     1 Renewal fee for book
 42759	     1 Packet Notepaper and Envelopes
 42760	     1 Dinner and Gratification
 42761	     1 Postal Order and Stamp
 42762	     Tramfare
 42763	     1 Pig's Foot
 42764	     1 Sheep's Trotter
 42765	     1 Cake Fry's Plain Chocolate
 42766	     1 Square Soda Bread
 42767	     1 Coffee and Bun
 42768	     Loan (Stephen Dedalus) refunded
 42769	     BALANCE
 42770	
 42771	
 42772	     L. s. d.
 42773	     0--0--3
 42774	     0--0--1
 42775	     0--1--6
 42776	     0--0--1
 42777	     0--5--0
 42778	     0--0--1
 42779	     0--0--7
 42780	     0--1--0
 42781	     0--0--2
 42782	     0--2--0
 42783	     0--2--8
 42784	     0--0--1
 42785	     0--0--4
 42786	     0--0--3
 42787	     0--0--1
 42788	     0--0--4
 42789	     0--0--4
 42790	     1--7--0
 42791	     0-17--5
 42792	     2-19--3
 42793	     CREDIT
 42794	
 42795	     Cash in hand
 42796	     Commission recd. _Freeman's Journal_
 42797	     Loan (Stephen Dedalus)
 42798	
 42799	
 42800	
 42801	
 42802	
 42803	     L. s. d.
 42804	     0--4--9
 42805	     1--7--6
 42806	     1--7--0
 42807	
 42808	
 42809	
 42810	
 42811	
 42812	     2-19--3
 42813	
 42814	
 42815	
 42816	
 42817	Did the process of divestiture continue?
 42818	
 42819	Sensible of a benignant persistent ache in his footsoles he extended
 42820	his foot to one side and observed the creases, protuberances and salient
 42821	points caused by foot pressure in the course of walking repeatedly in
 42822	several different directions, then, inclined, he disnoded the laceknots,
 42823	unhooked and loosened the laces, took off each of his two boots for the
 42824	second time, detached the partially moistened right sock through the
 42825	fore part of which the nail of his great toe had again effracted, raised
 42826	his right foot and, having unhooked a purple elastic sock suspender,
 42827	took off his right sock, placed his unclothed right foot on the margin
 42828	of the seat of his chair, picked at and gently lacerated the protruding
 42829	part of the great toenail, raised the part lacerated to his nostrils and
 42830	inhaled the odour of the quick, then, with satisfaction, threw away the
 42831	lacerated ungual fragment.
 42832	
 42833	
 42834	Why with satisfaction?
 42835	
 42836	Because the odour inhaled corresponded to other odours inhaled of other
 42837	ungual fragments, picked and lacerated by Master Bloom, pupil of Mrs
 42838	Ellis's juvenile school, patiently each night in the act of brief
 42839	genuflection and nocturnal prayer and ambitious meditation.
 42840	
 42841	
 42842	In what ultimate ambition had all concurrent and consecutive ambitions
 42843	now coalesced?
 42844	
 42845	Not to inherit by right of primogeniture, gavelkind or borough English,
 42846	or possess in perpetuity an extensive demesne of a sufficient number of
 42847	acres, roods and perches, statute land measure (valuation 42 pounds), of
 42848	grazing turbary surrounding a baronial hall with gatelodge and carriage
 42849	drive nor, on the other hand, a terracehouse or semidetached villa,
 42850	described as _Rus in Urbe_ or _Qui si sana_, but to purchase by private
 42851	treaty in fee simple a thatched bungalowshaped 2 storey dwellinghouse of
 42852	southerly aspect, surmounted by vane and lightning conductor, connected
 42853	with the earth, with porch covered by parasitic plants (ivy or Virginia
 42854	creeper), halldoor, olive green, with smart carriage finish and neat
 42855	doorbrasses, stucco front with gilt tracery at eaves and gable, rising,
 42856	if possible, upon a gentle eminence with agreeable prospect from balcony
 42857	with stone pillar parapet over unoccupied and unoccupyable interjacent
 42858	pastures and standing in 5 or 6 acres of its own ground, at such
 42859	a distance from the nearest public thoroughfare as to render its
 42860	houselights visible at night above and through a quickset hornbeam hedge
 42861	of topiary cutting, situate at a given point not less than 1 statute
 42862	mile from the periphery of the metropolis, within a time limit of not
 42863	more than 15 minutes from tram or train line (e.g., Dundrum, south, or
 42864	Sutton, north, both localities equally reported by trial to resemble the
 42865	terrestrial poles in being favourable climates for phthisical subjects),
 42866	the premises to be held under feefarm grant, lease 999 years, the
 42867	messuage to consist of 1 drawingroom with baywindow (2 lancets),
 42868	thermometer affixed, 1 sittingroom, 4 bedrooms, 2 servants' rooms, tiled
 42869	kitchen with close range and scullery, lounge hall fitted with linen
 42870	wallpresses, fumed oak sectional bookcase containing the Encyclopaedia
 42871	Britannica and New Century Dictionary, transverse obsolete medieval and
 42872	oriental weapons, dinner gong, alabaster lamp, bowl pendant, vulcanite
 42873	automatic telephone receiver with adjacent directory, handtufted
 42874	Axminster carpet with cream ground and trellis border, loo table with
 42875	pillar and claw legs, hearth with massive firebrasses and ormolu mantel
 42876	chronometer clock, guaranteed timekeeper with cathedral chime, barometer
 42877	with hygrographic chart, comfortable lounge settees and corner fitments,
 42878	upholstered in ruby plush with good springing and sunk centre, three
 42879	banner Japanese screen and cuspidors (club style, rich winecoloured
 42880	leather, gloss renewable with a minimum of labour by use of linseed
 42881	oil and vinegar) and pyramidically prismatic central chandelier lustre,
 42882	bentwood perch with fingertame parrot (expurgated language), embossed
 42883	mural paper at 10/- per dozen with transverse swags of carmine floral
 42884	design and top crown frieze, staircase, three continuous flights at
 42885	successive right angles, of varnished cleargrained oak, treads and
 42886	risers, newel, balusters and handrail, with steppedup panel dado,
 42887	dressed with camphorated wax: bathroom, hot and cold supply, reclining
 42888	and shower: water closet on mezzanine provided with opaque singlepane
 42889	oblong window, tipup seat, bracket lamp, brass tierod and brace,
 42890	armrests, footstool and artistic oleograph on inner face of door:
 42891	ditto, plain: servants' apartments with separate sanitary and hygienic
 42892	necessaries for cook, general and betweenmaid (salary, rising by
 42893	biennial unearned increments of 2 pounds, with comprehensive fidelity
 42894	insurance, annual bonus (1 pound) and retiring allowance (based on
 42895	the 65 system) after 30 years' service), pantry, buttery, larder,
 42896	refrigerator, outoffices, coal and wood cellarage with winebin (still
 42897	and sparkling vintages) for distinguished guests, if entertained to
 42898	dinner (evening dress), carbon monoxide gas supply throughout.
 42899	
 42900	
 42901	What additional attractions might the grounds contain?
 42902	
 42903	As addenda, a tennis and fives court, a shrubbery, a glass summerhouse
 42904	with tropical palms, equipped in the best botanical manner, a rockery
 42905	with waterspray, a beehive arranged on humane principles, oval
 42906	flowerbeds in rectangular grassplots set with eccentric ellipses of
 42907	scarlet and chrome tulips, blue scillas, crocuses, polyanthus, sweet
 42908	William, sweet pea, lily of the valley (bulbs obtainable from sir James
 42909	W. Mackey (Limited) wholesale and retail seed and bulb merchants and
 42910	nurserymen, agents for chemical manures, 23 Sackville street, upper), an
 42911	orchard, kitchen garden and vinery protected against illegal trespassers
 42912	by glasstopped mural enclosures, a lumbershed with padlock for various
 42913	inventoried implements.
 42914	
 42915	
 42916	As?
 42917	
 42918	Eeltraps, lobsterpots, fishingrods, hatchet, steelyard, grindstone,
 42919	clodcrusher, swatheturner, carriagesack, telescope ladder, 10 tooth
 42920	rake, washing clogs, haytedder, tumbling rake, billhook, paintpot,
 42921	brush, hoe and so on.
 42922	
 42923	What improvements might be subsequently introduced?
 42924	
 42925	A rabbitry and fowlrun, a dovecote, a botanical conservatory, 2 hammocks
 42926	(lady's and gentleman's), a sundial shaded and sheltered by laburnum
 42927	or lilac trees, an exotically harmonically accorded Japanese tinkle
 42928	gatebell affixed to left lateral gatepost, a capacious waterbutt,
 42929	a lawnmower with side delivery and grassbox, a lawnsprinkler with
 42930	hydraulic hose.
 42931	
 42932	
 42933	What facilities of transit were desirable?
 42934	
 42935	When citybound frequent connection by train or tram from their
 42936	respective intermediate station or terminal. When countrybound
 42937	velocipedes, a chainless freewheel roadster cycle with side basketcar
 42938	attached, or draught conveyance, a donkey with wicker trap or smart
 42939	phaeton with good working solidungular cob (roan gelding, 14 h).
 42940	
 42941	
 42942	What might be the name of this erigible or erected residence?
 42943	
 42944	Bloom Cottage. Saint Leopold's. Flowerville.
 42945	
 42946	
 42947	Could Bloom of 7 Eccles street foresee Bloom of Flowerville?
 42948	
 42949	In loose allwool garments with Harris tweed cap, price 8/6, and useful
 42950	garden boots with elastic gussets and wateringcan, planting aligned
 42951	young firtrees, syringing, pruning, staking, sowing hayseed, trundling a
 42952	weedladen wheelbarrow without excessive fatigue at sunset amid the scent
 42953	of newmown hay, ameliorating the soil, multiplying wisdom, achieving
 42954	longevity.
 42955	
 42956	
 42957	What syllabus of intellectual pursuits was simultaneously possible?
 42958	
 42959	Snapshot photography, comparative study of religions, folklore relative
 42960	to various amatory and superstitious practices, contemplation of the
 42961	celestial constellations.
 42962	
 42963	
 42964	What lighter recreations?
 42965	
 42966	Outdoor: garden and fieldwork, cycling on level macadamised causeways
 42967	ascents of moderately high hills, natation in secluded fresh water and
 42968	unmolested river boating in secure wherry or light curricle with kedge
 42969	anchor on reaches free from weirs and rapids (period of estivation),
 42970	vespertinal perambulation or equestrian circumprocession with inspection
 42971	of sterile landscape and contrastingly agreeable cottagers' fires of
 42972	smoking peat turves (period of hibernation). Indoor: discussion in
 42973	tepid security of unsolved historical and criminal problems: lecture of
 42974	unexpurgated exotic erotic masterpieces: house carpentry with toolbox
 42975	containing hammer, awl nails, screws, tintacks, gimlet, tweezers,
 42976	bullnose plane and turnscrew. Might he become a gentleman farmer of
 42977	field produce and live stock?
 42978	
 42979	Not impossibly, with 1 or 2 stripper cows, 1 pike of upland hay and
 42980	requisite farming implements, e.g., an end-to-end churn, a turnip pulper
 42981	etc.
 42982	
 42983	
 42984	What would be his civic functions and social status among the county
 42985	families and landed gentry?
 42986	
 42987	Arranged successively in ascending powers of hierarchical order, that
 42988	of gardener, groundsman, cultivator, breeder, and at the zenith of his
 42989	career, resident magistrate or justice of the peace with a family crest
 42990	and coat of arms and appropriate classical motto _(Semper paratus_),
 42991	duly recorded in the court directory (Bloom, Leopold P., M. P., P. C.,
 42992	K. P., L. L. D. (_honoris causa_), Bloomville, Dundrum) and mentioned in
 42993	court and fashionable intelligence (Mr and Mrs Leopold Bloom have left
 42994	Kingstown for England).
 42995	
 42996	
 42997	What course of action did he outline for himself in such capacity?
 42998	
 42999	A course that lay between undue clemency and excessive rigour:
 43000	the dispensation in a heterogeneous society of arbitrary classes,
 43001	incessantly rearranged in terms of greater and lesser social inequality,
 43002	of unbiassed homogeneous indisputable justice, tempered with mitigants
 43003	of the widest possible latitude but exactable to the uttermost farthing
 43004	with confiscation of estate, real and personal, to the crown. Loyal to
 43005	the highest constituted power in the land, actuated by an innate love of
 43006	rectitude his aims would be the strict maintenance of public order,
 43007	the repression of many abuses though not of all simultaneously (every
 43008	measure of reform or retrenchment being a preliminary solution to be
 43009	contained by fluxion in the final solution), the upholding of the letter
 43010	of the law (common, statute and law merchant) against all traversers in
 43011	covin and trespassers acting in contravention of bylaws and regulations,
 43012	all resuscitators (by trespass and petty larceny of kindlings) of
 43013	venville rights, obsolete by desuetude, all orotund instigators
 43014	of international persecution, all perpetuators of international
 43015	animosities, all menial molestors of domestic conviviality, all
 43016	recalcitrant violators of domestic connubiality.
 43017	
 43018	
 43019	Prove that he had loved rectitude from his earliest youth.
 43020	
 43021	To Master Percy Apjohn at High School in 1880 he had divulged his
 43022	disbelief in the tenets of the Irish (protestant) church (to which his
 43023	father Rudolf Virag (later Rudolph Bloom) had been converted from the
 43024	Israelitic faith and communion in 1865 by the Society for promoting
 43025	Christianity among the jews) subsequently abjured by him in favour of
 43026	Roman catholicism at the epoch of and with a view to his matrimony
 43027	in 1888. To Daniel Magrane and Francis Wade in 1882 during a juvenile
 43028	friendship (terminated by the premature emigration of the former) he
 43029	had advocated during nocturnal perambulations the political theory of
 43030	colonial (e.g. Canadian) expansion and the evolutionary theories of
 43031	Charles Darwin, expounded in _The Descent of Man_ and _The Origin
 43032	of Species_. In 1885 he had publicly expressed his adherence to the
 43033	collective and national economic programme advocated by James Fintan
 43034	Lalor, John Fisher Murray, John Mitchel, J. F. X. O'Brien and others,
 43035	the agrarian policy of Michael Davitt, the constitutional agitation of
 43036	Charles Stewart Parnell (M. P. for Cork City), the programme of
 43037	peace, retrenchment and reform of William Ewart Gladstone (M. P. for
 43038	Midlothian, N. B.) and, in support of his political convictions, had
 43039	climbed up into a secure position amid the ramifications of a tree
 43040	on Northumberland road to see the entrance (2 February 1888) into the
 43041	capital of a demonstrative torchlight procession of 20,000 torchbearers,
 43042	divided into 120 trade corporations, bearing 2000 torches in escort of
 43043	the marquess of Ripon and (honest) John Morley.
 43044	
 43045	
 43046	How much and how did he propose to pay for this country residence?
 43047	
 43048	As per prospectus of the Industrious Foreign Acclimatised Nationalised
 43049	Friendly Stateaided Building Society (incorporated 1874), a maximum
 43050	of 60 pounds per annum, being 1/6 of an assured income, derived from
 43051	giltedged securities, representing at 5 % simple interest on capital of
 43052	1200 pounds (estimate of price at 20 years' purchase), of which to be
 43053	paid on acquisition and the balance in the form of annual rent, viz. 800
 43054	pounds plus 2 1/2 % interest on the same, repayable quarterly in equal
 43055	annual instalments until extinction by amortisation of loan advanced for
 43056	purchase within a period of 20 years, amounting to an annual rental of
 43057	64 pounds, headrent included, the titledeeds to remain in possession
 43058	of the lender or lenders with a saving clause envisaging forced sale,
 43059	foreclosure and mutual compensation in the event of protracted failure
 43060	to pay the terms assigned, otherwise the messuage to become the absolute
 43061	property of the tenant occupier upon expiry of the period of years
 43062	stipulated.
 43063	
 43064	
 43065	What rapid but insecure means to opulence might facilitate immediate
 43066	purchase?
 43067	
 43068	A private wireless telegraph which would transmit by dot and dash system
 43069	the result of a national equine handicap (flat or steeplechase) of I or
 43070	more miles and furlongs won by an outsider at odds of 50 to 1 at 3 hr
 43071	8 m p.m. at Ascot (Greenwich time), the message being received and
 43072	available for betting purposes in Dublin at 2.59 p.m. (Dunsink time).
 43073	The unexpected discovery of an object of great monetary value (precious
 43074	stone, valuable adhesive or impressed postage stamps (7 schilling,
 43075	mauve, imperforate, Hamburg, 1866: 4 pence, rose, blue paper, perforate,
 43076	Great Britain, 1855: 1 franc, stone, official, rouletted, diagonal
 43077	surcharge, Luxemburg, 1878), antique dynastical ring, unique relic) in
 43078	unusual repositories or by unusual means: from the air (dropped by an
 43079	eagle in flight), by fire (amid the carbonised remains of an incendiated
 43080	edifice), in the sea (amid flotsam, jetsam, lagan and derelict), on
 43081	earth (in the gizzard of a comestible fowl). A Spanish prisoner's
 43082	donation of a distant treasure of valuables or specie or bullion lodged
 43083	with a solvent banking corporation loo years previously at 5% compound
 43084	interest of the collective worth of 5,000,000 pounds stg (five million
 43085	pounds sterling). A contract with an inconsiderate contractee for the
 43086	delivery of 32 consignments of some given commodity in consideration of
 43087	cash payment on delivery per delivery at the initial rate of 1/4d to be
 43088	increased constantly in the geometrical progression of 2 (1/4d, 1/2d,
 43089	1d, 2d, 4d, 8d, 1s 4d, 2s 8d to 32 terms). A prepared scheme
 43090	based on a study of the laws of probability to break the bank at Monte
 43091	Carlo. A solution of the secular problem of the quadrature of the
 43092	circle, government premium 1,000,000 pounds sterling.
 43093	
 43094	
 43095	Was vast wealth acquirable through industrial channels?
 43096	
 43097	The reclamation of dunams of waste arenary soil, proposed in the
 43098	prospectus of Agendath Netaim, Bleibtreustrasse, Berlin, W. 15, by the
 43099	cultivation of orange plantations and melonfields and reafforestation.
 43100	The utilisation of waste paper, fells of sewer rodents, human excrement
 43101	possessing chemical properties, in view of the vast production of the
 43102	first, vast number of the second and immense quantity of the third,
 43103	every normal human being of average vitality and appetite producing
 43104	annually, cancelling byproducts of water, a sum total of 80 lbs. (mixed
 43105	animal and vegetable diet), to be multiplied by 4,386,035, the total
 43106	population of Ireland according to census returns of 1901.
 43107	
 43108	
 43109	Were there schemes of wider scope?
 43110	
 43111	A scheme to be formulated and submitted for approval to the harbour
 43112	commissioners for the exploitation of white coal (hydraulic power),
 43113	obtained by hydroelectric plant at peak of tide at Dublin bar or at
 43114	head of water at Poulaphouca or Powerscourt or catchment basins of main
 43115	streams for the economic production of 500,000 W. H. P. of electricity.
 43116	A scheme to enclose the peninsular delta of the North Bull at Dollymount
 43117	and erect on the space of the foreland, used for golf links and rifle
 43118	ranges, an asphalted esplanade with casinos, booths, shooting galleries,
 43119	hotels, boardinghouses, readingrooms, establishments for mixed bathing.
 43120	A scheme for the use of dogvans and goatvans for the delivery of early
 43121	morning milk. A scheme for the development of Irish tourist traffic in
 43122	and around Dublin by means of petrolpropelled riverboats, plying in the
 43123	fluvial fairway between Island bridge and Ringsend, charabancs, narrow
 43124	gauge local railways, and pleasure steamers for coastwise navigation
 43125	(10/- per person per day, guide (trilingual) included). A scheme for
 43126	the repristination of passenger and goods traffics over Irish waterways,
 43127	when freed from weedbeds. A scheme to connect by tramline the Cattle
 43128	Market (North Circular road and Prussia street) with the quays (Sheriff
 43129	street, lower, and East Wall), parallel with the Link line railway
 43130	laid (in conjunction with the Great Southern and Western railway line)
 43131	between the cattle park, Liffey junction, and terminus of Midland Great
 43132	Western Railway 43 to 45 North
 43133	
 43134	Wall, in proximity to the terminal stations or Dublin branches of Great
 43135	Central Railway, Midland Railway of England, City of Dublin Steam Packet
 43136	Company, Lancashire and Yorkshire Railway Company, Dublin and Glasgow
 43137	Steam Packet Company, Glasgow, Dublin and Londonderry Steam Packet
 43138	Company (Laird line), British and Irish Steam Packet Company, Dublin
 43139	and Morecambe Steamers, London and North Western Railway Company, Dublin
 43140	Port and Docks Board Landing Sheds and transit sheds of Palgrave, Murphy
 43141	and Company, steamship owners, agents for steamers from Mediterranean,
 43142	Spain, Portugal, France, Belgium and Holland and for Liverpool
 43143	Underwriters' Association, the cost of acquired rolling stock for
 43144	animal transport and of additional mileage operated by the Dublin United
 43145	Tramways Company, limited, to be covered by graziers' fees.
 43146	
 43147	
 43148	Positing what protasis would the contraction for such several schemes
 43149	become a natural and necessary apodosis?
 43150	
 43151	Given a guarantee equal to the sum sought, the support, by deed of
 43152	gift and transfer vouchers during donor's lifetime or by bequest
 43153	after donor's painless extinction, of eminent financiers (Blum Pasha,
 43154	Rothschild Guggenheim, Hirsch, Montefiore, Morgan, Rockefeller)
 43155	possessing fortunes in 6 figures, amassed during a successful life, and
 43156	joining capital with opportunity the thing required was done.
 43157	
 43158	
 43159	What eventuality would render him independent of such wealth?
 43160	
 43161	The independent discovery of a goldseam of inexhaustible ore.
 43162	
 43163	
 43164	For what reason did he meditate on schemes so difficult of realisation?
 43165	
 43166	It was one of his axioms that similar meditations or the automatic
 43167	relation to himself of a narrative concerning himself or tranquil
 43168	recollection of the past when practised habitually before retiring for
 43169	the night alleviated fatigue and produced as a result sound repose and
 43170	renovated vitality.
 43171	
 43172	
 43173	His justifications?
 43174	
 43175	As a physicist he had learned that of the 70 years of complete human
 43176	life at least 2/7, viz. 20 years are passed in sleep. As a philosopher
 43177	he knew that at the termination of any allotted life only an
 43178	infinitesimal part of any person's desires has been realised. As a
 43179	physiologist he believed in the artificial placation of malignant
 43180	agencies chiefly operative during somnolence.
 43181	
 43182	
 43183	What did he fear?
 43184	
 43185	The committal of homicide or suicide during sleep by an aberration
 43186	of the light of reason, the incommensurable categorical intelligence
 43187	situated in the cerebral convolutions.
 43188	
 43189	
 43190	What were habitually his final meditations?
 43191	
 43192	Of some one sole unique advertisement to cause passers to stop in
 43193	wonder, a poster novelty, with all extraneous accretions excluded,
 43194	reduced to its simplest and most efficient terms not exceeding the span
 43195	of casual vision and congruous with the velocity of modern life.
 43196	
 43197	
 43198	What did the first drawer unlocked contain?
 43199	
 43200	A Vere Foster's handwriting copybook, property of Milly (Millicent)
 43201	Bloom, certain pages of which bore diagram drawings, marked _Papli_,
 43202	which showed a large globular head with 5 hairs erect, 2 eyes in
 43203	profile, the trunk full front with 3 large buttons, 1 triangular foot: 2
 43204	fading photographs of queen Alexandra of England and of Maud Branscombe,
 43205	actress and professional beauty: a Yuletide card, bearing on it a
 43206	pictorial representation of a parasitic plant, the legend _Mizpah_, the
 43207	date Xmas 1892, the name of the senders: from Mr + Mrs M. Comerford, the
 43208	versicle: _May this Yuletide bring to thee, Joy and peace and welcome
 43209	glee_: a butt of red partly liquefied sealing wax, obtained from the
 43210	stores department of Messrs Hely's, Ltd., 89, 90, and 91 Dame street:
 43211	a box containing the remainder of a gross of gilt "J" pennibs, obtained
 43212	from same department of same firm: an old sandglass which rolled
 43213	containing sand which rolled: a sealed prophecy (never unsealed) written
 43214	by Leopold Bloom in 1886 concerning the consequences of the passing into
 43215	law of William Ewart Gladstone's Home Rule bill of 1886 (never passed
 43216	into law): a bazaar ticket, no 2004, of S. Kevin's Charity Fair, price
 43217	6d, 100 prizes: an infantile epistle, dated, small em monday, reading:
 43218	capital pee Papli comma capital aitch How are you note of interrogation
 43219	capital eye I am very well full stop new paragraph signature with
 43220	flourishes capital em Milly no stop: a cameo brooch, property of Ellen
 43221	Bloom (born Higgins), deceased: a cameo scarfpin, property of Rudolph
 43222	Bloom (born Virag), deceased: 3 typewritten letters, addressee, Henry
 43223	Flower, c/o. P. O. Westland Row, addresser, Martha Clifford, c/o. P. O.
 43224	Dolphin's Barn: the transliterated name and address of the addresser
 43225	of the 3 letters in reversed alphabetic boustrophedonic punctated
 43226	quadrilinear cryptogram (vowels suppressed) N. IGS./WI. UU. OX/W. OKS.
 43227	MH/Y. IM: a press cutting from an English weekly periodical _Modern
 43228	Society_, subject corporal chastisement in girls' schools: a pink ribbon
 43229	which had festooned an Easter egg in the year 1899: two partly uncoiled
 43230	rubber preservatives with reserve pockets, purchased by post from Box
 43231	32, P. O., Charing Cross, London, W. C.: 1 pack of 1 dozen creamlaid
 43232	envelopes and feintruled notepaper, watermarked, now reduced by 3: some
 43233	assorted Austrian-Hungarian coins: 2 coupons of the Royal and Privileged
 43234	Hungarian Lottery: a lowpower magnifying glass: 2 erotic photocards
 43235	showing a) buccal coition between nude senorita (rere presentation,
 43236	superior position) and nude torero (fore presentation, inferior
 43237	position) b) anal violation by male religious (fully clothed, eyes
 43238	abject) of female religious (partly clothed, eyes direct), purchased by
 43239	post from Box 32, P. O., Charing Cross, London, W. C.: a press cutting
 43240	of recipe for renovation of old tan boots: a Id adhesive stamp,
 43241	lavender, of the reign of Queen Victoria: a chart of the measurements
 43242	of Leopold Bloom compiled before, during and after 2 months' consecutive
 43243	use of Sandow-Whiteley's pulley exerciser (men's 15/-, athlete's 20/-)
 43244	viz. chest 28 in and 29 1/2 in, biceps 9 in and 10 in, forearm 8 1/2 in
 43245	and 9 in, thigh 10 in and 12 in, calf 11 in and 12 in: 1 prospectus of
 43246	The Wonderworker, the world's greatest remedy for rectal complaints,
 43247	direct from Wonderworker, Coventry House, South Place, London E C,
 43248	addressed (erroneously) to Mrs L. Bloom with brief accompanying note
 43249	commencing (erroneously): Dear Madam.
 43250	
 43251	
 43252	Quote the textual terms in which the prospectus claimed advantages for
 43253	this thaumaturgic remedy.
 43254	
 43255	It heals and soothes while you sleep, in case of trouble in breaking
 43256	wind, assists nature in the most formidable way, insuring instant relief
 43257	in discharge of gases, keeping parts clean and free natural action, an
 43258	initial outlay of 7/6 making a new man of you and life worth living.
 43259	Ladies find Wonderworker especially useful, a pleasant surprise when
 43260	they note delightful result like a cool drink of fresh spring water on
 43261	a sultry summer's day. Recommend it to your lady and gentlemen friends,
 43262	lasts a lifetime. Insert long round end. Wonderworker.
 43263	
 43264	
 43265	Were there testimonials?
 43266	
 43267	Numerous. From clergyman, British naval officer, wellknown author, city
 43268	man, hospital nurse, lady, mother of five, absentminded beggar.
 43269	
 43270	
 43271	How did absentminded beggar's concluding testimonial conclude?
 43272	
 43273	What a pity the government did not supply our men with wonderworkers
 43274	during the South African campaign! What a relief it would have been!
 43275	
 43276	
 43277	What object did Bloom add to this collection of objects?
 43278	
 43279	A 4th typewritten letter received by Henry Flower (let H. F. be L. B.)
 43280	from Martha Clifford (find M. C.).
 43281	
 43282	
 43283	What pleasant reflection accompanied this action?
 43284	
 43285	The reflection that, apart from the letter in question, his magnetic
 43286	face, form and address had been favourably received during the course of
 43287	the preceding day by a wife (Mrs Josephine Breen, born Josie Powell),
 43288	a nurse, Miss Callan (Christian name unknown), a maid, Gertrude (Gerty,
 43289	family name unknown).
 43290	
 43291	
 43292	What possibility suggested itself?
 43293	
 43294	The possibility of exercising virile power of fascination in the not
 43295	immediate future after an expensive repast in a private apartment in
 43296	the company of an elegant courtesan, of corporal beauty, moderately
 43297	mercenary, variously instructed, a lady by origin.
 43298	
 43299	
 43300	What did the 2nd drawer contain?
 43301	
 43302	Documents: the birth certificate of Leopold Paula Bloom: an endowment
 43303	assurance policy of 500 pounds in the Scottish Widows' Assurance
 43304	Society, intestated Millicent (Milly) Bloom, coming into force at 25
 43305	years as with profit policy of 430 pounds, 462/10/0 and 500 pounds at
 43306	60 years or death, 65 years or death and death, respectively, or
 43307	with profit policy (paidup) of 299/10/0 together with cash payment of
 43308	133/10/0, at option: a bank passbook issued by the Ulster Bank, College
 43309	Green branch showing statement of a/c for halfyear ending 31 December
 43310	1903, balance in depositor's favour: 18/14/6 (eighteen pounds, fourteen
 43311	shillings and sixpence, sterling), net personalty: certificate of
 43312	possession of 900 pounds, Canadian 4 percent (inscribed) government
 43313	stock (free of stamp duty): dockets of the Catholic Cemeteries'
 43314	(Glasnevin) Committee, relative to a graveplot purchased: a local press
 43315	cutting concerning change of name by deedpoll.
 43316	
 43317	
 43318	Quote the textual terms of this notice.
 43319	
 43320	I, Rudolph Virag, now resident at no 52 Clanbrassil street, Dublin,
 43321	formerly of Szombathely in the kingdom of Hungary, hereby give notice
 43322	that I have assumed and intend henceforth upon all occasions and at all
 43323	times to be known by the name of Rudolph Bloom.
 43324	
 43325	
 43326	What other objects relative to Rudolph Bloom (born Virag) were in the
 43327	2nd drawer?
 43328	
 43329	An indistinct daguerreotype of Rudolf Virag and his father Leopold
 43330	Virag executed in the year 1852 in the portrait atelier of their
 43331	(respectively) 1st and 2nd cousin, Stefan Virag of Szesfehervar,
 43332	Hungary. An ancient haggadah book in which a pair of hornrimmed convex
 43333	spectacles inserted marked the passage of thanksgiving in the ritual
 43334	prayers for Pessach (Passover): a photocard of the Queen's Hotel,
 43335	Ennis, proprietor, Rudolph Bloom: an envelope addressed: _To My Dear Son
 43336	Leopold_.
 43337	
 43338	
 43339	What fractions of phrases did the lecture of those five whole words
 43340	evoke?
 43341	
 43342	Tomorrow will be a week that I received... it is no use Leopold to be
 43343	... with your dear mother... that is not more to stand... to her...
 43344	all for me is out... be kind to Athos, Leopold... my dear son...
 43345	always... of me... _das Herz... Gott... dein_...
 43346	
 43347	
 43348	What reminiscences of a human subject suffering from progressive
 43349	melancholia did these objects evoke in Bloom?
 43350	
 43351	An old man, widower, unkempt of hair, in bed, with head covered,
 43352	sighing: an infirm dog, Athos: aconite, resorted to by increasing doses
 43353	of grains and scruples as a palliative of recrudescent neuralgia: the
 43354	face in death of a septuagenarian, suicide by poison.
 43355	
 43356	
 43357	Why did Bloom experience a sentiment of remorse?
 43358	
 43359	Because in immature impatience he had treated with disrespect certain
 43360	beliefs and practices.
 43361	
 43362	
 43363	As?
 43364	
 43365	The prohibition of the use of fleshmeat and milk at one meal: the
 43366	hebdomadary symposium of incoordinately abstract, perfervidly concrete
 43367	mercantile coexreligionist excompatriots: the circumcision of
 43368	male infants: the supernatural character of Judaic scripture: the
 43369	ineffability of the tetragrammaton: the sanctity of the sabbath.
 43370	
 43371	
 43372	How did these beliefs and practices now appear to him?
 43373	
 43374	Not more rational than they had then appeared, not less rational than
 43375	other beliefs and practices now appeared.
 43376	
 43377	
 43378	What first reminiscence had he of Rudolph Bloom (deceased)?
 43379	
 43380	Rudolph Bloom (deceased) narrated to his son Leopold Bloom (aged 6) a
 43381	retrospective arrangement of migrations and settlements in and between
 43382	Dublin, London, Florence, Milan, Vienna, Budapest, Szombathely with
 43383	statements of satisfaction (his grandfather having seen Maria Theresia,
 43384	empress of Austria, queen of Hungary), with commercial advice (having
 43385	taken care of pence, the pounds having taken care of themselves).
 43386	Leopold Bloom (aged 6) had accompanied these narrations by constant
 43387	consultation of a geographical map of Europe (political) and by
 43388	suggestions for the establishment of affiliated business premises in the
 43389	various centres mentioned.
 43390	
 43391	
 43392	Had time equally but differently obliterated the memory of these
 43393	migrations in narrator and listener?
 43394	
 43395	In narrator by the access of years and in consequence of the use of
 43396	narcotic toxin: in listener by the access of years and in consequence of
 43397	the action of distraction upon vicarious experiences.
 43398	
 43399	
 43400	What idiosyncracies of the narrator were concomitant products of
 43401	amnesia?
 43402	
 43403	Occasionally he ate without having previously removed his hat.
 43404	Occasionally he drank voraciously the juice of gooseberry fool from an
 43405	inclined plate. Occasionally he removed from his lips the traces of food
 43406	by means of a lacerated envelope or other accessible fragment of paper.
 43407	
 43408	
 43409	What two phenomena of senescence were more frequent?
 43410	
 43411	The myopic digital calculation of coins, eructation consequent upon
 43412	repletion.
 43413	
 43414	
 43415	What object offered partial consolation for these reminiscences?
 43416	
 43417	The endowment policy, the bank passbook, the certificate of the
 43418	possession of scrip.
 43419	
 43420	
 43421	Reduce Bloom by cross multiplication of reverses of fortune, from which
 43422	these supports protected him, and by elimination of all positive values
 43423	to a negligible negative irrational unreal quantity.
 43424	
 43425	Successively, in descending helotic order: Poverty: that of the outdoor
 43426	hawker of imitation jewellery, the dun for the recovery of bad and
 43427	doubtful debts, the poor rate and deputy cess collector. Mendicancy:
 43428	that of the fraudulent bankrupt with negligible assets paying 1s. 4d.
 43429	in the pound, sandwichman, distributor of throwaways, nocturnal vagrant,
 43430	insinuating sycophant, maimed sailor, blind stripling, superannuated
 43431	bailiffs man, marfeast, lickplate, spoilsport, pickthank, eccentric
 43432	public laughingstock seated on bench of public park under discarded
 43433	perforated umbrella. Destitution: the inmate of Old Man's House (Royal
 43434	Hospital) Kilmainham, the inmate of Simpson's Hospital for reduced but
 43435	respectable men permanently disabled by gout or want of sight. Nadir of
 43436	misery: the aged impotent disfranchised ratesupported moribund lunatic
 43437	pauper.
 43438	
 43439	
 43440	With which attendant indignities?
 43441	
 43442	The unsympathetic indifference of previously amiable females, the
 43443	contempt of muscular males, the acceptance of fragments of bread,
 43444	the simulated ignorance of casual acquaintances, the latration of
 43445	illegitimate unlicensed vagabond dogs, the infantile discharge of
 43446	decomposed vegetable missiles, worth little or nothing, nothing or less
 43447	than nothing.
 43448	
 43449	
 43450	By what could such a situation be precluded?
 43451	
 43452	By decease (change of state): by departure (change of place).
 43453	
 43454	
 43455	Which preferably?
 43456	
 43457	The latter, by the line of least resistance.
 43458	
 43459	
 43460	What considerations rendered departure not entirely undesirable?
 43461	
 43462	Constant cohabitation impeding mutual toleration of personal defects.
 43463	The habit of independent purchase increasingly cultivated. The necessity
 43464	to counteract by impermanent sojourn the permanence of arrest.
 43465	
 43466	
 43467	What considerations rendered departure not irrational?
 43468	
 43469	The parties concerned, uniting, had increased and multiplied, which
 43470	being done, offspring produced and educed to maturity, the parties, if
 43471	not disunited were obliged to reunite for increase and multiplication,
 43472	which was absurd, to form by reunion the original couple of uniting
 43473	parties, which was impossible.
 43474	
 43475	
 43476	What considerations rendered departure desirable?
 43477	
 43478	The attractive character of certain localities in Ireland and abroad,
 43479	as represented in general geographical maps of polychrome design or
 43480	in special ordnance survey charts by employment of scale numerals and
 43481	hachures.
 43482	
 43483	
 43484	In Ireland?
 43485	
 43486	The cliffs of Moher, the windy wilds of Connemara, lough Neagh with
 43487	submerged petrified city, the Giant's Causeway, Fort Camden and Fort
 43488	Carlisle, the Golden Vale of Tipperary, the islands of Aran, the
 43489	pastures of royal Meath, Brigid's elm in Kildare, the Queen's Island
 43490	shipyard in Belfast, the Salmon Leap, the lakes of Killarney.
 43491	
 43492	
 43493	Abroad?
 43494	
 43495	Ceylon (with spicegardens supplying tea to Thomas Kernan, agent for
 43496	Pulbrook, Robertson and Co, 2 Mincing Lane, London, E. C., 5 Dame
 43497	street, Dublin), Jerusalem, the holy city (with mosque of Omar and gate
 43498	of Damascus, goal of aspiration), the straits of Gibraltar (the unique
 43499	birthplace of Marion Tweedy), the Parthenon (containing statues of nude
 43500	Grecian divinities), the Wall street money market (which controlled
 43501	international finance), the Plaza de Toros at La Linea, Spain (where
 43502	O'Hara of the Camerons had slain the bull), Niagara (over which no human
 43503	being had passed with impunity), the land of the Eskimos (eaters
 43504	of soap), the forbidden country of Thibet (from which no traveller
 43505	returns), the bay of Naples (to see which was to die), the Dead Sea.
 43506	
 43507	
 43508	Under what guidance, following what signs?
 43509	
 43510	At sea, septentrional, by night the polestar, located at the point of
 43511	intersection of the right line from beta to alpha in Ursa Maior produced
 43512	and divided externally at omega and the hypotenuse of the rightangled
 43513	triangle formed by the line alpha omega so produced and the line alpha
 43514	delta of Ursa Maior. On land, meridional, a bispherical moon, revealed
 43515	in imperfect varying phases of lunation through the posterior interstice
 43516	of the imperfectly occluded skirt of a carnose negligent perambulating
 43517	female, a pillar of the cloud by day.
 43518	
 43519	
 43520	What public advertisement would divulge the occultation of the departed?
 43521	
 43522	5 pounds reward, lost, stolen or strayed from his residence 7 Eccles
 43523	street, missing gent about 40, answering to the name of Bloom, Leopold
 43524	(Poldy), height 5 ft 9 1/2 inches, full build, olive complexion, may
 43525	have since grown a beard, when last seen was wearing a black suit. Above
 43526	sum will be paid for information leading to his discovery.
 43527	
 43528	
 43529	What universal binomial denominations would be his as entity and
 43530	nonentity?
 43531	
 43532	Assumed by any or known to none. Everyman or Noman.
 43533	
 43534	
 43535	What tributes his?
 43536	
 43537	Honour and gifts of strangers, the friends of Everyman. A nymph
 43538	immortal, beauty, the bride of Noman.
 43539	
 43540	
 43541	Would the departed never nowhere nohow reappear?
 43542	
 43543	Ever he would wander, selfcompelled, to the extreme limit of his
 43544	cometary orbit, beyond the fixed stars and variable suns and telescopic
 43545	planets, astronomical waifs and strays, to the extreme boundary of
 43546	space, passing from land to land, among peoples, amid events. Somewhere
 43547	imperceptibly he would hear and somehow reluctantly, suncompelled, obey
 43548	the summons of recall. Whence, disappearing from the constellation of
 43549	the Northern Crown he would somehow reappear reborn above delta in the
 43550	constellation of Cassiopeia and after incalculable eons of peregrination
 43551	return an estranged avenger, a wreaker of justice on malefactors, a dark
 43552	crusader, a sleeper awakened, with financial resources (by supposition)
 43553	surpassing those of Rothschild or the silver king.
 43554	
 43555	
 43556	What would render such return irrational?
 43557	
 43558	An unsatisfactory equation between an exodus and return in time through
 43559	reversible space and an exodus and return in space through irreversible
 43560	time.
 43561	
 43562	
 43563	What play of forces, inducing inertia, rendered departure undesirable?
 43564	
 43565	The lateness of the hour, rendering procrastinatory: the obscurity
 43566	of the night, rendering invisible: the uncertainty of thoroughfares,
 43567	rendering perilous: the necessity for repose, obviating movement: the
 43568	proximity of an occupied bed, obviating research: the anticipation of
 43569	warmth (human) tempered with coolness (linen), obviating desire and
 43570	rendering desirable: the statue of Narcissus, sound without echo,
 43571	desired desire.
 43572	
 43573	
 43574	What advantages were possessed by an occupied, as distinct from an
 43575	unoccupied bed?
 43576	
 43577	The removal of nocturnal solitude, the superior quality of human
 43578	(mature female) to inhuman (hotwaterjar) calefaction, the stimulation of
 43579	matutinal contact, the economy of mangling done on the premises in the
 43580	case of trousers accurately folded and placed lengthwise between the
 43581	spring mattress (striped) and the woollen mattress (biscuit section).
 43582	
 43583	
 43584	What past consecutive causes, before rising preapprehended, of
 43585	accumulated fatigue did Bloom, before rising, silently recapitulate?
 43586	
 43587	The preparation of breakfast (burnt offering): intestinal congestion and
 43588	premeditative defecation (holy of holies): the bath (rite of John): the
 43589	funeral (rite of Samuel): the advertisement of Alexander Keyes (Urim and
 43590	Thummim): the unsubstantial lunch (rite of Melchisedek): the visit to
 43591	museum and national library (holy place): the bookhunt along Bedford
 43592	row, Merchants' Arch, Wellington Quay (Simchath Torah): the music in the
 43593	Ormond Hotel (Shira Shirim): the altercation with a truculent troglodyte
 43594	in Bernard Kiernan's premises (holocaust): a blank period of time
 43595	including a cardrive, a visit to a house of mourning, a leavetaking
 43596	(wilderness): the eroticism produced by feminine exhibitionism (rite of
 43597	Onan): the prolonged delivery of Mrs Mina Purefoy (heave offering):
 43598	the visit to the disorderly house of Mrs Bella Cohen, 82 Tyrone
 43599	street, lower and subsequent brawl and chance medley in Beaver street
 43600	(Armageddon)--nocturnal perambulation to and from the cabman's shelter,
 43601	Butt Bridge (atonement).
 43602	
 43603	
 43604	What selfimposed enigma did Bloom about to rise in order to go so as to
 43605	conclude lest he should not conclude involuntarily apprehend?
 43606	
 43607	The cause of a brief sharp unforeseen heard loud lone crack emitted by
 43608	the insentient material of a strainveined timber table.
 43609	
 43610	
 43611	What selfinvolved enigma did Bloom risen, going, gathering multicoloured
 43612	multiform multitudinous garments, voluntarily apprehending, not
 43613	comprehend?
 43614	
 43615	Who was M'Intosh?
 43616	
 43617	
 43618	What selfevident enigma pondered with desultory constancy during 30
 43619	years did Bloom now, having effected natural obscurity by the extinction
 43620	of artificial light, silently suddenly comprehend?
 43621	
 43622	Where was Moses when the candle went out?
 43623	
 43624	
 43625	What imperfections in a perfect day did Bloom, walking, charged with
 43626	collected articles of recently disvested male wearing apparel, silently,
 43627	successively, enumerate?
 43628	
 43629	A provisional failure to obtain renewal of an advertisement: to obtain
 43630	a certain quantity of tea from Thomas Kernan (agent for Pulbrook,
 43631	Robertson and Co, 5 Dame Street, Dublin, and 2 Mincing Lane, London E.
 43632	C.): to certify the presence or absence of posterior rectal orifice in
 43633	the case of Hellenic female divinities: to obtain admission (gratuitous
 43634	or paid) to the performance of Leah by Mrs Bandmann Palmer at the Gaiety
 43635	Theatre, 46, 47, 48, 49 South King street.
 43636	
 43637	
 43638	What impression of an absent face did Bloom, arrested, silently recall?
 43639	
 43640	The face of her father, the late Major Brian Cooper Tweedy, Royal Dublin
 43641	Fusiliers, of Gibraltar and Rehoboth, Dolphin's Barn.
 43642	
 43643	
 43644	What recurrent impressions of the same were possible by hypothesis?
 43645	
 43646	Retreating, at the terminus of the Great Northern Railway, Amiens
 43647	street, with constant uniform acceleration, along parallel lines
 43648	meeting at infinity, if produced: along parallel lines, reproduced from
 43649	infinity, with constant uniform retardation, at the terminus of the
 43650	Great Northern Railway, Amiens street, returning.
 43651	
 43652	
 43653	What miscellaneous effects of female personal wearing apparel were
 43654	perceived by him?
 43655	
 43656	A pair of new inodorous halfsilk black ladies' hose, a pair of new
 43657	violet garters, a pair of outsize ladies' drawers of India mull, cut on
 43658	generous lines, redolent of opoponax, jessamine and Muratti's Turkish
 43659	cigarettes and containing a long bright steel safety pin, folded
 43660	curvilinear, a camisole of batiste with thin lace border, an accordion
 43661	underskirt of blue silk moirette, all these objects being disposed
 43662	irregularly on the top of a rectangular trunk, quadruple battened,
 43663	having capped corners, with multicoloured labels, initialled on its fore
 43664	side in white lettering B. C. T. (Brian Cooper Tweedy).
 43665	
 43666	
 43667	What impersonal objects were perceived?
 43668	
 43669	A commode, one leg fractured, totally covered by square cretonne
 43670	cutting, apple design, on which rested a lady's black straw hat.
 43671	Orangekeyed ware, bought of Henry Price, basket, fancy goods, chinaware
 43672	and ironmongery manufacturer, 21, 22, 23 Moore street, disposed
 43673	irregularly on the washstand and floor and consisting of basin, soapdish
 43674	and brushtray (on the washstand, together), pitcher and night article
 43675	(on the floor, separate).
 43676	
 43677	
 43678	Bloom's acts?
 43679	
 43680	He deposited the articles of clothing on a chair, removed his remaining
 43681	articles of clothing, took from beneath the bolster at the head of the
 43682	bed a folded long white nightshirt, inserted his head and arms into the
 43683	proper apertures of the nightshirt, removed a pillow from the head to
 43684	the foot of the bed, prepared the bedlinen accordingly and entered the
 43685	bed.
 43686	
 43687	
 43688	How?
 43689	
 43690	With circumspection, as invariably when entering an abode (his own or
 43691	not his own): with solicitude, the snakespiral springs of the mattress
 43692	being old, the brass quoits and pendent viper radii loose and tremulous
 43693	under stress and strain: prudently, as entering a lair or ambush of
 43694	lust or adders: lightly, the less to disturb: reverently, the bed of
 43695	conception and of birth, of consummation of marriage and of breach of
 43696	marriage, of sleep and of death.
 43697	
 43698	
 43699	What did his limbs, when gradually extended, encounter?
 43700	
 43701	New clean bedlinen, additional odours, the presence of a human form,
 43702	female, hers, the imprint of a human form, male, not his, some crumbs,
 43703	some flakes of potted meat, recooked, which he removed.
 43704	
 43705	
 43706	If he had smiled why would he have smiled?
 43707	
 43708	To reflect that each one who enters imagines himself to be the first to
 43709	enter whereas he is always the last term of a preceding series even if
 43710	the first term of a succeeding one, each imagining himself to be first,
 43711	last, only and alone whereas he is neither first nor last nor only nor
 43712	alone in a series originating in and repeated to infinity.
 43713	
 43714	
 43715	What preceding series?
 43716	
 43717	Assuming Mulvey to be the first term of his series, Penrose, Bartell
 43718	d'Arcy, professor Goodwin, Julius Mastiansky, John Henry Menton, Father
 43719	Bernard Corrigan, a farmer at the Royal Dublin Society's Horse Show,
 43720	Maggot O'Reilly, Matthew Dillon, Valentine Blake Dillon (Lord Mayor
 43721	of Dublin), Christopher Callinan, Lenehan, an Italian organgrinder,
 43722	an unknown gentleman in the Gaiety Theatre, Benjamin Dollard, Simon
 43723	Dedalus, Andrew (Pisser) Burke, Joseph Cuffe, Wisdom Hely, Alderman John
 43724	Hooper, Dr Francis Brady, Father Sebastian of Mount Argus, a bootblack
 43725	at the General Post Office, Hugh E. (Blazes) Boylan and so each and so
 43726	on to no last term.
 43727	
 43728	
 43729	What were his reflections concerning the last member of this series and
 43730	late occupant of the bed?
 43731	
 43732	Reflections on his vigour (a bounder), corporal proportion (a
 43733	billsticker), commercial ability (a bester), impressionability (a
 43734	boaster).
 43735	
 43736	
 43737	Why for the observer impressionability in addition to vigour, corporal
 43738	proportion and commercial ability?
 43739	
 43740	Because he had observed with augmenting frequency in the preceding
 43741	members of the same series the same concupiscence, inflammably
 43742	transmitted, first with alarm, then with understanding, then with
 43743	desire, finally with fatigue, with alternating symptoms of epicene
 43744	comprehension and apprehension.
 43745	
 43746	
 43747	With what antagonistic sentiments were his subsequent reflections
 43748	affected?
 43749	
 43750	Envy, jealousy, abnegation, equanimity.
 43751	
 43752	
 43753	Envy?
 43754	
 43755	Of a bodily and mental male organism specially adapted for the
 43756	superincumbent posture of energetic human copulation and energetic
 43757	piston and cylinder movement necessary for the complete satisfaction of
 43758	a constant but not acute concupiscence resident in a bodily and mental
 43759	female organism, passive but not obtuse.
 43760	
 43761	
 43762	Jealousy?
 43763	
 43764	Because a nature full and volatile in its free state, was alternately
 43765	the agent and reagent of attraction. Because attraction between agent(s)
 43766	and reagent(s) at all instants varied, with inverse proportion of
 43767	increase and decrease, with incessant circular extension and radial
 43768	reentrance. Because the controlled contemplation of the fluctuation of
 43769	attraction produced, if desired, a fluctuation of pleasure.
 43770	
 43771	
 43772	Abnegation?
 43773	
 43774	In virtue of a) acquaintance initiated in September 1903 in the
 43775	establishment of George Mesias, merchant tailor and outfitter, 5 Eden
 43776	Quay, b) hospitality extended and received in kind, reciprocated and
 43777	reappropriated in person, c) comparative youth subject to impulses of
 43778	ambition and magnanimity, colleagual altruism and amorous egoism, d)
 43779	extraracial attraction, intraracial inhibition, supraracial prerogative,
 43780	e) an imminent provincial musical tour, common current expenses, net
 43781	proceeds divided.
 43782	
 43783	
 43784	Equanimity?
 43785	
 43786	As as natural as any and every natural act of a nature expressed or
 43787	understood executed in natured nature by natural creatures in accordance
 43788	with his, her and their natured natures, of dissimilar similarity.
 43789	As not so calamitous as a cataclysmic annihilation of the planet in
 43790	consequence of a collision with a dark sun. As less reprehensible than
 43791	theft, highway robbery, cruelty to children and animals, obtaining money
 43792	under false pretences, forgery, embezzlement, misappropriation of public
 43793	money, betrayal of public trust, malingering, mayhem, corruption of
 43794	minors, criminal libel, blackmail, contempt of court, arson, treason,
 43795	felony, mutiny on the high seas, trespass, burglary, jailbreaking,
 43796	practice of unnatural vice, desertion from armed forces in the field,
 43797	perjury, poaching, usury, intelligence with the king's enemies,
 43798	impersonation, criminal assault, manslaughter, wilful and premeditated
 43799	murder. As not more abnormal than all other parallel processes of
 43800	adaptation to altered conditions of existence, resulting in a reciprocal
 43801	equilibrium between the bodily organism and its attendant circumstances,
 43802	foods, beverages, acquired habits, indulged inclinations, significant
 43803	disease. As more than inevitable, irreparable.
 43804	
 43805	
 43806	Why more abnegation than jealousy, less envy than equanimity?
 43807	
 43808	From outrage (matrimony) to outrage (adultery) there arose nought but
 43809	outrage (copulation) yet the matrimonial violator of the matrimonially
 43810	violated had not been outraged by the adulterous violator of the
 43811	adulterously violated.
 43812	
 43813	
 43814	What retribution, if any?
 43815	
 43816	Assassination, never, as two wrongs did not make one right. Duel by
 43817	combat, no. Divorce, not now. Exposure by mechanical artifice (automatic
 43818	bed) or individual testimony (concealed ocular witnesses), not yet. Suit
 43819	for damages by legal influence or simulation of assault with evidence of
 43820	injuries sustained (selfinflicted), not impossibly. Hushmoney by moral
