 44795	Mulveys was the first when I was in bed that morning and Mrs Rubio
 44796	brought it in with the coffee she stood there standing when I asked her
 44797	to hand me and I pointing at them I couldnt think of the word a hairpin
 44798	to open it with ah horquilla disobliging old thing and it staring her
 44799	in the face with her switch of false hair on her and vain about her
 44800	appearance ugly as she was near 80 or a loo her face a mass of wrinkles
 44801	with all her religion domineering because she never could get over the
 44802	Atlantic fleet coming in half the ships of the world and the Union Jack
 44803	flying with all her carabineros because 4 drunken English sailors took
 44804	all the rock from them and because I didnt run into mass often enough in
 44805	Santa Maria to please her with her shawl up on her except when there was
 44806	a marriage on with all her miracles of the saints and her black blessed
 44807	virgin with the silver dress and the sun dancing 3 times on Easter
 44808	Sunday morning and when the priest was going by with the bell bringing
 44809	the vatican to the dying blessing herself for his Majestad an admirer
 44810	he signed it I near jumped out of my skin I wanted to pick him up when
 44811	I saw him following me along the Calle Real in the shop window then
 44812	he tipped me just in passing but I never thought hed write making an
 44813	appointment I had it inside my petticoat bodice all day reading it up
 44814	in every hole and corner while father was up at the drill instructing to
 44815	find out by the handwriting or the language of stamps singing I remember
 44816	shall I wear a white rose and I wanted to put on the old stupid clock to
 44817	near the time he was the first man kissed me under the Moorish wall my
 44818	sweetheart when a boy it never entered my head what kissing meant till
 44819	he put his tongue in my mouth his mouth was sweetlike young I put my
 44820	knee up to him a few times to learn the way what did I tell him I was
 44821	engaged for for fun to the son of a Spanish nobleman named Don Miguel de
 44822	la Flora and he believed me that I was to be married to him in 3 years
 44823	time theres many a true word spoken in jest there is a flower that
 44824	bloometh a few things I told him true about myself just for him to be
 44825	imagining the Spanish girls he didnt like I suppose one of them wouldnt
 44826	have him I got him excited he crushed all the flowers on my bosom he
 44827	brought me he couldnt count the pesetas and the perragordas till I
 44828	taught him Cappoquin he came from he said on the black water but it was
 44829	too short then the day before he left May yes it was May when the infant
 44830	king of Spain was born Im always like that in the spring Id like a new
 44831	fellow every year up on the tiptop under the rockgun near OHaras tower
 44832	I told him it was struck by lightning and all about the old Barbary apes
 44833	they sent to Clapham without a tail careering all over the show on each
 44834	others back Mrs Rubio said she was a regular old rock scorpion robbing
 44835	the chickens out of Inces farm and throw stones at you if you went anear
 44836	he was looking at me I had that white blouse on open in the front to
 44837	encourage him as much as I could without too openly they were just
 44838	beginning to be plump I said I was tired we lay over the firtree cove
 44839	a wild place I suppose it must be the highest rock in existence the
 44840	galleries and casemates and those frightful rocks and Saint Michaels
 44841	cave with the icicles or whatever they call them hanging down and
 44842	ladders all the mud plotching my boots Im sure thats the way down the
 44843	monkeys go under the sea to Africa when they die the ships out far like
 44844	chips that was the Malta boat passing yes the sea and the sky you could
 44845	do what you liked lie there for ever he caressed them outside they love
 44846	doing that its the roundness there I was leaning over him with my white
 44847	ricestraw hat to take the newness out of it the left side of my face the
 44848	best my blouse open for his last day transparent kind of shirt he had I
 44849	could see his chest pink he wanted to touch mine with his for a moment
 44850	but I wouldnt lee him he was awfully put out first for fear you never
 44851	know consumption or leave me with a child embarazada that old servant
 44852	Ines told me that one drop even if it got into you at all after I tried
 44853	with the Banana but I was afraid it might break and get lost up in me
 44854	somewhere because they once took something down out of a woman that was
 44855	up there for years covered with limesalts theyre all mad to get in there
 44856	where they come out of youd think they could never go far enough up and
 44857	then theyre done with you in a way till the next time yes because theres
 44858	a wonderful feeling there so tender all the time how did we finish it
 44859	off yes O yes I pulled him off into my handkerchief pretending not to
 44860	be excited but I opened my legs I wouldnt let him touch me inside my
 44861	petticoat because I had a skirt opening up the side I tormented the
 44862	life out of him first tickling him I loved rousing that dog in the hotel
 44863	rrrsssstt awokwokawok his eyes shut and a bird flying below us he was
 44864	shy all the same I liked him like that moaning I made him blush a little
 44865	when I got over him that way when I unbuttoned him and took his out and
 44866	drew back the skin it had a kind of eye in it theyre all Buttons men
 44867	down the middle on the wrong side of them Molly darling he called me
 44868	what was his name Jack Joe Harry Mulvey was it yes I think a lieutenant
 44869	he was rather fair he had a laughing kind of a voice so I went round to
 44870	the whatyoucallit everything was whatyoucallit moustache had he he said
 44871	hed come back Lord its just like yesterday to me and if I was married
 44872	hed do it to me and I promised him yes faithfully Id let him block me
 44873	now flying perhaps hes dead or killed or a captain or admiral its nearly
 44874	20 years if I said firtree cove he would if he came up behind me and
 44875	put his hands over my eyes to guess who I might recognise him hes young
 44876	still about 40 perhaps hes married some girl on the black water and is
 44877	quite changed they all do they havent half the character a woman has she
 44878	little knows what I did with her beloved husband before he ever dreamt
 44879	of her in broad daylight too in the sight of the whole world you might
 44880	say they could have put an article about it in the Chronicle I was a bit
 44881	wild after when I blew out the old bag the biscuits were in from Benady
 44882	Bros and exploded it Lord what a bang all the woodcocks and pigeons
 44883	screaming coming back the same way that we went over middle hill round
 44884	by the old guardhouse and the jews burialplace pretending to read out
 44885	the Hebrew on them I wanted to fire his pistol he said he hadnt one he
 44886	didnt know what to make of me with his peak cap on that he always wore
 44887	crooked as often as I settled it straight H M S Calypso swinging my hat
 44888	that old Bishop that spoke off the altar his long preach about womans
 44889	higher functions about girls now riding the bicycle and wearing peak
 44890	caps and the new woman bloomers God send him sense and me more money I
 44891	suppose theyre called after him I never thought that would be my
 44892	name Bloom when I used to write it in print to see how it looked on a
 44893	visiting card or practising for the butcher and oblige M Bloom youre
 44894	looking blooming Josie used to say after I married him well its better
 44895	than Breen or Briggs does brig or those awful names with bottom in them
 44896	Mrs Ramsbottom or some other kind of a bottom Mulvey I wouldnt go mad
 44897	about either or suppose I divorced him Mrs Boylan my mother whoever she
 44898	was might have given me a nicer name the Lord knows after the lovely
 44899	one she had Lunita Laredo the fun we had running along Williss road to
 44900	Europa point twisting in and out all round the other side of Jersey they
 44901	were shaking and dancing about in my blouse like Millys little ones now
 44902	when she runs up the stairs I loved looking down at them I was jumping
 44903	up at the pepper trees and the white poplars pulling the leaves off and
 44904	throwing them at him he went to India he was to write the voyages those
 44905	men have to make to the ends of the world and back its the least they
 44906	might get a squeeze or two at a woman while they can going out to be
 44907	drowned or blown up somewhere I went up Windmill hill to the flats
 44908	that Sunday morning with captain Rubios that was dead spyglass like the
 44909	sentry had he said hed have one or two from on board I wore that frock
 44910	from the B Marche paris and the coral necklace the straits shining I
 44911	could see over to Morocco almost the bay of Tangier white and the Atlas
 44912	mountain with snow on it and the straits like a river so clear Harry
 44913	Molly darling I was thinking of him on the sea all the time after at
 44914	mass when my petticoat began to slip down at the elevation weeks and
 44915	weeks I kept the handkerchief under my pillow for the smell of him there
 44916	was no decent perfume to be got in that Gibraltar only that cheap peau
 44917	dEspagne that faded and left a stink on you more than anything else I
 44918	wanted to give him a memento he gave me that clumsy Claddagh ring for
 44919	luck that I gave Gardner going to south Africa where those Boers killed
 44920	him with their war and fever but they were well beaten all the same as
 44921	if it brought its bad luck with it like an opal or pearl still it must
 44922	have been pure 18 carrot gold because it was very heavy but what could
 44923	you get in a place like that the sandfrog shower from Africa and that
 44924	derelict ship that came up to the harbour Marie the Marie whatyoucallit
 44925	no he hadnt a moustache that was Gardner yes I can see his face
 44926	cleanshaven Frseeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeefrong that train again weeping tone
 44927	once in the dear deaead days beyondre call close my eyes breath my lips
 44928	forward kiss sad look eyes open piano ere oer the world the mists began
 44929	I hate that istsbeg comes loves sweet sooooooooooong Ill let that out
 44930	full when I get in front of the footlights again Kathleen Kearney
 44931	and her lot of squealers Miss This Miss That Miss Theother lot of
 44932	sparrowfarts skitting around talking about politics they know as much
 44933	about as my backside anything in the world to make themselves someway
 44934	interesting Irish homemade beauties soldiers daughter am I ay and whose
 44935	are you bootmakers and publicans I beg your pardon coach I thought you
 44936	were a wheelbarrow theyd die down dead off their feet if ever they got
 44937	a chance of walking down the Alameda on an officers arm like me on the
 44938	bandnight my eyes flash my bust that they havent passion God help their
 44939	poor head I knew more about men and life when I was I S than theyll all
 44940	know at 50 they dont know how to sing a song like that Gardner said no
 44941	man could look at my mouth and teeth smiling like that and not think of
 44942	it I was afraid he mightnt like my accent first he so English all father
 44943	left me in spite of his stamps Ive my mothers eyes and figure anyhow
 44944	he always said theyre so snotty about themselves some of those cads he
 44945	wasnt a bit like that he was dead gone on my lips let them get a husband
 44946	first thats fit to be looked at and a daughter like mine or see if they
 44947	can excite a swell with money that can pick and choose whoever he wants
 44948	like Boylan to do it 4 or 5 times locked in each others arms or the
 44949	voice either I could have been a prima donna only I married him comes
 44950	looooves old deep down chin back not too much make it double My Ladys
 44951	Bower is too long for an encore about the moated grange at twilight and
 44952	vaunted rooms yes Ill sing Winds that blow from the south that he gave
 44953	after the choirstairs performance Ill change that lace on my black dress
 44954	to show off my bubs and Ill yes by God Ill get that big fan mended make
 44955	them burst with envy my hole is itching me always when I think of him I
 44956	feel I want to I feel some wind in me better go easy not wake him have
 44957	him at it again slobbering after washing every bit of myself back belly
 44958	and sides if we had even a bath itself or my own room anyway I wish hed
 44959	sleep in some bed by himself with his cold feet on me give us room even
 44960	to let a fart God or do the least thing better yes hold them like that
 44961	a bit on my side piano quietly sweeeee theres that train far away
 44962	pianissimo eeeee one more song
 44963	
 44964	that was a relief wherever you be let your wind go free who knows if
 44965	that pork chop I took with my cup of tea after was quite good with the
 44966	heat I couldnt smell anything off it Im sure that queerlooking man in
 44967	the porkbutchers is a great rogue I hope that lamp is not smoking fill
 44968	my nose up with smuts better than having him leaving the gas on all
 44969	night I couldnt rest easy in my bed in Gibraltar even getting up to see
 44970	why am I so damned nervous about that though I like it in the winter its
 44971	more company O Lord it was rotten cold too that winter when I was
 44972	only about ten was I yes I had the big doll with all the funny clothes
 44973	dressing her up and undressing that icy wind skeeting across from those
 44974	mountains the something Nevada sierra nevada standing at the fire with
 44975	the little bit of a short shift I had up to heat myself I loved dancing
 44976	about in it then make a race back into bed Im sure that fellow opposite
 44977	used to be there the whole time watching with the lights out in the
 44978	summer and I in my skin hopping around I used to love myself then
 44979	stripped at the washstand dabbing and creaming only when it came to the
 44980	chamber performance I put out the light too so then there were 2 of us
 44981	goodbye to my sleep for this night anyhow I hope hes not going to get in
 44982	with those medicals leading him astray to imagine hes young again coming
 44983	in at 4 in the morning it must be if not more still he had the manners
 44984	not to wake me what do they find to gabber about all night squandering
 44985	money and getting drunker and drunker couldnt they drink water then he
 44986	starts giving us his orders for eggs and tea and Findon haddy and hot
 44987	buttered toast I suppose well have him sitting up like the king of
 44988	the country pumping the wrong end of the spoon up and down in his egg
 44989	wherever he learned that from and I love to hear him falling up the
 44990	stairs of a morning with the cups rattling on the tray and then play
 44991	with the cat she rubs up against you for her own sake I wonder has she
 44992	fleas shes as bad as a woman always licking and lecking but I hate their
 44993	claws I wonder do they see anything that we cant staring like that when
 44994	she sits at the top of the stairs so long and listening as I wait always
 44995	what a robber too that lovely fresh place I bought I think Ill get a bit
 44996	of fish tomorrow or today is it Friday yes I will with some blancmange
 44997	with black currant jam like long ago not those 2 lb pots of mixed plum
 44998	and apple from the London and Newcastle Williams and Woods goes twice as
 44999	far only for the bones I hate those eels cod yes Ill get a nice piece
 45000	of cod Im always getting enough for 3 forgetting anyway Im sick of that
 45001	everlasting butchers meat from Buckleys loin chops and leg beef and rib
 45002	steak and scrag of mutton and calfs pluck the very name is enough or
 45003	a picnic suppose we all gave 5/- each and or let him pay it and invite
 45004	some other woman for him who Mrs Fleming and drove out to the furry glen
 45005	or the strawberry beds wed have him examining all the horses toenails
 45006	first like he does with the letters no not with Boylan there yes with
 45007	some cold veal and ham mixed sandwiches there are little houses down
 45008	at the bottom of the banks there on purpose but its as hot as blazes he
 45009	says not a bank holiday anyhow I hate those ruck of Mary Ann coalboxes
 45010	out for the day Whit Monday is a cursed day too no wonder that bee bit
 45011	him better the seaside but Id never again in this life get into a boat
 45012	with him after him at Bray telling the boatman he knew how to row if
 45013	anyone asked could he ride the steeplechase for the gold cup hed say
 45014	yes then it came on to get rough the old thing crookeding about and the
 45015	weight all down my side telling me pull the right reins now pull the
 45016	left and the tide all swamping in floods in through the bottom and his
 45017	oar slipping out of the stirrup its a mercy we werent all drowned he can
 45018	swim of course me no theres no danger whatsoever keep yourself calm in
 45019	his flannel trousers Id like to have tattered them down off him before
 45020	all the people and give him what that one calls flagellate till he was
 45021	black and blue do him all the good in the world only for that longnosed
 45022	chap I dont know who he is with that other beauty Burke out of the City
 45023	Arms hotel was there spying around as usual on the slip always where he
 45024	wasnt wanted if there was a row on youd vomit a better face there was no
 45025	love lost between us thats 1 consolation I wonder what kind is that book
 45026	he brought me Sweets of Sin by a gentleman of fashion some other Mr de
 45027	Kock I suppose the people gave him that nickname going about with his
 45028	tube from one woman to another I couldnt even change my new white shoes
 45029	all ruined with the saltwater and the hat I had with that feather all
 45030	blowy and tossed on me how annoying and provoking because the smell of
 45031	the sea excited me of course the sardines and the bream in Catalan bay
 45032	round the back of the rock they were fine all silver in the fishermens
 45033	baskets old Luigi near a hundred they said came from Genoa and the tall
 45034	old chap with the earrings I dont like a man you have to climb up to to
 45035	get at I suppose theyre all dead and rotten long ago besides I dont like
 45036	being alone in this big barracks of a place at night I suppose Ill have
 45037	to put up with it I never brought a bit of salt in even when we moved
 45038	in the confusion musical academy he was going to make on the first floor
 45039	drawingroom with a brassplate or Blooms private hotel he suggested go
 45040	and ruin himself altogether the way his father did down in Ennis like
 45041	all the things he told father he was going to do and me but I saw
 45042	through him telling me all the lovely places we could go for the
 45043	honeymoon Venice by moonlight with the gondolas and the lake of Como he
 45044	had a picture cut out of some paper of and mandolines and lanterns O
 45045	how nice I said whatever I liked he was going to do immediately if
 45046	not sooner will you be my man will you carry my can he ought to get a
 45047	leather medal with a putty rim for all the plans he invents then leaving
 45048	us here all day youd never know what old beggar at the door for a crust
 45049	with his long story might be a tramp and put his foot in the way to
 45050	prevent me shutting it like that picture of that hardened criminal he
 45051	was called in Lloyds Weekly news 20 years in jail then he comes out and
 45052	murders an old woman for her money imagine his poor wife or mother or
 45053	whoever she is such a face youd run miles away from I couldnt rest easy
 45054	till I bolted all the doors and windows to make sure but its worse again
 45055	being locked up like in a prison or a madhouse they ought to be all shot
 45056	or the cat of nine tails a big brute like that that would attack a poor
 45057	old woman to murder her in her bed Id cut them off him so I would not
 45058	that hed be much use still better than nothing the night I was sure
 45059	I heard burglars in the kitchen and he went down in his shirt with a
 45060	candle and a poker as if he was looking for a mouse as white as a sheet
 45061	frightened out of his wits making as much noise as he possibly could
 45062	for the burglars benefit there isnt much to steal indeed the Lord knows
 45063	still its the feeling especially now with Milly away such an idea for
 45064	him to send the girl down there to learn to take photographs on account
 45065	of his grandfather instead of sending her to Skerrys academy where shed
 45066	have to learn not like me getting all IS at school only hed do a thing
 45067	like that all the same on account of me and Boylan thats why he did
 45068	it Im certain the way he plots and plans everything out I couldnt turn
 45069	round with her in the place lately unless I bolted the door first gave
 45070	me the fidgets coming in without knocking first when I put the chair
 45071	against the door just as I was washing myself there below with the glove
 45072	get on your nerves then doing the loglady all day put her in a glasscase
 45073	with two at a time to look at her if he knew she broke off the hand off
 45074	that little gimcrack statue with her roughness and carelessness before
 45075	she left that I got that little Italian boy to mend so that you cant
 45076	see the join for 2 shillings wouldnt even teem the potatoes for you of
 45077	course shes right not to ruin her hands I noticed he was always talking
 45078	to her lately at the table explaining things in the paper and she
 45079	pretending to understand sly of course that comes from his side of the
 45080	house he cant say I pretend things can he Im too honest as a matter of
 45081	fact and helping her into her coat but if there was anything wrong with
 45082	her its me shed tell not him I suppose he thinks Im finished out and
 45083	laid on the shelf well Im not no nor anything like it well see well see
 45084	now shes well on for flirting too with Tom Devans two sons imitating
 45085	me whistling with those romps of Murray girls calling for her can Milly
 45086	come out please shes in great demand to pick what they can out of her
 45087	round in Nelson street riding Harry Devans bicycle at night its as well
 45088	he sent her where she is she was just getting out of bounds wanting to
 45089	go on the skatingrink and smoking their cigarettes through their nose I
 45090	smelt it off her dress when I was biting off the thread of the button
 45091	I sewed on to the bottom of her jacket she couldnt hide much from me I
 45092	tell you only I oughtnt to have stitched it and it on her it brings a
 45093	parting and the last plumpudding too split in 2 halves see it comes out
 45094	no matter what they say her tongue is a bit too long for my taste
 45095	your blouse is open too low she says to me the pan calling the kettle
 45096	blackbottom and I had to tell her not to cock her legs up like that on
 45097	show on the windowsill before all the people passing they all look at
 45098	her like me when I was her age of course any old rag looks well on
 45099	you then a great touchmenot too in her own way at the Only Way in the
 45100	Theatre royal take your foot away out of that I hate people touching
 45101	me afraid of her life Id crush her skirt with the pleats a lot of that
 45102	touching must go on in theatres in the crush in the dark theyre always
 45103	trying to wiggle up to you that fellow in the pit at the Gaiety for
 45104	Beerbohm Tree in Trilby the last time Ill ever go there to be squashed
 45105	like that for any Trilby or her barebum every two minutes tipping me
 45106	there and looking away hes a bit daft I think I saw him after trying to
 45107	get near two stylishdressed ladies outside Switzers window at the same
 45108	little game I recognised him on the moment the face and everything but
 45109	he didnt remember me yes and she didnt even want me to kiss her at the
 45110	Broadstone going away well I hope shell get someone to dance attendance
 45111	on her the way I did when she was down with the mumps and her glands
 45112	swollen wheres this and wheres that of course she cant feel anything
 45113	deep yet I never came properly till I was what 22 or so it went into the
 45114	wrong place always only the usual girls nonsense and giggling that
 45115	Conny Connolly writing to her in white ink on black paper sealed with
 45116	sealingwax though she clapped when the curtain came down because he
 45117	looked so handsome then we had Martin Harvey for breakfast dinner and
 45118	supper I thought to myself afterwards it must be real love if a man
 45119	gives up his life for her that way for nothing I suppose there are a
 45120	few men like that left its hard to believe in it though unless it really
 45121	happened to me the majority of them with not a particle of love in their
 45122	natures to find two people like that nowadays full up of each other that
 45123	would feel the same way as you do theyre usually a bit foolish in the
 45124	head his father must have been a bit queer to go and poison himself
 45125	after her still poor old man I suppose he felt lost shes always making
 45126	love to my things too the few old rags I have wanting to put her hair up
 45127	at I S my powder too only ruin her skin on her shes time enough for that
 45128	all her life after of course shes restless knowing shes pretty with her
 45129	lips so red a pity they wont stay that way I was too but theres no use
 45130	going to the fair with the thing answering me like a fishwoman when
 45131	I asked to go for a half a stone of potatoes the day we met Mrs Joe
 45132	Gallaher at the trottingmatches and she pretended not to see us in her
 45133	trap with Friery the solicitor we werent grand enough till I gave her 2
 45134	damn fine cracks across the ear for herself take that now for answering
 45135	me like that and that for your impudence she had me that exasperated of
 45136	course contradicting I was badtempered too because how was it there was
 45137	a weed in the tea or I didnt sleep the night before cheese I ate was it
 45138	and I told her over and over again not to leave knives crossed like that
 45139	because she has nobody to command her as she said herself well if he
 45140	doesnt correct her faith I will that was the last time she turned on the
 45141	teartap I was just like that myself they darent order me about the place
 45142	its his fault of course having the two of us slaving here instead of
 45143	getting in a woman long ago am I ever going to have a proper servant
 45144	again of course then shed see him coming Id have to let her know or shed
 45145	revenge it arent they a nuisance that old Mrs Fleming you have to be
 45146	walking round after her putting the things into her hands sneezing and
 45147	farting into the pots well of course shes old she cant help it a good
 45148	job I found that rotten old smelly dishcloth that got lost behind the
 45149	dresser I knew there was something and opened the area window to let out
 45150	the smell bringing in his friends to entertain them like the night he
 45151	walked home with a dog if you please that might have been mad especially
 45152	Simon Dedalus son his father such a criticiser with his glasses up with
 45153	his tall hat on him at the cricket match and a great big hole in his
 45154	sock one thing laughing at the other and his son that got all those
 45155	prizes for whatever he won them in the intermediate imagine climbing
 45156	over the railings if anybody saw him that knew us I wonder he didnt tear
 45157	a big hole in his grand funeral trousers as if the one nature gave wasnt
 45158	enough for anybody hawking him down into the dirty old kitchen now is he
 45159	right in his head I ask pity it wasnt washing day my old pair of drawers
 45160	might have been hanging up too on the line on exhibition for all hed
 45161	ever care with the ironmould mark the stupid old bundle burned on them
 45162	he might think was something else and she never even rendered down the
 45163	fat I told her and now shes going such as she was on account of her
 45164	paralysed husband getting worse theres always something wrong with them
 45165	disease or they have to go under an operation or if its not that its
 45166	drink and he beats her Ill have to hunt around again for someone every
 45167	day I get up theres some new thing on sweet God sweet God well when Im
 45168	stretched out dead in my grave I suppose 111 have some peace I want to
 45169	get up a minute if Im let wait O Jesus wait yes that thing has come on
 45170	me yes now wouldnt that afflict you of course all the poking and rooting
 45171	and ploughing he had up in me now what am I to do Friday Saturday Sunday
 45172	wouldnt that pester the soul out of a body unless he likes it some men
 45173	do God knows theres always something wrong with us 5 days every 3 or 4
 45174	weeks usual monthly auction isnt it simply sickening that night it came
 45175	on me like that the one and only time we were in a box that Michael Gunn
 45176	gave him to see Mrs Kendal and her husband at the Gaiety something he
 45177	did about insurance for him in Drimmies I was fit to be tied though I
 45178	wouldnt give in with that gentleman of fashion staring down at me with
 45179	his glasses and him the other side of me talking about Spinoza and his
 45180	soul thats dead I suppose millions of years ago I smiled the best I
 45181	could all in a swamp leaning forward as if I was interested having to
 45182	sit it out then to the last tag I wont forget that wife of Scarli in
 45183	a hurry supposed to be a fast play about adultery that idiot in the
 45184	gallery hissing the woman adulteress he shouted I suppose he went and
 45185	had a woman in the next lane running round all the back ways after
 45186	to make up for it I wish he had what I had then hed boo I bet the cat
 45187	itself is better off than us have we too much blood up in us or what O
 45188	patience above its pouring out of me like the sea anyhow he didnt make
 45189	me pregnant as big as he is I dont want to ruin the clean sheets I just
 45190	put on I suppose the clean linen I wore brought it on too damn it damn
 45191	it and they always want to see a stain on the bed to know youre a virgin
 45192	for them all thats troubling them theyre such fools too you could be a
 45193	widow or divorced 40 times over a daub of red ink would do or blackberry
 45194	juice no thats too purply O Jamesy let me up out of this pooh sweets of
 45195	sin whoever suggested that business for women what between clothes and
 45196	cooking and children this damned old bed too jingling like the dickens
 45197	I suppose they could hear us away over the other side of the park till I
 45198	suggested to put the quilt on the floor with the pillow under my bottom
 45199	I wonder is it nicer in the day I think it is easy I think Ill cut
 45200	all this hair off me there scalding me I might look like a young girl
 45201	wouldnt he get the great suckin the next time he turned up my clothes on
 45202	me Id give anything to see his face wheres the chamber gone easy Ive a
 45203	holy horror of its breaking under me after that old commode I wonder
 45204	was I too heavy sitting on his knee I made him sit on the easychair
 45205	purposely when I took off only my blouse and skirt first in the other
 45206	room he was so busy where he oughtnt to be he never felt me I hope my
 45207	breath was sweet after those kissing comfits easy God I remember one
 45208	time I could scout it out straight whistling like a man almost easy O
 45209	Lord how noisy I hope theyre bubbles on it for a wad of money from some
 45210	fellow 111 have to perfume it in the morning dont forget I bet he
 45211	never saw a better pair of thighs than that look how white they are the

 45213	peach easy God I wouldnt mind being a man and get up on a lovely woman

 45217	who knows is there anything the matter with my insides or have I
 45218	something growing in me getting that thing like that every week when was
 45219	it last I Whit Monday yes its only about 3 weeks I ought to go to the
 45220	doctor only it would be like before I married him when I had that white
 45221	thing coming from me and Floey made me go to that dry old stick Dr
 45222	Collins for womens diseases on Pembroke road your vagina he called it I
 45223	suppose thats how he got all the gilt mirrors and carpets getting round
 45224	those rich ones off Stephens green running up to him for every little
 45225	fiddlefaddle her vagina and her cochinchina theyve money of course so
 45226	theyre all right I wouldnt marry him not if he was the last man in
 45227	the world besides theres something queer about their children always
 45228	smelling around those filthy bitches all sides asking me if what I did
 45229	had an offensive odour what did he want me to do but the one thing gold
 45230	maybe what a question if I smathered it all over his wrinkly old face
 45231	for him with all my compriments I suppose hed know then and could you
 45232	pass it easily pass what I thought he was talking about the rock of
 45233	Gibraltar the way he put it thats a very nice invention too by the
 45234	way only I like letting myself down after in the hole as far as I can
 45235	squeeze and pull the chain then to flush it nice cool pins and needles
 45236	still theres something in it I suppose I always used to know by Millys
 45237	when she was a child whether she had worms or not still all the same
 45238	paying him for that how much is that doctor one guinea please and asking
 45239	me had I frequent omissions where do those old fellows get all the words
 45240	they have omissions with his shortsighted eyes on me cocked sideways I
 45241	wouldnt trust him too far to give me chloroform or God knows what else
 45242	still I liked him when he sat down to write the thing out frowning so
 45243	severe his nose intelligent like that you be damned you lying strap O
 45244	anything no matter who except an idiot he was clever enough to spot
 45245	that of course that was all thinking of him and his mad crazy letters
 45246	my Precious one everything connected with your glorious Body everything
 45247	underlined that comes from it is a thing of beauty and of joy for ever
 45248	something he got out of some nonsensical book that he had me always at
 45249	myself 4 and 5 times a day sometimes and I said I hadnt are you sure
 45250	O yes I said I am quite sure in a way that shut him up I knew what was
 45251	coming next only natural weakness it was he excited me I dont know how
 45252	the first night ever we met when I was living in Rehoboth terrace we
 45253	stood staring at one another for about lo minutes as if we met somewhere
 45254	I suppose on account of my being jewess looking after my mother he used
 45255	to amuse me the things he said with the half sloothering smile on him
 45256	and all the Doyles said he was going to stand for a member of Parliament
 45257	O wasnt I the born fool to believe all his blather about home rule
 45258	and the land league sending me that long strool of a song out of the
 45259	Huguenots to sing in French to be more classy O beau pays de la Touraine
 45260	that I never even sang once explaining and rigmaroling about religion
 45261	and persecution he wont let you enjoy anything naturally then might he
 45262	as a great favour the very 1st opportunity he got a chance in Brighton
 45263	square running into my bedroom pretending the ink got on his hands to
 45264	wash it off with the Albion milk and sulphur soap I used to use and the
 45265	gelatine still round it O I laughed myself sick at him that day I better
 45266	not make an alnight sitting on this affair they ought to make chambers a
 45267	natural size so that a woman could sit on it properly he kneels down to
 45268	do it I suppose there isnt in all creation another man with the habits
 45269	he has look at the way hes sleeping at the foot of the bed how can he
 45270	without a hard bolster its well he doesnt kick or he might knock out
 45271	all my teeth breathing with his hand on his nose like that Indian god
 45272	he took me to show one wet Sunday in the museum in Kildare street all
 45273	yellow in a pinafore lying on his side on his hand with his ten toes
 45274	sticking out that he said was a bigger religion than the jews and
 45275	Our Lords both put together all over Asia imitating him as hes always
 45276	imitating everybody I suppose he used to sleep at the foot of the bed
 45277	too with his big square feet up in his wifes mouth damn this stinking
 45278	thing anyway wheres this those napkins are ah yes I know I hope the old
 45279	press doesnt creak ah I knew it would hes sleeping hard had a good time
 45280	somewhere still she must have given him great value for his money of
 45281	course he has to pay for it from her O this nuisance of a thing I hope
 45282	theyll have something better for us in the other world tying ourselves
 45283	up God help us thats all right for tonight now the lumpy old jingly
 45284	bed always reminds me of old Cohen I suppose he scratched himself in it
 45285	often enough and he thinks father bought it from Lord Napier that I used
 45286	to admire when I was a little girl because I told him easy piano O
 45287	I like my bed God here we are as bad as ever after 16 years how many
 45288	houses were we in at all Raymond terrace and Ontario terrace and Lombard
 45289	street and Holles street and he goes about whistling every time were on
 45290	the run again his huguenots or the frogs march pretending to help the
 45291	men with our 4 sticks of furniture and then the City Arms hotel worse
 45292	and worse says Warden Daly that charming place on the landing always
 45293	somebody inside praying then leaving all their stinks after them
 45294	always know who was in there last every time were just getting on right
 45295	something happens or he puts his big foot in it Thoms and Helys and Mr
 45296	Cuffes and Drimmies either hes going to be run into prison over his old
 45297	lottery tickets that was to be all our salvations or he goes and gives
 45298	impudence well have him coming home with the sack soon out of the
 45299	Freeman too like the rest on account of those Sinner Fein or the
 45300	freemasons then well see if the little man he showed me dribbling
 45301	along in the wet all by himself round by Coadys lane will give him much
 45302	consolation that he says is so capable and sincerely Irish he is indeed
 45303	judging by the sincerity of the trousers I saw on him wait theres
 45304	Georges church bells wait 3 quarters the hour l wait 2 oclock well
 45305	thats a nice hour of the night for him to be coming home at to anybody
 45306	climbing down into the area if anybody saw him Ill knock him off that
 45307	little habit tomorrow first Ill look at his shirt to see or Ill see if
 45308	he has that French letter still in his pocketbook I suppose he thinks I
 45309	dont know deceitful men all their 20 pockets arent enough for their lies
 45310	then why should we tell them even if its the truth they dont believe you
 45311	then tucked up in bed like those babies in the Aristocrats Masterpiece
 45312	he brought me another time as if we hadnt enough of that in real life
 45313	without some old Aristocrat or whatever his name is disgusting you more
 45314	with those rotten pictures children with two heads and no legs thats the
 45315	kind of villainy theyre always dreaming about with not another thing in
 45316	their empty heads they ought to get slow poison the half of them then
 45317	tea and toast for him buttered on both sides and newlaid eggs I suppose
 45318	Im nothing any more when I wouldnt let him lick me in Holles street one
 45319	night man man tyrant as ever for the one thing he slept on the floor
 45320	half the night naked the way the jews used when somebody dies belonged
 45321	to them and wouldnt eat any breakfast or speak a word wanting to be
 45322	petted so I thought I stood out enough for one time and let him he does
 45323	it all wrong too thinking only of his own pleasure his tongue is too
 45324	flat or I dont know what he forgets that wethen I dont Ill make him do
 45325	it again if he doesnt mind himself and lock him down to sleep in the
 45326	coalcellar with the blackbeetles I wonder was it her Josie off her head
 45327	with my castoffs hes such a born liar too no hed never have the courage
 45328	with a married woman thats why he wants me and Boylan though as for her
 45329	Denis as she calls him that forlornlooking spectacle you couldnt call
 45330	him a husband yes its some little bitch hes got in with even when I was
 45331	with him with Milly at the College races that Hornblower with the childs
 45332	bonnet on the top of his nob let us into by the back way he was throwing
 45333	his sheeps eyes at those two doing skirt duty up and down I tried to
 45334	wink at him first no use of course and thats the way his money goes this
 45335	is the fruits of Mr Paddy Dignam yes they were all in great style at the
 45336	grand funeral in the paper Boylan brought in if they saw a real officers

 45344	way like dabbling on a rainy day I see it all now plainly and they call
 45345	that friendship killing and then burying one another and they all with

 45347	barmaid he does of course his wife is always sick or going to be sick
 45348	or just getting better of it and hes a goodlooking man still though
 45349	hes getting a bit grey over the ears theyre a nice lot all of them well

 45352	on with his idiotics because he has sense enough not to squander every

 45356	insured comical little teetotum always stuck up in some pub corner and

 45359	youre goodlooking what men wasnt he yes he was at the Glencree dinner
 45360	and Ben Dollard base barreltone the night he borrowed the swallowtail
 45361	to sing out of in Holles street squeezed and squashed into them and
 45362	grinning all over his big Dolly face like a wellwhipped childs botty
 45363	didnt he look a balmy ballocks sure enough that must have been a
 45364	spectacle on the stage imagine paying 5/- in the preserved seats for
 45365	that to see him trotting off in his trowlers and Simon Dedalus too he
 45366	was always turning up half screwed singing the second verse first the
 45367	old love is the new was one of his so sweetly sang the maiden on the
 45368	hawthorn bough he was always on for flirtyfying too when I sang Maritana
 45369	with him at Freddy Mayers private opera he had a delicious glorious
 45370	voice Phoebe dearest goodbye _sweet_heart sweetheart he always sang it
 45371	not like Bartell Darcy sweet tart goodbye of course he had the gift of
 45372	the voice so there was no art in it all over you like a warm showerbath
 45373	O Maritana wildwood flower we sang splendidly though it was a bit too
 45374	high for my register even transposed and he was married at the time to
 45375	May Goulding but then hed say or do something to knock the good out of
 45376	it hes a widower now I wonder what sort is his son he says hes an author
 45377	and going to be a university professor of Italian and Im to take lessons
 45378	what is he driving at now showing him my photo its not good of me I
 45379	ought to have got it taken in drapery that never looks out of fashion
 45380	still I look young in it I wonder he didnt make him a present of it
 45381	altogether and me too after all why not I saw him driving down to the
 45382	Kingsbridge station with his father and mother I was in mourning thats
 45383	11 years ago now yes hed be 11 though what was the good in going into
 45384	mourning for what was neither one thing nor the other the first cry was
 45385	enough for me I heard the deathwatch too ticking in the wall of course
 45386	he insisted hed go into mourning for the cat I suppose hes a man now by
 45387	this time he was an innocent boy then and a darling little fellow in his
 45388	lord Fauntleroy suit and curly hair like a prince on the stage when I
 45389	saw him at Mat Dillons he liked me too I remember they all do wait by
 45390	God yes wait yes hold on he was on the cards this morning when I laid
 45391	out the deck union with a young stranger neither dark nor fair you met
 45392	before I thought it meant him but hes no chicken nor a stranger either
 45393	besides my face was turned the other way what was the 7th card after
 45394	that the 10 of spades for a journey by land then there was a letter on
 45395	its way and scandals too the 3 queens and the 8 of diamonds for a rise
 45396	in society yes wait it all came out and 2 red 8s for new garments look

 45398	poetry in it I hope he hasnt long greasy hair hanging into his eyes or
 45399	standing up like a red Indian what do they go about like that for only
 45400	getting themselves and their poetry laughed at I always liked poetry
 45401	when I was a girl first I thought he was a poet like lord Byron and not
 45402	an ounce of it in his composition I thought he was quite different I
 45403	wonder is he too young hes about wait 88 I was married 88 Milly is 15
 45404	yesterday 89 what age was he then at Dillons 5 or 6 about 88 I suppose

 45407	down in the old kitchen with him taking Eppss cocoa and talking of

 45409	out of Trinity college hes very young to be a professor I hope hes not

 45413	poetry is in the air the blue sea and the moon shining so beautifully
 45414	coming back on the nightboat from Tarifa the lighthouse at Europa point

 45418	bright as loves own star arent those beautiful words as loves young star

 45429	his finger up for you to listen theres real beauty and poetry for you

 45440	the lady herself and see if he comes out Ill read and study all I can

 45520	like they do or gambling every penny they have and losing it on horses

 45635	in Lombard street was much nicer the apron he gave me was like that
 45636	something only I only wore it twice better lower this lamp and try again
 45637	so as I can get up early Ill go to Lambes there beside Findlaters and

 45639	brings him home tomorrow today I mean no no Fridays an unlucky day first

 45641	asleep then we can have music and cigarettes I can accompany him first I
 45642	must clean the keys of the piano with milk whatll I wear shall I wear
 45643	a white rose or those fairy cakes in Liptons I love the smell of a rich
 45644	big shop at 7 1/2d a lb or the other ones with the cherries in them
 45645	and the pinky sugar I Id a couple of lbs of those a nice plant for the
 45646	middle of the table Id get that cheaper in wait wheres this I saw them
 45647	not long ago I love flowers Id love to have the whole place swimming in
 45648	roses God of heaven theres nothing like nature the wild mountains then
 45649	the sea and the waves rushing then the beautiful country with the fields
 45650	of oats and wheat and all kinds of things and all the fine cattle going
 45651	about that would do your heart good to see rivers and lakes and flowers
 45652	all sorts of shapes and smells and colours springing up even out of the
 45653	ditches primroses and violets nature it is as for them saying theres no
 45654	God I wouldnt give a snap of my two fingers for all their learning why
 45655	dont they go and create something I often asked him atheists or whatever
 45656	they call themselves go and wash the cobbles off themselves first then
 45657	they go howling for the priest and they dying and why why because theyre
 45658	afraid of hell on account of their bad conscience ah yes I know them
 45659	well who was the first person in the universe before there was anybody
 45660	that made it all who ah that they dont know neither do I so there you
 45661	are they might as well try to stop the sun from rising tomorrow the sun
 45662	shines for you he said the day we were lying among the rhododendrons on
 45663	Howth head in the grey tweed suit and his straw hat the day I got him to
 45664	propose to me yes first I gave him the bit of seedcake out of my mouth
 45665	and it was leapyear like now yes 16 years ago my God after that long
 45666	kiss I near lost my breath yes he said I was a flower of the mountain
 45667	yes so we are flowers all a womans body yes that was one true thing he
 45668	said in his life and the sun shines for you today yes that was why I
 45669	liked him because I saw he understood or felt what a woman is and I knew
 45670	I could always get round him and I gave him all the pleasure I could
 45671	leading him on till he asked me to say yes and I wouldnt answer first
 45672	only looked out over the sea and the sky I was thinking of so many
 45673	things he didnt know of Mulvey and Mr Stanhope and Hester and father and
 45674	old captain Groves and the sailors playing all birds fly and I say stoop
 45675	and washing up dishes they called it on the pier and the sentry in front
 45676	of the governors house with the thing round his white helmet poor devil
 45677	half roasted and the Spanish girls laughing in their shawls and their
 45678	tall combs and the auctions in the morning the Greeks and the jews and
 45679	the Arabs and the devil knows who else from all the ends of Europe and
 45680	Duke street and the fowl market all clucking outside Larby Sharons
 45681	and the poor donkeys slipping half asleep and the vague fellows in the
 45682	cloaks asleep in the shade on the steps and the big wheels of the carts
 45683	of the bulls and the old castle thousands of years old yes and those
 45684	handsome Moors all in white and turbans like kings asking you to sit
 45685	down in their little bit of a shop and Ronda with the old windows of the
 45686	posadas 2 glancing eyes a lattice hid for her lover to kiss the iron
 45687	and the wineshops half open at night and the castanets and the night we
 45688	missed the boat at Algeciras the watchman going about serene with his
 45689	lamp and O that awful deepdown torrent O and the sea the sea crimson
 45690	sometimes like fire and the glorious sunsets and the figtrees in the
 45691	Alameda gardens yes and all the queer little streets and the pink
 45692	and blue and yellow houses and the rosegardens and the jessamine and
 45693	geraniums and cactuses and Gibraltar as a girl where I was a Flower
 45694	of the mountain yes when I put the rose in my hair like the Andalusian
 45695	girls used or shall I wear a red yes and how he kissed me under the
 45696	Moorish wall and I thought well as well him as another and then I asked
 45697	him with my eyes to ask again yes and then he asked me would I yes to
 45698	say yes my mountain flower and first I put my arms around him yes and
 45699	drew him down to me so he could feel my breasts all perfume yes and his
 45700	heart was going like mad and yes I said yes I will Yes.
 45701	
 45702	Trieste-Zurich-Paris 1914-1921
 45703
